title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Announces Formation of New Department of Urology
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center has announced the creation of a new Department of Urology, headed by Alexander Kutikov, MD, FACS. Jay Simhan, MD, FACS will serve as the department's vice-chair, and Kristen Ragusa will be the lead administrator. Robert Uzzo, MD, MBA, FACS, the president and CEO of Fox Chase, expressed his pride in seeing the urology team grow and mature. The Fox Chase urology team specializes in personalized care, managing urologic cancers and benign urologic conditions. The department uses cutting-edge techniques, including advanced robotic and laparoscopic surgery, advanced endoscopy, reconstruction, and prosthetics, and has excellent outcomes. As a National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center, Fox Chase and its newest department are equipped to handle even the most challenging cases and complex patients with prostate, kidney, bladder, adrenal, testicular, and penile cancer. The urologists at Fox Chase are national and international opinion leaders who contribute to the world literature and collaborate on seminal clinical trials.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center's Dr. Alexander Kutikov to Receive Andrew C. Novick Award at 2023 International Kidney ...
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center's Dr. Alexander Kutikov will be awarded the Andrew C. Novick Award from the Kidney Cancer Association in 2023. The award acknowledges healthcare professionals who have made significant contributions in urology and medical oncology for the treatment of kidney cancer. Kutikov, who serves as the Chair of the Department of Urology and the Roberta R. Scheller Chair in Urologic Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center, was mentored by Fox Chase's President and CEO, Dr. Robert Uzzo, who was also honored with the award in 2016. The award highlights the work of leaders in the field of urology and medical oncology and recognizes Kutikov's exceptional contributions. As a recipient of the award, Kutikov will deliver a lecture at the Kidney Cancer Association's 2023 International Kidney Cancer Symposium: North America.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Has Second Highest Cancer Surgery Volume in Pennsylvania
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia has performed a high number of cancer surgeries in Pennsylvania in the last fiscal year, according to the 2022 Cancer Surgery Volume Report from the Pennsylvania Health Care Cost Containment Council. The center performed the most bladder cancer surgeries in the state and ranked second highest for colon cancer, liver, lung, prostate, and stomach. Robert Uzzo, MD, MBA, FACS, President and CEO of Fox Chase, said that these numbers indicate that Fox Chase is a top performer for cancer surgery in the region. The report includes data from July 1, 2021, through June 30, 2022, for surgeries performed at Pennsylvania hospitals for 11 types of cancer. Surgeries performed in ambulatory surgery centers are not included in the data.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center's Joel Helmke Named Vice Chair of the Board of Directors of the Alliance of Dedicated ...
summary: Joel Helmke, the COO of Fox Chase Cancer Center, has been appointed as the Vice Chair of the Board of Directors of the Alliance of Dedicated Cancer Centers (ADCC), a trade association that represents ten of the best cancer hospitals in the United States. These centers are at the forefront of developing the most effective practices for cancer treatment and conducting new research on the causes, prevention, and diagnosis of cancer. As a leader within the ADCC, Helmke will work to advance the association's priorities, which include safeguarding innovation in the development of next-generation therapies, enhancing efficiency in the delivery of cancer care, maintaining healthcare policies that prioritize quality, and establishing and measuring standards for the quality of cancer care in order to improve patient experience and clinical outcomes. After serving a two-year term as ADCC Vice Chair, Helmke will be promoted to Chair of the ADCC Board of Directors.

title: Funding for Fox Chase
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center thanked lawmakers Sens. Jim Dillon, Tina Tartaglione, and Rep. Kevin Boyle for securing $1.5 million in funding for the modernization of its research facilities. The center's director, Dr. Jonathan Chernoff, and its president and CEO, Dr. Robert Uzzo, represented Fox Chase at the event. Tartaglione promised to continue advocating for the cancer center despite redistricting taking it out of her Senate district. The funding will be used to update the research facilities at Fox Chase Cancer Center.

title: Temple Health Thank State Representative Kevin Boyle and State Senators Jimmy Dillon and Christine Tartaglione for ...
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center and Temple Health expressed their gratitude to State Representative Kevin Boyle and State Senators Jimmy Dillon and Christine Tartaglione for securing $1.5 million in funding for the modernization of Fox Chase research facilities. The Redevelopment Assistance Capital Program, administered by the Office of the Budget, provided the funding to further support community and economic development throughout Pennsylvania. The Fox Chase laboratory facility will be transformed into a cancer model production and analysis hub with this funding. Additionally, the central laboratory facility will be renovated by overhauling the air handling controls and replacing the lighting systems. Jonathan Chernoff, MD, PhD, Cancer Center Director, said that this funding is a crucial part of their mission as a National Cancer Institute-designated comprehensive cancer center, because facilities like this conduct cutting-edge cancer research.

title: Fox Chase Researchers Receive $1 Million Grant to Develop Platform That Could Assist in Development of New Drugs
summary: John Karanicolas, co-leader of the Cancer Signaling and Microenvironment research program at Fox Chase Cancer Center, has been awarded a $1 million grant from the W.M. Keck Foundation to develop a platform that could assist in the development of new drugs. The project aims to design new compounds known as molecular glues, which are small molecules that bind to the surface of a target protein and change its shape, allowing it to engage with a different set of protein partners than its usual repertoire. Karanicolas' project, "Using Deep Learning to Enable Rational Design of Molecular Glues," aims to develop machine learning tools for identifying compounds that stabilize select protein interactions. If successful, the studies will provide a necessary shift away from techniques that simply hope to find molecular glues by serendipity and move instead towards rational design methods that will enable much broader applications. Jonathan Chernoff, MD, PhD, Cancer Center Director at Fox Chase, commended Karanicolas' contribution to the project.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center's Biosample Repository Facility Receives Accreditation From College of American Pathologists
summary: The Fox Chase Cancer Center Biosample Repository Facility has been accredited by the College of American Pathologists (CAP). The facility performs various tasks such as collecting, processing, storing, disseminating, and analyzing biological samples and related clinical data for research purposes. The accreditation acknowledges the facility's high-quality laboratory practices and strict protocols for participant recruitment and consent. The facility is one of fewer than 80 CAP-accredited biorepositories in the US. The recognition is evidence of the work being done to provide top-of-the-line care to patients at Fox Chase. According to Jonathan Chernoff, MD, PhD, Cancer Center Director, the Biosample Repository will continue to be an essential tool in conducting groundbreaking research that will help us learn more about our communities and develop methods to better address their health needs.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Invests in Expanding Access to Lifesaving Radiopharmaceuticals for Cancer Patients
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center has invested in Nucleus RadioPharma, a company that specializes in the development and distribution of radiopharmaceuticals, targeted therapies that deliver radiation directly to cancer cells. The investment will fuel ongoing clinical trials and make these targeted therapies more accessible. The investment comes from the Fox Chase Cancer Center Director’s Innovation Fund, which is intended to incentivize translational research and science. Fox Chase and Nucleus have signed a Letter of Intent to potentially enable a deeper collaboration, including partnership in developing a radiopharmaceutical manufacturing site and clinical trials involving radiopharmaceuticals. Sangeeta Bardhan Cook, Chief Innovation Officer at Fox Chase, said, “As the first integrated radiopharmaceutical contract development and manufacturing organization and supply chain network, Nucleus RadioPharma is uniquely positioned to expedite the availability of lifesaving targeted therapies to wider populations.”

title: U of M president says new policy in the works after pro-Palestinian protest at honors convocation • Michigan Advance
summary: The University of Michigan is developing a policy to regulate disturbances in university operations caused by pro-Palestinian protests on campus. The protests demand that the university divest from companies with financial links to Israel and those that profit from Israel's military campaign in Gaza. University President Santa Ono has stated that those who engage in disruptive activities will be held accountable. The university has created an online survey to gather feedback from students, faculty, and staff. The TAHRIR Coalition plans to hold an emergency rally on the university's Diag on Thursday. The Anti-Defamation League has expressed concerns about anti-Semitism on campus following an online post that threatened death to anyone supporting Israel. The university's Vice President for Student Life condemned the message and stated that violations of the law or university policy will result in appropriate consequences, including expulsion.

title: UMich president bars student vote on resolution accusing Israel of genocide, 'settler colonialism'
summary: The president of the University of Michigan, Santa Ono, has blocked students from voting on two resolutions related to the Israel-Hamas war. One resolution requests the university to acknowledge "genocide" in Gaza and "settler colonialism" by Israel, while the other requests the university to support students "affected by ongoing violence in Israel and Gaza" and reveal plans to keep students safe. Each resolution seeking campus votes had more than 1,000 signatures. Ono said the resolutions were "controversial and divisive" and have done more to stoke fear, anger, and animosity on the campus than they would ever accomplish as recommendations to the university. The Michigan chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations accused the university of suppressing free speech. Seven of the eight members of the university's governing board supported Ono's statement. Ono promised to schedule meetings with student leaders to discuss "real and tangible ways" to address concerns.

title: Opinion: Inside Sparrow Hospital's trauma center after MSU shooting
summary: The trauma team at Sparrow Hospital, which includes various types of surgeons, radiologists, anesthesiologists, nurses, and others, quickly responded to an active shooter situation at Michigan State University. In just 17 minutes, the hospital received five critically injured victims who all required life-saving surgery. Sparrow Hospital spends $22 million each year to maintain its Level I trauma center, which is one of ten in Michigan. Dr. Denny Martin, acting president and chief medical officer, explained that the hospital uses algorithmic scripts developed during simulations to establish order in chaotic situations. The heroic efforts of Sparrow's caregivers and staff demonstrate the important role of Level I trauma centers in providing comprehensive care to patients with serious injuries. Marschall S. Runge, executive vice president for medical affairs and dean of the Medical School for the University of Michigan, praised the caregivers and staff for their exceptional care and acknowledged the emotional and financial toll of such care.

title: National Academy of Medicine Action Collaborative is combating climate change with Victor Dzau, MD
summary: The National Academy of Medicine Action Collaborative is taking action to fight climate change. Their aim is to reduce carbon emissions by 50% by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The collaborative is made up of hospitals, healthcare systems, doctors, nurses, educators, private industry, and government. They are addressing climate change because it is a serious threat to humanity and causes suffering. The healthcare sector is responsible for 8.5% of U.S. carbon emissions, and the collaborative aims to reduce this by changing the way medicine is practiced, promoting virtual care, and prevention. They also plan to change supply chains and create policies and incentives to support decarbonization. Dr. Victor Dzau, president of the National Academy of Medicine, is co-chairing the collaborative with Admiral Rachel Levine, the Secretary of Health, Andrew Witty, CEO of United, and George Barrett, the past CEO of Cardinal. The collaborative plans to launch a national movement in January 2024 to involve more organizations.

title: Health Professionals Can Play Important Role in Combatting Climate Change, Guest Lecturer Says
summary: Victor J. Dzau, M.D., president of the National Academy of Medicine, spoke at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences about the important role health professionals in the United States play in combating climate change, as it is also a public health crisis. Dzau explained how climate change can lead to various illnesses and diseases in humans, and cited pollution inequity, where people with lower socio-economic status are disproportionately affected. He also mentioned the health care sector itself emits about 8.5% of carbon emissions in the United States. Dzau called for action by the medical community to be educated about climate change and equipped with the tools to address it, stating that clinicians are uniquely positioned to be the messengers of climate change. The lecture was part of The Richard and Ellen Sandor Lecture Series on Medicine and Sustainability.

title: Victor Dzau on Leading the National Academy of Medicine
summary: Victor Dzau, M.D., President of the National Academy of Medicine (NAM), talks about his experience growing up as a refugee of the Chinese Civil War, his commitment to health equity and global health, and the NAM's efforts to provide expert evidence-based guidance on health, biomedical science, and health policy. He believes that clinicians should be more involved in public discourse and stresses the importance of medical professionals communicating scientific facts to the general public. Dzau is a renowned scholar in cardiovascular medicine, and his groundbreaking research paved the way for the development of blood pressure medications that are widely used today.

title: National Academy of Medicine President Victor Dzau to Deliver CI MED 2023 Convocation Address
summary: Victor Dzau, President of the National Academy of Medicine, will deliver the 2023 Carle Illinois College of Medicine convocation address. Dzau is an international leader in academic medicine and has served in leadership roles at some of the nation's leading medical schools, including Harvard, Stanford, and Duke University Health System. His organization provides objective advice through scientifically balanced research on important health-related issues. Dzau stresses the importance of academic health centers (AHCs) in national health care reform and emphasizes that academic health centers are critical in transforming medicine through a seamless innovation-to-care continuum that incorporates scientific discovery, translational research, and care delivery. The Carle Illinois College of Medicine is the world's first engineering-based college of medicine, with a strong emphasis on research, innovation, and entrepreneurship.

title: Bradley Bernstein of Dana-Farber elected to National Academy of Medicine
summary: Bradley Bernstein, MD, PhD, who is the Chair of Cancer Biology at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, has been chosen as a member of the National Academy of Medicine (NAM). NAM recognizes individuals who have shown exceptional professional accomplishment and dedication to service. The selection process for new NAM members is carried out by current members and acknowledges those who have made significant contributions to the advancement of medical sciences, healthcare, and public health. Victor J. Dzau, MD, NAM President, welcomed the new members and stated that their contributions to health and medicine are unparalleled, and their leadership and expertise will be essential to helping the NAM tackle today's urgent health challenges, inform the future of health care, and ensure health equity for the benefit of all around the globe.

title: Why U.S. health care must take steps to cut carbon emissions
summary: The U.S. health system is responsible for 8.5% of the country's carbon emissions, and the National Academy of Medicine has created the Action Collaborative on Decarbonizing the U.S. Health Sector to address the issue. The Climate Collaborative, co-chaired by Victor Dzau, M.D., aims to reduce total carbon emissions by 50% by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The initiative brings together hospitals, healthcare systems, doctors and nurses, educators, the supply chain, the private industry, the pharmaceutical industry, and the government. The Climate Collaborative has established four working groups to focus on specific actions related to care delivery, education, supply chain, and policy. The initiative hopes to expand its reach across the country in early 2024 to inspire more healthcare organizations to step forward and combat climate change.

title: Faculty Feature: Jeffrey Michael | Johns Hopkin Center for Injury Research and Policy
summary: Jeffrey Michael, Distinguished Scholar at the Department of Health Policy and Management, is a national and international leader in the analysis, development, and implementation of programs to improve transportation safety. He is currently working on a project with an interdisciplinary group of vehicle safety experts to facilitate the successful completion of a landmark new federal safety standard that will require every new car to be equipped with technology that can prevent its operation by impaired drivers. The potential payoff of this technology is a game-changer for road safety, saving more than 9,000 lives each year when fully deployed. Michael enjoys spending his free time with his 6-year-old grandson, bike-riding, driving radio-control cars, and building cardboard robots. If he could have brunch with any celebrity, he would choose Lewis Hamilton and talk about his race strategy and goals following his Formula One career. Michael is affiliated with the Johns Hopkins Injury Center and enjoys telling people that he works there.

title: Bronchopulmonary Dysphasia: Jahleel's Story
summary: Jahleel was born prematurely at 24 weeks gestation, weighing 1 pound, 11 ounces. He had bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), a chronic lung disease common in premature babies. A specialized team at Johns Hopkins All Children’s Hospital cared for him, performing surgical procedures to repair his collapsing airway and help him breathe better. Michael M.E. Johns, M.D. contributed to the Esophageal and Airway Treatment (EAT) team that performed the surgeries. Jahleel went home after nine months in the hospital and is now a happy baby.

title: Remembering Michael Beard, a Pioneer of Gun Violence Prevention | Johns Hopkins | Bloomberg School of Public ...
summary: Michael Beard, a pioneer in the movement to prevent gun violence, has passed away. He established the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence in 1974 and the Educational Fund to Stop Gun Violence in 1978. Beard tirelessly advocated for significant gun violence prevention legislation and played a crucial role in passing the Federal Assault Weapons Ban of 1994 and the Brady Bill. He directed the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence for more than 30 years and was a member of the advisory board of the Center for Gun Violence Solutions at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. In addition to his leadership, Beard was a mentor to co-director Josh Horwitz for many years. He also had a diverse and successful career as an actor and was a member of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Radio and Television Artists. His legacy will continue to inspire the fight for a world free from gun violence.

title: Meet the Dallas 500: Peter McCanna
summary: Peter McCanna, CEO of Baylor Scott & White Health, has been featured in the Dallas 500. He spoke about his biggest challenge, which is labor, and how the pandemic has forced them to adopt a different managerial operating style. He also discussed the future of healthcare, where technology and a customer-first mindset will play a big role. McCanna believes that they can take information about patients and use pattern recognition to give them a diagnosis and treatment plan that will work. Physicians will still have a big role, but it will be augmented by AI. McCanna also talked about the industry change and how they want to be accessible through multiple channels and give patients care when, where, and how they want it.

title: Baylor Scott & White inks deal to expand urgent care footprint
summary: Baylor Scott & White Health has partnered with NextCare Urgent Care to add 41 Texas urgent care clinics to its network. The deal will give the state's largest nonprofit health system a foothold in new markets. The deal also catapults Baylor Scott & White to a new role as one of Texas' major providers of urgent care services. The CEO of Baylor Scott & White, Peter McCanna, said that the deal is dedicated to providing customers with as much choice as possible when seeking care. The two companies will be hammering out branding, digital integrations, and other enhancements to better serve customers over the next several months. Baylor Scott & White is a major player in the Texas healthcare market with 51 hospitals and a total of over 1,200 locations through which 3 million-plus people access care.

title: North Texas Healthcare Compensation: Who's On Top?
summary: North Texas healthcare organizations are offering competitive salaries to attract top talent to lead them. D CEO Healthcare analyzed recent SEC filings and IRS forms to find out how local healthcare leaders are being compensated and what can be learned about their leadership. The list includes the top two earners from each organization in recent IRS and SEC filings. Tenet Healthcare CEO Saum Sutaria and McKesson CEO Brian Tyler were the highest compensated individuals with total compensation of $18,518,109 and $16,960,596 respectively. In the nonprofit world, CHRISTUS Health compensates its executives relatively better than others. CHRISTUS CEO Ernie Sadau earned more than $11 million in compensation, while the CEOs of Baylor Scott & White Health and Texas Health Resources earned significantly less. The second top earner in Baylor’s 2022 filing was Peter McCanna, who began the year as President and finished it as CEO and earned $3.6 million in total compensation in 2022.

title: Prince George’s County Libraries Mark Milestone With First Black CEO
summary: The Prince George's County Memorial Library System has appointed Mark Winston, Ph.D., as its new CEO. Winston is the first Black CEO in the library's 78-year history and a Maryland native. He will provide strategic and operational leadership to oversee the library, which serves a population that is 64 percent Black and nearly 21 percent Hispanic or Latino, according to U.S. Census data. Winston has extensive experience in library management, university faculty, and consulting and is an author, columnist, and book reviewer. He holds a doctorate in library and information science from the University of Pittsburgh, as well as a master's degree in library science from the University of Pittsburgh and a bachelor's degree in business management from Hampton University.

title: A search for unmarked graves. A list of last names. The quest to restore a lost piece of history in Prince George’s Co.
summary: Archaeologists and volunteers are working to document and properly account for hundreds of unmarked graves in Prince George's County, Maryland. Many of these graves contain the remains of African Americans, some of whom were enslaved on land that was once a Jesuit-owned plantation known as White Marsh. Dr. Laura Masur, an archaeologist and assistant professor of anthropology at Catholic University, is overseeing the efforts to identify unmarked graves on the grounds of Sacred Heart Catholic Church, as well as other cemeteries once owned by the Jesuits. The team has mapped close to 600 potential grave markers along the hillside, and Masur anticipates that there may be 100 to 200 more grave markers along the hillside. Descendants of those who lived and worked on the land decades, if not centuries, ago have started a nonprofit called the White Marsh Historical Society to help search through family trees, tax records, death records, and other genealogical records to try to determine who might be buried there.

title: UMich HPSA hosts Election Year Health Policy Outlook Panel
summary: The University of Michigan Health Policy Student Association hosted an Election Year Health Policy Outlook Panel, which discussed the cost of health insurance and prescription drugs, reproductive rights, and public health policy. The panel featured professors Scott L. Greer and Marianne Udow-Phillips, and John Z. Ayanian, director of the Institute for Healthcare Policy & Innovation. The discussion was led by Public Health student Jamaal Shaikh, HPSA president. The panel discussed the effectiveness of Democrats’ policy initiatives, such as the Inflation Reduction Act, at tackling high prescription drug prices. The panel also addressed the issue of institutional public health, with an emphasis on the United States’ response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Udow-Phillips said the public health issues that arose during the COVID-19 pandemic were due to the breakdown of local institutions in their response to COVID-19.

title: Florida doctors worried DeSantis gives 'fringe' dermatologist a platform
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has faced criticism from Florida doctors for promoting a "fringe" dermatologist named Jon Ward, who rejects COVID-19 vaccines and most pandemic-era mitigation efforts. Ward has appeared alongside DeSantis at multiple events, and the governor has sought his validation on several occasions. Members of the Florida Medical Association (FMA) are concerned that Ward has been given a statewide platform, and some doctors fear that the governor is promoting a "fringe" perspective in the medical community. DeSantis has made his opposition to COVID-19 restrictions and support for medical "free speech" a central part of his messaging strategy, and this issue may impact a potential 2024 presidential run. Marianne Udow-Phillips, founding executive director of the Center for Health and Research Transformation at the University of Michigan, stated that the medical profession is closely examining the issue and is deeply worried.

title: UnitedHealthcare offers rewards to insurance plan members who use activity trackers
summary: UnitedHealthcare, the largest health insurer in the US, is expanding its initiative to reward plan members for embracing healthy behavior, which will be monitored by activity trackers. UnitedHealthcare Rewards will provide up to $1,000 annually to members who use wearable devices to prove they're being healthy and take other steps to monitor their health. The program will be available first to the 3 million patients in UnitedHealthcare's fully insured plans, then rolled out to self-insured plan members in 2024. The rewards come in the form of a cash gift card or health savings account funds. The goal of the program is to motivate members to take charge of their health and stay engaged in activities to improve their quality of life and help improve healthcare overall. Critics are concerned that companies like United could eventually use such programs to pass costs along to people who spurn healthy behavior. Marianne Udow-Phillips, a senior adviser to the University of Michigan's Center for Health & Research Transformation, said that wearables with incentives tied to them can promote and encourage people to walk more and get more physically fit.

title: Gov. Gordon to bring mental health town hall meeting to Gillette Dec. 18
summary: Governor Mark Gordon will hold a town hall meeting in Gillette on December 18th to discuss mental healthcare in Wyoming. The meeting is part of a series of meetings across the state to increase awareness of available resources and improve access to care. The discussions are open to the public, and representatives from the executive, legislative, and judicial branches are invited to attend, as well as local elected officials. Governor Gordon is impressed with the honesty and engagement from community members during the previous town halls and is looking forward to these additional conversations.

title: Tampa General receives record donation for children's hospital
summary: Tampa General Hospital has received a record donation from philanthropists Pam and Les Muma. The amount of the gift has not been disclosed, but it is the largest in Tampa General's history and the largest ever made to any children’s hospital in the Tampa Bay region. The hospital has announced that its children’s facility will be renamed the Muma Children’s Hospital at TGH in recognition of the donation. The children’s hospital has 138 beds and provides a range of specialized medical services. The Mumas have a track record of philanthropy in the region, with institutions and facilities bearing their names, including the Muma Chair of Neonatology at USF Health and the Jennifer Leigh Muma Neonatal Intensive Care Unit at TGH. Les Muma co-founded Fortune 500 company Fiserv Inc. in 1984 and also served on the TGH Board of Directors.

title: Gordon announces new mental health initiative at town hall event
summary: Governor Mark Gordon has launched a new mental health initiative called the "Mental Health Roadmap" that identifies five key pillars to improve outcomes for those battling mental health issues in Wyoming. The five pillars include access to mental health care, affordability, quality of care, innovation, and suicide prevention and anti-stigma efforts. Gordon announced the initiative during a town hall event where he expressed that mental health care services should not only be accessible, but also affordable and of good quality. The initiative will focus on community mental health reform, workforce development, criminal justice reform, and suicide prevention. Gordon has requested funding of $250,000 to train workforces in behavioral health reform and an additional $2 million for pediatric virtual services. He also asked lawmakers for another $2 million to contract with mobile crisis services in Wyoming to support first responders. The initiative involves collaboration among the executive, legislative, and judiciary branches of state government.

title: Western leaders come to Wyoming to learn about the state's hope for solving climate change
summary: Wyoming's Governor, Mark Gordon, is leading a group of federal and state leaders in addressing climate change by exploring decarbonization. The group recently toured the Integrated Test Center (ITC) in Gillette, which is studying carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS). Wyoming is investing tens of millions of dollars into CCUS development, hoping to remove carbon from the fossil fuel process and keep the fossil fuel industry viable in a warming world. However, some environmental and conservation groups view it as an expensive and unproven solution. The clock is ticking as the United States aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2035. Gordon hopes CCUS can prove its viability by the end of the decade and prevent job losses in the energy sector. The Gillette visit is the first of several workshops exploring decarbonization as part of the Western Governors' Association.

title: Tampa General Hospital Welcomes Oscar J. Horton to Its Board of Directors
summary: Tampa General Hospital has appointed Oscar J. Horton to its Board of Directors. Horton, a Florida business leader, brings with him experience in enterprise growth and strong community relationships. Horton is the CEO of Horton Holdings LLC, which oversees the operations of Sun State International and Sun State Real Estate. He has also served as a board member for the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and Jacksonville Branch. Horton's appointment increases the Board's breadth and depth of expertise across various industries, including real estate, finance, healthcare, and private equity. Tampa General Hospital is one of the largest hospitals in America and is the region's only center for Level l trauma and comprehensive burn care. It is also the primary teaching hospital for the USF Health Morsani College of Medicine.

title: SurplusGLOBAL's CEO, Bruce Kim, Has Been Elected as a Members of The National Academy of Engineering of Korea
summary: SurplusGLOBAL's CEO, Bruce Kim, has been elected as a member of The National Academy of Engineering of Korea for his contributions to the semiconductor ecosystem. Bruce Kim established SurplusGLOBAL in 2000, and over the past 24 years, he has sold over 60,000 units of legacy semiconductor equipment, propelling the company to become a global industry leader. He has been recognized for his significant efforts in advancing technology across universities, corporations, and research institutions. Bruce Kim's dedication extends beyond business; he annually conducts research along the Silk Road, studying the rise and fall of nomads and merchants over the past 5,000 years, interpreting human history's dynamics from a business perspective rather than merely as heroes, emperors, or prophets. Additionally, since 2019, he has served as the organizing chairperson for Asia's first specialized autism exhibition, the Autism Expo.

title: Christian Professor Nearly Fired on LGBT Issues Leads Campus Ministry
summary: Corey Miller, the president and CEO of Lafayette-based Christian campus ministry Ratio Christi, has shared his experiences of facing discrimination against Christianity in academia with The Daily Signal. Miller was threatened with termination for discussing Christian doctrine on LGBT issues, and was accused by a former student of creating a "suicidal environment". Alliance Defending Freedom took up his case pro bono, and with the help of two atheist students, Miller was exonerated. Miller warns that universities have shifted from a place of "free exchange of ideas" to "political truth", and that the current cultural Marxism is the second revolution in the history of academia in America. Ratio Christi has launched the Malik Academic Fellowship, which aims to train Christian Ph.D. students to become "missional professors" and reclaim the intellectual voice of Christ in universities.

title: Blake Casper makes $1 million donation to Jesuit High School's campus master plan - Tampa Bay Business & Wealth
summary: Blake Casper, co-owner of the hospitality company Oxford Commons, has donated $1 million to Jesuit High School to support its campus master plan. Casper, who is an alumnus of Jesuit High School, understands the importance of philanthropy and paying it forward for current and future generations. The school's director of development, Nick Suszynski, said that Casper's contribution helps ensure Jesuit’s vision will become a reality as they develop the next phase of their Campus Master Plan. Jesuit’s Campus Master Plan projects have included the Antinori Center for the Arts, which opened this year, as well as Gonzmart Hall, Oliva Courtyard, and the Chapel of the Holy Cross. Upcoming projects include a student activities center and dining hall, and a science center. Casper is known for creating unique concepts such as Oxford Exchange, The Stovall House, and Predalina, a seafood-forward Mediterranean concept on Water Street Tampa.

title: Excellence in Governance 2023 Phillip Dingle
summary: Phillip S. Dingle, the managing partner of the private equity fund HealthEdge Investment Partners, has been a board member of Tampa General Hospital since 2007 and has served as chair since 2020. Working with President and CEO John Couris and the executive team, Dingle has helped advance initiatives for innovation, expansion, and financial viability at Tampa General, which is an academic medical center and the region's largest safety-net hospital. Tampa General has provided net community benefits worth about $240 million through healthcare services for uninsured and underinsured people, educational programs, and financial support to Tampa Bay area community organizations in fiscal 2022. The hospital has also established a $500 million master facility plan, which serves as a blueprint for continued capital and service growth.

title: Research outcome teams enhance research opportunities at MCOM
summary: The USF Health Morsani College of Medicine's Office of Research, Innovation & Scholarly Endeavors (RISE) has created Specialty-Specific Research Outcomes Teams (SSROT) to enhance and expand research capacity. These teams match medical students with resident physicians, fellows in training, and attending physicians on faculty at MCOM to define and sustain a pipeline of impactful research opportunities and mentorship. Since 2018, 95% of MCOM medical students have engaged in scholarly work during their medical school tenure, leading to a sharp increase in medical students presenting at national and international meetings, and authoring peer-reviewed publications. Dr. Rahul Mhaskar, professor and associate dean of medical student research, spearheaded the concept of more collaborative research environments with more students and physicians with similar research interests. The next evolution is creating interdisciplinary teams, allowing USF Health students from different colleges to collaborate on research projects using the SSROT model.

title: Interview with K. Scott Wester, CEO of Memorial Healthcare System - South Florida
summary: K. Scott Wester, the CEO of Memorial Healthcare System, is striving to manage costs and plan for growth in the face of inflation challenges in the healthcare industry. His goal is to decrease labor costs and workforce development while increasing wages for all employees. Memorial Healthcare System has implemented new cost processes and efficiencies to minimize inflation over the past six months. Wester has acquired an 8.2-acre site at the intersection of U.S. 441 and Hollywood Boulevard, which will be a mixed-use development focused on healthcare and housing. Memorial Healthcare System has expanded to three mammography centers and opened a new primary care office in Weston. The healthcare system employs AI in its radiology department and plans to increase its use of AI to assist clinicians and physicians in providing better therapeutics early for better outcomes. The biggest challenges that Memorial Healthcare System will face in the coming years are the economic pressures of the hospital industry and the need to recover costs for the care provided to government payors.

title: Memorial Healthcare Buys Hollywood Dev Site From Ben-Shmuels
summary: Memorial Healthcare System has acquired an 8.2-acre development site in Hollywood, Florida for $49m. They have preliminary plans to build a health and wellness center on the southeast corner of Hollywood Boulevard and State Road 7. The site currently consists of a two-story building leased to Gordon Food Service grocery store and an adjacent parking lot. Memorial Healthcare System plans to consult with Memorial and community interests and convene a group to come up with a project. Preliminary discussions have focused on a possible community health and wellness center. Memorial is a network of hospitals and wellness facilities throughout South Florida led by CEO K. Scott Wester, with Memorial Regional Hospital South and Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital in Hollywood. In 2018, the hospital paid $6.5m for a 16,000-square-foot Petco building at 12251 Pines Boulevard in Pembroke Pines, with plans to use the land as part of the expansion of Memorial Hospital West.

title: Dr. Ari Sareli to Lead Clinical Efforts for Memorial Healthcare System as Chief Medical Officer
summary: Dr. Aharon (Ari) Sareli has been appointed as the chief medical officer by Memorial Healthcare System, along with Dr. Holly Neville as associate CMO. Both bring medical and surgical expertise to CMO positions and connect the system's executive leadership to the front lines of care. Dr. Sareli has been with Memorial since 2009 and has quadruple board certification in internal medicine, pulmonary disease, critical care, and sleep medicine. He was also the director of Memorial Hospital West's Critical Care in 2010 and chief of critical care for the system in 2012. Dr. Neville is the chief of pediatric general surgery and program director of Memorial's surgical residency program. Memorial's CEO, K. Scott Wester, stated that both have worked throughout the system, earning respect and elevating patient care through collaborations with fellow physicians, nurses, and operational teams.

title: After decades of hospital work, what my sister's cancer taught me | Opinion
summary: Leah A. Carpenter, the Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Memorial Healthcare System, has shared her experience of dealing with her sister's cancer diagnosis. She emphasizes the importance of finding a healing environment that can nurture and guide everyone through the crisis, including not just the primary oncologist, but also nurses, respiratory therapists, navigators, and other support staff. Patients and their families must have confidence that the professionals they've entrusted can deliver the clinical expertise, experience, and compassion they need. Carpenter stresses that cancer is not just a gut punch to the person with the disease, but also to his or her entire family. Her sister's age, comorbidities, and familial history provided no guarantees of survival. Carpenter's experience taught her that it was critical to find a trusted expert whose words, mannerisms, and actions communicated a sense of "don't worry, we've got this."

title: How can ACLs and other serious injuries in women’s football be prevented?
summary: Leah A. Carpenter, the England captain, was among the many players at the top of the European club game to have sustained an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury over the past year. This raises the question of what needs to be done to potentially prevent others enduring the heartbreak of such injuries. From workload to making sure equipment is the best and most suitable it can be, there is plenty to look into. Men also sustain ACL damage, but the issue seems to be more prevalent in the women’s game. More investigation and study of female footballers is needed to find out why they get injured – not just ACLs but all physical matters. It is a hot topic at the moment, and rightly so. Young boys start their training a lot earlier than girls, and they have better medical care, more expertise and knowledge that makes the transition to the professional game easier.

title: Memorial Healthcare System could expand Pembroke Pines facility - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Memorial Healthcare System has submitted plans to expand its 24/7 Emergency Care Center in Pembroke Pines. The hospital will construct a new emergency department of over 30,000 square feet, featuring 20 exam rooms, five triage bays, 16 fast track rooms, a trauma room, and CT and X-ray machines. The new facility will have a larger capacity to treat patients and a more efficient flow of providing care. Matt Muhart, chief strategy officer of MHS, said that the old freestanding ED might be converted to a primary care center, but those plans haven’t been finalized. MHS has been expanding recently, including opening a cancer care center near Memorial Hospital West in Pembroke Pines, providing pediatric care at a freestanding ED that Broward Health is building in Sunrise, and opening a primary care center in Hialeah. MHS also bought an 8.2-acre site at U.S. 441 and Hollywood Boulevard.

title: Dr. Robin McGuinness Reappointed to Florida Center for Nursing Board of Directors
summary: Dr. Robin McGuinness, a Senior Executive Officer at AdventHealth West Florida Division, has been reappointed to the Board of Directors of the Florida Center for Nursing by Governor Ron DeSantis. McGuinness has extensive experience in nursing education and innovation, which has helped drive transformative initiatives within AdventHealth and healthcare in general. She has a bachelor's degree in nursing from Saint Joseph's College of Maine, a master's degree from the University of Hartford, and a doctorate in nursing from Florida State University. McGuinness is dedicated to improving patient safety and providing exceptional whole-person care to Florida residents. Other members appointed to the Florida Center for Nursing Board of Directors include Michele Panetta, Monica Puga, Leslie Rogers, Joanne Stevens Hoertz, Mary Anne Enns, and Suzanne Wilson Depew.

title: Technology Helps Memorial Healthcare System Patients Help Themselves
summary: Remote monitoring technology is helping patients and clinicians at Memorial Healthcare System. The system has over 800 patients connected to its remote patient monitoring program, which provides wearable watches, blood pressure cuffs, pulse oximeters, and scales to monitor patients' vital signs. Clinicians receive data in real-time, which is uploaded directly to the patient's electronic medical record. Memorial's commitment to remote patient monitoring has resulted in significant decreases in hospital admissions, readmissions, emergency department visits, and an increased number of visits to primary care providers. The amount saved by reducing hospital and emergency services already tops more than $4 million dollars. Monica Puga, RN, MSN, chief nursing executive for Memorial Healthcare System, says the system's commitment to remote patient monitoring has paid dividends for those in the program. Jules Penn, a patient in the program, can now walk 30 minutes on a treadmill and drive six hours to visit family in Jacksonville.

title: Dr. Ari Sareli to Lead Clinical Efforts for Memorial Healthcare System as Chief Medical Officer
summary: Dr. Aharon (Ari) Sareli has been appointed as the Chief Medical Officer by Memorial Healthcare System. He is a critical care physician and experienced clinical and executive leader. Along with Dr. Holly Neville, who has been appointed as the Associate Chief Medical Officer, they bring current, front-line experience to executive leadership positions. The partnership will connect the system's executive leadership to the front lines of care. Both Sareli and Neville will maintain their current roles. Sareli has played a key role in front-line clinical leadership in critical care during the COVID-19 pandemic. He was appointed director of Memorial Hospital West's Critical Care in 2010 and chief of critical care for the system in 2012. Sareli served in an executive role with clinical leadership of the evolving organization as chief physician executive of the Memorial Physician Group (MPG) in 2019.

title: The Exec: 'I Believe in a Servant Leadership Mentality'
summary: Aharon Sareli, the new chief medical officer of Memorial Healthcare System, believes in a servant leadership mentality to keep staff focused on patient care despite challenges such as supply chain and labor shortages, external pressures from payers, and expectations from patients as they relate to access and service. He emphasizes the importance of building relationships, fostering trust, and embracing teamwork, as well as listening more and talking less in physician engagement. Sareli's clinical background in critical care helps him understand the value of the team and his role as a leader in facilitating the success of the team. He also learned during the pandemic to focus on what can be impacted rather than getting lost in the negativity of what cannot be impacted. The primary clinical care challenges facing Memorial Healthcare System are recovering from labor shortages and addressing supply chain challenges.

title: Eco Flexibles appoints David Smith as general manager
summary: Eco Flexibles has appointed David Smith as general manager to ensure the company's strategic goals are met through operational excellence and continuous improvement. Smith has over two decades of experience in the paper-based and flexible packaging industries, including production and operational excellence directorship. Eco Flexibles is a recyclable monopolymer flexible packaging specialist that works with customers to switch incumbent mixed material flexible packaging to high-performance monopolymers. The company aims to show that brands never need to choose between recyclability and quality. Smith's role is to change the packaging industry for the better by creating a production workflow. Eco Flexibles takes a complete end-to-end approach, taking the pressure and legwork away from in-house teams.

title: Healing by Play
summary: Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital in Hollywood, Florida has expanded by adding a $166m addition, which includes four new floors with 156,000 square feet and four cardiac procedural suites. The hospital's CEO, Caitlin Stella, believes that the non-medical additions are just as important as the new equipment. Stella is dedicated to "the healing power of play" and has added more space indoors and outdoors for children to exercise and have fun in a cheerful environment. The hospital's design also includes an outdoor terrace next to the rehabilitation gym to make it easier for patients to get fresh air and sunshine. The 8th floor's Garth Brooks Teammates for Kids Child Life Zone, the 14th of its kind in the country, provides space for dancing, exercise, entertainment, and more. A family lounge allows for outside guests and has fostered supportive relationships among families whose children are patients.

title: Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital
summary: Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital is a healthcare provider for children that specializes in pediatric care. The hospital's philosophy of fun includes a child life program that offers music, art, yoga, dance, gaming, and technology therapies. The hospital has a therapy dog named Freedom and a resident clown to lighten the mood. The Garth Brooks Teammates for Kids Child Life Zone was created with the generosity of the Finker-Frenkel Family Foundation and has daily enriching activities. The hospital has been recognized as the best children's hospital for orthopedics and cardiology and heart surgery by US News & World Report. CEO Caitlin Stella, who previously worked at UCLA's autism center, has made Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital the first autism-certified emergency department in Florida. The hospital provides high-quality care to families from far and wide, and the Conine Clubhouse offers housing for families who need a place to stay.

title: Caitlin Beck Stella Named CEO of Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital • Hollywood Gazette
summary: Caitlin Beck Stella has been appointed as the new CEO of Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital, taking over from the recently retired Chantal Leconte. Stella has an impressive background in children's healthcare and has achieved notable professional accomplishments early in her career. She earned her undergraduate degree in Child Development from Virginia Tech and completed an internship in Child Psychiatry at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. Stella then worked in clinical research administration at the Semel Institute for Neuroscience and Human Behavior at UCLA Medical Center. Prior to joining Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital, she served as the Chief Administrative Officer for UCLA Mattel Children's Hospital and Women's Health. The hospital, which is part of the Memorial Healthcare System, is the largest pediatric hospital serving Broward, Palm Beach, and northern Miami-Dade counties, with 226 licensed beds and an entire floor dedicated to oncology.

title: Phil A. Wright to Lead Memorial Regional Hospital South (Hollywood, FL)
summary: Phil A. Wright has been appointed as the new CEO of Memorial Regional Hospital South in Hollywood, Florida. Wright brings over 25 years of healthcare experience to his new position, including most recently serving as a senior executive at AdventHealth Ocala. He is a graduate of Florida A&M University and the Medical University of South Carolina, where he earned a master's degree in health administration. Memorial Regional Hospital South is a 280-bed facility that offers a wide range of healthcare services and is home to the Memorial Rehabilitation Institute, South Florida's largest provider of physical rehabilitation services. It was named one of the best rehabilitation hospitals in the nation by U.S. News & World Report. Wright takes over for the recently-retired Douglas Zaren and will oversee a compassionate and collaborative setting.

title: Memorial Healthcare System names CEO of Hollywood hospital - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Phil A. Wright has been appointed as the CEO of Memorial Regional Hospital South in Hollywood by Memorial Healthcare System. He replaces the retired Douglas Zaren as the CEO of the 280-bed hospital. Wright has over 25 years of experience in the healthcare industry and was previously the chief business development officer and chief operating officer of AdventHealth Ocala. He has also served as the CEO of Southampton Memorial Hospital in Franklin, Virginia. Wright is a graduate of Florida A&M University, where he earned his bachelor's degree, and the Medical University of South Carolina, where he earned his master's degree in health administration. According to Leah A. Carpenter, the chief operating officer at Memorial Healthcare System, Wright has an impressive track record of hands-on leadership, collaborating directly with leaders, physicians, and staff to meet the needs of patients, families, and communities in an ever-changing healthcare environment.

title: Interview with K. Scott Wester, CEO of Memorial Healthcare System - South Florida
summary: K. Scott Wester, the CEO of Memorial Healthcare System, is striving to manage costs and plan for growth. He made a significant move by buying an 8.2-acre site at the corner of U.S. 441 and Hollywood Boulevard, where he intends to create a mixed-use development centered on healthcare and housing. He has also worked on decreasing the hospital's dependence on external labor and increasing salaries for all employees. However, healthcare inflation remains a challenge, with drug and drug-related expenses experiencing double-digit inflation. Memorial Healthcare is also expanding its facilities and implementing new technologies, such as AI, to help clinicians and physicians provide better treatments. The hospital still faces difficulties with government payors and commercial health plans, with a 50% decrease in operating margin from pre-Covid numbers.

title: The Exec: How Memorial Healthcare System's CEO Slashed Workforce Turnover
summary: Scott Wester, the President and CEO of Memorial Healthcare System, has shared details about his first year leading the South Florida-based nonprofit system. In his first year, the team has made progress in reducing staff turnover and agency utilization. They have decreased the use of outside contract labor by approximately 80%, resulting in savings of around $200 million. Additionally, the team has achieved a record year of hiring, bringing on 3,700 individuals, including 1,250 RNs. The turnover rate has dropped from 21% to below the historical average of 14% over the course of the year. Wester's future plans for the system include a two-year retention plan, a new communication strategy, and a structured short-term incentive program for the leadership team. The organization has a family-oriented and community-centered culture. Long-term goals for the system include maintaining financial strength, being efficient, and promoting learning across the organization.

title: South Broward Hospital District places Lubby Navarro on administrative leave, deactivates credit card
summary: The South Broward Hospital District has put Lubby Navarro, a former Miami-Dade public school board member, on administrative leave from her current job as a registered lobbyist in the Government Affairs Department at Memorial Regional Hospital. Her company credit card from Memorial Regional Hospital has also been deactivated. The board of commissioners has started an investigation into Navarro, who was arrested for allegedly using her school board-issued credit card for personal use, spending around $100,000. Hospital leaders have been monitoring the situation since her arrest. Scott Wester, President and CEO at Memorial Healthcare System, said there are no major concerns at this point in the investigation, but there are questions about the lack of documentation on certain receipts. Navarro was not present at the emergency meeting, and her attorney has not responded to requests for comment.

title: What 10 CEOs Said About Workforce Challenges in 2023
summary: CEOs across the healthcare industry have identified workforce as a major challenge in 2023, with labor costs and shortages being the biggest pain points. HealthLeaders spoke to CEOs from various organizations, big and small, urban and rural, and found that keeping the workforce strong was often the first thing mentioned. The CEOs shared their strategies for tackling labor shortages, including becoming a preferred employer, streamlining recruitment, investing in the workforce with pay and benefit increases, adding new employees, implementing new care models, embracing innovation, and reducing reliance on agency staffing. Scott Wester, CEO of Memorial Healthcare System, was particularly successful in slashing staff turnover and lowering utilization of agency nurses and outside contracts.

title: Memorial Healthcare Buys Hollywood Dev Site From Ben-Shmuels
summary: Memorial Healthcare System has purchased a development site in Hollywood for $49m, with preliminary plans to develop a health and wellness centre. The 8.2-acre site at 101 South State Road 7 includes a two-storey building leased to Gordon Food Service grocery store and an adjacent parking lot. The sellers, the Ben-Shmuel family, founded now-defunct Swiss Watch International. Memorial Healthcare System plans to consult with Memorial and community interests and convene a group to come up with a project, according to a Memorial news release. Preliminary discussions have focused on a possible community health and wellness centre. Led by CEO K Scott Wester, Memorial is a network of hospitals and wellness facilities throughout South Florida. In 2018, the hospital paid $6.5m for a 16,000 sq ft Petco building at 12251 Pines Boulevard in Pembroke Pines, with plans to use the land as part of the expansion of Memorial Hospital West.

title: How can ACLs and other serious injuries in women’s football be prevented?
summary: ACL injuries in women's football have been a hot topic, as players such as Alexia Putellas, Ellie Carpenter, and Leah Williamson have sustained such injuries. To prevent such injuries, Karen Carney suggests looking into workload and equipment, as well as investigating and studying female footballers to find out why they get injured. Carney also suggests reviewing the development of children in the academy system, as young boys have better medical care and more expertise and knowledge that makes the transition to the professional game easier. Additionally, she notes that understanding the menstrual cycle and its effects on diet, sleep, recovery from exercise, and hormone levels can help sportswomen through sleep strategies and know what type of training is suitable at different phases of the cycle.

title: Memorial Healthcare System could expand Pembroke Pines facility - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Memorial Healthcare System has filed plans for a major expansion of its 24/7 Emergency Care Center in Pembroke Pines, Florida. The Broward County Commission will consider a plat change for the 20-acre site at 801 S. Douglas Road on Dec. 12. The hospital plans to build a new emergency department of more than 30,000 square feet, with 20 exam rooms, five triage bays, 16 fast track rooms and a trauma room. Matt Muhart, chief strategy officer of MHS, said the new facility would have a larger capacity to treat patients and a more efficient flow of providing care. Muhart expects construction to take 13 to 15 months. The old freestanding ED might be converted to a primary care center, but those plans haven’t been finalized. Memorial Healthcare System has been busy expanding recently, with a cancer care center opening near Memorial Hospital West in Pembroke Pines and a primary care center in Hialeah.

title: Dr. Robin McGuinness Reappointed to Florida Center for Nursing Board of Directors
summary: Dr. Robin McGuinness, who is a Senior Executive Officer at AdventHealth West Florida Division, has been chosen again by Governor Ron DeSantis to serve on the Board of Directors of the Florida Center for Nursing. McGuinness has a bachelor's degree in nursing from Saint Joseph's College of Maine, a master's degree from the University of Hartford, and a doctorate in nursing from Florida State University. With her extensive experience and strong commitment to nursing education and innovation, McGuinness strives to improve patient safety and provide exceptional whole-person care to the people of Florida. Other members appointed to the Board of Directors of the Florida Center for Nursing include Michele Panetta, Monica Puga, Leslie Rogers, PhD, Joanne Stevens Hoertz, Mary Anne Enns, and Suzanne Wilson Depew.

title: Technology Helps Memorial Healthcare System Patients Help Themselves
summary: Remote monitoring technology is making a difference for patients and clinicians by proactively improving access, outcomes, and lowering costs. Memorial Healthcare System is currently connected to more than 800 patients, some needing only basic equipment to transmit important information. Wearable watches, which can be used to monitor glucose for diabetics, blood pressure cuffs, pulse oximeters (asthma), and scales are provided and configured for each individual, with data seen in real time by clinicians uploaded directly to that person's electronic medical record. Monica Puga, RN, MSN, chief nursing executive for Memorial Healthcare System, says the system's commitment to remote patient monitoring has paid dividends for those in the program, including significant decreases in hospital admissions, readmissions, emergency department visits, and an increased number of visits to primary care providers. The amount saved by reducing hospital and emergency services already tops more than $4 million dollars.

title: Dr. Ari Sareli to Lead Clinical Efforts for Memorial Healthcare System as Chief Medical Officer
summary: Dr. Aharon (Ari) Sareli has been appointed as the Chief Medical Officer of Memorial Healthcare System. Dr. Sareli is a critical care physician and longtime clinical and executive leader, and he will be joined by Dr. Holly Neville in an associate CMO role. Both doctors bring current, front-line experience to executive leadership positions and will maintain their current roles. Dr. Sareli has been with Memorial Healthcare System since 2009, and he has played a key role in front-line clinical leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic. Under his leadership, the Memorial Physician Group has grown to include 350+ physicians and 220 advanced practice providers. Dr. Neville is the lead coach of the American Pediatric Surgery Association's coaching program and serves on the education and wellness committee for the American Pediatric Surgical Association.

title: The Exec: 'I Believe in a Servant Leadership Mentality'
summary: Aharon Sareli, the new chief medical officer of Memorial Healthcare System, believes in a servant leadership mentality that embraces a team approach and facilitates everyone's ability to succeed. He seeks to build relationships, foster trust, and embrace teamwork to keep staff focused on patient care despite challenges. Health systems are facing supply chain challenges, labor challenges, external pressures from payers, and expectations from patients as they relate to access and service. To keep staff focused on patient care despite challenges, leaders need to earn trust through action. In physician engagement, leaders must listen more and talk less. Sareli was named CMO of the Hollywood, Florida-based health system last month. He first joined Memorial Healthcare System as an intensivist in 2009. He was appointed as chief of critical care for the health system in 2012. Sareli was promoted to chief physician executive of the Memorial Physician Group in 2019.

title: Eco Flexibles appoints David Smith as general manager
summary: Eco Flexibles has appointed David Smith as general manager to ensure the company's strategic goals are met through operational excellence and continuous improvement. The company specializes in recyclable monopolymer flexible packaging and works with customers to switch incumbent mixed material flexible packaging to high-performance monopolymers. Smith brings over two decades of experience in the paper-based and flexible packaging industries, including production and operational excellence directorship. Eco Flexibles' director, Matt Francklow, said they were delighted to welcome Smith aboard in a period of growth for the company. Smith said he was excited to be part of the company's mission to change the packaging industry for the better and praised its complete end-to-end approach to packaging sustainability.

title: Healing by Play
summary: Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital in Florida has expanded its facility with a $166m addition that includes four cardiac procedural suites and a mobile intraoperative MRI machine. The hospital's CEO Caitlin Stella said the institution is committed to "the healing power of play", with additional indoor and outdoor space for children to play and exercise, and a family lounge to support parents. The expansion also includes an outdoor terrace adjacent to the rehabilitation gym to make it easier for patients to get fresh air and sunshine. An ongoing fundraising campaign helped make the addition possible, with $70m in donations as of June. The hospital is part of Memorial Healthcare System.

title: Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital
summary: Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital, located in Hollywood, Florida, is a pediatric hospital that focuses on the healing power of play. The hospital's CEO, Caitlin Stella, believes that the child life program, which includes music, art, yoga, dance, gaming, and technology therapies, is essential. The hospital has a therapy dog named Freedom and a resident clown who helps to create a positive atmosphere. The hospital's Garth Brooks Teammates for Kids Child Life Zone, which was made possible by the Finker-Frenkel Family Foundation, looks like a children's museum and offers daily enriching activities. The hospital has been recognized by US News & World Report as the best children's hospital for orthopedics and cardiology and heart surgery. The hospital's spinal and orthopedic programs are nationally ranked, and the oncology and neurosurgery programs are top-notch. The NICU can accommodate the highest risk newborns. The hospital relies on area pediatricians and birth rates to keep them informed of the community's continued rising need for pediatric specialized healthcare.

title: Caitlin Beck Stella Named CEO of Joe DiMaggio Children's Hospital • Hollywood Gazette
summary: Caitlin Beck Stella has been appointed as the CEO of Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital, taking over from Chantal Leconte. Stella has an impressive background in children’s healthcare, including overseeing the establishment of a multi-million-dollar clinical research Center of Excellence funded by the National Institutes of Health while working as a clinical research administrator at the Semel Institute for Neuroscience and Human Behavior at UCLA Medical Center. During her tenure at UCLA, she also obtained a Master’s degree in Public Health in Health Policy and Management, which led her to pursue a management consulting career in the healthcare advisory practice of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP. Prior to joining Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital, Stella served as the Chief Administrative Officer for UCLA Mattel Children’s Hospital and Women’s Health. She spearheaded efforts to affiliate with Miller Children’s and Women’s Hospital and developed a system-wide strategy for the joint expansion of children’s health services in Southern California. Joe DiMaggio Children’s Hospital is the largest pediatric hospital in Broward, Palm Beach, and northern Miami-Dade counties, with 226 licensed beds, seven operating rooms, and an entire floor dedicated to oncology.

title: Phil A. Wright to Lead Memorial Regional Hospital South (Hollywood, FL)
summary: Phil A. Wright has been appointed as the CEO of Memorial Regional Hospital South in Hollywood, Florida. The facility was named one of the best rehabilitation hospitals in the nation by U.S. News & World Report. Wright brings more than 25 years of healthcare experience to his new position, including most recent roles as chief business development officer and chief operating officer at AdventHealth Ocala. He was also CEO at Southampton Memorial Hospital in Franklin, Virginia. Wright is a graduate of both Florida A&M University and the Medical University of South Carolina. At Memorial Regional Hospital South, he will oversee a 280-bed facility that offers a wide range of healthcare services in a compassionate, collaborative setting.

title: Memorial Healthcare System names CEO of Hollywood hospital - South Florida Business Journal
summary: Phil A. Wright has been appointed as the CEO of Memorial Regional Hospital South in Hollywood, Florida, taking over from the retired Douglas Zaren. Wright has more than 25 years of experience in healthcare, including being the CEO of Southampton Memorial Hospital in Virginia and serving as the chief business development officer and chief operating officer of AdventHealth Ocala. He holds a bachelor's degree from Florida A&M University and a master's degree in health administration from the Medical University of South Carolina. Leah A. Carpenter, the chief operating officer at Memorial Healthcare System, said that Wright has "strategic, financial, and operational management expertise in both for-profit and not-for-profit healthcare settings and balances his business acumen and clinical expertise with staff engagement, creating a healthy organizational culture and ensuring safe, high-quality care." Memorial Regional Hospital South is operated as a campus of the larger Memorial Regional Hospital.

title: JPM24: Scripps Health hires former FBI cybercrime lead
summary: Scripps Health, a health system based in San Diego, experienced a cyberattack in 2021 which caused care disruptions and over $100m in lost revenue. The cause of the breach is still unknown. Chris Van Gorder, the president and CEO of Scripps Health, cautioned other health system leaders at the J.P. Morgan Healthcare Conference that the cost of maintaining sufficient cybersecurity measures is likely to increase in the future. Scripps Health collaborated with the FBI to remove malware from thousands of computers and other systems. The health system has since hired Todd Walbridge, a retired FBI supervising agent in San Diego specializing in cybersecurity, as the senior director for corporate and system safety and security. Scripps Health also contracted cybersecurity technology firm CrowdStrike to provide live, 24/7 monitoring of its systems. The leadership team at Scripps Health has learned from the incident and warns other providers to prepare for cyberattacks, as they are inevitable, their effects can last for years, and the cost to recover from them will likely increase over time.

title: Two Large Medical Groups Shun Medicare Advantage Plans
summary: Two medical groups affiliated with Scripps Health in San Diego are terminating their Medicare Advantage contracts for 2024 due to insufficient reimbursement and prior authorization issues. This decision leaves 30,000 seniors who were previously enrolled in these plans to find new doctors or alternative coverage options. Scripps Health CEO Chris Van Gorder stated that negotiations with payers for Medicare Advantage with their medical foundation groups were unsuccessful, and the losses exceeded $75 million due to low reimbursement, denials, and administrative expenses. Van Gorder emphasized that patients can still see Scripps Health through traditional Medicare or switch to an independent medical group (IPA) that still maintains a Medicare Advantage contract. Over half of all Medicare beneficiaries are now enrolled in Medicare Advantage plans nationwide, and many health systems have announced that they are terminating their Medicare Advantage contracts or are seriously considering it.

title: Scripps Encinitas breaks ground on hospital expansion – North Coast Current
summary: Scripps Memorial Hospital Encinitas has started a significant expansion by holding a groundbreaking ceremony for the $263m Lusardi Tower and Lusardi Pulmonary Institute. The 224,000-square-foot complex, which is three stories tall, is expected to be completed within two years. It will add 64 private inpatient rooms, 16 intensive care unit beds, and several operating rooms. The project is partially funded by a $25m donation from philanthropists Warner and Debbie Lusardi of Rancho Santa Fe, which is the largest gift that the Encinitas hospital has ever received. Chris Van Gorder, the President and CEO of Scripps Health, stated that the event marked a significant milestone in the final phase of a master plan that is driving Scripps Encinitas into the future of healthcare with innovative growth that will serve the North County community for years to come. Scripps' presence in Encinitas dates back to 1964, when the hospital first opened.

title: Scripps Health CEO Retires as Reserve Sheriff
summary: Chris Van Gorder, the CEO and President of San Diego-based nonprofit integrated healthcare delivery system Scripps Health, has retired from his position as a reserve assistant sheriff in the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department after more than 20 years of volunteering. Van Gorder, who once worked in law enforcement before transitioning into healthcare, was severely injured in the line of duty during a family dispute call in 1978, leading to his retirement from the Monterey Park Police Department. He then transitioned to graduate school, which led to a career in healthcare administration. Van Gorder attributes much of his success in healthcare to what he learned in the police academy, including situational awareness, multitasking, command presence, and critical thinking. He will continue his leadership role at Scripps Health, which operates five acute-care hospital campuses and 28 outpatient centers and clinics.

title: $263 million Lusardi Tower breaks ground at Scripps Encinitas
summary: Scripps Health has celebrated the start of construction of the $263 million acute care Lusardi Tower and Lusardi Pulmonary Institute, which will offer a broad range of patient care services and facilities. The building, set to open before the end of 2025, will have 64 private inpatient rooms, including 36 private medical/surgical beds; 16 intensive care unit beds; multiple operating rooms; and the Lusardi Pulmonary Institute, which will build on the hospital’s existing state-of-the-art interventional pulmonary medicine program. The expansion will bring the hospital’s total bed count above 230. The Lusardi Tower and Lusardi Pulmonary Institute are key components of the second and final phase of the ongoing master plan to greatly expand the hospital campus. The newest building was supported with a $25 million gift in 2020 from philanthropists Warner and Debbie Lusardi of Rancho Santa Fe, the largest donation in the history of Scripps Encinitas. Chris Van Gorder, president and CEO of Scripps Health, said the event marked a major milestone in the final phase of a master plan that is propelling Scripps Encinitas into the future of health care with innovative growth that will serve the North County community for years to come.

title: Lusardi Tower breaks ground at Scripps Encinitas
summary: Construction has started on the Lusardi Tower and Lusardi Pulmonary Institute at Scripps Memorial Hospital Encinitas campus. The facility, which costs $263 million and spans three stories and 224,000 square feet, will provide a broad range of patient care services and amenities, including 64 private inpatient rooms, multiple operating rooms, and the Lusardi Pulmonary Institute. The Lusardi Tower and Pulmonary Institute are crucial elements of the second and final stage of the hospital campus' ongoing master plan to significantly expand. The hospital's total bed count will exceed 230 when the building opens by the end of 2025. In 2020, philanthropists Warner and Debbie Lusardi of Rancho Santa Fe donated $25 million to support the project, the largest donation in Scripps Encinitas' history. Chris Van Gorder, president and CEO of Scripps Health, stated that the event marked a significant milestone in the final phase of a master plan that is propelling Scripps Encinitas into the future of health care with innovative growth that will serve the North County community for years to come.

title: “It's definitely a lifestyle change” – Eric Cole opens up about discovering diabetes and dealing with fluctuating blood ...
summary: Eric Cole, a professional golfer, recently shared his experience of being diagnosed with type 1 diabetes at the age of 17. He spoke about the lifestyle change he had to undergo and the daily challenges he faces due to fluctuating blood sugar levels. However, he also added that he is happy to share his story and connect with fans, some of whom are also diabetics. Cole has had a successful start to the 2024 PGA Tour season, making seven cuts in nine starts and registering six top-25 finishes. He will next compete at the Players Championship 2024.

title: Scripps CMO: 'Physicians in Leadership at Health Systems can be Incredibly Instrumental'
summary: Physicians are playing important administrative leadership roles at Scripps Health, a health system based in San Diego. There are about 80 medical directors who oversee clinical departments and report to physician executives.
