Ghazala Sharieff, MD, MBA, is the corporate senior vice president and chief medical and operations officer for acute care at Scripps Health. She says that the health system has a strong physician leadership structure that has been strengthened over the past three years. Physicians are well-suited to succeed in administrative leadership roles, and with health systems and hospitals facing financial challenges, physicians can be instrumental in helping organizations maintain high standards of patient care with limited resources. Sharieff believes that physician leaders at health systems can have a positive impact on the broader healthcare system, and the practical experiences that physicians bring to the table are invaluable in guiding smart policy and planning decisions.

title: The Exec: Physicians Play Key Role in Healthcare Administration
summary: Physician operating executives and medical directors play a crucial role in healthcare administration at Scripps Health, according to Ghazala Sharieff, the corporate senior vice president of hospital operations and chief medical officer at the San Diego-based health system. She suggests that physicians are becoming more involved in healthcare organization administration in general because of the financial climate that hospitals are currently facing. Sharieff also emphasizes the importance of addressing healthcare worker burnout, which is being tackled at Scripps Health through peer-to-peer responder programs, employee assistance with psychologists, one-on-one coaching, and reminders about mental health. Additionally, she highlights the pivotal elements of a positive patient experience in the inpatient setting, which are nursing communication, physician communication, and the environment of the hospital. Sharieff draws on her clinical background in emergency medicine to explain how situational leadership has helped her serve in leadership roles such as CMO.

title: Four Scripps Hospital Campuses Receive a National 'A' Grade for Patient Safety
summary: Four campuses of Scripps Health hospital, including Scripps Green Hospital, Scripps Memorial Hospital Encinitas, Scripps Memorial Hospital La Jolla, and Scripps Mercy Hospital Chula Vista, have been awarded an "A" grade for patient safety by Leapfrog Group, an independent watchdog organization. Only 30% of the 3,000 general hospitals in the United States evaluated by the watchdog organization received "A" grades during this fall 2023 round of ratings. In California, only 10% of hospitals received the top grade. Dr. Ghazala Sharieff, a Scripps corporate senior vice president and chief medical and operations officer for acute care, said that patient care is always their top priority and these fall 2023 grades are a direct result of that focus. The Leapfrog Hospital Safety Grade is the only hospital ratings program based exclusively on hospital records of patient safety.

title: Scripps Health CEO Retires as Reserve Sheriff
summary: Chris Van Gorder, CEO and president of Scripps Health, has retired from his position as a reserve assistant sheriff after more than 20 years of volunteering for the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department. However, he will continue his leadership role at Scripps Health, which operates five acute-care hospital campuses and 28 outpatient centers and clinics. Van Gorder recruited Scripps Health Chief Medical Officer Dr. Ghazala Sharieff to also volunteer for the department, where she was sworn in as a civilian partner in 2013. Both Dr. Sharieff and Van Gorder will continue helping officers with maintaining their Emergency Medical Technician certifications. Van Gorder's unconventional path to his position as CEO and president of Scripps Health included working in law enforcement before transitioning into healthcare.

title: Patient Experience Week: How to Improve HCAHPS Scores
summary: Improving physician and nurse communication is crucial for achieving a good patient experience. To improve HCAHPS scores, Providence urges physicians to focus on listening carefully, courtesy and respect, and making sure patients understand their care. At Scripps Health, underperforming physicians receive tips to improve their communication with patients. Providence uses physician champions to improve physician communication, and nurse communication is promoted by ensuring that they can work to the top of their license. Scripps has hired patient care assistants to relieve nurses of tasks that someone else can do, and they are encouraging nurses to engage with patients at the bedside. Ghazala Sharieff, the corporate senior vice president of hospital operations and chief medical officer at Scripps Health, is featured in a video educational session by HealthLeaders on improving HCAHPS scores during Patient Experience Week.

title: Back to Profitability: How Non-Profit CFOs Can Battle the Red
summary: Non-profit hospitals are experiencing a decrease in profitability because of the high cost of labor and the fact that hospital revenue is inelastic. The median operating and operating EBITDA margins for non-profit hospitals have decreased significantly from fiscal year 2021 to 2022. CFOs of non-profit hospitals and health systems need to focus on operational efficiency, according to Brett Tande, CFO of Scripps Health. Scripps Health is facing challenges with profitability due to labor costs and pandemic-related difficulties, but they are concentrating on operational efficiency to maintain productivity levels. They are also rethinking traditional practices to reduce expenses and enhance patient experience and outcomes. Collaborating with payers is another way to cut costs. Tande stressed that reimagining operations must be done throughout the organization, not just in the clinical environment.

title: A Wage Increase Bill is Delayed, But The CFO's Need to Budget For It is Not
summary: California Governor Gavin Newsom has postponed a bill that would gradually increase the minimum wage of healthcare workers to $25 per hour due to the state's projected budget deficit of $38 billion. The bill was expected to cost $4 billion for the fiscal year 2024-25. The delay gives California hospitals and health systems more time to plan for the additional expenses, but they still need to prepare for these costs in the future. Brett Tande, CFO of Scripps Health, a California-based organization, said that the minimum wage bill would cost tens of millions of dollars per year for an organization of Scripps' size. CFOs in all states should prioritize budgeting for higher labor expenses.

title: Are Health Systems Mature Enough to Use AI Properly?
summary: Healthcare organizations are rushing to launch AI programs to ease administrative workflows or address care management gaps, but some experts are questioning whether they are equipped to use the technology. Shane Thielman, CHCIO, FACHE, corporate senior vice president and chief information officer at Scripps Health, says that healthcare is different and that organizations need to have corridors for testing with safeguards in place. Some healthcare organizations don't understand the challenges of using AI or have the maturity to manage how it's used. Healthcare organizations need to carefully plan how to develop and use AI, with a management strategy that addresses who, how, and why the technology is used and how to address errors and misuse. Healthcare leaders need to understand their organization's AI maturity and what they know and don't know. MI10, a for-profit consultancy, has developed a model called MIQ, using 11 factors to measure a health system's readiness and maturity, giving out a number on a scale of 1 to 100.

title: The AI Doctor-Patient Experience
summary: San Diego regional hospitals are at the forefront of AI development, adopting the latest advancements to improve the quality and speed of care while reducing costs for patients and providers. Scripps Health is utilizing AI in various ways, including a pilot AI tool that assists in drafting physician responses to patient inquiries, and an AI note-taking tool called Dragon Ambient eXperience that translates patient-doctor conversations into clinical notes. Palomar Health and Sharp HealthCare are also using AI tools for acute stroke care. However, there are concerns about patient privacy and equality regarding the use of technology in healthcare.

title: Scripps Health Tests AI for Patient Messages
summary: Scripps Health is starting a test program that utilizes generative AI to assist doctors in responding to patients' messages. The AI system will create responses based on patients' messages, current medications, recent results, and other clinical data. This technology is intended to streamline the drafting process while maintaining strict security measures to protect patient information. All messages will be checked by a human before being sent to ensure patient safety. The test will begin with one physician at the Scripps Clinic Anderson Medical Pavilion and will expand to all five primary care physicians and two advanced healthcare providers in the next month. The hospital network will partner with Epic Systems, a healthcare software provider, to improve the AI tool through weekly check-ins and clinician feedback. The goal of this initiative is to reduce clinician burnout and optimize the time spent on hands-on care.

title: How to Create a Gameplan for Assessing AI Readiness
summary: Healthcare leadership needs to evaluate their staff and medical professionals to determine their understanding and readiness to use AI. They should provide resources and ongoing communication as part of an AI strategy. Shane Thielman, FACHE, CHCIO, corporate SVP and chief information officer at San Diego-based Scripps Health, emphasized that leadership must commit to open dialogue and transparency to educate staff, clinicians, patients, and the public about how AI will be used. Healthcare organizations must establish a clear and transparent process for enterprise-wide AI governance. Providence's EVP and chief strategy and digital officer, Sara Vaezy, suggests that health systems should survey their staff and clinicians about what they want to know about AI, then create specific resources to address those concerns. Thielman and Vaezy also stated that health systems need to evaluate their infrastructure and data quality for AI governance. The first step is determining whether the organization is mature enough to use the technology.

title: Sunshine State Sonar divers look for sunken cars, missing people
summary: Sherman T. Moore, a nurse from South Florida who went missing in 2001, was discovered deceased in her white 1999 Saturn car that had sunk in a pond in Davie, north of Miami. This was made possible thanks to the efforts of Mike Sullivan, founder of Sunshine State Sonar, and his team of volunteers. Sullivan, who also owns an auto-parts ecommerce company, offers his diving expertise, sonar equipment, and team of volunteers to any local official willing to provide him with any tiny piece of information that could aid him in cracking open the otherwise stagnant list of missing persons cold cases. Since beginning in July 2021, Sullivan has located more than 250 cars in Florida's numerous man-made canals, ponds, and fountains, and has found almost a dozen bodies in sunken cars. Sullivan and his team have provided answers for families who have been unaware of the whereabouts of their loved ones for years, and in some cases, even decades.

title: New commander at Scott Air Force Base reflects on first months
summary: Colonel John Poole, who has been the commander of the 375th Air Mobility Wing for 81 days, has been reflecting on his first months at Scott Air Force Base. He has been learning as much as possible about daily operations and has avoided making big changes. However, he and his leadership team will write strategic plans for the remainder of his two years running the base. Poole wants to ensure all members are on the same page, working towards becoming combat-ready. He plans to build a shared understanding and focus on three areas: operating the flagship, deploying forces forward, and seizing competitive advantage. Poole also wants to create a long-term plan for facilities, given that the base is one of the oldest in the Air Force, built in 1917, and has a cutting-edge global mission.

title: Turks and Caicos at a crossroads: The urgent need for marine conservation and sustainable tourism
summary: Turks and Caicos Islands face a critical challenge of marine and coastal conservation, which is essential for the sustainability of the local economy and way of life. The decline in government support has led to the need for stronger collaboration among community groups and non-profits agencies. The urgent matter demands a comprehensive approach, including increased funding and stringent enforcement of existing environmental laws. The protection of marine inhabitants, including whales, dolphins, and stingrays, is vital for the tourism industry and economic vitality. The article suggests engaging and educating fishermen and tour operators on sustainability and empowering youth with environmental knowledge. The need for infrastructure improvement and additional resources, such as a proper boat ramp and installation and upkeep of boat moorings and channel markers, is critical to prevent ecological harm. The author, Ed Forbes, calls for decisive action to protect and preserve the environment for today's inhabitants and generations to come.

title: Allegheny Health Network raises hourly minimum wage to $18
summary: Allegheny Health Network has announced that it will increase its minimum hourly starting wage to $18, affecting approximately 1,700 employees who are currently at or near the current minimum hourly wage of $16 an hour. This increase will have the greatest impact on those in entry-level positions such as environmental services, dietary services, and patient care technicians. The decision comes as Pennsylvania's minimum wage has remained at $7.25 for 15 years. Highmark Health, AHN's parent company, has also stated that it will implement an $18 hourly minimum wage elsewhere within the organization by the end of the year. AHN is one of the largest employers in the region, with approximately 22,000 employees. AHN President Jim Benedict has stated that the company is committed to appropriately rewarding its exceptional caregivers for the important roles they play in helping the organization achieve its mission.

title: Highmark Health names James Benedict president of Allegheny Health Network
summary: Highmark Health has appointed James Benedict as the president of Allegheny Health Network (AHN), effective immediately. AHN is the provider arm of Highmark Health in Western Pennsylvania, which offers health insurance solutions under the Blues brand in four states. Benedict joined AHN as its executive vice president and COO in 2017, and he played a key role in the network's successful operational turnaround, as well as its market expansion strategy and capital investment of nearly $2 billion. Benedict is an experienced healthcare leader who has a proven track record of managing complex organizations, building high-performing teams, and executing winning strategies. As the new AHN president, he will continue to report to Bruce A. Meyer, MD, MBA, executive vice president and Western PA market president for Highmark Health.

title: Global Healthcare & Medical Tourism News
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN) has announced the opening of a new 27,500 square-foot multi-specialty outpatient center in Uniontown, Pennsylvania. The facility will offer a range of clinical and specialty services, including cardiology, neurosurgery, orthopedic surgery, and sports medicine. It will also provide diagnostic imaging capabilities such as X-ray, 3D mammography, and ultrasound screening, as well as a full spectrum of women's health offerings. The facility will be open to patients Monday through Friday from 7:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. The new Uniontown location will enable care coordination at the site between AHN and Preferred Primary Care Physicians (PPCP). Fayette County, where the facility is located, has been identified as a Health Professional Shortage Area due to its lower-than-average median household income.

title: Change continues: Top executives leave or are reassigned at Allegheny Health Network
summary: Top executives are leaving or being reassigned at Allegheny Health Network (AHN), a 14-hospital healthcare system owned by Highmark Health. The system has been struggling with operating losses for three years, with losses of $144.1m reported for the three months ending 30 September 2023. Eight AHN executives, including the system COO, have left or been reassigned within the past year, and the CFO has also announced his departure. AHN's chief financial officer position will be filled by Brian Devine, current CFO at Highmark subsidiary enGen, while Melissa Stephens Williamson, senior vice president for strategic programs and operations at Highmark Health, will succeed Devine as enGen CFO. AHN President Jim Benedict said the changes were part of efforts to "build a sustainable, integrated economic model for healthcare".

title: Allegheny Health Network names new president
summary: Jim Benedict has been appointed as the new president of Allegheny Health Network (AHN), taking over from Cynthia Hundorfean, who has transitioned to a new role as Highmark Health's chief living health development officer. Benedict became AHN's executive vice president and COO in 2017 and played a key role in the network's successful operational turnaround, as well as its nearly $2 billion capital investment and market expansion strategy. Benedict has a proven track record of effectively managing complex organizations, building high-performing teams, and assisting institutions in developing and executing winning strategies to achieve their goals. Benedict will continue to report to Dr. Bruce Meyer, executive vice president and Western Pennsylvania market president for Highmark Health, a newly created role.

title: Highmark Health Promotes AHN COO to Network President
summary: Jim Benedict has been appointed as the new president of Allegheny Health Network (AHN), effective immediately. Benedict has been with AHN since 2017 and was previously the COO. He will now lead the network's daily operations and long-term clinical strategy. Benedict has three decades of experience in healthcare, including hospital operations, physician practice management, and ambulatory operations. He is credited with being one of the "chief architects" of AHN's operational turnaround and nearly $2 billion capital investment and market expansion strategy. Benedict will continue to report to Bruce A Meyer, EVP and Western PA market president for Highmark Health, AHN's parent company. Meyer said that Benedict and his team will help transform AHN into the provider pacesetter of their Living Health model, creating and supporting the clinical infrastructure and blended payer-provider solutions that deliver better value, better experiences, and better outcomes for those they serve.

title: With days left on the clock, La Plata County prepares for public health transition
summary: La Plata County is getting ready for the transition of public health services as San Juan Basin Public Health is closing on December 28. La Plata County will now be responsible for these services after the shared public health district was dissolved in November 2022. The new department has hired 45 out of 47 staff members, with 39 coming from the previous department. The transition is expected to be smooth for clients as there will be minimal changes to the services provided. However, the department's biggest challenge will be communicating to the public that there have been few changes. The dissolution of the shared public health district was due to philosophical differences.

title: Dr. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew Appointed Academic Chair of Obstetrics & Gynecology - College of Medicine
summary: Dr. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew has been appointed as the academic chair of the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology at Drexel University College of Medicine, effective July 1. She joined the college in 2021 as a professor of obstetrics and gynecology and also supervises students and residents at Highmark Health and Allegheny Health Network. She brings experience as a clinician, educator, and national leader to her new role. Dr. Larkins-Pettigrew serves on the AAMC Group on Diversity and Inclusion and has been listed in Becker’s Hospital Review’s 149 Black Healthcare Leaders to Know. She is also a highly sought-after speaker and author of a 2020 memoir, The Colors of My Heart: Embracing My Blackness Through History, Family, Fear, and Faith. She has been awarded funding for projects pertaining to racial bias training for pregnancy providers and staff, underrepresented resident retention, medical school preparation for high school students, and reducing infant mortality through structural racism and unconscious bias training.

title: 2023 Diversity Leaders Luminaries Dr. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew
summary: Dr. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew is the Senior Vice President and Chief Clinical Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Officer at Allegheny Health Network/Highmark Health. She has spent over four decades working to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion on a national and global scale. She leads DEI initiatives at Highmark Health and recently oversaw efforts to expand programs promoting the health and well-being of Black families, especially pregnant patients. She also launched and heads the organization’s Equitable Care Institute. This year, she was appointed academic chair of the Drexel University College of Medicine’s Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology. She has helped raise over $14 million for Highmark’s health equity initiatives, affecting access to care within and beyond the Pittsburgh area.

title: Highmark Health/AHN Chief Clinical Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Officer Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew, MD, again ...
summary: Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew, MD, who serves as the Chief Clinical Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Officer for Highmark Health and Allegheny Health Network (AHN), has been recognized as one of the top diversity leaders in the industry by Modern Healthcare magazine for the third consecutive year. Dr. Larkins-Pettigrew has devoted her career to engaging marginalized communities and creating programs that promote access and equity in healthcare outcomes for vulnerable patients, particularly women, while also addressing socio-economic barriers to care. She founded the AHN Equitable Health Institute, which is working towards a comprehensive internal and external strategy to foster a culture of equity and inclusion throughout all aspects of the health and wellness enterprise. In addition, she was appointed as the academic chair of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Drexel University College of Medicine in 2023. Modern Healthcare's annual "Top Diversity Leaders" recognition honors a distinguished group of executives and organizations who are recognized by an expert panel as trailblazers in the areas of health care diversity, equity, and inclusion.

title: Bias complaints from hospital employees indicate culture shift
summary: Highmark Health, a US-based healthcare company, is seeing an increase in internal bias complaints from its employees, which the head of the company's diversity, equity, and inclusion programs views as a positive development. The company has implemented various measures to encourage employees to report any bias incidents, including a hotline, online reporting, and training programs. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew, the chief clinical diversity and inclusion officer at Highmark Health, believes that the rise in complaints is a sign of a culture shift, indicating that employees feel more comfortable reporting incidents of bias and discrimination. Highmark Health is committed to creating a diverse and inclusive workplace, and Larkins-Pettigrew's team is working to address the root causes of these complaints and implement strategies to prevent future incidents.

title: Women's History Month: 2 doctors working to provide everyone with optimal treatment
summary: Two Pittsburgh doctors, Dr. Tracey Conti and Dr. Margaret Larkins-Pettigrew, are working towards providing everyone with optimal treatment. They focus on giving women and underserved populations the best care to create a strong community. The doctors said that treatment has improved in recent years but more needs to be done, including prioritizing reproductive health, heart disease, and dementia among women. They also emphasize the importance of having a diverse workforce and creating an effective patient-physician relationship. Both hope their respective programs will help close the equity gap. These doctors believe the progress will continue as long as the community embraces equity. In 2022, AHN launched First Steps and Beyond to reduce Black infant mortality rates, which also decreases maternal deaths. UPMC opened the Matilda Theiss Health Center in the Hill District to create a one-stop shop for medical needs.

title: Allegheny Health Network Advances Virtual Critical Care Service with Launch of New, In-House 'TeleICU' Program
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN) and Highmark Health have launched a new virtual intensive care solution, called TeleICU, which combines telehealth technology and clinical expertise of AHN intensivists for centralized, 24/7 monitoring and management of critically ill patients at six of the network's hospitals across western Pennsylvania. The TeleICU program virtually connects a centrally located team of AHN board-certified critical care physicians, nurses, and data assistants with bedside hospitalists and nurses in intensive care units (ICUs) at AHN's hospitals. The program utilizes the FDA-approved eCareManager telehealth software platform from Philips to support continuous ICU monitoring through an infrastructure of real-time monitors, electronic medical records, and two-way, audio-visual conferencing. The TeleICU command center is located at 4 Allegheny Center on Pittsburgh's Northside nearby AHN Allegheny General Hospital. Ashis Barad, MD, pediatric gastroenterologist, and AHN's chief digital information officer said that this facility has emerged as a virtual health hub that is host to some of the most advanced technologies and tools which support caregivers and staff in delivering high-quality patient care, helping to improve outcomes and enhance the overall healthcare experience for both patients and their caregivers.

title: Allegheny Health Network Unveils 'Digital Nursing' Program to Revolutionize the Patient and Nurse Experience
summary: Allegheny Health Network (AHN) has launched a full-time Digital Nursing program to revolutionize the nursing profession while providing more efficient, effective care for hospitalized patients. The new in-house Digital Nursing team will begin serving AHN Forbes Hospital this summer, expanding to all AHN hospital facilities by the end of 2024. The digital nurses will partner with bedside nurses to interact with patients, ask and answer questions, provide education, and complete admissions and discharges more efficiently. Digital nurses are not intended to replace bedside nursing staff, but rather to complement and enhance their work by providing an extra set of "digital" hands. The virtual communications technologies that will be deployed at Forbes were first piloted at AHN Allegheny General Hospital (AGH), and the work processes used for digital admissions and discharges were designed by – and for – AHN nurses. The Digital Nursing program is also in keeping with AHN's and Highmark Health's "Living Health" care model.

title: AHN Wexford Hospital and AHN Westmoreland Recognized with Patient Experience Award from Press Ganey
summary: Allegheny Health Network's Wexford Hospital and Westmoreland Endoscopy Center have been awarded the 2023 Human Experience Guardian of Excellence Award in the 'patient experience' category by Press Ganey. The award is given to healthcare facilities that are ranked in the 95th percentile for patient experience. AHN Wexford Hospital's emergency department has received the Guardian of Excellence Award for the second consecutive year, and the hospital's inpatient care is also acclaimed as part of the 2023 award. AHN Outpatient Center—Westmoreland has received the Guardian of Excellence Award for three consecutive years. Eugene Scioscia, AHN chief experience officer, congratulated the caregivers and staff for receiving the award and said that their exceptional patient care sets great examples for AHN programs and facilities across the network and for health systems across the region.

title: Women of Influence: Dr. Vicenta Gaspar-Yoo, Allegheny Health Network - Pittsburgh Business Times
summary: Dr. Vicenta Gaspar-Yoo is the senior vice president of care continuum and transitions at Allegheny Health Network. She has decades of experience as a physician and leader in various organizations. Gaspar-Yoo led efforts to mitigate safety issues and medical errors while serving as the president of Allegheny Valley Hospital. She also introduced a scholarship to help diverse populations with nursing school tuition. Gaspar-Yoo oversees care management, residency management, care transitions, and hospital services across the entirety of AHN in her new role. She plans to work with all 10 hospitals in the network and drive operational excellence. Gaspar-Yoo created a scholarship program that helped one student with tuition for AHN’s Citizens School of Nursing in Tarentum. She moves into her new role leaving AVH with plans already in motion for the future, including adding a Healthy Food Center and a gym for providers to use.

title: New president named to Allegheny Valley Hospital
summary: Dr. Mark Rubino has been appointed as the new president of Allegheny Valley Hospital in Natrona Heights, Harrison. He is currently the president of Forbes Hospital in Monroeville and will start his new role on May 7. He will continue to be responsible for both hospitals. He will succeed Dr. Vicenta Gaspar-Yoo, who will be taking on a network-wide leadership role as AHN's senior vice president of Care Continuum and Transitions. Rubino is a practicing gynecologist and has been the president of Forbes Hospital since 2016. During his time there, he helped to lead multiple capital investment projects, including a $17 million perioperative expansion and a $35 million cancer and imaging center. Rubino was part of a leadership overhaul at the health system that put physicians in top positions.

title: Experts concerned over 'alarming' number of child, infant deaths in RI
summary: Health experts in Rhode Island have raised concerns about a significant increase in child deaths this year. In 2024, there have been 14 deaths and six near-deaths of children aged from newborns to 18-year-olds reported to authorities. Seven of the deaths were of children under a year old. The causes of death include unsafe sleeping practices, accidental substance exposure, domestic violence, and self-harm. The experts could not discuss any specific case. It is expected that the current trend of child deaths in 2024 will exceed the numbers of the past two years. Pediatrician Brett Silingsby at The Lawrence A. Aubin Sr. Child Protection Center, along with other experts, has urged parents and caregivers to practice safe sleeping habits and keep all drugs and alcohol away from children.

title: Health check kids: Preventing child abuse by listening, believing children
summary: Lawrence Aubin, Sr. Child Protection Center at Hasbro Children's Hospital aims to prevent child abuse by listening and believing children. Each child reacts differently to trauma, and it can go unnoticed. Play can be a coping mechanism for children, and it helps experts better understand what happened. Trauma-induced abuse can take many forms, including online abuse, which is horrifying. Experts suggest that adults need to make it clear to children that they should come forward if they experience abuse, and they will be supported. It takes a village of experts in different disciplines working collaboratively to support and help children heal.

title: State can finally start formal review process for Fatima and Roger Williams hospital acquisition • Rhode Island Current
summary: The Rhode Island Office of Attorney General and Rhode Island Department of Health have announced that the transfer of ownership of Roger Williams Medical Center and Our Lady of Fatima Hospital to a Georgia nonprofit, The Centurion Foundation, is complete. The decision on the application for transfer of ownership will be made after a review process, which will include public comment meetings and hearings to ensure that all statutory criteria are met and the public's interest is protected. Otis Brown, spokesperson for CharterCARE Health Partners, stated that the transacting parties are looking forward to sharing their vision and plans on how this proposed new venture will benefit these important hospitals, their dedicated employees, and the communities that rely on them for quality care. However, the financial difficulties of Prospect Medical Holdings, which owns CharterCARE, have been widely publicized, with recent unsealed court documents revealing that the company had over $24 million in accounts payable overdue for 90 days or more as of Oct. 31, 2023.

title: Agony of Alzheimer’s
summary: Rhode Islander Richard Paul Begin was diagnosed with Alzheimer's a few years before his death at age 74. His brother, former state representative, State Treasurer and Lt. Gov. Roger N. Begin, said that the first signs of the disease began to surface when Richard began to have memory issues and stopped doing things he loved. After being diagnosed with Alzheimer's, Richard's condition progressed towards the end stages of the disease, leaving him increasingly frustrated and disturbed, and his family correspondingly stressed. According to the Alzheimer’s Association, an estimated 6.7 million Americans aged 65 and older are living with Alzheimer’s. In 2020, 24,000 state residents aged 65 and older lived with Alzheimer’s in Rhode Island, and that number is projected to rise to 27,000 in the year 2025, an increase of 12.5%. The Rhode Island chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association provides a plethora of help, including a free helpline, resource directory, guide to how Alzheimer’s affects the brain, risk factors, risk-reduction measures, and treatment options.

title: Regulators say they can begin review of proposed sale of CharterCARE hospitals
summary: Rhode Island's Attorney General's Office and Department of Health have approved the application of Centurion Foundation of Georgia to buy CharterCARE Health Partners, including Roger Williams Medical Center in Providence and Our Lady of Fatima Hospital in North Providence from Prospect Medical Holdings. Centurion would convert the hospitals from for-profit to nonprofit. The application has been deemed complete under the state's Hospital Conversions Act, meaning the formal review period can begin. The Attorney General and the Rhode Island Department of Health will have 180 days to review the application before issuing their respective decisions. The process will also involve gathering public comment at hearings. The United Nurses and Allied Professionals union is waiting to hear from Centurion about its plans. Roger Williams Medical Center would be sold to an Atlanta-based company and return to nonprofit status.

title: CyBC to pay €1M in working conditions case
summary: The Cyprus Broadcasting Corporation (CyBC) has been ordered to pay over €1 million in compensation to journalist Evdokia Loizou due to an occupational illness caused by poor working conditions. The court recognized the testimony of Loizou's treating physician, Professor Michael G. Hanna, as well as two expert professors of medicine from abroad, Vassilios Makropoulos and Hanna, who came to Cyprus to prove her case. The court found that the CyBC building was not properly maintained, had poor ventilation and air conditioning systems, and was infested with rodents and insects. The Department of Labour Inspection conducted numerous checks on the premises and made successive recommendations for compliance. Despite this, CyBC did not take adequate measures to improve conditions until 2012, after protests from employees and discussions in the House of Representatives.

title: UCCI partners with US university to offer free education to Caymanian students
summary: UCCI has partnered with the New England Institute of Technology to offer free education to Caymanian students, with living expenses paid for. UCCI offers certificate and degree programmes in computer science and the building trades locally, but students must travel overseas to pursue advanced studies and degrees in high-demand sectors. However, for many students, this is cost prohibitive. NEIT has committed to providing on-campus accommodation and subsidised living expenses for Caymanian students, as part of a package worth up to US$10,000 a year, which will be awarded in addition to the Cayman Islands government scholarship. NEIT is a private, non-profit technical college in East Greenwich, Rhode Island, which offers a wide range of programmes at the associate’s, bachelor’s, and master’s degree levels. Beginning in the Fall of 2023, UCCI students will be eligible to apply to any of NEIT’s degree programmes.

title: Q&A: Janet Robinson on Disease X and pandemic preparedness
summary: Janet Robinson, who is the director of emerging infectious diseases and health security at FHI 360, explains Disease X. It is a name that was adopted by the World Health Organization in February 2018 and added to its existing shortlist of blueprint priority pathogens. These pathogens have the capacity to trigger an epidemic or potentially escalate to a pandemic. Adding Disease X to the list is a critical step in being prepared and is a core component of global health strategies. However, it is also important to prevent unnecessary panic while remaining aware and prepared. The global response to emerging infectious disease threats, such as COVID-19, the Ebola virus, and Zika virus, is largely reactive. At FHI 360, they understand the importance of proactively strengthening countries’ capacity to detect, respond to, and prevent priority diseases, as well as the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance.

title: Former Providence Mayor Angel Taveras Joins Adler Pollock & Sheehan
summary: Former Mayor of Providence, Angel Taveras, has joined Adler Pollock & Sheehan, a Providence-based law firm. Taveras, who was Providence's first Hispanic Mayor when he was elected in 2010, will focus his practice on civil, commercial, and government litigation, municipal restructuring, public finance, pensions, and public infrastructure. Robert Brooks, Managing Partner, said that Taveras’ extensive government experience, legal and communication skills, and network of contacts make him a valuable addition to the team. Taveras served as the Mayor of Providence, Rhode Island, from 2011 to 2015, and lost in the Democratic primary for governor in 2014. After leaving City Hall, he joined the law firm Greenberg Traurig, LLP as a litigation shareholder in the firm’s Boston office.

title: Mayo Clinic Board of Trustees approves plans to transform healthcare, improve experience for staff and patients ...
summary: Mayo Clinic's Board of Trustees has approved a multiyear strategic initiative called Bold. Forward. Unbound. in Rochester, which will transform healthcare and improve the experience for staff and patients. The initiative will reimagine Mayo Clinic's downtown Rochester campus and introduce new facilities with innovative care concepts and digital technologies. The new facilities will support hope and healing through nature, sunlight, and horizontally and vertically connected neighborhoods. These community-centered neighborhoods will bring services together around common patient needs and diseases, creating continuous care environments that will serve as patients’ homes while they are at Mayo Clinic. The total investment of the project is $5 billion over six years. Gianrico Farrugia, M.D., President and CEO of Mayo Clinic, says the initiative will enable transformation by blurring the lines across hospital, clinic, and digital care to help teams anticipate patients' needs, accelerate more cures, and greater connections to patients.

title: Philips CEO Roy Jakobs co-chairs US National Academy of Medicine's Steering Committee on AI Code of Conduct
summary: Philips CEO Roy Jakobs is co-chairing the US National Academy of Medicine's Steering Committee on AI Code of Conduct with Gianrico Farrugia, M.D., President and CEO of Mayo Clinic, and Bakul Patel, Senior Director of Global Digital Health Strategy & Regulatory at Google. The National Academy of Medicine is working on a three-year project to create a framework for responsible advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) and its applications in health, healthcare, and biomedical science. The AI Code of Conduct (AICC) project aims to ensure that AI algorithms and their applications in health, healthcare, and biomedical science perform accurately, safely, reliably, and ethically to improve health for all. The AICC Steering Committee has committed to a multi-year tenure with its first publication due in early 2024.

title: Mayo Clinic Platform Expands Distributed Data Network, Partnerships
summary: Mayo Clinic Platform has expanded its distributed data network, Mayo Clinic Platform_Connect, through new global partnerships with Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil, Sheba Medical Center in Israel, and University Health Network (UHN) in Canada to advance artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare. The alliance will focus initially on information collaboration and algorithm development, validation, and deployment, which will support the analysis of disease treatment and prevention patterns to promote proactive and predictive medicine. Gianrico Farrugia, MD, president and CEO of Mayo Clinic, said that the clinic is not doing this work alone and created Mayo Clinic Platform_Connect to enable innovative organizations to join them to create a healthier, more equitable future for everybody. The partnership aims to advance ethical health AI as part of a larger effort to transform patient care and improve outcomes.

title: Israel's Sheba Medical Center becomes part of Mayo Clinic's global alliance
summary: Israel's Sheba Medical Center has joined Mayo Clinic's Platform Connect, a global alliance that seeks to improve healthcare outcomes by using new technologies. The platform, developed by Mayo Clinic in the US, aims to create a data-sharing network to improve AI-based solutions for patient health worldwide. The alliance will enable the sharing of de-identified clinical data across three continents to generate models to identify diseases earlier and identify the best treatment options. The other two hospitals integrated into the Mayo Clinic Platform’s global alliance are the Hospital Israelita Albert Einstein in Brazil and the University Health Network in Canada. Director of Transformation and Innovation at the Sheba Medical Center, Prof. Eyal Zimlichman, expressed excitement about the new venture, which is intended to improve patient health outcomes by accelerating the development of innovative and effective treatments.

title: Richard Bold, M.D., named site director, Mayo Clinic Comprehensive Cancer Center in Arizona
summary: Richard Bold, M.D. has been appointed as the site director of Mayo Clinic Comprehensive Cancer Center in Arizona. Dr. Bold has an impressive career marked by excellence in patient care, innovative research, and dynamic leadership. He has served in various positions such as associate clinical strategy officer, UC Davis Health; physician in chief, UC Davis Comprehensive Cancer Center; executive vice chair, Department of Surgery; professor, Division of Surgical Oncology; medical director, UC Davis Cancer Care Network; and the Isabelle J. McDonald Endowed Professor of Cancer Research at the University of California, Davis. Dr. Bold's passion for bringing leading expertise to each patient with research and education that deliver innovation aligns seamlessly with Mayo Clinic's mission and values, making him an ideal fit for this role. He will begin his new role on Oct. 2 and will succeed Alan Bryce, M.D., prior chair of the Division of Hematology/Oncology and interim site director of Mayo Clinic Comprehensive Cancer Center in Arizona.

title: EBCTCG Meta-analysis Confirms Benefit of Ovarian Ablation or Suppression in Preventing Breast Cancer Recurrence
summary: A meta-analysis of randomized trials has confirmed that ovarian ablation or suppression can prevent breast cancer recurrence in premenopausal women with estrogen receptor-positive tumors. The study analyzed patient-level data from 23 randomized trials involving 14,999 women younger than 55 years who were premenopausal when randomly assigned to ovarian ablation or suppression or to no ovarian ablation or suppression. The findings showed a significant and persistent benefit from ovarian suppression and from ovarian ablation for premenopausal women with estrogen receptor-positive tumors. The benefit grew larger over time, with the absolute difference increasing from approximately 6% at 5 years to 8% at 10 years and to 10% at 15 years. The study also found that ovarian ablation or suppression was associated with significant reductions in breast cancer–related mortality and all-cause mortality, with no increase in deaths without recurrence.

title: Mayo Clinic contributes $2 million to Arizona nonprofit organizations
summary: Mayo Clinic has pledged to donate $2 million to three Arizona non-profit organizations working to meet the needs of underserved vulnerable populations. Circle the City, Adelante Healthcare, and The Society of St. Vincent de Paul will each receive a portion of the donation. Circle the City will receive $1 million to build its third respite center in the East Valley, Adelante Healthcare will receive $500,000, and The Society of St. Vincent de Paul will receive $400,000. The remaining $100,000 will go to various non-profit organizations and Title 1 schools to assist in meeting critical health and educational needs in the community. Richard J. Gray, M.D., CEO of Mayo Clinic in Arizona, stated that their goal is to touch more than half of the world's population by 2030.

title: Multiverse of Medicine
summary: Hospital medicine provides a wide range of career opportunities for hospitalists, including hospital leadership, quality improvement and research, education, and primary clinical care. Hospitalists are well-suited for leadership roles such as division chief, department chair, information technology director, utilization management director, vice president of medical affairs, and chief of staff or chief medical officer. Quality improvement and research are also important aspects of hospital medicine, as hospitalists are exposed to system-based errors that impact clinical care and can help navigate barriers in order-set creation, protocol development, and care-change implementation. Education is another career pathway for hospitalists, with opportunities to become a skilled physician-educator. Lastly, primary clinical care remains an important aspect of hospital medicine, with hospitalists serving as the backbone of direct inpatient care throughout the U.S. Early-career hospitalists should consider initial opportunities and faculty development in different domains to see what sparks their passion and brings them the most joy.

title: Mayo Clinic in Florida opens downtown Jacksonville site focused on education, research
summary: Mayo Clinic in Florida has opened a Community Health Collaborative in downtown Jacksonville, which aims to understand the healthcare needs of Mayo Clinic's neighbors and share health education and biomedical research that supports their needs. The site is nearly 3,100 square feet of office space and dedicated areas for community health education, clinical trial participation, outreach and more. Mayo Clinic will not provide medical care at this location. Mayo Clinic CEO in Florida, Kent Thielen, M.D. said, "Expanding Mayo Clinic’s footprint into downtown Jacksonville with a dedicated space for community engagement and Mayo Clinic research teams, allows us to fully explore innovative solutions that address the communities' most pressing health issues." The Community Health Collaborative will offer several programs, including Mayo Clinic Community Engagement Studios, Mayo Clinic Community Research Registry, Community Scientist Program, and Community-Engaged Research Advisory Boards.

title: Phoenix Mayo Clinic donates $2 million to Arizona nonprofits
summary: Mayo Clinic has donated $2 million to Arizona nonprofits, including Circle the City, Adelante Healthcare, and The Society of St. Vincent de Paul, to address issues such as homelessness, access to healthcare, education, and food insecurity. Circle the City will receive $1 million to build its third respite center in the East Valley, while Adelante Healthcare will receive $500,000 to provide care to uninsured and underinsured patients. The Society of St. Vincent de Paul will receive $400,000 to feed, clothe, house, and heal individuals and families experiencing homelessness. Roshanak Didehban, Mayo Clinic in Arizona chief administrative officer, was present at the donation event. Mayo Clinic is contributing $22 million to organizations in Arizona, Minnesota, and Florida to help meet the needs of underserved vulnerable populations.

title: Mayo Clinic contributes $2 million to Arizona nonprofit organizations committed to helping humanity
summary: Mayo Clinic is donating $2 million to Arizona nonprofit organizations that help underserved vulnerable populations, including Circle the City, Adelante Healthcare, and The Society of St. Vincent de Paul. The clinic is contributing $22 million in total to organizations in Arizona, Minnesota, and Florida. Mayo Clinic's CEO in Arizona, Dr. Richard Gray, stated that the clinic aims to touch over half the world's population by 2030, including patients they don't directly interact with. Phoenix Mayor Kate Gallego said that Mayo's award is a huge win for Phoenix in helping to heal homelessness. Circle the City's CEO, Kim Despres, expressed gratitude for Mayo Clinic's support, which will help provide healing and hope to patients experiencing homelessness. Adelante Healthcare's CEO, Pedro Cons, also expressed gratitude, stating that the donation will have an incredible impact on helping to close gaps in providing healthcare. The remaining $100,000 will go to five other non-profit organizations and Title 1 schools to assist in meeting important health and educational needs in the community. Roshanak Didehban, Mayo Clinic in Arizona's chief administrative officer, was present at the donation ceremony.

title: Ritter Helps Patient Get Back in Motion
summary: James Price, a resident of Mill Spring, Mo., experienced extreme pain for several years due to a hole in his femur and tibia caused by walking bone-on-bone. Seeking care from R. August Ritter III, MD, an orthopedic surgeon at the Saint Francis Orthopedic Institute, Price lost weight over six months to optimize his surgery results and underwent surgery on July 27. After just four weeks, he was able to walk normally without the use of a walker or cane and is back to doing activities he enjoys without pain. Price praises Ritter for his professional, courteous, and encouraging manner and for leading him to a successful solution. The team of experts at the Saint Francis Orthopedic Institute creates personalized treatment plans that include patients' input every step of the way.

title: Q&A with Geisinger CEO and President Dr. Jaewon Ryu, who will be CEO of the new Risant Health
summary: Dr. Jaewon Ryu, CEO and president of Geisinger Health, is set to become the CEO of the newly formed nonprofit organization Risant Health, created by Kaiser Foundation Hospitals. In an interview with Healthcare Finance News, Dr. Ryu expressed that being a part of Risant Health will help Geisinger achieve its goal of providing better health services to the communities they serve. He also mentioned that Geisinger will benefit from investments in digital platforms, provider enablement tools, data/analytics, insights, and patient and member engagement tools. Dr. Ryu confirmed that Geisinger will continue to work with other health plans, health systems, and independent providers, and that its name, mission, and community engagement will remain unchanged. Being a part of Risant Health will allow Geisinger to access the capital needed to accelerate its charitable mission and strategy.

title: 2023 Most Influential in Healthcare Dr. Jaewon Ryu
summary: Dr. Jaewon Ryu has been the President and CEO of Geisinger since 2018. He is expected to become the CEO of Risant Health, a non-profit organization created with Kaiser Foundation Hospitals that aims to acquire Geisinger in 2024. The plan is to acquire five or six other health systems over the next five years to establish a national network for value-based care. Under his leadership, Geisinger has improved operational efficiency and increased primary care for seniors, resulting in a decrease in inpatient admissions and emergency department visits. Ryu has also been a strong advocate for the use of digital tools, including an AI algorithm that targets high-risk patients for health screenings. Prior to his role at Geisinger, Ryu served as president of integrated care delivery at Humana, a corporate healthcare attorney at McDermott, Will & Emery, a White House Fellow at the Department of Veterans Affairs, and an emergency medicine physician at Kaiser Permanente. Ryu currently serves on the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission.

title: Geisinger names new president and future CEO | News | thetimes-tribune.com
summary: Geisinger Health's board of directors has appointed Dr. Terry Gilliland as president of the system. He has been selected to succeed Dr. Jaewon Ryu as chief executive officer when Ryu becomes CEO of Risant Health. Gilliland will become the eighth CEO in Geisinger's 109-year history when he replaces Ryu in that role. Prior to joining Geisinger, Gilliland served as chief medical officer and chief science officer at Cogitativo, a health care-focused artificial intelligence and machine learning company. Before that, he served as executive vice president of health care quality and affordability at Blue Shield of California and senior vice president and chief medical officer of Sentara Healthcare, among other experience. Ryu's contribution to Geisinger was not discussed in the article.

title: Risant Health completes acquisition of Geisinger
summary: Risant Health has completed its acquisition of Geisinger, which is the first health system focused on increasing access to value-based care and coverage. The goal of the organizations is to develop a new value-based care platform that includes best practices, tools, technology, and services to support leading community-based health systems. The acquisition brings together Kaiser Permanente's integrated care and coverage expertise and Geisinger's experience in advancing value-based care in a model that includes various payers and a broad network of providers. Jaewon Ryu, who has been Geisinger's president and CEO since 2019, will become the first CEO of Risant Health. Risant Health plans to acquire 4 to 5 additional leading community-based health systems over the next 4 to 5 years. Risant Health's value-based platform will provide its health systems with a set of technology, services, and capabilities designed to deliver superior health outcomes and a lower total cost of care in diverse business models.

title: Terry Gilliland named future chief executive officer
summary: Geisinger Health has appointed Terry Gilliland as their new President and upcoming CEO to take over from Jaewon Ryu when he becomes CEO of Risant Health. Dr. Gilliland is currently the Chief Medical Officer and Chief Science Officer at Cogitativo, a company that focuses on healthcare-related artificial intelligence and machine learning. He has extensive experience and has held senior roles in several large healthcare delivery and payer organizations. Dr. Gilliland received his Bachelor of Science in Biology from Stanford University, his Doctor of Medicine from the University of California, Los Angeles, and his Master of Science in Management from the Stanford Graduate School of Business. Geisinger is a non-profit system that generates $10 billion in annual revenues across 134 care sites, including 10 hospital campuses, and Geisinger Health Plan, with 600,000 members in commercial and government plans.

title: Kaiser Permanente's Risant Health closes Geisinger acquisition - Washington Business Journal
summary: Kaiser Permanente's nonprofit Risant Health has successfully bought Geisinger Health, and Dr. Jaewon Ryu, the former CEO of Geisinger, is now the CEO of Risant. This acquisition is the first of many planned acquisitions by Risant, which seeks to establish a technology platform for nonprofit health systems that operate under value-based care models. Risant plans to invest at least $2 billion in Geisinger until 2028, while Kaiser has committed a maximum of $5 billion to support Risant's growth. This acquisition will provide Geisinger with access to funding, technology, and resources to improve their facilities and invest in patient care. The transaction was structured as a member substitution.

title: UPDATE Risant's acquisition of Geisinger complete after regulatory approval
summary: Risant Health has completed its acquisition of Geisinger, with Dr. Jaewon Ryu becoming the first CEO of Risant Health. Dr. Terry Gilliland will assume the role of president and CEO of Geisinger once Ryu’s transition to Risant Health is complete. The acquisition was reviewed and approved by the appropriate federal and state agencies. Risant Health plans to add four to five more health systems to the Risant umbrella over the next four to five years. The goal is to expand and accelerate the adoption of “value-based care in diverse, multipayer, multiprovider, community-based health system environments and improve the health of millions of people in communities across the country.” Geisinger will maintain its name and mission, continue accepting patients covered by other health plans, and continue offering its members a broad network of care providers in addition to Geisinger.

title: Nominations Due March 13 for Julie Byerley Award for Faculty Excellence in Interprofessional Education and Practice ...
summary: The Dr. Julie Byerley Award for Faculty Excellence in Interprofessional Education and Practice is currently accepting nominations until March 13. This award recognizes faculty members who have made significant contributions to the advancement of interprofessional education and practice by creating intentional opportunities for students to learn from, with, and about each other to improve health outcomes. The winner of this award will receive a monetary prize of $2,500 and their name will be inscribed on a plaque in the Office of Interprofessional Education and Practice Collaboration Hub. Any full-time faculty member affiliated with a school or department in the Office of IPEP network whose contributions meet the WHO definition for Interprofessional Education or Interprofessional Collaborative Practice is eligible. All UNC-CH faculty, staff, and students are eligible to nominate their faculty, colleagues, and collaborators for this award. Dr. Julie Byerley established the interprofessional education and practice committee that would ultimately become the foundational framework for the Office of Interprofessional Education and Practice.

title: Geisinger's Plan to Boost Quality and Patient Experiences Through Virtual Nursing
summary: Geisinger's virtual nursing program aims to address workforce shortages and improve care quality, employee engagement, and patient experiences. The program provides new opportunities for nurses to have more flexibility, and for hospitals to use their staff more efficiently. Janet Tomcavage, executive vice president and chief nurse executive at Geisinger, outlined the goals of their virtual nursing model, including creating a new role for nurses to consider, especially later in their career, enhancing quality, mentoring new graduate nurses, and improving patient education. The response to the virtual nursing program has been overwhelmingly positive, with patients enthusiastic about the one-on-one time with nurses that's uninterrupted. The HealthLeaders Virtual Nursing Mastermind series features ideas, solutions, and insights on excelling virtual nursing programs. Geisinger is one of many health systems to embark on the virtual nursing journey, and according to Tomcavage, they are most excited to be fully leveraging technology for the first time as a way to support care.

title: COVID-19 Vaccine Safety with Eric G. Neilson, MD, and Robert Murphy, MD
hco: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY FEINBERG SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
summary: Eric G. Neilson, MD, and Robert Murphy, MD discussed COVID-19 vaccine safety and effectiveness in a podcast episode. They addressed concerns about rare side effects, including allergic reactions, and emphasized the importance of getting vaccinated to protect individuals and communities. They also discussed details about the three vaccines that have emergency use authorization, possible booster shots, and when to get vaccinated if you have recently contracted COVID-19. Other topics covered include CDC's new guidelines on masking for vaccinated people, vaccine safety during pregnancy, and possible reactions to the vaccines. They also addressed concerns about the vaccines from people who have a family history of auto-immune diseases and discussed religious and medical exemptions from COVID-19 vaccines.

title: New medical facility aimed at moms-to-be coming to Prince George’s Co.
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: A new medical facility focused on women's health is going to be built in Lanham, Maryland. The Luminis Health Pavilion, costing $300 million, will provide pre- and postnatal care and aims to increase the number of annual labor and delivery services in Prince George's County. Currently, 80% of mothers who live in the county give birth outside of the county, and the maternal death rate is high, especially for Black non-Hispanic mothers. Deneen Richmond, the president of Luminis Health Doctors Community Medical Center, hopes that the new facility will empower women to make positive changes for their own health. The Maryland Health Commission has approved the plan for the facility, and infrastructure work is scheduled to begin in early 2024. However, the entire facility is not expected to be completed until 2028.

title: Getting personal: Maryland colon cancer survivor wants to flush away stigma
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Deneen Richmond, a survivor of colon cancer, is striving to eliminate the negative perception surrounding colorectal cancer and motivate more individuals to undergo screening. She initiated colonoscopies at the age of 50 and perceived symptoms in between screenings, including blood in her stool and fatigue. Following a colonoscopy, she received a diagnosis of rectal cancer and received treatment for a year. Richmond is currently free of cancer and promoting the importance of screening, particularly since Black and African Americans are at a higher risk of developing colorectal cancer. She is also tackling the inequalities in access to screenings and treatment, collaborating with Luminis Health and Maryland’s Cancer Prevention, Education, Screening, and Treatment (CPEST) program to provide screenings for uninsured or underinsured residents of Prince George’s County.

title: Hospital President Deneen Richmond Offers Insights on Health Care
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Hospital President Deneen Richmond is leading a strategic plan called "Vision 2030" to reduce infant and maternal mortality. She is currently serving as president at Luminis Health Doctors Community Medical Center and is planning to expand the campus to better serve the residents of Prince George's County. Richmond has made it a priority to recruit staff from historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), and 70% of her staff are county residents. She has also revised procurement policies to favor local businesses. Luminis Health is currently raising $300 million from government and private sources to renovate and upgrade their nearly 50-year-old Lanham health center, which will include the addition of a Women's Health Center. This new center will provide inpatient obstetrics services, labor and delivery, and postpartum care. According to Richmond, the maternal mortality rate for Black women in Prince George's County is 50% higher than the national average, and eight out of 10 women residents give birth outside the county. Richmond's team has implemented measures to reduce health disparities and improve health services, including reducing cesarean sections, providing free mammograms, conducting mobile health screenings, and operating multiple state-run and community organized COVID testing and vaccine sites.

title: Prince George's Goes Pink for Breast Cancer Awareness
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Prince George's County in Maryland is promoting breast cancer awareness by partnering with local healthcare providers. The county executive's office has organized a month-long program throughout the county to offer information and encourage wellness to minimize the risks of breast cancer. Luminis Health Doctors Community Center provided free mammograms and clinical breast screenings during their event on October 6th, and the hospital received a $1.3 million state grant to provide breast cancer screenings to women in Prince George's County for three years. Deneen Richmond, the hospital president, stressed the importance of mammograms as the best early detection method. The Health Empowerment Network of Maryland is also working to ensure that telehealth options remain available for Marylanders. Their primary services include providing digital in-home or in-vehicle support, connecting patients with their primary care physician or specialist, assisting patients in completing online applications for services and resources, and connecting patients to care coordination companies.

title: Luminis Health paying $2M federal fine to settle predecessor's alleged violations of False Claims Act - Washington ...
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Luminis Health has agreed to pay $2 million to settle a billing issue that occurred before its acquisition of Prince George's County hospital. Luminis Health Doctors Community Medical Center and Diagnostic Imaging Associates have settled allegations of violating the False Claims Act. From March 2010 to October 2020, DIA billed Medicare and Medicaid and paid a portion of the fees to the hospital, but the center was not eligible for reimbursement as it was not enrolled in those programs. Luminis Health has initiated a comprehensive review of all operations following the acquisition. Deneen Richmond, the president of Luminis Health, is leading a $300 million fundraising campaign to renovate its Lanham hospital and build a new women's health tower for obstetrics services, labor and delivery, and postpartum care.

title: Luminis Health's hospital in Prince George's County plans new women's health expansion - Washington Business ...
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Luminis Health is planning to expand its women's health services at its Prince George's County hospital. It plans to establish a women's health hub with a new four-story tower on its Lanham campus. This hub will house a dedicated center for inpatient obstetrics services, labor and delivery, and postpartum care. Deneen Richmond, president of Luminis Health Doctors Community Medical Center, said that the organization filed a letter of intent earlier this month with the Maryland Health Care Commission. They will submit their certificate of need application in April. Luminis is also developing site improvement plans to improve traffic flow on its campus and to upgrade utility infrastructure for water, electric, and wastewater systems. They are asking the state for $30 million in capital funding from its fiscal 2024 budget to support the project. The hospital expects to add more than 100 full-time employees, including doctors, nurses, technicians, social workers, and support staff, to stand up the new hub.

title: Prince George's County has a women's health disparity gap, officials are working to fix it
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Prince George's County in Maryland is facing health disparities, especially among Black women. The county has a maternal mortality rate 50% above the national average and 40% above Maryland's average. Only 55% of women in the county receive prenatal care, 25% below the national average and 12% below Maryland's average. To address this, Luminis Health is embarking on a $300 million campaign to renovate its campus at Luminis Health Doctors Community Center in Lanham, which includes building a women's health center. The county is working with Luminis to secure $6 million in funding to support its construction. Deneen Richmond, the president of the Health Doctors Community Center, stated that the new facility will be a four-story building, with two floors dedicated to labor and delivery and providing postpartum care, and the other floors designed to modernize surgical suites and create better design and sizing for support services.

title: 2024: The Year We Strengthen Our Healthcare Tech Foundations
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Saad Chaudhry, a healthcare tech executive, predicts that 2024 will be the year when healthcare technology strengthens its foundations. The COVID-19 pandemic caused healthcare organizations to prioritize innovation and ignore standards, policies, and price tags to keep their doors open. However, this caused heartburn across the industry and highlighted the need to strengthen the foundational tech landscape. Chaudhry believes that healthcare technology will become more cohesive and streamlined, with a renewed focus on optimizing the electronic health record, networking architecture, and cybersecurity programs. He also predicts a focus on streamlining telehealth and patient engagement to meet the expectations of Gen-Z and Millennial populations. Chaudhry believes that technology has come a long way since 2020, and the maturity of organizations and tech-literacy of c-suites have increased, making it necessary to strengthen foundational tech landscapes.

title: Healthcare IT Leaders on Diversity, Equity and Inclusion in the Workforce
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: Saad Chaudhry, the Chief Digital and Information Officer at Luminis Health, is one of the healthcare IT leaders who are working to ensure diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in their organizations. Chaudhry and other leaders discussed DEI initiatives in healthcare IT, including the need to reduce inequities within organizations, supported by training in diversity, equity, and inclusion, with initiatives targeting clinical and nonclinical departments. They also shared specific diversity-related initiatives within their organizations, such as investing in an entire women and children's wing to serve diverse populations and building mentorship portals that connect underrepresented minority medical students with mentors. The leaders also emphasized the importance of having a diverse workforce that reflects the diversity of the community they serve.

title: Is Healthcare At The End Of Its Middle Age?
hco: LUMINIS HEALTH ANNE ARUNDEL MEDICAL CENTER
summary: The healthcare industry is facing significant challenges, with traditional providers struggling to adapt to the post-pandemic world. Costs have risen dramatically, while payments from payers have not, and patient expectations have shifted. The aging population is expected to reach close to 20% of the US population by 2030, accelerating the transformation of care beyond the confines of acute-care inpatient hospitals. This transformation will be digital in nature, relying heavily on technology to augment the workforce and change the way work gets done. Non-traditional entrants, such as Walmart Health and Dollar General, are beginning to capitalize on their retail footprint to roll out primary and urgent care centers, while established healthcare giants are scaling up. AI is also playing an increasingly important role in healthcare. Saad Chaudhry, an executive with 20+ years of experience in healthcare tech, suggests that the industry is at the end of its middle age and poised for a renaissance.

title: Appelbaum - Frederick R. Appelbaum, MD
summary: Fred Appelbaum is a medical oncologist who specializes in treating acute myeloid leukemia and other blood cancers. He led the first successful use of autologous bone marrow transplantation, which is now used in over 30,000 patients annually. He was also involved in the development of Mylotarg™, the first FDA-approved antibody-drug conjugate for acute myeloid leukemia. His current research focuses on improving stem cell transplant procedures and developing non-transplant treatments for blood cancers. Along with patient care and clinical trials, he is also the executive vice president and deputy director of Fred Hutch.

title: How 'Living Medicine' Came to Be: Fred Appelbaum on The Long Run - TimmermanReport.com
summary: Fred Appelbaum, an executive vice president at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center in Seattle, is the author of a new book called "Living Medicine: Don Thomas, Marrow Transplantation and the Cell Therapy Revolution". He is a physician, scientist, and administrator who has spent his career conducting research and treating patients with leukemias, lymphomas, and other blood cancers. Appelbaum was influenced by E. Donnall Thomas, who won the Nobel Prize in 1990 for the discoveries that paved the way for bone marrow transplantation to become a common and lifesaving procedure for people with blood malignancies. In this conversation, Fred discusses the book, the researching and writing, and a few things he learned.

title: Living Medicine Book Review for Myeloma Patients
summary: Dr. Fred Appelbaum's book, Living Medicine, has been reviewed in this article. The book tells the story of Dr. Don Thomas, who was a pioneer in bone marrow transplantation and his mission to cure leukemias through bone marrow transplantation. The sacrifices made by patients and their families and the dedication of Dr. Thomas and his team to find a cure are highlighted in the book. The book also covers many scientific discoveries in the field, such as the use of umbilical cords in marrow donations and immunotherapy breakthroughs. The author of the article is impressed by the desire of parents to save their child and contribute to a better future for other families. Dr. Appelbaum will be speaking at the HealthTree 2.0 Launch on October 23rd, where he will discuss how to create educated, connected communities that actively participate in a cure for blood cancers.

title: Author Fred Appelbaum, M.D., talks about his new book and the 'extraordinary' potential of marrow transplantation
summary: Author Fred Appelbaum, M.D., discusses his new book, "Living Medicine," which provides a detailed history and potential of marrow transplantation. Appelbaum worked with Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, the father of bone marrow transplantation, and shares insights into the procedure's three key principles: it can cure virtually every marrow-based disease, the transplanted immune system sees the leukemia as foreign and rejects it, and lifelong immunosuppression is not required after marrow transplantation. He also discusses the potential for using genetically engineered immune cells to attack cancer and the possibility of transplanting marrow simultaneously with solid organs to avoid the need for lifelong immunosuppression. Appelbaum hopes readers take away the message that, despite the complexity of human biology and disease, persistence and teamwork can lead to extraordinary advances in patient care.

title: Dr. Fred Appelbaum receives Lifetime Achievement award
summary: Dr. Fred Appelbaum, an oncologist and executive vice president of Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, has been honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy. Appelbaum played a key role in developing bone marrow transplantation as a successful treatment for leukemia, with more than 1.5 million patients worldwide having undergone the procedure. He has also helped to improve the safety and success of transplantation for a variety of blood cancers and disorders. Appelbaum has been part of the Fred Hutch leadership team, and helped to expand the scope of research and treatment there to cover the full range of cancers. He has also played a key role in the development of cellular therapies, such as CAR-T and adoptive T-cell therapies, which are raising tantalizing prospects for cures.

title: Living Medicine
summary: Living Medicine is a biography and memoir written by Fred Appelbaum, M.D. The book recounts the story of Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, who was the mastermind behind bone marrow transplantation, and the diseases that were cured by his discovery. Thomas's concept of using radiation to eliminate abnormal bone marrow and substituting it with healthy marrow was initially met with skepticism by the scientific community, but he persisted. After two decades of widespread discouragement and failure, he ultimately succeeded in curing patients who were otherwise incurable. His accomplishments earned him a Nobel Prize, and the treatments he inspired have transformed and will continue to transform the field of clinical medicine. Appelbaum, who was a member of Thomas's research team, reveals the secrets to Thomas's success, his unique traits, how he built an effective team of researchers, and how he overcame the technical challenges of marrow transplantation. The earnings from the book are invested in advancing medical research and education at Mayo Clinic.

title: ASTCT to Present Distinguished Honors at the 2023 Tandem Meetings
summary: The American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy (ASTCT) will present top awards to leaders in the field of transplantation and cellular therapy at the Tandem Meetings in Orlando, Florida. Fred Appelbaum, MD will receive the 2023 ASTCT Lifetime Achievement Award for his contribution to the development of transformative therapies for leukemia, lymphoma, and other blood cancers. Leslie Kean, MD, PhD will deliver the E. Donnall Thomas Lecture on Targeting GVHD: From the Bench, to the Bedside, to the FDA. The lecture is a special honor given to an individual who has contributed meritoriously to the advancement of knowledge in blood and marrow transplantation.
