Ukrainian medical professionals will receive the 2022 ASTCT Public Service Award for their dedication and resilience in providing top quality care in the midst of active war. Professor Sergiy Klymenko, MD, PhD and Sybiryna Korenkova, MD will accept this award on behalf of all Ukrainian medical professionals.

title: How George Santos and Al Owens’s early Cytoxan studies led to standard-of-care therapy in BMT
summary: George Santos, the founder of the Johns Hopkins University Bone Marrow Transplantation Program, made significant innovations in bone marrow transplantation that are still relevant today. Along with Albert H. Owens, Santos conducted mouse studies in the 1960s using Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) and found that it was the best drug for both facilitating the transplant and preventing graft-versus-host disease. Researchers at Hopkins continued the work with cyclophosphamide that began with Santos and Owens. The use of post-transplant cyclophosphamide, also known as PTcy, proved to be more effective than the standard of care treatment of calcineurin inhibitor plus methotrexate in patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation. Fred Appelbaum, the executive vice president, professor in the Clinical Research Division, and Metcalfe Family/Frederick Appelbaum Endowed Chair in Cancer Research at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, presented an overview of E. Donnall Thomas’s contributions to the field of Bone Marrow Transplantation. Santos was responsible for many of the firsts in the field of bone marrow transplantation.

title: 'Sobering' finding: Breast cancer's return many years post-treatment - UW Medicine | Newsroom
summary: A recent study published in the New England Journal of Medicine discovered that around 18% of 62,000 women who had successfully been treated for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer experienced a recurrence or spread of the disease up to 20 years later. Dr. Nancy Davidson, who heads the division of medical oncology at the University of Washington School of Medicine, has been part of the research group that reported these findings for a long time. The study indicates that despite the availability of effective endocrine therapy, many women are still at risk of recurrence much later on. This leads to several possibilities, including whether we should extend our endocrine therapy, which is currently being explored. For many women, it is recommended that they either continue taking tamoxifen or switch to an aromatase inhibitor for a total of 10 years.

title: Keep Your Cool While Cheering For Your Kid
summary: The National Alliance for Youth Sports discovered that almost 7 out of 10 kids quit participating in organized sports before the age of 13, and negative parental behavior is a significant factor. The improper conduct of parents in youth sports is based on the sin of idolatry. Christian parents should avoid idolizing their children or their athletic accomplishments. Instead, it's crucial to acknowledge and appreciate children's achievements as a reflection of both God's generosity and their own hard work and dedication. Ryan Leib, the director of Briarwood Soccer Club in Birmingham, Alabama, and Darin White, the founder of the Center for Sports Analytics at Samford University, offer practical advice to assist parents in remaining calm while cheering for their children. They suggest showing gratitude to coaches, focusing on the process rather than the outcome, cheering with elegance, preparing oneself spiritually, remembering what's at stake, and shining like stars.

title: Denene Prophet-Williams named vice president and chief nursing officer at Fred Hutch
summary: Denene Prophet-Williams has been appointed as the Vice President and Chief Nursing Officer at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center. She is an experienced healthcare executive with a 30-year nursing career. Prophet-Williams will lead the nursing staff to provide patient-focused and quality-centered care while supporting the staff. She has previously held leadership positions at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Prophet-Williams has been recognized for her outstanding achievements, including awards for leadership excellence and patient satisfaction. She is actively involved in professional organizations such as the American Nurses Association and the American Organization of Nurse Executives. Additionally, she volunteers her time in various community initiatives.

title: About Public Health Sciences
summary: The Public Health Sciences (PHS) division at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center was founded in 1975 and became a division in 1983. PHS serves as a central location for many national data and clinical coordination centers, and is also the home of the Genetics and Colorectal Cancer Consortium. Dr. Garnet Anderson is the director of PHS and provides scientific leadership for the division. Collaboration is a fundamental aspect of the research conducted at the PHS division, and groups like the Integrated Research Centers and the Seattle Tumor Translational Research encourage collaboration at a structural level. The PHS division focuses on a variety of research areas, including behavioral research, biostatistics, cell and gene therapy, diagnostics and biomarkers, disease prevention, epidemiology, gene regulation and expression, genetics and genomics, global health, health economics, hematopoietic transplantation, immunotherapy, infectious diseases, microbiome, survivorship, vaccine development, and virology.

title: New study of Asian, Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander populations gets $38.7M grant
summary: The Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center has been awarded a $38.7 million grant from the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute (NHLBI) to coordinate a large new national collaboration that will focus exclusively on the health issues of Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians, and Pacific Islanders. The study will include five research institutions, which will gather a pool of 10,000+ study participants, with Fred Hutch serving as the project’s coordinating center. The new study will look at risk factors that drive cardiovascular disease, metabolic disorders, mental health issues, and other conditions, collecting biospecimens like blood, urine, and microbiome samples to answer these questions and create a biorepository for future studies. They’ll also look at the social determinants of health to see how these elements have impacted populations over the years. Garnet Anderson, director of Fred Hutch’s Public Health Sciences Division, is one of the principal investigators for the new coordinating center.

title: How AI is changing the way scientists engineer drugs, biosensors, enzymes and more
summary: AI tools, including RF Diffusion, are changing the way scientists create proteins for use in therapeutics, industrial enzymes, biosensors, materials, and more. Seattle-based companies, many of which are spinouts of the University of Washington’s Institute for Protein Design (IPD), are leading the way. Although protein design is still in its early stages, the potential market is huge. Last year, protein-based therapeutics accounted for one-third of drug approvals. The same rapid AI advances that power generative AI tools like OpenAI’s DALL-E and ChatGPT are also driving changes in how scientists engineer proteins. Sue Biggins, head of the Basic Sciences Division at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, called AlphaFold “game-changing.” These innovations are driving investment, with IPD spinouts raising over $1 billion in total and forming partnerships with biopharma companies like Bristol Myers Squibb and Gilead Sciences.

title: Untangling the kinetochore
summary: Changkun Hu, who is a postdoctoral fellow working under Basic Sciences Division Director Sue Biggins at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, has been selected as a 2023 Jane Coffin Childs – HHMI Fellow by the Jane Coffin Childs Memorial Fund for Medical Research. Hu will receive support from the JCC Fund to gain a better understanding of how kinetochore components assemble to form a functional kinetochore, and how this process is coordinated. The kinetochore is a complex molecular machine that prevents aneuploidy and ensures that chromosomes are properly separated and sorted. Hu has developed a new method using TIRF microscopy (total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy) to map the sequence in which kinetochore components come together. His description of kinetochore assembly will be a significant advancement in understanding how the process is regulated, and will aid scientists in identifying how it breaks down and leads to aneuploidy.

title: The interplay between intestinal microbiota and graft-versus-host disease
summary: The Hill Lab at Fred Hutch has conducted research on the interplay between intestinal microbiota and graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). GVHD is a serious complication that occurs when cells from a transplant donor attack healthy cells of the recipient, leading to poorer outcomes and high-risk health scenarios. The study found that genetically identical mice of differing vendor origins have dramatically different intestinal microbiota and ileal MHC-II expression, resulting in significantly discordant GVHD severity. The authors also established distinct microbiota composition in those patients who went on to develop severe GVHD post-transplant compared to those who did not. The study highlights the mechanisms by which pre-transplant microbiota control the development of GVHD independently of genetic disparity and define therapeutic strategies to prevent disease. The research was funded by various organizations and contributors, including Geoffrey Hill.

title: Dr. Sara Hurvitz joins Fred Hutch, University of Washington
summary: Dr. Sara Hurvitz has been appointed as the Senior Vice President of the Clinical Research Division at Fred Hutch and Head of the newly united Division of Hematology and Oncology at the University of Washington Department of Medicine. She is an internationally recognized expert in breast oncology and a leader in clinical and laboratory-based oncology research, with extensive experience in leading clinical trials across all phases. Her new role will commence on August 1, 2023. Her expertise aligns with Fred Hutch's focus on expanding its pipeline of clinical cancer research and clinical trial design, funding, launch, and enrollment. Hurvitz will also work to enhance the national reputation of the solid tumor clinical research program and oversee the continued growth of clinical research programs in stem cell transplantation and cell therapy, hematologic cancers, and nonmalignant hematology.

title: Zanidatamab Combo Appears 'Exciting' in HER2+/HR+ Metastatic Breast Cancer
summary: Zanidatamab, when combined with palbociclib and fulvestrant, has produced exceptional results with respect to progression-free survival (PFS) among pretreated patients with HER2-positive, hormone receptor (HR)–positive, metastatic breast cancer. This was according to Sara Hurvitz, MD, FACP, who presented findings from a phase 2a trial evaluating the zanidatamab-based regimen among those with HR-positive, HER2-positive disease. The combination yielded a median PFS of 12 months in the overall population, and 67% of patients were progression free at 6 months. Additionally, the confirmed objective response rate among those with centrally confirmed HER2-positive disease was 48%, which included complete responses in 10% and partial responses in 38%. Hurvitz also stated that the experimental combination yielded a positive safety profile. Overall, 67% of patients experienced grade 3/4 treatment-related adverse effects, which commonly included neutrophil count decreases or neutropenia, diarrhea, and anemia.

title: Unanswered Questions in the HER2+ Breast Cancer Space
summary: Sara A. Hurvitz, a medical oncologist and clinical research leader at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, discusses the unanswered questions in the HER2-positive breast cancer space. One of the questions is how to optimally treat patients who have brain metastases with HER2-positive breast cancer. Hurvitz emphasizes the importance of ongoing studies evaluating the optimal management of interstitial lung disease, which can be life-threatening. She also talks about the challenges of treating breast cancer like brain metastases and the need for more data regarding the use of trastuzumab deruxtecan in active brain metastases. Additionally, Hurvitz is interested in seeing more data regarding the use of ADCs and whether they are effective when sequenced 1 after the other if they're going after a similar target, and whether or not the payload matters in the development of cross-resistance to ADCs.

title: Dr Sara Hurvitz: Addition of Tucatinib to T-DM1 Improves Outcomes in HER2+ Metastatic Breast Cancer
summary: Dr. Sara Hurvitz, a professor at the University of Washington and senior vice president of the Clinical Research Division at Fred Hutch, has shared insights into the results of the HER2CLIMB-02 trial. The trial evaluated the use of tucatinib and trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) in previously treated patients with HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. The study aimed to evaluate whether adding tucatinib to T-DM1 improves outcomes for patients with HER2-positive advanced breast cancer. Approximately 460 patients were enrolled and randomized to receive either T-DM1 with tucatinib or T-DM1 with placebo. The primary end point was progression-free survival (PFS) by investigator assessment. The results showed a two-month improvement in median PFS by adding tucatinib to T-DM1, and it was statistically significant. The adverse event profile showed more transaminase elevations by adding tucatinib to T-DM1, and slightly higher rates of diarrhea and cytopenias.

title: The Future of HER2+ Breast Cancer Treatment
summary: Sara Hurvitz, MD, along with other panelists, discussed the recent advances and future hopes for the treatment of HER2+ breast cancer. The panelists expressed their excitement over the numerous drugs available for treatment and the potential for de-escalation in patients with stage 2 and 3 disease. They also discussed the importance of clinical trials, biomarkers, and advances in basic sciences in the field. The panelists emphasized the need to find the right therapy for each patient and the possibility of preventing metastases from occurring. The discussion ended with the hope that the advancements in HER2+ breast cancer treatment will continue in the future.

title: Adding Tucatinib to T-DM1 Shows PFS Benefit in HER2-Positive Breast Cancer
summary: The phase III HER2CLIMB-02 trial demonstrated that the extension of progression-free survival (PFS) was observed by adding tucatinib to trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) compared to T-DM1 alone for patients with unresectable locally advanced or metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer who had been previously treated, including a positive trend in those with brain metastases. The trial included around 460 patients, half of whom had active brain metastases. The addition of tucatinib to T-DM1 improved outcomes for patients, although evidence of overall survival is still awaited. Dr. Sara A. Hurvitz, the investigator of the study, discussed the results of the dual HER2-targeted approach. Adding tucatinib to T-DM1 does increase the rate of grade 3 or greater events and treatment discontinuations. However, these were reversible events with discontinuation or treatment holds.

title: HER2CLIMB-02: Primary Analysis of a Randomized, Double-blind Phase 3 Trial of Tucatinib and Trastuzumab ...
summary: The HER2CLIMB-02 study examined the use of tucatinib and trastuzumab emtansine in patients with HER2+ metastatic breast cancer who had been previously treated. The study found that adding tucatinib to T-DM1 significantly improved progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with previously treated HER2+ LA/MBC, including those with brain metastases. The median PFS was 9.5 months compared to 7.4 months without tucatinib (HR, 0.76; P=0.0163). The types of adverse events were consistent with those previously reported for tucatinib and T-DM1. The data from the phase 3 HER2CLIMB-02 study was presented by Sara A. Hurvitz, MD, at the 2023 San Antonio Breast Cancer Symposium. This study is the second randomized study to demonstrate that a tucatinib-containing regimen delays disease progression in HER2+ LA/MBC, including patients with brain metastases.

title: Ongoing Second-Line Trials in Patients with HER2+ mBC and Expert Clinical Perspective
summary: Sara Hurvitz, MD, and other experts talked about the ongoing trials of second-line tucatinib combination therapy for patients with HER2+ mBC, with or without brain metastases. They shared their clinical perspective on which second-line regimens they typically recommend for their patients. The panelists also discussed ongoing trials such as HER2CLIMB-02 and HER2CLIMB-05, which combine T-DM1 with tucatinib, and the DESTINY study with T-DXd and tucatinib. They also talked about using T-DXd and HER2CLIMB regimen as a second line of therapy for patients who only have brain progression. The field of HER2+ breast cancer treatment is constantly evolving with the use of more active drugs and ongoing trials. The panelists hope that these trials will delay or even treat CNS disease in patients with HER2+ mBC.

title: Treating Early-Stage Node-Negative Triple-Negative Breast Cancer
summary: The Oncology Brothers, Rahul Gosain, MD, and Rohit Gosain, MD, were joined by Ruth M. O'Regan, MD, and Anna Weiss, MD, to discuss the treatment of early-stage node-negative triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). They talked about the application of treatment algorithms in clinical practice and how to optimize outcomes in patients with HER2+ metastatic breast cancer. The discussion was part of a series of episodes on TNBC. Sara Hurvitz, MD, did not contribute to this particular discussion.

title: Key Updates in Metastatic HER2+ Breast Cancer
summary: Sara M. Tolaney, Chief of Breast Oncology at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, discussed recent advances in treating metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer. Two treatments, the antibody-drug conjugate trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) and the HER2-specific tyrosine kinase inhibitor tucatinib, have shown significant efficacy in advanced HER2-positive disease. These treatments also provide options for patients with previously poor prognosis metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer that penetrates the brain. The DESTINY-Breast03 trial showed that T-DXd tripled progression-free survival (PFS) and improved overall survival compared to trastuzumab emtansine (T-DM1) in previously treated HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer. The HER2CLIMB trial added tucatinib to capecitabine and trastuzumab, showing improvements in PFS and overall survival over capecitabine/trastuzumab alone, including in the 50% of patients with treated or active brain metastases. Tucatinib’s label allows second-line use, sparing some patients upfront brain radiation.

title: HER2+ mBC: Emerging Agents in the Third-Line and Higher Setting
summary: Sara Hurvitz, MD, discusses the latest developments in novel therapies for later-line treatment of HER2+ mBC. Debu Tripathy, MD, mentions new antibody-drug conjugates, such as zanidatamab, which has shown activity in phase 1 trials as a single agent, and trastuzumab duocarmazine, which showed an improvement in PFS. The study of dalpiciclib and pyrotinib, a CDK inhibitor with a TKI, also showed activity. CAR T-cell therapy with HER2 is also being investigated. Pyrotinib has been studied in Asia but has severe diarrhea as a side effect. New super HER2-specific TKIs are in early development.

title: Nanoparticle HIV vaccine shows potential in trial
summary: A Phase I trial for a self-assembling nanoparticle HIV vaccine has shown positive results in inducing a T-cell response in almost all participants, according to a study published in Science Translational Medicine. The vaccine was evaluated for safety and effectiveness in healthy adult volunteers without HIV, who were given two doses of the vaccine or a placebo eight weeks apart. The trial identified the T cell epitopes and found several broadly immunogenic epitopes that might be useful for developing boosters and for other vaccines. The study was funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Collaboration for AIDS Vaccine Discovery, IAVI Neutralizing Antibody Center, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and Ragon Institute of MGH, MIT and Harvard. Dr Julie McElrath, Senior Vice President and Director of Fred Hutch’s Vaccine and Infectious Disease Division, said the vaccine could induce the critical T-cell help needed for maturing antibodies towards the pathway of broadly neutralising against HIV.

title: A promising HIV vaccine candidate gets a little help
summary: Researchers at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center have discovered that a CD4 T lymphocyte, also known as a helper T cell, could be instrumental in creating an effective HIV/AIDS vaccine. The McElrath lab studied T-cell reactions to an experimental vaccine created by Scripps Research and found that the vaccine produced a "strong" response of CD4 cells, making up about 5 out of every 1,000 CD4 cells present in circulating blood. The germline approach relies on encouraging the immune system, through a series of gradual vaccinations, to produce broadly neutralizing antibodies that are much more difficult for the constantly mutating HIV to evade. The McElrath lab frequently conducts such research for the Fred Hutch-based HIV Vaccine Trials Network, the world's largest publicly funded collaboration to evaluate HIV/AIDS vaccines.

title: Many long COVID patients suffer from persistent inflammation, study finds
summary: Many long COVID patients suffer from persistent inflammation, according to a study by the Allen Institute and Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center. The scientists found a set of molecules associated with inflammation that were present only in a subset of patients with long COVID and were not seen in those who recovered from their disease. Out of 55 patients with long COVID, about two-thirds had persistently high levels of certain signals of inflammation. The researchers hope to narrow down their molecular signature of “inflammatory long COVID” to a few markers that could be used in the clinic to sort this subset of long COVID patients out from the rest. Julie McElrath, Senior Vice President and Director of Fred Hutch’s Vaccine and Infectious Disease Division, is leading the Seattle COVID Cohort Study, which includes the patient volunteers in the new analysis. The study highlights the need for targeted treatment strategies and shows diagnostic utility for differentiating inflammatory and non-inflammatory long COVID.

title: HIV nanoparticle vaccine induces strong T-cell responses in early-phase clinical trial
summary: An HIV nanoparticle vaccine has generated strong T-cell reactions in a clinical trial involving humans, as per a report published in Science Translational Medicine. The vaccine is a self-assembling, germline-targeting HIV nanoparticle that aims to prime a certain type of B cells that create precursors to broadly neutralizing antibodies that attack a protein on the virus's surface. The study also established a correlation between the vaccine and the induction of vaccine-specific peripheral CD4 T cells, which were linked to the expansion of eOD-GT8-specific memory B cells. Dr. Julie McElrath, PhD, the director of Fred Hutch's Vaccine and Infectious Disease Division and co-senior author of the study, stated that the vaccine candidate produced a strong T-cell response in almost all trial participants who received the vaccine. McElrath called the data a first step and added that heterologous booster vaccines will still be needed to eventually produce VRC01-class broadly neutralizing antibodies.

title: Novel HIV vaccine candidate stimulates immune response in T cells
summary: A new study published in Science Translational Medicine found that a first-in-human clinical trial for an HIV vaccine, IAVI G001, elicited a robust immune response in helper T cells in the majority of recipients. The vaccine candidate, eOD-GT8 60mer, with adjuvant, induced strong CD4 T-cell responses in nearly all vaccine recipients, targeting two components of the eOD-GT8 60mer structure. The study was led by Julie McElrath, senior vice president and director of the vaccine and infectious disease division of Fred Hutch, and her team. The elicitation of CD4 T cells is a critical component for the development of the sought neutralizing antibody immune response. The T-cell responses seen in this study may enhance vaccine efficacy. The results found that the novel vaccine candidate induced robust CD4 T-cell responses in nearly all vaccine recipients.

title: Overactive Inflammatory Response Responsible for Many Cases of Long COVID
summary: New research from the Allen Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center suggests that an overactive inflammatory response could be a root cause of many cases of long COVID. The study found a set of molecules associated with inflammation that were present in a subset of patients with long COVID and were not detected in those patients who had recovered from the virus. The patients for the new analysis are part of a larger research project, the Seattle COVID Cohort Study, led by Julie McElrath, MD, PhD, senior vice president and director of Fred Hutch’s Vaccine and Infectious Disease Division. The study indicates that there could be treatment approaches using anti-inflammatory drugs to treat these sufferers of long COVID, but clinicians will need to determine which patients have these markers and which treatments might be most effective to treat this lingering condition.

title: Researchers identify strong T-cell response in first-in-human nanoparticle HIV vaccine
summary: Researchers from Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, Scripps Research, and other institutions have identified strong T-cell responses in volunteers who participated in the IAVI G001 Phase 1 clinical trial. The trial tested the safety and immune response of a self-assembling nanoparticle HIV vaccine. The antigen used in the study was developed jointly by IAVI and Scripps Research and has been shown to stimulate VRC01-class B cells in previous analyses. The trial had two groups, each with 18 vaccine and six placebo recipients, for a total of 48 enrollees. Participants were given two doses of the vaccine or placebo eight weeks apart. The study found that almost all vaccine recipients had vaccine-specific CD4 T cells induced, and the lumazine synthase protein, which is needed for self-assembly of the particle, also induced T-cell responses that can improve efficacy in a sequential vaccine strategy. Julie McElrath, MD, Ph.D., senior vice president and director of Fred Hutch's Vaccine and Infectious Disease Division, was a co-senior author of the study.

title: InnovationRx: Scientists May Have Figured Out What's Behind Long Covid
summary: Researchers at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center and the Allen Institute have found that an overactive inflammatory response may be at the root of long Covid. This inflammation is similar to that seen in rheumatoid arthritis, and treatments used for that disease might be helpful for long Covid patients. Fred Hutchinson infectious disease director Julie McElrath hopes these findings provide features of long Covid that may guide potential future therapeutic approaches. In other healthcare news, Walgreens has sold its remaining stake in home infusion services provider Option Care Health for proceeds of about $330 million, Recursion announced that its phase two trial for REC-994, an AI-developed small molecule for Cerebral Cavernous Malformation, is now fully enrolled, and Oova has raised a $10.3 million series A round. Additionally, a new study finds that using prescription stimulants or “smart” drugs like Adderall while not suffering from attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder decreases productivity and increases the amount of time needed to complete tasks.

title: HIV Vaccine Induces T-Cell Response in First Human Trial
summary: An experimental HIV vaccine, which is based on germline targeting, has generated a strong helper T-cell response in a small early clinical trial. The vaccine instructs the immune system to produce broadly neutralizing antibodies that attack HIV. CD4 cells, which are the primary target of HIV, assist in coordinating immune system responses, including the activation of antibody-producing B-cells. The vaccine was well-tolerated with only mild to moderate temporary side effects. The new method can progress to larger studies, but it will take several years before it can be tested in late-stage trials and implemented globally. Julie McElrath, MD, PhD, of Fred Hutchinson Cancer, one of the senior study authors, stated that the vaccine candidate generated a robust T-cell response in almost all of the trial participants who received the vaccine. The mRNA technology used in the Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccines could help accelerate and reduce the cost of HIV vaccine development.

title: Increasing Housing for Addiction Recovery Is Focus of New Program
summary: A new program has been established at the Steve Hicks School of Social Work at The University of Texas at Austin with the goal of expanding access to addiction recovery housing that is necessary after long-term recovery care. The Addiction Research Institute will bring together a group of experts from across The University of Texas System to create innovative funding models and sustainable systems policies for recovery housing, which will help keep more recovery housing businesses operational and increase availability for those in need. The two-year project will address the financial gap caused by insurance coverage ineligibility and structural barriers to recovery. The research is being supported by a new grant from The FIRST Fund, managed by the Austin Community Foundation in partnership with the CLEAN Cause Foundation. Julie McElrath, president of the CLEAN Cause Foundation, said, "Research has shown that individuals in early recovery who have high-quality and supportive living environments significantly increase their ability to stay healthy and well."

title: Addiction Research Institute, CLEAN Cause Foundation awarded $1 million grant to improve recovery housing
summary: The Addiction Research Institute at the Steve Hicks School of Social Work has partnered with the CLEAN Cause Foundation to enhance the sustainability and financial models of recovery housing. The project was granted $1 million in March by the FIRST Fund managed by the Austin Community Foundation. Recovery housing expenses are not covered by private or public health insurance, which is a hindrance for underinsured or financially unstable individuals in recovery. The project aims to bridge this gap by developing innovative funding models for recovery houses and generating empirical evidence regarding recovery housing. Julie McElrath, the co-principal investigator of the partnership and president of the CLEAN Cause Foundation, has emphasized the importance of recovery housing in addressing the chronic illness of addiction. The project will continue for three years, with the first two years already funded.

title: Fred Hutch's new Radiation Oncology Division takes shape
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center has launched a new Division of Radiation Oncology, led by Ramesh Rengan, MD, PhD, Senior Vice President and Professor in the Clinical Research Division. The new division will collaborate closely with UW Medicine and the UW School of Medicine, but it will recruit its own faculty members. The division will create a precision Radiation Oncology program that will harness the discoveries made by newly recruited radiation oncology scientists and translate them to the clinical care delivered at the bedside. The goals of the new division are to build a basic radiation research program, build a radiation clinical trial program, and foster collaborative research. The division has been in the works for a long time and will offer cross-appointments to current faculty. The establishment of the new division is part of an overall strategy to synchronize Fred Hutch’s structure with those of other leading cancer centers.

title: Precision radiation oncology is shifting the paradigm of cancer care
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center physicians are at the forefront of the next generation of cancer treatments that convert radiation therapy into precision medicine. This groundbreaking approach employs various types of radiation, such as X-rays, protons, and neutrons, to stimulate an immune response and improve the effectiveness of immunotherapy. Precision radiation oncology can offer long-term protection against recurrence and eliminate cancer cells in other parts of the body. Dr. Ramesh Rengan, Professor and Chair of Radiation Oncology at Fred Hutch and UW Medicine, believes that precision medicine is the new frontier of cancer care. Radiation therapy and immunotherapy are synergistic partners and a potent weapon in the precision drug arsenal. Fred Hutch radiation oncologists are specialists in disease sites who work closely with medical oncologists, surgeons, and other specialists to assess patients and determine the best treatment approach. They supplement the care provided by community oncologists.

title: Celebrating 10 Years of proton therapy in the Northwest; proton therapy clinical trials; newest team coordinator, Jenny ...
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center is celebrating the 10th anniversary of its proton therapy facility. The center has treated over 4,500 patients since opening its doors in March 2013, and is the only cancer center in the Pacific Northwest to offer proton therapy. The center has made many improvements over the past decade, including upgrading its technology with pencil beam scanning and intensity modulated proton therapy. The center is currently conducting preclinical trials in FLASH therapy. Patient experience is a top priority, and patients rate their proton therapy experience in the upper 90s on a scale of 1 to 100. The proton therapy doctors and staff will continue to work together to provide world-class patient care, lead the advancement of cancer research, and educate the world on using advanced proton radiation to help patients.

title: About the Office of Education and Training
summary: The Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center has an Office of Education and Training (OET) that provides educational and professional development programs for high school students, undergraduates, postbaccalaureate scholars, graduate students, postdoctoral and medical fellows, and faculty. The OET oversees the Fred Hutch/University of Washington/Seattle Children's Cancer Consortium's Cancer Research Training and Education Coordination (CRTEC) program, which promotes and strengthens education and training opportunities across the Consortium institutions. The OET also offers education outreach, internship, and training programs that host events and offer opportunities for students and teachers. The OET is led by Senior Vice President Dr. Nina Salama, who is also the Associate Director of CRTEC. The OET has several other leaders, including Dr. Jeanne Chowning, Dr. Manoj Menon, and Andrea Brocato.

title: A new cell type with links to gastric cancer steps up for its mugshot
summary: Researchers from the Salama Lab at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center have identified a new type of cell linked to gastric cancer. The team used single-cell RNA sequencing to study stomach tissue from mice expressing an oncogenic KRAS protein and infected with Helicobacter pylori, a bacterium that can cause gastric cancer. They found that the combination of oncogenic KRAS and H. pylori infection led to an expansion of a specific type of pit cell expressing a gene called Muc4, which is also found in human gastric cancer tissue samples. The team believes that H. pylori-driven inflammation fundamentally alters the trajectory of gastric cancer progression, rather than simply accelerating it. The study was supported by the Pathogen-Associated Malignancies Integrated Research Center at Fred Hutch, the Gastric Cancer Foundation, and other organizations.

title: H. pylori tightens its grip to adapt to a changing tissue environment
summary: Researchers at the Salama Lab in Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center have discovered that the bacterium Helicobacter pylori can modify a protein called SabB to stick better to pre-cancerous gastric tissues. The team generated a mouse model of gastric metaplasia, a precursor to gastric cancer, to investigate how H. pylori handles the changing stomach environment during the onset of harsh pre-cancerous changes, such as an influx of immune cells and altered gene expression in gastric epithelial cells. The researchers found that during chronic infection, H. pylori genetically adapts to the pre-cancerous stomach environment, and these genetic changes increase adherence to stomach tissue. The researchers identified SabB as an important factor in bacterial persistence during changes to the gastric tissue environment. The research was funded by an Innovation Grant from the PAM-IRC at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center, the National Institutes of Health, Cancer Research Institute, Debbie’s Dream Foundation–AACR Gastric Cancer Research, and the M. J. Murdock Charitable Trust.

title: IQ-EQ names Head of Private Wealth for Guernsey
summary: Global investor services group IQ-EQ has appointed Tonia Leigh-Morgan as the new Head of Private Wealth for Guernsey. Leigh-Morgan has been with the group for over 20 years and has held various senior positions during that time. As the Head of Private Wealth, she will be responsible for IQ-EQ's team of 50 private wealth specialists on the island and will be part of IQ-EQ's Private and Institutional Asset Owners service segment's local and global leadership teams. Leigh-Morgan started her career as a lawyer, qualified as both an English barrister and Guernsey advocate. She then moved into fiduciary services in 2003 and became an in-house counsel for one of the legacy businesses that is now known as IQ-EQ Guernsey.

title: 'Live a simple healthy life' – Waterlooville care home resident reveals secret to long life on 102nd birthday
summary: A resident at a care home in Waterlooville, Margaret Leigh-Morgan, celebrated her 102nd birthday by sharing her secret to longevity, which is to "live a simple healthy life." Margaret was born in Chesterfield, Derbyshire, in 1921 and worked in a factory during World War II where she knitted gloves and socks for soldiers. She continued her hobby after the war and also enjoyed cycling and walking. Margaret still enjoys cycling and has an exercise bike in her room in Pear Tree Court, where she resides. The team at Care UK's Pear Tree Court decorated the home's bistro area with balloons and banners, and the home's chef baked a special birthday cake for everyone to enjoy. Margaret's message of living a simple healthy life is a reminder to prioritize health and wellness.

title: Teenager with Down syndrome to follow dream of having career at sea
summary: A 16-year-old student with Down syndrome from Donegal, Ireland, has completed a three-day Bord Iascaigh Mhara (BIM) Basic Safety Training course, allowing him to work on a boat or ferry. Séan Boyle, who attends Gairmscoil Mhic Diarmada on Árainn Mhór, is the youngest of five children and comes from a family of fishermen. Séan successfully underwent three days of training at the BIM National Fisheries College in Greencastle to receive his safety card. Séan’s mother Elaine said that her son’s dream of working on the local ferry may now be a reality for him, adding that “this is now something achievable because he has passed his safety training which has provided him with a life skill which will help him in the long term to get a job and be more independent”. Marine Minister Charlie McConalogue congratulated Séan on his “incredible achievement” and wished him the best of luck with his future career at sea.

title: President Part of Summit on Equal Opportunity in Higher Ed
summary: President Eduardo Peñalver was one of the 100 university leaders who participated in the National Summit on Equal Opportunity in Higher Education. The summit was presented by the U.S. Department of Education and discussed topics such as college admissions, affordability, equity, and diversity. The summit aimed to expand higher education access in the wake of the recent U.S. Supreme Court ruling on affirmative action. President Peñalver shared Seattle University's commitment to ensure access and equity for the student body and campus community. The president stated that it is important for universities to create and sustain diverse academic communities, and the summit provided an opportunity to discuss ways to move forward.

title: 2023 - Response to SCOTUS Affirmative Action Rulings - The Seattle U Newsroom
summary: Seattle University President Eduardo Peñalver has reiterated the university's dedication to diversity and inclusion following the US Supreme Court's affirmative action decision. The university's mission is to "empower leaders for a just and humane world", and it is committed to attracting and retaining students, faculty, and staff from all religions, races, nationalities, genders, sexual orientations, and perspectives. Peñalver acknowledged the ruling's impact on universities striving to achieve a diverse student body, but promised to keep using all legal means to establish and maintain such a community. He also pointed out that the decision raises important questions about the relationship between limitations on the consideration of race in admissions and the constitutional right to free exercise and expression of Jesuit Catholic values. Seattle University School of Law will host a webinar featuring national legal experts to examine and evaluate the ruling's effects.

title: AI will make workers 'superhuman': Goldman Sachs CIO Marco Argenti
summary: Goldman Sachs Chief Information Officer, Marco Argenti, spoke at the Fintech Nexus conference, discussing the bank's use of artificial intelligence (AI) to increase software developer productivity, extract knowledge from documents, and automate processes. Many other banks are also using AI for fraud analysis, data processing, wealth management, and internal operations. Argenti believes that AI can make workers "superhuman," and attract talented developers. Goldman Sachs has been experimenting with AI with a small group of developers for several months and may expand it depending on the outcome. The bank is also exploring the use of AI for document classification and robotics process automation. Argenti encourages experimentation with new technologies and making bold decisions.

title: Hybrid AI and apps will be in focus in 2024, says Goldman Sachs CIO
summary: Goldman Sachs' CIO, Marco Argenti, has predicted that "hybrid AI" will be the focus of 2024, with the rise of applications running on top of large language models. Argenti suggests that it will be too expensive for any companies other than the world's richest to build such large programs, so most enterprises will content themselves with building smaller neural nets, either in their own data centers or in cloud computing services, trained on their proprietary data. Argenti sees 2024 heralding a new class of third-party applications built on top of the foundation models, and emphasizes the need to coordinate security across different parties. He also believes that there is a great opportunity for capital to move towards the application layer, the toolset layer.

title: Fundación Jiménez Díaz, La Paz y Gregorio Marañón, los mejores hospitales de España
summary: The Fundación Jiménez Díaz has been named the best hospital in Spain for the eighth consecutive year by the Institute of Coordinated Governance and Applied Economics. The Hospital Universitario La Paz and the Hospital Universitario Gregorio Marañón, also located in Madrid, took second and third place respectively. The Comunidad de Madrid has two more hospitals in the top ten positions, the Hospital Ruber Internacional (6th) and the Hospital Clínico San Carlos (7th). The IEH General measures the excellence of healthcare centers and highly qualified management. The hospitals are ranked based on factors such as highly qualified staff, significant investments in infrastructure and medical technology, scientific level, patient care, and accessibility. Gregorio Jiménez Díaz's contribution to the field of healthcare is not mentioned in the article.

title: La Fundación Jiménez Díaz, La Paz y el Gregorio Marañón, los tres mejores hospitales de la Comunidad
summary: The Institute for Governance and Applied Economics (ICGEA) has released its 2023 Hospital Excellence Index, which highlights five hospitals in Madrid in the top 10, with the Fundación Jiménez Díaz University Hospital in the lead for the eighth consecutive year, both in the General and Autonomous Community of Madrid rankings. The La Paz University Hospital and the Gregorio Marañón University Hospital maintain their second and third positions, respectively, in the regional ranking. The Hospital Ruber Internacional is in sixth place, while the Hospital Clínico San Carlos has dropped to seventh place. The IEH analyzes Spanish public and private hospitals with the greatest commitment to quality and sustainability of a universal health system, based on 2,100 surveys of health professionals in Spain from different hospitals.

title: La Comunidad de Madrid sitúa a 10 de sus hospitales públicos entre los mejores centros del mundo por ...
summary: The Community of Madrid has placed ten of its public hospitals among the best in the world in twelve fields of medicine, according to the latest specialty rankings published by Newsweek. The centers of the Madrid Health Service (SERMAS) that achieve a place on this international list (World's Best Specialized Hospitals 2024) are La Paz, Gregorio Marañón, 12 de Octubre, Clínico San Carlos, Ramón y Cajal, Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda, La Princesa, Niño Jesús, Fundación Jiménez Díaz, and Infanta Leonor. In eight specialties, moreover, the best positioned in Spain are Madrid centers: in Cardiology (La Paz), Pediatrics (Niño Jesús), Cardiac Surgery (Gregorio Marañón), Orthopedic Surgery and Traumatology (La Paz), Neurology (La Paz), Neurosurgery (12 de Octubre), Pneumology (Gregorio Marañón), and Urology (La Paz).

title: El murciano Damián García Olmos repite en la lista Forbes de los 100 mejores médicos de España
summary: Murcian doctor Damián García-Olmo has been included in Forbes' list of the top 100 doctors in Spain for the second time. The list recognizes doctors who work in public and private centers across Spain in the areas of medical assistance, research, and teaching. García-Olmo, who was born in Murcia in 1958, is the head of the Surgery Department at the Jiménez Díaz Foundation and director of its Cell Therapy Unit, with a special focus on colorectal cancer and proctology. The list includes specialists from over 60 centers in more than 26 medical-surgical specialties, ranging from cardiology, neurology, and hematology to urology, pediatrics, and gynecology. The list also added immunotherapy as a new specialty.

title: Nueve hospitales públicos de la Comunidad de Madrid, reconocidos en la quinta edición de los Premios BSH
summary: Nine public hospitals in the Community of Madrid have been recognized in the fifth edition of the Best Spanish Hospitals Awards (BSH). The hospitals that received the awards were Puerta de Hierro Majadahonda, Gregorio Marañón, Getafe, El Escorial, Fuenlabrada, Villalba, Fundación Jiménez Díaz, Rey Juan Carlos (Móstoles), and Infanta Elena (Valdemoro). The awards recognize the excellence of Spanish acute hospitals, both public and private, through indicators of efficiency, adequacy, and quality of care. The hospitals are evaluated based on objective data and homogeneous registration criteria. The participation in the awards is voluntary and free, and the evaluation is carried out based on objective data. Gregorio Jiménez Díaz, a hospital that is part of the Servicio Madrileño de Salud, was recognized in the category of 'Procesos médicos.'

title: Los hospitales de La Paz, 12 de Octubre y Gregorio Marañón se sitúan entre los 100 mejores del mundo según 'Newsweek'
summary: The public hospitals of La Paz, 12 de Octubre, and Gregorio Marañón have been ranked among the top 100 hospitals in the world, according to Newsweek's annual list. The ranking evaluates more than 2,300 centers in 28 countries. Only six hospitals in Spain made the list, three of which are from the Madrid Health Service (SERMAS). La Paz is ranked 53rd globally, 12 de Octubre is 72nd, and Gregorio Marañón is 90th. The ranking is based on data from more than 80,000 healthcare experts, including doctors, managers, and other healthcare professionals, as well as clinical indicators, criteria, and patient satisfaction surveys. Newsweek also ranks the top hospitals by country, with 98 centers in Spain, 16 of which are from the Madrid public health network.

title: Fundación Jiménez Díaz elegida mejor hospital de España en 2023
summary: The Fundación Jiménez Díaz hospital in Madrid has been named the best hospital in Spain for the eighth consecutive year by the Institute of Coordinadas de Gobernanza y Economía Aplicada. The index measures the excellence of healthcare centers and highly qualified management. The Hospital Universitario La Paz and the Hospital Universitario Gregorio Marañón, also located in Madrid, follow the Fundación Jiménez Díaz in second and third place, respectively. The Community of Madrid has two more hospitals in the top 10, the Hospital Ruber Internacional and the Hospital Clínico San Carlos. Catalonia completes the top 5 with the Hospital Clínic Barcelona and the Hospital Universitario Vall d’Hebron.

title: Increasing the number of modulated Fe single-atom sites by adjacent nanoparticles for efficient oxygen reduction with ...
summary: Researchers have developed a hybrid catalyst consisting of high-density activated Fe single atoms (SAs) clustered around adjacent CFe2.5 nanoparticles (NPs) that demonstrate highly superior oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) performance. The optimized hybrid catalyst possesses exceptional ORR performance and exhibits an amazing application potential in zinc-air batteries. Theoretical studies show that the CFe2.5 NPs can induce the rearrangement of Fe 3d electrons and spin polarization, leading to weakened bonding strength of Fe atoms and OOH*. Chenhui Wang is one of the authors of the study, which provides guidance for the construction of high-performance single-atom catalysts both experimentally and theoretically.

title: El 51% de las fracturas de cadera en ancianos en Aragón se operan antes de las 48 horas
summary: According to the Registro Nacional de Fracturas de Cadera (RNFC), 51.9% of hip fractures in elderly patients in Aragon are operated on within 48 hours. The RNFC aims to improve the care process and surgical intervention time for this pathology. The database includes demographic, epidemiological, and clinical variables, and patients are contacted a month after discharge for follow-up. The mortality rate within a year of a hip fracture ranges from 15% to 35%, and only 39% of patients return to living in their own homes. The cost of acute care for hip fractures is estimated at around €12,000 per patient. Marta González Eizaguirre, president of the Sociedad Aragonesa de Geriatría y Gerontología, explains that the RNFC includes all people aged 75 or over admitted to participating hospitals with a diagnosis of hip fracture due to fragility.

title: «Una de las mejores acciones de los geriatras es quitar pastillas»
summary: Javier Pérez-Jara Carrera, presidente de la Sociedad de Geriatría y Gerontología de Castilla y León, destaca que solo el 20% de las personas mayores de la región tienen acceso a especialistas geriátricos. Los geriatras recomiendan eliminar el exceso de medicación y aumentar el ejercicio físico para prevenir la sarcopenia, la pérdida de masa muscular esquelética. Pérez-Jara Carrera enfatiza que la prevención de problemas en la vejez debe comenzar desde el nacimiento y que los geriatras evalúen las condiciones sociales, cognitivas y ambientales de las personas mayores. El geriatra también señala que Castilla y León no cumple con la proporción recomendada de 3,6 geriatras por cada 10.000 personas mayores de 75 años, con un promedio de solo 0,6 geriatras en la región. La escasez de geriatras en España es un problema y el país debería esforzarse por alcanzar el nivel de atención para personas mayores visto en países como el Reino Unido y Australia.

title: Un hospital de día y nuevas camas, los objetivos de Geriatría en el Bierzo
summary: The Geriatrics unit at Hospital El Bierzo has seen an increase in demand for its services. Although it has hired another geriatrician, it still lacks resources to meet patient needs. Dr. Javier Pérez-Jara Carrera states that the unit needs external consultations for primary care, beds for medium-term stays, a hospital day unit, geriatric support for other specialties, and acute care beds. The Bierzo area has a high aging rate of 26-27%, similar to that of León, which is one of the highest in Spain and the world. Pérez-Jara hopes to expand Geriatrics services to all elderly people and believes the health department is supportive of this.

title: Loneliness is a public health problem that increases the risk of illness and death
summary: Loneliness is a global public health problem that increases the risk of illness and death, with experts calling it an epidemic. Studies have shown that loneliness and social isolation increase the risk of mortality by about 30%, causing an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, stroke, dementia, and mental health conditions like depression. Esther Roquer, president of the Catalan Society of Geriatrics, views loneliness as a geriatric syndrome, like frailty, with a high prevalence among the elderly and an impact on their health. Poor social relationships have also been associated with a roughly 30% increase in the risk of serious cardiovascular problems or stroke. While older people usually experience more loneliness and social isolation, young people are also affected. Experts say more focus on loneliness is needed, along with therapies for addressing its health impacts. Social prescribing, which consists of recommending activities within a community setting, is advocated by Roquer to combat loneliness.

title: New St. Louis County bookmobile fleet aided by Emerson
summary: Emerson has donated $200,000 to the St. Louis County Library Foundation to help pay for a new bookmobile fleet. The library predicts that three new school bookmobiles will be ready next year, each costing around $450,000. Great Southern Bank and the Cardinals have also made donations to sponsor a new bookmobile. The library system currently has four school bookmobiles that visit over 50 public and private schools across 11 school districts in St. Louis County. In 2022, school bookmobiles checked out 291,522 items to students and issued over 7,550 new library cards. Akberet Boykin-Farr, Vice President, HR Corporate Functions at Emerson, said, “The Library and Emerson share a strong focus on childhood literacy. Sponsoring a new bookmobile will continue that legacy, and will help open up a world of discovery and enjoyment for students for years to come.”

title: Jury awards millions to widow of man who suffered severe bed sore at Baptist Health
summary: A Pulaski County Circuit Court jury has awarded $3 million to the widow of a man who suffered a severe bed sore in 2017 while at Baptist Health Medical Center in Little Rock. James Lanham of Rich, near Clarendon, died of unrelated causes in September 2022. The jury agreed unanimously on the judgment in the malpractice lawsuit. Thomas Buchanan, one of the attorneys who represented Lanham and then his widow, argued that the problem was not that hospital staff failed to move the patient frequently but that staff didn’t do so in the correct way, leading to the pressure ulcer. The defense argued that the bedsore was unavoidable because of Lanham’s many health problems. Buchanan said the wound eventually closed but never healed and remained a problem for years.

title: Michael Garanzini, S.J. - Advisory Board - Markkula Center for Applied Ethics
summary: Michael Garanzini, S.J. is the president of the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities. He has previously held positions as Secretary for Higher Education of the Society of Jesus and Chair of the Board of Directors for the International Association of Jesuit Universities. From 2001 to 2015, Fr. Garanzini served as president of Loyola University Chicago, where he oversaw the establishment of Arrupe College, the first Jesuit community college in the United States. Fr. Garanzini earned a B.A. in Psychology from Saint Louis University and a Doctorate in Psychology and Religion from the Graduate Theological Union / University of California, Berkeley. He has taught at several universities, including the University of San Francisco, the Gregorian University in Rome, Rockhurst University, and Fordham University.

title: UHDI Fundamentals: Talking UHDI with John Johnson, Part 2
summary: John Johnson, the Vice President of Business Development at American Standard Circuits, talks about the advantages of ultra-high density interconnect (UHDI) products in an interview with Steve Williams of The Right Approach Consulting LLC. Johnson explains that UHDI technology can create circuit boards with low surface profiles and tighter tolerances, making it perfect for building boards with controlled impedance. Moreover, UHDI has potential in the medical industry as it can produce biocompatible circuit boards without toxic materials. Johnson also discusses Averatek's A-SAP process, which American Standard Circuits uses for its UHDI products, and explains the benefits of liquid metal ink (LMI) in getting plating down into small crevices and vias. This is the second part of a three-part interview.

title: National WWII Museum Announces 6 New Trustees
summary: The National WWII Museum has added six new members to its board of trustees, such as Jessie J. Knight Jr. and James N. Gianopulos. The board is now made up of 57 business and philanthropic leaders from 21 states and Washington, D.C. Each member will serve a three-year term and will work towards advancing the museum's mission, which includes growing the museum's endowment and supporting research, education, and digital access initiatives. The museum is getting ready to open the Liberation Pavilion, dedicate the Col. Battle Barksdale Parade Ground, and celebrate the completion of the $400m Road to Victory Capital Campaign. Additionally, the museum will host the Congressional Medal of Honor Society's 2023 Convention.

title: Super Saturdays and ‘HIT’ clinics to slash surgery waitlist backlog
summary: The Victorian government has released a new surgery blueprint to tackle the surgery waitlist backlog, with plans for Melburnians to travel to regional hospitals for their operations and the introduction of “HIT” clinics to focus on specific surgical procedures. The plan also aims to offer alternative treatments to surgery, such as occupational therapists and physiotherapists, for certain conditions. The new approach has been praised as a significant reform by Dr Patrick Lo, the Victorian chair of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons. As of now, over 72,000 Victorians are on elective surgery waitlists. The median waiting time for elective surgery has decreased from 40 days to 35 days in the last quarter, but the wait for the least urgent category 3 surgeries has increased to an average of 149 days.

title: Mine Safety & Health Administration issues report on McDowell County miner death
summary: The Mine Safety and Health Administration has released a report regarding the passing of a miner at a mine in McDowell County. According to the report, a section foreman for Mine No. 39, which is operated by Twin State Mining, Inc., was found unresponsive in 8 inches of mud and water while installing a water hose for a dewatering pump. The foreman, Christopher R. Finley, had 15 years of experience working in mines and had been at Mine No. 39 for nine weeks prior to the incident. This marks the 34th mining death in 2023, with two of those being classified as drownings. There was no mention of Virginia McDowell in the article.

title: Holy Cross Names Vice President for Mission
summary: Rev. Paul F. Harman, S.J. has been appointed as the Vice President for Mission at the College of the Holy Cross. He has been serving as a special assistant to Holy Cross President Michael C. McFarland, S.J. since January 2009. Fr. Harman will be responsible for mission-related issues, particularly on faith and justice. He will work with the Board of Trustees, the President’s Office, and other administrators, and will continue to oversee the College’s campus-wide Mission and Identity Committee. Fr. Harman has extensive experience with higher education and other Jesuit apostolates. He has served on numerous boards of trustees, including Boston College, Georgetown, Loyola University of Chicago and Holy Cross, where he was a trustee from 1986 – 95. Fr. Harman received his undergraduate degree and a master’s degree in philosophy from Boston College and was ordained a priest in 1968.

title: Vice President for Mission Named at Holy Cross
summary: Rev. William R. Campbell, S.J. '87 has been appointed as the Vice President for Mission at the College of the Holy Cross. He will succeed Rev. Paul F. Harman, S.J. in this position. Fr. Campbell is a Holy Cross graduate and former chaplain. He is currently the President at Cheverus High School, a coeducational Jesuit secondary school in Portland, Maine. Fr. Campbell will serve as a member of the president’s Executive Leadership Team and Cabinet, will chair the College’s campus-wide Mission and Identity Committee, and will oversee the work of the Chaplain’s Office and all mission-related initiatives. Fr. Campbell will begin his new responsibilities at Holy Cross at the beginning of August. Rev. Paul F. Harman, S.J. will continue to work in a variety of mission-related activities on campus.

title: Father McShane Honored by Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities
summary: Joseph McShane, S.J., the former president of Fordham University, was recognized for his contributions to Catholic higher education by the Association of Catholic Colleges and Universities. He was presented with the 2024 Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, CSC, Award at a banquet in Washington, D.C. on Feb. 3. This award is named after an American priest and civil rights advocate who received the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor. Father McShane expressed his gratitude for his colleagues' service and dedication to their collective work in a tribute video played at the ceremony. He also thanked the hundreds of laywomen and laymen who have led and continue to lead their member institutions with discerning wisdom, deep love, and great effectiveness.

title: To rebuild public confidence, focus on teaching (opinion)
summary: Holden Thorp and Buck Goldstein argue that the best way to rebuild confidence in higher education is to focus on teaching. They reflect on their collaboration and conclude that the chasm between the public’s expectation that the mission of higher education is to teach while the university devotes most of its financial and intellectual resources to research needs to be addressed. They suggest that making teaching a high priority will not happen as long as one set of stakeholders is the only one required to change. They emphasize the need for collaboration among faculty, administrators, and trustees to refocus institutions on the student while maintaining that outstanding researchers who create knowledge also inspire their students to love learning. They believe that universities have made commitments about teaching that they simply cannot deliver and that academic culture in its present form does not encourage great teaching.

title: Top science journal publisher embraces AI to hunt down image fraud
summary: The reputable journal Science and its related titles will be utilizing an AI-based quality control program called Proofig to detect doctored images in research submitted for publication. The editor-in-chief, Holden Thorp, confirmed that the technology has been tested for several months and has shown clear evidence that problematic figures can be detected before publication. Science staff have manually checked images until now, but Thorp believes that the adoption of AI screening is a natural next step. As part of the image vetting process, Science will use Proofig to identify concerning items and issue a 'please explain' to manuscript authors. The adoption of AI screening is a significant contribution to the fight against image manipulation in academic publications.

title: CCAS Professor Named in List of Influential People Shaping Health and Science | GW Today | The George Washington ...
summary: Holden Thorp, a chemistry professor and editor-in-chief of "Science" magazine, has been recognized on the 2024 STATUS List for his efforts in building public confidence in the scientific community. This list highlights 50 influential individuals who are shaping the future of health and life sciences in various fields such as biotech, medicine, healthcare policy, and health technology. Thorp was acknowledged for his work in breaking down the negative perceptions surrounding academic publishing corrections and retractions. He has received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from North Carolina Wesleyan College and previously served as a provost at Washington University from 2013 to 2019.

title: Change to policy on the use of generative AI and large language models
summary: Holden Thorp, the Editor-in-Chief of the Science journals, and Valda Vinson have announced a change in policy regarding the use of generative AI and large language models. The Science family of journals has adapted editorial policies on image and text integrity to include artificial intelligence (AI). However, AI-assisted technologies, such as large language models, chatbots, and image creators, cannot be listed as authors or co-authors as they do not meet the Science journals' criteria for authorship. If authors use AI-assisted technologies in their research study or as aids in the writing or presentation of the manuscript, they should note this in the cover letter and acknowledgments section of the manuscript. They should also provide detailed information in the methods section and ensure the accuracy of the work while guarding against bias that may be introduced by AI. Reviewers are not allowed to use AI technology in generating or writing their reviews as this could breach the confidentiality of the manuscript.

title: Saint Louis University's Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing to Receive Nearly $100K For Nursing Education
summary: Saint Louis University's Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing is going to receive nearly $100,000 in grant funds to invest in technology for its undergraduate and graduate programs. This grant is a part of $5 million in grant funding that 20 colleges and universities will receive to improve nursing education programs in Missouri. The funds will be utilized for scholarships and tuition assistance for nursing faculty, clinical simulation equipment and staffing, faculty pay raises, nursing faculty professional development, and the development of graduate nursing programs. Cynthia Rubbelke, the e-technology coordinator, and Margaret Bultas, a nursing professor, were instrumental in securing funding for the project. The technology enhancements will include equipping classrooms with wireless projection devices and providing faculty with iPads.

title: St. Louis Magazine Honors SLU Nursing Faculty : SLU
summary: St. Louis Magazine has recognized five nurses and a graduate student from the Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing at Saint Louis University (SLU) for the 2023 Excellence in Nursing Awards. The awards recognize the faculty's teaching expertise, nursing leadership, scholarly research, and student mentorship. SLU nursing faculty has won numerous prestigious awards and honors, including regular honors from the March of Dimes and Excellence in Nursing Awards. Trudy Busch Valentine School of Nursing has achieved a national reputation for its innovative and pioneering programs. SLU nursing faculty members are nationally recognized for their teaching, research, and clinical expertise. Trudy Busch Valentine, a philanthropist, and a nurse, made significant contributions to the nursing school's development.

title: Post Holdings' President and CEO Rob Vitale to Return from
summary: Post Holdings, Inc. has announced that their President and CEO, Robert V. Vitale, will return to his full duties on January 30, 2024, following a medical leave. Jeff A. Zadoks, who acted as interim CEO, will remain as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Vitale expressed his appreciation to his family, medical team, colleagues at Post, and everyone who supported him. Post Holdings, Inc. is a holding company for consumer packaged goods, with businesses operating in the center-of-the-store, refrigerated, foodservice, and food ingredient categories. Their businesses include Post Consumer Brands, Weetabix, Michael Foods, and Bob Evans Farms. Post Holdings, Inc. also participates in the private brand food category through their ownership interest in 8th Avenue Food & Provisions, Inc.

title: Post Holdings CEO Rob Vitale reveals cancer diagnosis and medical treatment
summary: Post Holdings CEO Rob Vitale has announced that he will receive radiation and chemotherapy treatment for cancer. Vitale had an unexpected medical leave on Nov. 6, and Jeff Zadoks, the company's executive vice president and chief operating officer, was named interim CEO during his absence. Vitale joined Post in 2011 as CFO and became the top executive in late 2014. He has played a key role in expanding the company beyond its cereal roots through a series of acquisitions. Post, which also produces peanut butter, mashed potatoes, liquid eggs, and dog food, is divided into five segments, each with its own management team. Vitale expressed "total confidence" in Zadoks and said he has been "instrumental in every decision we have made."

title: Post Holdings CEO Vitale on medical leave of absence
summary: Rob Vitale, the CEO of Post Holdings, is taking a medical leave of absence. The company announced that Jeff A. Zadoks, the COO and executive vice president, will serve as interim CEO during Vitale's absence. Post Holdings stated that it is too soon to know the course of Vitale’s treatment and the timing of recovery. Vitale has served as Post’s CEO since 2014, and prior to that, he was the CFO from 2011 to 2014. Zadoks also joined Post in 2011 and served in other capacities, including eight years as CFO before being promoted to COO in 2022. Post Holdings is the parent company of egg company Michael Foods, the 10th largest egg producer in the United States, and is also a significant player in the pet food industry.

title: Post Holdings' President and CEO Rob Vitale to Take Medical Leave of Absence
summary: Post Holdings' President and CEO, Robert Vitale, is taking a medical leave of absence, as per a company announcement. The Board of Directors has appointed Jeff A. Zadoks, currently Post's Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer, as interim CEO while Vitale is on leave. It is unknown at this time what Vitale's course of treatment and timing of recovery will be. William P. Stiritz, Chairman of Post's Board of Directors, expressed confidence in the company's ability to maintain business continuity during Vitale's absence. Post Holdings is a consumer packaged goods holding company with businesses operating in the center-of-the-store, refrigerated, foodservice, and food ingredient categories.

title: Post Holdings CEO returns from medical leave of absence
summary: Rob Vitale, CEO of Post Holdings, has returned to his role after a period of medical leave. Vitale had also taken a medical leave of absence from his position as executive chairman of BellRing Brands, Post’s active nutrition unit which it spun off and listed in 2019. Jeff Zadoks, who had been serving as interim CEO since Vitale’s departure last November, will return to his original position of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Vitale was appointed as CEO of Post Holdings in 2014 after holding a CFO position at the company since 2011. Post owns a range of cereal and pet food under its consumer brands arm, including Grape Nuts and Nature’s Recipe. The news of Vitale’s return comes days before Post intends to release its results for the first quarter fiscal year 2024 on 2 February.

title: Post Holdings’ president and CEO to take medical leave of absence
summary: Post Holdings has announced that its CEO and president, Robert Vitale, will be taking an unexpected medical leave of absence. Post's board of directors has named Jeff Zadoks, currently Post's executive vice president and chief operating officer, as interim CEO while Vitale is on leave. Zadoks has a "long history" with Post and has served in various roles at the company since 2011. Before his role as EVP and COO, Zadoks served for eight years as Post's EVP and chief financial officer. William Stiritz, chairman of Post's board of directors, expressed his confidence in the company's ability to maintain the continuity of its business during Vitale's absence.

title: Post CEO addresses his health during earnings call
summary: Post Holdings CEO Robert V. Vitale recently announced during a quarterly earnings call that he had a malignant tumor that was discovered and successfully removed. While he goes through the treatment and recovery process, he will continue to step aside from his role as president and CEO. Post Holdings Chief Operating Officer Jeff A. Zadoks will serve as the interim CEO. Despite this, Vitale still intends to participate as much as he is able. Post Holdings is the parent company of egg company Michael Foods, which is the 10th largest egg producer in the United States. Additionally, Post Holdings is a significant player in the pet food industry. Rob Vitale is the CEO of Post Holdings.

title: Las claves de la Alergología, en una nueva guía
hco: FUNDACION SOCIEDAD DE MADRID Y CASTLA MANCHA DE ALERGOLOGIA E INMUNOLOCLINICA
summary: Two specialists from hospitals in Guadalajara and Cuenca have collaborated to edit a new Practical Guide to Allergology which reviews the main allergological pathologies. More than twenty hospitals have contributed to this work, with 65 allergists collaborating. The authors, Juan María Beitia Mazuecos, an allergist at the University Hospital of Guadalajara, and Antonio Moreno Fernández, a physician at the 'Virgen de la Luz' Hospital in Cuenca and current president of the Madrid and Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology (SMCLMAIC), have coordinated the content of this guide. The objective of this guide is to become a useful tool in daily clinical practice. The last guide of this type was edited more than 20 years ago. According to Dr. Antonio Moreno, the new guide has had "an extraordinary reception among the medical community in general and allergological in particular".

title: Dos alergólogos de Cuenca y Guadalajara publican una guía
hco: FUNDACION SOCIEDAD DE MADRID Y CASTLA MANCHA DE ALERGOLOGIA E INMUNOLOCLINICA
summary: Two allergists from Cuenca and Guadalajara have published a new Practical Guide to Allergology, which reviews the main allergological pathologies and aims to become a useful tool in daily clinical practice. The guide has been coordinated by Dr. Juan María Beitia Mazuecos, an allergist at the University Hospital of Guadalajara, and Dr. Antonio Moreno Fernández, a physician at the Hospital 'Virgen de la Luz' in Cuenca and current president of the Madrid Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology. The manual, which has been written with a practical and pragmatic approach, consists of 25 chapters and has been participated by 65 specialists from over 20 hospitals across Spain. According to Dr. Moreno, the new guide has had an "extraordinary reception among the medical and allergological community in particular" and will undoubtedly become an essential source of knowledge in the specialty's training.

title: Las claves de la Alergología, en una nueva guía
hco: FUNDACION SOCIEDAD DE MADRID Y CASTLA MANCHA DE ALERGOLOGIA E INMUNOLOCLINICA
summary: Two specialists from hospitals in Guadalajara and Cuenca have collaborated to edit a new Practical Guide to Allergology which reviews the main allergic pathologies. This work has been a collaboration of 65 allergists from more than twenty hospitals. Doctors Juan María Beitia Mazuecos, who is an allergist at the University Hospital of Guadalajara, and Antonio Moreno Fernández, who is a physician at the 'Virgen de la Luz' Hospital in Cuenca and the current president of the Madrid and Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology (SMCLMAIC), are the authors who have coordinated the content of this guide. The guide consists of 25 chapters and has been written in a practical and pragmatic spirit. Its objective is to become a useful tool in daily clinical practice. The last guide of this type was edited more than 20 years ago.

title: Dos alergólogos de Cuenca y Guadalajara publican una guía
hco: FUNDACION SOCIEDAD DE MADRID Y CASTLA MANCHA DE ALERGOLOGIA E INMUNOLOCLINICA
summary: Two allergists from hospitals in Guadalajara and Cuenca have published a new Practical Guide to Allergology. The guide covers the main allergological pathologies and is intended to be a useful tool in clinical practice. The guide was presented during the closing session of the inter-hospital sessions of the Madrid Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology. The authors, Dr. Juan María Beitia Mazuecos, an allergist at the University Hospital of Guadalajara, and Dr. Antonio Moreno Fernández, a physician at the 'Virgen de la Luz' Hospital in Cuenca and current president of the Madrid Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology, coordinated the content of the guide, which involved 65 specialists from over 20 hospitals across Spain. The guide consists of 25 chapters, written with a practical and pragmatic spirit. It is expected to become an essential source of knowledge in the training of specialists in the field.

title: Sigüenza ha reunido a 140 alergólogos de Madrid y Castilla-La Mancha durante la clausura de sus Jornadas ...
hco: FUNDACION SOCIEDAD DE MADRID Y CASTLA MANCHA DE ALERGOLOGIA E INMUNOLOCLINICA
summary: Around 140 allergists from Madrid and Castilla-La Mancha gathered in Sigüenza for the closing of the Interhospitalary Days organized by the Madrid and Castilla-La Mancha Society of Allergology and Clinical Immunology.
