The bank's support will be provided through scholarships aimed at facilitating access to university and complementing academic training, mobility, and research; training courses to strengthen professional skills and facilitate access to the job market; and awards, challenges, and training to support entrepreneurs, start-ups, scale-ups, and SMEs. The bank has invested €400m in education, employability, and entrepreneurship between 2023 and 2026. Susana García Espinel, the director of Santander Universities and Universia Spain, said the bank's main motivation is to improve people's professional prospects and business development.

title: Santander y la VIU se unen para mejorar la empleabilidad de los universitarios
summary: Banco Santander and the Universidad Internacional de Valencia-VIU have signed their first collaboration agreement to reinforce the quality of university education and the employability of students. The agreement includes several areas of action for 2024, such as reinforcing the quality of teaching and academic management, promoting continuous training, and contributing to the internationalization of higher education. Both entities seek to promote access to education through the implementation of three Santander-VIU scholarship and aid programs. The first program aims to facilitate access to higher education for undergraduate or master's students through 15 scholarships. The second program seeks to promote research activity through 10 grants for pre-doctoral staff. The third program will promote international mobility through four scholarships for academic stays at non-European universities with agreements with VIU. Susana García Espinel, Director of Santander Universidades España, said that it is an honor for Banco Santander to sign its first collaboration agreement with VIU, providing its entire range of scholarships and training for the improvement of employability and entrepreneurial projects to its university community.

title: Santander dará más de 37.000 becas, ayudas y formación este año en España para mejorar la empleabilidad de los jóvenes
summary: Banco Santander plans to help over 33,000 Spanish university students, professionals, and entrepreneurs this year by providing scholarships, grants, courses, awards, and training to improve their academic and professional skills. The initiative aims to enhance the employability of individuals, particularly young people, whose unemployment rate exceeds 28% among those under 24 years old, and support the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. The bank is collaborating with 80 universities, academic centers, and institutions to provide the assistance. The program will be delivered through scholarships for university access, academic training, mobility, and research, as well as training courses and content to promote professional skills and access to the labor market. The bank's commitment to investing €400m in education, employability, and entrepreneurship between 2023 and 2026 is being maintained. Susana García Espinel, Director of Santander Universities and Universia Spain, said the bank's primary motivation is to improve the professional prospects of people and support the business development of entrepreneurs and SMEs.

title: El diseño y evaluación de una intervención psicológica para mejorar la salud mental, ganador de los XVIII Premios de Investigación Universidad de Deusto-Santander
summary: The University of Deusto and Banco Santander have given out the XVIII University of Deusto-Santander Research Awards for Scientific and Social Impact. The top prize was given to Susana Gorbeña's research project "Design and evaluation of a psychological intervention to cultivate mental health," while the second prize was awarded to Mari Luz Guenaga's project "Inspira STEAM - promotion of scientific and technological vocations among girls." Santander has had a long-standing collaboration with the University of Deusto through Santander Universities since 2004 to promote various academic initiatives. The mental health research project has been successful in producing statistically significant improvements in positive mental health and reducing emotional distress indicators. The Inspira STEAM project aims to encourage scientific and technological vocations among young people, particularly girls, by providing equal opportunities for literacy in these areas.

title: Robles cesa a Patricia Ortega, la primera mujer que llegó a general, como secretaria del INTA
summary: The first woman to become a general in the Spanish Armed Forces, Patricia Ortega García, has been dismissed by the Minister of Defense, Margarita Robles, from her position as Secretary General of the National Institute of Aerospace Technology (INTA). Ortega will now serve as an advisor to the Secretary of State, Amparo Valcarce. The decision was reportedly made after several clashes with the general director of the INTA. Ortega became a general in 2019 and was appointed as director of the Subdirectorate General of Land Systems of the INTA that same year. In April 2022, she was promoted to division general and became Secretary General of the same organization. Ortega is an agricultural engineer and comes from a family of military members. She has received several military decorations, including the Grand Cross of the Royal and Military Order of San Hermenegildo.

title: Defensa asciende a dos mujeres a general médico, las primeras del cuerpo de sanidad
summary: The Spanish Ministry of Defence has promoted two women to the rank of general of brigade physician, the first from the military health corps. The promotions of Colonel Physicians Elvira Pelet Pascual and María Rosa García Toledano bring the total number of women generals to nine. The first woman to achieve the rank of general in Spain was engineer Patricia Ortega García, who was promoted to general of brigade of the Army Polytechnic Engineers Corps in July 2019. The other women who have been promoted to the rank of general are from the military legal corps, the intervention corps, the Army and Air Force engineering corps, and the military audit corps. The latest promotions follow the promotion of Colonel Auditor of the military legal corps, María Rosario Herrera Abián, on 20 March.

title: Elvira Pelet, primera general médico y subdirectora del Hospital Gómez Ulla
summary: Elvira Pelet Pascual ha sido ascendida al rango de General de la Brigada Médica del Cuerpo de Sanidad Militar y nombrada subdirectora del Hospital de la Defensa Gómez Ulla en Madrid. Ella es la primera mujer general médico en el Cuerpo de Sanidad Militar. Maria Rosa García Toledano también ha sido ascendida al mismo rango. Con estas promociones, ahora hay nueve generales mujeres en las Fuerzas Armadas Españolas. Patricia Ortega García fue la primera mujer en lograr el rango de general en la historia de España en 2019.

title: Mujeres militares, 35 años tomando fuerza en la Armada: "De pequeña decía que quería hacer la mili"
summary: The article discusses the evolution of women in the Spanish Armed Forces, with Ana Villalobos, a first corporal in the Navy, and María del Carmen Álvarez, a sailor, discussing their integration and achievements. Patricia Ortega García was the first woman to join the Armed Forces in 1988, paving the way for women to access all ranks and positions. Women currently make up 13% of the military, with 15,864 women registered in 2022. Ana Villalobos, who joined in 1997, has noticed significant changes in the treatment of women during her career. Women have had to adapt to the norms of the military, and have fought for changes such as access to maternity leave and non-simultaneity for couples in the military. The article highlights the increasing number of women joining the military and their integration into the organization.

title: Solicitan colaboración para crear el primer mapa global de las garrapatas de España
summary: The GARES project aims to create the first global map of ticks in Spain and establish a plan for tick monitoring. The project is coordinated by Félix Valcárcel Sancho and Sonia Olmeda García and is funded by the Ministry of Health and the EU through Next Generation Funds. The unique biodiversity of the Iberian Peninsula, as a bridge between Africa and Europe, means that more tick species coexist in a relatively small area than in the rest of Central Europe, leading to a greater variety of transmitted diseases. The lack of consensus and errors in identification have resulted in a false sense of tick distribution in Spain. The GARES project hopes to create a National Expert Group on Ticks and Tick-borne Diseases, complete a national tick map, and improve knowledge of tick-borne diseases. The project invites collaboration from farmers, veterinarians, and researchers to collect tick samples.

title: Cuántas especies de garrapatas hay en España y dónde están las más peligrosas para los humanos
summary: A team of experts, including Ángeles Sonia Olmeda García, from the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine at the Complutense University of Madrid, has launched the Gares project to create the first global and updated map of ticks in Spain. The project aims to improve knowledge of tick species and distribution in Spain, as well as raise awareness among the population of the different types of ticks and their specific characteristics. The project will also help to identify the areas where ticks are most prevalent and the diseases they transmit. Tick-borne diseases such as Lyme disease and viral encephalitis can be transmitted to humans by ticks. The project will also help to identify the areas where ticks are most prevalent and the diseases they transmit.

title: El conseller de Sanidad reclama a la ministra paliar la falta de profesionales en el sistema sanitario
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller of Health, Marciano Gómez, has asked the Minister of Health, Mónica García, to implement measures to address the shortage of healthcare professionals. This is not just a problem in the Valencian Community, but throughout the country. During their meeting, they talked about the need to increase MIR positions and the difficulty in filling certain positions in some health departments. Gómez mentioned that the Valencian Community has requested an increase in the number of residents and specialized healthcare training places on multiple occasions. The minister confirmed that there will be an extraordinary call for MIR positions if there are vacancies after the current allocation process. They also talked about the need to train more professionals, especially in primary care and mental health, to deal with the retirement of professionals and the growing demand for quality healthcare.

title: La memoria de Sanidad contradice la denuncia del conseller Marciano Gómez sobre las pruebas de cáncer de mama
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller of Health of the Valencian Government, Marciano Gómez, has accused the previous team of irregularities in the management of breast cancer screening programs. He claims that only 250,000 women were invited to participate in the program, instead of the 410,000 women who should have been invited. However, data from the Generalitat Valenciana contradicts these claims. The data shows that in the last five years, more than 320,000 valid invitations were sent annually, except in 2020 when the program was suspended due to the pandemic. The program covers women aged 45 to 69, and in 2022, the age range was extended to include women up to 74 years old. The investigation by the Conselleria de Sanidad covers the screening of breast and colon cancer.

title: El conseller de Sanidad destaca que la Comunitat Valenciana está a la cabeza en cubrir las plazas MIR
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller de Sanidad, Marciano Gómez, has said that the Valencian Community is leading Spain in the number of places for resident intern doctors (MIR), with all Family Medicine positions filled and only one vacancy remaining in Preventive Medicine and Public Health. The Ministry of Health made a second call to fill the 473 vacant MIR positions in Spain this year, with 459 of them in Family and Community Medicine. Gómez attributes the success to the region's "capacity of attraction" and high-quality public health system. The Valencian Community offered 844 resident positions this year, including 232 in Family Medicine, all of which have been filled.

title: Sanidad reclama al Ministerio más especialistas ante el déficit de 1.000 médicos en el último lustro
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller of Health in Valencia, Marciano Gómez, has urged the Ministry of Health to provide more medical specialists due to a deficit of 1,000 doctors in the last five years. This lack of medical staff is a structural problem in the Valencian healthcare system and across Spain. The reduction of places for medical residents since 2010 has resulted in 4,813 fewer specialists being trained. Additionally, the high number of doctors approaching retirement age will create a deficit of 1,000 physicians in 2026, according to the latest report from the Official College of Physicians of Valencia. The Ministry of Health is responsible for increasing the number of resident places, while the Valencian Government is responsible for managing healthcare personnel. During a visit to the Clínic hospital in Valencia, both the Minister of Health, Mónica García, and Gómez expressed their willingness to collaborate to tackle this issue.

title: El Conseller de Sanidad Marciano Gómez anuncia que el hospital comarcal tendrá casi 400 camas
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller of Health, Marciano Gómez, has announced an expansion of the Marina Baixa Hospital, which will add almost 400 beds. The new plan involves modifying the Master Plan and adding 113 more beds, bringing the total to nearly 400. The project will require an additional budget of €45 million, making the total investment €102 million. Gómez acknowledges that there may be significant technical difficulties in executing the new project, but he is confident that it will be completed and available by 2028. The Conseller also mentioned that the hospital parking remains a problem and he will speak with the mayor of La Vila, Marcos Zaragoza, to resolve it.

title: Marciano Gómez pide comparecer en Les Corts para explicar la situación del cribado de cáncer
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Conseller of Health, Marciano Gómez, has requested to appear before the plenary of Les Corts Valencianes to explain the situation of the breast cancer screening program, which has been delayed due to political discordance. He publicly denounced that there are more than 150,000 women waiting to be invited to the breast cancer screening program, suffering a delay of three to four years. The President of the Generalitat, Carlos Mazón, has stated that the Fiscalía is investigating this matter and the Conselleria has opened an investigation to determine if there is any responsibility for the 150,000 women who have been excluded from the fight against cancer. The PSPV-PSOE has stated that there is no evidence of these delays and that the intention is to privatize the screening services. Compromís believes that the Conseller is trying to cover up his management errors.

title: El CICU atiende una media de 17 llamadas diarias sobre paradas cardiorrespiratorias
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Center for Information and Coordination of Emergencies (CICU) in Valencia has received an average of 17 calls per day related to cardiac arrest incidents, according to Marciano Gómez, the Conseller of Health. He emphasised the importance of starting resuscitation immediately, as research shows that this can increase the chance of survival by over 50%. The CICU has received 1,894 calls related to cardiac arrest incidents so far this year. During a visit to the I Health Fair in El Genovés, Gómez witnessed a basic cardiopulmonary resuscitation workshop for children aged between 6 and 14, which was led by professionals from the Emergency Health Service of the Valencian Community. The aim of the workshop was to teach the basic cardiac massage or cardiopulmonary resuscitation, the use of an automatic defibrillator, and the Heimlich manoeuvre to prevent choking leading to cardiac arrest.

title: Marciano Gómez afirma que la transición en el Hospital de Dénia está siendo "ordenada y serena"
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The transition of the Hospital de Dénia to public management is proceeding in an organized and peaceful manner, as stated by Marciano Gómez, the Conseller de Sanidad. He mentioned that there is continuous and smooth communication with the workers, and the transition is being carried out without any disruptions or changes in working conditions. The hospital professionals can be confident that their working conditions will remain the same, and they will receive a salary from Sanidad. The Conselleria's objective is to standardize the legal regimes of the staff to have equal status and rights. The transition will occur on February 1, and the Conselleria will be present to ensure that the objectives are achieved.

title: Elena Gras será la directora general de Farmacia de la Comunidad Valenciana | @diariofarma
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: Elena Gras has been appointed as the new Director General of Pharmacy for the Valencia region in Spain. Gras is a hospital pharmacist who has worked at various hospitals and institutes, and has a number of postgraduate qualifications in areas such as pharmaceutical oncology, rare diseases, and research methodology. The appointment was made as part of the restructuring of the Valencia government's health department, with two secretariats being created: one for Health, led by Francisco José Ponce Lorenzo, and one for Planning, Information, and Digital Transformation, headed by Bernardo Valdivieso Martinez. Gras will head the Directorate General of Pharmacy.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The Canarian Health Service (SCS) and the Valencian Community have presented the results of the BigData Personalized Medicine project, which aims to develop a mobile application based on artificial intelligence for the continuous monitoring of chronic pathologies at home and in the screening of emergency prioritization, among other aspects. The SCS led this initiative, carried out jointly with the Valencian Ministry of Universal Health and Public Health, in the framework of the FID Health Program of the Ministry of Science and Innovation. The project has a budget of €5.8 million, of which the Canaries have assumed €3.8 million (co-financed by FEDER at 85%) and the Valencian Community €2 million (co-financed by FEDER at 50%). Bernardo Valdivieso Martinez, a researcher at the La Fe Health Research Institute, was one of the professionals who participated in the event.

title: La UMH, en cólera (de nuevo) con el Consell por negarle impartir Enfermería: "Hay doble rasero"
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: The rector of the University Miguel Hernández (UMH) in Elche, Juan José Ruiz Martínez, has expressed his institution's "repulsion" at the "unjustifiable, belated and untimely decision of the Valencian Government to deny the Nursing degree at the UMH." The decision was made last Friday, 7 July, by the General Directorate of Universities of the Valencian Government, which issued a negative report with "scant and totally unsustainable justifications." Ruiz Martínez has highlighted that, unlike in Medicine, where there is a surplus of graduates, there is a shortage of nurses in Spain. The General Council of Official Colleges of Nursing has recently reported that Spain needs more than 95,000 nurses, and that the shortage of nurses in almost all of the autonomous communities jeopardises citizens' health. The UMH has filed a lawsuit against the Valencian Government's decree creating the Medicine degree, which the UMH claims contravenes Spanish law.

title: Dilemma Lab, una 'startup' entre la UMH y la URJC que desarrolla IA para el sector salud
hco: FUNDACIÓN ISABIALFUNDACIÓN DE LA COMUNITAT VALENCIAPARA LA GESTIÓN DE INSTITUTO DEINVESTIGACIÓN SANITARIA Y BIOMÉDICA
summary: Dilemma Lab is a startup that develops intelligent algorithms and data science products for various sectors, with a focus on the healthcare industry. The company was founded in 2022 by three researchers from the Universidad Rey Juan Carlos de Madrid and the UMH, including Francisco Javier Gimeno, José Luis Rojo, and Sergio Muñoz. The company offers services in data analysis, machine learning, artificial intelligence, business consulting, and TICs and biomedical engineering projects. The startup is a spin-off created by the UMH's Department of Communications Engineering professor, Francisco Javier Gimeno, and is particularly focused on the healthcare sector. The company is a part of the Parque Científico UMH, which houses over 100 innovative firms, including Blockiure and Dilemma Lab. The Parque Científico UMH aims to foster knowledge exchange between the university and the business world.

title: Oblio oncologico, Guido Liris: Una rivoluzione che cancella molte ingiustizie
summary: Guido Liris, a senator and coordinator of the "La Salute, un bene da difendere, un diritto da promuovere" group, has been honored with the Cancer Policy Award for his efforts in supporting cancer patients. The Cancer Policy Forum, organized by the same group, discussed the challenges faced by cancer patients, including delays and disparities in treatment. Liris emphasized his work in promoting interventions such as the establishment of a fund for oncological diseases, the right to oblio oncologico (the right to be forgotten after having cancer), and the inclusion of patient associations in legislative processes. He emphasized the importance of investing in oncological care and early diagnosis for both the patient's quality of life and the state's savings. The Cancer Policy Award recognizes politicians who defend the rights of cancer patients and their access to healthcare.

title: Contact Center Tecnocall, Liris: “Ok alla clausola sociale per i dipendenti”
summary: The Italian Senate has approved a social clause to protect the workers of call center Tecnocall. Guido Senatore, a member of Fratelli d'Italia, played a significant role in its approval. The clause will prevent job loss for the 117 Tecnocall employees. The decree's approval will now pass to the Chamber of Deputies. The clause was added in response to the risk of layoffs due to the transition of the energy market from a protected to a liberalized one. Tecnocall's employees are just one part of approximately 1,000 employees at risk of losing their jobs due to the transition.

title: Post sisma Marche, il commissario: "Superbonus salvo, ecco 400 milioni per i terremotati"
summary: Guido Senatore, the commissioner for post-earthquake reconstruction, has confirmed that the Superbonus scheme, which provides tax incentives for building renovations, is still available for those affected by the 2016 and 2009 earthquakes. He stated that a ceiling of €400 million has been set for the scheme, with €330 million allocated to the 2016 earthquake and €70 million to the 2009 earthquake. Senatore believes that the limit will be sufficient, as the state paid out €260 million for the Superbonus scheme in 2023 alone. He also stated that there are still 18,000 reconstruction projects outstanding, and that he hopes to have all displaced people back in their homes by 2024.

title: La Alianza #CEOPorLaDiversidad aborda el talento de la generación Z y su irrupción en el mercado laboral
summary: The #CEOPorLaDiversidad Alliance, which is supported by the Adecco Foundation and the CEOE Foundation, organized its yearly CEO meeting to discuss the role of Generation Z in today's society and business environment. The meeting focused on the characteristics of this new workforce, which includes their digital DNA, global vision, commitment to diversity, and environmental awareness. Representatives from 27 companies, such as Accenture, BASF, Siemens, and BBVA, among others, attended the meeting. The Alliance aims to bring together the top management of companies in Spain with a shared and innovative vision of diversity, equity, and inclusion, encouraging them to promote strategies that contribute to business excellence, inclusion, sustainability, and competitiveness. The meeting also featured young influencers Andrea Ramos and Alan "El Ruedas" and philosopher Diego S. Garrocho, who shared their views on the world and the company. Carles Navarro Vigo, CEO of BASF Spain, is one of the 81 companies and CEOs that form part of this alliance.

title: Cristina Henríquez de Luna: «Los grandes avances llegan al unir ciencia y tecnología»
summary: Cristina Henríquez de Luna, the President and CEO of GSK Spain, emphasizes the importance of combining science and technology to make significant advances in medicine. GSK has focused on research and development to become a bio-pharmaceutical company that focuses on the prevention and treatment of infectious, respiratory, oncologic, and immune-mediated diseases. GSK's priority is to offer vaccines and medicines using the science of the immune system, human genetics, and advanced technologies to find solutions for unmet needs in diseases. The company also aims to operate responsibly and sustainably, prioritizing innovation and making a positive impact on the health of more than 2.5 billion people before 2030. Henríquez de Luna believes that combining genetics, genomics, and Artificial Intelligence with Machine Learning can help develop better medicines in the future. GSK is also making progress in the fields of oncology and HIV, and the company is committed to improving access to innovation and healthcare.

title: GSK reafirma su compromiso con la SEFH con el fin de promover la formación continuada
summary: GSK and the Spanish Society of Hospital Pharmacy (SEFH) have signed a collaboration agreement to promote the continued education of hospital pharmacists in Spain. The aim of the agreement is to provide specialized knowledge to prepare students for public job offers in different regions. The collaboration also includes courses to prepare for the BPS certificate in Oncology. GSK's CEO, Cristina Henríquez de Luna, said that the agreement exemplifies their commitment to collaboration with hospital pharmacy, a key point of union between different hospital services, management, and patients. The collaboration expands their current alliance with SEFH. The agreement promotes projects such as FHarmateca, a library of specialized knowledge. GSK believes that collaboration with different sector agents is fundamental to advance faster in their goal of making innovative treatments and vaccines available to society to improve people's quality of life.

title: La Liga F y GSK se dan la mano: el deporte, antes, durante y tras un cáncer ginecológico, es clave
summary: GSK and La Liga F organized a roundtable discussion called "Caminando hacia la Esperanza: mujer, deporte y cáncer" to promote the importance of sports in a healthy lifestyle and cancer prevention, particularly gynecological tumors. The event aimed to raise awareness about the role of physical activity before and after cancer diagnosis. The president and CEO of GSK Spain, Cristina Henríquez de Luna, highlighted the importance of sports in transforming cancer into hope and focusing on prevention. The roundtable also discussed how physical activity and healthy habits can reduce the chances of developing cancer by 30%. Virginia Torrecilla, a former professional football player and cancer survivor, emphasized the importance of sports during her chemotherapy and recovery. The event coincided with the World Day of Sport on April 6.

title: Las farmacéuticas innovadoras, un modelo a seguir: el 67% de sus investigadores son mujeres
summary: The pharmaceutical industry has become a role model for the inclusion of women in biomedical research and development, with women occupying 67% of positions in research departments of innovative pharmaceutical companies, which is higher than the 53% of women employed in the sector as a whole. The industry is committed to gender equality and promoting female talent, with higher rates of women in leadership positions compared to other industries. The high level of employment quality and qualifications in the industry is noteworthy, with 64.4% of professionals holding degrees, rising to 90% in the area of research and development. Cristina Henríquez de Luna, President of GSK Spain, is one of many women leading companies in the sector. The pharmaceutical industry is considered a leader in diversity and equality and could serve as a model for other sectors in the country.

title: Cuatro microbiólogos del Hospital Gregorio Marañón, entre los 100 mejores de España
summary: Four doctors from the Microbiology and Infectious Diseases Service of the Gregorio Marañón University Hospital have been ranked among the top 100 in Spain, according to the prestigious Microbiology ranking by research.com. Emilio Bouza, a researcher at the center, is ranked second nationally, and Patricia Muñoz, the current head of the service, is ranked ninth. Juan Berenguer and Jesús Guinea also made the list at 61st and 98th place, respectively. The Microbiology and Infectious Diseases Service at the Gregorio Marañón University Hospital is directed by Dr. Patricia Muñoz, who is also among the top specialists worldwide in her field. The service has a team of 30 attending physicians, 13 residents, 26 nurses, 17 TCAEs, 30 laboratory technicians, and 8 administrators.

title: Emilio Bouza presidirá el comité científico covid-19 del Icomem
summary: Emilio Bouza, who previously headed the Clinical Microbiology Service at Gregorio Marañón Hospital in Madrid, will lead the new Covid-19 scientific committee of the Icomem. The committee has released its initial guidelines regarding the flu vaccine.

title: GSK visibiliza la enfermedad renal crónica en el Día Mundial del Riñón
summary: GSK has undertaken several initiatives to increase awareness about the significance of kidney health and enhance the approach towards chronic kidney disease (CKD) on the occasion of World Kidney Day. One such initiative was participation in a radio program that aimed to raise awareness about kidney diseases and featured experts like José María Portolés, head of nephrology at the Puerta de Hierro University Hospital in Madrid, and Daniel Gallego, president of the federation of patient associations ALCER and a kidney patient. María José Muñoz Juárez, medical director of GSK Spain, Portugal, and Israel, declared that the company is dedicated to nephrology and renal patients and collaborates with professionals, health authorities, and patient associations to spread knowledge about these diseases and better the lives of those affected. GSK's campaign, "The Red Line of Renal Anemia," developed in collaboration with the National Institute of Renal Anemia (INAR), aims to raise awareness among the general public about the importance of controlling hemoglobin levels in individuals with CKD.

title: Guía gratuita para enfermeras sobre vacunación en adultos
summary: The General Council of Nursing, in collaboration with GSK and the National Association of Nursing and Vaccines, has released a free guide for nurses on vaccinating healthy adults. The guide offers practical recommendations on vaccination principles, complete vaccination procedures, types of vaccines, and vaccination schedules throughout life. It also includes tools to promote vaccination and emphasizes the significance of staying current with vaccination calendars in healthy adults, as vaccination is a crucial aspect of public health. The guide was created by nursing professionals to reinforce the importance of vaccination in healthy adults and to prevent avoidable diseases. The guide was distributed for free, and it is expected to provide dependable information to enhance knowledge in the field of vaccination. María José Muñoz Juárez, Medical Director of GSK in Spain, stressed the importance of vaccination for healthy aging.

title: 'Sound of Freedom' Investor Arrested for Child Kidnapping
summary: Fabian Marta, a financial donor who supported the production of the anti-child trafficking movie, Sound of Freedom, has been arrested for child kidnapping. On July 23, Marta was arrested and charged with this felony offense. He was one of the many individuals who donated to the crowdfunding efforts for the film. Sound of Freedom is a movie that heavily dramatizes the work of anti-trafficking organization, Operation Underground Railroad, and its founder, Tim Ballard, who is portrayed by Passion of the Christ star Jim Caviezel. Marta was credited in the film as an "investor" who helped bring the movie to theaters. His bail has been set at $15,000, and his next court date is scheduled for August 28. However, details about his case remain unclear.

title: Sanitarios analizarán casos reales de pacientes en el Congreso Valenciano de Reumatología
summary: Sanitary professionals will analyze real cases of patients at the Valencian Congress of Rheumatology, which will be attended by 120 rheumatologists and specialized nurses in rheumatology on April 28 and 29 at the headquarters of the Official College of Physicians of Valencia. The congress will feature approximately 40 experts specialized in the field of rheumatology as speakers, who will discuss the latest advances in the diagnosis and treatment of rheumatic diseases. The first day of the congress will end with a session focused on psoriatic arthritis, moderated by Dr. Antonio Álvarez de Cienfuegos, where the evolution of the disease, implications in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and the use of upadacitinib and risankizumab in treatment will be discussed.

title: laura maria gonzalez cultivates sustainable biocement from microbes for exhibition at MIT
summary: Laura Maria Gonzalez has created biocement from microbes for an exhibition at MIT's Keller Gallery. The exhibition, titled Microbes Make Mountains, showcases the intersection of design and microbial life, exploring the hidden artistry of ancient communities and their potential to influence design concepts. Gonzalez's biocement is a sustainable alternative to traditional concrete, produced through a delicate act of cultivation and creation. The process involves nurturing bacteria, which are then introduced into specially designed 3D-printed molds filled with an aggregate mineral mixture. The addition of urea and calcium creates an environment conducive to the formation of calcium carbonate crystals, resulting in a series of biocemented spheres. The exhibition also presents two prototype sculptures to demonstrate the roles of iron and copper in the biocementation process. The project is funded by the Council for the Arts at MIT and the MIT Department of Architecture.

title: Dr. Laura Carlin-Gonzalez named Executive Director of Teaching and Learning
summary: Dr. Laura Carlin-Gonzalez has been appointed as the Executive Director of Teaching and Learning in Round Rock ISD. She will supervise the district's teaching and learning programs, including curriculum, advanced academics, professional development, and career and technical education. Dr. Carlin-Gonzalez is an experienced educational leader with more than 16 years of experience, having worked as a high school principal, assistant principal, instructional specialist, and math teacher. She holds a Doctorate of Education in educational leadership and policy from the University of Texas at Austin’s Cooperative Superintendency Program, and certifications as a Texas superintendent, principal, and secondary mathematics teacher. Her contributions will play a vital role in ensuring students and staff receive the necessary support for sustained educational excellence.

title: Ciclo de charlas "Ateneas": "Una epidemia de pezqueñines", por Lucía López
summary: Lucía López will be giving a talk titled "An Epidemic of Small Fish" as part of the "Ateneas" lecture series organized by the Instituto de Física de Cantabria (IFCA) in collaboration with the Ateneo de Santander. The talk will take place on February 28, 2024, and will explore the alarming decrease in the size of commercial fish in recent decades. López will present her recent work on the effects of fishing and warming waters on the size of fish, how size relates to other characteristics of the life cycle, and how changes in size can affect species relationships and modify the structure of the marine ecosystem as a whole. López is a researcher at the Oceanographic Center of Santander (IEO, CSIC) where she studies the impacts of human activities on the structure and functioning of marine ecosystems. She is committed to the training of young researchers and promoting scientific and oceanic culture through various outreach activities. The talk is free and open to the public.

title: Nigeria, U.S., 16 Others Converge On Spain For Road Safety Conference - News Agency Of Nigeria
summary: Young leaders from 18 countries, including Nigeria and the United States, have been selected to participate in the 2023 Youth for Road Safety and the Global Youth Coalition for Road Safety (YOURS) Leadership Retreat in Spain. The retreat is focused on building new skills in tackling the biggest killer of young people globally and is supported by Spain’s Fundacion MAPFRE, which will host the training at its Madrid headquarters, with the support of TotalEnergies Foundation and MICHELIN Corporate Foundation. Raquel Barrios, the Executive Director of YOURS, said that the 23 young leaders are active community leaders leading road safety actions, interventions, and advocacy. The retreat is the first of its kind and will be an excellent occasion for the youth to enhance their skills, build networks, and contribute meaningfully to the decision-making process of road management.

title: Spain's Horizons Optical raised funds to develop and distribute tech for ophthalmic industry
summary: Spain's Horizons Optical has obtained new funding from London's Oakley Capital to create and distribute technology for the ophthalmic industry. Oakley Capital's Origin Fund I will gain a majority stake in Horizons Optical, while CEO Santiago Soler will retain a significant share and continue to lead the company. Horizons Optical creates exclusive and patented software that is used by independent laboratories worldwide to produce customised 'progressive' lenses that can correct various eye conditions. The company asserts that the lenses made with its technology are situated within the optical industry's most valuable segments. Using Horizons Optical's technology, 10 million lenses were produced in 2023 alone. Furthermore, Horizons Optical provides opticians with equipment that can scan consumers' faces and measure significant facial parameters, making it easier to produce customised lenses and frames.

title: Oakley Capital Buying Stake In Horizons Optical Through Deal With Sherpa Capital
summary: Oakley Capital Origin Fund I is investing in Horizons Optical, a Barcelona-based company that provides medical software for making premium spectacle lenses. The deal involves Oakley buying a majority stake in the business along with CEO Santiago Soler, who will retain a significant share in the operation and continue leading Horizons. Oakley is acquiring the shares in Horizons that are owned by Sherpa Capital. Horizons’ proprietary and patented software is used by independent laboratories worldwide to manufacture bespoke progressive lenses that can correct a range of eye conditions. Lenses manufactured through Horizons’ patented technology are positioned in the optical industry’s higher-value-added segments. Last year, about 10 million lenses were produced with Horizons’ technology. Horizons also sells equipment for opticians that can scan consumers’ faces and measure relevant facial parameters to manufacture lenses and frames. Horizons has a strong track record of generating double-digit revenue growth.

title: Metas ambiciosas para ofrecer una mejor calidad de vida a los pacientes de enfermedades inflamatorias intestinales
summary: Experts in the field of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are calling for a joint approach to tackle the complex autoimmune conditions, which affect around 360,000 people in Spain. While there is no known cure for IBD, advances in treatment have helped patients manage their symptoms and improve their quality of life. Two types of IBD are recognised: ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease. Francisco Mesonero, a gastroenterologist and member of the IBD unit at the Ramón y Cajal University Hospital, said there was no difference in severity between the two. Mesonero added that the medical community was aiming to improve the quality of life of patients with more ambitious goals, such as finding an effective treatment for the complete healing of intestinal mucosa, which would reduce hospitalisation and surgery.

title: Doce profesionales con discapacidad protagonizan el calendario 2023 de Fundación Adecco para promover la ...
summary: Twelve professionals with disabilities are showcased in the 2023 calendar of the Adecco Foundation to promote labor inclusion. The campaign, with the hashtag #ThePowerOfExample, aims to highlight real-life success stories of people with disabilities who have secured employment. The calendar features 12 inspiring stories that serve as a source of motivation for those who face challenges, their families, and those who work with them. Each month is dedicated to a professional with disabilities who works in various fields, representing the talent of the 4.2 million people with disabilities in Spain. The calendar features some of the Foundation's ambassadors, including actor Javi Martín, digital influencer and announcer Caterina Moretti, coach Avi Mashiah, athlete Carmen Giménez, and the first European graduate with Down syndrome, Pablo Pineda. Francisco Mesonero, director general of the Adecco Foundation, stresses the importance of showcasing the potential and talent of people with disabilities and the need to accelerate their social inclusion.

title: Lourdes López Named Top 100 Latina Powerhouse 2023
summary: Lourdes López, the art director of the Miami City Ballet, has been named one of the most influential people in dance by Dance magazine. She began her career at the age of five and attended the School of American Ballet in New York City on a full scholarship. López became the first Latina dancer at the New York City Ballet and the only Latin American dancer to be named prima ballerina. After retiring from dancing, López continued to impact the dance industry as the executive director at the George Balanchine Foundation, co-founder of The Cuban Artists Fund, and co-founder of Morphoses. She has also produced various art segments aired on WNBC-TV New York and was awarded the “A Life for Dance” award by the International Ballet Festival of Miami. López's legacy in the dance scene is still felt today.

title: Miguel Rodríguez-Piñero, nombrado doctor Honoris Causa por la UNIA
summary: Miguel Rodríguez-Piñero, a jurist and former president of the Constitutional Court of Spain, has been awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Andalusia for his contributions to science, research, and culture. The investiture will take place at the UNIA's Santa María de la Rábida headquarters.

title: Sánchez de León, primer ministro de Sanidad: "Actualmente vivimos una epidemia de inmoralidad"
summary: Enrique Sánchez de León, the first Minister of Health and Social Security in Spain's democracy, has stated in an interview that there is currently an epidemic of immorality in society. He believes that the polarization in politics is a consequence of a society that has lost its way and that the values of respect and coexistence are essential. Sánchez de León also criticizes the state of the Spanish healthcare system, stating that hospital care is inadequate and that primary care is lacking in the most basic elements such as patient proximity. He also believes that the polarization of politics has led to an increase in the use of the term "fascist" and that the term has lost its meaning. Sánchez de León also discusses his career and his views on politics and society.

title: ‘Máster’ en la piscina y también en la batalla contra el cáncer
summary: Enrique Sánchez de León is the head of Radiation Oncology at the Caule University Hospital in León, Spain. He also competes in master swimming championships for those over 55 years old. He has won medals in various competitions and considers swimming to be an excellent exercise for older people as it does not damage joints, reducing the risk of joint or muscle injuries. He also highlights the benefits of exercise as a preventive factor against cancer, especially for common types such as breast or prostate cancer. The Hospital de León has protocols in place to improve physical activity for cancer patients to prevent other events such as osteoporosis. Sánchez de León believes that winning a tournament is an incentive to continue swimming and training.

title: Yolanda Lozano, la enfermera que más sabe en Juaneda Hospitales a la hora de pinchar y colocar vías en casos complejos
summary: Yolanda Lozano is a nurse at Juaneda Hospitals who is recognized as an expert in placing and puncturing veins in complex cases. She has become an expert in the field of canalizing venous, peripheral, or analytical pathways in difficult cases. Her experience has enabled her to solve very complex cases, and she is passionate about developing and expanding her knowledge every day. Yolanda shares her experience with her colleagues, encouraging them to take on challenging cases. Her expertise allows her to avoid having to refer patients to operating rooms or other services, which can delay the patient's treatment. Yolanda's skills and experience have made her a true artist in her field, and she is committed to providing the best care possible to her patients.

title: El cambio drástico en el comedor de 11 colegios alaveses: "Es un alivio, estábamos muy preocupados"
summary: The government of the Basque Country has announced that catering company Serunion will no longer manage school meals in 11 educational centres in Álava from Monday 5 February. Parents and teachers had been demanding that meals be cooked in each school or neighbourhood using local produce. Families had been eating twice a week in the school canteen in Durana to monitor the quality of the food from Serunion, which had been fined €40,000 ($49,000) by the Basque government. Parents and teachers at three schools in Salburua have called for professional kitchens to be installed in one of the area's empty buildings.

title: Best Mentors: Raquel Fernandez's Mentorship Comes From the Heart | Daily Business Review
summary: Raquel Fernandez is a civil litigator who joined Bilzin Sumberg five years ago. She is now the head of the firm's "Matters of the Heart" pro bono initiative. Fernandez believes that treating people with care and respect breeds loyalty, which is the most important leadership lesson she has learned. She also emphasizes the importance of listening to mentees' concerns and providing specific, practical advice rather than generalities. Face-to-face interactions are important for staying connected to mentors over time and locations. Fernandez meets one of her most important mentors, Rick Dunn, for breakfast once a week.

title: Lola Manterola, fundadora de CRIS Contra el Cáncer: “Si mi marido no me hubiese metido en un ensayo clínico me ...
hco: FUNDACION CRIS DE INVESTIGACIONPARA VENCER EL CANCEROx
summary: Lola Manterola, founder of CRIS Contra el Cáncer, shares her personal experience with cancer and the importance of supporting medical researchers. Her husband's research and connections helped her access a clinical trial that saved her life and inspired them to start the foundation, which has raised €50 million for cancer research. They use a model of philanthropy similar to the Anglo-Saxon approach, with private galas to raise funds for patients of all economic backgrounds. The foundation has supported 468 clinical trials, helped 65 institutions and benefited over 6,000 patients. Manterola emphasizes the need for more funding for cancer research and the importance of supporting excellent medical researchers. She hopes to see a day when cancer can be controlled with a pill.

title: FUNDACIÓN GONZALO RODRÍGUEZ– Promoting Safe and Healthy Mobility in Uruguay
hco: FUNDACION CRIS DE INVESTIGACIONPARA VENCER EL CANCEROx
summary: The Fundación Gonzalo Rodríguez is a non-profit organization in Latin America and the Caribbean that aims to eliminate serious injuries and deaths from traffic accidents by promoting safe and healthy mobility. The foundation collaborates with the Pan American Health Organization (PAHO) in Uruguay to reduce the burden that traffic accidents place on the country's health systems. They work together to create and disseminate relevant knowledge and promote regulations and public policy on road safety. The collaboration has generated knowledge based on documenting good practices and lessons learned to make the best possible evidence in decision-making processes available to those making and monitoring public policy. Fundación Gonzalo Rodríguez is a key partner for PAHO in meeting the goal of preventing and tracking the number of traffic-related deaths and injuries in the Americas.

title: “Ad without AI”, un sello para identificar el trabajo humano detrás de los anuncios
hco: FUNDACION CRIS DE INVESTIGACIONPARA VENCER EL CANCEROx
summary: Gonzalo Rodriguez de Marichalar, Creative Team Lead at Palladium, has created "Ad without AI", a label that recognizes the human work behind each advertisement. The idea arose from observing the potential of the images created by Sora, OpenAI's artificial intelligence model for generating videos from text instructions. The evolution of technology makes it difficult to identify creations made with AI, so Gonzalo has created this freely available label for professionals and agencies to naturally include in their ads to convey to viewers that the piece has been created with human talent. This label is an honest distinctive that recognizes the completely human work behind each advertisement.

title: Coyotes, Equality Health Kick Off Partnership with Youth Hockey Clinic | Arizona Coyotes
summary: The Arizona Coyotes and Equality Health have teamed up to organize a ball hockey clinic for students at Irene Lopez Elementary School. The "Raise the Pack" initiative will provide a curriculum to Physical Education teachers at 614 schools across the state. The Coyotes' hockey development team will also create a Valley-wide ball hockey league to make it easier to get into the sport. The partnership between the two organizations extends beyond the CSHL, as Equality Health is the official partner of the Arizona Coyotes Street Hockey League. This partnership is the largest initiative of its kind in the NHL, and Coyotes President and CEO Xavier A. Gutierrez said the two organizations will continue to expand the "Raise the Pack" curriculum, which served over 7,000 students last year. Equality Health and the Arizona Coyotes are donating $1,000 worth of equipment to all participating schools as part of the partnership.

title: “Refugees in Greece have become secondary, although more people are starting to arrive”
summary: Irene López, a Christian teacher at the school in Mavrovouni camp in Lesbos, discusses the current situation of refugees and their needs. The camp has a population of approximately 2,000 people, with up to 22 nationalities represented. The majority of refugees come from Afghanistan, followed by Somalia and Sudan. The new camp is currently under construction in the centre of Lesbos, which will improve many of the conditions of the facilities, but it will also make the camp residents much more isolated from the population centres and their services. The situation in Lesbos has become secondary, despite more people arriving, due to the conflict in Ukraine taking the media spotlight. López works at the school for children in the camp, run by the Christian-inspired organisation Eurorelief, which is developing a curriculum to teach English that has been created specifically for the refugee camp.

title: Pide José Luis Luege, declarar desastre por sequía en el Valle de México
summary: José Luis Luege, the former head of Mexico's National Water Commission (CONAGUA), has called for the extreme drought situation in the Valley of Mexico to be declared a natural disaster. Luege cited the 2023 drought as the worst in recorded history, with national dams at less than 50% capacity on average and the Cutzamala reservoir at a critical level of 38%. The lack of rainfall means that there is no possibility of bringing water to the Valley of Mexico until at least May, and possibly not even in April. Luege stated that the CONAGUA and the State Water Commission of the State of Mexico have decided to rehabilitate and drill wells to extract water from the aquifer, but this cannot be done due to a lack of resources. He called for a change in water policy and for urgent government support.

title: Local breast cancer survivor stresses importance of screenings
summary: Ana Castillo, a breast cancer survivor in Las Vegas, emphasizes the importance of timely breast cancer screenings, particularly for Hispanic women who tend to be diagnosed at later stages of the disease than non-Hispanic women. Dr. Arsalan Salamat, director of breast care for Optum Care, states that Hispanic women are usually diagnosed later and with tumors that are larger and more aggressive, making treatment more difficult. Castillo encourages all women, including her own family, to undergo regular breast cancer screenings. Early detection is critical in improving outcomes, despite socioeconomic and practical barriers to screening. Dr. Salamat recommends that women of average risk start annual mammograms, preferably the 3D type, at age 40. Castillo had a mammogram in November last year, and was diagnosed with cancer in February. She began treatment and completed chemotherapy in July. Today, she continues her treatment and feels well.

title: Bloomberg-Harvard City Leadership Initiative Brings Ana Castillo Romero to Paterson
summary: Ana Castillo Romero, a graduate alumna from Harvard University, has joined the Sayegh Administration as part of the Bloomberg Harvard City Leadership Initiative. The fellowship program places highly skilled graduate students in key leadership positions within local governments to tackle pressing challenges. Castillo's mission is to enhance Paterson's processes for development projects and revitalize blighted areas, and she brings a wealth of experience and enthusiasm to the role. Castillo's commitment to public service continued to flourish as she worked in various roles within the public sector, including the Ministry of Economy and Finance, where she gained insights into budget planning and investment. Castillo's fellowship in Paterson is a result of a unique partnership between Harvard University and the Bloomberg Philanthropies, which aims to provide funding for leadership development in local governments.

title: The enigma of the girl who turns into bone while her identical twin remains healthy
summary: Twelve-year-old twin sisters Cayetana and Celia share the same genetic mutation, but only one of them suffers from an extremely rare disease called progressive osseous heteroplasia, which turns muscle into bony plaques. Cayetana’s muscles are quickly turning into bone, and a year and a half ago, she requested that both her legs, already petrified, be amputated to make her life easier. Pediatrician Federico Martinón Torres co-leads the medical team that works to understand why the disease has it in for one sister and respects the other. Celia could hide the secret, or at least a clue, to cure the pathology. The researchers believe that the two sisters share the same mutation, but Cayetana also has an imprint that causes the GNAS gene to be activated or deactivated in certain parts of her body. This is what scientists call mosaicism: the girl would have two types of cells, each with a different epigenetic composition. The team has already looked for these epigenetic differences in the blood of the twins.

title: Celebradas las XV Jornadas de Inmunizaciones de la AEP en Girona, junto con la Societat Catalana de Pediatria
summary: The XV Immunization Conference of the Spanish Association of Pediatrics (AEP) was held in Girona, in conjunction with the Catalan Society of Pediatrics. The conference was well-attended both in person and online, and all presentations and videos are now available for public viewing. The conference also paid tribute to M.ª José Cilleruelo Ortega and Luis Ortigosa del Castillo for their contributions to the AEP's Advisory Committee on Vaccines. The AEP is accredited by the Committee for Continuing Education of Health Professionals of the National Health System. The CAV-AEP hopes to receive feedback from participants to plan future conferences.

title: Luis Ortigosa: "Se ha dado un salto gigante en proteger a la infancia con vacunas"
summary: Luis Ortigosa, a pediatrician and member of the Vaccine Advisory Committee in the Canary Islands, has praised the recent additions to the vaccine schedule for all ages, including the administration of the human papillomavirus vaccine to adolescent boys and a protection against the Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in infants. The RSV protection is not a vaccine but a monoclonal antibody for at-risk children and infants born during the RSV season. The vaccine for the flu will also now be administered to children from six months to five years of age. Ortigosa believes that these vaccines will be effective in preventing disease and reducing the burden on public health systems. The pediatrician also called for vigilance in ensuring that infant foods are free of potentially toxic substances.

title: Portal de Noticias del Gobierno de Canarias
summary: The Canarian Health Service has purchased 12,050 doses of the monoclonal antibody nirsevimab, which is effective against the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), at a cost of €2,518,450. The campaign will start on October 5th, and health center professionals will contact parents of vulnerable infants to schedule vaccination appointments. RSV is highly contagious and is the main cause of acute respiratory tract infections in children under one year of age. Until now, there was no general pharmacological prevention measure, such as vaccines, available. Luis Ortigosa, a pediatrician, stated that RSV has been a concern for the medical community since the virus was discovered in 1955, but only now is there an effective preventive measure. The new monoclonal antibody requires only one injection in neonates and infants and is intended for everyone.

title: “Hay que estar preparados ante las futuras pandemias, serán inevitables”
summary: Experts gathered at the Real Sociedad Económica de Amigos del País de Tenerife to discuss whether we are prepared for future pandemics. The panel included Luis Ortigosa, a member of the Canary Islands Vaccination Technical Group, who highlighted the importance of vaccines and global cooperation in addressing health emergencies. Basilio Valladares, founder of the Institute of Tropical Diseases and Public Health, emphasized the need for technological readiness and a strengthened public health system. Carmelo Rivero, Deputy Editor of DIARIO DE AVISOS, discussed the role of the media in combating misinformation during the pandemic. The panel agreed that while lessons had been learned from the COVID-19 pandemic, there were still challenges to overcome in preparing for future outbreaks, including political polarization, the impact of climate change, and the need for better education and collaboration among citizens.

title: Canarias inmunizará contra el virus que produce las bronquiolitis
summary: Canarias will be the fourth autonomous community in Spain to initiate a campaign to protect against the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), which produces most bronchiolitis cases. The campaign will use a monoclonal antibody (nirsevimab) to protect children under 6 months old. The strategy will be implemented in two ways: at primary care centers for those born from April 1, 2023, to October 7, 2023, and at hospitals for those born from October 7, 2023, to March 30, 2024. The campaign will cost €2,518,450 for the purchase of 12,050 doses. The pediatrics community is satisfied with the strategy, as RSV can cause significant inflammation in the lower respiratory tract and lead to hospitalizations. The campaign's protocol originated from the vaccine experts' group of the autonomous community. Pediatrician Luis Ortigosa has explained that it is not a vaccine but a direct injection of antibodies.

title: Ruiz Highlights Community Efforts at UNC Chatham Hospital in Improving Rural Maternity Care | Newsroom
summary: Jesus Ruiz, MD, who is an assistant professor of family medicine, has written an article in the Annals of Family Medicine about UNC Chatham Hospital's Maternity Care Center. The article is titled "Closing the Gap: How a Community Effort Can Improve Rural Maternity Care," and it discusses the collaboration between UNC Chatham Hospital, UNC Family Medicine, the Chatham Health Department, nonprofits, and local and state organizations to establish a Level-1 maternity care center in 2020. The center provides patient-centered, culturally and linguistically appropriate care to the local community to address barriers to care for pregnant individuals in rural areas. The innovative model of care, with an emphasis on continuity and community delivery, has garnered positive patient satisfaction and brought attention to health inequities, leading to increased support and resources for the community.

title: Miguel Angel Lopez provisionally suspended by UCI over a 'potential anti-doping rule violation'
summary: Cycling's world governing body, the UCI, has provisionally suspended Miguel Angel Lopez from racing due to a "potential anti-doping rule violation" that is said to have come before the 2022 Giro d'Italia, a race that the Colombian withdrew from on Stage 4. The UCI said that Lopez has been notified of a potential ADRV for use and possession of a prohibited substance in the weeks prior to the Giro d'Italia 2022. The UCI has decided to provisionally suspend the rider pending the final decision. Lopez had his contract with Astana Qazaqstan terminated in December 2022 because of what they called a "probable connection" with Dr Marcos Maynar, who was being investigated as part of a doping scandal. Lopez has consistently maintained his innocence, and he later announced he would be taking his former employers to the Court of Arbitration for Sport.

title: Miguel Angel Lopez provisionally suspended by UCI
summary: Miguel Angel Lopez, a Colombian cyclist, has been provisionally suspended by the UCI due to possible violations of anti-doping rules. The International Testing Agency (ITA) suspects Lopez of using a banned substance in the weeks leading up to the 2022 Giro d’Italia. The UCI's decision was prompted by recent ITA research into Dr. Marcos Maynar, who was arrested for drug trafficking and money laundering. Maynar was charged with a crime against public health, and the ITA used evidence from the Spanish Guardia Civil and the Spanish anti-doping organization CELAD. The ITA is an independent anti-doping agency established in 2018 by the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) and has been responsible for implementing the UCI anti-doping program since January 1, 2021.

title: Los pacientes buscan su espacio como agentes “indispensables” en el reto sanitario europeo | @diariofarma
summary: The VII Congress of Patient Organizations in Spain focused on the active participation of patients in the European health challenge. Patients want to be protagonists in the design of the new pharmaceutical policy, participation in clinical trials, and the construction of the European Health Data Space. The opening day discussed the challenges of the European Health Data Space, the new European Clinical Trials Regulation, and access to therapeutic innovation. The President of the European Patients' Forum, Marco Greco, called on patients to have a clear role in EU co-governance. The Vice President of Multiple Sclerosis Spain, Alfonso Castresana, moderated the discussion on the European Health Data Space. The speakers pointed out the historical opportunity that this new area represents, although they also highlighted the difficulties in the process, such as security and legal issues.

title: Cantabria detecta una media de 150 casos de cáncer de mama al año
summary: Cantabria detects an average of 150 cases of breast cancer per year, with the importance of screening being highlighted on International Breast Cancer Day. Although 77% of Cantabrian women participate in breast cancer screening programs, there is a deficit in participation among women who are called for the first time. Antonia Gimón, president of AMUCCAN, calls for the age range to be extended from 45 to 74 years old, as recommended by Europe. In Cantabria, tomosynthesis is used to detect smaller tumors, and quick deviation is taken in case of any diagnostic doubts. The public is advised not to rely on the internet for information after receiving a negative result.

title: Piden igualar la edad de las campañas de detección del cáncer de mama
summary: The president of the Spanish Federation of Breast Cancer (Fecma), Antonia Gimón, and the scientific coordinator of the cancer strategy of the National Health System, Josep Borrás, have urged all autonomous communities in Spain to agree on a common age range for early breast cancer screening campaigns, which should be between 45 and 74 years according to the recommendation of the European Union. Gimón lamented that in Spain, "everyone does their own thing" and expressed hope that the new Spanish government will revive the Oncological Oblivion Law project, which is present in all EU countries except Malta and Spain. The project aims to eliminate cancer from the medical history of people who have had it and have been medically discharged, so that they can access the same opportunities in their social and work life without any obstacles.

title: Cáncer de mama: piden igualar la edad de las campañas de detección en todas las comunidades
summary: Breast cancer experts, Antonia Gimón and Josep Borrás, have requested for a common age range to be established for early detection campaigns in Spain. The European Union suggests this age range to be between 45 to 74 years old, however, the current criteria in Spain is between 50 and 69 years old. Gimón hopes that the new Spanish government will restart the Oncological Oblivion Law project, which would eliminate cancer from the medical history of those who have been cured, thus allowing them to access the same opportunities in their social and work life without any obstacles. Borrás believes that it is essential to work with breast cancer patients, not just for them, to understand their priorities and needs. He also suggests that lowering the age range to 45 years old would make sense due to an increase in risk at this age.

title: La URV logra generar hidrógeno a partir de aguas residuales
summary: Researchers from the Department of Chemical Engineering at Rovira i Virgili University have developed a technology to generate renewable hydrogen from wastewater using solar radiation. The HACDOS project, which involves the Eurecat Technology Centre and the water cycle company Facsa, has validated an experimental pilot plant and is preparing for an industrial-scale plant to establish a profitable circular energy model. The project has registered a patent and is expanding to different countries. The pilot plant on the roof of a building at the URV campus in Tarragona uses photovoltaic panels with an active photocatalytic material to decompose wastewater, remove pollutants, and produce clean hydrogen from a renewable source. The project has received funding from Next Generation EU and the State Research Agency of the Ministry of Science and Innovation.

title: Expertos en enfermedades raras analizan los avances en su camino hacia la "atención integral"
summary: The IV Congress on Rare Diseases is currently taking place in Salamanca, Spain from April 17-19, 2024. Its purpose is to discuss advancements in the diagnosis, research, and therapies of rare diseases. The event is being promoted by the Association of Rare Diseases of Castilla and León and has been inaugurated by various authorities, including Juan Carrión Tudela, the President of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases. Tudela emphasized the importance of neonatal screening in detecting rare diseases early. Cristina Díaz del Cerro, the President of the Association of Rare Diseases of Castilla and León, highlighted the need to integrate research, diagnosis, and access to treatments and therapies in order to meet the needs of people with rare diseases. The Congress is being attended by experts, health professionals, researchers, patients, and their families.

title: La Universidad Pontificia de Salamanca acoge el IV Congreso de Enfermedades Raras de AERSCYL
summary: The University of Salamanca is currently hosting the 4th Congress on Rare Diseases from April 17th to 19th. The event is being promoted by the Association of Rare Diseases of Castilla y León and will showcase advancements in diagnosis, research, and therapies for these diseases. The theme of the congress is "Walking towards comprehensive care." Alejandro Vázquez Ramos, Santiago García-Jalón de la Lama, Carlos García Carbayo, Juan Carrión Tudela, and Cristina Díaz del Cerro were present at the opening ceremony. Juan Carrión Tudela, the president of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases, stated that Spain needs to train professionals in clinical genetics and learn from countries like Italy and Portugal. Cristina Díaz del Cerro, the president of the Association of Rare Diseases of Castilla y León, emphasized the importance of research, diagnosis, and access to treatments and therapies for those affected by rare diseases.

title: Reclaman la actualización del plan frente a las enfermedades raras
summary: Juan Carrión Tudela, the President of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (Feder), has requested an update of the Plan for Comprehensive Care of Rare Diseases before the Regional Assembly's Health and Social Policy Committee. He emphasized the importance of creating a model of sociosanitary coordination that would allow for quality care for patients, as well as the provision of necessary resources, both human and material, to the genetics field. There are currently 112,410 people with rare diseases in the Murcia region, and worldwide, between 6% and 7% of the population is estimated to have a rare disease. Carrión Tudela also stressed the need for early diagnosis and urged the establishment of a clinical genetics medical laboratory specialty. The previous rare disease plan was effective until 2022 and is currently undergoing evaluation, with a new plan set to be implemented in 2025.

title: Feder pide actualizar el plan de atención de enfermedades raras tras más de un año caducado
summary: Juan Carrión Tudela, the president of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (Feder), has called for an update of the Integral Care Plan for Rare Diseases for the period 2025-2028. The current plan expired on December 31, 2022, after being extended for two years due to the coronavirus pandemic. Tudela made the request during his appearance before the Regional Health and Social Policy Commission for Rare Disease Day, which is commemorated on February 29. Feder has identified 6,613 rare diseases to date and estimates that between 6 and 8% of the population lives with these diseases, which would be approximately 3 million Spaniards. Feder's second priority for the Autonomous Community's area of action is for the Ministry of Health to guarantee the funds it allocates to the associative movement this year to "develop direct actions to respond to needs to which, to date, the Administration does not reach."

title: El club presenta este miércoles las acciones previstas por el Día Mundial de las Enfermedades Raras
summary: The C.D. Leganes football club will present its planned actions for Rare Disease Day on February 29th in a press conference at the Municipal Butarque Stadium. The event will be attended by the club's vice president, Eduardo Cosin, the coach of the men's first team, Borja Jimenez, the captain, Sergio Gonzalez, and the president of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (FEDER), Juan Carrion Tudela. The club and the C.D. Leganes Foundation will detail the various actions they plan to carry out as part of a campaign to raise awareness for rare diseases throughout the 2023/24 season. The event will be streamed live on the club's YouTube channel.

title: Las enfermedades raras afectan a unos tres millones de personas en España - UIMP
category: The input text is categorized as 'Research'.
summary: The Universidad Internacional Menéndez Pelayo (UIMP) is organizing a course on rare diseases, which is being held in Santander, Spain. The course aims to explore how rare diseases are researched in Spain, with a focus on developing effective diagnostic strategies and therapies. The course features 23 presentations and six roundtable discussions, and is being held in collaboration with the Centre for Biomedical Research on Rare Diseases (CIBERER) and Eli Lilly and Company laboratories. According to Pablo Lapunzina, the scientific director of CIBERER INGEMM-Hospital Universitario La Paz de Madrid, there are around three million people in Spain who are affected by rare diseases, almost 7% of the population. The course also includes insights from patient associations, which play an important role in research, assistance, and support for those affected by rare diseases. Fidela Mirón Torrente, the vice president of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (FEDER), was among the speakers at the course.

title: El doctor Pablo Baltar, entre los mejores de España
summary: Santiago de la Riva, an odontologist and stomatologist at Clínica Baltar in Santiago de Compostela, has been recognized by Top Doctors as one of the 50 best private medical doctors in Spain. Top Doctors evaluates doctors throughout the year based on national and international recognition, clinical skills, research work, and patient feedback. The Clínica Baltar continues to consolidate itself as a reference in the field of private medicine in Santiago and Galicia. Two other Galician doctors were also recognized by Top Doctors: Dr. Ignacio Lojo Rocamonde, head of the Department of Angiology, Vascular and Endovascular Surgery at Quirón A Coruña, and urologist Alejandro Fernández Larrañaga, whose professional career focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of erectile dysfunction, ejaculation problems, and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Las enfermedades raras tendrán un plan integral
summary: Castilla y León will approve a Comprehensive Plan for Rare Diseases on March 10, as announced by the vice president of Feder, Santiago de la Riva. The strategy aims to ensure that patients do not have to visit seven specialists, but rather that specialists see the patient with the creation of specific units. The Board will not include the expansion of neonatal testing in the plan, as the ones stipulated by professionals are already performed in Castilla y León. The International Rare Disease Day brought together hundreds of people in the province in support of patients suffering from some of the 7,000 rare diseases that are known. In the province of León, there are approximately 35,000 registered cases out of the 160,000 in Castilla y León.

title: Las farmacias también colaboran en la accesibilidad | @diariofarma
summary: The Official College of Pharmacists of Cantabria and the ES Retina Association have signed a collaboration agreement to launch the "Step in Sight" campaign. The initiative aims to improve accessibility and safety for citizens by highlighting potentially dangerous steps in public or private areas. The campaign involves marking the edges of steps with a 5-centimeter-wide band that contrasts in texture and color with the pavement of the step. The campaign's graphics consist of a poster and a sticker with an image designed by the Cantabrian painter Pedro Sobrado. The president and representative of the ES Retina Association, Andrés Mayor Lorenzo, highlighted the importance of this initiative for the more than 2% of the Spanish population with serious visual problems.

title: Fallece José María Soria, ex presidente de Philips Lighting Ibérica y primer director general de Ambilamp ...
summary: José María Soria, the former president of Philips Lighting Ibérica and the first general director of Ambilamp, passed away on Friday in Madrid. He played a significant role in the electrical material sector, particularly in the lighting industry, and was one of its most prominent representatives and executives in the late 20th century and the first decade of the current one. Soria was instrumental in advancing the industry along with his counterpart at Osram, Benito Rodríguez, and increasing its visibility and impact in various sectors of society. After leaving Philips Iberia, he became the first general director of Ambilamp, an association created by major lighting multinationals to manage waste from lamps and comply with the obligations established by the Real Decreto 208/2005. Soria played a leading role in the company's early days and was his last significant professional position in the electrical material sector before retiring.

title: Fallece José María Soria, primer director general de Ambilamp y expresidente de Philips Lighting Ibérica
summary: José María Soria, who was previously the president of Philips Lighting Ibérica and the first general director of Ambilamp, has died in Madrid.
