Ambilamp, a non-profit organization that was created for the collection and final treatment of waste lamps and luminaires, has honored Soria's career and described him as "a person of drive, with a personality that overwhelmed, and of those whose courage and guts did not allow his fighting spirit to soften". Soria was also recognized as a "leader" by the president of Ambilamp, Benito Rodríguez, who added that Soria's professional training remained valid in the performance of activities different from those developed until his retirement. The Material Eléctrico area expressed condolences to Soria's family and friends.

title: Soria Saludable se vuelca con la salud mental y premia la labor de José María Ordovás
summary: The XXIX edition of the Soria Saludable conference, organized by the Fundación Científica de Caja Rural, will focus on mental health due to the current situation and the increase in suicidal behavior. The conference will begin on November 2 with a talk on suicide prevention by psychologist Javier Jiménez Pietrapaolo. Other speakers include Elena González Romero on cyberbullying and social media, and Ignacio Muñoz Siscart on the prevention of suicide. The conference will end on November 30 with a talk by José María Ordovás, a specialist in Nutrigenetics and Nutrigenomics, who will receive the National Research Award from the Foundation. The Foundation will also deliver the Refranero Temático of the Mediterranean Diet and the Human Values Award to Jesús Aguarón and the Healthy Sorians Award to the Emergency personnel of the Soria Healthcare Complex.

title: Isabel Motero, directora de FEDER, asiste a la XIII Jornada CIBERER “Investigar es Avanzar” | FEDER
summary: Isabel Motero, the director of FEDER, attended the XIII CIBERER Conference "Investigating is Advancing" which took place on February 29th in Madrid. The conference addressed various topics related to rare disease research, including the latest advances in the field, collaboration initiatives between researchers and patient associations, and the importance of biobanks in rare disease research. The event was held in honor of Rare Disease Day. During the conference, a debate was held on the topic of biobanks and their role in rare disease research, featuring Carmen Aguado, Federico Pallardó, Carlos Santos Ocana, Antonio López, Claudia López, and Beatriz Arconada.

title: Feder se reúne con las nuevas directoras del Instituto de Salud Carlos III e Imserso
summary: The Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (Feder) has met with the director of the Carlos III Health Institute, Marina Pollán, and the general director of the Imserso, María Teresa Castiello. Feder's director, Isabel Motero, and the social transformation manager, Patricia Arias, as well as the director of the Institute of Research on Rare Diseases, Eva Bermejo, attended the meeting. Feder has increased its budget for research to half a million euros and discussed projects such as IMPaCT, which focuses on genomics. Feder also highlighted its alliance with Imserso, which has worked on addressing the situation of disability and dependence in rare diseases. Finally, Feder requested an assessment of the implementation of a disability assessment scale and the impact of it on rare diseases, as well as the resumption of training for disability assessors.

title: Entrevista a Isabel Motero, nueva directora de FEDER
summary: Isabel Motero, the new director of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (FEDER), discusses the challenges she faces, the importance of early diagnosis, and the need for advances and specialization in genomic matters in Spain. Motero emphasizes the need for specialized training in the field of health, especially in rare diseases, and the importance of promoting cohesion among the 410 entities that make up FEDER. She also highlights the need to recognize the specialty of clinical genetics in Spain and to guarantee equal access to diagnostic tests such as genetic testing and neonatal screening. Motero also acknowledges the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the mental health of rare disease patients and their families. She believes it is essential to increase resources for psychological care in primary and specialized care. FEDER's main challenge is to continue working towards a more inclusive and accessible organization and to promote equal access to diagnostic tests and programs.

title: FEDER demandada una mayor inversión para el tratamiento de enfermedades raras
summary:
The translated text is: 

FEDER, the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases, has launched a new campaign called "Rare Diseases: Prevention is Better than Cure", aimed at increasing awareness and funding for research and treatment of rare diseases. The campaign was presented by important figures from FEDER and government entities, including FEDER President Juan Carrión, FEDER General Director Isabel Motero, and Director General of Disability Rights at the Ministry of Social Rights, Consumption and Agenda 2030 Jesús Martín Blanco. The campaign highlights the need for more research funding, early diagnosis, and appropriate treatment for rare diseases. The event also addressed concerns about the limited proportion of rare diseases that have been deeply studied, with only 20% of them analyzed to date. The campaign aims to sensitize people about the importance of increasing funds allocated to research, early diagnosis, and treatment of rare diseases.

title: Isabel Motero, directora de Feder: "Las enfermedades raras son una carrera de fondo"
summary: Isabel Motero, the director of the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (Feder), emphasized the need for an abbreviation in the diagnosis of rare diseases, which is a "marathon" because "365 days a year are lived with these pathologies." She explained that 70% to 80% of these diseases are genetically inherited and manifest at a very young age in two out of three cases. Therefore, "the consequences are serious, disabling, and we need to focus on early diagnosis and research." These statements were made on the occasion of Rare Disease Day, celebrated on February 28.

title: La puesta en marcha de la nueva Estrategia Madrileña de Coordinación Sociosanitaria, una prioridad para 400.000 ...
summary: The launch of the new Madrid Strategy for Sociosanitary Coordination is a priority for the estimated 400,000 people living with rare diseases or undiagnosed conditions in the region. This was emphasized at the second Madrid Forum organized by the Spanish Federation for Rare Diseases (FEDER), which brought together representatives from various sectors involved in addressing rare diseases. The forum discussed the need for a common framework to coordinate existing initiatives and improve access to diagnosis and care. Isabel Motero, Director of FEDER, highlighted the progress made in the last decade, including the consolidation of the Madrid association movement, which now includes 127 organizations within FEDER. The forum also discussed the social impact of rare diseases and the need for sociosanitary coordination, including the role of school nursing.

title: Las asociaciones demandan una mayor inversión para el tratamiento de las enfermedades raras
summary: Several associations in Spain, including the Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases (FEDER), are demanding increased investment in research, diagnosis, and treatment for rare diseases. Currently, only 20% of the more than 6,000 identified rare diseases are being researched, leaving approximately 4,800 conditions without adequate treatment options. The average wait time for a diagnosis is four years, and some patients wait up to a decade. Isabel Motero, the general director of FEDER, has highlighted that Spain only invests 1.43% of its GDP in rare disease research, far below the average investment of 2.72% in other countries. The initiative seeks to improve the quality of data and standardize procedures to obtain a more accurate epidemiological situation of these diseases in the country.

title: ¡Brindamos una cálida acogida a los nuevos miembros de esta gran familia FEDER! | FEDER
summary: The Spanish Federation of Rare Diseases, known as FEDER, recently hosted a meeting to welcome new members to their organization. FEDER's president, Juan Carrión, and director, Isabel Motero, as well as other board members, were in attendance. During the meeting, information was shared about FEDER's activities and services, and new members had the chance to meet the board and technical team. Carrión stressed the importance of making new members feel welcome, while Motero highlighted the significance of the meeting in supporting the rare disease community in Spain. FEDER's dedication to supporting the community and understanding its challenges and needs was also emphasized.

title: Nos reunimos por primera vez con la nueva directora del IMSERSO para definir nuestra hoja de ruta en la atención ...
summary: Translated text: FEDER held a meeting with the new director of IMSERSO to discuss the social care of people with rare diseases in Spain. The meeting was attended by FEDER's President, Juan Carrión, Director Isabel Motero, and Project Manager Vanesa Pizarro. They talked about the challenges and opportunities for both organizations to collaborate and meet the needs of families affected by rare diseases. The meeting also covered the implementation of a new disability assessment system and FEDER's proposal to evaluate its impact on rare diseases and provide additional training for assessors. The organizations have been working together for 25 years, especially through the Center of Reference for Rare Diseases and their Families (CREER), which aims to improve care for people with rare diseases.

title: Álvaro Lavandeira: "Los problemas de acceso a medicamentos huérfanos o a terapias avanzadas viene determinado por su precio"
summary: Alvaro Lavandeira, a lawyer who represents patients with rare diseases, states that the accessibility of orphan drugs or advanced therapies is based on their cost. The recent rulings by the Supreme Court regarding two rare disease drugs, Raxone and Translarna, establish new legal principles that lower courts and autonomous communities must consider when denying access to expensive orphan drugs. Lavandeira believes that these rulings will significantly alter access to orphan drugs. He argues that the health and well-being of patients should take priority over cost-saving measures, and that the government should play a more active role in financing these drugs to ensure universal access. Lavandeira also notes that doctors play a crucial role in prescribing these drugs, and that the availability of these drugs is limited due to the small number of cases and the high cost of development and production.

title: Premios a residentes de Medicina Familiar y Comunitaria de Azuqueca durante las Jornadas Nacionales de ...
summary: The Spanish Society of Primary Care Physicians (SEMERGEN) has awarded two resident doctors from the Azuqueca de Henares health center for their work presented at the X National Conference of Residents and Tutors held at the Menéndez Pelayo International University in Cuenca. Laura Pérez Martín, a third-year resident, won the award for the best Instagram image of the conference, while fourth-year resident Elena Sáez Gil won second prize for the best clinical case. The team, consisting of the two residents, along with Sara Bartolomé Jiménez and Marina Maroto Guerrero, second and first-year residents respectively, and their tutor, Dr. Raúl Piedra Castro, participated in the conference with two activities. Raúl Piedra highlighted the success of the team's first activity, a theatrical representation titled 'How to make a disastrous presentation', which was a comedy that addressed how to approach presentations correctly and avoid common errors.

title: Altas temperaturas: Así puedes reconocer un golpe de calor y diferenciarlo de una insolación
summary: The pediatric bronchopulmonologist, Gema Pérez, explained on the Mucho Gusto program how to recognize the symptoms of heat stroke and gave recommendations on how to treat it. It is important to distinguish heat stroke from sunstroke, as they are not the same. Sunstroke is caused by exposure to the sun without skin protection, while heat stroke is a significant increase in body temperature above 40°C, which can occur in these environmental conditions and is not a fever. The symptoms of heat stroke include high body temperature, palpitations, nausea, dizziness, intense and throbbing headache, and rapid heartbeat. To treat heat stroke, a person should be immersed in a cold bath or have cold compresses applied to their body before being taken to an emergency center.

title: MAZ y Unizar premian la excelencia en la investigación científica en Medicina del Trabajo
summary: MAZ and Unizar have awarded Paula Alquézar, Rocío García, María Isabel Iguacel, and Marta Supervía for their excellence in scientific research in Occupational Medicine. The II Edition of the 'MAZ Unizar Chair Awards for Excellence in Scientific Research in Occupational Medicine' was organized by Mutua MAZ, and the University of Zaragoza. The event was held at the Paraninfo de Zaragoza, and it was attended by several medical professionals. The conference also included a lecture on the prevention of suicidal behavior in the Guardia Civil. The Cátedra MAZ Unizar aims to improve health care and rehabilitation services based on scientific evidence. The awards were given to the best research projects in Occupational Medicine, carried out by students in their final year of study, master's, and doctoral thesis projects. The Cátedra MAZ also provides continuous training for health professionals, offers internships for students, and activities for communication.

title: El Macarena renueva el equipo de Coordinación de Trasplantes
summary: The University Hospital Virgen Macarena in Seville has appointed a new team of transplant coordinators, led by Pablo Manuel González, to facilitate organ donation for citizens at the end of their lives. The team, consisting of over 100 professionals, will work to ensure a smooth donation process when a potential donor is identified. The hospital has a highly active donation program, having achieved four donors in less than a week. Collaboration between different hospitals aims to provide the best possible assistance to the donor's family, while also minimizing the time between organ extraction and implantation. The ICU team is directly involved in the donation and transplantation process.

title: María Martín pide dejar a un lado los "personalismos"
summary: María Martín, who is the counselor of Health and Social Policies for the Government of La Rioja, has appealed to the PSOE and Podemos-IU parliamentary groups to "set aside personal issues and tantrums" in their fight against gender violence. She made this statement during an interpellation in the Regional Chamber, where both groups questioned the counselor about the management of gender violence in the health sector. They also raised questions about the dismissal of the coordinator of the Technical Commission on Gender Violence, María Antonia Aretio, in October 2023. María Martín thanked Aretio for her work and offered her collaboration with the regional government. The counselor criticized the previous government for not creating the position of coordinator of the Technical Commission on Gender Violence.

title: Los médicos catalanes que receten de más serán penalizados con menor sueldo
summary: Doctors in Catalonia who prescribe certain treatments excessively will face a pay cut. The Quality Index of Pharmaceutical Prescription (IQF) limits the prescription of certain higher-cost treatments, and doctors who exceed this limit will notice a reduction in their salary. The IQF is a management tool that allows for quantitative and qualitative evaluation of pharmaceutical prescriptions, identification of best practices, and comparisons. However, doctors who exceed the limit lose points to access one of the salary supplements, which is a "bonus." This has caused controversy, especially for patients with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), as doctors have a limit for prescribing the most effective therapy for this disease, the Triple Closed Therapy (TTC), which is limited to 20%. Alfons Viñuela, a patient with COPD, is one of the affected patients who "do not understand why there should be a limitation."

title: El investigador José Manuel García consigue 150.000 euros para su proyecto de investigación contra el cáncer
summary: José Manuel García, a researcher at the University of Zaragoza's Institute of Engineering Research, has received €150,000 in additional funding from the European Research Council to develop a tool to test the effectiveness of immunotherapy treatment on pancreatic, lung, and liver tumours. García and his team plan to recreate the tumour environment on a computer to see how cells react and to design a cell culture that can test the effectiveness of immunotherapy treatment. The tool could help doctors apply more efficient treatments to patients with tumours and avoid harmful side effects. The project, called VASTO, will be developed through a multidisciplinary approach that will involve different research groups from the University of Zaragoza and the Aragon Health Research Institute.

title: El Gobernador Zamora se encuentra internado en el Hospital Regional
summary: The Governor of Santiago del Estero, Gerardo Zamora, has been hospitalized at the Regional Hospital due to intestinal discomfort. He will be under observation for the next 48 hours after undergoing medical tests. Despite this, he is said to be in good health and is awaiting the results. Santiago Alfonso Zamora has not been mentioned in the given text, so it is not possible to include his contribution in the summary.

title: Asapme ha tratado este año a más de 120 menores de 25 años por problemas de salud mental
summary: Asapme, the Aragonese Association for Mental Health, has treated over 120 children and young people under the age of 25 for mental health problems this year alone. The demand for consultations regarding anxiety crises, learning problems, and suicidal ideation is growing, particularly among young people. Ana López Trenco, a doctor and manager at Asapme, highlights that severe mental disorders are emerging after "a pandemic and a social crisis that affects wars, climate change, migration crises...". It is estimated that one in four people will have a mental health problem at some point in their life, with half of cases appearing before the age of 14. Asapme is calling for more professionals and resources to meet the current demand, which has increased since the coronavirus pandemic. This demand is particularly urgent given the shortage of mental health professionals and resources, which can contribute to prevention and treatment.

title: Acuerdo entre Asapme y TOC Zaragoza para tener derecho a tarifas especiales
summary: Asapme Aragón, una ONG dedicada a ayudar a personas con enfermedades mentales y sus familias, ha firmado un acuerdo de colaboración con TOC Zaragoza. La asociación tiene como objetivo proporcionar un mayor acceso a los servicios de terapia psicológica y psiquiátrica ofrecidos por Asapme. El acuerdo compromete a ambas organizaciones, que forman parte de la Federación de Salud Mental de Aragón, a ser recetadores mutuos de servicios de salud que sean complementarios y ventajosos para los miembros y beneficiarios de ambas entidades. Asapme Aragón ha estado operando desde 1984 y es la asociación con la historia más larga de apoyo a personas con enfermedades mentales y sus familias en Aragón. Mientras tanto, TOC Zaragoza, que se estableció en 2018, es una asociación dedicada a informar, apoyar y ayudar a personas con Trastorno Obsesivo Compulsivo (TOC) y sus familias.

title: Día Mundial de la Salud Mental: "Hacen falta más recursos, tanto de profesionales como de infraestructuras"
summary: On the occasion of World Mental Health Day, the Federación Salud Mental Aragón and the Asociación Aragonesa Pro Salud Mental (Asapme) organized a sensitization event to raise awareness about the increasing number of cases of mental health issues, particularly among children, youth, and people over 65 years of age. The event aimed to highlight the need for more resources, both in terms of professionals and infrastructure, to address the growing problem. Asapme has already treated more than 120 children and young people under the age of 25 for mental health problems this year alone. The event also witnessed the presentation of awards to Fundación Sesé and journalist Ana Esteban for their contributions to the cause. Ana López Trenco, the medical manager of Asapme, emphasized the importance of having a direct dialogue with the government to address the lack of resources for mental health treatment.

title: Adventist South American Division Volunteers Begin Mission Trip to Paraguay
summary: Over 60 volunteers from the South American Division of the Adventist Church will voluntarily serve for 12 days in the restoration of the Adventist College of Eastern Paraguay. The volunteers include secretaries, programmers, pastors, treasurers, accountants, administrators, translators, nurses, and other professionals. The Human Resources department of the South American Division and the Adventist Volunteer Service continental chapter strategically developed this mission trip. The volunteers will carry out activities such as painting and renovating environments, evangelism, and providing medical attention to the community. The group of volunteers consists of Brazilians, Peruvians, Argentinians, Venezuelans, Mexicans, Ecuadorians, and Bolivians. Mariano Sanz is the current director of the Colegio Adventista del Este Paraguayo.

title: Banco Sabadell Foundation gives awards to researchers Manuel Valiente and Juan Miguel Morales
summary: The Banco Sabadell Foundation has awarded the 18th Banco Sabadell Foundation Award for Biomedical Research to Manuel Valiente, Doctor of neuroscience and leader of the Brain Metastasis Group at the Spanish National Cancer Research Centre (CNIO), while the 7th Banco Sabadell Foundation Award for Science and Engineering went to Juan Miguel Morales, Doctor of industrial engineering and head of the research group Optimisation and Analytics for Sustainable Energy Systems (OASYS) at the University of Malaga. The panel of judges for the Biomedical Research Award highlighted the contributions made by Dr Manuel Valiente to research into the mechanisms that generate brain metastasis, the identification of therapeutic targets, and their potential use in the selection of patients according to their response to the treatment. The panel of judges for the Science and Engineering Award underlined the work put in by Dr Juan Miguel Morales towards the development of computational tools for the deployment of distributed renewable energy resources.

title: Ávoris ficha a Endika Ormaeche para potenciar su relación con agencias
summary: Endika Ormaeche has been appointed as the new Director General of Associates and Strategic Distribution Projects at Ávoris Corporación Empresarial. Ormaeche has worked in key areas of various travel agencies, tour operators and hotel chains, including Muchoviaje.com, AR Hoteles and TDCS. His new role will contribute to Ávoris' strategic project of deepening its relationship with travel agencies and multiplying its presence in the distribution channel. The corporation aims to promote sustainable growth in its product proposal and factory. Ormaeche will report directly to Juan Carlos González, the group's general director. The addition of Ormaeche is expected to be beneficial for the development of Ávoris' relationship with the distribution channel.

title: Iberojet inauguró vuelo desde España a Costa Rica utilizando combustible sostenible
summary: Iberojet, una aerolínea española, ha lanzado su primer vuelo desde Madrid a San José, Costa Rica, utilizando combustible de aviación sostenible (SAF) en un Airbus A350-900. La aerolínea tiene como objetivo reducir su impacto ambiental mediante el uso de SAF en sus vuelos y cumplir con las regulaciones de la UE sobre la descarbonización de la aviación. El SAF está hecho de materiales renovables y reduce aproximadamente el 80% de las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero generadas en su ciclo de vida en comparación con los combustibles fósiles convencionales. El uso de SAF por parte de Iberojet también se alinea con la visión de turismo y sostenibilidad de Costa Rica. La aerolínea es la primera en implementar el uso de SAF antes de las obligaciones legales establecidas para 2025. José Ignacio Lugo, Subdirector General de Iberojet, afirmó que la reducción de las emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero de la aerolínea es una prioridad estratégica.

title: Acuerdo de Iberojet y Repsol para el suministro de SAF a partir de 2025
summary: Iberojet and Repsol have signed an agreement for the supply of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from 2025 to 2027. Repsol will provide more than 4,500 tons of SAF to Iberojet, reducing emissions by 10,400 tons of CO2 over two years. The agreement is a step towards the goal of carbon neutrality by 2050 and brings Iberojet closer to the EU's target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions in aviation by at least 55% by 2030. Iberojet previously used Repsol's SAF on its Madrid-San Jose route in Costa Rica. The director general of Iberojet, José Ignacio Lugo, highlighted the agreement's aim to reduce the environmental impact of their activities. The SAF is produced from renewable raw materials and reduces approximately 80% of greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional fuel.

title: From Hollywood to Hong Kong: Celebrity Aesthetician Joanna Vargas Launches at the Four Seasons
summary: Celebrity aesthetician Joanna Vargas has launched her signature spa treatments at the Four Seasons in Hong Kong. Vargas has sell-out salons in New York and Los Angeles, catering to clients that include some of the biggest names in Hollywood. She has just launched four of her signature facials at the Four Seasons Spa, including her Triple Crown Facial, which is dubbed the “red carpet facial” because of its popularity among Hollywood stars during award season. Vargas and her team spent two weeks in Hong Kong training the Four Seasons staff on her non-invasive treatments, which utilise a combination of LED, microcurrent and radio frequency with no downtime or side effects. Vargas has a reputation for being trustworthy and straight with people, and she is the first person to say you don’t need filler or botox.

title: Celeb Facialist Joanna Vargas Shares Her 7 Best Skin Tips
summary: Celebrity esthetician Joanna Vargas, who works with famous faces such as Keri Russell, Rachel Brosnahan, and Maggie Gyllenhaal, shares her seven best skincare tips. Her non-negotiable steps include cleansing, serum, moisturizer, and SPF. She recommends using retinol, hyaluronic acid, and oil-based serums. Vargas suggests using kojic, lactic, and mandelic acids to improve hyperpigmentation, and vitamin C to increase the efficacy of sunscreen. She advises focusing on skin prep, not makeup, for a big event, and taking more time to cleanse the skin. Vargas also recommends supplementing skincare routines with high-tech skin devices, such as the Magic Glow Wand and the Therabody TheraFace Pro. Finally, she encourages clients to focus on what they love about their face, not what they don't.

title: «¿Te han explicado el riesgo de ponerte esos labios?»
summary: Belén Alonso, an expert in aesthetics and nutrition, has cautioned against non-professionals carrying out cosmetic procedures. She has expressed concern about the "selfie syndrome" among young people and the necessity for more regulation in the field of aesthetic medicine. This warning comes after the College of Physicians denounced a Russian cosmetologist who was allegedly going to perform botox injections or rhinoplasties in an apartment, highlighting the problem of medical intrusion in the field of aesthetic medicine. Alonso has been practicing for over 20 years and stresses the significance of seeking out qualified professionals for cosmetic procedures.

title: Lupus: los pacientes reivindican detección precoz y el abordaje multidisciplinar | @diariofarma
summary: Silvia Pérez Ortega, president of Felupus, has urged for the timely identification and comprehensive treatment of lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease that affects more than 82,000 people in Spain and 5 million worldwide. AstraZeneca and Felupus have launched the campaign 'No Dejes que el Lupus Gane. Libera la Esperanza' (Don't Let Lupus Win. Free the Hope) with the objective of increasing awareness about the disease and its impact on patients. The campaign has been declared of social interest by the Spanish Society of Rheumatology (SER). The campaign's manifesto emphasizes on the need for early detection, better training for primary care, coordinated and multidisciplinary care, and access to new therapies for all patients. The campaign employs art as a tool to raise awareness of the disease and will showcase a sculpture of a girl to symbolize hope for a better future for lupus patients.

title: Reumatólogos, pacientes y GSK presentan el cortometraje “Hay un lobo entre nosotros” para contar la realidad del lupus
summary: Reumatologists, patients, and GSK have presented the short film "There is a wolf among us" to tell the reality of lupus. The film aims to raise awareness about lupus, the importance of early detection, and provide support to patients. Lupus affects around 96,000 patients in Spain, and there is currently no cure for this chronic disease. The film reflects the testimony of people living with lupus and addresses relevant topics for patients such as the impact on daily life, the importance of associationism, and the early approach to the disease. The campaign also includes a website with information and testimonials about the disease and the "Taking the wolf to the street" campaign, where statues in Seville will be surrounded by wolves to reflect how the disease suddenly appears and accompanies patients. Silvia Pérez Ortega, president of FELUPUS, emphasizes the importance of patient associations in disseminating the disease and defending the rights of those affected.

title: AstraZeneca presenta las conclusiones del “Proyecto Vitales”, una iniciativa para mejorar el abordaje del lupus ...
summary: AstraZeneca has presented the conclusions of the "Proyecto Vitales" initiative, which aims to improve the approach to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The initiative brought together professionals in the management of SLE to establish unified parameters for measuring the disease's activity in clinical practice. The consensus reached by professionals includes evaluating quality of life, disease activity control, and disease burden. Additionally, quality parameters and accumulated damage should be measured at least once a year on a scale of 0-10. SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects over 82,000 people in Spain and 5 million worldwide. The initiative aims to provide tools for professionals, considering the patient's needs and placing them at the center of the diagnostic and therapeutic process. The project also highlights the importance of early diagnosis and multidisciplinary management of SLE patients.

title: Inma Escriche: "El cáncer de pulmón es el feo, a nadie le gusta contar que lo sufre"
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Inmaculada Escriche, who is the vice president of the Spanish Association of Lung Cancer Patients (AEACaP), wishes to create awareness about the "hidden epidemic" of lung cancer which has had a "devastating" impact on her life. Escriche was diagnosed with lung cancer seven years ago and has undergone 112 chemotherapy sessions. She now aims to fight for the rights of those affected by the disease. Although she remains hopeful, Escriche is also realistic and knows that she will not be cured. She hopes to manage the disease chronically. Escriche has made significant contributions to the AEACaP by increasing awareness about lung cancer and advocating for better care and support for patients.

title: España es el país europeo con mayor participación en ensayos clínicos
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Spain has the highest participation rate in clinical trials in Europe, accounting for 43% of the total. Clinical trials offer a last chance for patients who cannot be treated with existing drugs. Inmaculada Escriche, who was diagnosed with metastatic lung cancer, was given four months to live, but thanks to a clinical trial combining chemotherapy with immunotherapy, she has survived for eight years. Spain's Agency for Medicines and Medical Devices authorizes clinical trials, which begin when a committee of ethics approves them. The trials are an opportunity for patients who have no other options, particularly in oncology, which accounts for 35% of all clinical trials. Spain is a leader in clinical trials, with only 7 out of 100 drugs reaching the market after a minimum of 10 years of research and development.

title: Paula Jiménez Fonseca, Premio Salud de LA NUEVA ESPAÑA: "Trabajar en el campo del cáncer te enseña lo esencial en la vida"
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Oncologist Paula Jiménez Fonseca has won the Health Award from La Nueva España in the Projection category. She specializes in digestive tumors, works at the HUCA, directs the national registry of esophageal-gastric cancer, and has just obtained a research grant in neuroendocrine tumors. She also coordinates the MIR Asturias Course. Jiménez Fonseca says that working in the field of cancer has taught her the essential things in life and the importance of putting everyday problems into perspective. She has learned the importance of balancing work with rest and leisure, and has established a routine that includes respecting her nocturnal sleep, dedicating an hour a day to sports, enjoying hiking and dancing on weekends, and participating in cultural activities every one or two weeks.

title: «Un hombre de 77 años habrá consumido en su vida menos azúcar que su nieto de siete años»
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Oncologist Paula Jiménez Fonseca spoke at the Semana de la Ciencia de Luarca about the importance of healthy eating in cancer prevention. She explained that only 5% of cancers are inherited, while 40% can be avoided by saying no to tobacco, alcohol, sedentary lifestyles, obesity, sun exposure without protection, and poor nutrition. She emphasized the benefits of the Mediterranean diet, including three pieces of fruit per day, vegetables at lunch and dinner, legumes, and blue fish three times a week. Jiménez also warned against processed or salted meat, associating them with colon and stomach cancer, while noting that consuming semi-skimmed milk daily can prevent breast cancer. She is the co-author of several books, including 'Comer para vencer el cáncer' and 'Remedios naturales para síntomas habituales'.

title: Paula Jiménez Fonseca, oncóloga en el HUCA: "Aunque procuro ser fuerte, a veces lloro con los pacientes"
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Paula Jiménez Fonseca, an oncologist at the Central University Hospital of Asturias (HUCA), has received the LA NUEVA ESPAÑA Health Prize in the Projection category. She specializes in digestive tumors and is in charge of the national registry of esophageal-gastric cancer. She has recently been granted research funds for neuroendocrine tumors and psycho-oncology. She is also the coordinator of the MIR Asturias Course, where she leads the team of tutors and simulation teachers, and teaches oncology, genetics, and palliative care. Jiménez Fonseca stresses the importance of being strong for her patients, but acknowledges that she sometimes cries with them.

title: Amalio Telenti y Paula J. Fonseca reciben los Premios Salud de LA NUEVA ESPAÑA
hco: ASOCIACION ESPAÑOLA DE AFECTADOSDE CANCER DE PULMONAEACAPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Amalio Telenti Asensio and Paula Jiménez Fonseca are the winners of the first edition of the LA NUEVA ESPAÑA Health Awards. Telenti is the executive vice president of Vir Biotechnology, a pharmaceutical company specializing in infectious diseases and immunology based in San Francisco. Fonseca is an oncologist at the Central University Hospital of Asturias (HUCA) and coordinator of the MIR Course of Asturias. They will receive the awards at a ceremony to be held at the Club Prensa Asturiana de LA NUEVA ESPAÑA on Friday. The jury, led by prestigious traumatologist Alejandro Braña Vigil, met on November 6 to evaluate the nominations submitted by medical societies and jury members themselves. The awards recognize Telenti's career and Fonseca's projection in the medical field.

title: Un mural anima a donar médula ósea en León
hco: ASOCIACION LEONESA CON LASENFERMEDADES DE LA SANGRE ALCLESAP
summary: Students from Maristas San José School and neighbors from the San Pedro Association in León have created a mural to commemorate the 30th anniversary of Alcles and encourage people to donate bone marrow. The graffiti is located on Ana María Matute Street and was made possible by the donation of the wall by the San Pedro Association and the León City Council. The author of the drawing, Nonia Alejandre Aguado Jolis, president of Alcles León, made the drawing during her recovery in the hospital and represents the bone marrow transplant process. The students, David López and Álvaro Fernández, voluntarily carried out this artistic work outside of their class schedule as part of their plastic arts subject and were supervised by their teacher. This initiative is part of Alcles León's calendar of new programs and events for its 30th anniversary activities.

title: León da luz al duelo gestacional y perinatal
hco: ASOCIACION LEONESA CON LASENFERMEDADES DE LA SANGRE ALCLESAP
summary: The association Aladus, which was founded by a group of women in León, has drawn attention to the impact of gestational and perinatal loss on families. To coincide with the World Day of Gestational, Perinatal or Neonatal Mourning, the organization held a gathering in front of the Santo Domingo fountain, which was illuminated for the occasion. The group will also introduce their association at the Hospital de León, with a panel discussion featuring professionals from Caule who work with women and families facing the loss of a child. These professionals include gynecologist Beatriz Pérez Prieto, midwife Beatriz Fernández Reguero, and social worker Mamen Olmo Prieto. The event will also feature women sharing their experiences, as well as the president of Aladus, Irene Cazón Seco.

title: El Colegio de Médicos celebra la llegada de nuevos doctores
hco: ASOCIACION LEONESA CON LASENFERMEDADES DE LA SANGRE ALCLESAP
summary: The College of Doctors in Huesca celebrated its annual festival in honor of their patron saint, the Virgin of Perpetual Help. The event welcomed new resident doctors who have chosen the province, paid tribute to retiring doctors, and presented scientific awards. The new doctors who passed the Medical Resident Intern (MIR) exam and chose Huesca province were welcomed by the president, José María Borrel. The retiring doctors were recognized as Honorary Members. The scientific awards were presented to Francesc Blanche, Soledad Lorés, and Celia Julia Romeo. The event also included a traditional mass at the Royal Basilica of San Lorenzo. José Ignacio De Blas Álvarez was one of the retiring doctors recognized as an Honorary Member.

title: Se estima que más de la mitad de los bulos que circulan en las RRSS se refieren al mundo sanitario
hco: GRUPO ESPAÑOL DE PACIENTES CON CÁNCGEPAC
summary: More than half of the fake news circulating on social media is related to the healthcare sector, as per the experts who took part in a panel discussion organized by the Spanish Society of Hematology and Hemotherapy. The experts agreed that it is crucial to anticipate misinformation and combat it through various channels, including the use of artificial intelligence, which can help in debunking fake news. However, they also cautioned that AI can be misused to create artificial content based on fake news. The panelists emphasized the importance of healthcare professionals being creative in their communication and creating a community among their peers to increase visibility and credibility. María Begoña Barragán García, president of the Spanish Association of Lymphoma, Myeloma, and Leukemia Patients, was one of the jurors for the HematoAvanza Journalism Prize, which recognized three articles on hematology and hemotherapy.

title: Lo que el deporte puede hacer contra el cáncer femenino
hco: ASOCIACION MAMA OVARIO HEREDITARIOASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Making physical exercise a part of cancer treatment can help patients recover better and even improve the results of their treatment. While exercise does not prevent or cure cancer, it can help prevent the disease and improve treatment outcomes. The case of Virginia Torrecilla, a former football player who overcame a brain tumor, is an example of how physical activity can help patients cope with cancer treatment. Women, who have a higher rate of physical activity abandonment than men, should be encouraged to stay active to prevent cancer. Studies have shown that physical activity can reduce mortality in cancer patients by up to 20%. However, not all physical activities are suitable for all patients, and professionals need to be trained to prescribe structured exercise programs as part of cancer treatment. Marcelo Ruz, the secretary of the association of patients with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, AMOH, has noted that physical exercise could reduce up to 30% of new cancer cases.

title: La formación superespecializada en cáncer de ovario, clave para una patología sin diagnóstico precoz
hco: ASOCIACION MAMA OVARIO HEREDITARIOASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: The importance of super-specialized training in ovarian cancer has been the focus of the "Together for excellence in the approach to gynecological cancers" conference held in Madrid. The lack of early diagnosis and the need for referral to a National Reference Center for Ovarian Cancer were also discussed. In 2020, 3,543 cases of ovarian cancer were diagnosed in Spain, and 1,933 women lost their lives to the disease. The cancer is the leading cause of death from oncogynecological diseases and is often diagnosed in advanced stages. The conference was organized by the Association of Ovarian Cancer Patients and the Association of Hereditary Breast and Ovarian Cancer, with the support of GSK. The need for more than 20 surgeries per year to justify operating in a center was also highlighted, as well as the importance of specialized teams and equipment.

title: Soria registra cuatro empresas y dos entidades que han firmado el Pacto de Economía Circular
hco: ASOCIACION MAMA OVARIO HEREDITARIOASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Four companies and two institutions in Soria, Spain have signed the Pact for Circular Economy in Castilla y León, a voluntary agreement to develop a circular economy model in their activities. The companies are Copiso, Torraspapel, Bioeléctrica de Garray, and Gestión de Residuos Soria, and the institutions are the Provincial Council and the Chamber of Commerce. The pact has already been signed by 119 public and private entities across the region. The initiative is co-financed by the EU through the Circular Ecosystems project, within the Interreg Poctep program. The presentation of the pact was attended by the Director General of Copiso, Pascual López, and the Head of Environment and Social Responsibility of the cooperative, Carmen Yagüe.

title: Cena con motivo del Patrón de Enfermería en Guadalajara
hco: ASOCIACION MAMA OVARIO HEREDITARIOASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: The Official College of Nursing in Guadalajara organized its traditional Brotherhood Dinner on March 24, which was attended by approximately 300 nurses from the Guadalajara province. The occasion not only commemorated the patron saint of nursing, but also honored retiring nurses who have devoted their lives to the profession. The dinner was graced by dignitaries from the local government, the University, and other professional organizations. Raúl Prieto, the President of the Official College of Nursing, expressed his gratitude to the attendees and acknowledged the significance of nursing in society, referring to it as the "foundation and philosophical basis of healthcare." The event also featured the presentation of diplomas and gold insignias to retiring nurses, including Carmen Yagüe Guerrero. The festivities concluded with a lively dance.

title: Is the SNOO FDA Approved? Historic Announcement Made
hco: ASOCIACION MAMA OVARIO HEREDITARIOASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: The Happiest Baby's SNOO smart bassinet has been granted De Novo approval by the FDA. This approval is due to its ability to keep babies on their backs while they sleep, reducing the risk of SIDS and SUID. Unlike unsafe foam wedges or positioners, the SNOO uses wearable blankets with "wings" clipped to the bassinet to prevent babies from rolling over. The FDA's approval is a historic announcement that has been years in the making, beginning in 2020 when the SNOO was accepted into the FDA's Breakthrough Devices program. The SNOO also features motion to rock a baby to sleep and has a white-noise function, which helps babies stay asleep longer. The SNOO is priced at $1,695, but there is a rental program available and some workplaces offer it as an employee benefit. Dr. Harvey Karp, the founder of Happiest Baby, hopes that more companies will offer the SNOO as a benefit, as it could potentially save lives.

title: La relación de una paciente de mieloma múltiple y su médica fuera de la consulta
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Teresa Regueiro, who is a patient with multiple myeloma and also the president of the Spanish Community of Patients with Multiple Myeloma (CEMMp), had a meeting with her doctor, María Victoria Mateos, outside of the consultation room to talk about the rare blood cancer. This disease starts in the bone marrow and affects patients who are over 65 years old. In Spain, there are around 3,000 new cases of this disease each year. Thanks to therapeutic innovation, the survival rates have increased from three to four years at the end of the last century to over 10 years today. This has allowed the disease to be treated as a chronic condition. The relationship between the doctor and the patient is very important in managing the disease, and trust is an essential element. The CEMMp provides patients with information and hope. New treatments, such as immunotherapy and CAR-T therapy, aim to help patients live with the disease as if they didn't have it.

title: Teresa Regueiro: "Yo siempre digo que el cáncer no te hace ni mejor, ni peor, tú eres lo que eres"
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Teresa Regueiro is the President of the European Myeloma Patients Association and has launched a project called Casa Vila, which aims to raise awareness of multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer that affects around 12,000 patients in Spain. Casa Vila is a documentary that tells the story of Regueiro's personal experience with the disease and the community of patients with multiple myeloma. The project needs to raise €10,000 by December 23, 2023, to cover the technical production costs. Regueiro hopes the documentary will show the true face of the disease and increase understanding and awareness of it. The project has currently raised 22% of its funding goal, and those who contribute can receive special rewards.

title: "España es un referente mundial en investigación del mieloma múltiple"
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Teresa Regueiro, the president of the Spanish Multiple Myeloma Patient Community (Cemmp), has said that Spain is a global leader in the research of multiple myeloma. Regueiro, who is herself a patient of the disease, established the Cemmp to assist and provide support to other patients. She has called for increased funding for CAR-T treatments, which have proven to be effective, and has emphasized the need for the approval of innovative treatments. Regueiro has also stressed the importance of fairness in diagnosis, treatment, and emotional support for patients, as well as access to information on nutrition and appropriate exercise programs. Spain is the second country in the world, after the US, to recruit patients for clinical trials for multiple myeloma, and has benefited from new drugs and tools for disease management.

title: Lanzado un diccionario sobre mieloma múltiple que puede contribuir a lograr un mejor manejo de la enfermedad
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Pfizer, in collaboration with hematologists and patients, has launched an online "Multiple Myeloma Dictionary" that provides information on the meaning of values in diagnostic and follow-up tests, among other things. The dictionary is endorsed by the Spanish Multiple Myeloma Patients Community (CEMMP) and the Pethema Foundation. The dictionary is a simple and intuitive information resource that functions like a regular search engine, allowing for a deep and organized exploration of all terms related to multiple myeloma, from A to Z. The dictionary aims to help newly diagnosed patients and their families understand the disease and related concepts better. Teresa Regueiro, president of CEMMP, believes that the dictionary will help patients clear up doubts about many words related to their disease that may be completely unknown to them.

title: Pacientes con mieloma múltiple piden a Sanidad la financiación "inmediata" de la terapia CAR-T
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: The Spanish Multiple Myeloma Patients Community (Cemmp) is requesting "immediate" funding from the Ministry of Health for CAR-T therapy, which has achieved remission of the disease in patients who had not achieved it before. The therapy CAR-T represents a promising option in the treatment of resistant multiple myeloma, according to known trials. All patients treated with CAR-T developed in the Hospital Clínic de Barcelona presented a response to treatment, of which nearly 70% are complete after 18 months and the rest are partial. Teresa Regueiro, the president of Cemmp, stated that the Ministry of Health "denies patients the most basic thing: access to the most innovative therapies." The Cemmp is also premiering an animated short film titled 'Discovering Multiple Myeloma' on Tuesday to raise awareness of this little-known hematologic cancer.

title: La tercera revolución terapéutica del mieloma múltiple que España todavía no financia
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Spain has played an important part in the progress of treating multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer that affects over 3,000 Spaniards annually. Hematologists are closer than ever to finding a cure, thanks to new treatments that have improved survival rates and quality of life for patients. However, CAR-T and bispecific molecular antibody therapies have not been approved for commercial use in Spain due to the government's lack of reimbursement. Teresa Regueiro, founder and president of the Spanish Multiple Myeloma Patients Community, is frustrated that these treatments are not available to patients. Despite this, researchers remain hopeful that these therapies will eventually lead to a cure for multiple myeloma.

title: Inquietud entre los pacientes con mieloma múltiple por no acceder a terapias CAR-T: "Significa muertes"
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Patients with multiple myeloma are worried about the limited availability of CAR-T therapies. Teresa Regueiro, the president of the Spanish Community of Multiple Myeloma Patients, claims that the Ministry of Health is unwilling to finance these treatments, despite their proven effectiveness. CAR-T therapy is a promising option for treating the incurable blood cancer that affects roughly 15,000 people in Spain. It is a type of immunotherapy that modifies the patient's T cells to target cancer cells. Regueiro cites a recent study conducted by the Hospital Clínic de Barcelona that demonstrated all patients treated with CAR-T exhibited a response to the therapy, with 70% achieving complete responses after 18 months. The Ministry of Health has not authorized funding for these therapies due to their high cost, but Regueiro argues that denying them to these patients will result in deaths.

title: New 3-in-1 TAVR guidewire capable of hemodynamic measurements, LV pacing impresses cardiologists
hco: COMUNIDAD ESPAÑOLA DE PACIENTESCON MIELOMA MULTIPLECEMPPASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: A new TAVR guidewire, the SavvyWire, capable of continuous hemodynamic measurements and LV pacing has been found to be safe and effective in a clinical trial. The device was developed by Canadian medical device company OpSens Medical and was acquired by Haemonetics Corp. for $253m in October. The SAFE-TAVI clinical trial included data from 119 patients, with TAVR procedures performed using the SavvyWire found to be both safe and effective. The study’s primary efficacy endpoint was seen in 98.3% of patients, while the secondary efficacy endpoint was seen in 99.2% of patients. A key safety endpoint was also seen in 99.2% of patients. No deaths, strokes or cases of ventricular perforation were reported. Future studies should examine the long-term clinical benefits of this technology. The study was led by Ander Regueiro, MSc, PhD, an interventional cardiologist with Hospital Clinic Barcelona in Spain.

title: CNIO Biobank Director Eva Ortega joins the Spanish Science, Technology and Innovation Advisory Council (CACTI)
summary: Eva Ortega Paíno, who is the scientific director of the CNIO Biobank, has been chosen as one of the 13 new members of the Ministry of Science and Innovation's Science, Technology and Innovation Advisory Council (CACTI). The CACTI allows the scientific and technological community, along with economic and social agents, to take part in issues related to science, technology, and innovation. Ortega has three decades of experience in the health sector, academia, and biotechnology industry, primarily in oncology. She is also in charge of the biobanks area within the national platform of Biobanks and Biomodels of the Carlos III Institute of Health, and the director of management of RENACER (the National Network of Brain Metastasis). Diego Moñux is also one of the new members of the CACTI, which comprises of internationally renowned members of the scientific and technological community, as well as representatives of the main business associations and trade unions.

title: La directora del Biobanco del CNIO, Eva Ortega, se incorpora al Consejo Asesor de Ciencia, Tecnología e Innovación
summary: Eva Ortega Paíno, a molecular biochemist and scientific director of the Biobank of the National Cancer Research Centre (CNIO), has been appointed as a member of the Advisory Council on Science, Technology and Innovation (CACTI) by the Spanish Ministry of Science and Innovation. Ortega is one of the 13 new members of the CACTI, which serves as a participation body for the scientific and technological community, as well as economic and social agents, on matters related to science, technology, and innovation. Diego Moñux is also a member of the CACTI, which received over 90 candidates for the position. Ortega has been the director of the Biobank of the CNIO since 2019 and coordinates the biobank area within the national platform of Biobanks and Biomodels of the Carlos III Health Institute.

title: The Boca Interview: Angel Sanchez
category: The given text is a 'Research' article about the life and career of fashion designer Angel Sanchez.
summary: The article titled "The Boca Interview: Angel Sanchez" discusses the life and career of Angel Sanchez, a famous fashion designer who has created couture for popular figures such as Beyoncé, Sandra Bullock, and Taylor Swift. Sanchez initially pursued a career as an architect, but later switched to fashion, having learned dressmaking from his mother. He won his first American fashion competition, which propelled him to the international market. Sanchez's designs have been featured on magazine covers, red carpets, and luxury department stores. He has collaborated with celebrities and served as a judge on "Project Runway Latin America." Recently, Sanchez relocated to South Florida with his spouse and established Sanchez + Coleman Studios, where he creates bespoke pieces and limited collections. His goal is to design collections that are surprising and reflect his clients' personalities.

title: Forseti Protection's Mario Rodriguez to teach cannabis security at NYU - Buffalo Business First
hco: ASOCIACION MADRILEÑA DE ENFERMOS DELUPUS Y AMIGOSASOCIACION DE PACIENTES
summary: Mario Rodriguez, founder and president of Forseti Protection Group in Buffalo, has been selected to teach a course on cannabis security at New York University. The course, called "Cannabis Security: Safeguarding the Green Industry," will cover ways to protect products at all levels of the cannabis supply chain and how to stay in compliance with state regulations on security. Rodriguez, who has been running Forseti for over a decade, has been helping cannabis companies across the state to build and implement effective and compliant security plans for their businesses. He said the opportunity came through an acquaintance with connections with NYU, which has a certificate program in the business of cannabis. Rodriguez will teach the virtual course as an adjunct professor with NYU.

title: Happy Munkey Founders Win New York Cannabis Permits - Now What?
summary: The co-founders of Happy Munkey, Vlad Bautista and Ramon Reyes, have won conditional adult use retail dispensary licenses in New York City. Bautista landed a Manhattan permit, and Reyes won one in Brooklyn. They plan to develop their respective marijuana shops individually, at least for now, although the Happy Munkey brand will continue. The brand and cannabis rolodexes the two have compiled positioned them to raise money and find store locations independent of the $200 million social equity fund being run by the Dormitory Authority of the State of New York. The licenses aren't tied to the Happy Munkey brand yet, but that could change. The pair has a big following and is confident of competing with unlicensed operators. They anticipate real estate to be a big hurdle and estimate that their new stores might open in the first quarter of 2024.

title: Soledad service dog wins award for providing comfort to Army veteran
summary: Soledad's service dog, Huey, has won the Dog Chow Visible Impact Award for providing comfort to Army veteran, Ramon Reyes. Reyes was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Traumatic Brain Injury from events that occurred in Iraq, and the key to his recovery was service dog Huey. Huey can detect when a dizzy spell is coming on by smelling changes in Reyes' body chemistry and can help him balance. He can also smell when Reyes is going to get a migraine well in advance of when the migraine actually hits. Reyes now works as a mentor and trainer at Operation Freedom Paws, where he is able to share his skills and experience with other veterans. As the winners of the Visible Impact Award, Huey and Reyes will receive $10,000, and Operation Freedom Paws will receive $25,000.

title: Las personas con VIH, protagonistas de su atención: “No somos una foto fija”
hco: GRUPO DE TRABAJO SOBRE TTO DEL VIH
summary: The documentary 'Optimal Model: for everyone' proposes a personalized model of care for people with HIV, in which their individual needs are taken into account. The model is developed by a multidisciplinary group of experts and NGOs involved in HIV care, and it aims to focus on chronicity and individualization, making the person with HIV the center of decisions. The importance of personalizing care is emphasized, as the needs of each person with HIV are different and may vary over time. Juanse Hernández, from the HIV Treatment Working Group, states that it is time to listen more to people with HIV and involve them in the process of their health. The role of the community and associations in care is also highlighted, as they are present where the health system does not reach or does not have networks. The goal is not to place the person with HIV at the center, but to put all the agents in their eyes.

title: Global Health Student Experiences: Paulina Ramirez - College of Medicine
hco: GRUPO DE TRABAJO SOBRE TTO DEL VIH
summary: Paulina Ramirez, a senior MS4 international elective student at Drexel University College of Medicine, had the opportunity to spend her last month of medical school in Trujillo, Peru, thanks to Medical Electives. She had two main goals: to strengthen her medical Spanish and to expose herself to obstetrics and gynecology. The Medical Electives' strong Medical Spanish program was ideal for her as it reinforced her conversational Spanish and focused on medical Spanish. Toward her second goal, the exposure in the hospital was very good and inspiring, and she was challenged to think outside the box and learn how to deal with challenges when technology or medications were not available at a moment's notice. She established strong relationships with her host family and future residents across the United States and the United Kingdom and learned so much about the Peruvian culture.

title: United Appoints Steve Wagner EVP – Training, Education and Development, Enhances Core Agent and Broker ...
summary: United Real Estate has appointed Steve Wagner as the Executive Vice President of Agent Training, Education, and Development (T.E.D.). Wagner's responsibility is to lead the development of a new multi-phase agent development system that builds competitive skills and increases agents' production levels at each phase of their careers. The company will deploy all agent and broker training globally through United University's learning management system within the company's proprietary technology platform, Bullseye Cloud. Wagner is the co-founder and CEO of Virtual Properties Realty - United, which is the largest residential brokerage in Greater Atlanta and the State of Georgia. He launched a successful real estate school and innovative, proprietary agent training programs that now support over 4,400 agents in his company. United's purpose-built brokerage model is capturing market share in a contracting real estate market. The company's profitability, driven by the efficiencies of its business model, has resulted in hundreds of millions of dollars recaptured for strategic investments and higher commission payouts to agents.

title: Arizona lawmakers can't agree on mental health legislation. Here's why
summary: Arizona lawmakers are struggling to agree on mental health legislation, despite a renewed bipartisan effort this year. Observers attribute this to the fact that mental health issues have been ignored for a long time and that it is difficult to hold providers accountable for the services they are paid to provide. Former state Senator Nancy Barto, who worked on mental health bills during her time in the legislature, believes that the entrenched power structure in how mental illness has been dealt with in the past is a major obstacle to progress. Barto is encouraged by the creative, bipartisan, and incremental bills being proposed this year, which include separating the oversight of the Arizona State Hospital from the Arizona Department of Health Services and creating secure residential facilities for people with serious mental illnesses. She believes that the will to get things done and an understanding of the need for change are the biggest barriers to progress.

title: Former senator encourages social workers to advocate for change - GCU News
summary: Former Arizona Senator Nancy Barto spoke to social work and sociology students at Grand Canyon University, urging them to advocate for change in the behavioral health system. Barto, who chaired the Health and Human Services committee, emphasized the importance of individual advocacy and encouraged students to engage with their legislators and become their own lobbyists. She also criticized the system, calling it "a mess" and challenging to reform due to conflicts of interest. Barto's primary concern was helping the chronically mentally ill, drawing on her personal experience with her brother's severe schizophrenia. Despite losing her recent election, Barto continues to educate legislators on these issues and relies on her faith as a guide. The event was attended by both graduate and undergraduate social work students.

title: Cataluña y País Vasco, oasis nacional en el “generalizado abandono” de la salud mental en prisiones
summary: The incidence of mental health problems in prisons is a growing concern in Spain, with around 45% of inmates suffering from a mental disorder. However, access to psychological support is limited, with just 0.2 psychiatrists per 1,000 prisoners. Only three regions in Spain have integrated prison healthcare into their services: Catalonia, Navarra and the Basque Country. The latter two have been praised for their provision of mental health support, with Álava prison having a dedicated psychiatric unit. The lack of resources means that prisoners are often prescribed medication as a substitute for professional support. The Spanish Penitentiary Health Society has called for increased access to mental health support in prisons, and for more doctors to be appointed to work in this field.

title: Albolote tiene un módulo terapéutico para 65 presos con trastornos mentales
summary: The Albolote Penitentiary Center in Granada, Spain has a therapeutic module for 65 inmates with severe mental disorders such as schizophrenia, delirium, and bipolarity. The prison has resources specifically designed to treat acute pathologies. José Joaquín Antón Basanta, the head of the prison's healthcare services, stated that the module is staffed by a multidisciplinary team consisting of psychologists, psychiatrists, and social workers who work together to provide personalized care to the inmates. According to Basanta, the module has been successful in rehabilitating inmates and reducing the number of incidents in the prison.

title: Sanidad dentro de los muros de la cárcel: «Yo no veo presos en nuestra consulta, veo pacientes»
summary: The article discusses the healthcare system in Spanish prisons and the challenges faced by healthcare professionals working in these facilities. The article highlights the high prevalence of mental illness among prisoners and the increased incidence of infectious diseases within the prison population. José Joaquín Antón Basanta, the president of the Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health, emphasizes the importance of providing adequate healthcare for prisoners and the need for more healthcare professionals in the field. The article also discusses the shortage of healthcare professionals and the lack of opportunities for younger professionals to learn from experienced colleagues. The article concludes by emphasizing the humanity of prisoners and the need to provide them with quality healthcare.

title: Adicción a la droga en prisión: "Es un problema muy importante, se necesitan más sanitarios"
summary: Around 76% of prisoners in Spain are drug users, according to a report by the Spanish Observatory of Drugs and Addictions. The issue is a significant health risk to inmates and requires a more substantial response from the penitentiary healthcare system, according to José Joaquín Antón Basanta, president of the Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health. However, the system faces a structural shortage of staff, and the responsibility for prison healthcare has not been transferred to the regional governments, except for Catalonia, Navarre, and the Basque Country. This hinders a more agile response to health issues. The prison system offers specific drug treatment modules, and NGOs such as Proyecto Hombre work with drug addiction within the prisons. Basanta calls for more healthcare staff in prisons to improve preventive work and for prisons to offer emotional and mental health support to inmates with drug addiction.

title: SESP: "La Atención Primaria ha desaparecido de las prisiones, somos una medicina de urgencia"
summary: The president of the Spanish Society of Penitentiary Health (SESP), José Joaquín Antón Basanta, has stated that primary care has disappeared from Spanish prisons, leaving them with only emergency care. The lack of medical professionals in prisons is a recurring problem, with only 160-170 prison doctors out of the 500 needed in Spain. The working conditions in prisons are also a deterrent to new doctors, with only 6-7 candidates applying for the last 80 vacancies. The situation has led to a lack of regular consultations and monitoring of patients, resulting in a focus on emergency care. This is a concern for prisoners and their families, especially as many prisoners have had limited contact with healthcare throughout their lives and may have health issues that require regular monitoring. The SESP has been calling for a response from public officials to address this issue for years.

title: Berakah alerta: aumento crítico de necesidades alimentarias y habitacionales en Vitoria
summary: Berakah, a social work organization linked to the Diocese of Vitoria, has reported a concerning increase in demand for food and housing assistance in the city. Asier López de Arkaute, a volunteer at Berakah, has emphasized the critical situation that many families in Vitoria-Gasteiz are currently facing. The report highlights the efforts of the 275 volunteers working in 36 different services, with a particular emphasis on the growing demand for services such as the Zugaz dining room, breakfasts and snacks for children and adolescents from families without resources, and the Garbin Txiki program for the care of babies. The report also notes that the lack of food resources and access to rental housing are the two major challenges facing the city. Berakah, in collaboration with Caritas Diocesana, has become one of the most important social and charitable resources in Vitoria, operating under the umbrella of the Alava Church.

title: Irene Sánchez-Escribano, convocada para el Mundial de Budapest
hco: ASOCIACION MURCIANA PARA LAPROMOCION DE LA SALUDAMUPROSA
summary: Irene Sánchez-Escribano, a Spanish athlete from Toledo, has been selected to compete in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the World Championships in Budapest. She is one of 56 athletes chosen by Spanish coach José Peiró to represent Spain at the biennial event, which will take place from August 19 to 27. The Spanish team includes 29 women and 27 men, with the possibility of expanding to 59 athletes when the World Ranking is finalized. Irene Sánchez Serrano's contribution to the team is in the 3,000-meter steeplechase event.

title: La atleta toledana Irene Sánchez-Escribano, subcampeona de España en los 3.000 obstáculos
hco: ASOCIACION MURCIANA PARA LAPROMOCION DE LA SALUDAMUPROSA
summary: Toledo athlete Irene Sánchez-Escribano has become the sub-champion of Spain in the 3,000m hurdles at the national championship held in Torrente, Valencia. Sánchez-Escribano finished the race with a time of 9:27.12, just one second behind the winner, Marta Serrano, who also broke the Spanish under-23 record. The Real Federación de Atletismo highlighted the beauty of the hurdles race, which was decided in the final moments. Sánchez-Escribano has already set her sights on the World Championships in Budapest, which takes place between 19 and 27 August. She sent a message through her social media accounts congratulating her fellow athletes and declaring her intention to compete in Budapest.

title: Sánchez-Escribano, subcampeona de España de 3.000 obstáculos | Noticias La Tribuna de Toledo
hco: ASOCIACION MURCIANA PARA LAPROMOCION DE LA SALUDAMUPROSA
summary: Irene Sánchez-Escribano, a Spanish athlete, finished as the sub-champion of Spain in the 3,000-meter hurdles event, clocking a time of 9:27.12. However, she was outdone by Marta Serrano, who won the championship with a time of 9:26.35, setting a new record for the sub-23 category and the championships. Irene Sánchez-Escribano had aimed to win her seventh national title in the 3,000-meter hurdles but fell short. She will now prepare for the World Championships in Budapest, Hungary, in August, with a training camp in Soria after the Spanish Championships. Irene Sánchez-Escribano hopes to make it to the finals in Budapest and achieve her first world championship medal.

title: Preservar la salud, un derecho que debemos cuidar
hco: SOC ENFERM INFECCIOSAS COMUN VALENCCOLEGIO OFICIAL DE MEDICOS DE VALEN
summary: Dra. Mercedes Hurtado Sarrió, the president of the Ilustre Colegio Oficial de Médicos de Valencia, emphasizes the importance of defending public health on World Health Day. The organization's primary function is to monitor the exercise of the medical profession to ensure that the population's health rights and interests are protected. They investigate and report all matters related to professional intrusion and maintain the appropriate level of quality of professional services provided by their members. The organization recently obtained a new conviction for professional intrusion, where a person injected hyaluronic acid into clients without proper preparation, qualifications, or membership. The organization's role in defending the right to protect our health is only one example. The organization's goal is to maintain a public healthcare system that is one of the fundamental pillars of society.

title: El Parlamento reprueba al consejero de Salud por sus "continuas salidas de tono en declaraciones públicas"
summary: The Parliament of Cantabria has reprimanded the Health Minister, César Pascual Fernández, for his "continual outbursts in public statements." The motion was initiated by the PSOE and supported by the PRC, while Vox abstained and the PP voted against it. The motion also urged the government to ensure medical services in all Cantabrian clinics, incentivize rural healthcare, and prevent the closure of clinics for more than 15 days due to a lack of physicians. The motion was prompted by Pascual's comments that the current management model of clinics had no future and that no physician wanted to work in rural areas. The opposition parties criticized Pascual's management of the healthcare system, while the PP defended him, accusing the opposition of manipulating data and lacking loyalty.

title: El gobierno de Cantabria nombra a César Pascual como consejero de Sanidad
summary: The government of Cantabria has appointed César Pascual as the new Health Minister. The President of Cantabria, María José Sáenz de Buruaga, announced the new structure of the autonomous government, which will have nine ministries. Pascual, who was previously the spokesperson for health in the Cantabrian Parliament, will be responsible for rebuilding the public healthcare system and returning efficient management to the Cantabrian Health Service. Pascual has a degree in Medicine and Surgery from the University of Cantabria and has also held various positions in the field of drug addiction, including coordinating the Regional Plan on Drugs in Cantabria and serving as sub-director of the National Plan on Drugs. He has also held positions of relevance in the political sphere, such as Vice-Minister and Director General of Coordination of Health Care Assistance in the Community of Madrid.

title: Más de 350 congresistas y 120 ponentes en la XVIII edición del Congreso Nacional de Pediatría para Estudiantes de ...
summary: The Faculty of Medicine at the University of Cantabria is hosting the XVIII National Congress of Pediatrics for Medical Students and Teaching Innovation from February 22 to 24. The congress has over 350 participants from across Spain, including Erasmus students, and features more than 120 speakers from different specialties. The event includes presentations, roundtables, and over 30 workshops. This year, a new space called "key points" has been created to emphasize various relevant issues for any pediatrician, such as pediatric emergencies or the vaccination calendar. The congress was officially inaugurated by the rector of the UC, Ángel Pazos, the mayor of Santander, Gema Igual, the health counselor of the Cantabria government, César Pascual Fernández, and other officials. The congress is organized by medical students at the University of Cantabria and is supported by various organizations.

title: Salud valorará establecer un punto de extracción de sangre semanal en el consultorio de Liaño
summary: The Health department in Cantabria is considering establishing a weekly blood extraction point at the Liaño medical center, which serves 50% of the population of Villaescusa. The proposal was made by the mayor of Villaescusa, Constantino Fernández, and will be evaluated by Health Minister César Pascual after receiving a report on the current state of the center and its resources. Pascual also discussed improving medical attention for residents of Liaño and La Concha with the mayor, including addressing shortages of professionals during vacation periods. Pascual promised to assess proposals from the municipality and provide an early and effective response to ensure the best healthcare for Villaescusa residents. The meeting was considered satisfactory by the mayor, and the councilor for Employment, Internal Organization, Social Services, and Equality, Mara San Miguel, also attended.

title: Pascual habla del copago como opción contra las listas de espera y PRC y PSOE reaccionan
summary: César Pascual, the Health Minister of Cantabria, has sparked controversy by proposing that copayments could be utilized to decrease waiting lists in the public health system. Pascual made these remarks during an interview with Diario Médico, but they have only recently been made public. The PSOE and PRC parties, who previously governed together, have strongly opposed the idea and stated that they will never support copayments. The PRC has requested clarification from the president, María José Sáenz de Buruaga, on whether she supports the "business health" system advocated by Pascual. The PSOE has scheduled a press conference to address the matter. The PRC will also interrogate the minister in parliament.

title: César Pascual asegura que Cantabria ya tiene "muy avanzado" su futuro Plan de Salud Digital
summary: César Pascual, the Health Minister of Cantabria, has announced that the region has made significant progress on its future Digital Health Plan, which will fully integrate technology to improve healthcare provision.
