summary: The Asociación Ciudadana Cántabra Anti Sida celebrated its 31st anniversary in Santander, Spain. The association works for the rights of people living with HIV in the region. The event was held at the Central Library in Santander under the theme '30 years and... a memory'. The association highlighted the progress made in the healthcare and social sectors since its inception. The Asociación Ciudadana Anti-SIDA has been working for the rights of people living with HIV for 31 years and has contributed significantly to the cause.

title: Las personas con VIH demandan un modelo de atención adecuado como pacientes crónicos
summary: People living with HIV are demanding an adequate care model as chronic patients, as they face premature aging, higher cardiovascular risk, and other health problems. In Spain, 55% of HIV-positive individuals are over 50 years old, and their risk of experiencing health issues increases with age. To address this, a multidisciplinary group of medical societies, patient associations, and community entities, including the Anti-AIDS Citizen Association, has identified the need to define an Optimal Model of Care for Patients with HIV from a chronic perspective. The group demands tools to stratify patients into seven profiles based on their needs, and each profile includes tailored care proposals adapted to their reality. The group made this demand during the VI Brunch&Share event, where they shared knowledge, best practices, and projects developed with the support of ViiV Healthcare in 2023.

title: El Área Campo de Gibraltar Oeste incorpora a un representante de las asociaciones de pacientes
summary: The Area of Sanitary Management of Campo de Gibraltar Oeste has added a representative of patients' associations to its Commission for Humanization of Health Care. The new member is from the Mutual Cooperation Group of Campo de Gibraltar, which includes up to 15 entities from the disability and health sector. The Association Ciudadana Anti-SIDA is one of the eight entities that are part of this group. The initiative aims to add the users' point of view to the decisions made to humanize the activities carried out in their health centers, both in the hospital and primary care areas. The Plan for Humanization has four strategic lines, one of which is citizen participation, and it is one of the concerns of the Andalusian Public Health System.

title: Insisten en la importancia de las pruebas frente al VIH para frenar la infección
summary: The Citizen Anti-AIDS Commission of Navarra has set up an information tent on Carlos III street to raise awareness about the significance of early HIV testing on the International Rapid HIV Test Day. The commission's goal is to decrease the spread of the infection by urging individuals who have engaged in risky practices to get tested. The commission also conducts the rapid HIV test at its headquarters on Carmen Street. The test is dependable and private, and the outcomes are obtained in 20 minutes. If the outcome is positive, the patient is directed to the public health system, where they can receive antiretroviral medication. The commission highlights the importance of sexual education in preventing, diagnosing, and treating other sexually transmitted infections, which have been increasing in recent years.

title: Una campaña para promover la salud sexual en San Fermín
summary: The Youth Council and the Citizen Anti-AIDS Commission of Navarra have launched a campaign to promote sexual health during the San Fermín festival. The campaign aims to provide free preventive material in 198 establishments in Pamplona, including bars and clubs, to promote equal, diverse, and consensual sexual relationships among young people. More than 23,000 male condoms, over 1,000 female condoms, over 600 latex wipes, and 3,000 single-dose lubricants will be distributed during the festival. In addition, 5,000 cardholders with campaign information, condoms, and lubricants, as well as badges and t-shirts, will be handed out. The campaign also includes a street parade that will distribute information and preventive material. The initiative has been supported by the Public Health and Labor Institute of Navarra and the Pamplona Federation of Peñas.

title: La Asociación Rayuela forma a jóvenes parados en idiomas y hostelería para facilitar su empleo en el sector turístico
summary: The Asociación para el Desarrollo Económico y Social Rayuela is promoting a project called Humboldt 10, which aims to train unemployed young people in languages and hospitality to facilitate their employment in the tourism sector. The project, which is aimed at 68 people, focuses mainly on training young people under 30 years of age who are unemployed and have no work experience, as well as long-term unemployed people, for their integration into the labour market. The project includes training in areas such as new technologies related to the tourism sector, obtaining a professional food handler certificate, cleaning and disinfection with COVID-19 protocols, community management, and preparation of orders and online sales. The project is executed by the Rayuela Association and financed by the Government of the Canary Islands through the Canarian Employment Service and the State Public Employment Service.

title: Nuevos programas de inserción laboral para mujeres en pequeños municipios
summary: The Canarian Government has approved a program to support women in both rural and urban areas of small Canarian municipalities, with the aim of promoting their employment. The program will receive a subsidy of €467,153 and will last for 12 months, benefiting a total of 284 women. The program will provide a personalized itinerary to improve their employability and chances of integration into the labor market, combining job orientation, advice, information, training, and acquisition of transversal competencies and skills. Additionally, the program will connect participants with the local business community. The entities responsible for developing the program include the Fundación Canaria ISBS, the Asociación para el Desarrollo Económico y Social Rayuela, and Acción Laboral.

title: El Comité Antisida de València responde al estigma del VIH con el servicio de atención psicológica en hospitales
summary: The Comité Antisida de València, con el apoyo de la Fundación "la Caixa", ofrece apoyo psicológico a personas con VIH en hospitales. El proyecto tiene como objetivo abordar las consecuencias psicológicas del estigma asociado con el VIH y el SIDA, que pueden llevar a estrés y problemas de salud mental. El servicio ha ayudado a 209 personas con VIH en 2023, principalmente aquellos con un diagnóstico reciente o aquellos que experimentan angustia psicológica relacionada con vivir con la enfermedad. El servicio está ubicado en el CIPS de Valencia y atiende a pacientes de varios hospitales, incluidos los hospitales Doctor Peset, La Fe, Clínico y Manises. El servicio es esencial para abordar las barreras sociales asociadas con el VIH y el SIDA, que pueden evitar que las personas busquen ayuda debido al estigma.

title: El Ayuntamiento apoyará la labor de Proxecto Home y del Comité Anti-sida con sendas subvenciones de 25.000 euros
summary: The Local Government of Ourense has approved two nominative subsidies of €25,000 each for the Monte do Gozo Foundation - Proxecto Home and the Comité Ciudadano Anti-SIDA de Ourense. These subsidies are meant to finance health programs in the city. The decision was made during the Local Government's meeting where they also approved seven urban licenses and a one-month extension to the concessionaire company Ibernisha to start repairing the Termas de A Chavasqueira.

title: Reivindican acabar con el estigma asociado con el VIH y que los avances en derechos sociales se alineen con los médicos
summary: On World AIDS Day, the Association Sare and the Citizen Anti-AIDS Commission have urged for an end to the stigma surrounding HIV and for social rights to align with medical advancements. These groups have emphasized the need for sexual education to combat discrimination and for a community-led approach to tackling the disease. Antonio López, the director general of health for the Navarre region of Spain, has called for affected individuals to be involved in decision-making processes and highlighted the importance of prevention strategies, including biomedical, structural, and educational interventions. López has also noted that while the number of undiagnosed cases had decreased, almost 50% of new diagnoses were still considered late. The groups have urged the government to improve accessibility to healthcare, including PrEP medication and education, and to develop a more holistic approach to care for those living with HIV.

title: Sare responde a Itxaso que a los presos de ETA no se les aplica "legislación ordinaria normalizada"
summary: Sare, a Basque prisoners' rights group, has responded to the Spanish government's delegate in the Basque Country, Denis Itxaso, stating that ETA prisoners are not subject to "standardised legislation". The group's spokespersons, Bego Atxa and Joseba Azkarraga, have also praised the demonstration held in Bilbao, which they say was attended by tens of thousands of people. They added that the mobilisation was a "backing to continue working against exceptional policies". The group called for the release of prisoners based on an ordinary penitentiary policy. They also criticised the "ad hoc" legislation that has been implemented, which they say has nothing to do with the current situation in Basque society.

title: La Fundación Eduardo Kocina presenta diversas formaciones ligadas al socorrismo en el deporte de montaña
summary: The Eduardo Kocina Foundation has launched various training courses related to mountain rescue to enhance competencies for job opportunities such as piste-ski patrollers, support lifeguards in mountain intervention units, and lifeguards in winter sports competitions and other events. The courses consist of intervention and rescue in accidents or emergency situations in ski areas, with a total of 60 hours, marking slopes, signaling and lifeguarding in spaces, with 60 hours, and first aid, with 40 hours. Most of the positions are already filled, but a few are still available. The foundation's goal is to be a reference for society in creating activities and programs that promote a more inclusive and supportive society. The courses are conducted in Pola de Lena and the polideportivo's climbing wall, with the Foundation Diversas contributing to the training.

title: Las notarías dispondrán de documentos en lectura fácil para que las personas con discapacidad intelectual puedan ...
category: The text can be categorized as 'Research'.
summary: The Fundación Aequitas, Fundación ONCE, and Plena inclusión have introduced a plan that modifies notarial texts, such as those pertaining to inheritances, sales, or donations, into easy-to-understand language. The goal is to enhance the cognitive accessibility of these types of documents by offering explanatory texts and simple models to guarantee that individuals with comprehension difficulties receive valuable and necessary information for their lives. The models will create informative versions of genuine documents that are more accessible to people with comprehension difficulties. The initiative involved six individuals with disabilities who signed a document at the notary, seven individuals with disabilities who allowed their cases to be utilized as an illustration to adapt to easy-to-read language, and seven support organizations. The Fundación Kyrios also participated in the project.

title: Acompañamos a la Fundación Mutua Madrileña en la entrega de sus XI Ayudas a la Acción Social | FEDER
summary: Fundación Kyrios de Apoyo Personal, along with Juan Carrión and Santiago de la Riva, accompanied the Mutua Madrileña Foundation during the XI Awards for Social Action ceremony. The event recognized and supported non-profit initiatives that contribute to improving the socio-economic reality and quality of life of vulnerable groups. The awards, which have an annual endowment of €1,000,000, were given to associations that have made a significant impact in areas such as disability, childhood, social exclusion, the environment, and health. Each of the selected associations received financial aid to continue developing their projects and improving the lives of the people they serve. The event was held at the Business Center of Mutua Madrileña and was attended by prominent figures from the business and social sectors.

title: SFM premia el servicio de ayuda al duelo de la Fundación Mario Losantos del Campo
summary: SFM has awarded 25,000 euros to Fundación Mario Losantos del Campo (FMLC) for their project "El duelo: un horizonte común" in the II Concurso de Proyectos de final de vida y/o ayuda al duelo. FMLC will use the funds to provide free therapeutic care to the population of Madrid in cases of complicated grief, grief training for socio-sanitary professionals, and awareness-raising activities for parents and teachers in educational centers. FMLC's project was chosen for its experience, success, and multidisciplinary approach towards the taboo topic of grief. The jury praised FMLC's work in offering specific training to professionals in a field where there is still a deep academic void. The competition aims to award a total of 100,000 euros to non-profit entities for the development of activities to help grief and/or people in the final stages of life in Madrid. The funds come from the recycling of metals obtained from municipal cremations managed by SFM. FMLC is a foundation that has been working for over two decades to build a better and fairer society, developing projects based on health and education in Spain, South America, and Africa.

title: La Universidad de Cantabria celebra el potencial investigador femenino en el Día Internacional de la Mujer y la Niña ...
summary: The University of Cantabria celebrated the International Day of Women and Girls in Science with a range of activities to showcase the contribution of women to science and encourage new generations to pursue scientific careers. During the event, researcher Cristina Manchado read a manifesto calling for greater gender equality in the scientific field. The university's rector, Ángel Pazos, highlighted the important role played by women in the institution's research. The program included conferences, talks, and contests held in different educational centers of the region, as well as collaborations with institutions such as the Filmoteca de Cantabria. The event also recognized the efforts of participants in various contests, including a drawing competition on the role of women in prehistory, a comic contest on women in computing, and a video contest highlighting the contribution of women.

title: El Gobierno regional entrega 520 lotes de uniformes al personal voluntario de 33 agrupaciones de Protección Civil
summary: The government of Castilla-La Mancha has distributed 520 sets of basic uniform to 33 local entities for their volunteer personnel of Protection Civil. The distribution is part of the government's efforts to provide necessary equipment to the region's 243 Protection Civil groups, which consist of 4,200 volunteers. The government has spent nearly 2.8 million euros since 2015 to provide new equipment to these groups. The uniform sets consist of a cap, a short-sleeved shirt, pants, a jacket, a belt, a pair of boots, and a reflective vest. The government has also provided other equipment, including emergency materials, portable generators, water trailers, cargo trailers, and more. The government has allocated around 450,000 euros in grants this year to provide equipment to these groups.

title: Personal joven voluntario de Irán planta 100.000 árboles para proteger a las personas y el planeta.
summary: A young volunteer from the Iranian Red Crescent Society led a national tree-planting campaign to mitigate the effects of climate change in Iran. The country has been hit by severe floods and droughts in recent years, and the Red Crescent Society has responded by planting 100,000 trees to help reduce the impact of natural disasters. Trees play a crucial role in combating climate change by absorbing carbon, producing oxygen, providing shade and cooling, and maintaining soil health. They can also protect communities from weather-related disasters by absorbing excess water during floods, retaining rainwater in the soil to reduce damage caused by droughts, and protecting coastal communities from tidal surges. The Red Crescent Society's campaign involved over 10,000 young volunteers who planted the trees in just 20 minutes, demonstrating unity and positive action in the face of the climate crisis.

title: CIMAR efectuó capacitaciones a personal voluntario del Bote Salvavidas | Directemar
summary: The Centro de Instrucción y Capacitación Marítima (CIMAR) conducted three training sessions for volunteers of the Bote Salvavidas, including basic first aid, induction in radar operation, and survival at sea. The first training was conducted remotely and covered basic first aid for 30 participants. The second training, held in person, provided an introduction to radar operation for four participants. The final training, which will take place on July 28, will cover survival at sea. These training sessions reinforce the cooperation between the Dirección General del Territorio Marítimo y de Marina Mercante and the Bote Salvavidas, and aim to ensure the safety of human life at sea.

title: #EXCLUSIVO El Gobierno va por la reestructuración de AySA antes de su privatización y lanza un agresivo plan de ...
summary: The government is planning to restructure AySA, a state-owned company that provides water and sewage services in Buenos Aires, before it is potentially privatized. To do so, it has initiated an aggressive plan of voluntary retirements and pre-retirements, which includes a special gratification payment that will be paid in installments based on the worker's seniority. This plan is available to the entire workforce, including pre-retirement personnel. AySA was included in the list of state-owned companies to be privatized in the latest project of the Ley Bases, which led to the restructuring plan. The Obras Sanitarias union, led by José Luis Lingeri, supports the measure and has provided guidance to workers throughout the process.

title: Subvenciones Injuve. Justificación
summary: The Manual de Instrucciones de Justificación de Subvenciones del Injuve provides guidelines for entities receiving subsidies for the maintenance, operation, and equipment of youth associations, organizations, and service providers. The manual includes regulatory information for subsidies, as well as instructions for document presentation and expense allocation. Additionally, the manual specifies the annexes that entities must complete for justification, including a certification of volunteer participation.

title: Los medios de comunicación conocen de primera mano la ‘hoja de ruta’ de la industria farmacéutica en España
summary: Farmaindustria organized the seminar "Industria Farmacéutica & Medios de Comunicación", where the Association's management team and journalists analyzed the current situation of the pharmaceutical sector in Spain. The seminar was attended by about thirty journalists from various media outlets and the Association had the opportunity to address the reality of the medication sector in Spain and answer questions from professionals in the field. The Association's director general, Juan Yermo, and subdirector general, Javier Urzay, discussed the challenges and priorities of the sector in the coming months, focusing on the Strategic Plan of the Pharmaceutical Industry and its three main axes: improving access to innovation, promoting biomedical R&D, and investing in national drug production. Isabel Pineros, the director of the Access Department, explained Farmaindustria's proposals to improve the model of access to innovation in the National Health System.

title: Crece el número de nuevos fármacos para tratar patologías poco frecuentes
summary: The European Medicines Agency approved 16 innovative therapies for rare diseases last year, which represents over a third of all approvals. One in four clinical trials conducted in Spain is for rare diseases. Despite the challenges of developing drugs for rare diseases, including low prevalence, complex and delayed diagnoses, and difficulties in conducting clinical trials, there have been decades of progress in molecular diagnosis, regulatory reform, and translational research. The European Union's Orphan Medicines Regulation, passed in 2000, stimulated the development of treatments for rare and mostly hopeless diseases. However, the approval of these drugs does not guarantee patient access to them. Isabel Pineros, director of Farmaindustria's Access Department, stated that "the absence of an agile and effective procedure drives the use of alternative, individually-based pathways that were not designed for this purpose."

title: Sanidad tarda 715 días en aprobar los fármacos urgentes
summary: Spain takes 715 days to approve Priority Medicines (Prime) - drugs that have been granted accelerated authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) due to their potential to address unmet medical needs or provide significant therapeutic advantages over existing treatments. This is despite the fact that the EMA only takes 150 days to approve these medicines. Spain has authorized the financing of only 15 Prime drugs, with 11 having restricted financing. Isabel Pineros, the Director of Access at Farmaindustria, has urged Spain to improve its access to innovative treatments and to accelerate the funding of Prime drugs. Pineros believes that Spain needs to be consistent with the steps taken in the European Union to ensure that innovation reaches patients as soon as possible.

title: Farmaindustria reconoce que la disponibilidad de medicamentos contra el cáncer en España "tiene que mejorar"
summary: The director of the Access department of Farmaindustria, Isabel Pineros, has acknowledged that the availability of cancer drugs in Spain needs improvement, as only 57% of those approved in Europe are available in Spain with an average waiting time of 20 months for patients to access them. This delay and lack of availability affects both public and private healthcare patients. Pineros highlighted that companies do not market new innovations in Spain until they have received funding approval from the Ministry of Health. This information was collected from the annual report of Indicators of Access to Innovative Therapies in Europe 2022, which analyzed the state of public funding for medicines authorized between 2018 and 2021. The report shows that the availability and waiting time for cancer drugs have worsened in Spain in the past year. Farmaindustria has proposed improvements to the evaluation and pricing procedures of drugs to reduce waiting times and ensure equal opportunities for Spanish patients.

title: España tarda, de media, dos años en aprobar un medicamento para una enfermedad minoritaria
summary: Spain takes an average of two years to approve a drug for a rare disease, and only 6% of rare diseases have any kind of treatment. There are 146 orphan drugs approved by the European Medicines Agency, but Spain only has 81 of them in its catalogue, while 25 have been rejected and 17 are still being studied. Isabel Pineros, Director of Access at Farmaindustria, says that the negative aspect is that these 21 new drugs took an average of two years to be included in funding, which is too long for patients who have no alternative. Spain is a leader in clinical trials, with 23% of the thousand initiated each year in Spain aimed at rare diseases. About three million patients in Spain have a rare disease, and approximately 80% are caused by a genetic mutation, with 65% being serious and disabling. Isabel Pineros calls for a predictable process with clear schedules that includes patients and clinicians, as they are the experts who must be heard in the case of rare diseases.

title: “Es necesario establecer un sistema de acceso temprano a los medicamentos que aporten mayor beneficio clínico a ...
summary: Isabel Pineros, the Director of Access at Farmaindustria, participated in the V Spanish Summit Against Cancer organized by the Spanish Group of Patients with Cancer (Gepac). During the summit, Pineros emphasized the need to establish an early access system for drugs that provide greater clinical benefit to cancer patients. She suggested the system should have participation from doctors and patients and a provisional price that would adjust based on results. Pineros also highlighted the importance of considering the social value of drugs, including savings in healthcare and non-healthcare costs, and the impact on quality of life. The summit brought together experts, researchers, healthcare professionals, and patients to discuss the current challenges of access to therapeutic innovation. The cancer diagnosis and treatment have improved significantly in recent decades, but the disease remains a significant global health challenge.

title: FI apuesta por el pago por resultados para que los fármacos 'Prime' sean prioritarios | @diariofarma
summary: Pharmaceutical company Farmaindustria believes that the Spanish government should use payment-for-results mechanisms to reduce uncertainty in the use of priority medicines, which currently take longer to be approved than other products. The company's director of access, Isabel Pineros, said that Prime, a programme that includes scientific advice from the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and an accelerated review process, should make data from clinical trials more robust. However, Prime medicines still face restrictions in Spain, even though they are prioritised by the EMA. Pineros called for risk-sharing agreements and payment-for-results mechanisms to be used more widely, and for a dialogue with the government to ensure that priority medicines are approved more quickly.

title: Nuevas iniciativas para avanzar en la promoción de la igualdad dentro del sector farmacéutico | @diariofarma
summary: Farmaindustria and Mujeres en Farma are collaborating to promote gender equality in the pharmaceutical industry. A group of female executives from Farmaindustria, along with the association's director general and the president and co-founder of Mujeres en Farma, met to design joint projects to encourage female talent in the sector. The pharmaceutical industry has made progress in promoting gender equality, with women representing 53.4% of the workforce, double the average of other industries, and 44.8% of women in executive committees, more than twice the average of companies in the IBEX-35. Isabel Pineros, director of the Access Department at Farmaindustria, participated in the meeting. The industry is also committed to hiring young talent and will create a specific job portal for young people in the coming weeks.

title: U.S. Naval Support Facility Diego Garcia Beautifies Unaccompanied Housing Unit 13
summary: Black Mace construction company has finished rebuilding the U.S. Naval Support Facility Diego Garcia Unaccompanied Housing unit 13, which was originally constructed in 1984. The project's goal was to improve the living conditions for military personnel stationed on the island, with a focus on critical aspects such as roofing, plumbing, air conditioning, ventilation, and electrical systems. The reconstruction project was completed with a ribbon-cutting ceremony on February 26, 2024, celebrating the physical transformation of the infrastructure and highlighting the U.S. Navy's commitment to providing optimal living conditions for its personnel. The revitalized UH 13 barracks serve as evidence of the Black Mace construction team's dedication and expertise.

title: SLU DCHS Associate Dean Accepts Position of Dean at New University : SLU
summary: Jesus Garcia-Martinez, the Associate Dean for Research at Saint Louis University's Doisy College of Health Sciences, has accepted the position of Dean of the Vera Z. Dwyer College of Health Sciences at Indiana University – South Bend. During his six-year tenure at SLU, Garcia-Martinez led various initiatives related to advancing the college's research culture and made significant progress in the Integrated and Applied Sciences Ph.D. program and the Summer Healthcare Exploration Camp for high school students. DCHS Dean Bernard Rousseau expressed confidence in Garcia-Martinez's future endeavors and wished him well. A national search will be conducted for the next DCHS Associate Dean for Research. Saint Louis University is a Catholic, Jesuit institution that values academic excellence, life-changing research, compassionate health care, and a strong commitment to faith and service.

title: El fiscal de delitos de odio: “La bandera LGTBI es un emblema y no debería ser objeto de discusión”
summary: Miguel Ángel Aguilar has been appointed to lead the first specialized unit of the General State Prosecutor's Office for hate crimes and discrimination in Spain. The unit will address the increase in hate crimes, especially those that go unreported. Aguilar's department is currently studying hate speech messages, including those related to the recent political controversy surrounding the LGBT flag. Aguilar believes that the LGBT flag is an emblem of freedom and should not be subject to discussion. He also stated that removing the flag could be considered a hate crime if done with violence or intimidation. Aguilar stressed the importance of defending citizens' rights and preserving the positive values of acceptance, respect, and diversity in society.

title: Miguel Ángel Aguilar tomó posesión como fiscal del Supremo contra los delitos de odio y discriminación
summary: Miguel Ángel Aguilar has been appointed as the first Fiscal de Sala of the Prosecutor's Office against Hate Crimes and Discrimination. The position is newly created, and his appointment was presided over by the Attorney General of the State, Álvaro García Ortiz. Aguilar has been a prosecutor since 1993 and has worked in several specialized services, including those for minors, prison surveillance, labor accidents, and organized crime and drug trafficking. He founded the specialized service in the Provincial Prosecutor's Office of Barcelona against hate crimes and discrimination in 2009, which is the first service in Spain dedicated to combating this type of criminal activity. Aguilar has also participated in various working groups focused on studying hate crimes and has received recognition and awards for his fight against any type of discrimination.

title: El fiscal de Sala contra el odio y la discriminación advierte: “Todos podemos ser víctimas de estos delitos”
summary: Miguel Ángel Aguilar, the Fiscal de Sala against hate crimes and discrimination, warns that anyone can be a victim of these crimes, including members of groups that are not typically at risk of discrimination. He emphasizes the importance of education and awareness campaigns to prevent these crimes, and highlights the need for better coordination among communities and authorities to investigate and prosecute hate crimes. Aguilar is a pioneer in this field, having launched the first specialized unit in Barcelona in 2009. He also discusses the evolution of hate crimes in Spain since then, noting that new types of discrimination have been added to the legal framework, such as aporophobia, and suggesting that more may need to be added in the future, such as discrimination based on language or territorial origin within Spain.

title: El Consejo de Ministros aprueba el proyecto de ley para crear la Agencia Estatal de Salud Pública
summary: The Council of Ministers has approved the project to create the State Public Health Agency, which aims to improve the health, equity, and well-being of the population. The agency will modernize the surveillance system, incorporate the concept of one health, reinforce the evaluation of climate change risks, and evaluate the social determinants of health. The agency will also support the surveillance of infectious outbreaks with pandemic potential and offer its support to the surveillance of health determinants, the possibility of conducting population screenings, and other mechanisms that are not currently centralized. The project was originally proposed after the H1N1 pandemic in 2009, but it was not until the COVID-19 pandemic that it became a priority for the Ministry of Health and the regions. The agency will be established within six months, but the location of its headquarters is still unknown.

title: Mónica García no descarta prohibir la venta de tabaco a los nacidos después de 2009
summary: Spain's Minister of Health, Mónica García, has not ruled out banning the sale of tobacco to those born after 2009 as part of the Comprehensive Plan for Smoking Prevention and Control. The plan aims to implement measures to achieve a smoke-free generation and smoke-free spaces. García stated that the plan has many multidimensional measures that need to be implemented, and experiences in other countries will be reviewed to determine which are applicable to Spain's population. The plan includes generic packaging for tobacco products, which will undergo the legislative process, and other measures will follow. García hopes that the plan will be approved by the Council of Ministers within two weeks, with the consensus of other ministries.

title: Sanidad creará un grupo de trabajo de anestesia verde para reducir la emisión de gases
summary: The Spanish Minister of Health, Mónica García, has announced the creation of a ministerial working group on green anaesthesia to reduce the emission of gases from this specialty. Anaesthesia has a significant impact on the environment as anaesthetic gases have potential warming effects up to 2,500 times greater than carbon dioxide. García wants to learn about the best practices of green anaesthesia and reduce the environmental impact of this specialty. She made the announcement during the annual congress of the Spanish Society of Anaesthesiology, Resuscitation and Pain Therapy, which was attended by over 200 anaesthesiologists. However, if the healthcare system were a country, it would be the fifth most polluting in the world. The congress is taking place in Valencia, Spain, and has over 1,700 registered participants.

title: Mónica García arrasa con las guardias de 24 horas y crea un modelo para que se trabajen máximo 17
summary: Mónica García, the Minister of Health in Spain, is determined to eliminate 24-hour shifts for medical professionals and establish a maximum of 17-hour shifts, despite opposition from some doctors. She believes that working 60 hours a week, which includes a weekend shift, is an "aberration" and needs restructuring. The change will require a modification of the Statute of the National Health System, which will be attempted in 2024. García plans to work with unions, scientific societies, and autonomous communities to implement the change gradually. She wants to stabilize medical professionals, who are currently overworked, and ensure that no patient is attended to during the 23rd hour. García has acknowledged that there will be resistance to the change, but she believes it is necessary to manage professionals better and change a 50-year-old model.

title: Mónica García anuncia la activación de la Estrategia para impulsar la industria farmacéutica en España
summary: Mónica García, the Minister of Health in Spain, has announced a strategy to boost the pharmaceutical industry in the country. She stressed the need to change the perception that "the best industrial policy is not to have an industrial policy" and to attract the sector to benefit the healthcare system. García also highlighted the importance of a multidisciplinary health approach and community sovereignty in medicine production. The collaboration between the government and companies will address digital and environmental transitions and ensure accessibility and sustainability of the healthcare system. The minister also emphasized the importance of social determinants of health, such as housing and social inequalities, and the need for consensus on health policies. García spoke at the IV edition of the Wake Up Spain! economic forum organized by EL ESPAÑOL, Invertia, and Disruptores.

title: Ayuso contra Mónica García por las residencias: "Es una rabieta. El traslado era decisión médica"
summary: Isabel Díaz Ayuso, the President of the Community of Madrid, has responded to criticism from the Minister of Health, Mónica García, about the management of elderly care homes during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ayuso has dismissed the criticism as a "tantrum" from someone who has lost at the polls and fled the Madrid Assembly. She has accused the left-wing parties of having a wrong conception of elderly care homes and claimed that they were not abandoning the elderly, but rather prioritizing medical decisions over political ones. Ayuso has also accused the opposition of attempting to judicialize politics and of being inhumane and lacking heart. During a breakfast meeting, Ayuso has rejected the possibility of transferring the Cercanías service to the Community of Madrid, as she believes that Spain is already "strongly decentralized."

title: Mónica García, ministra de Sanidad
summary: Mónica García Gómez has been appointed as the new Minister of Health in Spain. She faces several challenges, including reducing waiting lists in healthcare, promoting mental health, and increasing the number of medical professionals. Garcia was a doctor who specialized in anesthesiology before entering politics. She first participated in protests defending public healthcare as a spokesperson for the Association of Specialist Physicians of Madrid in 2012. She joined Podemos in 2015 and was elected as a deputy in the X legislature. She later joined Más Madrid, where she became the face and voice of the opposition to Isabel Díaz Ayuso. Garcia has also been involved in issues such as housing, the recognition of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic, and the rights of the Palestinian people.

title: Mónica García, nueva ministra de Sanidad | DiarioMedico
summary:
Mónica García Gómez ha sido nombrada como la nueva Ministra de Salud en España, reemplazando a José Manuel Miñones. García era previamente la líder de Más Madrid.

Translated text: Monica Garcia Gomez has been appointed as the new Minister of Health in Spain, replacing Jose Manuel Minones. Garcia was previously the leader of Mas Madrid.

title: Granite's “Saving By Shaving” Event Raises Another $3.5 Million for Boston Children's Hospital
summary: Granite Telecommunications raised $3.5 million for Boston Children's Hospital during its 11th annual "Saving by Shaving" event. The event featured over 700 Granite team members, Massachusetts Governor Maura Healey, and personalities from the Boston Celtics, including coach Joe Mazzulla, guard Jrue Holiday, and front office leaders Brad Stevens and Allison Feaster, alongside New England Patriots legends Joe Andruzzi and Matt Light, as well as Quincy Mayor Thomas Koch and Kevin Churchwell, MD, President/CEO of Boston Children's Hospital. The funds raised will contribute to essential pediatric research and treatments for future generations of children. Granite has donated over $300 million to numerous charitable causes and initiatives and has been named the no. 1 most philanthropic company in Massachusetts on three occasions. Kevin B. Churchwell, MD, President and CEO of Boston Children's Hospital, expressed his gratitude for the "unwavering support" from Granite Telecommunications and the community.

title: These are the highest-paid executives at Massachusetts' biggest hospitals - Boston Business Journal
summary: Executives at nonprofit hospitals in Massachusetts received pay raises in fiscal year 2021, despite financial stress caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, according to publicly required documents. The highest-paid executive in the state worked at Mass General Brigham, with former CFO and treasurer Peter Markell receiving $5.9 million in compensation, including a severance payment of $1.43 million. Mass General Brigham's current president and CEO, Anne Klibanski, received over $5 million in total compensation in fiscal 2021. Kevin B. Churchwell, who served as the predecessor of Sandra Fenwick, former CEO of Boston Children's Hospital, received total compensation of $2.86 million in fiscal 2021 after stepping into the role in March 2022. The president and CEO of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Laurie Glimcher, was the next highest-paid hospital executive, with total compensation of $3.99 million in fiscal 2021.

title: We as a community need to address gun violence
summary: Gun violence is a significant cause of increased rates of mental illness related to trauma, and communities of color are disproportionately affected by it. Boston Mayor Michelle Wu's leadership on this issue, demonstrated by her emphasis on a community-centered safety strategy and commitment to trauma support and recovery, is a cornerstone of our shared mission to develop a comprehensive and effective approach to preventing gun violence in the city. Dr. Kevin M. Simon is a child psychiatrist at Boston Children's Hospital and serves as the chief behavioral health officer for Boston. Dr. Kevin B. Churchwell is the president and CEO of Boston Children's Hospital. Dr. Alastair Bell is the president and CEO of the Boston Medical Center Health System.

title: Kevin Churchwell to speak April 24 on diversity, equity, inclusion - VUMC News
summary: Kevin Churchwell, former CEO of the Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital at Vanderbilt, will be giving a lecture on April 24th about the significance of equity, diversity, and inclusivity in medical education within the hospital environment. The lecture is named after John Chapman, MD, who was the dean of Vanderbilt University School of Medicine for more than 25 years. Churchwell is currently the president and CEO of Boston Children’s Hospital and has been actively involved in promoting health equity and inclusion for several years. He played a role in the development of Boston Children’s 2020 Declaration for Equity, Diversity and Inclusivity, which advocates for the creation and implementation of a comprehensive curriculum and training program aimed at promoting culturally effective pediatric healthcare delivery. Churchwell is a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Vanderbilt University School of Medicine.

title: Churchwell discusses DEI's role in medical education - VUMC News
summary: Kevin B. Churchwell, the former CEO of the Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt, spoke about the significance of equity, diversity, and inclusivity in medical education within the hospital environment. He stressed the importance of creating comprehensive structures that prioritize education, including equity, diversity, and inclusion programs. To ensure that these goals are continuously met, hospitals must develop a six-point Declaration for Equity, Diversity, and Inclusivity. This declaration demonstrates the hospital's commitment to recruiting, developing, and retaining a diverse workforce, eliminating structural racism from hospital policies, guidelines, and practices, and taking a leadership role in reducing child health disparities. In 2021, Boston Children's established the Sandra L. Fenwick Institute for Pediatric Health Equity and Inclusion to aid in reducing health inequalities through research, further diversifying the pediatric workforce, and influencing public policy.

title: Patriots' Devin McCourty, Matthew Slater, Gov. Maura Healey and 800+ Granite Teammates Participate in Granite's ...
summary: Over 800 people participated in Granite Telecommunications' 10th annual "Saving by Shaving" event, raising more than $4 million for Boston Children's Hospital and bringing the total raised in the event's history to over $50 million. The event also raised $100,000 each for two charities chosen by New England Patriots' football players. These include Boston Uncornered, a non-profit selected by safety Devin McCourty, and Edmiston Center, a non-profit selected by wide receiver Matthew Slater. During the event, Granite CEO Rob Hale presented a check to Kevin Churchwell, MD, President and CEO of Boston Children's Hospital. The event was attended by community leaders, celebrities, and athletes, including Massachusetts Governor Maura Healey, Quincy Mayor Thomas Koch, and radio personality Greg Hill.

title: Boston Children’s ranked second-best pediatric hospital in America
summary: Boston Children's Hospital has been ranked as the second-best pediatric hospital in America by U.S. News & World Report, with Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center taking the top spot. Boston Children's Hospital had previously held the number one position for nine consecutive years. The rankings are divided into seven multi-state regions, with Boston Children's being the top-ranked hospital in New England. The outlet also ranks hospitals by specialty, with Boston Children's and Cincinnati Children's tying for first place in the rankings of best pediatric diabetes and endocrinology treatment. Boston Children's was ranked number one in gastroenterology and neurology treatment, and number two in nephrology and urology treatment. Kevin B. Churchwell, President and CEO of Boston Children's Hospital, said in a statement that the hospital is "honored to be ranked among the nation's top pediatric hospitals."

title: Granite’s “Saving By Shaving” event raises $3.5M for Boston Children’s Hospital
summary: Granite Telecommunications, a company that provides communication and technology solutions to businesses and government agencies, has raised $3.5 million for Boston Children's Hospital's pediatric research through its annual "Saving by Shaving" event. This event, which began as a dare 11 years ago, now involves over 10,000 participants, including Tom Brady, Bill Belichick, and David Ortiz. Granite donated $2,500 for each participant, and this amount was matched by the Hale family, resulting in a $5,000 donation to The Every Child Fund at Boston Children's Hospital for each participant. The event was attended by Boston Celtics coach Joe Mazzulla, point guard Jrue Holiday, front office leaders Brad Stevens and Allison Feaster, along with legendary Patriots Joe Andruzzi and Matt Light, Quincy Mayor Thomas Koch, and Boston Children's Hospital Executive Director Kevin Churchwell. Over the 11 years, Granite has raised a total of $55 million for the hospital.

title: Equality for Women in Science: Not There Yet
summary: Nancy Andrews, the executive vice president and chief scientific officer of Boston Children’s Hospital, discussed the ongoing discrimination that women in science face today. This includes inadequate lab space, lower salaries, and fewer teaching and committee opportunities. Andrews acknowledged that progress has been slow and discrimination still exists, albeit in more subtle forms than in the past. She praised Duke University for its efforts to hire women into leadership roles, and during her time as dean of the School of Medicine, half of her vice deans were women. Andrews encouraged women scientists to seek out supportive colleagues with whom they can discuss challenges and celebrate successes. She also advised women to speak out when they experience inequities and to keep notes and files documenting instances of discrimination.

title: Joint Base Andrews' promotion testing goes digital
summary: Joint Base Andrews has introduced the Electronic Weighted Airman Promotion System (eWAPS) testing, marking a significant departure from the traditional pencil-and-paper testing method. The Air Force is adopting contemporary practices in personnel development to make the promotion process more efficient and fair. The rollout of eWAPS commenced with the Technical Sergeant cycle in February and will continue with the Staff Sergeant cycle. Spearheading this transition at Andrews is Nancy Floyd, 316th Force Support Squadron test control officer, along with a cadre of the 316th Force Support Squadron personnel dedicated to ensuring the successful implementation of the electronic testing platform. The eWAPS system allows test responses to be submitted directly to the Air Force Personnel Center, eliminating the need for traditional mailing of answer sheets. The new system offers greater flexibility and accessibility, especially for those facing logistical challenges due to their geographic location.

title: Stephen Herman Joins Fishman Haygood
summary: Stephen J. Herman has joined Fishman Haygood's litigation section as special counsel. Herman has 30 years of experience in civil practice, representing plaintiffs and defendants in commercial, class action, and professional liability matters. He was appointed in 2010 by the United States District Court - Eastern District of Louisiana as counsel for the businesses, individuals, and local governments involved in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill litigation. Apart from his legal practice, Herman teaches an advanced torts seminar on class actions at Loyola Law School and an advanced civil procedure course in complex litigation at Tulane Law School. He frequently speaks about and writes on various legal topics. Herman serves as president of the New Orleans Bar Association and chair of the Louisiana State Bar Association's Section on Class Actions, Mass Torts, and Complex Litigation. He is a past president of the Louisiana Association for Justice.

title: Fox Chase CEO Dr. Robert Uzzo Receives Society of Urologic Oncology's Joseph A. Smith Jr. Mentorship Award
summary: Robert Uzzo, the President and CEO of Fox Chase Cancer Center, has received the Joseph A. Smith Jr. Mentorship Award from the Society of Urologic Oncology. This award acknowledges Uzzo's contributions to mentoring trainees in the field of urologic oncology. He will be presenting a lecture on the significance of mentorship at the 24th Annual Meeting of the Society of Urologic Oncology. Uzzo is in charge of supervising Fox Chase's overall clinical operations and holds the G. Willing "Wing" Pepper Chair in Cancer Research. He is also the Executive Director of the recently launched Fox Chase-Temple Urologic Institute and the founding Executive Director of the Pennsylvania Urologic Regional Collaborative. Fox Chase Cancer Center is one of the top comprehensive cancer centers in the United States.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center is opening a Voorhees office
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center has announced the opening of its first office in New Jersey, located in Voorhees. The center sees around 14,000 new patients every year, with approximately 20% of those being from New Jersey. The new office will provide access to Fox Chase's cancer care services for patients in the state. Robert Uzzo, MD, FACS, is a urologic oncologist and the Chair of the Department of Surgical Oncology at Fox Chase Cancer Center. However, there is no mention of his specific contribution in the article.

title: Fox Chase Cancer Center Welcomes Patients to Newly Expanded Buckingham Site
summary: Fox Chase Cancer Center has invested $1.9m in expanding its Buckingham site in Pennsylvania, adding chemotherapy infusion and surgical consults to the services offered there. The location, which already offers other forms of radiation oncology, genetic counselling, high-risk breast clinical care, diagnostic CT scanning, surgical consults and access to clinical trials, has welcomed more than 500 patients per month since opening in 2009. The expansion includes eight infusion chairs, seven exam rooms and a CT scanner. The Buckingham site is home to Temple Health System’s CyberKnife Robotic Radiosurgery System, which delivers high-dose targeted radiation that can be completed in just a few sessions. It is an outpatient procedure that does not require incisions, anesthesia or hospitalization. Fox Chase Cancer Center President and CEO Robert Uzzo said the expansion would increase access to important treatments.

title: Here's what will revolutionize cancer care in the next 10 years, according to Fox Chase Cancer Center CEO Robert Uzzo
summary: Robert Uzzo, CEO of Fox Chase Cancer Center, predicts that cancer screening, treatment, and recovery will all change dramatically in the next 10 years due to advancements in medicine. He believes that researchers are on a very steep slope towards revolutionizing cancer care.

title: Local Car Dealer Helps 'Kick Cancer to the Curb'
summary: Local car dealer Gary Barbera donated $10,000 to Fox Chase Cancer Center as part of their “Kick Cancer to the Curb” campaign. This is the third annual donation by Gary Barbera’s on the Boulevard, a family owned and operated Dodge, Chrysler, Jeep, and Ram car dealership. Their fundraising efforts to support cancer research are part of Gary Barbera Cares, a charitable foundation established to give back to the Philadelphia community. The dealership’s beloved mascot, the Barbera Bear, made a special appearance to visit with nurses and staff from Fox Chase for the presentation. Fox Chase Cancer Center is one of the leading comprehensive cancer centers in the United States. Fox Chase President and CEO Robert Uzzo, MD, MBA, FACS received the check.

title: Dr. Ben Danielson Sues Seattle Children’s Hospital Alleging Unaddressed Serious Racism; Hospital Denies Allegations
summary: Dr. Ben Danielson, former head of Seattle Children’s Hospital’s Odessa Brown Children’s Clinic, filed a lawsuit on October 13, 2023, alleging systemic racism at SCH. Danielson, who served from 1999 to 2020 and resigned in protest, claims that racial biases negatively impacted the care of Black and Brown families. His lawsuit highlights the use of the phrase “Code Purple” to disproportionately target Black or Brown patients and an incident where a key administrator used a racial slur against him. Despite advocating for reforms, Danielson faced retaliation and scrutiny, leading to his resignation. The hospital denies these allegations, asserting their commitment to equitable care. Danielson’s lawsuit seeks damages under the Washington Law Against Discrimination, contending that SCH ignored his concerns and tolerated racist behavior. The case has been reassigned to Judge Ken Schubert, with a trial date set for October 14, 2024.

title: Former medical director sues Seattle Children's hospital alleging racial discrimination
summary: Dr. Benjamin Danielson, former medical director of the Odessa Brown Children’s Clinic at Seattle Children’s hospital, filed a lawsuit alleging racial discrimination and retaliation. Danielson, who resigned in November 2020 citing institutional racism, claims the hospital created a hostile work environment by permitting racial slurs and systemic racism, and treating Black and Brown employees unfairly. The lawsuit highlights issues such as lack of translation services and disproportionate use of security against Black patients. Despite his repeated concerns, Danielson faced an investigation for an alleged HIPAA violation, which he believed was retaliatory. Following his resignation, Seattle Children’s hired Eric Holder to conduct an independent investigation, which found persistent racial disparities and a culture of conflict avoidance. Danielson, a trusted pediatrician and advocate for equitable health care, led the clinic for over two decades and oversaw its expansion.

title: A shuttered clinic raises questions about anti-racism work in the medical field
summary: Seattle Children's Hospital's independent assessment of its anti-racism action plan highlighted ongoing challenges, including its relationship with the Odessa Brown Clinic. While a new clinic opened in Othello in 2022, the historic Central District location remains closed due to needed repairs. Dr. Ben Danielson, former medical director of the Odessa Brown Children’s Clinic, worked there for over 20 years and described it as a dream job. He left due to frustrations over the treatment of Black and Brown families at Seattle Children's Hospital and the institution's inadequate response to racism. Danielson is now a clinical professor at the University of Washington, focusing on preventing child incarceration. Seattle Children's Hospital's chief diversity officer, Alicia Tieder, acknowledged the difficulty of rebuilding community trust but emphasized the hospital's comprehensive anti-racism strategic plan initiated after George Floyd's death. The hospital plans to update the community on the Central District clinic's status by early fall.

title: OPINION | If We Can Find Millions to Build Fences Around a Youth Jail, We Can Invest in Helping Youth Thrive
summary: Recent events involving youth escaping a juvenile detention facility and the construction of a new fence have intensified debates on Washington's juvenile rehabilitation system. Critics argue that punitive measures and high-cost infrastructure, like the proposed $8 million fence and $9 million for private security, are ineffective and divert funds from more beneficial interventions. Research supports that early intervention and supportive services, such as mental health treatment and job training, are more effective in reducing youth offenses and recidivism. Dr. Ben Danielson, a pediatrician, advocates for ending youth incarceration and emphasizes the importance of investing in developmental opportunities for young people. He argues that the state should reallocate funds to programs that prevent offenses and support youth and families, rather than expanding detention facilities. This approach aligns with the original intent of the juvenile justice system, which aims to rehabilitate rather than punish.

title: Needlework group at Zachary United Methodist Church donates latest round of work to nursing home
summary: The Friends and Needles group at Zachary United Methodist Church recently donated various handmade items to local nursing facilities. The group, which includes members like Carla Murray, creates items such as walker caddies, shirt savers, and fidget blankets for patients. Their latest donation included 97 walker caddies, 90 shirt savers, and 30 fidget blankets. Additionally, they made 50 decorative pillowcases for Mother's Day gifts for female residents at Zachary Manor nursing home and are now working on pillowcases for male residents. The group also supports Louisiana United Methodist Children's and Family Services by making fleece blankets and quilts for children's homes and foster care programs. Carla Murray highlighted their prayer shawl ministry, where shawls and cloths are crocheted or knitted and distributed to those in need. The group operates on donations and received a $1,000 grant from JoAnn Fabrics in 2021. All items are blessed by their pastor before distribution.

title: ABC7's Cheryl Scott shares fertility journey, egg freezing experience as she takes reproductive future into her own hands
summary: Cheryl Scott, a meteorologist for ABC7 Chicago, has shared her fertility journey and experience with egg freezing. She began the process in February 2023, undergoing two cycles of hormone shots and egg retrievals. Scott chose to document and share her experience to support other women considering the procedure. Egg freezing has become increasingly popular, with over 25,000 procedures performed in the U.S. in 2021, a 31% increase from the previous year. Despite the high cost, ranging from $5,000 to $10,000 per cycle, more women are opting for it, with some employers and insurance companies offering coverage. Dr. Brian Kaplan, Scott's reproductive endocrinologist, explained the process and its benefits, including higher pregnancy rates and healthier babies when eggs are frozen at a younger age. Scott, in her late 30s, feels empowered by her decision, despite the challenging process, as it increases her chances of having children in the future.

title: Joan Eliasek Named New President of McKesson Canada
summary: Joan Eliasek has been appointed as the new President of McKesson Canada, succeeding Rebecca McKillican. Eliasek brings over 25 years of leadership experience in the healthcare sector and within McKesson Corporation, having held senior roles in operations, marketing, supplier management, extended care sales, and customer experience. As President, she will oversee McKesson Canada's diverse healthcare businesses, including pharmaceutical distribution, biopharma solutions, independent pharmacies, e-commerce retailer Well.ca, and the Rexall Pharmacy Group. Eliasek emphasized her commitment to improving health outcomes for Canadians and highlighted McKesson Canada's role in delivering medications, strengthening supply chains, and aiding patients with specialized therapies. She holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science and Business Administration from the University of Iowa and has served on several healthcare industry boards. Eliasek has been recognized with awards such as the Anne Eiting Klamar Leadership Award of Distinction and induction into the Medical Distributor Hall of Fame.

title: Bloom Burton & Co. Announces the 2024 Bloom Burton Award
summary: Bloom Burton & Co. has announced the launch of the 2024 Bloom Burton Award, with nomination submissions open until March 22, 2024. The award honors individuals who have made significant contributions to Canada's healthcare industry. Three finalists will be announced at the 2024 Bloom Burton & Co. Healthcare Investor Conference in April, and the winner will be celebrated at the Bloom Burton Award Gala on September 26, 2024, at The Ritz-Carlton, Toronto. Each finalist will receive a $25,000 cash prize. Joan Eliasek, President of McKesson Canada, is one of the esteemed judges for the award.

title: McKesson Canada Opens New State-of-the Art Distribution Centre in Surrey British Columbia
summary: McKesson Canada has opened a new state-of-the-art, 233,000 square-foot distribution center in Surrey, British Columbia, to support the province's growing healthcare needs. The facility delivers pharmaceutical medications, vaccines, and specialty pharmaceuticals to over 1,300 hospitals, clinics, and pharmacies. It features advanced automation technology to enhance efficiency and productivity, with the capacity to ship over 235,000 units daily. The site includes a Specialty Pharmacy campus for managing complex medications. Joan Eliasek, President of McKesson Canada, emphasized the company's commitment to improving health outcomes and ensuring reliable medication delivery across British Columbia. The investment also includes significant cold chain storage capabilities and environmental sustainability features. This new center is part of McKesson Canada's broader modernization efforts, including similar projects in Edmonton and Winnipeg, to bolster their distribution infrastructure and emergency response capabilities.

title: McKesson kicks off registration for ideaShare
summary: McKesson has opened registration for its ideaShare event in Las Vegas from June 22–25, 2023. Hosted by McKesson, Health Mart, and Health Mart Atlas, the event promises double the educational opportunities, new pharmacy technician-focused tracks, and a 2% rebate on OneStop Generics purchases up to $6,000. Nimesh Jhaveri, interim president of community pharmacy and health at McKesson, emphasized the importance of strong pharmacies for optimal healthcare outcomes and highlighted the comprehensive educational program, peer-to-peer learning, and access to the latest technology and tools. The event offers over 12 CE courses, allowing pharmacists to earn up to 10 CE credit hours. Additionally, it includes workshops, roundtable discussions, and sessions to help pharmacies prepare for upcoming CMS rule changes. Special programs for pharmacy technicians and a keynote session by Jason Dorsey are also featured. The event will conclude with a party headlined by Boyz II Men.

title: Genpact Extends Relationship to Transform McKesson's Finance Operations for Enhanced Service and Competitive ...
summary: Genpact and McKesson have extended their partnership to enhance McKesson's finance operations through automation and AI solutions. This collaboration, building on a 13-year relationship, aims to streamline and standardize finance processes, leveraging Genpact's expertise in process optimization. The focus will be on advancing McKesson's digital finance operating model, scaling capabilities, and evolving customer-centric models. Britt Vitalone, McKesson's EVP and CFO, emphasized that this partnership supports McKesson's strategic growth initiatives by reducing finance operation costs and better positioning the company to meet healthcare industry needs.

title: McKesson extends partnership with Genpact to enhance finance operations
summary: McKesson has extended its partnership with Genpact to enhance finance operations through automation and artificial intelligence solutions. This builds on their 13-year relationship, aiming to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of McKesson's finance processes. Britt Vitalone, McKesson's executive vice president and chief financial officer, emphasized that this collaboration will accelerate their strategic growth initiatives, reduce finance operation costs, and better position McKesson to meet healthcare industry needs. The partnership will focus on advancing the operating model, scaling capabilities with digital initiatives, and evolving customer-centric models. Tiger Tyagarajan, Genpact's president and CEO, highlighted the importance of adapting operating models in response to industry challenges. Genpact recently incorporated generative AI into its Enterprise360 platform to provide data-driven insights and enhance performance. Vidya Rao, Genpact's CIO, noted that this new capability will drive greater performance and transformation for clients.

title: Announcing the passing of William L. Henrich, MD, president since 2009
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: William L. Henrich, MD, MACP, president of UT Health San Antonio since 2009, passed away on March 14, 2024, at age 77 due to complications from his second stem cell transplant. Dr. Henrich's 15-year tenure saw the transformation of UT Health San Antonio into a top-tier academic health center, with significant advancements in cancer, obesity, diabetes, dementia, and aging programs. He led the institution through unprecedented growth, including $1 billion in construction projects, and significantly increased the institution's budget and research funding. A board-certified nephrologist and author of a widely used dialysis textbook, Henrich also guided the institution through the COVID-19 pandemic, expanding clinical practices and access to health care. His legacy includes the initiation of the UT School of Public Health San Antonio and a substantial increase in student enrollment and workforce. Dr. Henrich is survived by his wife, two children, and five grandchildren.

title: President of UT Health, William L. Henrich, has died
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: William L. Henrich, President of UT Health San Antonio, passed away at 77 due to complications from a stem cell transplantation for myelodysplasia, a rare blood cancer. Henrich, who had a successful stem-cell transplant 12 years earlier, had announced his medical leave in February. Serving as president since 2009, Henrich previously held roles as Dean of the School of Medicine and Vice President for Medical Affairs at UT Health San Antonio. Under his leadership, UT Health San Antonio became a top-ranked academic health center with renowned programs in cancer, obesity, diabetes, dementia, and aging. Henrich authored over 300 articles and was the founding editor of "Henrich’s Principles and Practice of Dialysis." He was a special trustee on the Texas Biomed Board of Trustees. Henrich is survived by his wife, two children, and five grandchildren. Memorial services are forthcoming.

title: Longtime UT Health San Antonio President Dr. William Henrich dies at 77
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Dr. William Henrich, who served as the president of UT Health San Antonio for 15 years, passed away at the age of 77 due to complications from a stem cell transplant for myelodysplasia. Henrich, a renowned kidney specialist and author of a textbook on dialysis, led the transformation of UT Health San Antonio into a top-ranked academic health center with world-class programs in various medical disciplines. His leadership, compassion, and dedication were widely recognized and celebrated by peers, including Dr. Sudha Seshadri and Larry Schelsinger. Henrich is remembered for his visionary contributions and supportive nature. He is survived by his wife, two children, and five grandchildren.

title: UT Health San Antonio President William Henrich has died at 77
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Dr. William L. Henrich, President of UT Health San Antonio, passed away at 77 due to complications from a second stem cell transplant. Leading the institution since 2009, Henrich significantly contributed to its growth, overseeing the establishment of the UT Health San Antonio Multispecialty and Research Hospital, the Center for Oral Health Care and Research, the Center for Brain Health, and the new UT School of Public Health San Antonio. A kidney specialist, Henrich authored 300 articles and the textbook "Henrich’s Principles and Practice of Dialysis." He was known for his mentorship and securing substantial research grants, expanding the institution's research capacity six-fold. Henrich's leadership, vision, and dedication left a lasting impact on the medical community and UT Health San Antonio. He is survived by his wife, two children, and five grandchildren.

title: February 2024 - IN MEMORIAM: WILLIAM L. HENRICH, MD | University of Maryland School of Medicine
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Dr. William L. Henrich, a renowned nephrologist and former chair of the University of Maryland School of Medicine's Department of Medicine, passed away in February 2024. Henrich served as chair from 1999 to 2006, during which time he made significant contributions to medical education and research. His tenure was marked by collaboration with prominent figures like Dr. Bruce Jarrell and Dr. Jay Perman, both of whom became university presidents. Henrich was known for his inspirational leadership and storytelling, which left a lasting impact on students and colleagues. His research focused on improving dialysis tolerance and understanding the role of renin in blood pressure regulation. He authored numerous articles and a major textbook on dialysis. After leaving Maryland, he became the President of the University of Texas Health-San Antonio. Henrich's legacy is remembered for his dedication to medical education, research, and patient care.

title: Beloved university President William L. Henrich remembered for contributions to his family, university and the world
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: William L. Henrich, MD, MACP, was a transformative leader and beloved President of UT Health San Antonio. Serving as president from 2009 until his passing in 2024, Henrich oversaw significant growth, including $1 billion in construction projects like the UT Health San Antonio Multispecialty and Research Hospital. He was remembered for his extraordinary character, humor, kindness, and selflessness. His leadership elevated UT Health San Antonio to a top-ranked academic health center with world-class programs in cancer, obesity, diabetes, dementia, and aging. Henrich was also a prolific author and a dedicated family man, deeply loved by his wife, children, and grandchildren. His legacy continues through the William L. Henrich, MD, MACP, Memorial Endowed Scholarship.

title: UT Health San Antonio mourns passing of 'visionary' president
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: William Henrich, the president of UT Health San Antonio since 2009, passed away due to complications from surgery. Henrich, a nephrology specialist, previously served as dean of the medicine school and vice president of medical affairs at UT Health San Antonio. During his presidency, he oversaw significant expansion and innovation, including the construction of a Center for Brain Health, the initiation of a proton therapy treatment center, and the groundbreaking of a $430 million multispecialty care and research hospital. Henrich also established a multi-year partnership with the San Antonio Spurs as their official sports medicine partner. His leadership and contributions to the institution and the broader community, particularly in COVID-19 research, have been widely recognized and appreciated.

title: President William L. Henrich remembered as friend, mentor, visionary at university tribute
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio held a tribute ceremony on April 5, 2024, to honor the late President William L. Henrich, MD, MACP, who passed away on March 14. Henrich was celebrated for his energy, compassion, and ability to unite people. He began his presidency in 2009 and transformed the institution into a premier academic health center. Despite battling cancer, Henrich remained committed to his vision. He inspired colleagues, overcame setbacks, and led significant projects. His legacy includes the Henrich Family Award for Compassionate Care, recognizing healthcare workers' empathy and respect. Henrich's dedication to family and humor were also highlighted. The William L. Henrich Memorial Endowed Scholarship was established in his honor.

title: The unexpected passing of William L. Henrich, university president
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: William L. Henrich, M.D., MACP, the President of UT Health San Antonio, passed away unexpectedly following complications from a second stem cell transplantation. During his 15-year tenure, Dr. Henrich transformed the institution into a top-ranked academic health center with world-class programs in cancer, obesity and diabetes, dementia, and aging. He was celebrated for his visionary leadership, creativity, hard work, and passion. Dr. Henrich's contributions significantly advanced the university's mission, making it a leading center for advanced academics, life-saving research, and comprehensive clinical care. His legacy will continue to inspire, and his absence is deeply felt by the entire community.

title: schools ranked among best in the nation - UT Health San Antonio
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio’s schools have been recognized nationally in the U.S. News and World Report’s list of best graduate schools for 2024. The Joe R. and Teresa Lozano Long School of Medicine ranked 36th for primary care and 50th for research medical schools. The School of Nursing’s Doctor of Nursing Practice program ranked 69th. Sonya Renae Hardin, dean of the School of Nursing, highlighted the importance of this achievement, especially given the current critical need for quality nurses. The School of Health Professions’ Master of Physician Assistant Studies program ranked 40th, and its occupational and physical therapy programs were also highly ranked. The Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences ranked 100th in the Best Biological Science Programs for 2022. UT Health San Antonio’s School of Dentistry was previously ranked number one in the 1990s. The rankings help prospective students choose the best graduate programs based on various criteria, including faculty resources and academic achievements.

title: Message from the President
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: President William L. Henrich of UT Health San Antonio announced he will be away for medical treatment starting February 19, 2024, with a positive outlook for his return. During his absence, Dr. Rob Hromas will serve as acting president while maintaining his roles as dean of the Long School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs. Andrea Marks, senior executive vice president and chief operating officer, will provide administrative and operational support to ensure smooth university operations. Dr. Henrich expressed confidence in Dr. Hromas, Ms. Marks, and the Executive Committee to continue the university’s missions and will maintain regular meetings with senior leaders. He appreciates the community’s support and looks forward to returning to the vibrant environment of UT Health San Antonio.

title: Structural insights into BCDX2 complex function in homologous recombination
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The study published in Nature explores the role of the BCDX2 complex, composed of RAD51B, RAD51C, RAD51D, and XRCC2, in homologous recombination (HR), a crucial process for DNA repair. Using cryogenic electron microscopy, the research reveals the structural details of BCDX2 in both its apo and ssDNA-bound states, highlighting how the amino-terminal domains of RAD51B, RAD51C, and RAD51D facilitate complex formation and ssDNA-binding specificity. Single-molecule DNA curtain analysis demonstrates BCDX2's enhancement of RAD51–ssDNA nucleoprotein filament assembly. The study also elucidates how RAD51C mutations in cancer patients impair DNA binding and HR mediator activity of BCDX2. Robert Hromas contributed to this research through his affiliation with the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, where he supported experimental design and data interpretation.

title: 2024 Presidential Awards recipients recognized at ceremony
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The 2024 Presidential Awards ceremony at UT Health San Antonio recognized 15 individuals for distinguished research, clinical excellence, teaching excellence, and staff individual excellence, as well as a team for outstanding collaboration. Established in 1985, these awards honor exemplary faculty and staff who excel in their roles and uphold the institution's mission and values. Acting President Robert Hromas, MD, FACP, praised the awardees for embodying the mission to improve lives through creativity, perseverance, and leadership. Hromas emphasized their collective contribution to education, research, and hope. He also honored the late President William L. Henrich, MD, MACP, highlighting the event's significance in continuing Henrich's legacy. Each awardee received a senate proclamation from Senator José Menéndez and a monetary award.

title: Repurposed drug brings new hope to treat breast cancer
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: A repurposed drug, cyclosporin, traditionally used for transplant recipients, shows promise in treating a specific type of inherited breast cancer. Virginia Kaklamani, MD, DSc, will lead a three-year study at the Mays Cancer Center, UT Health San Antonio, to evaluate cyclosporin in newly diagnosed patients. Robert Hromas, MD, professor of medicine and dean of the Long School of Medicine, along with Kimi Kong, PhD, discovered cyclosporin's potential to kill certain cancer cells.
