They are collaborating with Kaklamani to conduct clinical trials. This study aims to determine the optimal dosage for cancer patients, differing from transplant patients. The clinical trial is funded by the National Institutes of Health and the Mays Cancer Center, which is the only National Cancer Institute-designated Cancer Center in South and Central Texas. The ultimate goal is to provide another treatment option for breast cancer, which affects 300,000 people annually in the U.S.

title: UT Teen Health and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services host community dialogue
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Teen Health, part of UT Health San Antonio, has been collaborating with community organizations since 2003 to implement teen pregnancy prevention programs in South Texas. In July 2023, it received a $9.86 million federal grant to reduce teen birth rates in its 38-county service area. On February 23, Robert Hromas, MD, dean of the Joe R. and Teresa Lozano Long School of Medicine, welcomed Jessica Swafford Marcella from the Office of Population Affairs for a community dialogue. The event included discussions on staff safety, adolescent confidentiality, and access to healthcare. In the afternoon, Marcella led discussions on the "Take Action for Adolescents" initiative, aiming to support adolescent health and well-being nationwide. Kristen Plastino, MD, emphasized the importance of these initiatives for the health and well-being of youth aged 10 to 24, aiming to decrease high school drop-out and teen birth rates in South Texas.

title: Cancer survivors and their supporters celebrate life, raise funds during annual 5K
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Cancer survivors and their supporters celebrated life and raised funds at the 7th annual Give Cancer the Boot Survivorship 5K and 1 Mile Walk on April 6, despite misty skies. Over 900 participants gathered at Mays Cancer Center, home to UT Health San Antonio MD Anderson Cancer Center. Robert Hromas, MD, FACP, acting president for UT Health San Antonio, helped kick off the event and shared a personal story about his mother-in-law's battle with cancer. Hromas emphasized the importance of perseverance in the fight against cancer and the commitment to finding new treatments. The event raised $40,000 for the cancer center’s Patient and Family Services program, which offers vital support such as transportation and consultations. Ovarian cancer survivor Maria Gonzales attended to support others, despite her own health challenges. Mark Bonnen, MD, highlighted the Mays Cancer Center's history and its new state-of-the-art facility, marking a new era in cancer care and research.

title: President William L. Henrich remembered as friend, mentor, visionary at university tribute
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: President William L. Henrich of UT Health San Antonio was remembered for his energy, compassion, and ability to unite people during a tribute ceremony on April 5. Henrich, who passed away on March 14, had a profound impact on the university, inspiring many to join and work towards his vision of transforming UT Health San Antonio into a premier academic health center. Acting President Robert Hromas spoke about Henrich's legacy, expressing deep sorrow over his passing and recalling Henrich's optimism and leadership. Despite personal and professional setbacks, Henrich's resilience and dedication propelled the institution forward. His commitment to family and compassionate care was also highlighted, with the establishment of the Henrich Family Award for Compassionate Care. Henrich's legacy continues to inspire the university community to strive for excellence in education, healthcare, and research.

title: IBC Foundation awards $2 million for endowed faculty positions
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The International Bancshares Corporation (IBC) Foundation has awarded $2 million to The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio and The University of Texas School of Public Health San Antonio. This donation will fund four endowed professorships, each valued at $500,000, in various health disciplines. At the check presentation, Robert Hromas, acting president of UT Health San Antonio, highlighted the significance of this contribution, emphasizing that it will enable the recruitment of outstanding faculty and bolster the economic and educational landscape of San Antonio. Hromas noted that these endowments provide faculty with the security to innovate in medicine, public health, nursing, and research, fostering advancements in technology and addressing community health needs. The IBC Foundation aims to support lasting legacies in education and research, contributing to the future success of the university and the broader community.

title: Olvera to become psychiatry department chairman in the Long School of Medicine
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Rene L. Olvera, MD, MPH, will become the chairman of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio effective September 1, succeeding Steven R. Pliszka, MD, who retires on August 31. Robert A. Hromas, MD, FACP, dean of the Joe R. and Teresa Lozano Long School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs, announced the appointment. Olvera, originally from Brownsville, Texas, has extensive academic and clinical experience, including a focus on treating underserved children and adolescents. He has held various leadership roles and has been involved in numerous research studies funded by the National Institute of Mental Health. Olvera's wife, Michelle Villa-Olvera, MD, is an obstetrician-gynecologist practicing in San Antonio.

title: Newest UT Health San Antonio location opens, ready to serve growing northwest Bexar County
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio has opened its newest location, the UT Health Outpatient and Surgery Center at Kyle Seale Parkway, to serve the growing northwest Bexar County area. The opening ceremony on March 18 included leaders from The University of Texas System, UT Health Physicians, and The University of Texas at San Antonio, along with community representatives. Acting President Robert Hromas recalled envisioning the facility three years ago with the late President William L. Henrich and UTSA President Taylor Eighmy. Hromas emphasized the center's mission to provide cutting-edge medical care and innovative treatments. The five-story, 108,000-square-foot facility offers a range of services, including primary care, various specialties, diagnostic testing, and outpatient surgery. The center aims to enhance access to high-quality healthcare and support the community's growing needs. The project is expected to have an annual economic impact of $42.4 million and support around 130 jobs.

title: The Center for Global and Community Oral Health launches
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The University of Texas Health Science Center San Antonio School of Dentistry launched the Center for Global and Community Oral Health to address global dental challenges. The center aims to increase access to oral health care, integrate it with medical care, and disseminate health information. Peter M. Loomer, DDS, PhD, MBA, professor and dean, emphasized the center's potential for collaboration and knowledge exchange to improve global oral health. The center consolidates existing community programs, partnering with 76 training sites in South Texas, providing low-cost care to nearly 18,000 patients in 2023. It also extends its outreach globally, such as in Kenya, where significant improvements in oral health were observed. The center's initiatives are expected to enhance research and attract funding for various oral health issues.

title: UT Health San Antonio School of Dentistry opens special-care dental clinic in South Texas
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The UT Health San Antonio School of Dentistry has inaugurated the Phil and Karen Hunke Special Care Clinic, the first academic setting clinic in South Texas dedicated to treating individuals with intellectual, developmental, cognitive, or physical disabilities. The clinic features seven treatment rooms, five conscious sedation suites, and a "Zen Den" to reduce anxiety, serving up to 40 patients daily. It aims to address the shortage of trained dental professionals for special needs patients, providing essential training for students across various healthcare disciplines. Dean Peter M. Loomer emphasized the clinic's role in building a clinician base to serve this underserved population.

title: San Antonio officials visit UT Dentistry, learn about community programs
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: San Antonio Mayor Ron Nirenberg and city councilmembers visited UT Dentistry at UT Health San Antonio to learn about its community programs. They toured the Center for Oral Health Care and Research and discussed potential partnerships to expand dental services in underserved areas. Councilwoman Teri Castillo praised the Ricardo Salinas Pediatric Dental Clinic for serving low-income families, highlighting the importance of oral health in job readiness. The School of Dentistry has 11 community-based training programs and 76 affiliated sites, providing care and education. Mayor Nirenberg emphasized the link between oral health and well-being, pledging support for the school's initiatives. Dean Peter M. Loomer expressed commitment to serving the community and collaborating with local officials to improve public health.

title: School of Dentistry tops in Texas, 7th nationally in NIH research funding - UT Health San Antonio
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio School of Dentistry ranked first in Texas and seventh nationally in NIH research funding among 71 accredited dental schools for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2022. The school received $11,258,229 from the NIH, a 123% increase from the previous year. This achievement, highlighted by Peter M. Loomer, DDS, PhD, dean of the dental school, underscores the impactful research conducted by the faculty, students, and staff. Notable contributions include a $4.7 million grant led by Armen Akopian, PhD, to study pain mechanisms, and a K99 NIH Pathway to Independence Award for Audrey Rakian, DDS, PhD. The school secured a record $35 million in single- and multi-year grants during the academic fiscal year ending August 31, 2022.

title: A High-tech Research Clinic on Wheels
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The NHLBI is conducting the Risk Underlying Rural Areas Longitudinal (RURAL) Cohort Study to investigate high rates of heart and lung diseases in the rural South. This region, including Appalachia and the Mississippi Delta, has alarming rates of heart disease, obesity, high blood pressure, and COPD. The study utilizes a state-of-the-art mobile exam unit (MEU) to bring advanced health technologies to remote areas, facilitating in-depth health assessments. Vasan Ramachandran, M.D., a co-leader of the study, emphasized the region's health decline since the 1980s, attributing it to factors like food insecurity and poor healthcare access. The study aims to enroll 4,600 participants and has already examined around 2,100 individuals. Initial findings indicate significant health challenges, including early-onset heart disease and high obesity rates. The study collaborates with local communities to build trust and aims to inform better healthcare policies.

title: Sex-specific differences in the genetic and environmental effects on cardiac phenotypic variation assessed by ...
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The study examines sex-specific differences in heritability and genetic versus environmental contributions to cardiac variations using echocardiography in the Framingham Heart Study cohort. Results indicate significant heritability for both sexes, with no major differences in traits. However, sex-based differences were found in genetic and environmental inter-trait correlations. Men showed more genetic associations between cardiac structure and function, while women had more environmentally influenced associations. These findings suggest potential pathways for sex-based divergent heart failure phenotypes. Vasan Ramachandran contributed to the study design, analysis, and critical review of the manuscript.

title: Framingham Heart Study celebrates 75th anniversary
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The Framingham Heart Study celebrates its 75th anniversary, marking decades of groundbreaking research on heart disease and other age-related conditions. Initiated with 15,000 participants in 1948, the study has expanded to include diverse cohorts and multiple generations. Key findings include identifying high blood cholesterol, high blood pressure, cigarette smoking, and diabetes as major cardiovascular risk factors. Vasan Ramachandran, MD, FACC, serves as the Principal Investigator and Director, contributing significantly to the study's ongoing success. The study's impact is commemorated with events, including a fall open house and a spring celebration involving the local community and various institutions. The dedication of participants has been crucial, with no monetary compensation, reflecting their pride in contributing to global health knowledge.

title: Integrated omics analysis of coronary artery calcifications and myocardial infarction: the Framingham Heart Study ...
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The study titled "Integrated omics analysis of coronary artery calcifications and myocardial infarction: the Framingham Heart Study" utilized an integrative trans-omics approach to analyze genetic, epigenetic, and transcriptomic data from 3106 participants. The aim was to identify candidate genes associated with coronary artery calcification (CAC) and myocardial infarction (MI). Significant associations were found between CAC and genes like AHRR and EXOC3, and between MI and genes such as FYTTD1 and PINK1. The study highlighted the involvement of various biological pathways, including inflammation and endothelial function, in coronary disease. Vasan Ramachandran contributed significantly to the conception, design, and interpretation of the data. The findings suggest potential novel therapeutic targets for preventing coronary artery disease, although further research is needed for validation.

title: UT School of Public Health San Antonio inaugural dean receives $1.6 million UT System Faculty STARs award
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Vasan S. Ramachandran, MD, the inaugural dean of The University of Texas School of Public Health San Antonio, received a $1.6 million UT System Faculty STARs award. This award will fund infrastructure and renovations to advance public health in South Texas. Ramachandran, an internationally recognized physician-scientist and clinical epidemiologist, has been the principal investigator and director of the Framingham Heart Study since 2014. He joined UT Health San Antonio on September 1, after serving over 25 years at Boston University School of Medicine and School of Public Health. In Boston, he established three clinical stations for cardiac imaging, vascular function analysis, and cardiopulmonary exercise testing. The STARs award will enable him to construct similar facilities at UT Health San Antonio. The UT System Faculty STARs program, initiated in 2004, aims to attract and retain top faculty to enhance UT System institutions statewide.

title: Public Health Week observed in city, county proclamations
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Public Health Week was observed in San Antonio, highlighting the importance of addressing health inequities post-pandemic. Vasan Ramachandran, MD, dean of The University of Texas School of Public Health San Antonio, emphasized the need for strategies to tackle public health challenges exacerbated by the pandemic, such as mental health crises and economic hardships. The new School of Public Health, a collaboration between UT Health San Antonio and UTSA, aims to educate public health leaders and address regional health disparities. Ramachandran highlighted significant health challenges in San Antonio, including economic factors and health disparities in certain areas. He stressed the importance of focusing on social determinants of health and noted the alarming gap in life expectancy between different ZIP codes. The school plans to offer a Master of Public Health degree in 2024 and develop a Doctor of Public Health program, focusing on solutions for the region’s diverse population.

title: San Antonio, Bexar County observed Public Health Week
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: San Antonio and Bexar County observed National Public Health Week from April 3–9, 2023, with several local events supported by leaders from The University of Texas School of Public Health San Antonio. At a City Council meeting on April 6, Vasan Ramachandran, MD, the founding dean, along with his team, received city and county proclamations. The week aimed to educate the public, policymakers, and health care professionals about improving public health. The University of Texas School of Public Health plans to have nearly 400 students within its first five years, offering a Master of Public Health degree starting in 2024 and developing a Doctor of Public Health degree program. The new school is a collaboration between The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio and The University of Texas at San Antonio and is one of three public health schools in The University of Texas System. Events included proclamations, keynote lectures, and a Dean’s Community Lecture.

title: Delegates from Rep. Joaquin Castro's office visit School of Public Health
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Delegates from Rep. Joaquin Castro’s office, led by Rose Ann Maldonado, visited the University of Texas School of Public Health San Antonio to highlight the institution's efforts in public health education and workforce development. Dean Vasan Ramachandran and Associate Dean Deepu Kurian guided the tour through the newly renovated Research Administration Building. Congressman Castro secured $1 million in federal funding for the renovation, emphasizing the school's role in enhancing educational opportunities and community health in San Antonio. Ramachandran shared the school's vision, promoting inclusivity and collaboration, and expressed optimism about future interactions with elected officials to benefit students and residents. The visit underscored the school’s mission to be community-centered in its educational and research endeavors.

title: Honoring the life and work of Dr. Fernando Guerra
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) will host an event to honor Dr. Fernando Guerra, longtime director of the Metropolitan Health District. Community leaders will discuss healthcare in San Antonio and beyond. The event will be moderated by Dr. Vasan S. Ramachandran, Founding Dean of the University of Texas School of Public Health at San Antonio. Panel members include Henry Cisneros, Theresa De La Haya, and Reverend David Garcia. The event is in partnership with Metro Health and hosted by the College for Health, Community and Policy (HCAP) at UTSA. It will take place on April 5, 2023, from 12:00 PM to 1:00 PM at the UTSA Downtown Campus, Buena Vista Theater.

title: AtlantiCare Announces VISION 2030--its Ambitious 6-Year Plan Advancing Systemwide Strategies and Bringing in ...
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: AtlantiCare has announced VISION 2030, a six-year plan aimed at transforming healthcare through innovative strategies and new partnerships. Under the leadership of President and CEO Michael J. Charlton, appointed in October 2023, the initiative focuses on improving social determinants of health, expanding medical education, and leveraging technology via "AtlantiCare Powered by Oracle Health." Key partnerships include Oracle Health for digital transformation, Drexel University College of Medicine for medical training, Cleveland Clinic Cancer Institute for advanced cancer care, and Global Neurosciences Institute for enhanced neurological services. The plan is structured around four strategic pillars: serving the community, workplace excellence, accelerating transformation, and growing market share, each with specific, measurable goals.

title: New AtlantiCare CEO looks to make an impact, inside and outside the health system
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Michael Charlton, the new CEO of AtlantiCare Health System, aims to enhance patient access and experience while contributing to the revival of Atlantic City. Charlton, who previously served as interim CEO and has extensive experience in both healthcare and hospitality, is focused on maintaining AtlantiCare’s independence and exploring partnerships to improve care. He emphasizes the importance of patient-centric services, reducing clinician workload, and addressing community challenges such as food insecurity and housing. Charlton’s vision includes leveraging telehealth, expanding outpatient services, and fostering local collaborations to support both the health system and the community.

title: AtlantiCare Reveals Ambitious VISION 2030 Plan
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: AtlantiCare, the largest healthcare organization in South Jersey, has launched its VISION 2030 plan under the leadership of President and CEO Michael J. Charlton. This six-year initiative aims to transform healthcare delivery through new technologies, partnerships, and community-focused goals. Key partnerships include Oracle Health for digital transformation, Drexel University College of Medicine for medical education, Cleveland Clinic Cancer Institute for advanced cancer treatment, and Global Neurosciences Institute for enhanced neurological care. VISION 2030 sets ambitious targets such as reducing food insecurity and homelessness, expanding life expectancy, and growing market share. Charlton emphasizes the plan’s focus on innovation, efficiency, and equitable care delivery.

title: UChicago Medicine will begin offering resmetirom
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UChicago Medicine will soon offer resmetirom (Rezdiffra), the first FDA-approved drug for treating advanced metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), previously known as nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). This groundbreaking medication targets metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), a severe MASLD stage marked by liver inflammation and fibrosis. Michael Charlton, MBBS, Director of the Transplant Institute, highlighted that resmetirom is the first treatment to reverse fibrosis, potentially preventing severe outcomes like liver failure and cancer. Charlton and Mary Rinella, MD, led a phase three clinical trial showing that resmetirom halted or reversed liver fibrosis in most participants after a year of treatment. They emphasize the importance of routine screenings to identify more patients who could benefit from this drug. UChicago Medicine plans to integrate resmetirom into comprehensive treatment plans for eligible patients, including dietary therapy and lifestyle modifications.

title: Charlton named new head of AtlantiCare
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Michael Charlton has been appointed the new president and CEO of AtlantiCare, after serving as its interim president and CEO since June 1. The decision was made by AtlantiCare's Board of Trustees following a selection process by Korn Ferry. Charlton has been a board member since 2009 and served as chairperson for six years. He succeeds Lori Herndon, who retired in June. Charlton will oversee operations involving over 6,500 employees across five southern counties in New Jersey. He emphasized his commitment to patient-centered care and continuing AtlantiCare's 125-year legacy of quality care.

title: Michael Charlton Appointed President and CEO of AtlantiCare Healthcare System
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Michael J. Charlton has been appointed President and CEO of AtlantiCare Health System, following a selection process by Korn Ferry. Charlton, who has served as Interim President and CEO since June 1, 2023, will oversee AtlantiCare's operations and strategic growth, leading over 6,500 employees in southeastern New Jersey. He has a strong background in business and healthcare leadership, having been a local business owner, a member of AtlantiCare's Board of Directors for over 14 years, and a former Board Chair. Charlton holds degrees from the University of Louisville and Brown University and is recognized for his collaborative and innovative leadership style.

title: Office of the Vice President and Chief Information Officer Yeman Collier: ALERT — Direct Deposit Attacks
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: A phishing campaign at UT Health San Antonio led to the redirection of payroll deposits for 22 employees across three University of Texas campuses. The attackers exploited either active secure sessions in Peoplesoft or manipulated users into accepting fraudulent 2-factor authentication (2FA) prompts. Chief Information Officer Yeman Collier emphasized the importance of logging out of secure sessions, maintaining strong passwords, and being cautious of suspicious emails and links. Collier also urged users to avoid "2FA fatigue" by being vigilant with all online accounts. The Finance, Human Resource, and Technology divisions are working on additional controls to prevent future attacks. Employees are encouraged to contact Information Security for further guidance and to report any suspicious activities.

title: honored for digital excellence by the College of Healthcare Information Management Executives - UT Health San Antonio
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: UT Health San Antonio has been recognized as a “Digital Health Most Wired” organization by the College of Healthcare Information Management Executives (CHIME). This award acknowledges health care organizations that excel in adopting and using information technology. UT Health San Antonio outperformed over 55,000 facilities in areas such as analytics, data management, population health, infrastructure, and patient engagement, earning a “Certified Level 8” designation. Yeman Collier, vice president and chief information officer, emphasized the institution's commitment to digital health excellence, highlighting improvements in quality, safety, patient experience, and scientific discovery. The recognition underscores UT Health San Antonio's role in advancing health care through technology, despite challenges like cybersecurity threats and staffing shortages.

title: Women faculty members selected for and graduate from prestigious leadership program
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Barbara Taylor, MD, MS, has been selected for the 2023-2024 Hedwig van Ameringen Executive Leadership in Academic Medicine (ELAM) Program. ELAM is a prestigious year-long program for senior women faculty in academic health centers. Kristen Plastino, MD, recently graduated from this program, joining a community of over 1,200 alumnae in leadership roles globally. Chiquita A. Collins, PhD, MA, vice president for diversity, equity, and inclusion, served as a Learning Community Advisor for ELAM, guiding a group of six fellows. Collins, an ELUM from the class of 2020, played a pivotal role in facilitating the learning community and supporting the fellows throughout the year-long fellowship. UT Health San Antonio celebrates its faculty members' achievements in this prestigious program.

title: Collins to deliver keynote remarks for Black History Month event
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Chiquita A. Collins, PhD, MA, will deliver a virtual keynote address for Black History Month on February 9, 2023, at 6 p.m. Collins is the inaugural vice president for diversity, equity, and inclusion and the chief diversity officer at UT Health San Antonio. The event, themed “Kicking Off Black History Month – Resistance. Persistence. Excellence,” marks the beginning of UTSA’s Black History Month celebrations.

title: KSAT Q&A: BioMed SA, UT Health representatives discuss Texas' selection as ARPA-H hub
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Heather Hanson of BioMed SA and Dr. Jennifer Sharpe Potter of UT Health discussed Texas' recent selection as a hub for the Advanced Research Projects Agency for Health (ARPA-H) during a KSAT Q&A session. The conversation highlighted the significance of this designation for Texas, focusing on the potential advancements in biomedical research and healthcare it could bring to the state. Dr. Jennifer Sharpe Potter emphasized the collaborative efforts between local and statewide institutions, underscoring the importance of this selection in fostering innovation and job creation in the biomedical field.

title: TXST Health Scholar Showcase features interdisciplinary health researchers, keynote speaker Dr. Jennifer Sharpe Potter
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The seventh annual Health Scholar Showcase at Texas State University will occur on March 3 at the TXST Performing Arts Center. This event, hosted by the Translational Health Research Center, is the largest university-wide faculty research gathering, featuring interdisciplinary health research, community partnerships, and funding opportunities. Keynote speaker Dr. Jennifer Sharpe Potter, vice president for research and professor of psychiatry and behavioral sciences at UT Health San Antonio, will address the development of a multidisciplinary, collaborative research enterprise. Potter, a national expert in substance-use disorders funded by the NIH, will also discuss engaging the community in impactful research. The showcase aims to foster dialogue and new connections among attendees. Additionally, the event will identify potential new Health+Resilience Research Faculty Fellows from poster presentations. Students are encouraged to participate through the Student Health Scholar Showcase Speaker Series on March 2, featuring BioMedSA president Heather Hanson discussing health and biomedical job trends.

title: School of Nursing inspires research collaboration through retreat
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: The Office of Nursing Research and Scholarship at UT Health San Antonio held its first School of Nursing Research Retreat on March 31, bringing together investigators, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and local health system collaborators. The retreat aimed to foster community-campus research and educational partnerships. Faculty showcased their research and community-based intervention programs, focusing on social determinants of health, health disparities, and community health. Dean Sonya Hardin highlighted the school’s achievements in these areas. Keynote speaker Bei Wu from NYU discussed improving health equity among Asian Americans. Jennifer Sharpe Potter, the vice president for research, emphasized the research resources and strategic plan's research pillar, outlining the School of Nursing's role. The retreat aimed to motivate and initiate collaborative discussions for quality research benefiting community outcomes.

title: Be Well Texas celebrates grand opening of new facility providing substance use treatment services statewide
hco: THE UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT SAN ANTONIO
summary: Be Well Texas, a program of UT Health San Antonio, has opened a new 20,000-square-foot facility to provide substance use treatment services statewide. The center offers comprehensive services regardless of ability to pay, including in-person and telehealth clinical space, research laboratories, and educational training for providers. Jennifer Sharpe Potter, PhD, MPH, the executive director of Be Well Texas, emphasized the importance of equitable access to evidence-based treatment for substance use disorders. The program integrates addiction medicine specialists, behavioral health experts, and individuals with lived experience in recovery. It also coordinates a network of approximately 140 community providers across Texas. The facility aims to improve treatment outcomes through cutting-edge research, including trials for new treatments for cocaine, methamphetamine, and cannabis use disorders. The initiative is part of UT Health San Antonio's broader mission to enhance health outcomes through education, research, and community engagement.

title: NYU Langone Health Marks 10th Anniversary of Sala Institute with 'Sala-bration' Event
summary: NYU Langone Health celebrated the 10th anniversary of the Sala Institute for Child and Family Centered Care with a “Sala-bration” event on November 6. Founded in 2013, the Sala Institute, part of Hassenfeld Children’s Hospital, has been pivotal in enhancing care for children and families through support services, resilience programs, and safety initiatives. The event raised $2.1 million to further these efforts. Robert I. Grossman, MD, CEO of NYU Langone and dean of NYU Grossman School of Medicine, highlighted the institute’s critical role in ensuring high-quality, personalized care. The institute's name honors Sala Bierman Elbaum, a Holocaust survivor. Founding donors Trudy Elbaum Gottesman and Robert W. Gottesman were acknowledged for their contributions. The Sala Institute collaborates with clinical teams on various programs, including child life, creative arts therapies, and family partnership initiatives, playing an essential role in pediatric care at the hospital.

title: NYU Langone Health ranked #1 in US for quality and safety
summary: NYU Langone Health has been ranked No. 1 in the US for quality and safety. It received the Bernard A. Birnbaum, MD, Quality Leadership Award for superior patient care and the Ambulatory Quality and Accountability Award for excellence in outpatient care. This is the second consecutive year it has achieved this ranking. NYU Langone Hospital—Long Island and NYU Langone Hospital—Brooklyn also received top national rankings. Dr. Robert Grossman, CEO of NYU Langone Health and dean of NYU Grossman School of Medicine, credited the dedicated teams for their tireless work in achieving this national recognition. The rankings, developed by Vizient, are based on mortality and infection rates, patient experience scores, and other quality measures.

title: Ten lessons for data sharing with a data commons | Scientific Data
summary: A data commons is a cloud-based platform with a governance structure that enables a community to manage, analyze, and share data, thus accelerating research. Robert Grossman highlights ten lessons from a decade of developing data commons. These include the importance of targeting specific research communities, curating and harmonizing data, reducing access barriers, and supporting an ecosystem of applications. Grossman also emphasizes the significant costs associated with data curation and user interface development, the unpredictability of data utility, and the benefits of integrating data commons into larger data meshes. The NCI Genomic Data Commons is cited as a successful example, democratizing access to cancer genomics data and facilitating new research discoveries.

title: Five Things to Know About Long Island's Only Tuition-Free Medical School
summary: NYU Long Island School of Medicine has been renamed NYU Grossman Long Island School of Medicine in honor of Robert I. Grossman, MD, CEO of NYU Langone Health. This change coincides with a transformative $200 million gift from Kenneth and Elaine Langone, ensuring Full-Tuition Scholarships for all future students in perpetuity. The school stands out as the only tuition-free, three-year medical school in the U.S. focused on primary care. Its mission is to address the national shortage of primary care physicians by training doctors in internal medicine, family medicine, pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology, and general surgery. Additionally, the program allows students to graduate one year earlier than traditional four-year programs, saving them significant costs. The majority of graduates remain in New York for their residency training.

title: NYU Long Island School of Medicine Receives $200 Million Gift from Kenneth & Elaine Langone
summary: NYU Long Island School of Medicine received a transformative $200 million gift from Kenneth and Elaine Langone, ensuring full-tuition scholarships for all students in perpetuity. This landmark donation will alleviate the financial burden for future medical students and help expand access to medical care in Long Island and beyond. In recognition of this contribution, the school will be renamed NYU Grossman Long Island School of Medicine, honoring Robert I. Grossman, MD, CEO of NYU Langone Health and dean of NYU Grossman School of Medicine. Grossman's visionary leadership has been pivotal in shaping the future of medical education and ensuring the affordability of medical school.

title: Study Links Key Gene to Protection from Severe Illness & Death from COVID-19 Infections in Men Under Age 75
summary: A genetic analysis by NYU Grossman School of Medicine has identified a variant of the IL1RN gene that protects men under 75 from severe COVID-19 illness and death. The IL1RN variant, rs419598, reduces inflammation, a key factor in severe COVID-19 cases. The study, published in The Journal of Infectious Diseases, found that men with this variant were 80% less likely to die from the disease. Steven Abramson, MD, highlighted the biological link between inflammation in COVID-19 and rheumatoid arthritis, suggesting that IL1-inhibiting therapies could be effective against COVID-19. Further research is planned to explore the role of the IL-1 pathway in long COVID.

title: Gene variant provides clue for why some men were less severely ill from COVID
summary: A study led by Dr. Steven Abramson of NYU Langone Health found that men under 75 with a specific gene variant hospitalized with COVID-19 were 80% less likely to die compared to those without the variant. The gene variant, rs419598, is linked to anti-inflammatory molecules. While it reduces mortality in men, it does not offer protection for women. The research, conducted between March 2020 and March 2021, involved 2,589 COVID-19 patients and was published in the Journal of Infectious Diseases. The findings suggest that understanding this gene variant could help develop strategies to combat severe COVID-19.

title: Visionary $15 Million Gift from Wayne & Wendy Holman to NYU Langone Health Ensures Continued Excellence in ...
summary: NYU Langone Health has received a $15 million donation from Wayne and Wendy Holman, leading to the establishment of the Holman Division of Endocrinology, Diabetes, and Metabolism. This division will enhance research, education, and clinical care in endocrine disorders. Steven Abramson, MD, highlighted that the gift will drive growth through new translational research, clinical trials, and academic forums. The division, ranked No. 2 by U.S. News & World Report for 2023–24, has made significant contributions to diabetes care, thyroid disease, and other areas. Wayne Holman, a founder of Ridgeback Capital and Ridgeback Biotherapeutics, has supported drug development for various diseases.

title: Study: Men with key anti-inflammatory genetic variant almost 80% less likely to die of COVID
summary: A study by New York University researchers found that hospitalized male COVID-19 patients under 75 with the rs419598 variant of the interleukin-1 receptor antagonist (IL1RN) gene had a significantly lower risk of severe inflammation and death. The study, published in The Journal of Infectious Diseases, analyzed blood samples from 2,589 patients from March 2020 to March 2021. Results showed that men with the rs419598 variant had lower inflammatory biomarker levels and a reduced death rate (10.0% vs 17.8%), particularly pronounced in men under 75, who had a 78% lower death rate. Steven Abramson, MD, highlighted the biological link between severe inflammation in COVID-19 and rheumatoid arthritis, suggesting that IL-1 inhibiting therapies could be effective against COVID-19.

title: New Hybrid Treatment Forces Cancer Cells to Starve
summary: A new study by NYU Grossman School of Medicine and Tezcat Biosciences demonstrates a hybrid treatment that starves multiple myeloma cancer cells by combining a drug with a protein fragment. This combination targets RAS-mutant cancer cells by exploiting their overactive macropinocytosis pathway, crucial for nutrient uptake. The treatment, involving a monobody linked to MMAE, effectively blocks cell division and growth. In mouse models, it significantly reduced tumor size and improved survival rates, showing promise for clinical application. Dafna Bar-Sagi, PhD, senior vice president and chief scientific officer at NYU Langone, highlighted the potential clinical importance of this approach.

title: Bringing the Art of Hospitality to the Doctor's Office
summary: NYU Langone Health has implemented a hospitality training program, FGP C.A.R.E.S., inspired by Ritz-Carlton's customer service, to enhance patient satisfaction across its 330+ Faculty Group Practice locations. The program, developed by Andrew Rubin, focuses on building emotional connections and consistent patient experiences. Training includes modules on professional conduct, optimizing interactions, and service recovery. The initiative has led to improved patient satisfaction scores, with over 6,000 frontline workers, including Andrew W. Brotman, MD, completing the training. The program aims to maintain high standards and continue evolving to attract and retain top talent.

title: NYU Langone Officially Opens State-of-the-Art Ambulatory Care Center in Former Garden City Bloomingdale's Building ...
summary: NYU Langone Health has opened its largest ambulatory care center on Long Island, located in the former Bloomingdale's building in Garden City. The 260,000-square-foot facility houses 32 clinical specialties and expects to serve 400,000 patients annually. Andrew W. Brotman, MD, highlighted the center's commitment to providing high-standard care close to where patients live, with integrated services and a unified electronic health record system. The facility includes 260 patient exam rooms, expanded adult ophthalmology services, and a modern design focused on patient experience. The center enhances NYU Langone's extensive network, known for its excellence in various medical specialties.

title: NYU Langone Health Opens Comprehensive, Five-Story Multispecialty Care Center in Cobble Hill
summary: NYU Langone Health has opened the Joseph S. and Diane H. Steinberg Ambulatory Care Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. This five-story, 165,000-square-foot facility offers a 24-hour emergency department, cancer care, outpatient surgeries, and various medical specialties. The center includes an infusion center, radiology, and imaging services. Andrew W. Brotman, MD, emphasized that the center will significantly enhance the quality and accessibility of care for over 200,000 patients annually. The facility aims to address community healthcare needs and is conveniently located near mass transit with valet parking available. It expands NYU Langone’s presence in Brooklyn, which includes NYU Langone Hospital—Brooklyn and over 65 practices. The center is designed with patient experience in mind, featuring natural light, local artwork, and sustainable building practices aiming for LEED Gold certification. The new facility is named in recognition of Joseph S. and Diane H. Steinberg's generosity.

title: Health system opens ambulatory care center in Garden City
summary: NYU Langone Health has opened a 260,000-square-foot ambulatory care center in Garden City, located in the former Bloomingdale’s and Sears building at 1111 Franklin Avenue. The center houses 32 clinical specialties and is expected to serve 400,000 patients annually, with 35,000 patient visits each month. Dr. Andrew Brotman, executive vice president and chief clinical officer at NYU Langone Health, highlighted the center's commitment to providing high-standard care close to patients' homes and the benefits of integrated care through a unified electronic health record system. The facility includes 260 patient rooms and expanded adult ophthalmology services. The building's renovation focused on enhancing patient experience with natural light, an outdoor garden, and a holistic design approach. The center offers a range of services including cardiology, dermatology, endocrinology, and more, and is located a mile from NYU Langone Hospital—Long Island.

title: NYU Langone opens ambulatory care center, ER in Cobble Hill
summary: NYU Langone Health opened the Joseph S. & Diane H. Steinberg Ambulatory Care Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, featuring a 24-hour emergency department, outpatient surgical center, and various medical practices. The facility, located at 70 Atlantic Ave., was inaugurated with a ribbon-cutting ceremony attended by NYC Mayor Eric Adams, U.S. Rep. Dan Goldman, and NYU Langone executives. Dr. Robert Grossman, CEO of NYU Langone Health, emphasized the center's role in providing equitable, high-quality healthcare. Dr. Andrew Brotman, executive VP, vice dean for clinical affairs and strategy, and chief clinical officer, highlighted the center's transformational impact on the neighborhood. The center includes advanced medical services and is connected to other NYU Langone facilities via a unified electronic health record system. The opening marks a significant enhancement in healthcare access for Brooklyn residents.

title: NYU Langone Earns Top Hospital Award for Outstanding Quality & Safety Outcomes
summary: NYU Langone Health has received a Top Hospital award from the Leapfrog Group, recognizing its excellence in patient safety and quality care. This honor is given to only 6 percent of inpatient units surveyed. Tisch Hospital, Kimmel Pavilion, and NYU Langone Hospital—Long Island were all designated as Top Teaching Hospitals. Fritz François, MD, executive vice president and chief of hospital operations, emphasized the staff's dedication to providing the best care possible, highlighting the continuous efforts to improve quality, safety, and patient experience. NYU Langone has consistently earned high ratings, including "A" grades from Leapfrog and recognition from Vizient Inc. and U.S. News & World Report.

title: NYU Langone opens ambulatory care center, ER in Cobble Hill
summary: NYU Langone Health has opened the Joseph S. & Diane H. Steinberg Ambulatory Care Center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The new facility, featuring a 24-hour emergency department and various medical services, aims to bring high-quality healthcare to the community. Mayor Eric Adams and other officials attended the ribbon-cutting ceremony. Dr. Fritz Francois, executive vice president and chief of hospital operations, emphasized NYU Langone's commitment to providing excellent care in Brooklyn. The center is expected to serve over 200,000 patients with services ranging from emergency care to cancer treatment.

title: Joseph Lhota | NYU Langone Health
summary: Joseph Lhota has been appointed as the Chief Financial Officer of NYU Langone Health, effective February 1. Lhota, who has served as the executive vice president, vice dean, and chief of staff since 2014, has played a crucial role in integrating NYU Langone's clinical, academic, and research missions. His previous roles include serving as the city's finance commissioner, director of the Mayor’s Office of Management and Budget, and CEO of the MTA. Lhota will be replacing Daniel Widawsky, who is returning to the finance sector.

title: Vicki Match Suna On the Expanding Footprints of Health Care Systems
summary: Vicki Match Suna, NYU Langone Health’s executive vice president and vice dean for real estate development and facilities, discusses the expansion of healthcare systems, particularly NYU Langone, which has grown to include around 600 locations in the tri-state area. She explains that consolidation into larger systems has been driven by economic efficiency, enabling better resource allocation and advanced care. Suna highlights the importance of NYU Langone’s integrated approach combining research, education, and clinical care. She also notes that the disruption in the office market presents opportunities for healthcare systems to repurpose spaces. During the COVID-19 pandemic, NYU Langone swiftly adapted facilities to accommodate patients, demonstrating resilience and flexibility. Suna emphasizes NYU Langone’s commitment to sustainability, despite the challenges posed by regulations like Local Law 97, and outlines ongoing and future growth plans, including acquiring new sites and converting buildings for medical use.

title: NYU Langone Health to adopt new Philips health technology solutions in multi-year partnership directed at patient ...
summary: NYU Langone Health and Royal Philips announced an 8-year, USD 115 million partnership to enhance patient care through innovative health technology solutions. This collaboration includes digital pathology, clinical informatics, AI-enabled diagnostics, and an enterprise monitoring as a service model. The goal is to improve patient safety, quality, and outcomes by enabling real-time clinician collaboration and personalized care plans. Nader Mherabi, Chief Digital and Information Officer at NYU Langone, emphasized the importance of transforming data into insights to maintain their leadership in precision medicine. The partnership will also focus on unifying patient monitoring systems and simplifying workflows. NYU Langone will adopt Philips' IntelliSite Pathology solution, AI-enabled diagnostic imaging technologies, and the Philips Capsule Medical Device Information Platform to enhance data integration and patient care.

title: Philips and NYU Langone Health Forge 8-Year, $115 Million Partnership to Elevate Patient Care through Innovation
summary: Philips and NYU Langone Health have entered into an 8-year strategic partnership worth up to $115 million to enhance patient care through innovation. The collaboration aims to develop new technologies enabling real-time clinician collaboration, data sharing, and personalized care plans, ultimately reducing costs and improving outcomes. NYU Langone will implement Philips’ IntelliSite Pathology solution, enterprise informatics, and AI-enabled diagnostic imaging technologies like the Lumify Handheld Ultrasound. Additional solutions include the Philips Patient Information Center iX and the Capsule Medical Device Information Platform (MDIP) to streamline workflows and leverage data. The partnership will deploy Philips Capsule MDIP in a predictable EMaaS subscription model for seamless integration across the network. This integrated approach aims to improve patient experiences through faster diagnosis and treatment. Nader Mherabi, Chief Digital and Information Officer at NYU Langone, plays a key role in this partnership, aligning NYU Langone’s innovation efforts with Philips’ technological leadership.

title: NYU Langone Health to Hold AI “Prompt-a-Thon” Event
summary: NYU Langone Health is hosting its first Generative AI Prompt-A-Thon on August 18, where teams of clinicians, educators, and researchers will explore AI-powered healthcare solutions using de-identified patient data. The event will focus on large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4, which can summarize texts, extract key information, and generate human-like conversations. Nader Mherabi, executive vice president, vice dean, and chief digital and information officer at NYU Langone, highlighted that they have established one of the nation's first HIPAA-compliant GPT-4 ecosystems in healthcare. This secure setup allows NYU Langone's staff to test AI applications responsibly, aiming to improve patient care and safety.

title: NYU Langone Match Day 2024: The Results Are In
summary: On March 15, 2024, 107 students from NYU Grossman School of Medicine and 24 from NYU Grossman Long Island School of Medicine participated in Match Day, learning where they will complete their residencies. Victoria C. Dinsell, MD, associate dean of student affairs, praised the students for their courage and dedication. The event marks a critical transition as students embark on residencies in various specialties, with internal medicine being the most popular. The Long Island school's graduating class, benefiting from a donation that ensures full-tuition scholarships, saw 42% of its students matching with NYU Langone locations and a significant focus on primary care. The Match Day process is overseen by the National Resident Matching Program, using an algorithm that earned a Nobel Prize for its creators.

title: Artificial Intelligence Supercharges Learning for Students at NYU Grossman School of Medicine
summary: NYU Grossman School of Medicine has implemented AI-driven tools to personalize medical education, a program called Precision Education. This initiative tailors the curriculum to individual students' learning styles and goals using machine learning and predictive analytics. First-year student Lily Ge benefits from these tools, such as a virtual microscope and 3D body models, to enhance her anatomical studies. The program, led by Marc M. Triola, MD, aims to improve learner outcomes and clinical decision-making by utilizing de-identified patient data. Verity E. Schaye, MD, MHPE, contributed by developing NoteSense, an app using natural language processing to aid residents in refining their clinical skills. The success of this program is drawing interest from other medical schools.

title: 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations & Scholarship Conference Highlights
summary: The 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations & Scholarship Conference, held by NYU Grossman School of Medicine on October 23, showcased over 55 presentations and workshops. Keynote speaker Dr. Adam Rodman discussed leveraging AI in medical education. The conference also featured a Generative AI Prompt-a-Thon and workshops on various topics including narrative medicine and educational research. Verity Schaye, MD, MHPE, presented "NoteSense 2.0," focusing on advanced AI for automated feedback on resident clinical reasoning documentation. Additionally, Schaye co-authored a poster on student perceptions of the clinical learning environment. Awards were given to faculty for their contributions, and five posters were recognized for innovation and impact. The event highlighted the school’s advancements and ongoing initiatives in medical education.

title: ChatGPT in medical education: Generative AI and the future of artificial intelligence in health care
summary: The AMA Update video discusses the transformative impact of AI, specifically ChatGPT, on medical education. Dr. Marc Triola, associate dean of education informatics and director of the Institute for Innovations in Medical Education at NYU Grossman School of Medicine, highlights how AI is integrated into their curriculum to enhance learning and research. AI tools like DX Mentor provide personalized educational resources for students based on their patient interactions. Additionally, AI aids students in studying by generating USMLE-type questions and virtual patients for practice. AI also supports career planning by offering goal-oriented advice. Dr. Triola emphasizes AI's role in augmenting education and preparing students for future clinical applications, envisioning a future where AI enables precision medical education.

title: 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations & Scholarship Conference Highlights
summary: The 2023 Annual Medical Education Innovations & Scholarship Conference at NYU Grossman School of Medicine highlighted significant advancements and contributions in medical education. The event featured over 55 presentations and workshops, with keynote speaker Adam Rodman, MD, MPH, discussing "Leveraging AI for Medical Education." Awards were given to faculty for their outstanding contributions, and various sessions showcased innovative work in the field. Marc M. Triola, MD, played a crucial role by moderating the Lightning Talks and facilitating the Generative AI Prompt-A-Thon, which focused on utilizing AI in medical education. Workshops covered topics like workplace-based assessments, program development, and narrative medicine. The conference also included poster presentations, with five posters recognized for their innovation and impact. Participants engaged in discussions to enhance their understanding of medical education scholarship and explored the integration of narrative medicine into healthcare practices.

title: Artificial Intelligence Supercharges Learning for Students at NYU Grossman School of Medicine
summary: NYU Grossman School of Medicine has introduced an AI-driven approach called Precision Education to tailor medical education to individual students' learning styles and goals. This initiative, partly funded by the American Medical Association, uses machine learning to customize curriculum and study aids based on students' academic records, practical experiences, and preferences. Marc M. Triola, MD, associate dean for educational informatics and founding director of the Institute for Innovations in Medical Education, explains that this personalized approach can improve both learner and patient outcomes. The system also helps students with clinical decision-making by utilizing de-identified patient data and predictive analytics for early career exploration. As the first year of Precision Education concludes, Dr. Triola and his team are refining the tools based on feedback, with plans to extend the AI model to residents, enhancing their focus on clinical specialties.

title: How ChatGPT could help medical students learn on the fast track
summary: The future of ChatGPT and other AI applications in clinical environments is uncertain due to liability and privacy concerns, but they are already valuable in medical education. At the AMA ChangeMedEd 2023 conference, Marc M. Triola, MD, from NYU Grossman School of Medicine, highlighted the use of ChatGPT to enhance precision education. Tools like DX Mentor provide real-time data on medical students' diagnoses, mapped to educational resources, and personalized AI-generated practice questions. ChatGPT also offers summaries of relevant articles and advice on achieving educational goals. NYU's StudyBuddy maps clinical texts to educational resources, aiding self-study. Triola emphasized that these tools make learning seamless and personalized, improving medical education efficiency.

title: AACN Webinar: Using Technology and Data to Support the Move to Competency-Based Education - The Elm
summary: The American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) announced a new vision for sharing data and information across nursing education, practice, and regulation. This vision involves developing an integrated information system supported by technology, people, and processes to facilitate data sharing among nursing schools, healthcare settings, and regulatory bodies. A webinar on January 24 will outline this vision, focusing on using technology and data to support the transition to Competency-Based Education (CBE). Marc Triola, MD, associate dean for educational informatics and associate professor of medicine at New York University, alongside Janelle Sokolowich, PhD, MS, will present an overview of AACN’s vision for technology, including criteria for identifying or developing technology to support the 2021 Essentials. The webinar is free for faculty, staff, and students from AACN member schools.

title: Good Choices | Harvard Medicine Magazine
summary: Judith Hochman, MD ’77, is the Harold Snyder Family Professor of Cardiology and Senior Associate Dean for Clinical Sciences at New York University Grossman School of Medicine. Initially inspired by a high school biology teacher, Hochman pursued a master’s degree in cellular and developmental biology at Harvard University. However, she shifted to a medical degree at HMS, leading to her current prestigious roles. Mentored by notable figures like Lewis Dexter and Eugene Braunwald, and influenced by Bernadine Healy, Hochman now enjoys mentoring others, emphasizing its exponential impact. Balancing a high-powered career and family, she made strategic choices, focusing on clinical research and leadership, resulting in significant discoveries and publications. Hochman values collaboration in research and attributes her success to her supportive husband.

title: Global Longitudinal Strain as Predictor of Inducible Ischemia in No Obstructive Coronary Artery Disease in the CIAO ...
summary: The study investigated the relationship between resting Global Longitudinal Strain (GLS) and ischemia in patients with myocardial ischemia but no obstructive coronary artery disease (INOCA). The research, part of the CIAO-ISCHEMIA study, involved analyzing left ventricular GLS from stress echocardiography (SE) images at enrollment and one-year follow-up. Results showed that GLS values were largely normal and did not correlate with the presence, severity, or location of stress-induced ischemia. These findings suggest that resting GLS does not provide additional diagnostic utility for detecting subclinical myocardial dysfunction in INOCA patients. Judith Hochman contributed to this research as one of the authors.

title: Perlmutter Cancer Center Researchers Receive National Cancer Institute Grant to Study Early Steps of Melanoma ...
summary: Researchers at NYU Langone Health’s Perlmutter Cancer Center have received a U54 grant from the National Cancer Institute to study the early steps of melanoma metastasis. Led by Eva M. Hernando-Monge, PhD, and Iman Osman, MD, the team aims to create a detailed map of tumor microenvironment interactions that regulate early dissemination of metastatic cells in melanoma. This research will leverage single-cell genomics and mouse models to identify critical "switches" driving tumor progression and potential therapeutic targets. The team includes notable contributors such as Mayumi Ito, PhD, Markus Schober, PhD, Amanda W. Lund, PhD, Itai Yanai, PhD, and Kelly V. Ruggles, PhD. The initiative is part of the NCI’s Metastasis Research Network (MetNet) and involves analyzing tissue samples from nearly 5,000 patients. Dr. Osman emphasizes the potential of this research to uncover processes driving metastatic dissemination in other cancers as well.

title: Mountainside Medical Center Strengthens Leadership with Additions to Board of Trustees
summary: Mountainside Medical Center has strengthened its leadership by appointing three new members to its Board of Trustees, effective January 1. Dr. Sung T. Kim, Chief James Mazza, and Dr. Joseph Ravenell have joined the board, each bringing valuable expertise and commitment. Dr. Joseph Ravenell, an associate professor at NYU Grossman School of Medicine and Associate Dean for Diversity and Inclusion, is recognized for his leadership in health equity research. His dedication to advancing diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging will contribute significantly to the hospital's mission. Tim O’Brien, CEO of Mountainside Medical Center, expressed gratitude for the new additions, highlighting their diverse backgrounds and commitment to community service as assets to the hospital's ongoing success in providing exceptional healthcare services. Each appointee will serve a minimum term of two years, furthering the hospital's dedication to excellence in healthcare.

title: Mountainside Medical Center strengthens leadership with accomplished additions to board
summary: Mountainside Medical Center has appointed Dr. Sung Kim, James Mazza, and Dr. Joseph Ravenell to its board of trustees for a minimum two-year term starting January 1. CEO Tim O’Brien highlighted their diverse expertise and commitment to community service as valuable assets to the hospital’s mission. Dr. Sung Kim, with extensive experience in family medicine, serves as the medical director at Vanguard Medical Group’s Glen Ridge location. James Mazza, with 17 years in emergency medical services, brings a unique perspective to the board. Dr. Joseph Ravenell, an associate professor at NYU Grossman School of Medicine, is renowned for his work in health equity research, focusing on improving health outcomes for minoritized communities.

title: Diversity Plays a Key Role in Black Americans' Trust of Videos About Prostate Cancer
summary: A study led by NYU Grossman School of Medicine highlights the importance of racial diversity among healthcare providers to improve trust in medical information among Black Americans. The research, involving over 2,900 participants, found that Black Americans are 1.6 times more likely to trust medical information presented by a Black physician or patient compared to a White speaker. Joseph E. Ravenell, MD, an associate professor in the Departments of Population Health and Medicine at NYU Langone, emphasized the responsibility of healthcare providers in public communication. He noted the need to increase diversity in the healthcare workforce to enhance trust and reduce misinformation. The study also revealed a general preference for physician-presented information over patient-presented information and highlighted the importance of including diverse representation in medical content. The findings were published in JAMA Network Open on July 19, 2023.

title: Diversity Plays Key Role in Blacks' Trust of Prostate Cancer Videos
summary: New research highlights the importance of increasing racial diversity among U.S. healthcare providers, showing that Black patients are more likely to trust medical information presented by Black doctors or patients compared to white ones. The study, led by Dr. Stacy Loeb, involved 2,900 participants who watched videos about prostate cancer. Findings revealed that Black Americans were 1.6 times more likely to trust information from Black presenters. Regardless of race, participants found physicians more trustworthy than other patients. Dr. Joseph Ravenell, a co-author and associate professor at NYU Langone Health, emphasized the responsibility of healthcare providers in public communication, especially amidst widespread misinformation. The study underscores the need for diversified representation in medical content to improve trust and health outcomes among Black patients.

title: NYU Grossman School of Medicine Celebrates Graduating Class of 2023
summary: NYU Grossman School of Medicine celebrated the graduation of 111 new doctors on May 17, 2023, at Lincoln Center’s Alice Tully Hall. The graduates, who will join top residency programs, received their Doctor of Medicine degrees and recited the Hippocratic Oath. Dean Robert I. Grossman emphasized the importance of their contributions to global health. Keynote speaker Linda G. Mills, president-designate of NYU, shared lessons from her late father, a cardiologist, highlighting the importance of precision, dedication, and action in medicine. Anthony J. Grieco, MD, associate dean for alumni relations and academic events, also made remarks during the ceremony. The class benefited from NYU Grossman’s full-tuition scholarships and need-based debt-free scholarships. Twenty students completed the accelerated three-year MD pathway, and 24 students earned dual MD/master’s degrees in various fields.

title: KUMC leader Dr. Robert Simari to retire in June, immediately step down as executive vice chancellor
summary: Dr. Robert Simari, the executive vice chancellor at the University of Kansas Medical Center (KUMC), will retire on June 30, 2024. He will immediately step down from his executive vice chancellor role but will continue as the Franklin E. Murphy Professor of Cardiology until his retirement. Dr. Matthias Salathe, vice chancellor for research at KUMC, will serve as interim executive vice chancellor. Simari, an alumnus of the KU School of Medicine, served as executive dean from 2014 to 2019 and as executive vice chancellor since 2018, including a six-month interim period. Chancellor Douglas Girod praised Simari's leadership, noting his contributions during a transformational period, such as hiring deans for the schools of Medicine and Nursing, helping the KU Cancer Center earn comprehensive designation from the National Cancer Institute, and fostering a valued workforce. Girod acknowledged that Simari's retirement is a significant loss for the university.

title: 10 Questions with Robert Simari
summary: Robert Simari, Executive Vice Chancellor of KU Medical Center, published his first book, "A Prescription to Lead: How Medical Training Prepares America’s Physician Leaders." Inspired by his collaboration with physician leaders, Simari utilized the pandemic period to interview top medical professionals about leadership. His key findings include the absence of a set leadership pathway and the importance of following one's unique path and maintaining outside interests. A standout interview was with Dr. LouAnn Woodward, who highlighted the impact of a single doctor's presence in the ER. Simari emphasized that medical training fosters work ethic, collaboration, and communication skills essential for leadership. His own curiosity and background in interventional cardiology at the Mayo Clinic shaped his leadership skills. The book aims to guide aspiring physician leaders, medical school affiliates, and those interested in leadership training outside medicine. Simari plans to focus on promoting this book before considering another.

title: Medical Leadership and 2024 Predictions With Author Dr. Robert Simari
summary: Dr. Robert Simari, executive vice chancellor at the University of Kansas Medical Center and author of "A Prescription to Lead," discusses medical leadership and provides healthcare predictions for 2024 in a HealthLeaders Podcast episode.

title: Message from the Dean
summary: This summer has been exhilarating for the University of Kansas School of Medicine. Key events include the graduation of 201 students, Dr. Doug Girod becoming the 18th chancellor, and the opening of the new Health Education Building. Robert Simari, interim executive vice chancellor, highlighted the building's state-of-the-art design and its role in interprofessional education. The Salina campus will complete its new health education building by July 2018, and the ACE curriculum was implemented to transform medical teaching. The School of Medicine is also focusing on faculty and student wellness and celebrated the renewal of the KU Cancer Center grant. Simari invites everyone to visit the campuses to experience the excitement firsthand.

title: Match Day 2024: Ceremonies and celebrations mark the next big step in the lives of KU medical students
summary: Match Day 2024 at the University of Kansas School of Medicine celebrated 192 students matching into 22 specialties, with 56 staying in Kansas and 136 training in 37 other states. At the Wichita campus, all 71 graduating students matched, including Joshua Ng and Tyler Martin who will serve in military medical roles, and Thanh Nguyen pursuing internal medicine in California. In Kansas City, Mary Mitchell and Nicholas Choi matched in ophthalmology and urology, respectively. Robert D. Simari, M.D., executive vice chancellor, highlighted the significance of Match Day, sharing his personal experience from 1986 and expressing best wishes to the students.

title: New dean of the University of Kansas School of Medicine-Salina takes the helm
summary: Tyler Hughes, M.D., has been appointed as the new dean of the University of Kansas School of Medicine-Salina, succeeding Robert Moser, M.D. Hughes has served as the director of medical education at the Salina campus since 2016 and has a strong background as a rural surgeon in McPherson, Kansas. His passion for rural health care and education aligns with his new role. Robert D. Simari, M.D., executive vice chancellor of the University of Kansas Medical Center, expressed confidence in Hughes' ability to serve the Salina community and advance the success of the medical school. Hughes aims to inspire students to pursue rural medicine, highlighting the unique challenges and rewards of practicing in rural areas. He emphasizes leadership through coordination and mentorship, drawing on his extensive experience in surgery and education. Hughes is excited about the potential to impact the Salina community and beyond.

title: KU Medical Center program works to reduce drowning and bring the joy of swimming to those on the autism spectrum
summary: KU Medical Center's Sensory Enhanced Aquatics program aims to reduce drowning risks and bring the joy of swimming to children and adults on the autism spectrum. Supported by a grant from the USA Swimming Foundation, the program uses evidence-based teaching methods and sensory strategies tailored to individual needs. Over the past decade, it has taught over 300 children with autism to swim, recently expanding to include adults. Research indicates that 100% of parents felt their children were safer around water after participating in the program. Abiodun Akinwuntan, Ph.D., MPH, MBA, dean of KU School of Health Professions, participated in a swim relay to support the program, emphasizing the school's commitment to community service and the importance of teaching water safety to children with autism.

title: Dean Sally Maliski announces retirement from KU School of Nursing
summary: Dean Sally Maliski, Ph.D., FAAN, will retire from the University of Kansas School of Nursing after seven years of service. Appointed as dean in January 2016, Maliski has led significant initiatives, including the expansion to the Salina campus and the Community College Nursing Partnership program. She has also spearheaded efforts to address the national nursing shortage by engaging stakeholders across Kansas. A researcher focused on cancer treatment-related symptoms among underserved populations, Maliski has been the principal investigator for multiple studies funded by the Department of Defense and the National Institutes of Health. Her career spans 45 years, including roles in the Army Reserve Nurse Corps and various educational positions. Maliski will serve as interim dean until December while a national search for her successor is conducted.

title: Solving the Nursing Shortage Crisis
summary: The Kansas Nursing Workforce Center was launched on August 3, 2023, to address the severe nursing shortage in Kansas. Spearheaded by Sally L. Maliski, Ph.D., FAAN, dean of the University of Kansas School of Nursing, the center aims to combat shortages in nurses and nursing faculty statewide. Maliski highlighted the crisis, exacerbated by the pandemic and retiring nurses, emphasizing the need for systemic solutions involving education, retention, and a broad stakeholder coalition. Before her retirement, Maliski provided the startup funding for the center, marking a significant part of her legacy. The center will focus on data collection to inform strategies and partnerships to strengthen the nursing workforce in Kansas.

title: KU Medical Center working to improve equity in health care through new Center for African American Health
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center has launched the Center for African American Health to enhance health outcomes for Black, African, and other marginalized communities. This initiative emerged from discussions among community partners, health leaders, and advocates during the COVID-19 pandemic. Jerrihlyn McGee, vice chancellor for diversity, equity, and inclusion at KU Medical Center, highlighted the collaborative effort behind the center's creation. The center aims to provide a comprehensive approach to health equity through community engagement, advocacy, education, and research. Dr. Jason Glenn is leading "The Repair Project," which aims to update medical curricula. The center's launch involves recruiting leadership, marketing, and building community coalitions. It will be guided by four pillars: service, education, research, and policy. More details will be shared at the Juneteenth Jazz Festival and Celebration on June 16.

title: University of Kansas Establishes Center for African American Health
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center (KUMC) has established the Center for African American Health to enhance health outcomes for Black, African American, and marginalized communities. The center, led by the KUMC Office for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion, aims to build community coalitions, foster trust, and dismantle structural healthcare barriers. It will provide services such as primary care, referrals, and clinical care management, as well as mentorship, workforce development, and support for curricular changes. The center also plans to conduct research and advocate for policies that improve health outcomes. This initiative emerged from discussions during the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on racism as a public health issue. Jerrihlyn McGee, KUMC's vice chancellor for diversity, equity, and inclusion, highlighted the importance of leveraging resources and relationships to support the creation of the center, emphasizing collaboration with community partners.

title: Kansas Citians talk first-hand knowledge of medical bias in health care
summary: Kansas Citians discuss firsthand experiences of medical bias and efforts to improve healthcare equity. Kevin Holmes of KSHB 41 interviewed doctors, professors, and patients about the impact of explicit and implicit biases in medical settings. This led to the creation of "The Repair Project," aimed at revising medical school curricula to address these disparities. Dr. Jerrihlyn McGee, from the University of Kansas Medical Center's office of diversity, equity, and inclusion, emphasized the importance of recognizing and addressing biases in medical education. She advocates for faculty accountability and curriculum changes to foster medical equity. The project also involves collecting stories of medical bias, which are stored at the Black Archives of Mid-America to educate and promote change. The initiative highlights the need for equitable healthcare and aims to eliminate race-based medicine practices.

title: KU Medical Center launches the Center for African American Health to focus on improving health outcomes of ...
summary: The University of Kansas Medical Center has launched the Center for African American Health to improve health outcomes for Black, African American, and other marginalized populations.
