Spearheaded by the Office for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI), the center will focus on service, education, research, and policy to address and eliminate structural barriers. Jerrihlyn McGee, DNP, vice chancellor for diversity, equity, and inclusion, highlighted that the initiative stemmed from discussions during the COVID-19 pandemic about leveraging resources to improve lives. McGee emphasized the center's community-led approach and its work in Wyandotte and Sedgwick counties. The center's efforts will include community engagement, mentorship, innovative research, and policy advocacy. The launch's first phase involves recruiting leadership and building community coalitions, with further details to be shared at the Juneteenth Jazz Festival on June 16.

title: Joint WSU-KU biomedical campus could receive nearly $150 million in funding
summary: A proposed joint biomedical campus by Wichita State University (WSU) and the University of Kansas (KU) in downtown Wichita could receive nearly $150 million in funding. This project aims to house KU’s School of Medicine and School of Pharmacy along with all of WSU and WSU Tech's health programs at a single site. Dr. Garold Minns, dean of the Wichita campus for the KU School of Medicine, highlighted the benefit of having diverse healthcare workers in one building. The Kansas state legislature has allocated $142 million from federal COVID funds and $35 million for design and architecture, with the total project cost estimated at $300 million. Pending Governor approval, the project aims to start construction in early 2024 and complete by 2026.

title: McPherson College Honors Alumni
summary: McPherson College honored distinguished alumni with the Citation of Merit award for 2023: Dwight Oltman, Zane Smith, and Garold Minns. These awards recognize their lifelong commitment to the college's values of Service, Scholarship, and Participation. Garold Minns, a 1973 graduate with a degree in biology, continued his education at the University of Kansas School of Medicine-Wichita, where he completed a residency in internal medicine and an infectious disease fellowship. He joined the faculty in 1980 and now serves as dean and associate dean for Academic and Student Affairs, professor, and former chair of the Department of Internal Medicine. As Sedgwick County health officer, Minns played a crucial role in leading health policy during the pandemic. He also works part-time at the Wichita Veterans Hospital and is actively involved in community service, including youth sports physical exams and as a camp physician for the Boy Scouts of America.

title: ACS Vice President-Elect Dr. Tyler Hughes Named Dean of KU School of Medicine-Salina | ACS
summary: Dr. Tyler G. Hughes, ACS First Vice President-Elect, has been appointed as the dean of the University of Kansas (KU) School of Medicine-Salina. A clinical professor of surgery and former director of medical education at KU School of Medicine-Salina since 2016, Dr. Hughes is dedicated to advancing surgical education, especially in rural areas. He has practiced in McPherson, KS, and is now focused on educating future surgeons. Dr. Hughes emphasizes the critical need for rural physicians and medical programs to ensure care for remote communities. He has been a significant figure in the American College of Surgeons (ACS), advocating for rural surgeons and holding various leadership roles, including Editor of the ACS Communities and Immediate-Past ACS Secretary. He established and chaired the Advisory Council for Rural Surgery and has been involved in numerous ACS committees and workgroups.

title: New dean of the University of Kansas School of Medicine-Salina takes the helm
summary: Tyler Hughes, M.D., has been appointed as the new dean of the University of Kansas School of Medicine-Salina, succeeding Robert Moser, M.D. Hughes, who has served as the director of medical education at the Salina campus since 2016, brings a wealth of experience as a former rural surgeon and educator. He aims to share his passion for rural health care and surgery with students, emphasizing the unique challenges and rewards of practicing in rural areas. Hughes envisions his role as a conductor of a symphony, coordinating and listening to his team rather than dictating. His commitment to rural medicine and education has been recognized nationally, and he looks forward to advancing the Salina campus's mission to produce excellent doctors and serve the community.

title: Patient-Centered Outcomes With a Multidisciplinary CKD Care Team Approach: An Observational Study
summary: The study "Patient-Centered Outcomes With a Multidisciplinary CKD Care Team Approach" explored the impact of multidisciplinary care on patient-centered outcomes in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients. Conducted as a cross-sectional study, it compared patients receiving general nephrology care to those receiving multidisciplinary care involving a pharmacist, social worker, dietitian, and nephrologist. The outcomes assessed included CKD-specific knowledge, disease-related stress, and perceptions of overall health. The study found no significant differences in these outcomes between the two groups. However, patients in multidisciplinary care were generally older and had more advanced CKD. The study suggests that a team-based approach may better support sicker, more vulnerable patients to achieve similar outcomes to younger patients with less advanced CKD. Akinlolu Ojo contributed to this research, highlighting the importance of multidisciplinary care in managing CKD. Limitations include the study's cross-sectional design and limited generalizability due to the proximity of the clinics involved.

title: Report from a Multidisciplinary Symposium on the Future of Living Kidney Donor Transplantation
summary: A multidisciplinary symposium addressed the stagnation of living donor kidney transplantation in the U.S. over the past two decades. Experts discussed ethical principles, donor incentives, and the limits of altruism in donation. They suggested that compensating donors could save up to 40,000 lives annually and reduce taxpayer costs, with survey data indicating voter support for such compensation. The symposium reviewed living donor kidney exchanges and the limited availability of deceased donor kidneys. Consensus was reached on removing barriers in donor evaluation, expanding living donor chains, ensuring the safety of live kidney donation, and preventing donors from incurring expenses. Akinlolu Ojo contributed to these discussions, emphasizing the need for changes in legal and practice standards to realize the full potential of living kidney donation.

title: KUMC leader Dr. Robert Simari to retire in June, immediately step down as executive vice chancellor
summary: Dr. Robert Simari, the executive vice chancellor at the University of Kansas Medical Center, will retire on June 30, 2024. He will step down from his current role immediately but will continue as the Franklin E. Murphy Professor of Cardiology until his retirement. Dr. Matthias Salathe, the vice chancellor for research at KU Medical Center, will serve as interim executive vice chancellor. Simari, an alumnus of the KU School of Medicine, has held various leadership positions, including executive dean of the School of Medicine from 2014 to 2019 and executive vice chancellor since 2018. Chancellor Douglas Girod praised Simari for his leadership during a transformational period, which included significant achievements like hiring deans for the schools of Medicine and Nursing and helping the KU Cancer Center earn comprehensive designation from the National Cancer Institute. Simari’s retirement is seen as a significant loss for the university.

title: KU Health System doctors express praise for Fauci's leadership from HIV to COVID-19 • Kansas Reflector
summary: Two University of Kansas Health System physicians, Steven Stites and Dana Hawkinson, praised Anthony Fauci's leadership at the National Institutes of Health, highlighting his work during the HIV-AIDS epidemic and the COVID-19 pandemic. Fauci, who served as director of the NIH’s allergy and infectious diseases institute for 38 years, retired recently. Stites, the chief medical officer, commended Fauci for his transparency and resilience despite political attacks, stating that Fauci provided truthful information during the pandemic. Hawkinson, the director of infection prevention and control, described Fauci as a voice of reason amidst the politicization of the pandemic. In contrast, U.S. Sen. Roger Marshall criticized Fauci, alleging conspiracy and financial misconduct related to the pandemic.

title: January ushers in COVID-19 turning points year after year in Kansas • Kansas Reflector
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic marked significant events in Kansas each January. January 2020 saw the first COVID-19 death in Kansas, revealing the virus's early presence. January 2021 experienced the deadliest surge, with 949 deaths and a major push for vaccinations, marking a turning point in the battle against the virus. Steven Stites, chief medical officer of the University of Kansas Health System, highlighted these critical moments through his updates. January 2022 faced the peak of infections with the Omicron variant, overwhelming healthcare systems. By January 2023, the situation appeared more stable, though risks remained. Stites and other medical experts noted the chronic nature of COVID-19, reflecting on the pandemic's ongoing challenges.

title: KU Cancer Center receives $2.4 million training grant to support future cancer researchers
summary: The University of Kansas Cancer Center has received a $2.4 million grant from the National Cancer Institute to train future clinical and translational cancer researchers. The program, led by Ronald Chen, M.D., MPH, will focus on training cancer clinicians to conduct research. Scott Weir, Pharm.D., Ph.D., associate director for translational research, and Lisa Harlan-Williams, Ph.D., assistant director for administration and education, will support Chen. This grant, the first K12 award for the center, aims to empower trainees to develop and conduct their own clinical trials, enhancing their careers and advancing cancer treatment. Participants will benefit from the expertise of nearly 50 experts and access to the Institute for Advancing Medical Innovation, led by Weir.

title: Mount Sinai Health System Names Brendan Carr, MD, MA, MS, as Next Chief Executive Officer
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System has appointed Brendan Carr, MD, MA, MS, as its new Chief Executive Officer, effective early next year. Dr. Carr, who joined Mount Sinai as head of emergency medicine in February 2020, played a crucial role during the COVID-19 pandemic. He led initiatives to enhance emergency and critical care capacity. Dr. Carr is recognized for his work in academic medicine and health policy, focusing on emergency care systems. He will succeed Kenneth L. Davis, MD, who will become Executive Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees. Dr. Carr will oversee Mount Sinai's strategic and operational functions, including its hospitals and ambulatory locations.

title: Chutes & Ladders—New CEO atop Mount Sinai Health System summit
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System has appointed Brendan Carr, M.D., as its new CEO, with Kenneth Davis, M.D., elected as executive vice chairman of the boards of trustees. Carr, who joined Mount Sinai in February 2020 as head of emergency medicine, significantly improved the system’s emergency and critical care capacity. He will now lead the strategy for the health system, which includes eight hospitals, the Icahn School of Medicine, and over 400 ambulatory locations and physician practices. Davis, who served as CEO for over 20 years, is credited with forming the health system in 2013 and driving its academic and research growth.

title: Mount Sinai Health System names Brendan Carr as next CEO
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System has appointed Dr. Brendan Carr as its new Chief Executive Officer, effective early next year. Dr. Carr, an executive in emergency medicine, will be taking over the leadership role at the prominent healthcare organization. This announcement highlights a significant leadership change within the Mount Sinai Health System.

title: Dennis S. Charney
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Dennis S. Charney is the Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs for the Mount Sinai Health System. He is a leading expert in mood and anxiety disorders, contributing significantly to understanding and treating these conditions. Recruited in 2004, Charney has advanced the institution’s research capabilities, establishing numerous research institutes and fostering a collaborative, innovative environment. His work on ketamine as a treatment for depression is particularly notable. Charney has also prioritized diversity, equity, and anti-racism initiatives, founding the Mount Sinai Institute for Health Equity Research. His leadership has positioned Icahn Mount Sinai among the top recipients of NIH funding and has led to significant partnerships and advancements in biomedical research and education.

title: The Prescription to My Recovery
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Dr. Dennis S. Charney, the dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, faced a life-threatening situation when he was shot by a former employee, Hengjun Chao, in 2016. Charney's recovery was both physical and emotional, involving five days in intensive care and coping with PTSD. His resilience was bolstered by his support system and his own research on resilience, which he applied to his recovery process. Charney emphasized reframing stressful thoughts and not wasting energy on anger. He used his experience to help others, including a young doctor affected by a similar trauma, and continues to advocate for resilience through his work and personal example.

title: Building a Resilient Family
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Research indicates that exposing children to manageable stress can build resilience. Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, and his son, Alex Charney, MD, discuss this in the "Road to Resilience" podcast. Dennis Charney shares his personal experiences, emphasizing the importance of role models in building resilience. He applied these principles by challenging his children with outdoor activities and stressful situations, helping them develop a "psychological toolbox" for handling adversity. This resilience training proved crucial when Dennis Charney survived a life-threatening shooting, demonstrating the effectiveness of his methods.

title: Mount Sinai Launches Institute for Regenerative Medicine
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: The Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai in New York has launched the Institute for Regenerative Medicine to advance research and training in regenerative biology and medicine across various departments. The Institute, announced by Dennis S. Charney, MD, will include three centers: the Alper Center for Neural Development and Regeneration, the Center for Epithelial and Airway Biology and Regeneration, and the Center for Advancement of Blood Cancer Therapies. These centers will focus on diseases such as leukemia, Alzheimer’s, breast cancer, and airway diseases, aiming to translate research findings into improved treatments.

title: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai Dean and Researcher Receives Prestigious Award in Psychopharmacology
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, received the prestigious Donald Klein Lifetime Achievement Award from the American Society for Clinical Psychopharmacology (ASCP). This award acknowledges Charney's significant contributions to the understanding and treatment of mood and anxiety disorders. He is renowned for his work on the neurobiology and treatment of these conditions, particularly his research demonstrating ketamine as a rapidly acting antidepressant. Charney's contributions include being a co-inventor on a patent for using ketamine to treat treatment-resistant depression, a therapy that has received strong support from the FDA. His extensive research and publications have earned him numerous awards and election to the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai Researchers Awarded $15.1 Million Grant to Explore Immune Rejection of ...
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Researchers at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai have received a $15.1 million grant from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) to explore immune rejection in organ transplants. The study will focus on "trained immunity," the innate immune system's memory-like response, as a potential target to prevent transplant rejection. The multi-center research program involves institutions including Massachusetts General Hospital and Radboud University Medical Center. Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of Icahn Mount Sinai, emphasized the potential of this research to develop new therapeutic strategies that could improve transplant outcomes and benefit other medical fields like bone marrow transplantation and autoimmune diseases.

title: Mount Sinai Health System Launches New Season of Road to Resilience Podcast
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System has relaunched its Road to Resilience podcast after a yearlong hiatus, featuring a new producer and host, Stephen Calabria. The podcast, which began in 2018, is based on the book "Resilience: The Science of Mastering Life’s Greatest Challenges," co-authored by Dennis S. Charney, MD, and Steven Southwick, MD. Dr. Charney, Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, has significantly contributed to the research on resilience, which spans 25 years. The podcast aims to provide insights into resilience through expert discussions and personal stories. It will be available on platforms like iTunes and Spotify.

title: Road to Resilience Archive
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: The "Road to Resilience" podcast, launched in 2018 by Mount Sinai, shares inspiring stories of human resilience. The series draws from the book "Resilience: The Science of Mastering Life's Greatest Challenges," co-authored by Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, and resilience expert Jonathan Depierro, PhD. Charney's contributions include insights on resilience factors, strategies for overcoming adversity, and personal experiences, such as his recovery from being shot by a former employee. The podcast covers diverse topics, from coping with COVID-19 to overcoming personal trauma, offering listeners practical advice and inspiration.

title: Executive Leadership
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: The Mount Sinai Health System's Executive Leadership team oversees eight hospitals, a medical school, a nursing school, and over 400 practices. Their mission is to provide compassionate care, advance medicine through education, research, and outreach, and maintain national and international prominence. Key leaders include Brendan Carr, CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, President for Academic Affairs; Margaret Pastuszko, President and COO; Beth Essig, General Counsel; Jeffrey Silberstein, EVP and CAO; Mark Kostegan, Chief Development Officer; Jane Maksoud, Chief Human Resources Officer; Gary C. Butts, EVP for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion; Frank Cino, Chief Risk and Compliance Officer; Vicki LoPachin, Chief Medical Officer; David A. Feinberg, Chief Marketing and Communications Officer; Erik Lium, Chief Commercial Innovation Officer; Beth Oliver, Chief Nurse Executive; Kelly Cassano, CEO of Mount Sinai Doctors Faculty Practice; Eric J. Nestler, Chief Scientific Officer; Stephen Harvey, CFO; Douglas E. Carney, SVP for Real Estate; Jodi L. Cohen-Ansari, Chief Strategy Officer; and Arthur A. Gianelli, Chief Transformation Officer. Dennis S. Charney contributes as President for Academic Affairs.

title: Mount Sinai Health System Celebrates Its 38th Annual Crystal Party in Person After Four Years
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System celebrated its 38th annual Crystal Party in person after four years, raising $3 million with 800 attendees. The event, chaired by Dina Powell McCormick and David McCormick, featured inspiring patient stories, including a Ukrainian teen's life-saving heart procedure, a Staten Island child's comprehensive care, and a double lung transplant for a 9/11-exposed chef. Dennis S. Charney, MD, emphasized the role of philanthropy in enabling Mount Sinai to provide top-quality healthcare, educate future medical leaders, and achieve scientific breakthroughs. The funds raised will support various programs and departments within the health system.

title: Mount Sinai launches Discovery and Innovation Center in Midtown West
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
summary: Mount Sinai Health System has opened its new Discovery and Innovation Center in Midtown West, New York City, significantly expanding research capabilities in collaboration with clinical neuroscience and neurosurgery centers at Mount Sinai West. The center, spanning over 150,000 square feet, will house advanced research facilities including Stem Cell Engineering, Genomics Technology, and Therapeutic Antibody Development cores. Dennis S. Charney, Dean of the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, highlighted the center’s role in fostering innovation and collaboration among leading experts in genomics, stem cell science, neuroscience, and immunology. This initiative aims to accelerate scientific breakthroughs and enhance patient care through advanced research and technology. The center is part of Mount Sinai’s commitment to advancing health and medical research, benefiting both local and national communities.

title: Mount Sinai Launches New Research Center in Midtown Manhattan West
hco: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI

Mark Lebwohl, MD, an investigator and dean at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, highlighted bimekizumab's superior skin clearance at week 16 compared to placebo and other biologics, with lasting effects up to a year. The approval was based on three phase 3 trials showing significant efficacy and safety. Common adverse reactions include respiratory infections and headaches. Bimekizumab will be available in the US in about a month and is administered via autoinjector or syringe. The recommended dosage varies based on patient weight. The drug is also being studied for other conditions and was previously approved in the EU for psoriasis and other autoimmune disorders. Lebwohl has not accepted consulting payments from UCB.

title: CKD and Rapid Kidney Function Decline During the COVID-19 Pandemic
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION OF COLORADO NEW MEXICO MONTANA AND WYOMING INC
summary: A study in Kidney Medicine examined COVID-19's impact on kidney function in CKD stages G3-4. Using deidentified data from Medicare Advantage and commercially insured enrollees between 2018-2021, it found COVID-19 increased the odds of rapid kidney function decline (eGFR decline of ≥40%). 9% of the CKD cohort had COVID-19, showing higher rapid decline than those uninfected. Factors like advancing CKD stage, higher comorbidity index, and Asian race increased odds of decline. Joseph Vassalotti contributed to the study. It highlights the need for close monitoring of CKD patients, especially those with COVID-19, to mitigate long-term consequences.

title: Albuminuria-Based CKD Screening Falls Short in At-Risk Populations

Vassalotti, MD, NKF’s Chief Medical Officer, analyzed data from over 7 million adults, revealing that while annual eGFR tests were conducted in over 90% of patients, UACR testing was below 40%. title: Rationale and design of a randomised phase III registration trial investigating finerenone in participants with type 1 ...
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: The FINE-ONE trial is a phase III, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of finerenone in adults with type 1 diabetes and chronic kidney disease (CKD). Despite existing treatments, up to 40% of individuals with type 1 diabetes develop CKD, risking kidney failure. Finerenone, already approved for type 2 diabetes, is hypothesized to benefit type 1 diabetes patients similarly. The trial involves approximately 220 participants and measures changes in urine albumin/creatinine ratio (UACR) over six months as the primary endpoint. UACR serves as a bridging biomarker for regulatory approval. Secondary outcomes include incidences of treatment-emergent adverse events, serious adverse events, and hyperkalaemia. Sylvia E. Rosas is one of the contributing authors to this study. If successful, finerenone could become the first registered treatment for CKD in type 1 diabetes in nearly 30 years. The trial is registered under ClinicalTrials.gov NCT05901831.

title: Fact Check: Exercise And Diet Do NOT Cure Type 1 Diabetes
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: At the time of writing, there is no cure for Type 1 diabetes, according to medical experts, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and the Mayo Clinic. Claims that exercise and diet can cure Type 1 diabetes are false. Sylvia Rosas, president of the National Kidney Foundation, confirmed that while lifestyle factors such as exercise and a healthy diet are important for managing blood sugar levels and controlling complications, they are not sufficient to cure diabetes. She recommended specific diets like the Mediterranean, DASH, vegetarian, or low-carb diets but emphasized that medication is often necessary for adequate glycemic control.

title: S2 Episode 4: Chronic Kidney Disease: FSGS, Genetic Testing, and APOL1
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: Dr. Kirk Campbell, a prominent nephrologist at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, contributed significantly to the discussion on focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) and the role of genetic testing, particularly the APOL1 gene variants. Campbell emphasized that FSGS is a histologic pattern of injury rather than a single disease, complicating its treatment. He highlighted that genetic testing is crucial, especially for patients with a strong family history of kidney disease or those resistant to steroids. Campbell also discussed the groundbreaking discovery of APOL1 variants, which significantly impact kidney disease in individuals of West African ancestry. He elaborated on the potential of precision-based therapies targeting specific genetic mutations, such as inaxaplin for APOL1-associated kidney disease. Campbell's insights underscore the importance of a personalized approach in nephrology, combining genetic, histologic, and clinical data to optimize patient care.

Campbell emphasizes the importance of supporting and training frontline workers to deliver equitable care. He also highlights initiatives such as mentorship programs, unconscious bias training, and the development of dashboards to track clinical outcomes and demographic data. These efforts aim to ensure that vulnerable populations receive optimal care and address longstanding health disparities.

title: How one patient went off dialysis — and others can too - STAT
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: Melissa Lawson, diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, faced severe kidney failure requiring frequent dialysis. Despite initial setbacks, she moved to UCSF Medical Center, where she met nephrologist Chi-yuan Hsu. Hsu, who believed many acute kidney injury patients could be weaned off dialysis earlier, included Lawson in his study. The study, published in the Journal of the American Society of Nephrology, found that 40% of acute kidney injury patients recovered kidney function, with many potentially over-treated with dialysis. Paul Palevsky, a nephrology expert, supported the notion that some patients remain on dialysis longer than necessary due to lack of tailored care. Ultimately, Lawson's condition improved, allowing her to cease dialysis, highlighting the importance of individualized patient assessment and the potential for recovery.

Alison Steiber, PhD, RDN, LD, the Academy’s chief science officer, emphasized the tool's ease of use in clinical settings and its role in improving patient outcomes and reducing healthcare costs. The AAIM tool's effectiveness is supported by two scientific papers, demonstrating its predictive validity for clinical outcomes such as hospital stays, emergency visits, readmission rates, and patient mortality. title: Perspective: Nutritional Status as a Biological Variable (NABV): Integrating Nutrition Science into Basic and Clinical ...

summary: The text discusses the evolution of nutrition science from identifying essential nutrients to developing dietary recommendations for health promotion and disease prevention. The text highlights the need for comprehensive research to address the complexities of nutrition in the context of global health challenges, including COVID-19. title: For healthy kidneys, avoid excess alcohol and salt, get regular screenings
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: To maintain healthy kidneys, avoid excess alcohol and salt, stay hydrated, and exercise regularly. Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects over a third of people aged 65 and older and is becoming more common. Key risk factors include diabetes, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, and long-term use of certain medications. A diet low in salt and sugar and high in unprocessed foods can protect kidney health. Regular screenings are essential, especially for those over 60 or with high blood pressure or diabetes. Early detection through blood and urine tests can help manage CKD. Lifestyle changes, such as dietary modifications and quitting smoking, along with certain diabetes medications, can slow CKD progression. In severe cases, dialysis or a kidney transplant may be necessary. Prevention through healthy habits and routine screenings is vital.

title: Outpatient management of the kidney patient for the primary care practitioner
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC

This initiative aims to provide a comprehensive overview of managing chronic kidney disease (CKD) in outpatient settings, emphasizing early detection, novel interventions, and management strategies. Sumeska Thavarajah, a nephrologist at Johns Hopkins University, has significantly contributed to this collection. She focuses on CKD and dialysis care and has a strong interest in education programs for professionals and patients. Thavarajah has worked extensively with the National Kidney Foundation and has been involved in BMC Nephrology as a blog editor since 2019. The collection encourages submissions on various topics, including diagnostic strategies, management tools, and the role of primary care in handling CKD-related complications.

title: EMERALD: Patiromer for Hyperkalemia Treatment in Pediatric CKD
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: The EMERALD trial (NCT03087058) evaluates the pharmacodynamics and safety of patiromer, a sodium-free potassium binder, in children aged 2 to 18 with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and hyperkalemia. This open-label, multiple-dose study includes a 14-day dose-finding phase and a 5.5-month treatment phase. Bradley A. Warady, MD, presented initial results at Kidney Week 2019. The study aims to enroll up to 54 patients in three age-based cohorts, assessing various starting doses of patiromer to achieve a target serum potassium level of 3.8 to 5.0 mEq/L. Initial results from Cohort 1 (ages 12-18) showed a significant reduction in serum potassium levels, with 50% of patients achieving the target by day 14 and 82% by week 26. Adverse events were mostly mild to moderate, with no severe events leading to discontinuation. The study suggests that patiromer is effective and well-tolerated in adolescents with CKD and hyperkalemia.

title: CKD and Rapid Kidney Function Decline During the COVID-19 Pandemic

hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) and Healthy.io have partnered to enhance access to kidney disease testing. They will distribute Minuteful Kidney™ test kits as part of the "Are You the 33%?" campaign, allowing at-risk individuals to test for chronic kidney disease (CKD) at home using a smartphone camera. This initiative, launched on Kidney Day 2023, aims to educate and provide resources for early detection of CKD, especially in underserved communities. Joseph Vassalotti, MD, NKF's Chief Medical Officer, emphasized the campaign's goal to raise awareness and promote kidney health equity. The at-home test, the first FDA-cleared of its kind, seeks to overcome barriers like transportation and cost, which often prevent routine testing.

title: Albuminuria-Based CKD Screening Falls Short in At-Risk Populations
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: Research indicates that albuminuria-based screening for chronic kidney disease (CKD) is insufficient among at-risk populations, including those with diabetes and hypertension. Less than 40% of adults with diabetes received recommended CKD testing in 2017. Joseph A. Vassalotti, MD, Chief Medical Officer of the National Kidney Foundation, highlighted that testing for albuminuria leads to better evidence-based care. Vassalotti and colleagues analyzed data from over 7 million diabetic adults, revealing that while eGFR testing was common, UACR testing was underutilized. The study found that fulfilling Kidney Health Evaluation Measure criteria improved CKD diagnosis and management. Socioeconomically disadvantaged groups had the lowest testing rates. Population-wide screening and home-based methods were explored as potential solutions to improve early detection and treatment of CKD.

title: Warwick resident named 'chief people officer' at National Kidney Foundation
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: Joanne "Jo" Rencher has been appointed as the Chief People Officer at the National Kidney Foundation (NKF). Rencher, a Warwick resident, will lead NKF's People and Culture Department, focusing on Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) strategies. Reporting to CEO Kevin Longino, Rencher brings extensive experience from various sectors, including healthcare, financial services, and nonprofits. Her career highlights include pioneering roles at the Girl Scouts, American Red Cross, and the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative. Rencher has also received leadership awards and authored a career manual for women. She expressed her commitment to advancing NKF's mission of advocating for quality kidney care and leveraging data for strategic decision-making.

title: Two Nurses Launch Commission For Nursing Reimbursement
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: The Commission for Nursing Reimbursement was launched in April 2023 to address the financial model of nursing care, which has remained unchanged since the 1930s. Co-chaired by Rebecca Love and Sharon Pearce, the Commission aims to transform nursing care from a non-billable expense into a billable service, addressing financial disparities and staffing shortages in the nursing profession. Sharon Pearce, with over 20 years of experience in legislative outreach and policy strategy, emphasizes the critical need to value nurses appropriately to prevent the ongoing exodus from the profession. The Commission plans to work with various healthcare organizations to propose solutions to Congress, aiming to reduce healthcare costs and improve working conditions for nurses.

title: Miller School Pathologist Receives International Medal of Merit - InventUM
hco: NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION IOWA AND NEBRASKA INC
summary: Elizabeth Montgomery, M.D., a professor of pathology and laboratory medicine and vice chair of Faculty Development and Mentoring at the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine, was awarded the Medal of Merit by the International Academy of Pathology (IAP) Arab Division. The award, presented during IAP’s 34th annual congress in Qatar, recognizes individuals dedicated to promoting academic pathology and educational activities. Dr. Montgomery expressed her gratitude and highlighted the Arab Division's commitment to pathology education. Her colleagues, Rhonda Yantiss, M.D., and Andrew Rosenberg, M.D., also contributed to the congress by leading sessions on gastrointestinal and bone tumor pathology, respectively. Dr. Merce Jorda praised Dr. Montgomery as an icon in pathology, noting her significant impact on the training program and patient care at Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, UHealth, and Jackson Health System. The Miller School’s participation underscored its global leadership in academic pathology.

title: Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute and Wayne State University name Boris C. Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., FACP ...
summary: Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute and Wayne State University have appointed Boris C. Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., FACP, as President and Chief Executive Officer, effective August 28, 2023. Dr. Pasche will also chair the Department of Oncology at Wayne State University School of Medicine and serve as Principal Investigator for the Comprehensive Cancer Center Core Grant, pending NCI approval. Previously, at Wake Forest Baptist Health, he significantly expanded the cancer research program and increased NCI funding by 97%. Dr. Pasche’s new role involves setting strategic visions for Karmanos, overseeing clinical care, research, and community engagement, and advancing cancer research and treatment.

title: This is why an NCI designation matters when choosing where to receive cancer care
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute, part of McLaren Health Care, is a National Cancer Institute (NCI)-Designated Comprehensive Cancer Center in metro Detroit. This prestigious designation ensures that Karmanos meets stringent requirements, including conducting advanced research, offering early-phase clinical trials, and providing community outreach. The institute diagnoses and treats over 14,000 new cancer cases annually across 16 locations. Patients benefit from innovative treatments and therapies often unavailable elsewhere. Boris C. Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., FACP, president and CEO, highlighted that Karmanos provides access to new drugs and immunotherapies before FDA approval. The NCI designation signifies top-tier care and positions Karmanos at the forefront of developing future cancer treatments.

title: Discrimination a Key Social Determinant of Health in Frailty, Outcomes
summary: A study published in the journal Cancer highlights discrimination as a significant social determinant of health, particularly in relation to frailty among Black cancer survivors. The research, led by Jeanne Mandelblatt, MD, MPH, demonstrates that cumulative stress from racism and discrimination can lead to adverse health outcomes, including increased frailty. The study surveyed over 2,200 Black individuals in cancer remission, revealing that those who experienced more types of discrimination had higher frailty scores. Ann Schwartz, Ph.D., MPH, a co-author of the study, emphasized that discrimination impacts health outcomes as significantly as other social determinants like income. Schwartz, who is also a professor and associate chair of oncology at Wayne State University, highlighted that individuals facing multiple types of discrimination showed greater frailty regardless of their economic status. This research underscores the need for healthcare providers to understand and address the impact of discrimination on patient health.

title: Heath Discusses Utility of NECTIN-4 as a Target in Urothelial Carcinoma
summary: Elisabeth I. Heath, MD, FACP, highlights the potential of NECTIN-4 as a target in urothelial carcinoma, emphasizing its role in cell adhesion and metastasis. The phase 3 EV-302/KEYNOTE-A39 trial demonstrated significant efficacy of enfortumab vedotin, a NECTIN-4–targeted antibody-drug conjugate (ADC), combined with pembrolizumab, showing superior progression-free survival compared to chemotherapy. Enfortumab vedotin received FDA approval for treating locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer, marking a shift in the standard of care. Heath notes NECTIN-4's visibility and impact on cellular signaling as key factors in its attractiveness for drug development. The findings from the EV-302/KEYNOTE-A39 trial have significantly impacted the urothelial oncology community, offering a new treatment paradigm. Heath also discusses the potential for NECTIN-4-targeted therapies in other cancers, such as pancreatic, breast, esophageal, lung, and head and neck cancers, and the ongoing development of additional ADCs targeting NECTIN-4 to improve potency and reduce toxicity.

title: Optimizing mHSPC Care and Collaboration for Triplet Therapy - Jason Hafron & Elisabeth Heath
summary: The discussion between Jason Hafron, M.D., and Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP, focuses on optimizing care for metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) through triplet therapy, emphasizing the importance of collaboration between urology and medical oncology. Dr. Hafron highlights the evolution of their partnership, involving shared knowledge and patient referrals for clinical trials and advanced treatments. Dr. Heath elaborates on the dynamics of their collaboration, navigating patient care across different health systems while respecting each other's expertise. They discuss patient identification, education on treatments, and the division of responsibilities in prescribing therapies. Both emphasize respect, understanding, and communication in providing comprehensive care and advancing treatment options for mHSPC patients. Dr. Heath's contributions are crucial in managing complex cases and offering advanced clinical trials, enhancing the overall quality of patient care.

title: Third annual Prostate Cancer Awareness Night: Smashing success for awareness, early detection
summary: The third annual Prostate Cancer Awareness Night, organized by the Barbara Ann Karmanos Institute with the Detroit Tigers and McLaren Health Care, successfully promoted awareness and early detection of prostate cancer. The event, held on June 20, 2023, at Comerica Park, featured blue-themed decorations and engaged hundreds of prostate cancer survivors and their families. Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP, emphasized the importance of discussing prostate cancer and early detection to improve survival rates. The night honored survivors, provided educational information, and raised funds for research. Activities included visits by the Tigers' mascot PAWS to patients, batting practice for survivors, and inspirational stories shared by survivors like Michael Dudley. The event highlighted the critical role of screening and early detection in combating prostate cancer, urging men to undergo regular screenings.

title: Overview of the Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer Treatment Paradigm
summary: Expert oncologists provide an overview of the current treatment paradigm for metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). The discussion highlights the continuum of diseases from metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC) to mCRPC and the numerous treatment options available. Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP, from Karmanos Cancer Institute, emphasizes the importance of monitoring molecular changes to understand resistance mechanisms to therapy. The conversation also covers the aggressive nature of certain patient populations and the need for tailored treatment strategies, including the potential use of lutetium and other therapies to improve patient outcomes.

title: Practical Application of PARP Inhibitors in Metastatic CRPC
summary: The article discusses the practical application of PARP inhibitors in treating metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). An expert panel, including Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP from Karmanos Cancer Institute, evaluates the efficacy and safety of these inhibitors. Dr. Heath emphasizes the importance of genomic testing for personalized treatment, highlighting that not all patients benefit equally from PARP inhibitors combined with androgen receptor-targeted therapies. The panel also discusses the need for specific clinical trials to address unanswered questions and optimize treatment strategies. Dr. Heath argues for careful consideration of trial designs and endpoints to ensure meaningful results, underscoring the necessity of continued research and patient participation in clinical trials to advance the field.

title: Breakthroughs in Imaging Modalities for Prostate Cancer
summary: Recent advances in imaging modalities for prostate cancer, particularly PSMA-PET, have significantly impacted the field. A panel of five experts, including Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP, discussed these developments. Dr. Heath emphasized the transformative role of PSMA (prostate-specific membrane antigen) in both imaging and treatment since its introduction. She highlighted the initial approval of Gallium 68 PSMA in December 2020, followed by Pylarify and the lutetium-177 compound, which have shifted clinical conversations and practices. The panel discussed the integration of PSMA-based imaging into guidelines like the NCCN and RADAR VI, despite challenges with insurance coverage and the need for further validation of its impact on survival. Dr. Heath and her colleagues underscored the potential of PSMA-PET to improve staging and treatment decisions, enhancing patient outcomes in both nonmetastatic and metastatic prostate cancer.

title: Treatment Goals for Patients With Metastatic Hormone-Sensitive Prostate Cancer
summary: The discussion focuses on treatment goals for patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC). Elisabeth Heath, M.D., FACP, explains the evolving landscape of treatment, emphasizing the shift from traditional androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) to more intensive approaches involving combinations of ADT with other therapies. Heath highlights the complexity of treatment decisions due to ongoing clinical trials and the need for real-world application of data. She notes that while intensification improves survival and quality of life, many patients still receive only ADT monotherapy. Heath stresses the importance of shared decision-making, considering patient comorbidities and preferences, and simplifying complex information for patients to ensure they understand their treatment options.

title: Addressing Barriers to Care in Metastatic Castration-Resistant Prostate Cancer
summary: Tanya Dorff, MD, and Elisabeth Heath, MD, FACP, discuss the significant challenges in providing care for patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). They highlight issues such as insurance barriers that impede access to necessary diagnostic tools like PSMA PET scans, which are crucial for determining the suitability of certain treatments. Heath emphasizes the struggle in states like Michigan, where obtaining oral chemotherapy drugs is still problematic. Both experts stress the need for better sequencing of treatments to preserve bone marrow function and the importance of reliable markers to assess treatment efficacy, especially in bone metastases. Heath also underscores the complexity of disease progression and the need for improved diagnostic parameters to evaluate patient responses effectively.

title: LaTonya Riddle-Jones, M.D., receives 2023 Leonard Tow Humanism in Medicine Award
summary: LaTonya Riddle-Jones, M.D., M.P.H., an assistant professor at Wayne State University School of Medicine, received the 2023 Leonard Tow Humanism in Medicine Award. This award, presented by the Gold Humanism Honor Society, recognizes faculty who demonstrate exceptional compassion, respect, and clinical excellence. Dr. Riddle-Jones, vice chair of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in the Department of Internal Medicine, expressed gratitude for being chosen by students. A 2008 graduate of the School of Medicine, she served as the medical director for Corktown Health Center, Detroit's first nonprofit medical home for adult LGBTQ patients. Named a Health Care Hero by Crain’s Business Detroit in 2020, her work focuses on preventive health, health equity, and health literacy. She is also the associate director of the Tri-County Breast and Cervical Cancer Control Program. Dr. Riddle-Jones emphasized the importance of humanism in medicine and cultural humility during her keynote address at the White Coat Ceremony for the Class of 2027.

title: Taskforce works to end racialized differences in medical education and practice
summary: The Wayne State University School of Medicine’s End Race-Based Medicine Taskforce, co-created by Ijeoma Nnodim Opara, M.D., and LaTonya Riddle-Jones, M.D., M.P.H., aims to eliminate race-based medical practices and research. The taskforce includes members from various institutions and focuses on three primary goals: discontinuing race-based medicine, adopting racism-conscious medicine, and organizing community discussions. Dr. Riddle-Jones emphasized that race-based medicine harms patients and communities and should end immediately. The taskforce, supported by several medical organizations, seeks to remove racialized reporting from medical records, discontinue race-corrective functions in tests, and eliminate race as a risk factor in medical treatments. Their efforts are rooted in addressing the systemic racism embedded in medical practices and promoting equitable health care.

title: Two Options for Implicit Bias Training Next Week
summary: The Michigan State Medical Society (MSMS) is offering two options for implicit bias training next week. The first, "Monday Night Medicine - Implicit Bias Training," will be on March 13, 2023, from 5:30 – 8:30 pm, featuring presentations by Lynn Smitherman, MD, and LaTonya Riddle-Jones, MD, MPH. Dr. Riddle-Jones, Vice-Chair of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at Wayne State University, specializes in Internal Medicine/Pediatrics and LGBTQ+ Health. She holds a Medical Degree from Wayne State University and a Master of Public Health from Harvard. The second training, "Reducing Unconscious Bias - an Imperative (RUBI): Foundation and Impacts on Patient Care," is a two-part series created with the Henry Ford Health System, including an on-demand video and a live webinar on March 15, 2023, from 12:00 – 1:00 pm EST.

title: 2023 Medical Education Research and Innovation Conference winners announced
summary: The Wayne State University School of Medicine held its fifth annual Medical Education Research and Innovation Conference on Nov. 16, showcasing various medical education research and innovation projects. The event featured keynote speakers LuAnn Wilkerson, Ed.D., and John Mitchell, M.D., and included judging of entries in three categories: Medical Education Research, Medical Education Innovation, and Works in Progress. Notable winning entries included first place for “Starting Off on the Right Foot: Student Feedback of Medical School Orientation” and second place for “Integration of a Social Needs Program into an Urban Student-Run Free Clinic.” LaTonya Riddle-Jones, M.D., M.P.H., contributed to the third-place project “Unmasking Race-Based Medicine: Examining Its Impact and Elimination Efforts in Medical Education.” The conference aimed to highlight ongoing and completed efforts to improve medical education through research and innovative solutions.

title: Faculty celebrated with promotion and tenure, and dean's awards
summary: The Wayne State University School of Medicine celebrated its faculty's achievements during the 2023 Faculty Awards and Promotion and Tenure Ceremony. Honorees included Yuan He, Zhibing Zhang, and Samson Jamesdaniel, who received tenure. Rhonda Dailey received the Outstanding Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Faculty Scholar Award for her leadership in DEI education and mentorship. Nashat Imran was awarded the Excellence in Clinical Science Teaching Award for his mentoring skills. Dennis Goebel received the Moghissi Basic Science Teaching Award for his contributions to teaching basic sciences. Mark Greenwald was honored with the Outstanding Research Achievement Award for his work in drug addiction and treatment. Felicity Harper received the Outstanding Faculty Mentor Award for her dedication to mentoring. Teen Chopra was awarded the Women in Medicine & Science Leadership Award for her contributions to mentoring and advancing women in medicine. LaTonya Riddle-Jones, M.D., M.P.H., was recognized with a College Teaching Award for her instructional expertise.

title: Innovative treatment uses radio frequency to target and reduce cancerous tumors
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute in Michigan is the first in the U.S. to offer the TheraBionic P1 device, an FDA-approved at-home treatment for advanced hepatocellular carcinoma, the most common type of liver cancer. The device emits low levels of radio-frequency electromagnetic fields to inhibit tumor growth without affecting healthy tissue. Patients use it in three one-hour sessions daily. Boris Pasche, M.D., Ph.D., co-inventor of TheraBionic P1, highlighted its potential to prolong patients' lives. Anthony Shields, M.D., Ph.D., professor of Oncology at Karmanos, emphasized its importance for patients with limited treatment options due to impaired liver function. Shields expressed excitement about offering this safe and effective therapy. The TheraBionic P1 has shown a comparable response rate to existing treatments and no serious adverse events after six years of use. Clinical trials are ongoing for other cancer types.

title: "It's Racism Not Race" panel discussion set for Feb. 28
summary: The Wayne State University School of Medicine’s End Race-Based Medicine Taskforce will host a panel discussion titled “It’s Racism Not Race: Moving From Race Science and Race-Based Medicine to Racism Conscious Medicine in Practice, Education and Policy” on February 28 from 5 to 7 p.m. via Zoom. The event is part of the taskforce’s townhall roundtable series. Panelists include David Underwood, Kim Rhoads, M.D., M.P.H., Ebony Madden, Ph.D., Camille Clare, M.D., M.P.H., and State Rep. Abraham Aiyash. The discussion will be moderated by Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., professor of Oncology and associate director of the Office of Cancer Health Equity and Community Engagement at the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute. Keynote speakers are Joseph Graves, Ph.D., and Michelle Morse, M.D., M.P.H. Registration is required to receive the Zoom link. For more information, contact innodim@med.wayne.edu or lriddle@med.wayne.edu.

title: Call for abstracts: College of Nursing welcomes urban health topics for 2024 conference
summary: The Wayne State University College of Nursing is accepting abstracts for its 2024 Urban Health Research Conference, themed “Contemporary Issues in Urban Health: Building Trust in Health Care Among Diverse Populations,” scheduled for April 17, 2024. Abstracts should focus on urban health, with reports of completed research, quality improvement/evidence-based practice projects, and literature reviews being acceptable. Selected abstracts will be presented as posters at the conference in Midtown Detroit. The event aims to address medical mistrust and discrimination, featuring speakers such as Associate Professor Arash Javanbakht, M.D., and Professor of Oncology Hayley Thompson, Ph.D. Attendees will explore the significance of medical mistrust, its impact on diverse populations, and strategies to build trust in health care. Abstracts are due by December 13, 2023, and can be submitted online. Questions can be directed to Dr. Elizabeth Jenuwine. Authors will be notified of acceptance by January 31, 2024.

title: CAPABLE expands into Dearborn, will offer free exercise classes to Arab-American breast cancer survivors
summary: The CAPABLE program, supported by a $50,000 grant from Karmanos funding, is expanding into Dearborn to offer free exercise classes to Arab American breast cancer survivors. The program provides 12 weeks of physical activity classes, including interval training and strength workouts, as part of a clinical trial to improve cancer survivors' quality of life. Hayley S. Thompson, Ph.D., associate center director of Community Outreach and Engagement and professor at Wayne State University School of Medicine, co-leads CAPABLE. The program collaborates with ACCESS-Dearborn Cancer Action Council to address health and wellness priorities in the Arab American community. Research shows regular exercise benefits cancer outcomes, and CAPABLE aims to adapt its program to meet the needs of Arab American breast cancer survivors in Dearborn.

title: Detroit research team to develop novel strategies to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and overcome barriers ...
summary: A Detroit research team, led by Drs. Ann Schwartz and Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, received a $9.6 million grant from the National Cancer Institute to study genetic contributions to cancer risk and improve genetic testing for African Americans. The project aims to enhance the identification and management of hereditary and multiple primary cancers in this underrepresented group. Dr. Schwartz emphasized the importance of genetic testing in identifying high-risk populations and reducing cancer burden. Dr. Beebe-Dimmer highlighted the need to understand genetic susceptibility and modifiable risk factors in African Americans. Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., along with Felicity Harper, Ph.D., will develop strategies to overcome barriers to genetic testing in this population. The initiative seeks to address disparities in cancer incidence and mortality by expanding clinical testing and improving early diagnosis and treatment.

title: Enrollment now open for free CAPABLE fitness sessions for cancer survivors
summary: Enrollment is now open for the free CAPABLE fitness sessions for cancer survivors offered by the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute. These 12-week physical activity classes are part of a clinical trial aimed at improving the quality of life for cancer survivors. The study, led by Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, Ph.D., MPH, and co-led by Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., will include 20 participants each from Detroit and Petoskey. The CAPABLE program focuses on interval training, strength, and conditioning workouts tailored to each participant's fitness level. The study involves functional testing, surveys, and offers a $100 gift card upon completion. In Detroit, classes will be held at the Durfee Innovation Society, while in Petoskey, they will take place at CrossFit® Petoskey. Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., contributes as the associate center director of Community Outreach and Engagement and faculty supervisor of the Office of Cancer Health Equity and Community Engagement (OCHECE).

title: Faculty celebrated with promotion and tenure, and dean's awards
summary: The Wayne State University School of Medicine celebrated its 2023 Faculty Awards and Promotion and Tenure Ceremony, recognizing numerous faculty members for their contributions. Yuan He, Zhibing Zhang, and Samson Jamesdaniel received tenure. Rhonda Dailey was awarded the Outstanding Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Faculty Scholar Award for her leadership in promoting DEI, with Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., highlighting Dr. Dailey’s efforts in her nomination. Nashat Imran received the Excellence in Clinical Science Teaching Award, and Dennis Goebel was honored with the Moghissi Basic Science Teaching Award. Mark Greenwald was recognized with the Outstanding Research Achievement Award for his work in drug addiction and treatment. Felicity Harper received the Outstanding Faculty Mentor Award for her dedication to mentoring, and Teen Chopra was honored with the Women in Medicine & Science Leadership Award for her support and mentorship of women faculty. Numerous other faculty members were promoted and recognized for their teaching and research excellence.

title: Study finds relationship between discrimination and frailty in Black cancer survivors
summary: A study by Wayne State University, the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute, and Georgetown University found that discrimination significantly impacts frailty in Black cancer survivors. The research, published in the journal Cancer, involved 2,232 Black cancer survivors who reported experiencing various types of major discrimination. The findings showed that those who faced more discrimination had higher frailty scores, regardless of socioeconomic status. Ann Schwartz, Ph.D., M.P.H., a co-lead author, emphasized that discrimination independently contributed to frailty beyond traditional health factors. Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., contributed as an associate center director of Community Outreach and Engagement at Karmanos and professor of Oncology at Wayne State University. The study underscores the need for healthcare providers to consider the impact of discrimination on the health of Black cancer survivors.

title: Detroit research team to develop novel strategies to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and overcome barriers ...
summary: A Detroit research team from Wayne State University and the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute has received a $9.6 million grant from the National Cancer Institute to study genetic contributions to cancer risk in African Americans. Led by Drs. Ann Schwartz and Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, the project aims to improve the identification and clinical management of hereditary and multiple primary cancers in this underrepresented population. The study, involving one of the largest cohorts of African American cancer survivors, will address barriers to genetic testing and explore genetic susceptibility. Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., along with Felicity Harper, Ph.D., will develop novel strategies to enhance genetic testing accessibility for African Americans. This research seeks to mitigate health disparities and improve cancer outcomes within the community.

title: CVS Health teams with WSU to improve health outcomes in underserved communities
summary: CVS Health has partnered with Wayne State University (WSU) to launch the CVS Health Community Equity Alliance, aimed at improving health outcomes in underserved communities by addressing barriers to care. This initiative will expand the community health worker workforce, enhance connections between healthcare institutions and communities, and address disparities in heart and mental health. WSU, Meharry Medical College, and Sinai Chicago are the first institutions to join, with CVS Health providing funding for localized initiatives. The collaboration with WSU's Center for Health Equity and Community Knowledge in Urban Populations (CHECK-UP), led by Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., includes a $300,000 commitment to reduce health disparities in Detroit. CHECK-UP aims to integrate community voices and resources, train faculty and community members, and promote community-based participatory research to improve health equity. The alliance seeks to make healthcare more accessible and reduce health disparities through collaborative efforts and evidence-based interventions.

title: Why African American parents may delay or refuse HPV vaccination for their children
summary: A study led by Ariel Washington, Ph.D., MSSW, explored why African American parents may delay or refuse the HPV vaccine for their children. Using the Vaccine Hesitancy Determinants Matrix, the research identified concerns such as the child's age, discrimination, mistrust of doctors, and vaccine safety. The study, conducted with 20 parents from Detroit, Inkster, and Flint, highlighted that parents often felt unheard regarding HPV vaccination discussions. The findings suggest that personal and influential life experiences significantly impact vaccine decision-making, emphasizing the need for comprehensive conversations about HPV vaccination. Hayley Thompson, Ph.D., contributed as the faculty supervisor of the OCHECE, associate center director for Community Outreach and Engagement at Karmanos, and professor of oncology at Wayne State University. The study, titled “'Why is it so necessary?’: African American Parents’ Perspectives on Delaying and Refusing HPV Vaccination,” was published in the Journal of Pediatric Health Care in February 2023.

title: Top executives at McLaren Health Care, Karmanos Cancer Institute recognized on DBusiness Magazine's “Detroit 500 ...
summary: Top executives at McLaren Health Care and Karmanos Cancer Institute have been recognized on DBusiness Magazine’s “Detroit 500” list, which highlights the 500 most influential business leaders in metro Detroit. This recognition includes Philip A. Incarnati, President and CEO of McLaren Health Care, and Brian R. Gamble, President of Karmanos Cancer Hospital and Network. The selection criteria for the “Detroit 500” list include factors such as the size of the company or organization, growth rate, geographical reach, and extensive personal contacts.

title: Dr Deol on Potential Avenues for CAR T-Cell Therapy Research in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Abhinav Deol, MD, from the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute and Wayne State University School of Medicine, discusses potential research avenues for CAR T-cell therapy in multiple myeloma. Dr. Deol highlights the need to shorten CAR T-cell infusion wait times, as many eligible patients cannot receive treatment due to limited manufacturing slots. The approval of teclistamab-cqvy (Tecvayli) offers new therapy options for these patients. Dr. Deol also explores the potential of using CAR T-cell therapy earlier in the disease course to achieve deeper responses, longer remissions, or prolonged disease control. Additionally, he mentions ongoing investigations into allogeneic CAR T cells, which are off-the-shelf and available for immediate infusion, showing promising safety and efficacy without causing graft-vs-host disease. Further research aims to develop strategies to mitigate lymphodepletion before administering allogeneic CAR T cells.

title: Five Physicians Recognized as Karmanos Top Docs in Celebration of Doctors’ Day 2024
summary: Five physicians, including Abhinav Deol, M.D., were honored as Karmanos Top Docs in celebration of Doctors’ Day 2024 by McLaren Health Care. These physicians were recognized based on positive feedback from patients, families, staff, and colleagues in the Press Ganey Survey throughout 2023. Dr. Deol, a member of the Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Transplant, Multiple Myeloma and Amyloidosis, and Hematology Oncology Multidisciplinary Teams (MDT), received praise for his friendly demeanor and attentive care. Other recognized physicians include Dipenkumar Modi, M.D., Robert Morris, M.D., Jay Yang, M.D., and Jeffrey Zonder, M.D., each receiving commendations for their dedication and patient care. This recognition highlights their commitment to creating positive experiences and exemplary service at Karmanos.

title: Dr Deol on Sequencing Treatment Options With CAR T-Cell Therapy in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Abhinav Deol, MD, discusses the sequencing of CAR T-cell therapies with other available agents in multiple myeloma. He highlights the growing treatment landscape, particularly with the FDA approval of teclistamab-cqvy (Tecvayli), a BCMA-directed bispecific T-cell engaging antibody. This therapy targets both BCMA on myeloma cells and CD3 on T cells, creating cellular toxicity to eliminate myeloma cells. Deol notes that many studies excluded patients who had prior BCMA-directed therapy, resulting in limited data on their responses to subsequent CAR T-cell therapy. Real-world data shows that while responses are still seen, they are lower when BCMA has been previously targeted. Deol emphasizes the need to understand the mechanisms of relapse, such as T cell loss or changes in BCMA expression, to determine optimal next treatments. He concludes by stressing the importance of setting patient expectations for second-line BCMA-targeted therapies, as they are likely to be less effective.

title: New book for clinical providers fills a critical gap in care of hematopoietic stem cell transplant patients
summary: A new textbook titled “Pulmonary and Critical Care Considerations of Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation,” edited by Dr. Ayman Soubani, addresses the complex care of hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) patients. Published by Springer, it combines insights from pulmonologists, intensivists, and oncologists, including contributions from Wayne State University (WSU) faculty and fellows. The book covers a range of complications such as immunological changes in lungs, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, bronchiolitis obliterans, and pulmonary fibrosis, as well as neurologic, renal, gastrointestinal, and cardiac issues. Dr. Abhinav Deol, an Associate Professor of Hematology-Oncology at WSU, is one of the contributing authors. This comprehensive guide aims to serve as a valuable resource for healthcare providers managing the increasing population of HSCT patients globally. Dr. Soubani emphasized the importance of this work in filling a critical gap in medical literature.

title: KSP, McLaren's Specialty Pharmacy, recognized as a Leader in Performance Measurement
summary: KSP, McLaren’s Specialty Pharmacy, was awarded as a 2022 Pioneer in URAC’s Leaders in Performance Measurement (LPM) program. This award highlights KSP's commitment to improving healthcare quality through advanced performance measurement. Stephen Smith, MS, RPh, FASHP, Chief Pharmacy Officer at Karmanos Cancer Hospital and KSP, emphasized their dedication to making a difference in patient care. KSP, which started in 2019, provides affordable medications for patients with complex diseases, ensuring a seamless continuum of care. The URAC recognition reflects KSP’s efforts to exceed mandatory reporting requirements and achieve full accreditation in 2020.

title: Top Docs List 2023
summary: The Top Docs List 2023 by Hour Detroit Magazine features over 1,000 leading physicians in metro Detroit, nominated by their peers. The selection was conducted by Professional Research Services through an online peer-review survey among physicians in Wayne, Oakland, Macomb, Washtenaw, and Livingston counties. The doctors were screened for licensing and infractions. Dr. George Yoo, a notable inclusion, specializes in Otolaryngology at Detroit Medical Center, Karmanos Cancer Institute, and McLaren Health Care. He highlights that approximately 68,000 cases of mouth and throat cancers and 43,000 cases of thyroid cancers are diagnosed annually, stressing the importance of early detection and consulting a specialist if symptoms persist. The list covers various medical specialties, ensuring comprehensive recognition of top medical professionals in the region.

title: Hour Detroit’s 2023 Top Docs List includes over 30 Karmanos physicians
summary: Hour Detroit’s 2023 Top Docs List includes over 30 physicians from the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute. The list is compiled through an annual peer-to-peer review survey conducted by Professional Research Services (PRS), where physicians from Wayne, Oakland, Macomb, Washtenaw, and Livingston Counties nominate top doctors in various fields. George Yoo, M.D., FACS, an otolaryngologist and member of the Head and Neck Oncology and Melanoma Multidisciplinary Teams at Karmanos, is featured in this year's list. The list highlights the best doctors in specialties such as breast surgery, critical care medicine, dermatology, diagnostic radiology, endocrinology, gynecologic oncology, hematology, hospice and palliative medicine, infectious diseases, interventional radiology, neurosurgery, oncology, otolaryngology, psychiatry, radiation oncology, surgical oncology, thoracic oncology, and urology.

title: Karmanos Cancer Institute hires new vice-president of Karmanos Cancer Network
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute has appointed Doris Ranski-Zazula, RN, MSA, as the new vice president of the Karmanos Cancer Network, part of McLaren Health Care. In her new role, Ranski-Zazula will oversee the daily operations of Karmanos locations associated with various McLaren facilities, including McLaren Bay Region, Central Michigan, Clarkston, Flint, Greater Lansing, Lapeer, Macomb, Northern (Petoskey and Gaylord), Oakland, Port Huron, and Thumb Region. She brings over 30 years of healthcare experience to the position. Since joining McLaren in 2018, she has served as the director at McLaren Oakland, overseeing the respiratory therapy department, outpatient specialty clinic, and hospital information desk, as well as the regional director of Cancer Services. Ranski-Zazula holds a Master of Science in Health Care Administration from Central Michigan University and a Bachelor of Science in Nursing from Northern Michigan University.

title: Detroit research team to develop novel strategies to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and overcome barriers ...
summary: Drs. Ann Schwartz and Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer are leading a $9.6 million National Cancer Institute research study to improve the identification and clinical management of hereditary and multiple primary cancers in African Americans. This study, which involves one of the largest cohorts of African American cancer survivors, aims to address genetic susceptibility and testing barriers in this population. Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, Ph.D., co-principal investigator, is a professor of oncology at Wayne State University and leader of the Population Studies and Disparities Research Program at Karmanos Cancer Institute. The research will focus on identifying modifiable risk factors and enhancing access to genetic counseling and testing services for African Americans, who have been underrepresented in genetic research. The study's goal is to reduce cancer disparities and improve outcomes in this community.

title: Detroit research team to develop novel strategies to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and overcome barriers ...
summary: A Detroit research team led by Drs. Ann Schwartz and Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer has received a $9.6 million grant from the National Cancer Institute to identify genetic contributions to cancer risk and improve genetic testing access for African Americans. The five-year study, “Genetic Variation in Cancer Risk and Outcomes in African Americans,” aims to enhance the identification and clinical management of hereditary and multiple primary cancers in this underrepresented population.

title: Enrollment now open for free CAPABLE fitness sessions for cancer survivors
summary: The Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute is seeking cancer survivors for a 12-week free physical activity program called CAPABLE, aimed at improving their quality of life through exercise. The study, enrolling 20 participants each in Detroit and Petoskey, includes interval training, strength, and conditioning workouts tailored to each participant. Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, Ph.D., MPH, who leads the Population Studies and Disparities Research (PSDR) Program and serves as the scientific director of the Epidemiology Research Core at Karmanos Cancer Institute, developed the CAPABLE protocol. She emphasizes the physical and mental wellness benefits of exercise. Participants will undergo functional testing and complete surveys during the study, with no prior exercise experience required. The program also offers a $100 gift card upon completion. In Detroit, sessions are held in collaboration with Wayne State University and Gilda’s Club, while in Petoskey, they partner with McLaren Northern Michigan and CrossFit® Petoskey.

title: CAPABLE expands into Dearborn, will offer free exercise classes to Arab-American breast cancer survivors
summary: The Cross Training and Physical Activity: A Better Life Experience (CAPABLE) program is expanding into Dearborn, targeting Arab American breast cancer survivors. Funded by a $50,000 grant from Karmanos, CAPABLE offers 12 weeks of free physical activity classes, including interval training and strength workouts. The program is part of a clinical trial to explore how exercise improves cancer survivors' quality of life. Jennifer Beebe-Dimmer, Ph.D., MPH, co-leads CAPABLE. She is the leader of the Population Studies and Disparities Research (PSDR) Program, scientific director of the Epidemiology Research Core at the Barbara Ann Karmanos Cancer Institute, and a professor at Wayne State University School of Medicine. The initiative aims to address the lack of cancer prevention efforts in Arab American communities, working with ACCESS-Dearborn to adapt the program based on community feedback.

title: Researchers discover possible solution to suppress prostate cancer tumor growth
summary: Researchers at Wayne State University, in collaboration with several institutions, have discovered a potential method to suppress prostate cancer tumor growth. Their study, published in Theranostics, focuses on targeting the biomarker TRA-1-60 using radiopharmaceutical therapy. By selectively ablating TRA-1-60+ pluripotent cancer stem cells, they were able to suppress tumor progression and prevent relapse and metastasis. Dr. Nerissa Viola, Associate Professor of Oncology at Wayne State and leader of the Molecular Imaging Research Program at Karmanos, played a significant role in the study. The team used a zirconium-89 radiolabeled antibody for imaging and Lutetium-177 for therapeutic purposes in mice, demonstrating the clinical significance of TRA expression in prostate cancer. Future studies will explore targeted drug combinations to fully eradicate tumors. Dr. Viola emphasized the importance of preclinical studies in validating the efficacy of such treatments before moving to clinical trials.

title: Novel PET radiotracer facilitates early, noninvasive detection of inflammatory bowel disease
summary: A novel PET radiotracer targeting the IBD biomarker IL12/23p40 has been developed to facilitate early, non-invasive detection of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). This new imaging tool provides a detailed inflammation map of the gastrointestinal tract, aiding in accurate disease detection and staging. Current diagnostic methods for IBD, such as endoscopy and physical examinations, do not fully meet the need for precise and reliable visualization of gastrointestinal inflammation. Nerissa T. Viola, Ph.D., an associate professor at Wayne State University, contributed significantly by developing the immuno-PET imaging agent that targets IL12/23p40. Using a chemically induced mouse model of ulcerative colitis, the agent successfully detected acute inflammation, demonstrating its potential clinical value. Viola highlighted that this tool could serve as a companion diagnostic to FDA-approved treatments targeting the same biomarker, establishing a framework for future non-invasive imaging tools.

title: PAVmed Digital Health Subsidiary Veris Health's Veris Cancer Care Platform™ Goes Live
hco: NEW JERSEY SOCIETY OF ONCOLOGY MANAGERS
