summary: PAVmed Inc.'s digital health subsidiary, Veris Health, has launched the Veris Cancer Care Platform™ (Veris CCP) to enhance personalized cancer care through remote patient monitoring. The platform, which includes VerisBox™ connected devices and a smartphone app, allows patients to transmit real-time physiologic data and report symptoms to their cancer care team via a cloud-based clinician portal. Denise Johnstone, Executive Director of New Jersey Cancer Care (NJCC), praised the seamless onboarding process and responsiveness of the Veris team. NJCC has started using the platform with their initial group of patients and plans to expand its usage.

title: New Jersey Cancer Care launches remote patient monitoring
hco: NEW JERSEY SOCIETY OF ONCOLOGY MANAGERS
summary: New Jersey Cancer Care (NJCC) has initiated a remote patient monitoring (RPM) program using the Veris Cancer Care Platform. This platform allows cancer care teams to monitor patients' physiological and clinical data in real time and provide personalized care. The integration includes a cloud-based clinician portal and a patient smartphone app that enables patients to report symptoms and health information, and allows caregivers to track the patient's journey. Denise Johnstone, NJCC's executive director, noted that the first group of patients has been successfully onboarded and more patients are scheduled for enrollment. The NJCC can now bill for RPM services monthly.

title: Supporters Honored at 19th Annual Distinguished Alumni & Service Awards
summary: The University of South Alabama National Alumni Association celebrated its 19th annual Distinguished Alumni & Service Awards on March 14, 2024, at the MacQueen Alumni Center. Honorees included Travis Bedsole Jr., Dr. Jack DiPalma, Susan Bedsole, Alexis Atkins, Maxey Roberts, Chandra Brown Stewart, John McMillan, Dan Ollis, and Peter Lindquist. Katherine Alexis Atkins, a recipient of the Distinguished Service Award, was recognized for her significant contributions to the university. Despite being a single mother with a full-time job, Atkins completed her degree in human resources in 1997 and has since been a staunch advocate for the University of South Alabama. She has served as president of the National Alumni Association Board of Directors, vice chair of the University’s Board of Trustees, and has been actively involved in various university committees and community services. Her dedication has immensely benefited the university and its community.

title: Supporters Honored at 19th Annual Distinguished Alumni & Service Awards
summary: The University of South Alabama National Alumni Association honored notable alumni and supporters at the 19th annual Distinguished Alumni & Service Awards on March 14. The event recognized individuals for their leadership, service, and dedication to the University and their communities. Chandra Brown Stewart, who received the Distinguished Service Award, was highlighted for her nearly two-decade tenure as executive director of Lifelines Counseling Services in Mobile. Her leadership has transformed the organization into a vital non-profit serving tens of thousands annually with mental wellness services, crisis response, credit counseling, and social service referrals. Brown Stewart's expertise in program planning and community support has significantly contributed to the Gulf Coast region. Additionally, she has an extensive volunteer history and serves on the University of South Alabama Board of Trustees. The event celebrated the 50th year of the USA National Alumni Association and included videos showcasing each honoree's story.

title: Meet the 2023 Women Who Shape the State honorees
summary: The 2023 Women Who Shape the State honorees, recognized by This is Alabama, celebrate leadership, persistence, and fearlessness across various sectors in Alabama. The honorees include CEOs, civic leaders, educators, and entrepreneurs, all dedicated to improving their communities. A celebratory luncheon will be held on March 8 in Birmingham, featuring keynote speaker Col. Eries L.G. Mentzer. Among the honorees, Chandra Brown Stewart, Agency Director of Family Counseling Center of Mobile, emphasizes self-worth and the importance of rest, encouraging individuals to pursue their dreams without feeling the need to constantly achieve or overcome.

title: Match 2024: Make regulations easier for physicians
summary: Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, emphasizes the need for regulatory reforms to support independent primary care physicians. He advocates for the recognition of the importance of value-based care, the removal of prior authorization burdens, and the mitigation of issues caused by electronic health records. Furr's comments come in response to the record number of primary care positions offered in the 2024 Match, highlighting the critical role of easing regulations to ensure the success and well-being of primary care practitioners.

title: Congress Should Simplify Medicare's Vaccine Coverage
summary: Dr. Steven P. Furr, a family physician and president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, argues that Congress should simplify Medicare's vaccine coverage. He highlights that Medicare Part B currently covers only four vaccines (COVID-19, flu, pneumonia, and hepatitis B for at-risk patients), while other recommended vaccines like shingles and RSV are covered under Part D, which contracts with pharmacies. This split coverage creates barriers for patients, particularly seniors, who often struggle with fragmented care and additional logistical challenges. Dr. Furr emphasizes that allowing all ACIP-approved vaccines to be covered under Medicare Part B would enable primary care physicians to administer these vaccines directly, improving vaccination rates and fostering trust in the healthcare system. He calls on Congress to update the Medicare Part B statute to include all recommended adult vaccines, thereby eliminating confusion and barriers to access.

title: Doctors, hospitals denounce Medicare payment plans for 2024
summary: The Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) announced the 2024 payment schedules for doctors and outpatient services, sparking criticism from the medical community. The CMS approved a 3.4% reduction in the conversion factor for physician payments, which Jesse Ehrenfeld, president of the American Medical Association, described as financially destabilizing, especially with rising medical practice costs. Anders Gilberg from the Medical Group Management Association and Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, also criticized the cuts. Furr acknowledged improvements in primary care reimbursements but warned that the conversion factor cut could harm family physicians, emphasizing the need for long-term Medicare payment reform. Hospitals also criticized the 3.1% increase in outpatient payments as inadequate, with Stacey Hughes from the American Hospital Association highlighting the financial challenges hospitals face. Both doctors and hospitals plan to advocate for more support from Congress.

title: New Prior Auth Rule to Reduce Doctors' Burden, Groups Say
summary: A new federal rule, effective January 17, 2024, mandates health insurers to streamline and disclose more information about their prior authorization processes. This rule requires insurers in federal programs like Medicare Advantage and Medicaid to respond to expedited requests within 72 hours and other requests within 7 days. Insurers must also provide reasons for denials and publicly release data on denial and approval rates. Compliance deadlines are set for January 2026 and 2027. Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, praised the rule, highlighting how prior authorizations divert valuable time from patient care and contribute to physician shortages. The rule aims to reduce administrative burdens and improve patient care, a sentiment echoed by other medical professionals.

title: Biden admin Medicare rule speeds up health insurance authorizations
summary: The Biden administration has introduced a new federal rule to expedite health insurance authorizations, significantly reducing wait times for patients needing urgent medical services. Announced on Wednesday, the rule mandates insurers to respond within 72 hours for urgent care requests and one week for non-urgent ones. This aims to streamline the "prior authorization" process, which has been criticized for delaying necessary medical care. Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, praised the rule, noting it alleviates administrative burdens and reduces care delays. The rule, effective in 2026 for private Medicare, Medicaid, and Affordable Care Act plans, requires insurers to provide reasons for care denials and publicly report authorization figures. Additionally, by 2027, insurers must develop computer systems allowing doctors to access historical claims data. The health insurance industry initially had concerns about costs but acknowledged that electronic authorizations could improve care delivery.

title: Match 2024: An expert's advice for new family doctors
summary: Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, offers valuable advice for new family physicians preparing to start their practices. In an interview with Medical Economics, Furr discusses the record number of primary care positions available in the 2024 Match. He emphasizes the importance of primary care and provides insights into the current and future landscape of family and internal medicine. Furr's guidance aims to help new physicians navigate their early careers effectively, highlighting the significance of their roles in the healthcare system.

title: Match 2024: Independent voices in medicine
summary: More American physicians are choosing to work as employees instead of independent practitioners. Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, discusses this trend and emphasizes the importance of independent doctors' voices in the U.S. healthcare system. Furr's insights were shared with Medical Economics in light of the record number of primary care positions offered in the 2024 Match.

title: Match 2024: Lessons learned from COVID-19
summary: Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, discussed the lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic, focusing on self-care, personal well-being, and caring for other physicians and clinicians. These insights are considered potential long-term effects of the pandemic. Dr. Furr's observations were made in the context of the record number of primary care positions offered in the 2024 Match, highlighting the ongoing impact of COVID-19 on the medical profession.

title: Match 2024: Recruiting new doctors, and the best part of the job
summary: The 2024 Match emphasizes the importance of recruiting new doctors, starting as early as high school, to ensure a steady flow of future family physicians. Dr. Steven P. Furr, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, highlights the need for medical students to experience the diversity within family medicine. He shares his passion for the specialty, discussing its various aspects and the fulfillment it brings. Dr. Furr's insights are part of a broader conversation about the 2024 Match, which addresses current trends and future prospects in family and internal medicine.

title: Match 2024: Good news for primary care
summary: The 2024 Match, announced on March 15, 2024, revealed a significant increase in interest in family medicine. Dr. Steven P. Furr, MD, FAAFP, president of the American Academy of Family Physicians, highlighted this positive trend, indicating a promising future for family and internal medicine.

title: Primary care reaches record incoming class in 2024 Match
summary: The 2024 Match saw a record number of primary care positions offered, with a 92.9% fill rate, welcoming nearly 4,600 future doctors. Family medicine had 4,595 matches out of 5,231 slots, reflecting a bright future for the specialty, according to the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP). AAFP President Dr. Steven P. Furr highlighted the unique nature of family medicine, emphasizing the deep connections formed with patients and communities. He expressed pride in the students and graduates who chose family medicine, underscoring its essential role in the healthcare system. Despite a slight decrease in the overall primary care fill rate due to changes in pediatrics, the specialty remains strong. Emergency medicine saw a rebound with a 95.5% fill rate, while OB/GYN maintained a high interest with a 99.6% fill rate. The resilience of medical students, particularly those who began their studies during the COVID-19 pandemic, was also commended.

title: $460B spending bill averts shutdown, some physician pay cuts
summary: Congress passed a $460 billion bipartisan spending bill to prevent a partial government shutdown and reduce Medicare physician pay cuts. The bill, signed by President Joe Biden, funds government agencies through the 2024 fiscal year and delays Medicaid DSH reductions. It also reverses 1.68 percent of the scheduled 3.37 percent cuts to Physician Fee Schedule reimbursements. The American Medical Association and other healthcare groups have lobbied against these cuts, emphasizing their impact on rural and underserved areas. Dr. Steven P. Furr, President of the American Academy of Family Physicians, acknowledged the temporary relief but urged Congress for long-term Medicare payment reform to ensure stable healthcare access and support for family medicine residents.

title: Chairman of Alabama Medical Cannabis Commission resigns following months of licensing issues
summary: Dr. Steven H. Stokes resigned as chairman of the Alabama Medical Cannabis Commission after months of licensing issues. In his resignation letter, Stokes expressed disappointment but believed stepping down was in the best interest of Alabama citizens needing medical cannabis. He noted his departure could eliminate distractions hindering progress. The commission had paused business license proceedings due to "potential inconsistencies in the tabulation of scoring" and sought an independent review. Despite his resignation, Stokes remains confident in the commission's future and its mission to deliver medical cannabis to patients. The commission appreciated Stokes' contributions and expects him to continue influencing Alabama's medical cannabis program.

title: Stokes Gift $2 Million to Marine and Environmental Sciences
summary: Dr. Steven H. Stokes and his wife Angelia have donated $2 million to the University of South Alabama's School of Marine and Environmental Sciences. This significant contribution has led to the renaming of the school to the Angelia and Steven Stokes School of Marine and Environmental Sciences. Dr. Stokes, an alumnus of the university, has a long history of supporting the institution, with total contributions exceeding $6.8 million. Their funding has facilitated the establishment of the Environmental Resiliency Center and expanded research activities, resulting in numerous grant awards. The new donation will support a five-year growth plan, including new faculty hires, facility enhancements, and funding for graduate assistantships and the Gulf Scholars Program. Dr. Stokes' commitment has been instrumental in positioning the school as a leading environmental center on the Gulf Coast.

title: Alabama Medical Cannabis Commission chairman Dr. Steven Stokes…
summary: Dr. Steven H. Stokes, chairman of the Alabama Medical Cannabis Commission (AMCC), has resigned following a lawsuit questioning his eligibility to serve simultaneously on both the commission and the University of South Alabama board of trustees. Despite initially having no plans to resign, Stokes decided to step down to avoid delaying medical marijuana availability. His resignation was confirmed by an AMCC spokeswoman, who acknowledged his significant contributions as Chairman and Vice-Chair of Alabama’s Medical Cannabis Study Commission. The AMCC is set to re-award business licenses on August 10, after suspending previously awarded licenses due to inconsistencies in scoring data. The lawsuit argued that Stokes' dual roles violated the law prohibiting public officials from serving on the commission. Stokes' resignation is seen as a step towards ensuring a transparent and lawful application process for medical cannabis licenses in Alabama.

title: The Jewel in UVM’s Crown: Patty Prelock Shines in Role as Provost
summary: Patricia A. Prelock has served as provost and senior vice president at the University of Vermont (UVM) since 2019, contributing significantly to the university’s recent successes. A nationally recognized expert in autism spectrum disorders, Prelock has created environments that facilitate communication for individuals with disabilities. Her leadership has been pivotal in doubling UVM’s research funding and increasing student applications by 64%. Prelock also played a crucial role in establishing the Osher Center for Integrative Health at UVM. Previously, she was the dean of UVM’s College of Nursing and Health Sciences and has an extensive academic record, including over $24 million in grant funding and more than 200 publications. Her colleagues and university leaders praise her for her empathy, resilience, and collaborative skills, which have greatly benefited UVM’s academic and research environment.

title: Over 20 Students Receive Awards at CNHS Honors Ceremony
summary: The College of Nursing and Health Sciences (CNHS) held an awards ceremony on May 18 in Billings Hall to celebrate the achievements of over 20 graduating students. Dean Patricia A. Prelock opened the ceremony, encouraging students to continue being leaders in their fields. She emphasized their responsibility to lead, strive, and innovate due to their talents and intellectual curiosity. Awards were presented across all four academic departments for clinical, academic, and community service achievements. Notable awards included the F.W. Van Buskirk Awards in the Department of Medical Laboratory and Radiation Sciences, the “Spirit of Nursing Award” in the Department of Nursing, and the Eleanor M. Luse Graduate Student Award in the Department of Communication Sciences and Disorders. Dean Prelock's remarks highlighted the importance of leadership and the potential impact of the graduates in their respective fields.

title: 2018 Sara Stubblefield Advocacy Award
summary: The Epilepsy Foundation awarded the 2018 Sara Stubblefield Advocacy Award to Dr. Bettyjo Bouchey during the Public Policy Institute conference. Dr. Bouchey, a Board of Advisors member and State Advocacy Leader for the Epilepsy Foundation Indiana, has been a fervent advocate for the epilepsy community. Her advocacy began when her son was diagnosed with epilepsy in 2015. She has played a pivotal role in state legislative efforts, particularly in promoting access to medical cannabis for those with intractable epilepsy. Her dedication has significantly impacted individuals and families dealing with epilepsy in Indiana.

title: Cleveland Clinic taps Epic MyChart to drive clinical research engagement
summary: Cleveland Clinic is leveraging Epic MyChart to enhance patient engagement in clinical research. Dr. Lara Jehi, the chief research information officer, and Craig Martin, IT product director for population health, discussed the initiative. They aim to use the patient portal to effectively communicate research opportunities to patients, thereby increasing participation and engagement. This strategy highlights the potential of electronic health records (EHRs) in driving patient involvement in clinical studies.

title: Cleveland Clinic Gets Its Own IBM Quantum Processor For Advanced Biomedical Research
summary: Cleveland Clinic has installed a 127-qubit IBM Eagle quantum processor on its main campus to advance biomedical research. The processor, placed in a highly visible cafeteria, aims to inspire researchers and physicians to explore quantum computing applications. Dr. Lara Jehi, Cleveland Clinic's first Chief Research Information Officer, emphasized that quantum processing could overcome computational barriers in medical research. Jehi highlighted two main research areas: quantum chemistry for drug discovery and quantum machine learning (ML). Quantum chemistry projects include identifying protein targets and accelerating molecular docking predictions. Quantum ML projects aim to optimize physician scheduling, assemble large genomes, create personalized radiation therapy plans, and improve clinical trial efficiency. The Cleveland Clinic-IBM partnership, part of a 10-year Discovery Accelerator initiative, seeks to apply quantum processing to real-world problems and make it accessible to researchers without requiring deep technical knowledge.

title: EDAC and TBM Diagnosing and Treating Airway Collapse Diseases
summary: Dr. Tom Gildea, section head of Interventional Pulmonary and Bronchoscopy at Cleveland Clinic, discusses Excessive Dynamic Airways Collapse (EDAC) and Tracheobronchomalacia (TBM) in a podcast episode. He explains the differences between EDAC and TBM, noting that EDAC involves hypermobility or collapsing segments of the posterior airway wall, while TBM is due to the failure of tracheal cartilages. Dr. Gildea highlights the use of dynamic CT scans and bronchoscopies for diagnosis and mentions treatment options such as CPAP and custom 3D stents. He also emphasizes the importance of considering related conditions like asthma, COPD, and obesity in managing these airway collapse diseases.

title: Tracheobronchomalacia
summary: Tracheobronchomalacia (TBM) occurs when the main airway and airways leading to the lungs collapse more than normal, impairing breathing. In a podcast episode of Respiratory Inspirations, Dr. Thomas Gildea discusses TBM and excessive dynamic airway collapse (EDAC). He explains the function of large airways, what happens when they malfunction, how he diagnoses TBM/EDAC, and treatment options. Gildea highlights the role of bronchoscopy in diagnosis and the use of CPAP machines and surgical interventions for treatment. He also mentions the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and the TBM Foundation as a resource for patients.

title: The oncogenic fusion protein TAZ::CAMTA1 promotes genomic instability and senescence through hypertranscription ...
summary: The oncogenic fusion protein TAZ::CAMTA1, present in over 90% of Epithelioid Hemangioendothelioma (EHE) cases, induces hypertranscription in endothelial cells, leading to significant DNA damage and S phase arrest. This process results in impaired homologous recombination, evidenced by reduced BRCA1 and RAD51 foci formation, causing cells to enter senescence. The study developed a model system to induce TAZ::CAMTA1 expression in primary endothelial cells, revealing the fusion protein's role in promoting genomic instability and offering insights into potential therapeutic options. Brian Rubin contributed to this research, enhancing understanding of TAZ::CAMTA1's oncogenic mechanisms.

title: Cleveland Clinic Children's Ranks Among the Nation's Best Children's Hospitals by U.S. News & World Report
summary: Cleveland Clinic Children’s has been recognized as one of the nation’s top pediatric hospitals by U.S. News & World Report’s 2023-24 “Best Children’s Hospitals” rankings, with all ten of its pediatric specialties ranked among the top 50. Notably, cardiology and heart surgery ranked 10th, while gastroenterology, neonatology, and urology were in the top 20. This marks the 15th consecutive year of such recognition. Regionally, it tied for third place in both the Midwest and Ohio. The hospital has been at the forefront of pediatric clinical innovation and research, including studies on sickle cell disease and MIS-C, and advancements in neonatal care. Robert Wyllie, M.D., chair of Cleveland Clinic Children’s, stated that these rankings reflect the dedication of their caregivers. The hospital supports 389 beds and over 400 specialists, providing comprehensive pediatric care across more than 50 outpatient sites.

title: Cleveland Clinic Children’s is ranked in nation’s top children’s hospitals
summary: Cleveland Clinic Children’s has been ranked among the nation’s top 50 pediatric hospitals by U.S. News & World Report for the 15th consecutive year. In the 2023-24 rankings, the hospital's cardiology and heart surgery specialty ranked in the top 10 nationally, while gastroenterology and gastrointestinal surgery, neonatology, and urology ranked in the top 20. Dr. Robert Wyllie, chair of Cleveland Clinic Children’s, attributed the rankings to the dedication of their caregivers in providing high-quality patient care, research, education, and advocacy. Cleveland Clinic Children’s tied for third best pediatric hospital in Ohio and the Midwest overall. Dr. Tom Mihaljevic, CEO and President of Cleveland Clinic, praised the pediatric specialists for their excellent patient outcomes.

title: Caring for Caregivers: How Healthcare Organizations Can Fully Support the Wellness and Wellbeing of Nurses
summary: The podcast "Caring for Caregivers: How Healthcare Organizations Can Fully Support the Wellness and Wellbeing of Nurses" discusses the evolving healthcare workplace and the importance of supporting caregivers. Chief Caregiver Officer Kelly Hancock emphasizes the need for programs that support nurses from their first day to retirement. Hancock highlights Cleveland Clinic's unique role in creating the Chief Caregiver Officer position to ensure equity and support for nearly 80,000 caregivers. The office focuses on various aspects like workforce strategy, diversity, equity, inclusion, and health and wellbeing. Hancock also discusses the importance of engagement, financial health, and flexible work arrangements. She advises nurses to seek organizations that align with their values and offer growth opportunities.

title: Masking becomes optional at Cleveland Clinic starting April 20
summary: Starting April 20, masking will become optional at all Cleveland Clinic facilities for patients, visitors, and caregivers. This policy change is attributed to improving respiratory virus numbers. Leslie Jurecko, the chief safety, quality, and patient experience officer at the Cleveland Clinic, emphasized that while masks are no longer mandatory, individuals can still choose to wear them, and staff will accommodate patients' requests for mask-wearing. Masks will remain required in certain situations, such as when dealing with immunocompromised patients. Jurecko highlighted that this change is a positive step for communication and a relief for caregivers. However, mandatory masking may return in the fall due to potential increases in respiratory viruses. The decision was based on national and global virus data, and similar policies are being adopted by other healthcare organizations.

title: Cleveland Clinic Named to Honor Roll of US News & World Report's 2023-24 Best Hospital Rankings
summary: Cleveland Clinic has been named to the Honor Roll of US News & World Report’s 2023-24 Best Hospital Rankings, recognized as the No. 1 hospital for cardiology, heart, and vascular surgery for the 29th consecutive year, and as the top hospital in Ohio. This year, US News did not rank Honor Roll hospitals numerically, acknowledging that all meet the highest quality standards. Leslie Jurecko, M.D., Cleveland Clinic’s Chief Safety, Quality, and Experience Officer, emphasized the importance of using various sources to identify quality care and reiterated the hospital's commitment to providing high-quality, safe, patient-centered care, supporting research and clinical innovation, and serving communities. Cleveland Clinic is known for its transparency in healthcare, reporting outcomes and quality metrics across specialties. The nonprofit academic medical center, founded in 1921, integrates clinical care with research and education and has pioneered numerous medical breakthroughs. It operates a 6,690-bed health system with locations worldwide.

title: Maria Shriver, Cleveland Clinic launch new Women’s Comprehensive Health and Research Center
summary: Maria Shriver and the Cleveland Clinic have launched a new Women’s Comprehensive Health and Research Center. Shriver, serving as chief visionary and strategic advisor, collaborated with Cleveland Clinic’s chief of staff, Dr. Beri Ridgeway, to create the center. The initiative aims to help women navigate their healthcare with a focus on access, connectivity, education, research, and innovation. The center will streamline appointment processes, enhance outreach programs, and prioritize health equity. It will offer specialty care in areas like behavioral health, breast health, and menopause, among others. Ridgeway emphasized the importance of this initiative, recalling her first meeting with Shriver and their shared experiences regarding the lack of quality healthcare for women. The center will connect women with patient navigators and aims to expand its services beyond Ohio and Michigan in the future.

title: Cleveland Clinic Selected for Nationwide Initiative to Translate Research to Patient Care
summary: Cleveland Clinic has been selected by the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) for a nationwide initiative aimed at improving the translation of research findings into clinical practice. The initiative, which includes 42 U.S. healthcare systems, seeks to reduce the estimated 17-year lag in implementing new treatments. PCORI has committed up to $50 million for this effort, with initial funding of up to $500,000 per health system to build capacity for implementation projects. Cleveland Clinic's Healthcare Delivery and Implementation Science Center, launched in 2019, plays a pivotal role in this initiative. Dr. Anita Misra-Hebert and Dr. Beri Ridgeway, Cleveland Clinic’s Chief of Staff, co-lead programs under this initiative, emphasizing the importance of translating research into real-world practice to expedite scientific discoveries' adoption and implementation.

title: Cleveland Clinic Launches New Women's Comprehensive Health and Research Center
summary: Cleveland Clinic has launched the Women’s Comprehensive Health and Research Center to address the unique health needs of women during midlife and beyond. The center focuses on access, connectivity, education, and research to empower women in their health journeys. Maria Shriver, founder of The Women’s Alzheimer’s Movement Prevention and Research Center, will serve as chief visionary and strategic advisor. The center offers specialized care in areas such as behavioral health, breast health, cardiovascular care, and more. Beri Ridgeway, M.D., Chief of Staff at Cleveland Clinic, emphasized the importance of a holistic approach to women's health, including menopausal, hormonal, reproductive, mental health, chronic conditions, and preventive care. The center aims to ensure all women can access the care they need and make informed health decisions.

title: Cleveland Clinic Expands Access to High-Quality Care in Middleburg Heights Community
summary: Cleveland Clinic has inaugurated its new Middleburg Heights Family Health Center with a ribbon-cutting ceremony and community event. The 93,000-square-foot facility, located at 17840 Bagley Rd., is one of the clinic’s largest family health centers and marks its first venture of this size in the area. The center employs nearly 200 staff members and offers a range of medical services, including specialty and primary care, radiology, urgent care, and Cleveland Clinic’s first drive-through pharmacy. Donald A. Malone Jr., M.D., executive vice president of Cleveland Clinic’s Northeast Ohio Market, expressed enthusiasm for serving the community and acknowledged the collaboration with Middleburg Heights and Premier Development Partners in redeveloping the site. The facility aims to provide advanced care close to patients' homes and includes specialized services like pulmonary care, neurology, orthopedics, and maternal fetal medicine.

title: Cleveland Clinic Mentor Hospital Opens for Patient Care
summary: Cleveland Clinic Mentor Hospital, the first hospital in Mentor, Ohio, and Cleveland Clinic's first in Lake County, opened to patients today. This new facility aims to provide a broad range of services for residents, including inpatient care, outpatient services, and the city's first 24-hour Emergency Department. The hospital features 34 inpatient/observation rooms, 23 outpatient rooms, and various specialized care units. Donald A. Malone Jr., M.D., president of Cleveland Clinic Ohio Hospitals and Family Health Centers, emphasized the hospital's design based on community needs, offering a wide scope of services supported by the Cleveland Clinic health system. The facility also incorporates sustainable features like on-site solar energy production and electric vehicle charging capabilities. Managed by Cleveland Clinic Hillcrest Hospital, Mentor Hospital is designed to be versatile and expandable to meet future community needs.

title: Cleveland Clinic opens its first hospital in Lake County
summary: Cleveland Clinic has opened its first hospital in Lake County, located in Mentor, Ohio, at 8300 Norton Pkwy. This new facility, which started patient care on July 11, 2023, is the first new hospital in northeast Ohio since 2016. The Mentor Hospital aims to provide shorter hospital stays with follow-up care at home and includes services like general surgery, orthopaedics, and primary care. It also features Mentor's first 24-hour emergency department. Dr. Donald A. Malone Jr., president of Cleveland Clinic Ohio Hospitals and Family Health Centers, emphasized that the hospital will offer a broad scope of services and will be supported by the entire Cleveland Clinic health system. This new hospital is designed to meet the community's needs and has the potential for future expansion.

title: Blue Owl reports 6% increase in AUM for quarter, 20% for year
summary: Blue Owl Capital reported a 6% increase in assets under management (AUM) for the fourth quarter, reaching $165.7 billion as of Dec. 31, and a 20% increase for the year. Co-CEO Marc S. Lipschultz highlighted the firm's focus on permanent capital and less volatile earnings. Blue Owl acquired Cowen Healthcare Investments, adding $1 billion in life science assets. Lipschultz noted the firm's significant activity in the healthcare sector, with $11 billion in loans and investments. The firm is also expanding in alternative credit and managing capital for insurance companies. Blue Owl's real estate AUM grew to $26.9 billion, and it closed its fifth general partner minority stakes fund at $12.9 billion, with plans to close a sixth fund in the coming years. Additionally, Blue Owl formed a joint venture with Lunate to focus on minority stakes in midsize private capital firms.

title: Cardinal Health CFO talks Specialty Networks acquisition, AI
summary: Cardinal Health CFO Aaron Alt discussed the company's fiscal second-quarter earnings, which surpassed Wall Street expectations with $57.45 billion in revenue. Despite the positive earnings, shares of Cardinal Health fell. The company recently acquired Specialty Networks for $1.2 billion in cash. Alt highlighted the strategic benefits of this acquisition, emphasizing the integration of AI to enhance business operations and customer service. He noted that AI could drive significant improvements in practice enhancement and overall portfolio performance. Alt also mentioned the company's strong performance in the pharma distribution business, driven by generics and branded prescription demand. He outlined the company's investment strategies, including $500 million in capital expenditures for fiscal year 2024, focusing on specialty pharmaceuticals and distribution networks. Alt expressed optimism about the future impact of AI and the acquisition on Cardinal Health's long-term growth.

title: Cryo-EM structure of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 complex reveals the molecular mechanism of scaffolding functions
summary: The study reveals the cryo-EM structure of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 (MRN) complex, essential for DNA double-strand break repair. The MRN complex from Chaetomium thermophilum is shown as a 2:2:1 complex with a single Nbs1 peptide wrapping around the autoinhibited Mre11 nuclease dimer. It has two DNA-binding modes: ATP-dependent for DNA ends and ATP-independent via Mre11’s C terminus. MRN’s structure includes two 60-nm-long coiled-coil domains forming a linear rod, with apices assembled by zinc-hook motifs that can dimerize, forming 120-nm MRN-MRN structures. Aaron Alt contributed to this research, helping to elucidate MRN’s architecture and its dual catalytic and scaffolding roles.

title: Business of Pride: Main Line health care exec amplifying LGBTQ+ voices at work, play and alma mater Penn ...
summary: Emily Gallo, a senior vice president at Cardinal Health, has significantly contributed to amplifying LGBTQ+ voices both within her company and the broader community. Joining Cardinal Health nearly a decade ago, she became deeply involved with the company's LGBTQ+ employee resource group, Proud, serving as co-chair and leading initiatives that increased membership and allyship. Gallo spearheaded a rebranding effort and launched campaigns to enhance the visibility and support for LGBTQ+ employees, including a major ally initiative and improving systems for gender identification. Outside of work, Gallo is active in the Penn Leadership Q at her alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, working to elevate LGBTQ+ representation in university leadership. Her efforts extend to creating inclusive environments in everyday settings, such as her participation in the Philadelphia Falcons soccer team and engaging in community activities that foster acceptance and visibility for LGBTQ+ individuals.

title: Tech Driven Healthcare Leadership
summary: In a podcast episode, Michelle Greene, EVP and Chief Information Officer at Cardinal Health, discusses the integration of healthcare and technology with Pari Natarajan, CEO of Zinnov. Greene emphasizes the importance of empathy in leadership and the critical role of data in transforming healthcare distribution. She shares her journey from data analyst to CIO, highlighting her leadership philosophy centered on kindness, collaboration, and servant leadership. Greene explains how Generative AI is creating new opportunities for technology talent and the significance of data-driven decision-making in healthcare. She underscores the need for bridging the gap between technology, business, and board members, fostering innovation, and developing talent. Greene's approach aims to enhance patient outcomes through efficient and transparent healthcare processes.

title: Retired nurse reaches Tampa Bay's Black community through 'The Color of Wellness'
summary: Michelle Greene Rhodes, a retired nurse, launched "The Color of Wellness" magazine to address the lack of representation of Black people in medical publications and to improve health outcomes in the Black community. Inspired by her mother's encouragement and driven by her observations over 20 years in the field, Greene Rhodes saw a need for more visibility and trust in healthcare for communities of color. The magazine was released at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic and aims to empower Black nurses and elevate their roles in healthcare. The initiative was supported by the Minority Empowerment Program (MEP) of the Tampa Bay Chamber, which helps Black and Hispanic-owned businesses integrate into the community.

title: Wrexham Maelor Hospital apologises for A&E delays and shortage of inpatient beds
summary: Wrexham Maelor Hospital has apologized for significant delays in its A&E department and a shortage of inpatient beds due to increased demand. Patients experienced long waits, with some ambulances queued outside the hospital. Dr. Michelle Greene, Director of the East Integrated Health Community at Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, acknowledged the challenges and confirmed that the hospital is reviewing all options to reduce delays. She emphasized the difficulties in discharging patients to suitable accommodations, which affects the entire hospital system. Dr. Greene urged the public to use the Emergency Department only for life-threatening conditions and to seek alternative NHS services when appropriate.

title: Opinion: Businesses must be part of Ohio's mental health solution
summary: Mental health issues are increasing globally and in Ohio, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Ohio business leaders, including Pat Tiberi and Jason Hollar, emphasize the importance of businesses in addressing mental health. A significant discussion involving Ohio CEOs, Gov. Mike DeWine, and various health leaders highlighted the impact of mental health on productivity and the need for employer support. The roundtable underscored the collective effort required to destigmatize mental health and improve resources. Gov. DeWine's budget focuses on reducing stigma, expanding mental health resources, and addressing children's mental health needs. Jason Hollar, CEO of Cardinal Health, has played a role in these efforts, leveraging his extensive experience and commitment to community initiatives. The Ohio business community supports the governor's mental health provisions, recognizing the importance of a robust mental health care system for employees, children, and the broader community.

title: Cardinal Health says demand for weight loss drugs may level off but remain strong
summary: Cardinal Health has reported strong fourth-quarter results, driven by high demand for GLP-1 weight loss drugs. The pharmaceuticals unit saw a 15% revenue increase, reaching $49.7 billion. CEO Jason Hollar emphasized the importance of these drugs to customers and the company. Despite the revenue boost, these branded drugs do not significantly contribute to profits. Cardinal Health expects a 10% to 12% revenue growth for the next fiscal year, with profits growing 4% to 6%, consistent with previous forecasts. The company’s total revenues for the fourth quarter were $53.5 billion, surpassing Wall Street expectations.

title: Making DEI a Corporate Priority
summary: Cardinal Health prioritizes diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in its corporate strategy, setting specific goals to enhance workforce diversity by 2030. Rob Schlissberg, president of Cardinal Health at-Home Solutions, emphasizes that DEI is essential for business success, fostering innovation and smarter decision-making. Schlissberg, who is part of the Women’s Impact Network ERG steering committee, highlights that DEI efforts at Cardinal Health are driven by a DEI steering council and supported by various employee resource groups. The company also implements pay transparency, equity guidelines, and differentiated training programs to promote leadership diversity. Additionally, Cardinal Health has removed college degree requirements for most positions to focus on individual strengths. Schlissberg advises homecare companies to diversify their teams to better serve customers and ensure equitable access to care, particularly for underrepresented populations. He underscores the importance of collective efforts to achieve these goals and the positive impact of engaging with diverse suppliers.

title: Cardinal Health to build at-Home Solutions distribution center in South Carolina
summary: Cardinal Health announced plans to build a new distribution center in Greenville, South Carolina, to support its at-Home Solutions business. This facility, the largest built by at-Home Solutions to date, will cover approximately 350,000 square feet and feature advanced automation and robotics. Rob Schlissberg, president of at-Home Solutions, highlighted the significance of this new space, noting it as a testament to the business's growth. The facility will be the 11th distribution center nationwide for at-Home Solutions, creating up to 200 jobs and shipping around 8,000 packages daily to patient homes. The center will utilize AutoStore technology by Swisslog, enhancing inventory accuracy and employee productivity. Construction is set to begin this summer, with full operations expected within 18 to 24 months.

title: Central Ohio Workforce Summit: Addressing workforce challenges in 2023 and beyond - Columbus Business First
summary: The "Central Ohio Workforce Summit: Addressing workforce challenges in 2023 and beyond," presented by Dawson and Columbus Business First, brought together regional leaders to discuss workforce issues and solutions. Ola Snow, chief human resources officer at Cardinal Health, delivered the keynote address, emphasizing employee engagement, culture, and a commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion (DEI), and mental health as keys to business success. The summit also featured a panel discussion with leaders like Dave Cofer, Stephanie Hightower, Nick Jones, and Doug McCollough, who addressed the skills gap, talent development, and the importance of creating an inclusive workplace culture to retain diverse employees.

title: Cardinal Health names Kerry Christopher VP, comms, for pharma
summary: Cardinal Health has promoted Kerry Christopher to VP of communications for its pharmaceutical segment and Erich Timmerman to VP of external affairs and enterprise marketing. These promotions were part of a strategic succession-planning process led by Chief Human Resources Officer Ola Snow. Christopher, who previously served as VP of internal communications, will now oversee communications for the pharmaceutical segment, taking over from Victor Scott, who has been promoted to SVP of communications and enterprise marketing. Timmerman, who joined Cardinal Health in 2020, previously served as senior director of external affairs and enterprise marketing. Both Christopher and Timmerman will continue to report to Scott.

title: Cardinal Health says contracts with UnitedHealth's OptumRx will not be renewed
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with UnitedHealth Group's OptumRx unit will not be renewed after their expiration at the end of June. The company aims to mitigate the impact of losing these contracts through new customer acquisitions and growth in its specialty pharmacy business. Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Cardinal Health's pharmaceutical and specialty solutions division, expressed optimism about future opportunities, highlighting the onboarding of new customers and the integration of Specialty Networks in fiscal 2025 as key strategies. Cardinal Health declined to provide further comments on the OptumRx contracts. OptumRx functions as a pharmacy benefit manager, negotiating prescription drug prices between insurers and drugmakers.

title: Cardinal Health acquiring Specialty Networks for $1.2B
summary: Cardinal Health has announced a $1.2 billion acquisition of Specialty Networks to enhance its specialty therapeutic areas and provider offerings. Specialty Networks, which serves 11,500 providers in 1,200 independent practices, offers group purchasing, population health management, patient engagement, workflow automation, and clinical research. A key asset in the acquisition is Specialty Networks' PPS Analytics platform, which uses real-world data and AI for actionable insights, complementing Cardinal Health's existing capabilities. Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Cardinal Health Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions, highlighted that integrating Specialty Networks' services and technology with Cardinal Health’s distribution partnerships will enhance value for specialty group purchasing organization members and positively impact patients. The acquisition is expected to be accretive to Cardinal Health’s earnings within 12 months post-close, pending regulatory approval. Specialty Networks' CEO, Shailendra Sharma, will remain to lead his team within Cardinal Health.

title: Cardinal Health to create 100 jobs, add a fourth distribution center in central Ohio
summary: Cardinal Health is set to build a new 350,000-square-foot distribution center in the Rickenbacker Global Logistics Park in central Ohio, creating approximately 100 jobs. This will be the company's fourth distribution facility in the region, supplementing its corporate headquarters in Dublin. The new center, expected to open in summer 2025, aims to enhance the distribution of over-the-counter consumer health products. Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions at Cardinal Health, highlighted the significant growth in demand for consumer health products over the past five years. She emphasized that the new Consumer Health Logistics Center will meet customer needs by providing affordable, reliable, and comprehensive options for over-the-counter medications, treatments, and diagnostic solutions.

title: Transaction Data Systems Announces Closing of Merger with Outcomes™
summary: Transaction Data Systems (TDS) has completed its merger with Outcomes™, expanding clinical opportunities for patient engagement across a combined network of 48,000 pharmacy locations. The merger integrates patient engagement, clinical, and pharmacy workflow solutions, creating the largest network of retail, chain, and grocery pharmacies in the U.S. TDS will rebrand as Outcomes by the end of the year. Jude Dieterman will remain CEO, and Brent Stutz will become President. Cardinal Health will hold a minority stake, and Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Cardinal Health's pharmaceutical segment, will join the board of directors. Weitzman emphasized the merger's potential to enhance pharmacy care and diversify revenue streams. The combined company aims to improve operational efficiency and health outcomes through its integrated capabilities.

title: Cardinal Health's 'Outcomes' Business Merges With Pharmacy Tech Firm TDS
summary: Cardinal Health is merging its Outcomes business with pharmacy tech firm Transaction Data Systems (TDS). This merger will grant Cardinal Health a minority stake in the new entity. Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Cardinal Health’s pharmaceutical segment, will join the TDS board of directors. The combined entity aims to offer a comprehensive suite of pharmacy workflow software, patient engagement, and clinical solutions, benefiting patients, pharmacies, payers, and pharmaceutical companies. This merger will integrate Outcomes' patient engagement and clinical care solutions with TDS' pharmacy management systems and patient communication applications, enhancing pharmacists' ability to participate in clinical interventions and improving access for payors and pharmaceutical companies. This deal aligns with consumer demand for a unified healthcare platform, as identified in a PYMNTS/Lynx study, which highlights that 58% of consumers believe a unified digital platform would enhance their healthcare management convenience.

title: Cardinal Health Executives Visit Capitol Hill, Engage With Members Of Congress On Key Legislative Priorities
summary: Cardinal Health executives, including Debbie Weitzman, CEO of the Pharmaceutical Segment, and Jessica Mayer, chief legal and compliance officer, visited Capitol Hill to engage with U.S. Congress members on legislative priorities. They met with several lawmakers, such as Congresswoman Nanette Barragán and Congressman Troy Balderson, to discuss issues critical to Cardinal Health and its customers, emphasizing the wholesaler's role and the need for permanent flexibilities post-Public Health Emergency. Additionally, they attended a PAC reception for Congressman Mike Carey and visited the Healthcare Distribution Alliance's new Washington office.

title: Cardinal Health Reaffirms Fiscal 2024 non-GAAP EPS Guidance and Long-term Targets Amidst Nonrenewal of ...
summary: Cardinal Health announced that its pharmaceutical distribution contracts with OptumRx will not be renewed after June 2024. Despite this, the company reaffirmed its fiscal 2024 non-GAAP EPS guidance of $7.20 to $7.35 and long-term profit targets for its Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions segments. Cardinal Health anticipates growth in fiscal 2025 through new customer acquisitions and specialty growth, even though OptumRx accounted for 16% of its 2023 revenue. CEO Jason Hollar expressed confidence in the company's resilience and strategy. Debbie Weitzman, CEO of Pharmaceutical and Specialty Solutions, highlighted the company's focus on new market opportunities and integration of Specialty Networks in fiscal 2025. Cardinal Health expects to generate an average adjusted free cash flow of $2B from fiscal 2024 to 2026, with lower-than-average flow in fiscal 2025 due to the OptumRx contract's impact.

title: Baptist C-suite retirement Paul DePriest, Bill Griffin, David Elliott
summary: Baptist Memorial Health Care's C-suite is undergoing significant changes with the retirement of three key leaders. Dr. Paul DePriest, COO/EVP, and Bill Griffin, CFO/EVP, retired on September 30, while David Elliott, VP and CEO of Baptist Health Services Group, will retire on October 31. Chris Anderson, previously CEO of Jackson-based Mississippi Baptist Health System, assumed the COO role on October 1. Kimberly Young, currently VP of finance operations, will become CFO on November 1. Ron Wachsman, who has been VP of revenue cycle since joining Baptist in 2018, will join the C-suite as Chief Revenue Officer on November 1, overseeing managed care operations, including BHSG.

title: CHEST President shares inside look at priorities, plans for 2023
summary: At the CHEST 2022 Opening Session, CHEST President Doreen J. Addrizzo-Harris, MD, FCCP, outlined her priorities for 2023, reflecting on her leadership role during the pandemic. In March 2020, she managed ICU staffing at NYU Langone Health’s Bellevue Hospital Center and coordinated volunteer physicians, many of whom were CHEST members. Dr. Addrizzo-Harris praised the dedication of CHEST’s leadership and staff and aims to build on this spirit during her presidency. Her plans include enhancing collaboration with sister societies in the U.S., advancing international outreach, and supporting diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives. Additionally, she intends to bolster clinical research grants, expand patient education and advocacy, and support programs like the First 5 Minutes™ and the Harold Amos scholarship program to train future leaders.

title: CHEST 2023 Master Classes offer advanced learning from big names in chest medicine
summary: CHEST 2023 Master Classes, held from October 7-13 in Hawai’i, offer advanced learning in chest medicine through intensive case-based discussions and interactive sessions. These classes, replacing previous postgraduate courses, are available to both registrants and nonregistrants of CHEST 2023. The sessions are designed for seasoned providers seeking deeper-dive learning and cover complex topics not easily addressed by guidelines. Kevin M. Chan, MD, FCCP, is among the distinguished faculty contributing to the "2023 Pulmonary Literature Review and Complex Case Presentations" course. Dr. Amy E. Morris emphasizes the value of these interactive classes for personal engagement with global providers and master clinicians.

title: Barbara Lee Bass, MD, Honored by Mayor Muriel Bowser at Annual Washington Women of Excellence Awards
summary: Barbara Lee Bass, MD, was honored by Washington, D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser at the Annual Washington Women of Excellence Awards on March 28, 2024. Bass, the dean of George Washington University (GW) School of Medicine and Health Sciences (SMHS), professor of surgery, vice president for health affairs, and CEO of The GW Medical Faculty Associates, was recognized for her significant contributions. She was the first woman to serve as dean of the medical school at GW and the first to hold the titles of dean, vice president for health affairs, and CEO simultaneously. Bass played a crucial role in negotiating a new affiliation agreement, planning Cedar Hill Regional Medical Center, and leading GW's COVID-19 emergency response. Under her leadership, GW SMHS emerged as a premier integrated health system and academic medical enterprise.

title: A New Approach to Treatment and Prevention is on the Menu at SEVA Teaching Kitchen Grand Opening
summary: The George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences (SMHS) inaugurated the SEVA Teaching Kitchen, a new facility for its Culinary Medicine Program, funded by Seema Kakar, MD, and her husband, Sonny. This initiative aims to educate medical students and the community on the role of nutrition in health. Barbara L. Bass, MD, emphasized the importance of this program in preparing future healthcare providers to understand the impact of food on health. The kitchen offers hands-on cooking classes to teach basic cooking skills, nutrition, and grocery shopping. The program seeks to address root causes of diseases through better dietary practices, promoting a holistic approach to medicine.

title: GW Academic Medical Community Takes a Bow at the Bicentennial Excellence Awards | GW Today | The George ...
summary: The George Washington University Academic Medical Enterprise celebrated its Bicentennial Excellence Awards, recognizing faculty and staff for their achievements in education, service, research, and community engagement. Barbara L. Bass, Dean of SMHS and CEO of The GW Medical Faculty Associates, highlighted the institution's two-century legacy of clinical care, education, and scientific discovery. Bass introduced a video emphasizing the school's mission and strategic pillars. She also presented staff awards to ten exemplary members and acknowledged faculty achievements, including the Distinguished Teacher Awards, Distinguished Service Award, and Diversity and Inclusion Award. Additionally, research excellence was honored with awards such as the Elaine H. Snyder Cancer Research Award and the Distinguished Researcher Award. The event concluded with the Pillars of Excellence Awards, recognizing 25 members for their contributions to the institution's core missions.

title: GW School of Medicine and Health Sciences Installs Three Prominent Members of the Academic Medical Enterprise ...
summary: The George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences recently honored three distinguished academic medical leaders with endowed positions. Robert Sterling was named the Dr. John P. Adams Research Professor in Orthopedic Surgery, Dominic Raj was appointed as the Bert B. Brooks Chair in the Medical School, and David Belyea became the inaugural Daniel P. Shepard, M.D., and Dennis D. Shepard, M.D., Professor in Ophthalmology. Barbara L. Bass, professor of surgery and CEO of the GW Medical Faculty Associates, emphasized the significant contributions of these leaders to the university's academic clinical enterprise, highlighting their inspiration to faculty, students, residents, and patients.

title: CancerCare® Announces Appointment of Christine Verini to CEO
summary: CancerCare® has appointed Christine Verini as its new CEO, effective December 1, following the retirement of Patricia J. Goldsmith. Verini, who has over twenty years of oncology expertise, has been with CancerCare since 2015, serving as Executive Vice President/Chief Operating Officer. During her tenure, she has expanded the organization's programs and services and strengthened collaborations and partnerships. Previously, she held leadership roles in the healthcare sector, including Vice President of Corporate Communications and Advocacy at Eisai. Verini is recognized for her contributions to the cancer community and her dedication to advocating for those affected by cancer.

title: EISAI AND PATIENT ADVOCACY PARTNERS LAUNCH MADE OF MORE -- AN EDUCATION INITIATIVE TO ...
summary: Eisai Inc. and several patient advocacy groups have launched "Made of More," an educational initiative focused on head and neck cancer. This initiative aims to unite individuals affected by the disease, emphasizing that they are more than their diagnosis. The campaign features personal stories from survivors and caregivers, highlighting their experiences and providing resources for support and community. Christine Verini, Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Cancer Care, emphasized the importance of the initiative in providing support and resources to help patients navigate the challenges of living with head and neck cancer. The website MadeOfMore.com offers information on the disease, risk factors, symptoms, and resources for patients and caregivers. The initiative seeks to raise awareness and provide a sense of connection and support for those impacted by head and neck cancer.

title: An atlas of healthy and injured cell states and niches in the human kidney
summary: Researchers have created a detailed cellular atlas of the human kidney, examining both healthy and diseased states using advanced single-cell and single-nucleus assays, analyzing over 400,000 cells. This study identified 51 main cell types, including rare and novel populations, and 28 cellular states affected by kidney injury. The atlas integrates transcriptomic, epigenomic, and spatial imaging data, revealing complex cellular interactions and molecular profiles across different kidney regions. Sylvia Rosas contributed to this research, which aims to enhance understanding of kidney disease mechanisms and aid in the development of targeted treatments.

title: Organ transplant system overhaul: What it means and who will benefit
summary: The U.S. organ transplant system, managed by the nonprofit United Network for Organ Sharing (UNOS) for nearly 40 years, is undergoing a significant overhaul due to inefficiencies and disparities, particularly affecting people of color. The Biden administration announced plans to modernize the system, including updating the IT infrastructure and increasing competition by involving more organizations. Critics argue that while these reforms are a step forward, more concrete measures are needed to improve organ availability and delivery. Dr. Sylvia Rosas, board president of the National Kidney Foundation, emphasized the urgency of these reforms, noting the current system's failure to adequately serve patients of color and the need for increased transparency and efficiency in organ allocation.

title: National Kidney Foundation Honors Dr. Delgado with Prestigious Garabed Eknoyan Award
summary: Dr. Cynthia Delgado, a nephrologist and health equity expert, received the National Kidney Foundation's Garabed Eknoyan Award for her significant contributions to kidney care, particularly in removing race as a factor in diagnosing chronic kidney disease. She will be honored at the NKF's 2023 Spring Clinical Meetings. Dr. Delgado, a Professor of Medicine at the San Francisco Veterans Affairs Healthcare System and the University of California, San Francisco, serves as the Associate Chief of Nephrology and Director of the Dialysis Program. She also chairs the Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Committee for the American Society of Nephrology and co-chaired the NKF-ASN Task Force on Reassessing the Inclusion of Race in Diagnosing Kidney Disease. NKF President Sylvia Rosas praised Dr. Delgado's groundbreaking work and its impact on achieving healthcare equity.

title: Mom, 41, has legs amputated after kidney stone turns almost deadly: 'Life over limb'
summary: Lucinda Mullins, a 41-year-old mother from Kentucky, experienced a life-threatening ordeal after a kidney stone led to severe sepsis. Initially diagnosed with kidney stones in both kidneys, she underwent preventative surgery. After the second surgery, she developed a high fever and severe symptoms, leading to septic shock and multiple organ failure. Doctors had to amputate her legs and will also amputate her arms to save her life. Dr. Sylvia Rosas, a nephrologist and president of the National Kidney Foundation, noted that such severe complications from kidney stones are rare. Despite the devastating outcome, Mullins remains positive, grateful to be alive, and is preparing for a new life with prosthetics. Friends have set up a GoFundMe page to assist with her medical expenses.

title: Fact Check: Exercise And Diet Do NOT Cure Type 1 Diabetes
summary: Medical experts and organizations such as the CDC and Mayo Clinic confirm that there is no cure for Type 1 diabetes as of April 2024. Claims that diet and exercise can cure the disease are false. Barbara O'Neill's assertion that a man she knew "conquered" Type 1 diabetes through lifestyle changes is not supported by evidence. Sylvia Rosas, president of the National Kidney Foundation, emphasized that while lifestyle factors like exercise and diet are essential for managing diabetes, they do not cure it. Medications remain necessary for Type 1 diabetes management.

title: S2 Episode 4: Chronic Kidney Disease: FSGS, Genetic Testing, and APOL1
summary: Dr. Kirk Campbell, a professor at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai, contributes significantly to the understanding and treatment of focal segmental glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) and chronic kidney disease (CKD). In a discussion with Dr. Matthew Sparks, Campbell elaborates on FSGS, highlighting its complexity as a histologic pattern rather than a single disease. He emphasizes the importance of genetic testing, especially for congenital forms and patients with a strong family history of glomerular disease. Campbell also discusses the role of APOL1 genetic variants in kidney disease, noting that individuals with two high-risk alleles are more susceptible to nondiabetic kidney diseases. He is involved in research on precision-based therapies, including the drug inaxaplin, which targets mutant APOL1 proteins. Campbell's work aims to advance personalized treatment approaches in nephrology, particularly for patients with genetic predispositions to kidney disease.

title: Dr Kirk Campbell Discusses Mount Sinai's Educational Research, Clinical Initiatives on Health Equity
summary: Dr. Kirk Campbell, Vice Chair for Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at Mount Sinai Health System, highlighted Mount Sinai's efforts in educational research and clinical initiatives focused on health equity. The Institute for Health Equity Research, established in 2020, plays a pivotal role in these efforts. The initiatives include training resident physicians, medical students, and senior faculty on community engagement, cross-cultural communication, and avoiding stigmatizing language. Mount Sinai has also developed a comprehensive 11-point plan to address racism and health disparities, involving an equity scorecard and integrating clinical practices to ensure consistent care quality. Community engagement and reforms in financial and business strategies are also key components. Additionally, formal workshops and cross-cultural communication activities are part of the residency training to prioritize health equity.

title: Mount Sinai's Kirk Campbell, MD: Increased Data Collection, Education Driving Equitable Care Strategies
summary: Dr. Kirk Campbell, MD, FASN, vice chair for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in the Department of Medicine at Mount Sinai Health System, plays a pivotal role in advancing health equity. Under his leadership, Mount Sinai has emphasized data collection, educational research, and workforce training to improve clinical outcomes for underserved communities. Campbell's efforts focus on three pillars: workforce, education, and clinical outcomes. He oversees initiatives such as the Institute for Health Equity Research, which aims to enhance demographic data collection and address social determinants of health (SDOH). Campbell's work includes supporting and training frontline workers, implementing an 11-point plan to combat disparities, and ensuring equitable care delivery. His experience in nephrology informs his approach to addressing workforce and clinical challenges, emphasizing the importance of comprehensive data and quality metrics to guide health equity initiatives.

title: 2 Pitt Medicine professors were elected to the Association of American Physicians
summary: Two University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine professors, Douglas B. White and Paul Palevsky, have been elected to the Association of American Physicians (AAP). White, the UPMC Endowed Chair for Ethics in Critical Care Medicine, joined the faculty in 2009 and focuses on surrogate decision-making for critically ill patients. Palevsky, chief of the kidney medicine section at the VA Pittsburgh Healthcare System, has been with the University since 1989. He is an internationally recognized expert in acute kidney injury and critical care nephrology, contributing significantly through clinical trials on acute dialysis, prevention of acute kidney injury, and diabetic kidney disease management. The AAP, established in 1885, honors leading physician-scientists for their impactful contributions to health improvement. White and Palevsky will be recognized at an event in April.

title: How one patient went off dialysis — and others can too - STAT
summary: Melissa Lawson, diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, faced severe complications including acute kidney injury, leading to prolonged dialysis. Despite initial bleak prospects, she was weaned off dialysis under the care of Dr. Chi-yuan Hsu at UCSF, who believed many patients with acute kidney injury remain on dialysis longer than necessary. Hsu's study revealed that 40% of such patients recover kidney function, yet many continue dialysis without weaning. Paul Palevsky, a professor at the University of Pittsburgh, supports this, noting the lack of data on optimal dialysis duration for these patients. Palevsky emphasizes careful patient monitoring to identify recovery signs. The study underscores the need for more tailored dialysis approaches and better communication between hospitals and dialysis centers to improve patient outcomes.

title: Nanavati Max Super Speciality Hospital unveils Bioengineering Lab with 3-D Printing Technology
summary: Nanavati Max Super Speciality Hospital in Mumbai has launched a Medical 3D printing laboratory to enhance precision in oncologic, reconstructive orthopaedic, and specialized dentistry surgeries. The lab, equipped with two 3D printers, produces bone models and surgical cutting guides for accurate surgical planning and execution, particularly in bone cancer surgeries. Dr. Manish Agarwal, Director of Surgical Oncology (Orthopaedic) at Nanavati Max Institute of Cancer Care, led this project. He emphasized that this technology is not only faster and cost-effective but also significantly improves patient outcomes by utilizing custom-made jigs, detailed bone models, and advanced navigational tools. The virtual design of 3D bone models is created using CT scans, ensuring unparalleled accuracy in the produced models and guides. This integration of technology is revolutionizing healthcare across multiple domains, extending beyond orthopaedic and head and neck cancer surgeries to general orthopaedic, maxillofacial, and plastic surgeries.

title: 2023 Top 25 Diversity Leaders Monica Davy
summary: Monica Davy, as the Senior Vice President and Chief Culture, Diversity, and Impact Officer at Vizient, has been leading the company's diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) strategy since 2021. Under her leadership, over 100 organizational leaders support DEI initiatives, serving as executive sponsors and network champions for eight employee resource groups. Davy has overseen more than 120 DEI workshops and implemented a gender identity and expression inclusion policy. Additionally, she served as the executive sponsor for a DEI-focused network for Vizient members, facilitating the exchange of strategies and best practices among chief diversity officers, chief health equity officers, and other leaders.

title: Meet Our Executive Leadership Team
summary: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics is the world's largest organization of nutrition and dietetics practitioners. It includes a diverse Executive Leadership Team. Wylecia Wiggs Harris, the CEO, manages the Academy’s extensive operations and initiatives. Rayane AbuSabha oversees the accreditation of dietetics education programs. Jeanne Blankenship leads public policy strategy, while Sharon McCauley focuses on certification and professional development. Paul Mifsud ensures the financial health of the organization. Carrolyn Patterson manages human resources and diversity initiatives. Liz Spittler coordinates executive governance and special projects. Alison Steiber, as Chief Mission, Impact and Strategy Officer, aligns the Academy’s mission with strategic direction and resources, overseeing strategic partnerships, public policy, advocacy, and research. Mary Beth Whalen drives revenue and growth strategies. The Academy offers members benefits such as professional education opportunities, discounts, and exclusive events.

title: Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics Promotes Tool to Help Diagnose Malnutrition in Hospitalized Adults
summary: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics has introduced the AAIM tool to help diagnose malnutrition in hospitalized adults, addressing a significant health issue affecting 25% to 50% of these patients. This tool enables registered dietitian nutritionists (RDNs) to accurately diagnose malnutrition through a nutrition-focused physical examination assessing weight loss, muscle and fat loss, and reduced energy intake. Alison Steiber, the Academy's chief science officer, emphasized the tool's ease of use and its potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce health care costs. Two scientific papers validate AAIM's effectiveness in predicting hospital stays, emergency visits, and readmission rates.

title: Perspective: Nutritional Status as a Biological Variable (NABV): Integrating Nutrition Science into Basic and Clinical ...
summary: The field of nutrition has transitioned from identifying essential nutrients to applying this knowledge to promote health and prevent disease. This shift has led to recognizing nutritional status as a biological variable (NABV), emphasizing that it is not limited to dietary intake but is crucial in all aspects of health promotion, disease prevention, and treatment. NABV considers the multifactorial interactions affecting and affected by nutritional status, necessitating new research tools for precise health care and dietary interventions. Alison Steiber, contributing to this perspective, is an employee of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, serves on advisory boards, and is part of the International Society of Renal Nutrition and Metabolism. The article underscores the importance of integrating nutrition science into both basic and clinical research to improve public health outcomes.

title: For healthy kidneys, avoid excess alcohol and salt, get regular screenings
summary: To maintain healthy kidneys and reduce the risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD), avoid excessive alcohol and salt, stay hydrated, and exercise regularly. CKD, affecting over a third of people aged 65 and older, can lead to serious health issues and is often symptomless, making regular screenings crucial. Sumeska Thavarajah, an assistant professor at Johns Hopkins University, emphasizes a diet low in salt and sugar and high in unprocessed foods. Thavarajah also stresses the need for adequate fluid intake, especially during physical activity, and recommends annual screening tests for those over 60 or with high blood pressure or diabetes. Early detection and lifestyle modifications can help manage CKD and prevent its progression.

title: EMERALD: Patiromer for Hyperkalemia Treatment in Pediatric CKD
summary: The EMERALD trial investigates the use of patiromer, a sodium-free potassium binder, for treating hyperkalemia in children aged 2 to 18 with chronic kidney disease (CKD). Currently approved for adults, patiromer’s safety and efficacy in children are being assessed through a 14-day dose-finding phase and a 5.5-month treatment phase. Bradley A. Warady, MD, presented initial results at Kidney Week 2019, showing that a starting dose of 4.2 g/day of patiromer, with titration, led to significant reductions in serum potassium levels. By day 14, 50% of patients reached target potassium levels; by week 26, this increased to 82%. Adverse effects were mostly mild to moderate, with gastrointestinal issues being most common. No severe adverse events led to discontinuation. The study suggests patiromer is effective and well-tolerated in pediatric CKD patients with hyperkalemia.

title: The Healthcare Marketing Influencer 25 Class of 2024: Dr. John Wigneswaran
summary: Dr. John Wigneswaran, the Chief Medical Officer at Walmart, has been recognized as part of the Healthcare Marketing Influencer 25 Class of 2024. Known in the industry as Dr. Wig, he leverages Walmart's extensive network of over 5,000 pharmacies, with around 4,000 located in underserved areas, to combat health deserts. Dr. Wigneswaran emphasizes the critical role of pharmacists in patient care, highlighting the importance of education and trust-building during every patient interaction. His efforts focus on improving health literacy and ensuring that patients receive the necessary care and medication guidance.

title: National Kidney Foundation Appoints Walmart Chief Medical Officer Dr. Wigneswaran to National Board of Directors
summary: Dr. John Wigneswaran, Walmart's Chief Medical Officer, has been appointed to the National Kidney Foundation's (NKF) National Board of Directors. With a background in nephrology, Dr. Wigneswaran brings extensive expertise in safety, clinical program development, innovation, and medical affairs. His career includes roles at Cigna, DaVita, Fresenius Medical Care, and Johnson & Johnson. Dr. Wigneswaran is committed to advocating for kidney disease patients, particularly those in underserved communities. His academic credentials include a medical degree from Tufts University, a nephrology fellowship at New York-Presbyterian/Weil Cornell Medical Center, and an MBA from MIT Sloan School of Management.

title: Dissecting Walmart's healthcare strategy - MM+M Podcast
summary: Walmart has been strategically expanding its healthcare services, aiming to provide accessible and affordable care. Dr. John Wigneswaran, Walmart's Chief Medical Officer, discussed the company's healthcare ambitions, focusing on improving patient outcomes and leveraging Walmart's extensive retail presence. He emphasized Walmart's initiatives such as low-cost generic medications, research participation, and the integration of health services into their retail footprint. Dr. Wigneswaran highlighted the importance of consumerism in healthcare and Walmart's efforts to address health equity by including diverse patient populations in research. The company aims to complement existing healthcare services rather than reinvent them, focusing on areas where they can make a significant impact.

title: The Healthcare Marketing Influencer 25 Class of 2024
summary: MM+M has announced the Healthcare Marketing Influencer 25 Class of 2024, highlighting 25 individuals with significant impact in healthcare marketing. The selection process involved MM+M editors and reporters narrowing down an initial list of 70 candidates. The honorees represent a diverse range of disciplines, channels, and organizations, reflecting recent shifts in the field.
