Among the influencers is Dr. John Wigneswaran from Walmart, recognized for his contributions to healthcare marketing. The list aims to spark debate and discussion within the industry, inviting feedback from readers.

title: My Purpose, Our Mission – Stephanie Graham, Medical Dosimetrist
summary: Stephanie Graham, a medical dosimetrist at SSM Health Cancer Care, is highlighted in the "My Purpose, Our Mission" series for her dedication and personal connection with patients. Initially studying medical illustration, Stephanie transitioned to oncology, becoming a registered radiation therapist in 2018 and later earning a master’s degree in medical dosimetry in 2021. She designs individualized radiation treatment plans using advanced imaging technologies and collaborates closely with oncologists. Known for her empathy, Stephanie forms deep bonds with patients, exemplified by her relationship with a patient who became a grandfather figure to her. Despite her individual recognition, Stephanie credits her team's collective effort for their exceptional patient care.

title: 22 Faculty Members Honored at Endowed Professorship Ceremony: Development & Alumni Relations: Feinberg ...
summary: On September 18, 2023, Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine honored 22 faculty members with endowed professorships during a ceremony at The Peninsula Hotel in Chicago. Eric G. Neilson, MD, emphasized the importance of faculty in advancing the medical school's missions. Cecilia Berin, PhD, was invested as the inaugural Bunning Professor of Food Allergy Research. Francesca Elizabeth Duncan, PhD, and Lynn M. Yee, MD, MPH, were recognized as Thomas J. Watkins Memorial Professors. These positions enable continued advancements in medical research and education at Feinberg.

title: COVID-19 Vaccine Safety with Eric G. Neilson, MD, and Robert Murphy, MD
summary: The podcast episode "COVID-19 Vaccine Safety with Eric G. Neilson, MD, and Robert Murphy, MD" features a discussion on the safety and effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines. Eric G. Neilson, MD, the dean of the Feinberg School of Medicine, emphasizes the importance of widespread vaccination to eliminate the virus and return to normalcy. Robert Murphy, MD, addresses concerns about rare side effects, such as allergic reactions, and reassures that they are manageable. The conversation covers various topics, including the three vaccines with emergency use authorization (Pfizer, Moderna, Johnson & Johnson), vaccination timing after contracting COVID-19, potential virus transmission by vaccinated individuals, CDC masking guidelines, vaccine reactions, travel post-vaccination, vaccination for children, vaccine safety during pregnancy, and exemptions. Neilson and Murphy aim to provide clear information to alleviate fears and encourage vaccination.

title: McCormick and Feinberg Prof. Eric Perreault to serve as vice president for research
summary: Eric Perreault will serve as Northwestern University’s next vice president for research starting September 15, as announced by President Michael Schill and Provost Kathleen Hagerty. Perreault, who joined Northwestern’s faculty in 2002, has held roles such as chair of biomedical engineering and associate dean for research administration at the McCormick School of Engineering. His tenure saw a 30% increase in research funding for McCormick. Perreault will succeed Milan Mrksich, who is stepping down. Under Perreault's leadership, the Office for Research recently exceeded $1 billion in annual research funding for the first time. Perreault aims to focus on interdisciplinary collaboration, diversity, and addressing complex global issues.

title: Optimism persists when walking in unpredictable environments | Scientific Reports
summary: The study investigated human adaptation strategies for stable walking in unpredictable environments, focusing on lateral deviations of the center of mass (COM). Participants performed a goal-directed walking task with a randomly applied laterally-directed force field. Results showed that with practice, participants reduced COM lateral deviations by 28% (left) and 44% (right). This was achieved through two distinct strategies: anticipatory postural adjustments and lateral foot placement. Catch trials indicated an impedance control strategy, while trial-by-trial analysis suggested a predictive control strategy. Eric Perreault contributed to the experimental design, data analysis, and manuscript preparation, providing insights into motor control mechanisms.

title: Kiyatec strengthens its leadership position with the addition of Mark Capone, former CEO of Myriad Genetics, as ...
summary: Kiyatec, a leader in functional precision oncology, has appointed Mark Capone, former CEO of Myriad Genetics, as a strategic advisor. Capone brings nearly 40 years of experience in molecular diagnostics, biotechnology, and pharmaceuticals. He previously transformed Myriad Genetics into a global precision medicine leader. Kiyatec President Eric Perreault emphasized Capone's invaluable oncology expertise, which will help the company enhance cancer care. Kiyatec aims to advance its 3D Predict™ platform, offering oncologists patient-specific therapeutic response evidence and aiding biopharmaceutical companies in drug development. Capone expressed enthusiasm for contributing to Kiyatec’s mission of revolutionizing cancer care.

title: New medical hub combines efforts of nine Chicago institutions
summary: Nine Chicago institutions have established the Chicago Biomedical Consortium Hub for Innovative Technology and Entrepreneurship in the Sciences (CBC-HITES) to accelerate the delivery of medical innovations to patients. The hub, based at Northwestern Medicine’s Comprehensive Transplant Center, aims to transform medical research into commercial products by fostering partnerships between academic inventors and biopharma leaders. Eric Perreault, Northwestern’s vice president for research, highlighted the hub's potential to expedite biomedical innovations and translate scientific breakthroughs into commercial ventures with significant societal impact. The initiative includes scientists from Northwestern University, University of Chicago, University of Illinois Chicago, and other regional institutions. Funded by The Searle Funds at The Chicago Community Trust, The National Institutes of Health, and the Walder Foundation, CBC-HITES will join 12 other hubs under the NIH’s Research Evaluation and Commercialization Hub program. Prof. Satish Nadig emphasized the hub's role in connecting medical scientists with the necessary expertise to develop biotech applications.

title: Austin doctor hopes to make personalized health care affordable for Texans
summary: Dr. Jobby John, a compound pharmacist and founder of Nimbus Healthcare, aims to make personalized health care affordable for Texans. His journey began with his own struggle with alopecia, leading him to create an at-home testing and telemedical service. Utilizing genetic profiles and blood biochemistry from home testing kits, his team offers FDA-approved solutions for issues like hair loss and hormone imbalances at reduced costs. This approach allows patients to pay hundreds instead of thousands of dollars for tailored treatments. Dr. John emphasizes that personalized health care avoids the trial-and-error of traditional methods, providing more precise and effective treatments. Nimbus Healthcare has shown positive early results with around 300 patients, offering hope to individuals like Spanki Mills-Farris, who struggled with general diagnoses and costly treatments. Dr. John’s initiative underscores the importance of individualized care in improving health outcomes affordably.

title: Announcing the Winners of the 2023 UT Pharmacy Alumni Awards
summary: The University of Texas at Austin College of Pharmacy Alumni Association has announced the winners of the 2023 Alumni Awards. Dr. Jobby John, Pharm.D., received the Distinguished Young Alumnus Award. He is recognized for his innovative contributions to pharmacy practice, including founding Lake Hills Compounding Pharmacy and Wellness Center in Austin, Texas, at the age of 26, making him one of the youngest pharmacy owners in the U.S. Dr. John also founded Nimbus Healthcare, a digital platform integrating AI and data analytics to revolutionize patient care. His career blends traditional pharmacy wisdom with cutting-edge technology. Other award recipients include George Polansky, Jr., who received the Legend of Pharmacy Award, and Debbie B. Garza, R.Ph., who was honored with the William J Sheffield Outstanding Alumnus Award. The recipients will be celebrated at the Texas Pharmacy Homecoming Tailgate on November 4, 2023.

title: UPSHER-SMITH AND THE NATIONAL ALLIANCE OF STATE PHARMACY ASSOCIATIONS (NASPA) ANNOUNCE ...
summary: Upsher-Smith Laboratories, LLC and the National Alliance of State Pharmacy Associations (NASPA) announced the 2023 recipients of the NASPA Excellence in Innovation Award. This award, sponsored by Upsher-Smith and overseen by NASPA, honors pharmacists who have demonstrated significant innovation in their practice, resulting in improved patient care or advancements in the pharmacy profession. The award is presented by over 40 state pharmacy associations throughout the year. Among the recipients is Jobby John, Pharm.D., from Texas. Both organizations expressed pride and gratitude in recognizing these innovative contributions to the field of pharmacy.

title: 6 of the Best Medication Reminders
summary: Healthline reviews six top medication reminders, essential for ensuring timely medication intake. The article, medically reviewed by Alan Carter, Pharm.D., highlights various options like TabTime Timer, e-pill TimeCap & Bottle, PillPack, MedMinder, Medisafe, and Hero. These tools range from simple timers and smart pill bottles to comprehensive services that pre-dose medications. Studies cited indicate that such reminders significantly improve medication adherence. Healthline's vetting process ensures the safety and efficacy of recommended products. The review includes product features, pricing, pros, and cons to help users choose the best fit for their needs.

title: Fentanyl Overdose Symptoms: Myth vs. Fact
summary: Fentanyl, a potent opioid, can suppress breathing, leading to unconsciousness or death. Misunderstandings about fentanyl overdoses are widespread. Alan Carter, Pharm.D., emphasizes the importance of recognizing overdose symptoms like constricted pupils, loss of consciousness, and slow or weak breathing. Overdoses often occur due to tolerance buildup or unknowingly consuming fentanyl mixed with other drugs. Contrary to myths, fentanyl overdose through skin contact is highly unlikely. In emergencies, calling 911, administering naloxone, and monitoring the person are crucial steps. The CDC reports that synthetic opioids, primarily fentanyl, were responsible for over 65% of drug overdose deaths in the U.S. in 2021. Dispelling myths and understanding the facts can improve response and save lives.

title: Announcing the Winners of the 2023 UT Pharmacy Alumni Awards
summary: The University of Texas at Austin College of Pharmacy Alumni Association board has announced the winners of the 2023 UT Pharmacy Alumni Awards. Dr. Jobby John received the Distinguished Young Alumnus Award for his innovative contributions to pharmacy practice, including founding Lake Hills Compounding Pharmacy and Nimbus Healthcare. George Polansky was honored with the Legend of Pharmacy Award for his extensive career in retail pharmacy and his contributions to various health programs and boards. Debbie Garza, R.Ph., received the William J Sheffield Outstanding Alumnus Award. As CEO of the Texas Pharmacy Association since 2017, Debbie has excelled in government relations, public policy, and pharmacy operations, advocating for the pharmacy profession and mentoring future leaders. The awards will be presented at the Texas Pharmacy Homecoming Tailgate on November 4, 2023.

title: How Austin, Texas, is being impacted by national drug shortage
summary: Austin, Texas, is experiencing impacts from a national shortage of hundreds of medications, particularly affecting diabetes, weight loss, and ADHD treatments. Dr. Rannon Ching, president and chief pharmacy officer at Tarrytown Pharmacy, emphasized the importance of maintaining communication with healthcare providers to manage potential medication shortages. Ching advises working closely with prescribers and pharmacists to find alternative treatments if specific medications are unavailable. He noted that the shortages are due to various factors, including production issues, supply chain disruptions, and natural disasters, but many manufacturers do not disclose specific reasons for the shortages. Hospital-related medications, such as hormones and chemotherapy-related fluids, are among the most affected. Ching highlighted the lack of transparency in the reasons behind these shortages, complicating efforts to address the issue.

title: Bills would allow pharmacists to give kids vaccines
summary: Bills proposed in Texas aim to allow pharmacists to "test and treat" for flu, strep, and COVID-19, eliminating the need for a doctor's prescription. Rep. Jacey Jetton and Rep. Four Price are spearheading these initiatives, which also include permitting pharmacists to administer vaccines to children under three with a doctor's note. The COVID-19 pandemic saw a significant shift towards pharmacies for vaccinations, with 90% of Americans receiving their COVID-19 vaccines at pharmacies. Rannon Ching, Pharm.D., from Tarrytown Pharmacy, emphasizes the importance of these bills, noting that pharmacies are accessible in both urban and rural areas and can provide critical healthcare services during nights and weekends. Ching highlights the potential setback if these bills are not passed, stressing the progress made in increasing healthcare access through pharmacies.

title: Texans with ADHD struggle with unprecedented drug shortages
summary: Texans with ADHD are facing severe medication shortages, particularly for Adderall and its generics, due to increased demand and supply chain issues. The FDA and manufacturers have not provided clear resolutions, leaving many patients struggling to find their prescriptions. Aiden Carter, a 24-year-old from Austin, highlights the difficulty of managing daily tasks and job searches without her medication. Psychiatrist Dr. Brent Turnipseed notes the strain on medical staff trying to locate available drugs for patients. Pharmacist Rannon Ching reports receiving around 50 calls daily about ADHD medications, emphasizing the unprecedented duration and extent of the shortage.

title: How to store refrigerated medication during power outages
summary: Power outages in Central Texas pose a significant challenge for those dependent on refrigerated medications like insulin and certain antibiotics. Pharmacist Rannon Ching, Pharm.D., from Tarrytown Pharmacy in Austin, advises patients to contact the medication's manufacturer if their drugs experience a "temperature excursion." Manufacturers often have specific data on how their products are affected by temperature changes. Ching also suggests using coolers with traditional ice, ensuring the medication is in waterproof containers and not in direct contact with ice. For expensive medications, contacting insurance companies for a potential override on lost or damaged medications is recommended. Ching emphasizes not relying on local pharmacies for storage during outages and instead suggests finding alternative refrigeration options with friends, workplaces, or using insulated carriers.

title: Faculty and Students Honored at 2024 Celebration of Excellence
summary: The University of Texas at Austin’s Pharmacy Council celebrated the 2024 Celebration of Excellence on April 3, honoring faculty and students for their outstanding contributions. Dr. Christian Whitman, Dr. Tyler Kiles, and Dr. Samantha Catanzano received Teaching Excellence Awards for the classes of 2027, 2026, and 2025, respectively. Professor Terry Weaver was recognized as Outstanding Faculty Advisor. Dean Ashley Castleberry was named Pharmacy Educator of the Year. Dr. Morgan Stewart, Dr. Elysha Donaldson, and Dr. Brandon Dittmar were awarded Preceptor of the Year in their respective categories. Ashley Garling, Pharm.D., was a notable nominee for multiple awards including Teaching Excellence and Faculty Advisor. Other awards included Outstanding Teaching Assistant, Outstanding Tutor, and Outstanding Academic Assistant. The event highlighted the commitment of educators and students to excellence in pharmacy education and practice.

title: Who are the 50 most influential leaders in pharmacy?
summary: The Pharmacy 50 program, initiated in 2021 by The Pharmacy Podcast Network (PPN), honors individuals significantly impacting the pharmacy sector. Recognized through a social media campaign, honorees come from diverse practice backgrounds. Nadia Ahmad, a Walgreens dispensing pharmacist, tops the list for her leadership and customer care. Haley McKeefer, Pharm.D. Candidate 2024, is among the honored professionals. The program's inclusivity allows both pharmacists and non-pharmacists to be acknowledged. Todd Eury, CEO of PPN, emphasizes the program's scope and inclusivity. This year, Cardinal Health and the Independent Pharmacy Cooperative sponsored the program, boosting voter participation by 300%. A formal awards ceremony will be held at PPN's headquarters, streaming live on various platforms. Darren Thieding of IPC praises the winners' excellence, expressing confidence in the industry's future.

title: OHSU only Oregon hospital to offer vital COVID-19 treatment to patients on an outpatient basis
summary: Oregon Health & Science University (OHSU) is the only hospital in Oregon offering remdesivir for outpatients, a vital COVID-19 treatment. Remdesivir, an antiviral medication, is FDA-approved to prevent severe COVID-19. It is administered via three daily intravenous infusions. Due to staffing shortages, fewer hospitals provide this treatment. Young Yoon “YY” Ham, Pharm.D., an infectious disease pharmacist at OHSU, emphasizes the importance of early treatment, especially for high-risk patients. This includes those over 50 or with conditions like high blood pressure, diabetes, or obesity. Other COVID-19 treatments include Paxlovid and molnupiravir, but remdesivir is crucial for those who can't use these due to other medication interactions. Josie Gold, a patient, experienced significant improvement after receiving remdesivir at OHSU’s COVID-19 Therapy Clinic. The clinic, located in Portland, offers appointments for remdesivir infusions, ensuring patients receive timely and effective care.

title: 1,300 Providence Everett nurses go on strike | king5.com
summary: 1,300 nurses at Providence Medical Center in Everett, represented by UFCW 3000, began a strike over unfair labor practices, primarily due to staffing shortages. Kelli Johnson, a nurse and bargaining team member, emphasized that the ongoing staffing issues have been raised for over a year and a half, impacting patient care and leading to incidents like a recent wrongful death claim. Despite hospital offers of a 21.5% raise and flexible scheduling, nurses rejected the proposal as it didn't address staffing concerns. The hospital, led by Kristy Carrington, has brought in replacement nurses to manage patient care during the strike.

title: How psychedelic medicine will be administered following TGA approval
summary: Researchers in Australia, led by Dr. Mike Millard of St Vincent's Hospital, are set to begin a clinical trial on administering psychedelic medicine following the Therapeutic Goods Administration's (TGA) approval of psilocybin for treatment-resistant depression and MDMA for PTSD. Australia is the first country to legalize these substances for mental health treatment. The trial involves patients undergoing a six-hour session with eye masks and headphones while being monitored by psychiatrists. Millard emphasizes the importance of a carefully curated and healing environment for the treatment. The trial is a collaboration between St Vincent's Hospital and the Black Dog Institute. Despite the promising potential, some experts, like Professor Colleen Loo, express caution regarding the sudden approval and the treatment's high cost. The TGA requires strict protocols and safety measures for prescribing these drugs.

title: Oregon Sen. Ron Wyden heading congressional investigation
summary: Oregon Senator Ron Wyden is leading a congressional investigation into the high costs of prescription medications and the role of pharmacy benefits managers (PBMs) in pricing. As chair of the U.S. Senate Finance Committee, Wyden conducted a hearing with experts to address the issue. PBMs, which manage drug benefits for about 85% of Americans, are criticized for practices that drive up medication costs, negatively impacting independent pharmacies and consumers. Originally intended to help insurers manage drug spending, PBMs have evolved into profit-driven entities with a lack of transparency. Mike Millard, a professor at Pacific University, highlighted the problem, noting that the benefits intended for patients are often retained by PBMs and insurers. The investigation aims to bring transparency and affordability to medication pricing.

title: Dr. Karen Knudsen
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Dr. Karen Knudsen is the Chief Executive Officer of the American Cancer Society (ACS). She became the first female CEO in the organization's history in April 2021. Under her leadership, the ACS launched a joint venture with Color Health in June 2023 to provide cancer prevention and screening solutions to over 150 million Americans. This partnership aims to address the challenges Americans face in accessing preventive cancer services, even with health insurance. Early diagnosis of major cancers can significantly reduce costs and improve survival rates. Knudsen's efforts align with the Biden administration's Cancer Moonshot initiative, which seeks to reduce the cancer death rate by 50% over the next 25 years. Knudsen emphasizes the importance of collaboration and integrated work plans to address the entire cancer continuum, from prevention and detection to treatment and survivorship. Her contributions have accelerated the ACS's progress in saving lives affected by cancer.

title: Press Releases
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) expressed support for Dr. Francis Collins, former NIH director, following his prostate cancer diagnosis. Dr. Karen E. Knudsen, CEO of ACS and ACS CAN, commended Dr. Collins for his transparency in raising awareness about prostate cancer. Dr. Collins has significantly contributed to cancer research, notably through his role in the Human Genome Project and the Cancer Moonshot initiative, which advanced early cancer detection and immunotherapies. His leadership also increased NIH funding substantially. Dr. Knudsen emphasized the importance of early detection, given the rise in advanced prostate cancer diagnoses. ACS and ACS CAN are intensifying efforts to combat prostate cancer and promote early detection. The American Cancer Society aims to end cancer through advocacy, research, and patient support, while ACS CAN advocates for cancer-related public policies.

title: Women of Influence 2023: Karen E. Knudsen, American Cancer Society
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Karen E. Knudsen, CEO of the American Cancer Society (ACS) and its advocacy affiliate, the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, is honored as a 2023 Woman of Influence by the Philadelphia Business Journal. Appointed in 2021, Knudsen is the first woman to hold this position in the nonprofit's history. With a robust background in healthcare, including roles at Philadelphia’s Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center and Thomas Jefferson University, she now leads strategic planning for ACS, impacting 55 million people annually through advocacy, research, and patient support. Under her leadership, ACS exceeded its revenue growth goals and launched initiatives like national roundtables for the Cancer Moonshoot and the American Cancer Society Center for Diversity in Research Training, ensuring equitable care.

title: CMS starts paying for patient navigation; ACS offers navigation credentialing program
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Medicare has introduced new CPT codes to reimburse patient navigation services, which guide patients through complex healthcare systems. This initiative, part of the Biden Administration's Cancer Moonshot, highlights the importance of patient navigation, originally developed by Harold Freeman in the 1960s. Karen Knudsen, CEO of the American Cancer Society (ACS), celebrated this as a significant step forward. ACS has been pivotal in advocating for this change and has developed a standardized training and credentialing program to meet CMS requirements. This ensures that navigators are properly trained and certified, enhancing the quality and consistency of care provided to patients.

title: How to tell your kids someone they love has been diagnosed with cancer — amid Kate Middleton's battle
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Kate Middleton has revealed her cancer diagnosis to her three children in an "appropriate way," reassuring them that she will be okay. Dr. Karen E. Knudsen, CEO of the American Cancer Society, emphasized the difficulty of explaining such news to children, highlighting the need for timely and clear communication. Elizabeth Farrell, a clinical social worker, advises parents to provide information as soon as they have clarity about the condition and treatment plan. Children should be updated on major changes and encouraged to ask questions. Involving teachers and close contacts can also help monitor the child's well-being.

title: Recognizing Symptoms Of Breast Cancer In Men
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, emphasizing that men can also be affected by the disease. The American Cancer Society estimates that 530 men will die of breast cancer this year. Survivor Juan Namnun, a high school baseball coach, discovered a lump in his chest in July 2022, which was diagnosed as Stage 2 Breast Cancer. Dr. Karen Knudsen from the American Cancer Society highlighted the lack of routine breast cancer screening for men, making awareness crucial. Namnun underwent a double mastectomy and emphasizes the importance of self-examination for early detection. Now an ambassador for the American Cancer Society, he urges men to be vigilant about changes in their bodies.

title: American Cancer Society Releases Latest Cancer Statistics, Launches Initiative to Address Prostate Cancer ...
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The American Cancer Society (ACS) released its annual report, Cancer Statistics, 2023, highlighting a 33% drop in overall cancer mortality since 1991, preventing approximately 3.8 million deaths. Significant findings include a 65% reduction in cervical cancer rates among women aged 20-24 due to the HPV vaccine and a concerning 3% annual increase in advanced prostate cancer diagnoses from 2014 to 2019. Karen Knudsen, ACS CEO, emphasized the urgency of addressing the rise in advanced prostate cancer, particularly among Black men, through the new initiative IMPACT (Improving Mortality from Prostate Cancer Together). This initiative aims to mobilize resources across advocacy, patient support, and research to reverse disparities and reduce prostate cancer death rates by 2035.

title: Blood tests that detect cancer: How they work
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Multi-cancer early detection tests (MCEDs) have the potential to detect various cancers at early stages, improving survival chances. Despite their availability, they lack FDA approval and clear clinical guidance. Karen Knudsen, CEO of the American Cancer Society, highlights the rapid advancement of this technology, emphasizing its promise as the next frontier in oncology. However, the challenge lies in interpreting the data and determining actionable steps. Knudsen notes that while MCEDs can identify cancer DNA in the bloodstream, it doesn't always mean actionable cancer is present. Clinical trials are ongoing to assess the reliability and benefits of MCEDs, with the hope that they can one day screen for currently unscreenable cancers. Until then, Knudsen advises patients to discuss their cancer risk and potential lifestyle changes with their healthcare providers.

title: Cancer deaths drop, but more late-stage prostate cancer diagnoses spark concerns
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Cancer deaths in the U.S. have decreased by 33% over the past three decades, with cervical cancer rates dropping by 65% among women in their early 20s, largely due to the HPV vaccine. However, there is a concerning rise in advanced prostate cancer diagnoses, increasing by 4.5% annually since 2011. Karen Knudsen, CEO of the American Cancer Society, attributes the overall decline in cancer deaths to investments in research, prevention, early detection, and new treatments. She emphasizes the need for better prostate cancer screening and highlights the racial disparity in prostate cancer outcomes, particularly among Black men. Knudsen calls for more research and equitable access to quality care to address these issues.

title: Medicaid expansion will prove extremely valuable in the fight against cancer • NC Newsline
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Medicaid expansion in North Carolina, effective December 1, 2023, will provide affordable health insurance to nearly 600,000 residents, significantly aiding in the fight against cancer. The American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN) celebrates this achievement, emphasizing that health coverage is crucial for early cancer detection and treatment. Lisa Lacasse, president of ACS CAN, highlights that the expansion will enable more people to undergo cancer screenings, receive necessary treatments, and improve survival rates. This initiative is particularly vital for people of color, who face higher medical costs and financial hardships. The expansion also supports rural hospitals and reduces long-term medical expenses. Advocates like DonnaMarie Woodson, who benefited from affordable health insurance, campaigned vigorously for this change, understanding its life-saving potential. North Carolina is now the 40th state to close the healthcare coverage gap, promising a healthier workforce and reduced health disparities.

title: 'Closing the Care Gap': Efforts Aligning With World Cancer Day
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: In honor of World Cancer Day, ongoing advocacy efforts were highlighted, focusing on closing the care gap for cancer patients. Key initiatives include the Lymphedema Treatment Act, which mandates Medicare coverage for compression garments, and the PACT Act, expanding benefits for veterans exposed to toxins. Despite these advancements, disparities persist, such as the 2023 chemotherapy shortage affecting Medicaid patients more severely. Lisa Lacasse, president of the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network (ACS CAN), emphasized the urgent need for Congress to address these shortages. Additionally, disparities in genetic testing for breast cancer among minority and LGBTQIA+ communities were noted, with organizations like FORCE working to provide support and information.

title: Analysts, advocates, pharma outline areas for CMS to improve IRA
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: During the Milken Institute's Future of Health Summit, stakeholders discussed the need for updates to the Inflation Reduction Act's (IRA) drug cost controls, highlighting concerns about access, innovation, and pricing. The IRA allows Medicare to negotiate prices for certain drugs, with more to be included over time. Meena Seshamani from CMS emphasized the importance of adapting to market dynamics and gathering feedback from various sources, including patient-focused sessions. Lisa Lacasse, president of the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, warned of the unintended consequences of policy interventions, stressing the need for community collaboration to address potential issues affecting patient costs and treatment development. Other panelists discussed the potential impacts on pharmaceutical innovation and the necessity for CMS to carefully monitor these effects to ensure patient access and affordability.

title: American Cancer Society study links medical debt to premature death
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A new study by the American Cancer Society, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association Network Open, links high levels of medical debt to declining physical and mental health and even premature death. The study analyzed 2018 medical debt data from the Urban Institute's Debt in America project and compared it to health statuses and premature death rates across nearly 3,000 counties. It found that a 1% increase in medical debt correlates with more unhealthy physical and mental days and higher mortality rates. Lisa Lacasse, president of the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, emphasized that the rising cost of healthcare significantly impacts patients and their families, making addressing medical debt a growing public policy priority. The study highlights the urgent need to consider medical debt as a critical social determinant of health.

title: Press Releases
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A recent study by the American Cancer Society (ACS) indicates that Medicaid expansion in the U.S. is linked to increased palliative care for advanced cancer patients. Palliative care, which provides symptom relief and stress management, saw a rise from 17.0% to 18.9% in expansion states and from 15.7% to 16.7% in non-expansion states. The study, published in Health Affairs, highlights the importance of Medicaid in improving access to palliative care, particularly for advanced pancreatic, colorectal, lung, and other cancers. Lisa Lacasse, President of ACS CAN, emphasized the need for legislation to enhance palliative care access and Medicaid expansion to address health inequities and improve cancer patient outcomes.

title: Feast for Your Brain engages both body and mind
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The second annual Feast for Your Brain event, held on September 23, 2023, at the University of Arizona Health Sciences campus, focused on promoting healthy aging. Sponsored by the Mel and Enid Zuckerman College of Public Health, the Precision Aging Network, and MindCrowd, the event featured performances, presentations, health services, games, and more. With over 500 attendees, it included 35 information tables, 13 presenters, and 11 performances. The event aimed to increase awareness about healthy aging and brain health, and it was presented in both English and Spanish for the first time. David O. Garcia, PhD, FACSM, an associate professor, highlighted the Nosotros Comprometidos a Su Salud program, which aims to increase awareness and engagement in health disparities research. The event brought together experts, community partners, and health service providers to address cognitive decline and age-related diseases.

title: Daily Consumption of Sugary Drinks Linked to Increased Risk of Liver Cancer and Chronic Liver Disease
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Researchers from Brigham and Women’s Hospital, part of the Mass General Brigham healthcare system, found a significant link between daily consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and an increased risk of liver cancer and chronic liver disease mortality in postmenopausal women. The study, involving nearly 100,000 participants from the Women’s Health Initiative, revealed that women consuming one or more sugary drinks daily had an 85% higher risk of liver cancer and a 68% higher risk of chronic liver disease mortality compared to those with lower consumption. David O. Garcia contributed to this research, which was published in JAMA. The study underscores the need for further research to confirm these findings and understand the mechanisms behind the increased risks.

title: Unsung heroes make Health Sciences labs work
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The smooth operation of University of Arizona Health Sciences labs relies heavily on the contributions of lab managers, research technicians, and coordinators. David O. Garcia, PhD, FACSM, an associate professor at the Mel and Enid Zuckerman College of Public Health, highlights the essential role of Edgar A. Villavicencio, the research coordinator for the Nosotros Comprometidos a Su Salud program. Villavicencio, who started as a research assistant in 2018, oversees active research studies, ensures data compliance, and coordinates community outreach events. His work focuses on reducing health disparities in Hispanic communities in Southern Arizona. Garcia credits Villavicencio's leadership, communication skills, and dedication to community relevance as key to the success of their projects, particularly in developing collaborative care models for liver disease.

title: Victory is sweet in Super Bowl challenge won by the KU Cancer Center
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The University of Kansas Cancer Center celebrated the Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl LVII victory over the Philadelphia Eagles with a friendly wager against the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center (SKCC) at Jefferson Health. Roy Jensen, M.D., vice chancellor and director of the KU Cancer Center, led the challenge, resulting in a win that included barbeque and Philly cheesesteaks. Despite the rivalry, both centers, designated by the National Cancer Institute (NCI), are collaborating on cancer research. Jensen, who also serves on the SKCC external advisory board, emphasized their united effort against cancer. Researchers from both institutions are working on grants and projects, including studies on tRNA fragments in cancer biology. The KU Cancer Center serves a broad area, including rural regions, with significant cancer-related challenges. The collaboration aims to advance cancer research while maintaining a friendly sports rivalry.

title: Fran, Margaret, and Connor McCaffery talk about Patrick’s battle with anxiety: ‘He’s mentally and physically exhausted’
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Patrick McCaffery, a basketball player, announced an indefinite leave from the court due to severe anxiety affecting his performance, sleep, appetite, and stamina. His father, Fran McCaffery, who is also Iowa's head coach, emphasized the importance of Patrick's well-being over his role as a player, highlighting the family's support. Margaret McCaffery, Patrick's mother, detailed the physical and mental exhaustion Patrick faces, noting his lack of adrenaline and the toll it takes on his body. Patrick's brother, Connor, observed significant changes in Patrick's energy and stamina, mentioning incidents of nausea and vomiting. Despite his leave, Patrick will remain with the team, with Connor stepping into his starting position.

title: State Health Officials Alarmed by U.S. Measles Outbreaks, Stress the Importance of Adhering to Established Public ...
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: State health officials are alarmed by the recent U.S. measles outbreaks and emphasize the importance of adhering to public health practices and vaccinating the unvaccinated. Marcus Plescia, MD, MPH, Chief Medical Officer of the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials (ASTHO), highlighted the severity of measles, especially for children, noting that it can lead to hospitalization, pneumonia, brain injury, and even death. Plescia stressed that measles was declared eliminated in the U.S. in 2000, but it remains highly contagious. He urged vaccination, as two doses are over 97% effective. He also recommended that unvaccinated individuals exposed to measles stay home for 21 days to prevent further outbreaks. Public health professionals are committed to educating and supporting communities to maintain health and prevent disease spread.

title: TikTok’s ‘mystery virus’ is a pandemic side effect
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The spread of a “mystery virus” on TikTok, with symptoms like nausea and faintness, is likely a post-pandemic anxiety response, according to public health experts. Marcus Plescia, chief medical officer of the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, noted that the symptoms are consistent with common viruses such as the cold. Despite social media users' concerns about a new virus, experts, including Georges Benjamin of the American Public Health Association, see this as typical seasonal illness exacerbated by increased social interactions post-pandemic. Callum Hood from the Center for Countering Digital Hate criticized social media for spreading health misinformation, urging platforms to address it. Lori Freeman, CEO of the National Association of County and City Health Officials, emphasized the importance of relying on credible sources like the CDC for health information.

title: CDC changes COVID data tracking to focus on deaths, severe cases
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The CDC will stop tracking daily COVID-19 cases and focus on hospitalizations and deaths, similar to flu surveillance. This change aligns with the end of the public health emergency on May 11 and the WHO's declaration that COVID-19 is no longer a global emergency. The CDC will now use weekly updates and rely on hospital data, wastewater analysis, and genomic surveillance to monitor the virus. Dr. Marcus Plescia supports this approach, stating it makes more sense to track COVID-19 like other respiratory viruses. The new method aims to provide actionable information for health officials and the public.

title: U.S. Mpox Cases Rising Again as Vaccinations Lag
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Mpox cases are rising in the U.S., with infections doubling compared to the same time last year. Public health experts emphasize the need for improved vaccination rates to control the spread. Dr. Marcus Plescia, chief medical officer for the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, highlighted the effectiveness of the mpox vaccine and the necessity for higher vaccination coverage among at-risk populations to prevent further outbreaks. Despite having a vaccine, less than a quarter of the at-risk population has been fully vaccinated since its emergency use authorization in August 2022. The CDC has also alerted about a more transmissible and severe subtype of the virus spreading in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The U.S. government had managed vaccine supplies during the 2022 outbreak, but the process has since been commercialized. Vaccines are expected to be available in pharmacies and healthcare offices next month.

title: Health Departments Provide Essential Support to Multisector Community Partnerships Working to Address Social Determinants of Health
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Health departments play a crucial role in supporting multisector community partnerships (MCPs) that address social determinants of health (SDOH). These departments provide essential resources such as funding, technical assistance, and connections between organizations with shared missions. Addressing SDOH is vital for reducing chronic disease disparities and promoting health equity. Through the Getting Further Faster (GFF) evaluation, 42 MCPs were studied to understand health departments' support. Findings indicated that health departments enhance MCPs' credibility, foster new relationships, and provide tangible resources. Marcus Plescia contributed as the chief medical officer at the Association of State and Territorial Officials (ASTHO), highlighting the importance of health departments in these initiatives. However, funding constraints and competing priorities sometimes limit collaboration. Effective support from health departments includes providing resources, training, technical assistance, and expertise to help MCPs implement and evaluate SDOH initiatives. Sufficient resources are necessary for health departments to manage core programs and respond to public health emergencies.

title: Florida's response to measles outbreak troubles public health experts |
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Florida's response to a recent measles outbreak has raised concerns among public health experts. The outbreak began in mid-February at Manatee Bay Elementary School in Broward County and has since spread to at least ten cases across two counties. Florida's surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, has not recommended vaccinations or quarantines for unvaccinated children, leaving the decision to parents. Dr. Ali Khan and Dr. Scott Rivkees emphasize the importance of following established public health guidelines to prevent further spread. Dr. Marcus Plescia, chief medical officer for the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, highlighted the high infectiousness of measles, stressing the risk posed to unvaccinated children. Plescia pointed out that 8% of kindergartners in Broward County are unvaccinated, posing a significant risk. Experts warn that ignoring public health advice could lead to more widespread disease outbreaks.

title: TikToks mystery virus trend: Genuine concern or social media hype
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: A TikTok trend has emerged with young users discussing a "mystery disease" with symptoms similar to COVID-19, despite negative tests for known viruses. Health experts attribute these symptoms to post-pandemic anxiety rather than a new virus. Georges Benjamin of the American Public Health Association dismisses the idea of a new threat, noting the symptoms align with common viruses. Marcus Plescia, Chief Medical Officer of the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, expects a rise in respiratory infections due to post-pandemic socializing. Plescia highlights the role of social media in spreading both hysteria and misinformation. The CDC reports a decline in COVID-19 cases and positive flu tests, but concerns about social media's impact on health information persist, with calls for platforms to combat misinformation.

title: COVID-19 lockdowns returning? Here's why public health experts say that's unlikely
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Public health experts deem the return of COVID-19 lockdowns or widespread mask mandates in the U.S. highly unlikely due to increased immunity from vaccinations and prior infections. Hospitalizations are rising but remain lower than previous peaks. Instead of broad mandates, individual institutions may temporarily require masks. Marcus Plescia, chief medical officer for the Association of State and Territorial Health Officials, highlighted that current conditions differ significantly from early pandemic stages when vaccines and treatments were unavailable. Experts agree that broad mandates would be ineffective and face legal and political challenges. Temporary measures by specific institutions are expected as new variants drive case increases.

title: Karen Winkfield named VICC director for Community Outreach and Engagement - VUMC News
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Karen Winkfield, MD, PhD, has been appointed as the associate director for Community Outreach and Engagement at Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center (VICC). Winkfield, also an Ingram Professor of Cancer Research and professor of Radiation Oncology, will lead VICC's community outreach and engagement initiatives. She is recognized for her expertise in addressing health disparities and promoting workforce diversity. Winkfield also serves as the executive director of the Meharry-Vanderbilt Alliance, enhancing collaborations to address health disparities. Appointed by President Joe Biden to the National Cancer Advisory Board in 2021, she chairs the subcommittee on population science, epidemiology, and disparities. Prior to Vanderbilt, she was at Wake Forest Baptist Comprehensive Cancer Center. She holds a BS in Biochemistry from Binghamton University, an MD, and a PhD in Pathology from Duke University, and completed her residency in the Harvard Radiation Oncology Program. She succeeds Debra Friedman in this role.

title: Karen Winkfield named a fellow of the American Society for Radiation Oncology - VUMC News
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Karen Winkfield, MD, PhD, executive director of the Meharry-Vanderbilt Alliance and professor of Radiation Oncology, has been named a fellow of the American Society for Radiation Oncology (ASTRO). This prestigious recognition will be officially conferred on October 3 during ASTRO’s annual meeting. Winkfield joins a distinguished group of only 450 fellows out of ASTRO's 10,000 members since the fellowship's inception in 2006. Each year, a select few are honored for their significant contributions to radiation oncology, cancer research, education, and patient care. Geraldine Jacobson, MD, MBA, MPH, chair of the ASTRO board of directors, congratulated Winkfield on her achievement and highlighted her inclusion among the 29 physicians and medical physicists recognized this year.

title: Episode 3: Cancer Survivorship and Sexual Health and Wellness
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Dr. Ann H. Partridge and Dr. Karen M. Winkfield discuss the often-overlooked topic of sexual health and cancer survivorship in a Medscape podcast. Dr. Winkfield, executive director of the Meharry-Vanderbilt Alliance and professor of radiation oncology at Vanderbilt University, emphasizes the importance of addressing sexual health with cancer patients, noting that many providers neglect this aspect due to lack of training or time constraints. She shares personal experiences highlighting the need for better education and resources for both providers and patients. Dr. Winkfield advocates for routine inquiries about sexual and intimate health, regardless of the patient's age or background, and stresses the importance of having a supportive healthcare team. She also highlights the unique challenges faced by minority and LGBTQ+ communities and the need for culturally sensitive care. The discussion underscores the necessity of integrating sexual health into cancer care to improve overall patient well-being.

title: Better cancer trials could be around the corner
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Tobias Janowitz and Clinical Fellow Hassal Lee have developed a new approach to make cancer trials more accessible and diverse. By using data from the U.S. Census Bureau and the National Trial Registry, they created population maps around high-volume cancer trial sites, revealing that these sites are often in affluent, less diverse neighborhoods. Their tool identifies nearby hospitals in more diverse communities to expand patient recruitment. Karen Winkfield, Executive Director of the Meharry-Vanderbilt Alliance and member of the National Cancer Advisory Board, co-authored the study. She emphasizes the importance of providing access to clinical trials in diverse communities and believes this tool could facilitate significant collaborations with community health centers and hospitals. The team aims to expand their analysis to other population segments and trials beyond cancer, hoping to streamline and diversify clinical trials.

title: How dogs helped Covenant School families heal; new treatment for chronic rhinosinusitis; and other news stories with ...
hco: AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETY CANCER ACTION NETWORK
summary: The text highlights various news stories with Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) sources. Former VUMC physician-in-chief Kimryn Rathmell, MD, is now director of the National Cancer Institute. Karen Winkfield, MD, PhD, a professor of Radiation Oncology, was quoted by Politico on diversifying participants in cancer trials. Evan Brittain, MD, discussed his study on genetic risk and obesity with People and National Geographic. Kathryn Edwards, MD, and Marie Griffin, MD, MPH, commented on the safety of the bivalent COVID-19 vaccine in MedPage Today. The New York Times reported on how dogs, including Squid from Monroe Carell Jr. Children’s Hospital, helped Covenant School families heal after a shooting. Rick Chandra, MD, was quoted in MedPage Today and Healio about a new treatment for chronic rhinosinusitis. WTVF News Channel 5 covered the Tennessee Poison Center's services, quoting Rebecca Bruccoleri, MD, during National Poison Prevention Week.

title: Human cytomegalovirus infection triggers a paracrine senescence loop in renal epithelial cells | Communications Biology
summary: Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection in renal proximal tubular epithelial cells (RPTECs) triggers a paracrine senescence loop, leading to organ-specific pathogenesis. RPTECs are fully permissive to HCMV replication, showing an inflammatory gene signature resembling the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP). This senescence is characterized by downregulation of LAMINB1 and KI67 mRNAs, and increased secretion of IL-6 and IL-8. HCMV-infected RPTECs can induce a similar senescence/inflammatory phenotype in neighboring uninfected cells via IL-6. This paracrine loop is not observed in human fibroblasts (HFFs) or retina-derived epithelial (ARPE-19) cells. Andrea Iannucci contributed to the study by performing transcriptomic analysis and participating in the intellectual discussions. This unique inflammatory loop may contribute to HCMV-related kidney disease.

title: A novel tumour enhancer function of Insulin-like growth factor II mRNA-binding protein 3 in colorectal cancer | Cell ...
summary: In the study "A novel tumour enhancer function of Insulin-like growth factor II mRNA-binding protein 3 in colorectal cancer," researchers investigated the role of IMP3 in colorectal cancer (CRC). IMP3, an RNA-binding protein, is highly expressed in CRC tissues and correlates with poor prognosis. The study analyzed IMP3 expression using public databases and human samples, revealing that its knockdown enhances caspase-independent cell death in CRC cell lines, without affecting key molecules involved in pyroptosis, ferroptosis, or necroptosis. IMP3 was found to bind Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL mRNAs, regulating the intrinsic apoptotic pathway. Andrea Iannucci contributed to the research, particularly in the experimental procedures. The findings suggest that IMP3 controls CRC cell survival and could be a potential target for therapeutic strategies.

title: Self-Adjuvanting TLR7/8 Agonist and Fentanyl Hapten Co-Conjugate Achieves Enhanced Protection against Fentanyl ...
summary: The study explores a novel approach to combat opioid use disorders (OUDs), particularly focusing on fentanyl, by developing a vaccine that combines a Toll-like receptor 7/8 (TLR7/8) agonist (UM-3006) with a fentanyl-based hapten (F1) on the carrier protein CRM197. This co-conjugation significantly enhances the generation of high-affinity fentanyl-specific antibodies, providing greater protection against fentanyl challenges in mice compared to an unconjugated adjuvant control. The inclusion of aluminum hydroxide (alum) further boosts antibody titers and protection, as evidenced by reduced fentanyl levels in serum and brain tissue. Jay T. Evans, Ph.D., contributed to this research, which underscores the potential of TLR7/8 agonist conjugates in enhancing anti-opioid vaccine efficacy, presenting a promising strategy for addressing OUDs.

title: A lipidated TLR7/8 adjuvant enhances the efficacy of a vaccine against fentanyl in mice | npj Vaccines
summary: The study addresses the opioid crisis in the U.S., particularly focusing on fentanyl-related overdoses. Researchers developed a fentanyl vaccine, incorporating a synthetic TLR7/8 agonist (INI-4001), which significantly increased the production of high-affinity fentanyl-specific antibodies in mice. The vaccine, when combined with alum, showed enhanced protection against fentanyl-induced effects, reducing drug distribution to the brain. Jay T. Evans, Ph.D., contributed significantly to this research, particularly in the development and testing of the TLR7/8 adjuvant. The study suggests that this vaccine could be an effective strategy against opioid use disorders and fatal overdoses.

title: Montana State to host immunologist Jay Evans for lecture on Nov. 7
summary: Montana State University will host immunologist Jay Evans for a lecture on Nov. 7 as part of the Hilleman Symposium Series. The event, free and open to the public, will take place at 2 p.m. in the Procrastinator Theater, followed by a reception. Evans, director of the Center for Translational Medicine at the University of Montana and co-founder of the biotechnology company Inimmune, will discuss “Bridging the Gap Between Innate and Adaptive Immunity.” His research focuses on vaccine and adjuvant development for various diseases. Mark Jutila, MSU Regents Professor in the Department of Microbiology and Cell Biology, praised Evans' cutting-edge work in vaccine development. Evans has a Ph.D. in molecular and cellular biology from Oregon State University and has researched responses to illnesses such as COVID-19 and influenza. More information on the MCB Seminar Series is available at montana.edu/mbi/MCBseminar.html.

title: Brother Bob Begley and Melinda White honored with Engroff Ostermeyer Legacy Award
summary: Brother Bob Begley and Melinda White were honored with the Engroff Ostermeyer Legacy Award for their dedication to the community's well-being. Presented by the Franklin Grand Isle Community Partnership, the award recognizes individuals who exemplify the legacies of John W. Engroff and Robert Ostermeyer. Begley, coordinator of Martha’s Community Kitchen, was acknowledged for his decade-long service in feeding and connecting local people, fostering a culture of empathy and belonging. White, a recovery coach supervisor with Turning Point of Franklin County, was commended for her commitment to supporting the recovery community and those returning from incarceration. Her personal experience with addiction and recovery has driven her to share success stories and volunteer extensively within the community. Both recipients were celebrated for their compassionate contributions and efforts in making a positive impact in Franklin and Grand Isle Counties.

title: Grateful JABSOM Alums Celebrate, Give Back, with Kūlike Kākou Gala
summary: Dr. Jaimie Tom and Dr. Shane Morita, alumni of the John A. Burns School of Medicine (JABSOM), celebrated their 25th anniversary with the Kūlike Kākou Gala. Dr. Tom, an Emergency Medicine physician, and Dr. Morita, Vice Chief of Staff and Medical Director of Surgical Oncology at The Queen's Medical Center, aimed to give back to their alma mater through this event. The gala, held at the Kahala Hotel & Resort, honored outgoing University of Hawaiʻi President David Lassner and raised approximately $250,000 for JABSOM's Rural and Neighbor Island Medical Education fund. The event featured performances by comedian Tumua Tuinei and singer Kamakakēhau Fernandez, and brought together healthcare professionals and community members to support rural health initiatives in Hawaiʻi. Dr. Morita emphasized the importance of community support and the impact of their medical training on their careers and personal lives.

title: Tumua at JABSOM's Kulike Kakou Gala in Honolulu
summary: The John A. Burns School of Medicine (JABSOM) held its Kulike Kakou gala at the Kahala Resort, headlined by local comedian Tumua Tuinei. The event aimed to provide relief to health professionals and support JABSOM's rural and neighbor island medical education fund, a cause close to Tumua's heart. Over 400 attendees enjoyed the evening, which emphasized the importance of laughter during tough times. The gala also honored U.H. President David Lassner, who is retiring. The event was organized by JABSOM alums, including Dr. Shane Morita, who, along with Dr. Jaimie Tom, aimed to give back to the university.

title: Health professionals cure burnout with laughter at JABSOM Kulike Kakou Gala
summary: The first Kulike Kakou Gala, aimed at alleviating stress and burnout among Hawaii's health professionals, was held at the Kahala Resort ballroom. Headlined by local comedian Tumua Tuinei, the event emphasized the healing power of laughter. Dr. Jaimie Tom and her husband, Dr. Shane Morita, co-chaired the event, which brought together over 400 attendees to celebrate the Aloha spirit and support JABSOM’s “Rural and Neighbor Island Medical Education Support Fund.” The gala also honored University of Hawaii President David Lassner, who is retiring, with a special proclamation from Governor Josh Green.

title: SOLD OUT: Kūlike Kākou Gala: Standing Together
summary: The Kūlike Kākou Gala: Standing Together, scheduled for April 13, 2024, at The Kahala Resort Maile Ballroom, is sold out. The event, organized by Dr. Jaimie Tom and Dr. Shane Morita in collaboration with the University of Hawaiʻi Foundation and the John A. Burns School of Medicine (JABSOM), will feature comedian Tumua Tuinei. The gala aims to honor UH President David Lassner and will include an evening of laughter, food, and fun. All net proceeds will benefit JABSOM's Rural/Neighbor Island Medical Education Fund. Despite being sold out, donations are still welcome to support the fund. For more details, contact kulikekakou2024@gmail.com.

title: American Oncology Network Expands to Hawaii, Welcomes New Practice to Network
summary: American Oncology Network (AON) has expanded its services to Hawaii by partnering with Hawaii Cancer Care. This collaboration aims to enhance cancer care accessibility and quality for the local community. Hawaii Cancer Care, which has clinics in Aiea and Honolulu, offers a range of treatments including chemotherapy, immunotherapy, and other targeted therapies. The medical team comprises Board-certified oncologists and hematologists such as Jon S. Fukumoto, MD, Melvin P. Palalay, MD, David J. Tamura, MD, and Arnold K. Yee, MD, MPH. AON's CEO Todd Schonherz emphasized the importance of partnering with independent practices to provide affordable and high-quality care. David J. Tamura, MD, along with his colleagues, will benefit from AON's resources to continue their patient-first care approach. Stephen "Fred" Divers, MD, AON’s chief medical officer, expressed eagerness to support Hawaii Cancer Care in delivering comprehensive cancer services.

title: National Cancer Institute's Director's Award for UH researcher | University of Hawaiʻi System News
summary: Christa Braun-Inglis, an Assistant Researcher at the University of Hawaiʻi Cancer Center, received the National Cancer Institute’s (NCI) Director’s Award for her significant contributions to expanding the role of Advanced Practice Providers (APPs) in cancer clinical trials. Recognizing the barriers faced by APPs, Braun-Inglis led a nationwide survey in 2020 that identified systemic issues such as policy restrictions and lack of training. Her efforts led to a policy change by the NCI in September 2021, allowing APPs to fully utilize their credentials, enroll patients in supportive care trials, and prescribe medications. This has increased APP participation in NCI-sponsored trials and improved patient access to clinical trials, particularly in rural areas. Braun-Inglis continues to lead national initiatives to integrate APP working groups through a five-year grant supported by The Hope Foundation for Cancer Research.

title: UH cancer scientist's passion leads to national changes, community award | University of Hawaiʻi System News
summary: Christa Braun-Inglis, a researcher at the University of Hawaiʻi Cancer Center, received the 2024 David King Community Clinical Scientist Award from the Association of Community Cancer Centers (ACCC). She was honored for her dedication to cancer research and education, particularly her efforts to help advanced practice providers (APPs) participate in clinical trials. Her work has led to significant national policy changes, expanding the roles of APPs in National Cancer Institute (NCI) clinical trials. Braun-Inglis has focused on increasing diversity, optimizing cancer care delivery, and specializing in areas such as breast cancer. Her proposal for an APP and clinical trials survey, endorsed by the ACCC, initiated these policy changes and a new care delivery research concept. She was recognized at the ACCC's 50th Annual Meeting and Cancer Center Business Summit in Washington, D.C.

title: ACCC AMCCBS 2024: On Location Interviews, Day 2
summary: The 2024 Association of Cancer Care Centers (ACCC) 50th Annual Meeting & Cancer Center Business Summit (AMCCBS) featured interviews with Katherine Meese, PhD, and Nadine Barrett, PhD, MS, MPH, discussing topics such as workforce sustainability and health equity. On day 2, Hayden Klein, associate editor at AJMC, highlighted Meese's keynote on managing health care workforce turnover and burnout. Barrett provided insights into the ACCC president's theme and her research on health equity. The event also included a panel on 4R care sequences and awarded Robert A. Winn, MD, the 2024 clinical research award. Christa Braun-Inglis, DNP, APRN, FNP-BC, AOCNP, received the 2024 David King Community Clinical Scientist Award for her contributions as a nurse practitioner and assistant researcher at the University of Hawaii Cancer Center. Further coverage and interviews are available at AJMC.com.

title: Breast cancer: Improving survival, access to treatment for rural patients | University of Hawaiʻi System News
summary: The University of Hawaiʻi Cancer Center is conducting research to improve breast cancer treatment access for rural patients in Hawaiʻi, where breast cancer is the most common cancer among women and the second leading cause of cancer death. The research, led by Izumi Okado and funded by the Hawaiʻi Community Foundation Robert C. Perry Fund, builds on a 2020 study highlighting treatment delays for neighbor island patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly 43% of these patients travel to Oʻahu for treatment, facing barriers like increased costs and extended time away from family. Okado, along with researchers Jeffrey Berenberg, Brenda Hernandez, Lenora Loo, and Christa Braun-Inglis, aims to design interventions to reduce treatment delays and foster inter-island collaborations. These efforts seek to address cancer health disparities and improve survival outcomes for rural breast cancer patients.

title: Dr Richardson on the UPLIFT Trial of Upifitamab Rilsodotin in Ovarian Cancer
summary: Dr. Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, discussed the outcomes of the UPLIFT trial involving upifitamab rilsodotin (UpRi) for ovarian cancer at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer. The phase 1/2 trial aimed to demonstrate sufficient efficacy of UpRi in treating platinum-resistant serous ovarian cancer, targeting an objective response rate (ORR) exceeding 12%, comparable to standard chemotherapy. UpRi, an antibody-drug conjugate targeting NaPi2b, aimed to offer a new treatment option with fewer toxicities. However, the trial showed an ORR of 15.6% in the NaPi2b-positive subgroup and 13.1% overall, falling short of the efficacy threshold. Consequently, the development of UpRi was discontinued. Dr. Richardson emphasized the challenges in translating preclinical success to clinical outcomes, highlighting the need for continued research in platinum-resistant ovarian cancer treatments.

title: Dr Richardson on the Safety of Upifitamab Rilsodotin in Platinum-Resistant Ovarian Cancer
summary: Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, discussed the safety profile of upifitamab rilsodotin in the phase 1/2 UPLIFT trial for patients with platinum-resistant ovarian cancer. The trial revealed an overall response rate (ORR) of 15.6% in NaPi2b-positive patients, which did not meet the primary endpoint, leading to the discontinuation of the drug's development. Richardson highlighted the manageable adverse effect profile, noting common grade 1/2 toxicities such as elevated aspartate aminotransferase, nausea, fatigue, anemia, and decreased platelet count, with pneumonitis occurring in 9.6% of patients. However, grade 5 bleeding events necessitated vigilant monitoring. Additionally, Richardson mentioned other promising research presented at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting, including studies on raludotatug deruxtecan and avutometinib, which offer new therapeutic avenues in ovarian cancer treatment.

title: Dr Richardson on the Efficacy of Selinexor in TP53 Wild-Type Endometrial Cancer
summary: Dr. Debra L. Richardson, associate professor and chief of the Section of Gynecologic Oncology at the University of Oklahoma, discussed the efficacy of selinexor in treating TP53 wild-type advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. The phase 3 ENGOT-EN5/GOG-3055/SIENDO trial evaluated selinexor as maintenance therapy, revealing no significant improvement in median progression-free survival (PFS) in the overall population. However, a subgroup analysis showed a notable PFS benefit for patients with TP53 wild-type endometrial cancer. Selinexor, an XPO1 inhibitor, blocks the export of tumor suppressor proteins, potentially correlating with p53 functionality. Richardson emphasized the need for further validation through randomized trials, with the ongoing phase 3 XPORT-EC-042 trial aiming to confirm these findings and explore selinexor's efficacy across different molecular profiles.

title: Journey Ends for Upifitamab Rilsodotin in NaPi2b+ Platinum-Resistant Ovarian Cancer
summary: Upifitamab rilsodotin (UpRi; XMT-1536), a NaPi2b-directed antibody-drug conjugate, showed modest activity in NaPi2b-positive patients with platinum-resistant high-grade serous ovarian cancer, failing to meet the primary endpoint of the phase 1/2 UPLIFT trial. Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, reported that the overall response rate (ORR) was 15.6% in NaPi2b-positive cases and 10.2% in NaPi2b-low cases. The intention-to-treat population had an ORR of 13.1%. Due to the failure to achieve the primary objective, the development of upifitamab rilsodotin was discontinued. Richardson, an associate professor and chief of the Section of Gynecologic Oncology at Stephenson Cancer Center, discussed the trial's rationale, efficacy, safety profile, and other significant research at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer.

title: clinicians named in Seattle Met Magazine’s 2023 Top Doctors list | Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center
summary: Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center announced that over 90 of its physicians, physician assistants, and nurse practitioners were named in Seattle Met Magazine’s 2023 Top Doctors list. The list recognizes clinicians across more than 20 practice areas, including hematology/oncology, breast, gynecologic oncology, and cancer surgery. Renata R. Urban, MD, was among those honored in the gynecologic oncology specialty. The selection criteria included years of experience, competency, patient rapport, and ability to collaborate effectively with colleagues. Dr. Nancy Davidson, executive vice president for clinical affairs, praised the clinical staff's skills, collaborative spirit, and compassion. The "Top Doctors" list, now in its 18th year, features the best health practitioners in the Seattle area, chosen by their peers for their excellence in patient care.

title: Curebound announces $6 million in grant funding
summary: Curebound, a San Diego-based philanthropic organization, has announced a $6 million investment in grant funding for oncology research. This funding will support 17 collaborative research projects across six San Diego institutions, focusing on prevention, diagnostics, novel therapies, immunotherapies, cancer equities, and pediatric cancers. The 2023 Cure Prize, the highest award for bold innovation in cancer research, was awarded to UC San Diego researchers Rebecca Rakow-Penner, MD, PhD; Anders Dale, PhD; and Michael McHale, MD. Their project aims to develop an advanced diffusion MRI protocol for early detection of ovarian cancer in high-risk patients, potentially improving outcomes and reducing the need for prophylactic surgeries. This initiative aligns with Curebound’s mission to accelerate cancer cures through innovative research.

title: Social Determinants of Health Linked With Varying Cervical Cancer Rates in the US
summary: Social determinants of health, such as poverty, race, and access to early-stage treatment, contribute to geographical variations in cervical cancer rates in the US. Tara Castellano, MD, emphasized that these factors lead to disparities in cervical cancer outcomes, particularly in regions with higher poverty levels and limited access to modern treatments. Castellano and colleagues presented findings at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting showing decreased screening and increased cancer burden in low-income areas. The Cervical Cancer Geo-Analyzer tool was developed to visualize these disparities and assist in resource allocation. Castellano, an assistant professor at Louisiana State University, highlighted the need for optimized healthcare resources and education to minimize these disparities. The study revealed significant associations between poverty, race, and cervical cancer burden, with higher screening rates linked to reduced burden in certain regions. The presence of brachytherapy centers also correlated with lower recurrent/metastatic cancer rates.

title: Targeted Pulse: Social Determinants Link to Cervical Cancer, FDA News, and More
summary: This week's Targeted Pulse covers recent developments in cervical cancer, the FDA ODAC's vote for cilta-cel, and more. The combination of nivolumab and ipilimumab has shown improved overall survival for advanced hepatocellular cancer patients. A study presented at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting highlighted that low-income regions have lower screening rates and higher cervical cancer burdens. Tara Castellano, MD, emphasized the need to optimize healthcare resources and minimize disparities. The POSEIDON trial update showed long-term survival benefits for a triplet therapy in non-small cell lung cancer. The TRANSCEND CLL 004 study supports lisocabtagene maraleucel for relapsed/refractory CLL or SLL. The FDA's ODAC favored cilta-cel for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma, despite some concerns.

title: Louisiana actress brings awareness to ovarian cancer treatment | wwltv.com
summary: Louisiana actress Kathi Callahan, diagnosed with stage 3 metastatic ovarian cancer, is working to raise awareness about ovarian cancer treatment. She will join other survivors at the Royal Teal Tea luncheon on September 27 to support patients and advance research. Dr. Tara Castellano, a gynecologic oncologist at LSU Health Sciences Center, emphasized the importance of regular pelvic exams and seeing a specialized oncologist for ovarian cancer treatment, which can improve survival rates and reduce recurrence. Castellano highlighted that BRCA gene mutations increase the risk of ovarian cancer and that symptoms often appear late, making early detection challenging.

title: Donate to Help needed for medical treatment., organized by Christine Walsh
summary: Christine Walsh is organizing a fundraiser to raise $5,000 for lifesaving radiation treatment for Cholangiocarcinoma, a deadly cancer. Diagnosed on March 4, 2021, she has undergone chemo, surgery, and radiation. However, two lymph nodes still need treatment, requiring travel and accommodation expenses for a 3-week stay at MD Anderson. Her personal resources are depleted after two years of medical expenses. Despite the challenges, Christine has seen significant improvements in her condition, attributing her progress to divine intervention and the support of her community. She expresses immense gratitude to all who have supported her journey.

title: Genome-wide association analyses of ovarian cancer patients undergoing primary debulking surgery identify ...
summary: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) on 7,705 ovarian cancer patients undergoing primary debulking surgery identified genetic variants associated with residual disease, highlighting MGMT and PPP2R5C genes. The study found a significant association between rs72845444 near MGMT and resection status, and PPP2R5C gene variants correlated with methylation, transcript levels, and progression-free survival in patients with residual disease. PPP2R5C mRNA levels were predictive of progression-free survival, suggesting inherited genetic factors influence residual disease. Amanika Kumar contributed to the research and analysis. The findings suggest potential predictive markers for surgical outcomes and patient prognosis in ovarian cancer.

title: Mayo Clinic pilot study pinpoints resectable high-grade serous ovarian cancer
summary: In a pilot study at Mayo Clinic, Dr. Amanika Kumar and her team discovered that combining CT scans with tumor molecular subtyping offers crucial pre-surgical insights for patients with advanced-stage high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC). This method helps identify patients unlikely to benefit from complex surgeries, enhancing decision-making for both surgeons and patients. Published in Gynecologic Oncology in 2022, the study emphasizes that achieving no gross residual disease post-surgery significantly improves patient outcomes. Dr. Kumar advocates for high-quality surgery and suggests that upfront surgery, if successful, yields better results than chemotherapy alone. She also highlights the potential of AI in improving resectability predictions and calls for further studies to validate these findings.

title: Indo-Asian News Service-IEHP EARNS NCQA HEALTH EQUITY ACCREDITATION
summary: Inland Empire Health Plan (IEHP) has received Health Equity Accreditation from the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA), becoming the second public health plan in California to achieve this status. This accreditation acknowledges IEHP's commitment to addressing health care disparities and improving community health outcomes. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, praised the achievement, emphasizing the importance of eliminating racial and ethnic disparities in health care to enhance overall quality. IEHP's Vice President Lorena Chandler highlighted that the accreditation process underscored the organization's strong foundation in health equity. This recognition aligns with IEHP's mission to support over 1.6 million residents in Riverside and San Bernardino counties. The accreditation is also a requirement for IEHP's participation in Covered California's health care exchange, with renewal needed every three years.

title: UniCare Health Plan of West Virginia First in the State to Earn NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
