summary: UniCare Health Plan of West Virginia has become the first in the state to earn the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its commitment to addressing health disparities among socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This new accreditation builds on UniCare’s previous Health Equity Accreditation, recognizing its data-driven approach to identifying and addressing social needs through partnerships with community-based organizations. UniCare’s innovative programs include culturally relevant maternal health services, chronic condition interventions, mobile dental services, and more. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, praised UniCare’s efforts, stating that organizations like UniCare are crucial in bridging healthcare quality gaps caused by racial and ethnic disparities.

title: Wellpoint Washington Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Wellpoint Washington Inc., previously Amerigroup Washington Inc., has received the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its dedication to health equity. This accreditation acknowledges Wellpoint’s efforts to address health disparities among socioeconomically marginalized individuals in Washington. Wellpoint's president, Anthony E. Woods, emphasized the importance of this milestone in advancing health equity through innovative programs. The accreditation builds on last year's Health Equity Accreditation, recognizing Wellpoint’s strategic framework for prioritizing health equity across various demographics. The new accreditation also acknowledges Wellpoint’s data-driven approach to identifying social needs and collaborating with community-based organizations. Wellpoint's Find Help tool aids members in locating community resources. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, praised Wellpoint for leading efforts to bridge racial and ethnic healthcare disparities. The NCQA is a nonprofit organization focused on improving healthcare quality and provides various accreditations and certifications to healthcare organizations.

title: Health Affairs Briefing: Rational Health Care Spending Growth – Can We Get There From Here?
summary: Health Affairs held a special forum on February 3, 2023, to explore strategies for moderating health care spending growth in the US. The event, chaired by William H. Frist and Margaret A. Hamburg, featured discussions on four key levers: administrative streamlining, price regulation and competition support, spending growth targets, and value-based payment. The forum included input from experts like David M. Cutler, Mark V. Pauly, John M. Colmers, and Jennifer L. Kowalski. Margaret E. O’Kane contributed to the discussions, emphasizing the importance of value-based care and efficient spending. The initiative, supported by the National Pharmaceutical Council and Elevance Health, aimed to address the high levels and growth rates of US health spending compared to other developed nations with better health outcomes.

title: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Indiana Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield in Indiana has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its commitment to addressing health disparities among socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This new accreditation recognizes Anthem's innovative programs that provide personalized care and collaborate with community-based organizations to improve health outcomes. Anthem's efforts include a dedicated team addressing social needs, a Social Determinants of Health Case Management program, and community health workers. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, praised Anthem's leadership in bridging racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare, emphasizing their role in advancing health equity.

title: Vivid Clear Rx Earns Utilization Management Accreditation from the National Committee for Quality Assurance
summary: Vivid Clear Rx, a national pharmacy benefit manager, has earned the Utilization Management Accreditation from the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA). This accreditation recognizes organizations that improve service quality and consumer protection. Jessica Ringena, president of Vivid Clear Rx, emphasized the company's commitment to providing affordable pharmacy benefits and high-quality service. Margaret E. O’Kane, president of NCQA, highlighted that Vivid Clear Rx meets the strictest quality standards in utilization management. Founded in 2020, Vivid Clear Rx offers an extensive network of over 62,000 pharmacies and is dedicated to transparent pricing and exceptional customer service. The company is known for its high net promoter score of 97.

title: Wellpoint Maryland Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Wellpoint Maryland has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, recognizing its commitment to addressing health disparities and providing equitable, high-quality healthcare to marginalized communities. This accolade highlights Wellpoint’s data-driven approach to identifying and addressing social needs, enabling personalized services and collaborations with community-based organizations to improve health outcomes. Dr. Darrell Gray, II, President of Wellpoint Maryland, emphasized the importance of health equity in their mission. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, commended Wellpoint Maryland for leading efforts to bridge healthcare gaps caused by racial and ethnic disparities. This achievement positions Wellpoint as the first and only Medicaid managed care organization in Maryland to receive this advanced accreditation, underscoring its innovative programs and dedication to whole-person health.

title: Healthy Blue Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Healthy Blue Missouri has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, recognizing its efforts to provide equitable, high-quality healthcare to socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This accreditation highlights Healthy Blue's commitment to eliminating health disparities and improving health outcomes through innovative, data-driven programs. These include partnerships with community-based organizations (CBOs) and new services like doula support for high-risk pregnancies. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, acknowledged the significance of this achievement, emphasizing that organizations like Healthy Blue are leading efforts to bridge racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare.

title: Wellpoint New Jersey, Inc. Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Wellpoint New Jersey, Inc. has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its commitment to health equity and addressing the needs of socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This recognition builds on the previous Health Equity Accreditation Designation and emphasizes Wellpoint’s data-driven approach to identifying social needs and creating personalized services to combat health disparities. The company collaborates with community-based organizations and state partners to improve health outcomes, particularly in maternal and child health. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, acknowledged Wellpoint’s role in bridging racial and ethnic healthcare gaps, commending their dedication to health equity.

title: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its commitment to health equity and addressing the needs of socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This new accreditation builds on the previous Health Equity Accreditation, recognizing Anthem's data-driven approach to identify social needs and develop personalized services. Anthem's partnerships, such as with Food Bank For New York City’s ‘Food as Medicine’ program, aim to improve food security and health outcomes. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, praised Anthem for leading efforts to bridge racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare.

title: Anthem Blue Cross in California Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Anthem Blue Cross in California has received the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its dedication to health equity and addressing the needs of socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This accreditation builds on a previous designation, recognizing Anthem’s strategic framework to prioritize health equity across various demographics. Anthem uses a data-driven approach to identify social needs and develop personalized services, including its Find Help tool for locating community resources. Margaret E. O’Kane, President of NCQA, commended Anthem for leading efforts to bridge racial and ethnic disparities in healthcare.

title: Wellpoint Texas Earns NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus
summary: Wellpoint Texas has earned the NCQA Health Equity Accreditation Plus, highlighting its commitment to equitable, high-quality healthcare for socioeconomically marginalized individuals. This new accreditation builds on the previous Health Equity Accreditation, recognizing Wellpoint’s strategic framework to address health equity across various demographics. Wellpoint’s data-driven approach collects information on social needs to develop personalized services and collaborate with community-based organizations, thereby improving health outcomes. Initiatives like doula pilot projects aim to enhance maternal and child health, particularly among Black women. Margaret E. O’Kane, NCQA President, commended Wellpoint’s efforts in reducing racial and ethnic healthcare disparities.

title: Spatially Health Appoints Tom Fluegel to Advisory Board to Foster Advancements and Expansion in Healthcare
summary: Spatially Health has appointed Tom Fluegel to its Advisory Board to advance healthcare innovation and expansion. Fluegel, with over 25 years of leadership experience in the healthcare industry, will be instrumental in shaping the company's strategic vision and decision-making. His expertise includes quality improvement and addressing social determinants of health (SDOH). Previously, he served as Chief Operating Officer for the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) and held various leadership roles at UnitedHealth Group and Cigna. Spatially Health, a cloud-based platform focused on health equity, aims to leverage Fluegel's experience to tackle rising healthcare costs, access issues, and care inequities. CEO Dr. Hillit Meidar-Alfi emphasized Fluegel's crucial role in enhancing the company's influence and trajectory.

title: Chutes & Ladders—ABOUT Healthcare CEO departs for Kalderos
summary: Jonathan Shoemaker has been appointed as the new CEO of ABOUT Healthcare, succeeding Angie Franks effective September 25. Shoemaker brings 25 years of experience in healthcare operations and information systems, previously serving at Allina Health. Angie Franks, the outgoing CEO of ABOUT Healthcare, has taken up the CEO position at Kalderos, replacing Brent Dover. Kalderos specializes in drug discount management using machine learning. Upperline Health has named four new executives, including CFO Jin Zou and COO Marcus Moreno. DocGo promoted Lee Bienstock to president and CEO following Anthony Capone's resignation. Additionally, Spatially Health has appointed Tom Fluegel, COO for the National Committee for Quality Assurance, to its advisory board. Several other leadership changes were announced across various healthcare organizations, including Lifepoint Health, Abridge, Wolters Kluwer, and Seattle Children’s, among others.

title: ISPOR 2024 Plenaries and Speakers Announced
summary: ISPOR, the Professional Society for Health Economics and Outcomes Research, announced the plenary sessions and speakers for ISPOR 2024, its annual international conference, to be held May 5-8 in Atlanta, GA, USA. The conference will focus on the theme “HEOR: A Transformative Force for Whole Health” and will gather nearly 5000 healthcare stakeholders globally. Plenary sessions will address whole health and improved healthcare decision-making. Eric C. Schneider, MD, MSc, FACP from the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) will contribute to the first plenary session, "Advancing Whole Health: How Do We Know When We’re Succeeding?" on May 6, discussing innovation in whole-person health and evaluation gaps. Other sessions will cover real-world data integration and the role of AI in HEOR and health technology assessment. Two colocated events, the Patient-Centered Research Summit and the HEOR Short Course Program, will precede the conference.

title: How to introduce quality measures that are useful for providers
summary: The healthcare industry is striving to reduce the administrative burden of quality measures on providers while ensuring these measures provide useful data. Brad Ryan, MD, chief growth officer at NCQA, highlights the need for transformation in quality measures, particularly with the advent of digital measures. He notes that CMS's Meaningful Measures Initiative reduced the burden by 3 million hours, yet value-based care efforts like MIPS have increased administrative tasks. Ryan argues for reimagining quality measures to better reflect physician experiences and the specific needs of patient populations. He emphasizes the importance of digital transformation in reducing costs, improving quality use cases, and creating more relevant measures. Ryan also points out the necessity of aligning quality measures across different value-based contracts to reduce variation and enhance the provider's understanding of quality metrics.

title: Democratizing HEDIS with open source CQL
summary: Edward Yurcisin, the chief technology officer at the NCQA, is utilizing the organization's open-source Clinical Quality Language (CQL) engine to digitize HEDIS measures. This initiative aims to enhance the quality of healthcare in the U.S. and internationally by integrating with FHIR standards.

title: Researchers look for answers to the mysteries of long COVID
summary: Researchers are investigating the persistent symptoms of long COVID, which include extreme fatigue, shortness of breath, brain fog, and heart and lung issues. Dr. Sarah Jolley from the Colorado School of Medicine directs the UCHealth Post-COVID Clinic at CU Anschutz, while Dr. Irina Petrache from National Jewish Health in Denver is also at the forefront of this research. Dr. Petrache and her team are exploring the potential causes of these lingering symptoms, contributing significantly to the understanding and treatment of long COVID.

title: A look back at the COVID pandemic
summary: As the United States officially ends the coronavirus pandemic emergency, In Focus host Mike Kallmeyer interviewed Dr. Raed Dweik, chair of the Respiratory Institute at the Cleveland Clinic, to review the past few years. Dr. Dweik commended Ohio's response to the pandemic, noting that despite initial uncertainties about COVID-19, the state effectively learned from experiences in Asia and other U.S. cities. He highlighted that Ohio set a commendable example in managing the pandemic. Dr. Dweik also mentioned that the respiratory unit at Cleveland Clinic is now refocusing on care that was deferred due to the pandemic.

title: Sleep Apnea Identification and Treatment
summary: The Cleveland Clinic's Respiratory Exchange Podcast, hosted by Raed A. Dweik, MD, focuses on sleep apnea identification and treatment. In the episode, sleep experts Loutfi Aboussouan, MD, and Reena Mehra, MD, discuss the importance of recognizing symptoms such as snoring, gasping, and daytime sleepiness. They emphasize the use of the STOP-BANG tool for quick assessment and recommend home sleep tests or polysomnography for diagnosis. CPAP is highlighted as the first-line treatment, with alternatives like oral appliances and hypoglossal nerve stimulation for specific cases. Dr. Dweik underscores the significance of treating sleep apnea due to its prevalence and associated health risks.

title: On the Job: Identifying Occupational Lung Disease
summary: Occupational lung disease encompasses a wide range of work-related respiratory conditions, such as black lung, silicosis, and occupational asthma. These diseases can arise from both historical and current job exposures. Dr. Raed A. Dweik, Chairman of the Respiratory Institute at Cleveland Clinic, hosts the Respiratory Exchange podcast, which delves into these topics. In an episode featuring Dr. Maeve MacMurdo, the discussion highlights the importance of taking a comprehensive occupational history to identify potential lung diseases. This includes not just current jobs but past employment and conditions of work. Early detection and removal from exposure can slow disease progression and improve outcomes. The podcast underscores that occupational lung diseases remain prevalent and that new exposures continue to emerge. Dr. Dweik emphasizes the value of consulting specialists for accurate diagnosis and management.

title: RSV in Children
summary: Dr. Kimberly Gifford, a primary care pediatrician at Cleveland Clinic Children's, discusses respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in children on the Respiratory Inspirations podcast. She explains RSV’s impact on the body, noting it primarily affects the lungs and can cause symptoms like fever, runny nose, and trouble breathing. This year has seen a surge in RSV cases due to reduced immunity from prior mask-wearing. Dr. Gifford emphasizes prevention through good hygiene and the potential future availability of a vaccine. For treatment, she recommends mucus clearance and oxygen for severe cases. Dr. Raed Dweik, chairman of the Respiratory Institute at Cleveland Clinic, hosts the podcast, emphasizing the importance of understanding respiratory health and disease.

title: Where Are They? Patients with Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency
summary: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition that often goes unrecognized and can predispose individuals to COPD, emphysema, and liver disease. Dr. James Stoller, an expert on the subject, discusses its under-recognition, pathogenesis, and clinical manifestations. He emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis through a simple blood test, as delayed recognition worsens clinical outcomes. Effective therapies, including augmentation therapy with pooled human plasma-derived alpha-1 antitrypsin, exist and can slow disease progression. Dr. Raed Dweik, the podcast host and Chairman of the Respiratory Institute at Cleveland Clinic, highlights the genetic nature of the disease, which necessitates family testing. Novel treatments such as gene editing and corrector molecules are also being investigated, offering hope for future advancements.

title: Burn Pit Exposure
summary: The Cleveland Clinic's Respiratory Exchange Podcast, hosted by Dr. Raed A. Dweik, focuses on burn pit exposure and its impact on military personnel. Burn pits, used to dispose of waste during deployments, have been linked to serious lung diseases like asthma, interstitial lung disease, and constrictive bronchiolitis. Drs. Maeve MacMurdo and Neha Solanki discuss the health risks, challenges in diagnosing these conditions, and the importance of thorough medical history and evaluation. The recently passed PACT Act acknowledges the health hazards of burn pits, expanding VA coverage for affected veterans. Dr. Dweik emphasizes the need for both healthcare providers and veterans to be proactive in recognizing and addressing deployment-related lung diseases. The Cleveland Clinic offers specialized testing and care for these conditions, advocating for comprehensive evaluation and support for veterans.

title: Providence nurses in Portland and Seaside plan 5-day strike starting Monday
summary: About 1,800 Providence nurses in Portland and Seaside plan to strike for five days starting Monday, prompting the health system to move patients, delay surgeries, and bring in temporary staff. Contract negotiations broke down for nurses at Providence Portland Medical Center, Providence Seaside Hospital, and Providence Home Health and Hospice. Nurse Kimberly Martin emphasized the need for better working conditions, sick leave, and pay. Providence Portland Medical Center, which usually cares for up to 400 patients daily, is rescheduling surgeries and transferring patients from specialty units. Chief Executive Krista Farnham warned of potential long wait times in the emergency department and advised seeking alternative care if possible. Both hospitals will continue to see emergency patients.

title: Providence nurses strike expected to begin Monday
summary: About 1,800 Providence nurses in Portland and Seaside plan to strike next week, demanding better pay, more paid time off, and improved working conditions. This strike, expected to last five days, will impact two hospitals and Providence’s home health and hospice teams. If it proceeds, it will be the first nurses strike in Portland in over 20 years. The Oregon Nurses Association and Providence have ceased negotiations, leading to the strike. Providence Portland Medical Center, led by Chief Executive Krista Farnham, is preparing by transferring patients to other hospitals and canceling scheduled surgeries. Farnham emphasized efforts to ensure patient safety and expressed hope for continued conversations post-strike. Nurses are concerned about patient care and are seeking respect, better compensation, and improved working conditions. The central issues include wages, paid time off, and productivity targets. Providence has offered raises and better paid leave, but negotiations remain stalled.

title: Providence cuts services in Seaside and Portland as nurses prepare to strike
summary: Providence Health & Services is preparing for a potential five-day strike by nearly 2,000 nurses and allied workers in Portland and Seaside due to unresolved negotiations with the Oregon Nurses Association. The health system is delaying surgical procedures, relocating patients, and hiring temporary staff to minimize disruptions. Krista Farnham, Providence Portland Medical Center's chief executive, emphasized the hospital's commitment to patient care and readiness for the strike. She stated, "Our nurses are incredible... we will welcome them back on Saturday after the strike." The strike, the first in over 20 years, stems from disputes over wages, staffing levels, and patient care. Providence has offered significant contract proposals, but the union remains focused on addressing chronic staff shortages and improving working conditions.

title: Dr Johnson on the Initial Efficacy of Ifinatamab Deruxtecan in Refractory SCLC
summary: Melissa L. Johnson, MD, presented findings on the efficacy of ifinatamab deruxtecan (I-DXd; DS-7300) in patients with refractory small cell lung cancer (SCLC) at the 2023 IASLC World Conference on Lung Cancer. A phase 1/2 trial assessed I-DXd in heavily pretreated patients with various advanced solid tumors. The subgroup analysis focused on response rates, survival outcomes, and B7-H3 expression in the SCLC cohort. Results showed robust, durable responses in patients treated with 6.4 mg/kg or less of I-DXd, with an objective response rate of 52.4%, median duration of response of 5.9 months, progression-free survival of 5.6 months, and overall survival of 12.2 months. No new safety signals were observed, and the regimen was tolerable. B7-H3 expression was moderate to high, but no correlation with response, survival, or progression-free survival was found. Future studies are needed to confirm these findings.

title: Eastern Oklahoma VA holds personal goals for 2024 event - VA News
summary: The Eastern Oklahoma VA held an event titled "Whole New Year, Whole New You!" on February 18, 2024, to help Veterans and staff set personal goals for the year. The event, coordinated by multiple departments including Healthy Living, Whole Health, and Tobacco Cessation, aimed to provide education, encouragement, and resources to assist in reaching these goals. Joan McWilliams, Whole Health coordinator, initiated the event at the Jack C. Montgomery VA in Muskogee. Melissa Johnson, Health Behavior coordinator, expressed excitement over the turnout of about 70 participants and highlighted the positive feedback received. Johnson noted the event's success in fostering connections and providing support, with plans to expand it to more sites in 2025.

title: January 10, 2024: In This Friday's PCT Grand Rounds, a Lottery for Allocating Scarce COVID-19 Resources
summary: On January 12, 2024, Erin McCreary from the University of Pittsburgh will present at the PCT Grand Rounds on the topic "Design and Implementation of a Weighted Lottery to Equitably Allocate Scarce COVID-19 Resources." McCreary, a clinical assistant professor of medicine and director of infectious diseases improvement and clinical research innovation at UPMC, will discuss strategies for fair allocation of limited COVID-19 resources. She is also the president-elect of the Society of Infectious Diseases Pharmacists. The session will be held online at 1:00 pm eastern.

title: Weighted lottery helped low-income patients get Covid drug - STAT
summary: During the 2021 Covid-19 surge, UPMC health system in Pittsburgh received 450 doses of Evusheld, a scarce antibody cocktail for immunocompromised patients. With 200,000 patients needing the drug, Erin McCreary, an infectious disease pharmacist at UPMC, led a team to devise a fair distribution method. They implemented a weighted lottery, prioritizing patients from disadvantaged neighborhoods. This approach increased the allocation to these areas from 17% to 29%. However, only 7% of Black patients received the drug compared to 29% of white patients, highlighting persistent disparities. McCreary emphasized that while the weighted lottery was a step towards equitable distribution, more comprehensive efforts are needed to address deep-rooted inequalities in healthcare.

title: Deconstructing Long-Held Antibiotic Prescribing Myths
summary: Long-held antibiotic prescribing practices are often passed down from instructors to learners, despite evolving scientific literature. Erin K. McCreary, PharmD, BCPS, BCIDP, emphasizes the importance of challenging these traditional beliefs. As the first author of a study published in the Clinical Infectious Diseases journal, McCreary discusses how antibiotic myths, such as avoiding cefazolin for CNS infections, persist without definitive supporting evidence. She advocates for a culture of trust, humility, and openness to new data among clinicians. The study's inspiration came from a Twitter discussion initiated by Jason C. Gallagher, PharmD, which prompted McCreary and others to compile and scrutinize these myths. McCreary highlights the need for continuous learning and adapting to updated scientific information to improve prescribing practices.

title: Health system program improves equity in allocation of scarce medication, but reveals needed improvements
summary: A program by the University of Pittsburgh and UPMC aimed at equitable allocation of scarce medication, specifically Evusheld, showed feasibility in a large health system. The program used a weighted lottery to prioritize patients from disadvantaged neighborhoods, significantly improving equity in drug receipt. Despite this, challenges remain in contacting and gaining the trust of Black patients, who received the drug at lower rates than their white counterparts. Erin McCreary, Pharm.D., emphasized the distinction between equitable allocation and receipt, highlighting the need for continued efforts to bridge racial equity gaps. The study underscores the importance of removing barriers to healthcare access.

title: Who can get the new infant RSV immunization? Here's what the CDC says – Deseret News
summary: The CDC recommended a new RSV immunization for all children under 8 months old, but due to limited supplies, priority is now given to infants under 6 months with chronic conditions. Whitney Buckel, an infectious diseases pharmacist at Intermountain Health, highlighted the challenges posed by the shortage. Intermountain Health is prioritizing neonatal intensive care unit patients and hopes to extend the treatment to babies under 11 pounds soon. Buckel emphasized the importance of promoting RSV vaccines for pregnant women to protect infants. The shortage is disappointing for parents and healthcare providers, who must now decide which infants receive the treatment.

title: Association between physician continuity of care and patient outcomes in clinical teaching units: a cohort analysis
summary: This study investigates the impact of physician continuity on patient outcomes in clinical teaching units (CTUs) across three Calgary hospitals from 2015 to 2017. It examines the association between the number of attending physicians a patient sees and outcomes such as ICU admission, readmission, and mortality. The findings reveal no significant differences in patient outcomes between those with one or two attending physicians. However, patients with three or more attending physicians had a higher 30-day readmission rate. Irene W.Y. Ma contributed significantly by co-conceiving the project, obtaining data, and revising the manuscript. Further research is needed to explore these associations and their implications on patient care.

title: Govt working to bring in dengue vaccine
summary: The Bangladesh government is working to introduce a dengue vaccine, with three options available globally: Qdenga (TAK003), TV005, and Denvaxia. Health authorities are prioritizing the single-dose TV005 vaccine, effective for both children and adults, following successful trials in the country. Prof Dr Ahmedul Kabir from the Directorate General of Health Services highlighted ongoing discussions with pharmaceutical companies for further trials and manufacturing. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends Qdenga for children aged 4-16. Amid a severe dengue outbreak, with over 2.11 lakh hospitalizations and 1,030 deaths, health experts urge swift vaccine introduction. The National Immunization Technical Advisory Group (NITAG), led by Prof Dr Khan Abul Kalam Azad, was formed to evaluate the suitability of existing dengue vaccines for Bangladesh.

title: Symptom changes raise dengue danger in Bangladesh
summary: Dengue in Bangladesh is becoming more severe due to changes in symptom patterns, making it harder for physicians to manage late hospitalizations. Symptoms now include mild fever, diarrhea, sore throats, and coughs, deviating from the World Health Organization's March update. The death toll has reached 186, with young females predominantly affected. Dhaka Medical College's principal, Md Titu Miah, and former principal Khan Abul Kalam Azad noted an increase in hemorrhagic fever and shock syndrome cases among young women. Research is needed to understand why young women are more vulnerable. The high number of DEN-2 serotypes is causing new symptoms, impacting various organs. Public health officials warn that the situation could worsen without controlling Aedes mosquito breeding. Dhaka has the highest mosquito density in five years, with most hospitalizations and deaths occurring there.

title: Celebrating Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders at Stanford Medicine
summary: Stanford Medicine celebrates the contributions of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPI) in various fields. Chwen-Yuen Angie Chen, a clinical associate professor, spent five years as a nun in a Buddhist monastery in Nepal. This influences her approach to treating patients with addiction, seeing parallels between Buddhism and medicine. The article highlights other notable AAPI members at Stanford Medicine, including clinical psychologist Ranak Trivedi, nurse practitioner Anthony Pho, research scientist Che-Hong Chen, medical student Grace Li, and radiation oncology resident Kekoa Taparra, each contributing significantly to their fields and advocating for their communities.

title: Doctors are as vulnerable to addiction as anyone: California grapples with a response
summary: California is addressing addiction among doctors by developing a new program through the Medical Board of California to treat and monitor those with substance use issues. A debate exists on whether doctors who join the program voluntarily should be publicly disclosed, with patient advocates emphasizing consumer protection and addiction professionals advocating for confidentiality to encourage early intervention. Chwen-Yuen Angie Chen, an addiction medicine doctor at Stanford Health Care, highlighted the risk of addiction among doctors due to their access to medications. The program aims to balance physician privacy with patient safety while addressing the high costs involved for participating doctors.

title: Dr. Ruth Weissberger and Dr. Anthony Yoder
summary: Dr. Ruth Weissberger and Dr. Anthony Yoder authored an article in CT Viewpoints emphasizing the unsustainable burden placed on consumers by the rising costs of health insurance company profits. They argue that the current inefficient system makes it increasingly difficult for individuals to access essential health care. Their contribution highlights the need for a reformed approach that prioritizes patients over the financial gains of insurance companies.

title: Extraordinary People. Extraordinary Moments.
summary: During the COVID-19 pandemic, various healthcare professionals at Johns Hopkins Medicine have stepped up to contribute significantly. Denise Fu managed the preparation and administration of COVID-19 vaccinations, coordinating a team of certified vaccinators. Catherine Wren transitioned to a field-based clinical research site to assist with COVID-19 studies. Rickey Jenkins and Roark Nixon focused on maintaining cleanliness and safety in hospital environments. Shmuel Shoham, M.D., played a pivotal role by forming a consortium to launch clinical trials using COVID-19 survivor plasma as a treatment, significantly increasing plasma donations to treat over 7,000 patients. Other staff members, such as nurses, doctors, and support personnel, adapted to new roles and protocols to ensure patient care and safety.

title: CINDY LAGONE, M.D. FACP; ANNE FUREY SCHULTZ, M.D. FACP: AUTHENTIC INTERNAL MEDICINE
summary: Dr. Cindy Lagone and Dr. Anne Furey Schultz co-founded Authentic Internal Medicine, a concierge internal medicine practice affiliated with Northwestern Medicine in Chicago’s Western Suburbs. Both physicians bring 50 years of combined experience and strong connections to top specialists. They emphasize the importance of the doctor-patient relationship in providing exceptional medical care. Their practice offers personalized, comprehensive, and coordinated care through an innovative membership model that allows for easy access and longer visits. Dr. Schultz highlights the depersonalization and fragmentation in recent healthcare trends and aims to provide patients with a consistent medical home. Additionally, they contribute to the community through their Authentic Teaching Kitchen, which offers free monthly sessions to promote healthy habits. This initiative is in collaboration with the Culinary Institute of America and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. Dr. Lagone and Dr. Schultz are committed to restoring primary care to its intended, patient-focused roots.

title: Addressing women's health care concerns
summary: The gender bias in healthcare treatment remains a significant problem in the United States, with middle-aged women being twice as likely to be diagnosed with a mental illness compared to men when presenting with chest pain. The issue is even more severe for Black women, who receive up to 10 percent fewer early treatments for heart problems than white patients. Dr. Anne Furey Schultz, who examines patients at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, is part of the broader conversation addressing these disparities. Listeners have shared personal stories of challenges in receiving proper diagnoses, highlighting the need for solutions. The program has previously explored the reasons behind these disparities and is now focusing on creative solutions to the crisis. Guests include Kistein Monkhouse, Dr. Jan Werbinsk, and Damon Centola, who contribute to the discussion on improving healthcare equity.

title: Medical experts are warning about a rise in strep cases. Here's what you need to know
summary: Medical experts are warning about a rise in strep throat cases, particularly a severe strain known as invasive group A strep, following the deaths of two children in Illinois. Symptoms of strep throat include sore throat, pain when swallowing, fever, and swollen tonsils. Dr. Anna Richie from Memorial Health notes that strep cases have significantly increased, with a 30% positivity rate. Vidya Sundareshan, chief of infectious diseases at Southern Illinois University School of Medicine, highlights the higher incidence of invasive group A strep, which can lead to severe complications if untreated. Sundareshan emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and antibiotic treatment for effective outcomes. Preventive measures include good hygiene practices and seeking medical attention at the onset of symptoms.

title: Medical storytelling brings the human side of health care to the stage
summary: Medical storytelling emphasizes the human aspect of healthcare by sharing personal experiences of medical professionals. Dr. Tseganesh Selameab, a primary care doctor and associate director of the Center for Art in Medicine at the University of Minnesota, is organizing a live event in collaboration with the podcast "The Nocturnists" on April 22, 2023. This event, themed "Rebirth," will feature seven healthcare professionals narrating their stories. Selameab highlights the importance of physicians connecting with patients on a human level and integrating empathy into their practice. She believes that storytelling helps doctors engage with their own humanity, which enhances their ability to care for patients effectively. The event aims to foster a deeper understanding of the personal and emotional dimensions of medical practice.

title: Literary pick: 'An Evening of Medical Storytelling' by health care workers
summary: "An Evening of Medical Storytelling" will be held on April 22, 2023, at the Parkway Theater in Minneapolis, celebrating Earth Day. Presented by The Nocturnists and the University of Minnesota's Center for the Art of Medicine (CFAM), the event aims to humanize healthcare through storytelling. The Nocturnists, founded by Dr. Emily Silverman in 2016, has grown to include over 450 clinicians and features live performances and an award-winning podcast. CFAM, led by physicians including Tseganesh Selameab, promotes the integration of arts and humanities in medical education. The evening will feature music by the Ari Nahum Trio and storytelling by Minnesota physicians. Tickets are available for purchase.

title: Symptomatic Junctional Bradycardia Due to Untreated Hypothyroidism After Beta-Blocker Discontinuation: A Case Report
summary: The case report discusses a 74-year-old female with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and gastric ulcers who developed symptomatic junctional bradycardia due to untreated hypothyroidism after discontinuing beta-blocker therapy. Her heart rate improved with intravenous levothyroxine but led to severe hypertension, requiring antihypertensive management. The case highlights the need for further studies to establish guidelines correlating thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with heart rate for safe hormonal supplementation. Sandhya Wahi-Gururaj contributed to the research and writing of the case report, emphasizing the importance of thyroid hormone regulation in cardiovascular health.

title: Movers and Shakers
summary: Dr. Vashist Amit Vashist was recognized by Becker’s Healthcare as a top health system CMO, focusing on clinical quality and safety at Ballad Health. Dr. Unaka Ndidi Unaka was named a 2023 Career Woman of Achievement for her work in quality improvement and health equity. Dr. Chippa Venu Madhav Chippa joined Ascension St. Vincent as an internist and academic hospitalist. The hospitalist program at FirstHealth of the Carolinas celebrated its 20th anniversary. Dr. Ronen Joshua Ronen was promoted to assistant professor at UCSF Medical Center. Dr. Imtiaz Khokhar joined Beebe Healthcare as a hospitalist. Dr. Kwame Dapaah-Afriyie joined the board of directors for HopeHealth and is the director of hospital medicine at The Miriam Hospital. Dr. Steven L. Cohn was elected as a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians of London. Dr. James Troy was appointed associate chief at Albert B. Chandler Hospital.

title: Figure - Six Extensively Drug-Resistant Bacteria in an Injured Soldier, Ukraine - Volume 29, Number 8—August 2023 ...
summary: The research letter in the August 2023 issue of the Emerging Infectious Diseases journal discusses the identification of six extensively drug-resistant bacteria in an injured soldier from Ukraine. The study was conducted by a team from the Multidrug-Resistant Organism Repository and Surveillance Network at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research and other affiliated institutions. Joshua S. Hawley-Molloy contributed to the research from the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center in Germany. The study includes a phylogenetic analysis of Klebsiella pneumoniae strains, highlighting the presence of specific virulence and antimicrobial resistance genes. The findings emphasize the challenges posed by drug-resistant infections in conflict zones.

title: Allergic conjunctivitis
summary: Allergic conjunctivitis is an inflammation of the conjunctiva caused by allergens such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, and mold. Symptoms include red, itchy, and teary eyes, and puffy eyelids, often worsening with higher pollen levels. Diagnosis involves looking for bumps on the eyelids and conducting allergy tests. Treatment focuses on avoiding allergens, using lubricating eye drops, cool compresses, and over-the-counter antihistamines. Severe cases may require prescription eye drops. Prognosis is generally good with treatment, though symptoms can persist with ongoing allergen exposure. Stuart I. Henochowicz, MD, FACP, reviewed this information, contributing his expertise as a Clinical Professor of Medicine at Georgetown University Medical School.

title: Immunodeficiency disorders
summary: Immunodeficiency disorders occur when the body's immune response is reduced or absent, affecting any part of the immune system. Causes include inherited conditions, medications, diseases like HIV/AIDS, malnutrition, and aging. Symptoms often involve recurrent infections, poor response to treatments, and certain cancers. Diagnosis may involve blood tests, HIV tests, and white blood cell counts. Treatment aims to prevent and manage infections, possibly using antibiotics, antifungals, interferons, or immunoglobulin therapy. Preventive measures include vaccinations and avoiding contact with infected individuals. Prognosis varies from mild to severe, and complications can include frequent illness and increased cancer risk. Stuart I. Henochowicz, MD, FACP, a Clinical Professor at Georgetown University Medical School, reviewed the information on immunodeficiency disorders, ensuring its accuracy and relevance.

title: Recurrent Erythema Multiforme Major Following COVID-19 Infection
summary: A 34-year-old male experienced recurrent Erythema Multiforme Major (EMM) following a COVID-19 infection. EMM, a serious immune-mediated skin reaction, often presents with mucocutaneous lesions and can be misdiagnosed. The patient had a severe rash involving oral and genital mucosa and required an extended recovery period. Despite being fully vaccinated and treated with various medications, his condition persisted. Ian Motie, along with other authors, contributed to documenting this case, which highlights the rare association between recurrent EMM and COVID-19. The findings suggest a need for further research to understand the correlation and establish specific treatment protocols.

title: Lauren Barnes Joins Ossium Health's Board of Directors
summary: Lauren Barnes has joined Ossium Health’s Board of Directors, bringing extensive experience in healthcare product commercialization. Her expertise will enhance Ossium’s ability to grow and provide solutions for patients with hematologic diseases, organ transplant rejection, and musculoskeletal defects. Kevin Caldwell, Ossium’s CEO, emphasized that Barnes’ insights are crucial as the company transitions to a commercial entity. Barnes currently serves as Senior Vice President at Blueprint Medicines and has held significant roles at Vertex Pharmaceuticals, Avalere Health, and Amgen. She also serves on the board of Ascelia Pharma AB and was Chair of the Board for Cancer Support Community. Barnes expressed excitement about Ossium’s innovative technologies and their impact on the blood cancer community. Her appointment highlights Ossium’s commitment to a diverse and expert board to achieve its goals.

title: Cross Q&A: Role of Belantamab Mafodotin in MM
summary: The panel discusses the role of belantamab mafodotin in treating multiple myeloma, highlighting its efficacy and placement in the treatment landscape. Craig Cole, MD, shares his positive experiences with the drug, noting patients who remained in complete response (CR) for extended periods after discontinuation. He emphasizes the potential of belantamab mafodotin for patients in remote areas or those unable to access expensive therapies, suggesting it could be a viable option for older patients or those with travel constraints. Despite the challenges, including eye management issues, Cole sees potential in the drug's future applications as treatment protocols evolve.

title: Can Real World Data Accelerate CLL Research?
summary: The HealthTree Foundation is promoting the use of real-world data (RWD) to enhance Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) research. Dr. Craig Cole, a blood cancer specialist at Michigan State University, explains that RWD encompasses patient experiences, including lab results, genetics, therapies, and side effects. This data can be collected retrospectively or prospectively, providing a broader and more accurate understanding of patient responses compared to clinical trials. RWD includes diverse patient populations, offering insights into therapy effectiveness across various demographics. To conduct RWD research, expertise, patient participation, and funding are essential. HealthTree Foundation is facilitating this by inviting blood cancer investigators to submit research proposals, encouraging patients to connect their medical records, and fundraising. Participation in surveys and studies within the HealthTree Cure Hub is also encouraged to influence CLL treatment approaches.

title: DREAMM-3: Belantamab Mafodotin in Patients With Relapsed/Refractory MM
summary: The DREAMM-3 study evaluated the efficacy and safety of single-agent belantamab mafodotin (belamaf) versus pomalidomide and dexamethasone (Pom-dex) in patients with relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. Craig Cole, MD, contributed by reviewing the study data, highlighting that belamaf showed a longer median progression-free survival (PFS) compared to Pom-dex, though it did not reach statistical significance. The study faced challenges such as being conducted during COVID-19, which may have affected therapy intensity. Despite deeper responses in the belamaf arm, the FDA withdrew its approval in November 2022 due to unmet primary objectives. Ongoing research in DREAMM-7 and DREAMM-8 continues to explore belamaf's potential.

title: IMF Medical Student Scholars for Health Equity in Myeloma Present Research at the 2023 NMA Annual Convention ...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF), in collaboration with the National Medical Association (NMA) and other partners, presented research at the 2023 NMA Annual Convention in New Orleans. Eleven IMF Medical Student Scholars for Health Equity in Myeloma, along with their mentors, showcased their findings on various topics related to myeloma, including racial disparities and patient awareness. Craig Cole, MD, from Michigan State University, contributed by mentoring students Justin Thomas and Jan Powell on research about CAR T-Cell Therapy and racial differences in myeloma outcomes. This initiative highlights the IMF’s commitment to health equity and fostering future healthcare leaders.

title: Team Introductions: MM Experts From Karmanos Cancer Institute and Cleveland Clinic
summary: A panel of multiple myeloma experts from Karmanos Cancer Institute and Cleveland Clinic introduced themselves for a team-vs-team debate on recent data in multiple myeloma. The event, hosted by Judy Schreiber, PhD, RN, is designed to be both educational and competitive. Dr. Andrew Kin from Karmanos Cancer Institute and Dr. Jack Khouri from Cleveland Clinic lead their respective teams. The Karmanos team includes Dr. Jeffrey Zonder and Dr. Craig Cole, a myeloma expert at McLaren Lansing Karmanos partnership. The Cleveland Clinic team features Dr. Faiz Anwer, among others. The format involves one team presenting a study, followed by a challenge from the opposing team, with audience participation in scoring the teams based on the accuracy of their answers. Dr. Craig Cole's contribution as a myeloma expert is highlighted as part of the Karmanos team.

title: ESTEEMED ONCOLOGY NURSE BRINGS BOLD AND INNOVATIVE VISION
summary: Sally Werner has been appointed as the new CEO of Cancer Support Community (CSC), effective January 1, 2024. With over 25 years in oncology care and leadership roles, Werner succeeds Debbie Weir. Rich Mutell, Chair of CSC’s Board of Directors, expressed excitement about Werner’s expertise and vision to guide the organization. Werner's journey with CSC began in 2010 as a Board of Trustees member at Gilda’s Club Quad Cities, later becoming its CEO in 2016. She joined CSC Headquarters in 2017, most recently serving as Chief Experience Officer. Werner aims to expand CSC’s support services globally, ensuring accessibility for all cancer patients and caregivers.

title: Alpine Immune Sciences Announces Appointment of Wolfgang Dummer, M.D., Ph.D., as Chief Medical Officer and ...
summary: Alpine Immune Sciences, a clinical-stage immunotherapy company, has appointed Wolfgang Dummer, M.D., Ph.D., as Chief Medical Officer effective October 2, 2023. He succeeds Andrew Sandler, M.D., who will transition responsibilities to Dr. Dummer through the remainder of the year. Dr. Dummer brings over 20 years of global drug development experience and has led multiple drug approvals in immunology and rare diseases. Andrew Sandler has been acknowledged for his leadership and significant contributions during his tenure, playing a crucial role in evolving Alpine's development efforts. Dr. Dummer previously served as Chief Medical Officer at Rigel Pharmaceuticals and held key roles at BioMarin and Genentech.

title: Delaware County Leadership: Dr. Michael Mittelman, President, Salus University
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: Dr. Michael Mittelman, President of Salus University, shared his journey from growing up in Long Island to leading Salus. Mittelman, who has a background in optometry and served as the deputy surgeon general of the U.S. Navy, discussed his early life, education, and career. He highlighted his involvement in theater, sports, and his transition from considering dentistry to pursuing optometry. Mittelman reflected on mentors who influenced his career in the Navy and his eventual decision to join Salus University. He emphasized the importance of adapting to changes in education and his focus on ensuring a smooth merger with Drexel University. Mittelman also shared personal interests like working out and model trains and mentioned the significance of being gentle with people, a lesson from his mentor Mike Cowan.

title: Drexel and Salus Universities Formalize Merger Agreement at Ceremonial Signing
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: Drexel University and Salus University formalized a merger agreement with a ceremonial signing on June 13, 2023. The merger, pending regulatory and judicial approvals, aims to combine the strengths of both institutions in graduate health sciences education and clinical practice. Drexel President John Fry highlighted the merger's potential to enhance Drexel's leadership in health sciences. Salus University, known for its specialized programs in optometry, audiology, and more, will expand Drexel’s offerings. Salus President Michael Mittelman emphasized the merger's benefits, including improved student experiences, new clinical opportunities, and research collaborations. An Integration Council will be formed to oversee the merger's implementation, which will take over a year to complete. The merger supports Drexel's 2030 Strategic Plan and both universities' commitment to civic engagement and community outreach.

title: Fort Worth leaders gather to discuss social issues
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: Fort Worth leaders convened at the North Texas Social Impact Summit on November 3 to address pressing social issues in Tarrant County. The summit aimed to foster collaboration among city and community leaders. Sylvia Trent-Adams, president of The University of North Texas Health Science Center at Fort Worth, was one of the key speakers. She, alongside Leah King, CEO of the United Way of Tarrant County, discussed the community's COVID-19 experiences, emphasizing the need for better communication and trust-building, particularly within African-American and Hispanic communities. Trent-Adams highlighted the widespread distrust in science and the medical community observed during the pandemic. The event sought to create a support network and share best practices to enhance public health and leadership, with plans for a 2024 summit already in motion.

title: Dr. Sylvia Trent-Adams to be inaugurated as president of HSC
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: Dr. Sylvia Trent-Adams is set to be inaugurated as the president of the University of North Texas Health Science Center (HSC) at Fort Worth on March 7. The public event will be held at the Will Rogers Memorial Center Auditorium. Trent-Adams, who took over as HSC’s seventh president in September, has a distinguished background in health care, including roles as Deputy Surgeon General and Acting Surgeon General. She is the first Black woman to lead a health science center in Texas. Her leadership aims to enhance campus research, fundraising, and enrollment. Prior to her presidency, she served as HSC’s executive vice president and chief strategy officer. The inauguration will feature keynote speakers Dr. Brett Giroir and Dr. William Trent. Trent-Adams has already initiated a campuswide listening tour to engage with faculty, staff, and students. The event underscores her commitment to advancing HSC’s mission and fostering a healthier community.

title: WC, UNTHSC sign agreement expanding pathways for students
hco: ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
summary: Weatherford College (WC) and the University of North Texas Health Science Center (UNTHSC) have signed an agreement to expand educational pathways for students. This collaboration aims to enhance opportunities in medical and health services management, nursing, and other health-related fields. The partnership was formalized by WC President Tod Allen Farmer and UNTHSC President Sylvia Trent-Adams. Sylvia Trent-Adams, in her role as UNTHSC President, played a significant part in this initiative, which is expected to provide a more streamlined and accessible route for students pursuing careers in healthcare. This agreement underscores a commitment to improving educational access and workforce development in the healthcare sector.

title: USA College of Nursing Secures $3.4 Million to Grow Nursing Workforce
summary: The University of South Alabama College of Nursing has received a $3.4 million, four-year grant to increase the number of registered nurses, especially in rural and underserved areas. Dr. Leigh Minchew, associate dean for academic affairs, is the project director for this initiative. The grant from the Health and Human Resources and Services Administration will fund the LEAP program, which aims to transition licensed practical nurses (LPNs) and licensed vocational nurses (LVNs) into registered nursing careers. LEAP will provide social and financial support, mentorship, and educational resources to help LPNs/LVNs advance their careers while addressing nursing shortages and promoting health equity. The program will emphasize community health nursing competencies and integrated behavioral health services, preparing nurses for leadership roles. An informational open house is scheduled for September 19, and the first cohort will begin in spring 2024.

title: University of South Alabama awarded $3.4 million grant
summary: The University of South Alabama has been awarded a $3.4 million grant to address the shortage of ethnically diverse nurses in Alabama, where less than 20% of nurses are ethnically diverse. Dr. Leigh Minchew, the Associate Dean of Academic Affairs at South’s College of Nursing, is spearheading the initiative through a new online program called Leveling Education and Social Support Resources to Advance Professional Nursing Practice (LEAP). This program aims to help licensed practical and vocational nurses become registered nurses by allowing them to continue working while attending school online and completing clinicals in their own communities. The College of Nursing is the only institution in the Southeast to receive this grant. The first cohort of students will be admitted in Spring 2024, with an information session scheduled for September 19.

title: Solving the Caregiving Crisis is a Collective Endeavor
summary: The caregiving crisis in the U.S. is a significant issue affecting many, with over 1 in 5 Americans serving as family caregivers. The situation is exacerbated by the aging baby boomer generation, resulting in immense pressure on families and a lack of adequate support for caregivers. Amy Brown highlights the need for a collective effort to address this crisis, emphasizing the importance of political will, employer support, public awareness, and collective resolve. Women, especially women of color, are at the center of the care economy but face low pay and poor working conditions. Solutions include better policies, government intervention, and business support, such as paid family leave. Molly Moon Ice Cream serves as a model for providing such benefits. Amy Brown, a seasoned sustainability writer, underscores the urgency of building a robust care infrastructure to support future generations.

title: Global epidemiology of cirrhosis — aetiology, trends and predictions
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: Cirrhosis is a significant global health issue, causing 2.4% of global deaths in 2019. Its epidemiology is evolving due to rising obesity and alcohol consumption, alongside better management of hepatitis B and C. This review highlights global trends, aetiologies, and future projections for cirrhosis. Viral hepatitis remains the leading cause, but non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and alcohol-associated cirrhosis are increasing. Between 2012 and 2017, cirrhosis deaths rose, though age-standardized death rates (ASDRs) for most causes declined, except for NAFLD. Predictions indicate a continued rise in cirrhosis deaths, necessitating enhanced prevention, early detection, and treatment efforts. Norah Terrault contributed to this comprehensive review, which underscores the need for greater global health initiatives to combat cirrhosis.

title: VIDEO: Prevalence of HCV has not changed since 2013-2016 estimate
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: Norah Terrault, MD, MPH, FAASLD, discussed findings from an abstract presented at The Liver Meeting, revealing that the prevalence of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in the United States has remained unchanged from the 2013-2016 estimates through 2017-2020. Terrault, a professor of medicine and chief of gastroenterology and liver diseases at the University of Southern California Keck School of Medicine, highlighted that the number of infected individuals has not decreased, indicating that new HCV infections are occurring at a faster rate than the cure of existing cases. This underscores the ongoing challenge in reducing HCV prevalence despite medical advancements.

title: Large VA trial could change how patients are screened for liver cancer
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: A new study by the Department of Veterans Affairs, known as PREMIUM (PREventing Liver Cancer Mortality through Imaging with Ultrasound vs. MRI), aims to revolutionize liver cancer screening. This large-scale trial will compare abbreviated MRI protocols with traditional ultrasound exams to determine which method offers better accuracy and earlier cancer detection. With 4,700 veterans participating over eight years, the study could significantly impact clinical practices for both veterans and non-veterans. The trial addresses the limitations of ultrasound, such as patient and user dependency, which can lead to missed or inaccurate diagnoses. Dr. George Ioannou of the VA Puget Sound Healthcare System and Dr. Tamar Taddei of the VA Connecticut Healthcare System co-chair the trial, emphasizing its potential to resolve long-standing debates about liver cancer screening methods.

title: VCU liver institute names Saul Karpen as its first Chief Scientific Officer
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: The Stravitz-Sanyal Institute for Liver Disease and Metabolic Health at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) has appointed Saul J. Karpen, M.D., Ph.D., as its first Chief Scientific Officer (CSO). Karpen, a distinguished pediatric hepatologist, currently holds the Raymond F. Schinazi Distinguished Biomedical Chair at Emory University School of Medicine and Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta. Beginning his new role in March 2024, Karpen will oversee and strategically plan the expansion of liver and metabolic disease research at the institute. He aims to enhance diagnostics and coordinate innovative research to improve patient care. Karpen will also serve as a professor at the VCU School of Medicine and hold an adjunct position in pediatrics at the Children's Hospital of Richmond at VCU. His appointment is expected to significantly advance the institute’s mission to be a global leader in liver disease and metabolic health.

title: Expert describes the health benefits of 'Dry January'
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: "Dry January" is a growing trend where people abstain from alcohol for the month of January. Dr. Rotonya Carr, head of gastroenterology at the University of Washington School of Medicine, discusses its benefits. She notes that participants often feel better overall and see improvements in cholesterol, blood sugar, and blood pressure levels. Liver function also improves within a month of sobriety. Carr emphasizes the importance of social support and planning for success. She advises heavy drinkers to consult a doctor before stopping to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Remarkably, many who participate in Dry January continue to reduce their alcohol consumption months later, leading to sustained health benefits. Carr underscores the need to reduce the stigma around alcohol consumption and educate the public about its risks, noting that alcohol is a class one carcinogen.

title: FDA approves novel treatment for liver disease | News | dailyuw.com
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: The FDA has approved a novel drug, Rezdiffra (resmetirom), for treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, known as metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH), which affects 15 million Americans. This marks the first approved medication for MASH, a condition causing liver inflammation and scarring. Resmetirom has shown efficacy in clinical trials, reducing liver fat, inflammation, and scarring. Dr. Rotonya Carr, division head of gastroenterology at UW and clinical hepatologist, expressed optimism about the drug's impact, noting the long-standing challenge in understanding the disease's biology. Resmetirom, an oral thyroid hormone receptor beta agonist, works by oxidizing liver fat and targeting liver-specific thyroid hormone receptors. The drug, developed by Madrigal Pharmaceuticals, is estimated to cost $40,000 to $50,000 annually per patient, with potential future cost reductions as alternative drugs emerge. UW Medicine continues its clinical research on MASH.

title: UW launches new center to explore the microbiome: HealthLink
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: The University of Washington has launched the Microbial Interactions & Microbiome Center (mim_c) to explore the vast world of microbes. Dr. Rotonya M. Carr, head of UW Medicine's Department of Gastroenterology, played a crucial role in establishing the center. Carr emphasized the importance of microbes, including bacteria, viruses, and fungi, in maintaining human health. The center aims to connect microbiologists with other researchers to study how microorganisms affect health and the environment, potentially leading to new therapies. Dr. Joseph Mougous will lead the center, which is funded by a grant from Lynn M. and Michael D. Garvey.

title: Awards & Accolades: May 2023
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: Rebecca Clark, PhD, MSN, RN, has been named a fellow in the Betty Irene Moore Fellowship for Nurse Leaders and Innovators at UC Davis, focusing on improving patient care through video reviews. César de la Fuente, PhD, was recognized as a National Academy of Medicine Emerging Leaders Scholar for integrating human and machine intelligence in scientific discovery. Mustafa Mir, PhD, was selected as a Howard Hughes Medical Institute Freeman Hrabowski Scholar for his work on visualizing gene expression in live embryos. Kim M. Olthoff, MD, chief of Transplant Surgery, received the 2023 Pioneer Award from the American Society of Transplant Surgeons for her contributions to liver regeneration, transplantation genomics, and advancing living liver donation. The Penn Measey Scholars in Molecular Medicine Program announced its first cohort, including Wumush KC, MD, PhD, Edward Kreider, MD, PhD, and Elizabeth Traxler, MD, PhD. Penn Medicine is a leading academic medical center with a history of pioneering medical innovations.

title: Gift of life: Fayetteville daughter donates part of her liver to her mother
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: Meredith Stiehl, 57, from Fayetteville, received a life-saving liver transplant from her 26-year-old daughter, Kenan, at UNC Hospitals. The surgery, led by Dr. Chirag Desai and Dr. Sorabh Kapoor, marked UNC's first living-donor liver transplant in nearly 20 years. Dr. Oren Fix, the medical director of the liver transplant program, emphasized the importance of living-donor transplants in addressing the high demand for organs. The procedure involved removing a portion of Kenan's healthy liver and transplanting it into Meredith, whose liver disease had severely affected her quality of life. The success of this surgery has led UNC Health to expand its transplant services, making it the second program in North Carolina to perform living-donor liver transplants. Both Meredith and Kenan are recovering well, and the procedure has given Meredith a new lease on life.

title: Loss of CEACAM1 in endothelial cells causes hepatic fibrosis
hco: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE STUDY OF LIVER DISEASES FOUNDATION
summary: The study investigates the role of endothelial CEACAM1 in preventing hepatic fibrosis. Mice with endothelial loss of CEACAM1 (VECadCre+Cc1 fl/fl) showed increased endothelin1 (ET1) production, leading to hepatic fibrosis and inflammation, despite maintaining insulin sensitivity and reduced visceral obesity. The fibrosis was reversed in mice with combined endothelial loss of Cc1 and Et1 genes. Analysis of liver biopsies from NASH patients revealed a decline in endothelial CEACAM1 and increased plasma ET1 levels with fibrosis progression. Harmeet Malhi contributed to this research, which highlights the importance of endothelial CEACAM1 in mitigating hepatic fibrosis by regulating ET1 production.

title: Joining IDSA's Board of Directors: A Clinician's Perspective
summary: Steven K. Schmitt, President-elect of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA), and Daniel McQuillen, Immediate Past President, discuss their journeys and experiences as clinicians on the IDSA Board of Directors. Schmitt highlights his early exposure to IDSA through Ward Bullock and his involvement in state and regional societies. Both emphasize the importance of clinician representation on the board, reflecting the diverse membership and enhancing decision-making. They stress the ease of getting involved today compared to the past, citing initiatives like the Leadership Institute and various volunteer opportunities. Schmitt and McQuillen underscore the value of diverse voices and the critical role of IDSA staff in supporting volunteer efforts.

title: Increasing vaccination and addressing vaccine hesitancy in 2024
summary: In 2024, increasing vaccination rates and addressing vaccine hesitancy are critical goals. Tina Tan, MD, FAAP, FIDSA, FPIDS, emphasizes the rise in severe vaccine-preventable diseases like pneumococcal and group A streptococcal infections post-pandemic due to lifted protective measures. She notes a significant increase in hospital cases, highlighting the importance of extended valency pneumococcal conjugate vaccines. Tan hopes to counteract the growing vaccine hesitancy and ensure children are up to date with their immunizations to prevent outbreaks of diseases such as measles and pertussis. Her insights underscore the need for continued public health efforts to promote vaccination and mitigate the resurgence of infectious diseases.

title: mRNA Technology in COVID-19 Vaccine Production
summary: The discussion between Drs. Tina Q. Tan and Rodney Rohde highlights the transformative impact of mRNA technology in vaccine development, particularly for COVID-19. They discuss how mRNA technology, which has been available for decades, was accelerated during the pandemic due to streamlined regulatory processes. This technology allows the body to produce specific proteins, like the COVID-19 spike protein, enhancing the immune response. The conversation emphasizes the potential of mRNA for future viral outbreaks and diseases like cancer and tuberculosis. They also explore the development of combination vaccines, such as a COVID-RSV-flu vaccine, and the possibility of a universal flu vaccine. The speakers express optimism about mRNA technology's role in public health, aiming to dispel misconceptions and improve vaccine acceptance. They foresee longer-lasting vaccines and a transformative era in genomic and proteomic advancements.

title: A Year of RSV Highs and Lows, with Tina Tan, MD
summary: In 2023, significant advancements were made in the fight against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), particularly with the FDA approval of two vaccines, Arexvy and Abrysvo, for adults over 60, and the monoclonal antibody nirsevimab for newborns and infants. Tina Tan, MD, highlighted the year's unpredictable RSV surges, especially the unprecedented Fall surge that overwhelmed pediatric healthcare systems. Tan discussed the challenges in meeting the high demand for nirsevimab, noting parents' desperation to secure the treatment for their children. Looking forward, Tan expressed cautious optimism about the impact of limited nirsevimab supplies and maternal immunization on reducing severe RSV cases in the upcoming season.

title: Philips' Profit To Be Dented By FDA-Decreed AED Sales Halt
summary: Philips has signed a consent decree with the US FDA, resulting in a halt in the manufacture and sales of external defibrillators from two facilities until compliance with good manufacturing practice requirements is met. This suspension is anticipated to negatively affect Philips' EBITA for the fourth quarter of 2017 and for 2018. Tina Tan reported on this development, highlighting the regulatory compliance issues faced by Philips and the expected financial impact on the company.

title: IDSA Media Briefing: Fall Vaccine Updates
summary: The IDSA Media Briefing on Fall Vaccine Updates featured discussions on CDC vaccine recommendations, COVID-19, RSV, flu, and other mitigation measures. Key speakers included Jeffrey Duchin, MD, from Public Health Seattle & King County, and Tina Q. Tan, MD, from Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital of Chicago. The briefing aimed to address questions from the media and provide comprehensive updates on fall vaccines. The event was moderated by Dana S. Wollins, DrPH, Vice President of Clinical Affairs & Guidelines at IDSA.

title: Fall vaccines: Here's what to know about RSV, flu and COVID booster shots, plus when you can get them
summary: Several vaccines will soon be available to protect against RSV, flu, and COVID-19 this fall and winter. Dr. Tina Tan, an infectious disease specialist at Ann & Robert H. Lurie Children’s Hospital, highlights that the RSV vaccine, a monoclonal antibody, is recommended for all children under 8 months entering their first RSV season. Pediatric offices in Chicago are awaiting the vaccine's arrival, expected by the end of October. Flu shots are recommended for everyone over six months old, with new guidelines eliminating egg allergy precautions. Updated COVID boosters targeting recent variants will also be available, pending FDA authorization and CDC recommendations. Dr. Julie Holland of Advocate Health Care notes that eligible individuals can receive all three vaccines simultaneously.

title: In the Aftermath of the Pandemic, IDSA Looks to Address COVID-19's Health Care Disparities
summary: The Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA), with over 12,000 professionals, aims to enhance health through excellence in patient care, education, research, and public health. It focuses on public health policy and developing antibiotics, including the Pasteur Act. Tina Q. Tan, MD, a professor at Northwestern University, is elected vice president of the IDSA. Tan highlights the need to address disparities in clinical trials, especially the underrepresentation of the pediatric population. She emphasizes including infants and children in drug and vaccine trials and outlines IDSA’s 2023 priorities as serving providers and educating the public.

title: The April 2024 issue of Contemporary Pediatrics: Latest updates and clinical pearls
summary: The April 2024 issue of Contemporary Pediatrics, highlighted by Editor-in-Chief Tina Tan, MD, FAAP, FIDSA, FPIDS, covers crucial updates and clinical pearls. Dr. Tan emphasizes the significance of measles vaccination amidst ongoing outbreaks, stressing the role of unvaccinated individuals in spreading the disease. The issue includes articles on pediatric irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), the efficacy of tapinarof cream for atopic dermatitis in patients with skin of color, and the benefits of maternal COVID-19 vaccination. Additionally, it reviews the risks of congenital malformations linked to maternal asthma exacerbations and discusses the increasing threats from lone star tick bites. An article by Dr. Candice Jones addresses the appropriate timing for giving children cell phones. Dr. Tan encourages healthcare providers to ensure patient vaccinations and to take care of themselves while enjoying the spring season.

title: Long-term open-label vebicorvir for chronic HBV infection: Safety and off-treatment responses
summary: The study evaluated the long-term safety and efficacy of vebicorvir (VBR) combined with nucleos(t)ide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NrtIs) in patients with chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. Conducted as an extension of two phase II studies, the research involved 92 patients who received VBR+NrtI for at least 52 weeks. The results showed continued suppression of HBV nucleic acids but no sustained virologic response after treatment discontinuation. The treatment was generally well tolerated, with few adverse events and no deaths. Ronald G. Nahass contributed to the study's oversight, experiments, procedures, data acquisition, analysis, and interpretation.

title: PEPFAR Saves Lives
summary: PEPFAR (President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief) has played a crucial role in the global fight against HIV/AIDS, saving countless lives. However, policymakers are currently at an impasse regarding the reauthorization of the program. Maximo O. Brito, MD, MPH, FIDSA, who serves as the IDSA Treasurer, has highlighted the importance of PEPFAR in combating the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Brito's contributions emphasize the program's significant impact and the urgency of resolving the legislative deadlock to continue its life-saving work.

title: Events set with Carlos Del Río, MD, for Hispanic Heritage Month
summary: Carlos Del Río, MD, president of the Infectious Diseases Society of America and interim dean of the Emory School of Medicine and Grady Health System, will be featured at several events in Omaha to celebrate Hispanic Heritage Month. Sponsored by the UNMC Department of Internal Medicine and Division of Infectious Diseases, the National Hispanic Medical Association (NHMA) Nebraska Chapter, and NHMA National, these events include a breakfast meeting, a trivia vaccine clinic at the Mexican Consulate, and an internal medicine grand rounds session on "The Health Care Needs of Migrants." Dr. Del Río's participation aims to engage the community and promote health awareness.

title: President's Podcast: Fostering the next generation of Hispanic leaders
summary: Carlos del Rio, President of IDSA, hosts a podcast discussing the fostering of the next generation of Hispanic leaders in infectious diseases. He is joined by fellow Hispanic ID physicians and board members Dr. Lilian Abbo, Dr. Cesar Arias, and Dr. Max Brito, who share their journeys from their home countries to successful careers in the United States. They highlight the importance of resilience, hard work, and mentorship in their paths. Del Rio emphasizes the value of community and networking within IDSA, encouraging foreign medical graduates to get involved and contribute to the society. The podcast underscores the significance of supporting and mentoring the next generation of Hispanic leaders in the field.

title: Emory experts provide information and guidance on staying safe through COVID-19 and other illnesses
summary: Emory University experts have been actively providing updates and guidance on COVID-19 and other illnesses to ensure the safety of the campus community. As the fall 2023 semester progresses, the emphasis remains on staying vigilant due to ongoing COVID-19 surges and the approaching flu season. Key recommendations include staying updated with COVID-19 and flu vaccinations, self-monitoring health, following proper testing and isolation protocols, and keeping masks handy.
