Carlos del Rio, MD, highlighted the importance of the new COVID-19 vaccine, noting its role in updating immunity against new variants and protecting against severe disease, hospitalization, and death. Emory continues to encourage community members to use the knowledge and tools gained over the past years to manage both COVID-19 and flu effectively.

title: President's Podcast: IDSA Volunteer Restructure
summary: In September 2023, the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) introduced a new volunteer structure to better engage members and support its strategic initiatives. In a podcast episode, IDSA President Carlos del Rio and Vice President Tina Tan discussed the reasons behind the restructure and its future impact. Del Rio highlighted that the society had not reviewed its governance in over 50 years, despite significant growth in membership and committees. The new structure aims to streamline operations, improve communication, and provide more meaningful volunteer opportunities aligned with members' interests. Del Rio emphasized that the changes would help focus on strategic initiatives and better utilize the diverse expertise within the profession.

title: Carlos del Rio to serve as interim dean for Emory University School of Medicine
summary: Carlos del Rio, an internationally recognized clinician and epidemiologist, has been appointed interim dean of Emory University School of Medicine, effective March 1, 2023. He succeeds Vikas Sukhatme, who will return to the Emory faculty. Del Rio, also interim chief academic officer for Emory Healthcare, is currently the Leon L. Haley, Jr. MD, Distinguished Professor of Medicine and executive associate dean at Emory. He co-directs the Emory Center for AIDS Research and has a notable history in global health, particularly HIV/AIDS and COVID-19. Emory leaders, including President Gregory L. Fenves and Ravi Thadhani, commend del Rio’s dedication to public health, education, and equitable healthcare. Del Rio has received numerous accolades, including the Phoenix Award from Atlanta for his COVID-19 efforts and election to the National Academy of Medicine. His commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion is also highlighted.

title: Clade I Mpox Response
summary: Dr. Mati Hlatshwayo Davis, director of health for the City of St. Louis, discusses the clade I Mpox response with Jennifer McQuiston and Agam Rao from the CDC. The conversation focuses on the concerning Mpox outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where cases have surged significantly. The CDC issued a Health Alert Network advisory to raise awareness among clinicians and public health officials. Key points include the similarities and differences between clade I and clade II Mpox, the importance of early diagnosis, and the need for clade-specific testing. The discussion highlights the severity of clade I infections and the effectiveness of existing vaccines and therapeutics. The CDC is expanding clade-specific testing and working on prevention strategies, including behavioral changes and vaccination. Efforts are also underway in the DRC to control the outbreak and prevent its spread globally. Dr. Davis emphasizes the need for close collaboration between clinicians and public health departments.

title: The intersection of infectious diseases and public health: strengthening career paths
summary: The text discusses the intersection of infectious diseases and public health, emphasizing the importance of creating accessible career paths for ID fellows. Dr. Mati Hlatshwayo Davis, along with Dr. Nahid Bhadelia, Dr. Eric Chow, and Dr. Virginia Caine, highlight their experiences and contributions in public health. Dr. Bhadelia speaks on her work in emerging infectious diseases and the importance of sustained financing and trust in public health. Dr. Chow elaborates on the Epidemic Intelligence Service (EIS) and its role in training public health leaders. Dr. Caine emphasizes the need for better integration of public health training in academia. Dr. Davis underscores the necessity of diversity, equity, and inclusion in public health to build trust and representation. The conversation points to the need for better funding, mentorship, and innovative collaborations to support public health infrastructure and workforce development.

title: St. Louis cancels mask mandate, <24 hours after issuing it
summary: St. Louis officials rescinded a mask mandate for city employees less than 24 hours after it was issued. Originally, St. Louis Director of Health Matifadza Hlatshwayo Davis cited significant increases in COVID-19, RSV, and flu cases as the reason for the mandate. However, the health department later updated its data, showing less alarming trends. Area hospitals, including BJC Health Care and Mercy Hospital, reported typical winter increases in respiratory illnesses without significant strain on capacity. St. Louis County also reported moderate, non-alarming levels of illness. Mayor Tishaura Jones' office confirmed discussions with Gov. Mike Parson's office regarding the policy shift.

title: Opinion: Black Maternal Health Week highlights disparities in care
summary: Black Maternal Health Week (BMHW) highlights the significant disparities in maternal care experienced by Black women. Dr. Kanika A. Cunningham, director of the St. Louis County Department of Public Health, and Dr. Matifadza Hlatshwayo Davis, director of health for the city of St. Louis, emphasize the importance of addressing these inequities. They advocate for improved healthcare policies and practices to ensure better maternal health outcomes for Black women. Their contributions aim to raise awareness and drive systemic changes to reduce the maternal mortality rate and improve overall health care for Black mothers.

title: St. Louis City Retracts Mask Mandate for City Employees [UPDATE]
summary: The City of St. Louis initially mandated masks for city employees due to rising cases of COVID-19, flu, and RSV, but quickly retracted it, making masks strongly recommended instead. This decision followed concerns about the authority of the city's health director, Dr. Matifadza Hlatshwayo Davis, to issue such a mandate under state law. Despite the retraction, Mayor Tishaura Jones supports Dr. Davis's efforts to protect employee health. Dr. Davis highlighted the alarming rise in winter virus cases, including a 55% increase in flu cases and a 190% rise in RSV positive tests, stressing the need for preventive measures to avoid overburdening hospital systems.

title: ...Ready For It? (IDWeek 2023's version)
summary: IDWeek 2023, the annual meeting of the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) and other related societies, will be held in Boston, combining educational sessions, scientific presentations, and networking opportunities. Hosts Buddy Creech, Paul Sax, and Matifadza Hlatshwayo Davis discuss the significance of the event, emphasizing the importance of mentorship, collaboration, and the rejuvenation it brings to professionals. Davis highlights the critical role of community and fellowship, especially in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, and expresses excitement about the closing plenary on PEPFAR and public health. Both Sax and Davis share their strategies for navigating the conference, including attending debates and engaging in mentorship opportunities. They also touch on the expected behaviors regarding COVID-19 precautions and share personal anecdotes about their most embarrassing conference moments and favorite swag.

title: Advocacy, Equity and Beyond: The End of the COVID-19 Emergency Order
summary: The lifting of the COVID-19 public health emergency order has significant implications for clinical care, public health, and research. Dr. Mati Hlatshwayo Davis, the director of health for St. Louis, emphasized the critical role the emergency order played in facilitating rapid responses, including vaccine distribution, Medicaid expansion, and eviction pauses. Both Dr. Allison Agwu and Dr. Max Brito highlighted the potential negative impacts of ending the order, particularly on marginalized communities who benefited from the emergency provisions. They stressed the need for continued advocacy to maintain access to healthcare and support services. Dr. Davis called for a focus on health equity, urging for policies that sustain the gains made during the pandemic and prepare for future public health crises. The conversation underscored the importance of proactive measures and legislative advocacy to ensure vulnerable populations do not lose essential healthcare access.

title: Learn about Trauma-Related Resources Through the City of St. Louis Department of Health's First Instagram Live
summary: The City of St. Louis Department of Health will hold its first Instagram Live on December 19, 2023, to discuss trauma-related resources. The event will feature Dr. Mati Hlatshwayo Davis, Director of Health, and Dr. LJ Punch, Executive Director of Power4STL. They will highlight Power4STL's efforts to reduce overdose rates and provide trauma support in St. Louis. In 2022, St. Louis had 487 overdose deaths, disproportionately affecting Black residents. Power4STL's initiatives include community events, training, and support programs. Dr. Hlatshwayo Davis emphasizes the importance of community involvement and will discuss ways residents can volunteer and access resources. The Instagram Live aims to raise awareness and encourage participation in trauma-related support efforts.

title: St. Louis health director urges caution as hospitals drop mask requirements
summary: Dr. Matifadza Hlatshwayo Davis, St. Louis Department of Health director, advises caution as hospitals like SSM Health, Mercy, and St. Luke's drop mask mandates due to decreased COVID-19, flu, and RSV cases. She emphasizes that decisions on masking should consider the most vulnerable populations and that a one-size-fits-all approach is not feasible. Each healthcare system should tailor policies based on their specific conditions and patient demographics. This trend of easing mask requirements is expected to continue among hospitals, although some, like BJC Healthcare and St. Elizabeth’s in O’Fallon, Illinois, still mandate masks. Dr. Hlatshwayo Davis underscores the importance of adaptive policies rather than uniform mandates.

title: Case 40-2023: A 70-Year-Old Woman with Cough and Shortness of Breath | NEJM
summary: A 70-year-old woman in South Africa with advanced HIV presented with cough and shortness of breath. Despite antiretroviral therapy (ART), she experienced virologic failure and recurrent infections, including tuberculosis and COVID-19. Dr. Rajesh T. Gandhi contributed to the differential diagnosis, identifying persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection and aspergillus superinfection, exacerbated by her immunocompromised state. Diagnostic tests confirmed persistent SARS-CoV-2 with mutations. The patient’s ART regimen was adjusted to improve immune function, but she developed severe headaches and neurological symptoms, leading to a diagnosis of rhinocerebral aspergillosis. Despite treatment, she succumbed to her illnesses. Dr. Gandhi’s insights were crucial in understanding the interplay of her infections and immunodeficiency.

title: Among fully vaccinated, study shows Paxlovid does not shorten symptoms
summary: A study published in the New England Journal of Medicine found that for fully vaccinated individuals with at least one risk factor for severe COVID-19, the antiviral drug Paxlovid did not significantly reduce the duration of symptoms. The trial involved 1,296 participants, with no significant difference in symptom alleviation between those who took Paxlovid and those who took a placebo. The median age of participants was 42, and only 5% were 65 or older. Michael Osterholm emphasized that the findings might not apply to older, high-risk populations. Rajesh T. Gandhi, in an editorial, noted that Paxlovid's benefits might vary, with higher-risk patients deriving more significant benefits. Gandhi also called for longer-term studies to assess Paxlovid's effectiveness against long COVID.

title: Paxlovid Benefits Some COVID-19 Patients — Precision Vaccinations News
summary: A recent study published in The New England Journal of Medicine, sponsored by Pfizer Inc., examined the benefits of Paxlovid (nirmatrelvir–ritonavir) for COVID-19 patients. The study found no significant difference in the time to sustained alleviation of COVID-19 symptoms between those who received Paxlovid and those who received a placebo, with median times of 12 and 13 days, respectively. The study primarily involved younger participants, with a median age of 42. An editorial by Dr. Rajesh T. Gandhi and Dr. Martin Hirsch highlighted that Paxlovid benefits unvaccinated high-risk individuals but not those at lower risk for severe COVID-19. They emphasized the need for effective oral treatments for high-risk patients to reduce symptom duration and the risk of severe disease.

title: CDC/IDSA COVID-19 Clinician Call: Variants, Testing & Treatment: The Latest
summary: The CDC/IDSA COVID-19 Clinician Call on January 23, 2023, focused on the latest updates regarding COVID-19 variants, testing, and treatment. Key speakers included Pragna Patel, MD, MPH, who provided an epidemiology update, and Natalie J. Thornburg, PhD, who discussed the current variants landscape and diagnostic algorithms. Rajesh T. Gandhi, MD, FIDSA, contributed significantly by updating on COVID-19 therapeutics and clinical decision-making. Dr. Gandhi is the Director of HIV Clinical Services and Education at Massachusetts General Hospital and Co-Director of the Harvard Center for AIDS Research. The session also covered COVID-19 viral rebound, with further insights from Pragna Patel. The event aimed to provide clinicians with the latest information to improve patient care and outcomes.

title: IDWeek Chair: “Come up With the Best Program Possible”
summary: Heather Yun, MD, FACP, FIDS, serves as the IDWeek Chair for the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) and emphasizes the collaborative effort required to organize the extensive conference. She highlights the importance of teamwork, organization, and support in creating a successful program. Yun feels privileged to be part of the IDWeek team and aims for attendees to leave the conference feeling inspired, knowledgeable, and optimistic about their roles in infectious disease management. Outside of her conference duties, Yun focuses on research related to multidrug-resistant infections in wartime, discussing how wars exacerbate disease spread and antimicrobial resistance (AMR). She notes that war environments, like those in Ukraine and Israel, create complex health challenges due to injuries, endemic diseases, and displaced populations. Yun's insights cover IDWeek, AMR in wartime, and emerging infectious disease threats.

title: Heather Yun, MD, IDWeek 2023 Chair, Says Emerging Threats May be Bigger than Pathogens
summary: Heather Yun, MD, chair of IDWeek 2023, highlighted that emerging threats to human health may extend beyond pathogens. As deputy commander for Medical Services at Brooke Army Medical Center and a professor at the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, Yun emphasized the interconnectedness of infectious diseases with various global issues. During the IDWeek 2023 scientific sessions in Boston, she stressed that a range of factors, not just pathogens, pose significant risks to human health. Yun's insights underscore the importance of addressing broader systemic challenges in conjunction with infectious disease management.

title: KOL Spotlight on Infectious Disease Week 2023
summary: ID Week 2023, themed "advancing science and improving care," focused on the latest science and strategies for the prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and epidemiology of infectious diseases. The event featured Dr. Johanna Kaufmann, who presented a study on a next-generation intranasal COVID-19 vaccine. Dr. Heather Yun, the IDSA program chair for this year, discussed emerging threats and trends in infectious disease.

title: BAMC patients have new option for dialysis treatment
summary: Brooke Army Medical Center (BAMC) now offers inpatients an additional dialysis treatment option to manage kidney failure, including peritoneal dialysis, which provides continuous filtration using the abdominal lining. This new service complements the existing hemodialysis option. Dr. Mai Nguyen, a BAMC nephrologist, highlights the benefits of peritoneal dialysis, such as maintaining residual renal function longer and having fewer dietary restrictions. The nephrology team, supported by surgical and nursing colleagues, aims to provide optimal patient care and training opportunities. Air Force Col. Heather Yun, deputy commander for medical services, praised the nephrology team's efforts to expand treatment options, emphasizing their commitment to offering cutting-edge care.

title: IDWeek 2023, October 11-15: Preview of Topics and Presentations
summary: IDWeek 2023, held from October 11-15 in Boston, will feature topics in infectious disease, including COVID-19 vaccines, climate change impacts, and strategies to end the HIV epidemic. Michael Osterholm will discuss COVID-19 vaccines' future. Sessions on influenza and respiratory syncytial virus will be highlighted. The effects of climate change on pathogens will be addressed, with experts like George Thompson III and A. Krishna Rao presenting. Outreach programs for vulnerable populations to end the HIV epidemic will be discussed, and disparities in infection prevention and antimicrobial stewardship will be examined. Heather Yun, MD, IDWeek chair, emphasized the collaborative nature of the event.

title: Regena Spratling, PhD, RN, APRN, CPNP-PC, FAANP, FAAN: Highlights From NAPNAP Annual Conference
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Regena Spratling, PhD, RN, APRN, CPNP-PC, FAANP, FAAN, is the president of the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) and a professor at Georgia State University. At the NAPNAP 2024 annual meeting, she highlighted the organization's growth in membership and conference attendance, emphasizing the importance of member engagement through virtual events and book clubs. Dr. Spratling discussed the focus on pediatric mental and behavioral health, including initiatives to screen mothers for postpartum depression. She also mentioned the NAPNAP Partners for Vulnerable Youth program. Her research centers on children requiring medical technology, leading to the development of the COPE-STAR intervention, which provides educational modules for parents of children with tracheostomies and feeding tubes. Dr. Spratling's term as NAPNAP president will conclude in July 2024.

title: NAPNAP Launches Second Phase of CE Courses to Support Pediatric Mental Health
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: The National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) has launched the second phase of its NAPNAP Cares program, which includes 20 online continuing education (CE) courses aimed at addressing pediatric mental health. These courses are designed to prepare pediatric-focused nurse practitioners (NPs) and advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) to meet the growing mental and behavioral health needs of pediatric patients and their families. Regena Spratling, NAPNAP President, highlighted the importance of these courses in promoting positive patient outcomes by focusing on every step of mental health care, from evaluation to ongoing management. The program has received a positive response from members and offers free access to NAPNAP members for up to a year.

title: Daniel Crawford, DNP: Moving the Needle on Quality Health Outcomes for Children
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Daniel Crawford, DNP, is a key figure in advancing pediatric health care, particularly for underserved and rural populations. As the Associate Dean for Graduate Practice Programs and an Associate Professor at the University of Iowa College of Nursing, he also serves as the president-elect of the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP). Crawford emphasizes the importance of providing equitable, high-quality health care and has co-led NAPNAP's strategic planning task force to address these goals. He highlights the shortage of primary care providers, particularly pediatric nurse practitioners, and stresses the need for increased federal funding for NP education. Crawford also maintains a clinical practice in pediatric neurology, specializing in epilepsy, and has a personal connection to the field through his daughter's experience with the condition. His leadership aims to enhance health outcomes for children and support the professional growth of nurse practitioners.

title: We Are Not Ok, Say Pediatric NPs
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: A survey by the National Association of Pediatric Nurse Practitioners (NAPNAP) reveals significant burnout and mental health issues among pediatric advanced practice registered nurses (APRNs) due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Nearly 90% of pediatric APRNs reported professional burnout, with worsening symptoms like exhaustion and moral distress. Conducted between February 2021 and September 2022, the survey led by NAPNAP President Jennifer T. Sonney and Dr. Jessica L. Peck highlighted a rise in concerns about burnout, anxiety, and depression. Additionally, 94% of respondents expressed alarm over pediatric patients' mental health. High rates of misinformation, health inequities, and rapid policy changes were identified as barriers to clinical practice. Telehealth adoption was a positive outcome, increasing access to care. Drs. Peck and Sonney emphasized the urgent need for systemic support to address these issues.

title: Officers who helped save baby overdosing on fentanyl speak out
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF PEDIATRIC NURSE PRACTITIONERS
summary: Fort Myers police officers saved a baby overdosing on fentanyl. Bodycam footage shows them performing CPR until EMTs arrived. The mother, Mary Sinopoli, was arrested for aggravated child abuse. Officer Darian Lutz focused on the baby, while Officer Zach Shifflet worked seamlessly with his team. Cassandra Newell, the 911 operator, persistently called back after the initial call was disconnected, ensuring timely assistance. Officer Kelley Whyt, emotionally affected, compared the situation to her own child. The officers credited Newell's persistence for the successful rescue. This incident highlights the dangers of fentanyl, which claims many lives annually.

title: 2023 Massey Awards recognize service to Carolina | UNC-Chapel Hill
hco: KAPLAN NORTH AMERICA LLC DBA PROJECTS IN KNOWLEDGE
summary: The 2023 Massey Awards at UNC-Chapel Hill recognized five employees and one team for their exceptional service to the university. The awards, established in 1980 by C. Knox Massey, honor outstanding contributions by university staff. Recipients include David Barnette, Allan Blattner, Ken Cleary, Melissa Mack, Chineka Stanley, and the Campus Health leadership team. Melissa Mack, the operations manager and special events coordinator at the Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center, was highlighted for her nearly 30-year tenure. She manages daily administrative duties, faculty recruitment, and major research events, receiving acclaim for her dedication and professionalism. Each awardee receives a $10,000 stipend and an award citation.

title: Recommendations for Addressing Health-Related Social Needs in Cancer Care Introduced at NCCN Policy Summit
summary: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) held a policy summit to introduce new recommendations for addressing health-related social needs (HRSNs) in cancer care. Key speakers, including Ellen Lukens and Danya Garner, highlighted the importance of screening and addressing HRSNs such as transportation, housing, food access, and financial security. The recommendations, developed by a working group led by Yelak Biru and Loretta Erhunmwunsee, emphasize routine annual screening and at care transition points. Danya Garner, representing the Oncology Nursing Society, stressed the critical role of addressing patients' physical, emotional, psychological, and social needs in achieving better health outcomes. The summit underscored the need for systemic changes, education, and policy advocacy to ensure comprehensive and equitable cancer care.

title: Sylvester Nurse Next President of the Oncology Nursing Society - InventUM
summary: Jessica MacIntyre, with over 20 years of experience at Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center, will become the next president of the Oncology Nursing Society (ONS) in April 2024. Her presidency aims to support early-career oncology nurses and nurse practitioners, preparing them to care for future oncology patients. MacIntyre has significantly impacted cancer care, contributing to publications, educational modules, and advanced practice initiatives through the ONS. She plans to promote mentorship, professional development, and advanced education to empower oncology nurses and nurse practitioners. Inspired by her grandmother’s cancer journey, MacIntyre pursued a career in oncology nursing, eventually earning a Master of Science in Nursing and a Doctor of Nursing Practice. She currently oversees several clinical programs at Sylvester, including oncology social work and cancer prevention. MacIntyre hopes her role as ONS president will bring more visibility to Sylvester and attract top nursing talent to the center.

title: EMR App Increases Patient Referrals to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society
summary: Jessica MacIntyre, DNP, MBA, APRN, NP-C, AOCNP, and her colleagues developed a Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR)-based app to increase patient referrals to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) via electronic medical records (EMRs). Prior to the app's implementation, the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center saw only 10 referrals in two years using paper forms. The app, embedded in EMRs, facilitated 245 referrals over 15 months, resulting in approximately 700 interactions between patients and LLS. MacIntyre presented these findings at the 48th Annual Oncology Nursing Society Congress, highlighting how the app streamlined the referral process and enabled better tracking of metrics. The app also ensured patients received financial assistance, education, and conference information from LLS. The next steps involve integrating the referral process into the navigator pane for advanced practice providers and physicians, while addressing challenges related to different EMR systems.

title: Opinion | Medical Misinfo Runs Rampant Online. The Gov't Must Retain the Right to Intervene.
summary: Medical misinformation, particularly about vaccines, is rampant online and poses a significant threat to public health. This misinformation undermines trust in science, reduces vaccine uptake, and leads to the resurgence of preventable diseases like measles. Benjamin D. Hoffman, MD, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, and Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association, argue that the government must have the authority to intervene and combat false medical claims. They emphasize that preventing the spread of misinformation is crucial and requires a collective effort from the federal government, public health agencies, healthcare organizations, social media companies, media outlets, and individual physicians. Hoffman and Ehrenfeld highlight the importance of maintaining this authority to protect public health and prevent unnecessary harm.

title: OHSU Doernbecher offers water safety tips to help prevent drowning
summary: OHSU Doernbecher Children's Hospital emphasizes water safety to prevent drownings, especially as Oregon children experience higher drowning rates than the national average. Pediatricians, including Benjamin Hoffman, M.D., stress the importance of constant and capable adult supervision around water. Hoffman, a professor of pediatrics and medical director of the Tom Sargent Safety Center, shares that drowning can occur silently and quickly, often within seconds. He advocates for "layers of protection" which include swim lessons, attentive supervision, life jackets, CPR training, and physical barriers around water sources. Hoffman, who is also the president-elect of the American Academy of Pediatrics, underscores that these measures can significantly reduce the risk of water-related injuries and fatalities.

title: Negotiating to get paid what you deserve
summary: Susan J. Kressly, MD, FAAP, shared insights on negotiating fair compensation during her session at the 2023 American Academy of Pediatrics National Conference & Exhibition. She emphasized the importance of understanding one's value and leveraging unique skills to negotiate contracts effectively. Kressly highlighted disparities in earnings, particularly for women, and stressed the need for physicians to own their worth and advocate for themselves. She advised both new and experienced physicians to understand the business aspects of medicine, know their wants versus needs, and continually reassess their compensation packages. For those uncomfortable with negotiation, Kressly recommended practice and viewing compensation discussions as essential for long-term career satisfaction and resource management. She also noted the significance of understanding hiring motivations and maintaining ongoing contract discussions throughout one's career.

title: 2023 Most Influential in Healthcare Dr. Sandy Chung
summary: Dr. Sandy Chung, ranked 91st among the 100 Most Influential People in Healthcare in 2023, is the President of the American Academy of Pediatrics, representing over 67,000 pediatricians. Chung has advocated for the automatic enrollment of newborns in a combined Medicaid and Children’s Health Insurance Program, with an opt-out option if other coverage is available. She focuses on improving youth behavioral care services, promoting vaccinations, and enhancing the sustainability of the pediatric profession. Additionally, Chung is the CEO of Trusted Doctors, medical director of informatics at Children’s National’s Pediatric Health Network, medical director of the Virginia Mental Health Access Program, and co-chair of the Virginia Task Force on Primary Care.

title: HELLO PEDIATRICS COMPLETES SERIES B FUNDING ROUND SUPPORTING PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT ...
summary: Hello Pediatrics, a provider of after-hours telehealth services for children, completed a series B funding round led by Sequoia Health Strategies and Dialectic Capital, raising $3 million. The funding will support the addition of integrated behavioral health services, expansion into new states, and technology enhancements. Paul Portsmore, CEO of Sequoia Health Strategies, and Sandy Chung, MD, a board-certified pediatrician, will join the board, along with John Fichthorn of Dialectic Capital. Dr. Sandy Chung expressed enthusiasm for Hello Pediatrics' mission to provide comprehensive healthcare services to children, highlighting the importance of integrating behavioral health services and collaboration with primary care providers. CEO Lucy Janoyan emphasized the company's commitment to leveraging technology to improve healthcare delivery and expand their reach.

title: What Congress can do to address the rural doctor shortage - STAT
summary: The physician shortage in rural America has been worsened by burnout, financial challenges, and administrative burdens, alongside an aging population and workforce. Nearly 334,000 healthcare professionals left the field in 2021, and a significant shortage of mental health professionals is projected by 2025. Policymakers must focus on reducing medical student debt, which deters many from entering lower-paying primary care fields and affects diversity within the physician workforce. Sandy Chung, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, advocates for policies that provide debt relief for physicians in high-need roles and supports legislation like the Resident Education Deferred Interest Act. Expanding programs like the National Health Service Corps and Medicare Graduate Medical Education slots can help place physicians in underserved areas. Congress should also support the Conrad State 30 and Physician Access Reauthorization Act to retain foreign doctors in the U.S. These measures are crucial to sustaining a robust healthcare workforce.

title: All children deserve healthcare. So why are kids dying in CBP custody?
summary: An 8-year-old girl, Ana Danay Reyes Álvarez, died in U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) custody due to systemic failures in medical care. Despite having sickle cell disease and a heart condition, Ana's symptoms were repeatedly dismissed by medical personnel. Dr. Sandy Chung, president of the American Academy of Pediatrics, highlights the urgent need for comprehensive reforms in CBP facilities to prevent such tragedies. Chung advocates for the appointment of a pediatrician as chief medical officer and calls for a full investigation into Ana's death and other similar incidents. Dr. Paul Wise's recommendations for improving medical assessments and care in CBP facilities are also emphasized. The American Academy of Pediatrics stresses the importance of providing trauma-informed care and a child-friendly environment in CBP custody to ensure the health and safety of children.

title: AAP board creates task force on pediatrician safety and well-being, extends CEO contract
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Board has created a Task Force on Safety and Wellbeing Within the Pediatric Profession in response to the 2022 Leadership Conference's top resolution. This initiative aims to support pediatrician advocates facing stress, threats, or public attacks. Additionally, the board extended CEO Mark Del Monte's contract for another five years, recognizing his leadership during the COVID-19 pandemic and his efforts in advocacy, equity, diversity, and inclusion. AAP President Sandy L. Chung praised Del Monte's contributions, highlighting his energy and dedication. The board also discussed extending terms for some members to stabilize governance and approved a $142 million budget for the 2023-’24 fiscal year.

title: Medical Group Backs Youth Gender Treatments, but Calls for Research Review
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) reaffirmed its support for gender-affirming care for minors, despite such treatments being banned in 19 states. The AAP also commissioned a systematic review of medical research on these treatments, mirroring efforts in Europe that found uncertain evidence for their effectiveness in adolescents. Mark Del Monte, AAP's chief executive, emphasized the board's confidence in current policies but acknowledged the need for more detailed evidence. The AAP plans to update clinical guidance based on the review. The decision comes amid political pressures and legislative bans on gender-affirming care, which the AAP has condemned. Critics argue the recommendations are based on weak evidence, while supporters highlight the positive impact on mental health for transgender adolescents.

title: Pediatricians’ group plans evidence review to inform care for transgender youth
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has reaffirmed its support for gender-affirming care for transgender youth and plans to conduct an additional review of research to further inform and support pediatricians. This review aims to create expanded documents, including a clinical report and a technical report, to ensure clinicians have the best possible evidence. Mark Del Monte, CEO of the AAP, stated that the review was triggered by academy bylaws requiring policy statements to be reviewed every five years. The updated review will involve outside experts and aims to provide comprehensive guidance for managing transgender patients. Gender-affirming care includes mental health care, social services, and medical treatments such as hormone therapy. Despite the support from major medical associations, gender-affirming care faces bans in 21 states and ongoing debates over its long-term effects.

title: AAP Reaffirms Policy Supporting Gender-Affirming Care for Minors
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) reaffirmed its 2018 guidance supporting gender-affirming care for minors and initiated a systematic literature review to provide updated advice to pediatricians. AAP CEO Mark Del Monte emphasized the creation of two additional documents—a clinical report and a technical report—to ensure clinicians have the best evidence. This process will be enhanced by an external systematic review aimed at broadening and deepening the AAP's guidance. The reaffirmation reflects confidence in existing evidence, despite concerns from some quarters about the timing of the review. Critics argue that the review should precede policy reaffirmation, while supporters, including Kellan Baker, highlight the robustness of the current evidence base.

title: Leading U.S. Pediatricians' Group Reaffirms Support for Gender-Related Care for Minors
summary: The American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) has reaffirmed its support for gender-related treatments for minors while planning a thorough review of existing medical research. This decision comes amid legislative bans in 19 U.S. states and follows similar reviews in England and Sweden, which found uncertain evidence for the treatments' effectiveness. Mark Del Monte, AAP's chief executive, emphasized the board's confidence in the current policy but acknowledged the need for additional details. The AAP aims to issue updated clinical guidance following the review. The organization argues that legislative bans interfere with doctor-patient decisions and has supported court challenges against such bans. Critics argue that recommendations are based on weak evidence, while proponents highlight the positive impact on transgender adolescents' mental health.

title: A ‘game changer’ for mental health
summary: The MC3 program, based at the University of Michigan Department of Psychiatry, provides rapid and confidential mental health consultation to primary care providers across Michigan. This service is crucial, given the state's shortage of mental health professionals. Dr. Lia Gaggino, a primary care pediatrician in Kalamazoo, has been using MC3 since 2012. She highlights how MC3 has significantly enhanced her ability to diagnose and treat children's mental health issues, improving her confidence and competence as a caregiver. MC3 supports over 3,200 medical professionals, offering same-day consultations, educational resources, and medication guides. The program has successfully reduced the need for higher-level mental health care in 95% of cases. Dr. Gaggino attests to MC3 being a "game changer," transforming her prescribing behavior for the better by providing expert guidance.

title: A 'game changer' for mental health
summary: The MC3 program at the University of Michigan Department of Psychiatry supports primary care providers across Michigan in managing patients' mental health needs, particularly for pregnant, postpartum women, children, adolescents, and young adults. Providers can consult U-M psychiatrists for rapid advice via phone or secure online forms. This service is crucial in areas with a shortage of mental health providers. MC3 also offers updated medication guides and free online education. Pediatrician Lia Gaggino, an early user of MC3, highlights its impact on her prescribing practices and the management of complex mental health cases. The program has been especially valuable during the mental health crisis exacerbated by the pandemic.

title: Mississippi moves from last to 33rd in developmental screenings of kids
summary: Mississippi has improved its early childhood development screening rate from last place to 33rd in the nation, thanks to a $17-million federal grant and the Mississippi Thrive! project. Dr. Susan Buttross, director of the child development clinic at the University of Mississippi Medical Center, highlighted this unprecedented improvement. Despite the end of federal funding, Buttross and her team continue their work through the Early Childhood Development Coalition, securing financial support to sustain their efforts. The project, a collaboration between UMMC and Mississippi State University, trained physicians and other stakeholders, significantly increasing screening rates. Buttross emphasized the importance of early detection and intervention for better child development outcomes.

title: Mississippi sees rise in child development screenings
summary: Mississippi has improved its ranking in childhood developmental and behavioral screenings from 50th to 34th in the nation over five years. This progress is attributed to the Mississippi Thrive! partnership between the University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC) and Mississippi State University’s Social Science Research Center. In 2017, only 18.6% of children in Mississippi received developmental screenings, but this figure has increased by 15.5%. The initiative is supported by $17.4 million from the Health Resources and Services Administration and includes subcommittees like Mississippi Help Me Grow and Enhanced Pediatric Medical Home Services. Dr. Susan Buttross from UMMC has been instrumental in this coalition, which aims to connect children and families with necessary care to prepare them for school.

title: Jacksonville pediatrician: 'Early intervention' key to child obesity
summary: An 8-year-old girl in Jacksonville, considered obese, struggled with high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and pre-diabetes. Her pediatrician, Dr. Madeline Joseph of UF Health Pediatric Multispecialty Center, contributed significantly to the American Academy of Pediatrics' new guidelines on childhood obesity. These guidelines emphasize early intervention, therapy, and medication rather than delaying treatment. Joseph used the girl's dream of performing cartwheels to motivate her weight loss through behavior modification. The new guidelines recommend comprehensive, family-involved treatment plans and caution against relying on medication and surgery unless necessary. Joseph highlighted the importance of addressing obesity early and the need for systemic change to support healthier lifestyles for children. She noted the COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated childhood obesity due to increased indoor time and reliance on fast food. The girl eventually achieved her cartwheel goal, reversing her pre-diabetes, illustrating the effectiveness of early intervention and personalized motivation.

title: Transcriptional co-activators: emerging roles in signaling pathways and potential therapeutic targets for diseases ...
summary: Transcriptional co-activators are critical in regulating gene expression through interactions with transcription factors. Deregulation of these co-activators is linked to various diseases, including cancer, developmental, and metabolic disorders. Historically considered "undruggable," transcription factors can now be targeted indirectly through co-activators. The review by Priyanka Dey Talukdar and Urmi Chatterji explores the roles of co-activators in transcription regulation, emphasizing their potential as therapeutic targets. It highlights the importance of understanding co-activator mechanisms, their involvement in diseases, and the development of small molecule inhibitors, PROTACs, and molecular glue degraders to modulate their activity. This approach aims to improve patient outcomes by offering new therapeutic strategies with enhanced benefits and reduced side effects.

title: Biodegradation of ciprofloxacin using machine learning tools: Kinetics and modelling
summary: The study investigates the biodegradation of ciprofloxacin using microbial consortia and machine learning tools, such as Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and Response Surface Methodology (RSM). It highlights the limitations of conventional physico-chemical treatment processes and proposes biodegradation as a cost-effective and sustainable alternative. The research aimed to optimize the parameters for ciprofloxacin degradation, achieving a 95.5% efficiency. Amal Krishna Saha contributed to the study by handling software, formal analysis, and data curation. The study underscores the environmental implications of antibiotic pollution and the efficacy of machine learning tools in improving biodegradation processes, thereby offering a greener solution for wastewater treatment.

title: Sofosbuvir/Velpatasvir/Voxilaprevir for Hepatitis C Virus Retreatment in Difficult-to-treat Patients: A Real-life ...
summary: This observational study from India investigates the efficacy of sofosbuvir/velpatasvir/voxilaprevir as a second-line therapy for difficult-to-treat Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) patients who failed to achieve sustained virological response at 12 weeks (SVR12) with other treatments. Fifteen patients, predominantly male and with genotype-3 infections, were treated with this combination plus ribavirin for 12 weeks. Fourteen patients achieved SVR12, indicating a high success rate. Rajani Singh contributed to the analysis, investigation, and writing of the original draft. The study concludes that this combination is effective for HCV retreatment in challenging cases.

title: What Does It Mean to Get Diagnosed with Lynch Syndrome?
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: Lynch syndrome is an inherited condition that increases the risk of various cancers, including colorectal, endometrial, and others. Adrienne Skinner, Wenora Johnson, and Alejandro Mirazo share their experiences with Lynch syndrome, highlighting the importance of awareness and proactive health measures. Skinner discovered her condition after her sister's cancer diagnosis and underwent preventive surgeries and regular screenings. Johnson, diagnosed with colorectal cancer in 2011, opted for a hysterectomy and emphasizes the importance of genetic testing and research. Mirazo learned about his condition through a DNA sequencing study, leading to early-stage colon cancer detection. They advocate for broader awareness and accessibility of genetic testing, particularly for high-risk groups.

title: Spotlight On: Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered (FORCE)
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: Sue Friedman, diagnosed with breast cancer at 33, discovered she had a BRCA2 mutation, which increases cancer risk. Finding no existing support for those with hereditary mutations, she founded FORCE (Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered) in 1999. FORCE provides resources and support for individuals and families impacted by hereditary cancers, including those with BRCA mutations and others like Lynch syndrome. The organization offers a helpline, peer navigation, online forums, and support groups. FORCE advocates for laws to protect those at risk and ensures access to screening and treatment. They also host the Joining FORCEs Against Hereditary Cancer conference. FORCE aims to educate and support families to make informed healthcare decisions and hopes for greater awareness and better prevention options for hereditary cancers.

title: Adipose tissue and skeletal muscle wasting precede clinical diagnosis of pancreatic cancer
hco: FORCE FACING OUR RISK OF CANCER EMPOWERED
summary: The study investigates whether adipose tissue and skeletal muscle wasting can precede the clinical diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. By analyzing CT scans from 714 pancreatic cancer cases and 1748 controls, it was found that adipose tissue loss is detectable up to 6 months before diagnosis, while skeletal muscle wasting can be observed up to 18 months prior. These findings suggest that tissue wasting could serve as an early indicator of pancreatic cancer, occurring in both localized and metastatic cases. The study emphasizes the potential of longitudinal tissue measurements in high-risk populations for early cancer detection. Matt Yurgelun contributed to the study's design, data acquisition, and manuscript revision.

title: FORECAST 2024: OCOM coming to Horizon West | West Orange Times & Observer
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC INTERNISTS INC
summary: The Orlando College of Osteopathic Medicine (OCOM) in Horizon West, set to open in August 2024, is a $200 million investment expected to generate a $1.7 billion economic impact by 2045. The institution aims to train skilled osteopathic physicians, with an inaugural class of 90 students and a full enrollment target of 180. Dr. Kiran C. Patel, the benefactor, emphasized the transformative impact on regional healthcare. Under the leadership of Dean and Chief Academic Officer Dr. Robert T. Hasty, OCOM has recruited nearly 1,000 clinical faculty and designed a cutting-edge curriculum. Hasty highlighted the school's commitment to creating a world-class medical education environment, featuring modern facilities and comprehensive support systems for students. OCOM has secured affiliations with 20 hospitals and medical centers, facilitating clinical rotations by 2026. The campus will also contribute significantly to the local economy and community health services.

title: opens new medical school amid projected physician shortage
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC INTERNISTS INC
summary: Central Florida has inaugurated its first osteopathic medical school, the Orlando College of Osteopathic Medicine, in Winter Garden. The institution, funded by billionaire philanthropist Dr. Kiran C. Patel, cost around $200 million, including $75 million for a 144,000-square-foot facility built over 18 months. The inaugural class consists of 97 students starting in August 2024. Dr. Robert T. Hasty, serving as the Dean and Chief Administrative Officer, has been instrumental in the establishment and administration of the college. This new school aims to address the projected physician shortage in the region.

title: Another hit for gender-affirming care as FL osteopathic board reverses itself • Florida Phoenix
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC INTERNISTS INC
summary: The Florida Board of Osteopathic Medicine reversed its tentative support for nonsurgical gender-affirming care for minors, aligning with the Florida Board of Medicine's stance. This decision followed the recent appointment of Dr. Watson Ducatel by Governor Ron DeSantis. Ducatel, practicing in Tampa, moved to remove the exemption for such treatments, sparking anger during a public hearing. The board's reversal aligns with DeSantis's agenda to end gender-affirming care for minors. The decision has faced criticism from advocates like Simone Chriss, who highlighted the benefits of gender-affirming care and the negative consequences of its denial. The board's move to unify standards with the Board of Medicine was also supported by John Wilson from the Florida Department of Health. Democratic representatives Jennifer Harris and Anna Eskamani emphasized the overwhelming support for gender-affirming care from leading medical groups, warning that its removal could lead to severe mental health consequences for affected minors.

title: DeSantis is appointing new medical board members while slamming gender-affirming care for youth • Florida Phoenix
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC INTERNISTS INC
summary: Governor Ron DeSantis has appointed six new members to the Florida Board of Medicine and Board of Osteopathic Medicine since December 2022, amidst a push to ban gender-affirming care for minors. The osteopathic board, now including Dr. Watson Ducatel, has proposed more lenient rules allowing nonsurgical treatments for minors in clinical trials, while the Board of Medicine opposes any exceptions. A joint meeting on February 10, 2023, will discuss these rules, sparking outrage from LGBTQ+ advocates. DeSantis has publicly criticized gender-affirming care, pledging to revoke medical licenses for providers offering such treatments to minors and to legislate further restrictions.

title: Florida Board of Medicine votes to prohibit gender-affirming care to minors
hco: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OSTEOPATHIC INTERNISTS INC
summary: On February 10, 2023, the Florida Board of Medicine and the Florida Board of Osteopathic Medicine unanimously voted to prohibit most gender-affirming care for transgender minors, including hormone therapies and surgeries. The decision followed two hours of public comment and was influenced by a perceived lack of research on the subject. Newly appointed board member Dr. Watson Ducatel introduced a successful motion to remove an exemption for clinical trials. Despite protests and public opposition, including emotional testimonies from affected individuals, the boards upheld the proposed rules. The new regulations do not yet have an established enactment date.

title: Chasing Cancer
summary: The Washington Post's "Chasing Cancer" event highlighted advancements and challenges in cancer treatment and prevention. Key figures like Dr. Douglas R. Lowy, Ellen V. Sigal, and Dr. Richard Pazdur discussed innovative treatments, drug policy, and early detection. Ellen V. Sigal, PhD, contributed significantly as the Chairperson and Founder of Friends of Cancer Research, an organization that drives collaboration to advance science, policy, and regulation for faster, safer cancer treatments. The event emphasized the potential of lifestyle changes in preventing up to 50% of cancers and featured discussions on patient autonomy in health management. Additionally, Imagine Dragons shared their work with the Tyler Robinson Foundation to support families affected by pediatric cancer.

title: Board of Directors + Governance
summary: The Foundation for the National Institutes of Health (FNIH) is led by a distinguished Board of Directors, including experts in medicine, science, and business. Dr. Steven M. Paul, Chairman, is a renowned CNS drug development expert with significant contributions to Eli Lilly and the NIH. Dr. Julie Louise Gerberding, President and CEO, has a notable background with Merck and the CDC. Dr. Solomon H. Snyder, Vice Chairman, is celebrated for his work in neuroscience at Johns Hopkins. Ellen V. Sigal, PhD, is the Chairperson and Founder of Friends of Cancer Research, a nonprofit organization dedicated to accelerating cancer research and treatment. She has held numerous leadership roles in cancer advocacy and public policy organizations, significantly impacting cancer research funding and public education. The board also includes other prominent figures with substantial contributions to their respective fields, ensuring robust governance and strategic direction for FNIH.

title: Nixon National Cancer Conference - the legacy of the National Cancer Act
summary: The Nixon National Cancer Conference (NNCC) is an annual event focused on cancer research and patient care, featuring prominent figures such as Nobel laureates, physicians, and specialists. Initiated by the 1971 National Cancer Act, which was a significant healthcare legislation under Nixon's administration, the conference aims to advance understanding and treatment of cancer. The 2025 NNCC will be held on January 15-16 at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum. Marlene Malek, R.N., has been a notable contributor, serving on the steering committee for multiple years, including 2021 and 2022. The conference includes keynote speeches, panel discussions, and contributions from various sponsors and institutions, emphasizing ongoing innovation and collaboration in oncology.

title: From Policy to Progress: Third Annual Nixon National Cancer Conference Highlights How the Visionary National ...
summary: The third annual Nixon National Cancer Conference, held on January 17-18, 2024, at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library, gathered over 400 experts to discuss advancements in cancer research stemming from the National Cancer Act of 1971. Annette Walker highlighted the Act's impact, celebrating 18 million cancer survivors. Dr. Douglas Lowy discussed the SEER program's global research potential. Dr. William Li received the inaugural Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach Award for his contributions to cancer treatment. Marlene Malek, Vice Chair and Co-Founder of Friends of Cancer Research and Nixon Foundation Board member, introduced Dr. Li. Panels on AI in oncology, precision oncology, the gut microbiome, and patient care provided insights into current and future cancer research and treatment. The conference underscored the ongoing commitment to improving cancer care and research, with next year's event scheduled for January 15-16, 2025.

title: Silverchain partners with Sheba Beyond to revolutionise digital home care in Australia
summary: Australia’s Silverchain, a leading home care provider, has teamed up with Sheba Beyond, a virtual hospital, to improve digital home care in Australia. This collaboration aims to develop innovative home care models using digital technologies, enhancing patient care. The partnership includes Sheba's ARC Center for Innovation in Israel. Silverchain's CEO, Dale Fisher, emphasized the importance of this international knowledge exchange. This marks the first Sheba MoU in Australia involving Sheba Beyond. The partnership will use Sheba's digital care expertise and Silverchain's research, focusing on mental health, palliative care, cardiology, rehabilitation, and acute health care. Professor Anna Barker, Silverchain’s Executive Director of Research and Innovation, plays a key role in this initiative. Sheba’s Chief Innovation Officer, Professor Eyal Zimlichman, expressed excitement for the partnership, aiming to transform healthcare delivery and improve health equity in Australia.

title: Annual Meeting 2024: Opening Ceremony Highlights Banner Year
summary: The AACR Annual Meeting 2024, led by CEO Margaret Foti, PhD, MD (hc), marked a significant year with over 23,000 registrants. Foti highlighted the progress in cancer research, noting a 33% decline in cancer death rates over three decades and over 18 million cancer survivors in the U.S. Despite rising cancer incidence, the meeting aimed to inspire further advancements. Key initiatives included the AACR Cancer Centers Alliance, the AACR Center for Cancer Clinical Trials, and the inaugural AACR Oncology Industry Partnering Event. The meeting also emphasized health equity and scientific communication, with new working groups and task forces dedicated to various cancer research areas.

title: Chi Van Dang to receive 2024 AACR-Margaret Foti Award
summary: Chi Van Dang will receive the 2024 AACR-Margaret Foti Award for Leadership and Extraordinary Achievements in Cancer Research. The award ceremony will be held during the AACR annual meeting from April 5-10 in San Diego, CA. Margaret Foti, after whom the award is named, has made significant contributions to cancer research and leadership within the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR).

title: Driving Japan-US Collaboration in Oncology | National Cancer Center Japan
summary: Dr. Hitoshi Nakagama and Dr. Hiroyuki Mano, along with Dr. Margaret Foti, CEO of the American Association of Cancer Research, met with Mr. Raymond F. Greene, the Deputy Chief of Mission of the US embassy in Japan on September 20, 2023. Dr. Mano is the President of the 82nd Annual Meeting of the Japanese Cancer Association. The meeting focused on promoting closer collaboration between the academic institutions of Japan and the US in oncology. Mr. Greene expressed support for the Japanese Cancer Association meeting and encouraged further collaboration, including the revival of the Korea-US-Japan Trilateral Moonshot Initiative. Dr. Foti's involvement underscores the commitment to enhancing collaborative efforts in cancer research between the two nations. The National Cancer Center Japan will continue to drive these collaborative efforts.

title: Convening the Nation's Cancer Centers to Accelerate Progress
summary: The American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) has launched the AACR Cancer Centers Alliance, a collaboration among the nation's cancer centers to enhance their impact on patient care. This initiative, announced in Washington, D.C., follows meetings where cancer center directors discussed joint efforts to accelerate cancer research discoveries. Margaret Foti, PhD, MD (hc), the CEO of AACR, emphasized that the Alliance aligns with AACR's mission to foster collaboration in cancer research, marking a significant milestone in the fight against cancer. The Alliance aims to synergize with President Biden’s Cancer Moonshot and the National Cancer Plan to improve patient outcomes.

title: AACR Annual Meeting 2023: Opening Ceremony Heralds Extraordinary Science
summary: The AACR Annual Meeting 2023 began with an Opening Ceremony led by Margaret Foti, CEO of AACR. Foti expressed excitement about the science to be presented, covering the spectrum of cancer research. This year's theme is "Advancing the Frontiers of Cancer Science and Medicine." She highlighted progress in cancer research and the importance of public trust in science. The meeting also celebrated anniversaries such as the 10th anniversary of the Rally for Medical Research and Cancer Immunology Research journal, and the 25th anniversary of the Scientist↔Survivor Program®. New initiatives were announced, including a high school internship and the expansion of AACR Project GENIE.

title: Yikes! $1 Million Charity Salaries | Charity Ratings | Donating Tips | Best Charities | CharityWatch
summary: CharityWatch has compiled a list of nonprofit executives earning $1 million or more in compensation, based on data as of October 2, 2023. The list includes details such as base salary, bonuses, retirement benefits, and other compensations. Notable entries include Chris Cox of the NRA, Ellen Raney of Shriners Hospitals, and Robert W. Stone of City of Hope. Edward J. Benz, Jr., M.D., President/CEO Emeritus of Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, also features with a compensation of $1,396,571 for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2022. CharityWatch emphasizes that high salaries do not necessarily indicate inefficiency, as compensation varies based on roles and responsibilities. They recommend donors consider the overall efficiency of a charity, rather than focusing solely on executive compensation, before making donation decisions.

title: Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD in honor of Lung Cancer Awareness Month
summary: Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, has significantly contributed to lung cancer treatment advancements, including targeted therapy, immunotherapy, and multimodality therapy. Despite these advances, he emphasizes the need for earlier diagnosis and increased screening for lung cancer. Herbst advocates for personalized treatment through tumor profiling and stresses the importance of education, awareness, and access to care for all patients, regardless of socio-economic status or ethnicity. Inspired by his mentor, Dr. Emil Frei III, Herbst has dedicated nearly 30 years to oncology, witnessing substantial progress in patient survival and quality of life. He highlights the critical role of clinical trials in advancing treatment standards and encourages patients to consider trial participation. Herbst also advocates for grassroots efforts to promote lung cancer screenings and envisions mobile CT scans to reach at-risk populations.

title: Dr Herbst on Adjuvant Osimertinib in EGFR-mutant NSCLC
summary: Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, discussed the overall survival analysis from the phase 3 ADAURA trial, which evaluated adjuvant osimertinib in patients with resected stage IB-IIIA non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with EGFR mutations. The trial involved 682 patients who were randomized to receive either osimertinib or placebo. The primary endpoint was disease-free survival (DFS), with secondary endpoints including overall survival (OS). Initial DFS results showed significant improvement with osimertinib, leading to its FDA approval in 2020. Updated DFS analysis in 2023 confirmed sustained benefits. The OS data revealed that osimertinib significantly improved survival rates, with a 5-year OS of 85% in stage II-IIIA patients compared to 73% with placebo. Across all prespecified subgroups, osimertinib showed an OS benefit, highlighting the efficacy of this third-generation EGFR-targeted therapy. Herbst emphasized osimertinib's tolerability and potent CNS activity, allowing patients to continue treatment for three years in the ADAURA trial.

title: The Cancer Moonshot: Opportunities to Fulfill the Vision of the National Cancer Plan
summary: The Cancer Moonshot initiative, reignited by President Biden, aims to cut cancer death rates by half within 25 years and enhance the lives of cancer patients and survivors. Dr. Roy S. Herbst hosted a panel at the American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) annual meeting, dedicated to Senator Dianne Feinstein, to discuss the National Cancer Plan. This session allowed National Cancer Institute (NCI) leadership to share recent cancer research breakthroughs and emphasized the need for continued robust funding from Congress. Panelists included notable figures like Kimryn Rathmell, Elizabeth Jaffee, Patricia LoRusso, and Bianca Islam, who discussed the significant opportunities and challenges in cancer research. Dr. Herbst, a prominent figure in oncology, highlighted the critical need for sustained investment in biomedical research to advance cancer prevention, detection, treatment, and reduce health inequities.

title: ASCO23 Plenary Video: Dr. Roy Herbst on LBA3
summary: Dr. Roy S. Herbst presented the updated results of the ADAURA study at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting. The ADAURA trial is a phase 3 study investigating osimertinib, a third-generation EGFR inhibitor, as adjuvant therapy for completely resected lung cancer stages 1B to 3A. Herbst highlighted the significant improvement in survival rates, showing a 51% improvement with a hazard ratio of .49. The study demonstrated that targeted therapy, when used early, can significantly enhance patient outcomes. Herbst emphasized the importance of genetic profiling for early lung cancer patients to determine EGFR mutation status and the potential inclusion of osimertinib in treatment plans. He also discussed ongoing and future studies to further explore osimertinib's use in earlier stages and other contexts, aiming to personalize and improve lung cancer treatment.

title: Adjuvant Osimertinib Improves Overall Survival in Resectable EGFR-Mutated NSCLC
summary: The ADAURA trial demonstrated that adjuvant osimertinib significantly improves overall survival in patients with resectable EGFR-mutated non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Presented at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting, the final analysis revealed a 51% reduction in the risk of death for patients with stage IB to IIIA NSCLC treated with osimertinib compared to placebo. Lead investigator Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, Deputy Director of Yale Cancer Center, emphasized that osimertinib should become the new standard of care for these patients. The trial's results, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, underscored osimertinib’s efficacy, showing an 88% five-year overall survival rate for patients with stage IB to IIIA NSCLC, compared to 78% with placebo. Dr. Herbst highlighted the importance of early treatment with the right drug, reinforcing the trial's practice-changing implications for treating resected EGFR-mutated NSCLC.

title: Lenvatinib/Pembrolizumab/Chemo Induces Inferior OS vs Pembrolizumab/Chemo in Previously Untreated NSCLC
summary: The LEAP-006 phase 3 trial revealed that lenvatinib combined with pembrolizumab, pemetrexed, and carboplatin or cisplatin did not improve overall survival (OS) compared to placebo with the same regimen in untreated stage IV nonsquamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Median OS was 21.8 months for the lenvatinib group and 22.1 months for the placebo group. Progression-free survival (PFS) and overall response rates (ORR) were also similar between the groups. Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, highlighted that the efficacy of pembrolizumab with chemotherapy remained consistent with previous studies and continues to be a standard treatment. Herbst, a prominent figure at Yale Cancer Center, contributed significantly to the study's presentation and analysis, emphasizing the ongoing search for better treatment outcomes.

title: Exciting Lung Cancer Advances from 2023
summary: In honor of World Lung Cancer Day, CURE® highlighted significant 2023 advancements in lung cancer treatment. Keytruda (pembrolizumab) received FDA approval for treating stage 1B, 2, or 3A non-small cell lung cancer post-surgery and chemotherapy. Dr. Roy S. Herbst from Yale Cancer Center noted this approval offers patients "another form of insurance" to prevent cancer recurrence. Research also identified inflammatory biomarkers linked to depression as predictors of lung cancer survival, emphasizing the importance of addressing mental health. Additionally, combining immunotherapy with chemotherapy showed benefits for high-risk NSCLC patients. A blood test, in conjunction with risk factors, was found to predict lung cancer mortality risk accurately. Surgical advancements include sublobar resection showing similar survival outcomes to lobar resection in early-stage NSCLC. These developments reflect ongoing progress in improving lung cancer treatment and patient outcomes.

title: Message from the Chief < Medical Oncology
summary: Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, highlights the significant advancements in medical oncology at Yale. Since the first chemotherapy in 1941, Yale has led in cancer pharmacology, developing innovative drugs. The discovery of cancer gene mutations has ushered in targeted, effective care. The Yale Cancer Center and Smilow Cancer Hospital are translating these advances into personalized treatments. The Smilow Cancer Hospital, opened in 2009, and 15 community care centers extend compassionate care. The Cancer Biology Institute and other Yale centers support novel cancer therapies. Multidisciplinary teams have secured NIH-funded SPORE grants for skin, lung, and head and neck cancers. These efforts aim for personalized, less toxic treatments, potentially curing many cancers. The fellowship program educates future oncologists. Faculty lead groundbreaking immunotherapy trials, resulting in new FDA-approved treatments. Roy S. Herbst is committed to maintaining Yale's status as a top cancer research and patient care center.

title: Adjuvant Osimertinib Improves Survival in Patients With Resected EGFR-Mutated NSCLC
summary: The ADAURA study, presented at the 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting by Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, demonstrated that adjuvant treatment with osimertinib significantly reduces the risk of death in patients with resected EGFR-mutated stage IB to IIIA non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). This international trial involved 682 patients across 26 countries, showing that 88% of those treated with osimertinib were alive five years post-surgery, compared to 78% in the placebo group, indicating a 51% lower risk of death. Osimertinib, a third-generation EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is now the first targeted agent approved by the FDA for this patient group. Dr. Herbst emphasized that these findings establish osimertinib as the standard of care for resected EGFR-mutated NSCLC and highlight the importance of identifying patients using biomarkers at diagnosis. Future ADAURA analyses may provide further insights, including molecular profiling.

title: AI More Accurately Identifies Patients With Advanced Lung Cancer Who Respond to Immunotherapy
summary: Yale Cancer Center researchers at Yale School of Medicine used artificial intelligence (AI) and digital pathology to enhance the accuracy of identifying patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer who would benefit from immunotherapy, specifically atezolizumab. The study compared AI-powered digital scoring with traditional manual scoring of the PD-L1 biomarker, revealing that AI provided better predictive accuracy. Roy S. Herbst, the lead study author and deputy director of Yale Cancer Center, presented these findings at the World Conference on Lung Cancer. Herbst emphasized that AI technology could improve PD-L1 scoring accuracy, aiding both clinical practice and trials. The study utilized data from the phase III IMpower 110 trial and found that AI identified more PD-L1 positive patients than manual methods. Additionally, AI demonstrated that PD-L1+ lymphocytes in patients with squamous histology correlated with improved progression-free survival when treated with atezolizumab.

title: Dr Herbst on the Implications of the AEGEAN Trial in NSCLC
summary: Dr. Roy S. Herbst discusses the implications of the phase 3 AEGEAN trial in patients with resectable non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Presented at the 2023 AACR Annual Meeting, the trial evaluated perioperative durvalumab (Imfinzi) plus neoadjuvant platinum-based chemotherapy versus placebo with chemotherapy. The trial showed positive results with a hazard ratio of 0.68 and a 32% improvement in event-free survival (EFS), and a pathologic complete response rate of 17.2% compared to 4.3% in the control arm. However, the median follow-up was only 11.7 months, indicating early data. Herbst emphasizes the need for further research to establish a definitive standard of care and highlights the importance of pre-competitive collaboration and pragmatic trial approaches to better understand treatment sequencing.

title: Yale at ASCO 2023 < Yale School of Medicine
summary: The American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) 2023 meeting featured significant contributions from Yale Cancer Center and Smilow Cancer Hospital faculty. Eric Winer, MD, Director of Yale Cancer Center and Physician-in-Chief of Smilow Cancer Hospital, served as ASCO President, emphasizing the importance of patient partnerships in cancer care. Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, Deputy Director of Yale Cancer Center and Assistant Dean for Translational Research at Yale School of Medicine, presented notable findings from the ADAURA trial. This trial demonstrated that osimertinib significantly improves survival and reduces recurrence risk in patients with EGFR mutant non-small cell lung cancer post-surgery, marking a practice-changing advancement. The meeting also highlighted various Yale-led research, underscoring the critical role of science in improving cancer treatment outcomes.

title: Study Shows Osimertinib Improves Survival Following Surgery for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
summary: A Yale Cancer Center study has shown that osimertinib, a targeted therapy, improves survival rates and reduces recurrence in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) following surgery. The ADAURA trial, led by Dr. Roy S. Herbst, focused on patients with EGFR-mutated NSCLC. The phase III trial demonstrated significant benefits, including prolonged disease-free survival (DFS), reduced risk of metastases, and improved central nervous system DFS. Five years post-surgery, 88% of patients treated with osimertinib were alive compared to 78% on a placebo. Herbst, who presented the findings at the 2023 ASCO annual meeting, emphasized the practice-changing impact of early osimertinib treatment in preventing cancer spread and improving overall survival. The trial was supported by AstraZeneca.

title: Combination Therapies Benefit Patients With Advanced Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
summary: The ongoing phase II KEYNOTE-495/KeyImPaCT study at Yale Cancer Center shows that combining pembrolizumab with other treatments can reduce tumor size and improve survival rates for patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study, published in Nature Medicine, categorized patients into four biomarker-defined groups based on gene expression and mutation. Each group received pembrolizumab with either lenvatinib, quavonlimab, or favezelimab. Results indicated varying objective response rates (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) among groups, with group IV showing the highest ORR (50%-60%) and PFS (6.3-17.8 months). Senior author Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, emphasized the importance of personalized medicine and the promising outcomes of pembrolizumab-based regimens. Further research will explore optimal combinations for specific molecular subtypes in NSCLC.

title: Yale Cancer Center Experts to Present New Research at Annual AACR Meeting
summary: Yale Cancer Center and Smilow Cancer Hospital researchers are set to present new studies at the 2023 American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) Annual Meeting in Orlando, Florida, from April 14 to 19. The event will showcase advancements in cancer treatments, diagnostics, and findings on various cancers. Roy S. Herbst, MD, PhD, a key contributor, will present on "Harnessing the Immune System in the Clinic" on April 16. The meeting will feature numerous presentations, workshops, and educational sessions under the theme “Advancing the Frontiers of Cancer Science and Medicine.” Congratulations to all Yale presenters for their recognized contributions.

title: Oak Park parents feel betrayed by pediatrician’s tweets
summary: Dr. Elizabeth Thompson, known as “SuzySidewalk” on Twitter, is on an extended leave from Oak Park Pediatrics due to her controversial tweets. These tweets included homophobic, anti-immigrant, anti-mask, and anti-trans sentiments, which have caused outrage among Oak Park parents. Thompson’s tweets, such as supporting the hashtag #BoycottTarget and opposing drag queen story time, have circulated widely on social media. Oak Park Pediatrics issued a statement distancing itself from Thompson’s views, emphasizing its commitment to inclusivity. The practice is rescheduling her patients with other doctors. Thompson, a vice president and director at the practice, has had her profile removed from their website. Parents, particularly those with LGBTQ+ children, feel betrayed and are reconsidering their association with the practice, despite acknowledging the overall quality of care provided. Some supporters defend Thompson’s right to her beliefs, while others criticize the harm her views could cause.

title: Michigan President Santa Ono discusses challenges, opportunities after first year
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: Santa J. Ono, the 15th president of the University of Michigan, reflects on his first year in office, discussing the achievements, challenges, and opportunities for growth and partnership with the region and community. Ono, a distinguished leader in higher education, with a background in vision research and experimental medicine, holds multiple professorships at U-M. He chairs the U-M Health Board, Fulbright Canada, and the University Climate Change Coalition, among others. Ono has previously led the University of British Columbia and the University of Cincinnati, and has served on various national and international educational and scientific boards. His contributions to higher education and his advisory roles to governments and companies highlight his influence and commitment to advancing academic and research excellence.

title: U-M Flint announced Donna Fry as interim chancellor
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: Donna Fry, the dean of the College of Health Sciences at the University of Michigan-Flint, has been appointed as interim chancellor of the Flint campus, starting August 18. University President Santa Ono announced Fry's role in an email, emphasizing her suitability for the position during the transition period.
