Fry, who also serves as a professor of physical therapy, will replace Debasish Dutta, who will leave on September 15 to become a senior advisor at the University of Illinois. Fry expressed enthusiasm for her new role and commitment to working with the administration to advance the Flint Strategic Transformation Plan, aimed at increasing enrollment and graduation rates. Fry will continue this work until a permanent chancellor is appointed. The University plans to launch a nationwide search for a new chancellor soon.

title: New UM-Flint interim chancellor values community partnerships, transparency in role
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: Donna Fry, a longtime faculty member and current dean of the College of Health Sciences, has been appointed as the interim chancellor at the University of Michigan-Flint as of August 17. Fry, who holds three degrees from the University of Michigan, has been an integral part of the institution, serving in various administrative roles including associate dean and dean. Her appointment comes during a strategic transformation period for UM-Flint, which aims to redefine its role in the evolving landscape of higher education. Fry emphasizes the importance of community partnerships and transparency, aligning with former Chancellor Deba Dutta's vision. She is actively involved in several community boards and is considering applying for the permanent chancellor position. Fry's broad experience and commitment to the community are seen as assets in her new role.

title: University of Michigan-Flint announces interim chancellor
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: The University of Michigan-Flint has appointed Donna Fry as interim chancellor for the upcoming semester. Fry, currently the Dean of the College of Health Sciences, was selected by President Santa J. Ono and will assume her new role on August 18, 2023. Fry has been a faculty member and administrator at UM-Flint since 1987 and has served as dean since 2015. Her appointment will be reported to the Board of Regents in September. President Ono expressed confidence in Fry's leadership during this transitional period, emphasizing the importance of having a chancellor in place for the start of the new academic semester. Fry replaces Chancellor Debasish Dutta, who will leave UM-Flint on September 15 to join the University of Illinois. Fry expressed her commitment to the university and the local community, highlighting her long-standing ties to Flint and Genesee County. A formal search for a permanent chancellor will begin soon.

title: Santa Ono recommends full term for University of Michigan provost
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: University of Michigan President Santa Ono has recommended that Provost Laurie McCauley serve a full term through June 30, 2027, pending approval by the Board of Regents. McCauley, who succeeded Susan Collins as provost in May, has been praised for her leadership and initiatives in student success, faculty hiring, professional standards, and academic infrastructure. Her reappointment will be decided at the regents' meeting on February 16. McCauley has been part of the university since 1992, previously serving as the dean of the School of Dentistry, where she oversaw significant expansions and improvements. She continues to hold professorships in periodontics and other disciplines.

title: Laurie McCauley recommended to receive full provost term
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: University President Santa Ono has recommended Provost Laurie McCauley for a full term as the University of Michigan’s provost, to be considered by the Board of Regents on Feb. 16. McCauley’s current term, which began in 2022, is set to expire in June 2023. If approved, her term will extend until June 2027. McCauley, who previously served as dean of the Dentistry School for 10 years, has held various academic positions within the university. Ono praised McCauley's leadership and expressed his support for her continued partnership. McCauley expressed her commitment to promoting academic excellence and fostering an environment of innovation and inclusivity.

title: University of Michigan warns that personal information was leaked during cyberattack
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: The University of Michigan disclosed that a cyberattack in August led to the leak of sensitive personal information from students, applicants, employees, and others. Despite disconnecting the campus network from the internet to contain the attack, hackers accessed university systems from August 23 to August 27. The breach involved Social Security numbers, driver's license numbers, government IDs, financial information, and health data. The university, with an incident response firm, is working with law enforcement and has notified affected individuals, offering free credit monitoring services. Chief Information Officer Ravi Pendse and Chief Information Security Officer Sol Bermann assured the community of their support during this incident. The attack disrupted internet access for over 51,000 students at the beginning of the school year. The nature of the attack, whether ransomware or not, remains unspecified, but it follows a trend of similar attacks in Michigan.

title: Why ranking hospitals don't make sense
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: Dr. Marschall S. Runge, executive vice president for medical affairs and dean of the medical school at the University of Michigan, argues that ranking hospitals is an oversimplification that cannot capture the complexities of health care. Americans have a fascination with rankings for various aspects of life, from the best places to work and live to the top products. However, Runge emphasizes that health care quality and outcomes are influenced by numerous factors, making it difficult to distill into a single ranking. He suggests that such rankings can be misleading and do not provide a comprehensive picture of a hospital's performance or the quality of care it offers.

title: Opinion: Inside Sparrow Hospital's trauma center after MSU shooting
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: On the night of February 13, Sparrow Hospital's trauma center rapidly mobilized after an active shooter was reported at Michigan State University. Over 100 caregivers, including various specialists, were summoned to prepare operating rooms and resources. Within 17 minutes, the first of five critically injured victims arrived. Dr. Denny Martin, Sparrow’s acting president, noted the team's preparedness through constant rehearsals and algorithmic scripts. Despite the chaos, the staff efficiently managed the crisis, attending to both the shooting victims and other emergencies. Marschall S. Runge, executive vice president for medical affairs at the University of Michigan, highlighted Sparrow's heroic efforts and the importance of Level I trauma centers. He emphasized the emotional and financial toll on healthcare providers, acknowledging the staff's dedication and the advanced care they provide. Runge's commentary underscores the critical role of trauma centers and the need to appreciate the often-overlooked efforts of medical professionals.

title: UM med school to drop out of U.S. News and World Report rankings
hco: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
summary: The University of Michigan Medical School will no longer participate in the U.S. News & World Report rankings of medical schools, joining other prestigious institutions like Harvard and Duke. Marschall S. Runge, dean of the UM Medical School, criticized the ranking criteria, stating that an aggregated score fails to reflect individual priorities and attributes of the schools. Despite numerous suggestions for improvement from UM and other deans, only minor changes were made to the ranking methodology. UM will still participate in U.S. News rankings for hospitals and health systems. This decision follows the UM Law School's similar move and aligns with other top universities' decisions to withdraw from these rankings. Debra F. Weinstein emphasized that UM will share specific data points on their website to help prospective students make informed decisions.

title: Augusta University leadership named to Georgia Trend's influential leaders list
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: Augusta University President Brooks A. Keel, PhD, Georgia Cancer Center Director Jorge Cortes, MD, and retired Col. Eric Toler have been named to Georgia Trend’s list of the Georgia 500 most influential leaders for 2023. Keel, recognized for his contributions to Augusta University, has been on Georgia Trend's list of “100 Most Influential Georgians” for eight consecutive years. Under his leadership, Augusta University has surpassed the 10,000-student enrollment mark and achieved significant economic impact, including a $2.94 billion boost to the state economy in fiscal year 2022. Keel also oversaw the creation of Wellstar MCG Health through a partnership with Wellstar Health System. He expressed pride in the university's accomplishments and its commitment to student success and healthcare excellence.

title: MCG dean honors Keel, Braun, Hamrick at annual State of the College Address
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: Medical College of Georgia Dean David Hess honored Augusta University President Brooks A. Keel at the annual State of the College address. Keel, who has had a distinguished 40-year career in research and higher education, received the MCG Advocacy Award for his significant contributions to the medical school. His leadership was crucial in the 3+ curriculum redesign, expanding class sizes, and establishing a new campus in Savannah. As acting CEO of Augusta University Health System, Keel oversaw a partnership with Wellstar Health System, stabilizing finances and enabling educational growth. Keel plans to retire at the end of the 2023-24 academic year.

title: MCG Center for Healthy Aging, Hess honored with Golden Helix Awards
hco: MEDICAL COLLEGE OF GEORGIA FOUNDATION INC
summary: The Medical College of Georgia (MCG) Center for Healthy Aging and its dean, Dr. David C. Hess, were honored with Golden Helix Awards by The Center for Global Health Innovation’s Office of Life Sciences and Digital Health. Dr. Hess received a Community Award for his significant contributions to Georgia’s life sciences community. He has played a pivotal role in advancing medical education and scientific research at MCG, including the establishment of the Center for Healthy Aging and the Immunology Center of Georgia. Additionally, he developed the REACH telestroke network, which enhances stroke care in rural Georgia. The Center for Healthy Aging, recognized with a Deal of the Year Award, focuses on research and clinical expertise in musculoskeletal, neurological, and orofacial repair to address aging-related health issues. The awards were presented on March 29, 2023, at the Fox Theatre in Atlanta.

title: Mental health of surgeons now getting attention: Rutgers prof
summary: Anil Nanda, a professor of neurosurgery at Rutgers University, highlighted the increasing focus on the mental health of surgeons during the B Ramamurthi Oration, commemorating Dr. B Ramamurthi's birth centenary. Organized by the World Federation of Neurological Societies and Kauvery Hospital, Nanda's speech addressed various challenges surgeons face, including procedural failures, gun violence, and mental health deterioration. He emphasized that surgeons have the highest suicide rates among professionals, citing the threat of gun violence in the U.S. Nanda also discussed how medical wisdom extends beyond textbooks, noting the importance of technical skill and continuous improvement in the medical field.

title: What is microchimerism and how does it affect maternal health?
summary: Microchimerism is a biological phenomenon where cells are exchanged between mother and fetus during pregnancy, resulting in individuals carrying cells from different genetic origins. Kristine Chua, a postdoctoral researcher in biology at the University of California Santa Barbara, is studying this form of chimerism. Her research aims to redefine how scientists understand the human body and improve maternal health. Chua's work is part of a broader effort to develop sophisticated tools for studying microchimerism, and it also contributes to advancing biological anthropology, a field that has faced challenges in diversity and ethical approaches. Justin Chen reported on Chua's contributions and the potential implications of her research.

title: Justin Chen Li: Wins China OK for Liver Cancer Test
summary: Justin Chen Li, CEO of Helio Genomics, announced that their liver cancer test received approval from China’s National Medical Products Administration. This test, developed by their sister company, Laboratory for Advanced Medicine & Health Group (LAMH), is tailored to the Asia-Pacific population and leverages the same intellectual property as Helio's HelioLiver test. Li expressed confidence that the successful China trial bodes well for the U.S. trial. Under Li's leadership, Helio Genomics has raised over $165 million and expanded its lab space. The test aims to detect liver cancer early, significantly improving survival rates. The company plans to submit its clinical trial to the FDA by year-end, with an expected approval in 2024. The Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule has set the cost of HelioLiver at $662.32, which is competitive in the market. Li was previously honored at the Business Journal’s Innovator of the Year Awards for his contributions.

title: As microbiome science forges ahead, will some be left behind?
summary: Research on the human microbiome has significantly advanced our understanding of human health, with the FDA's approval of the first microbiome-based therapeutic, Rebyota, marking a pivotal moment. However, there is concern that the benefits of microbiome science may not be equitably distributed globally due to a disproportionate focus on samples from the U.S. and Europe. This imbalance limits the applicability of future therapeutics for underrepresented communities. To address these disparities, scientists must broaden microbiome sampling to include diverse populations and foster equitable collaborations between researchers in different regions. Justin Chen, as the director of external affairs at OpenBiome, contributes to these efforts by working with scientists globally to collect and characterize microbiome diversity. Expanding representation in microbiome research is crucial for developing a comprehensive understanding of the human microbiome and ensuring global health equity.

title: Time – and organ size – are critical for kids awaiting organ transplant
summary: Nearly 100,000 Americans are waiting for life-saving organ transplants, including over 2,000 children. Children have unique medical needs, and congenital conditions often place them on transplant lists early. A third of these children are under 5 years old. Organ size is crucial for successful transplants, especially for heart, lung, and liver transplants, as children respond better to child-sized organs. Donations typically come from other young people, though older children and adults can sometimes be matches. Living donor donations are possible for kidneys and livers. Teenagers can register as donors, but parental consent is required until they turn 18. In 2023, over 1,900 children received transplants from nearly 900 pediatric donors. National Pediatric Transplant Week highlights the importance of organ donation. One donor can save or heal up to seven people. Meera Gupta, M.D., surgical director of the pediatric kidney program at UK HealthCare Transplant Center, emphasizes the critical nature of timely and size-appropriate organ donations for children.

title: Meera Gupta | Sloan Kettering Institute
summary: Meera Gupta is a Postdoctoral Research Fellow at the Anna-Katerina Hadjantonakis Lab, Sloan Kettering Institute, working jointly with Dr. Eric Siggia at Rockefeller University. She began her fellowship in 2023 and is now a Postdoctoral Fellow at the Rabinowitz Lab, Princeton University. Gupta has contributed significantly to the field of proteomics, with notable publications including research on global protein-turnover quantification in Escherichia coli and Bayesian confidence intervals for multiplexed proteomics. Her work has been published in reputable journals such as bioRxiv and Molecular & Cellular Proteomics.

title: Is rodeo spurring on your allergies? - Baylor College of Medicine Blog Network
summary: Before attending the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo, individuals prone to allergies should take preventative measures. Dr. Carla Davis, an allergy expert at Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children's Hospital, highlights that people with existing seasonal allergies are more susceptible to reactions from animal exposure or outdoor environments. Symptoms can include sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy eyes, and in severe cases, asthma-related issues. Besides animal allergens, hay and mold spores can also trigger reactions. Preventative strategies include using over-the-counter antihistamines, decongestants, or nasal sprays. Dr. Davis also advises caution with food allergies, recommending verification of ingredients from vendors and avoiding uncertain foods. In case of severe allergic reactions, immediate medical assistance should be sought.

title: As a nurse in rural Tennessee, I know how food deserts harm residents | Opinion
summary: Carla Davis, a certified advanced practice nurse with over 15 years of experience, highlights the severe impact of food deserts on residents in rural Tennessee. Serving communities in West Tennessee and Kentucky, she emphasizes that limited access to healthy food options contributes significantly to poor diets, leading to obesity, heart disease, cancer, and diabetes. Food deserts, defined as areas with limited access to supermarkets, exacerbate food insecurity. Davis advises her patients to seek healthier options available at local discount and convenience stores, such as dairy items, frozen vegetables, lean proteins, canned fruits, and whole grains. She also notes the importance of discussions about healthy eating and meal planning. Some convenience stores now offer fresh produce and accept SNAP and EBT benefits, which many residents are unaware of. Davis calls for community engagement to promote healthier food choices despite the challenges posed by food deserts.

title: As a nurse in rural Tennessee, I know how food deserts harm residents | Opinion
summary: Carla M. Davis, a certified advanced practice nurse with over 15 years of experience, highlights the impact of food deserts on residents in rural Tennessee. As a family nurse practitioner in West Tennessee and Kentucky, she observes that limited access to healthy food contributes to obesity, heart disease, cancer, and diabetes. Davis emphasizes the importance of guiding patients to make healthier food choices within their budget, especially in areas lacking supermarkets. She advises seeking healthier options at local discount stores, such as dairy items, frozen vegetables, lean proteins, canned fruits, and whole grains. Davis advocates for community discussions on healthy eating and leveraging local resources to combat food insecurity and promote better health outcomes.

title: Intelerad Announces Three Executive Leadership Appointments to Drive Transformative Client Experiences in 2024 ...
summary: Intelerad Medical Systems has announced the appointment of three new executives to enhance client experiences in 2024 and beyond. The new leaders include Pete Srejovic as Chief Technology Officer, Vivek Rao as Chief Customer Officer, and Erikka Buracchio as Chief People Officer. Vivek Rao brings over 25 years of experience in SaaS delivery organizations, focusing on growth and transformation. He previously served as Senior Vice President of Customer Success at Cloud Software Group. CEO Jordan Bazinsky emphasized that these appointments demonstrate Intelerad's commitment to delivering exceptional client outcomes and experiences. The new executives will manage client delivery and improve experiences for Intelerad’s global client and employee bases.

title: Doctors press on all fronts to fix Medicare, protect care access
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) is advocating to address critical issues affecting Medicare, particularly the imminent 3.37% physician pay cut scheduled for January 2024. In Odessa, Texas, allergist and immunologist Vivek Rao, MD, has highlighted the challenges faced by Medicare physicians. Dr. Rao, who represents the Texas Medical Association in the AMA House of Delegates, emphasized that continuous pay cuts threaten the sustainability of medical practices and patient care quality. The AMA's House of Delegates has adopted policies to prioritize Medicare payment reform, aiming to prevent further cuts and ensure inflation-adjusted payment updates. Dr. Rao, among other physicians, actively participated in advocacy efforts, including contacting Congress to support Medicare payment reforms. The AMA's ongoing campaign, "Fix Medicare Now," seeks to engage physicians and the public to press for systemic changes to protect access to care for Medicare beneficiaries.

title: Value of Invasive Hemodynamic Assessments in Patients Supported by Continuous-Flow Left Ventricular Assist Devices
summary: Left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are increasingly used in patients with end-stage heart failure (HF), but they carry a risk of hemocompatibility-related adverse events. Optimizing LVAD support through invasive hemodynamic assessment can personalize patient care, reduce hospitalizations, and manage persistent low-flow alarms, pulmonary vasculature remodeling, and right ventricular function. This method can also identify causes of residual HF symptoms and physical limitations during exercise, making it crucial for assessing myocardial recovery. The review underscores the importance of invasive hemodynamic assessments for tailored management of LVAD patients. Vivek Rao, MD, PhD, contributed to this comprehensive review, highlighting the benefits of these assessments in improving patient outcomes.

title: Women in Stem with Ashley Hall
summary: The October edition of the Women in STEM series highlights Ashley Hall, Chief Development Officer of Reneo Pharmaceuticals. Ashley shares her journey in STEM, starting with a fascination for science and overcoming challenges in mathematics. Despite discouragement, she pursued her passion, combining her scientific and legal backgrounds in the pharmaceutical industry. Ashley's notable contributions include leading the regulatory strategy for the Repatha® programme at Amgen, resulting in the world’s first approval of a PCSK9 inhibitor for cholesterol lowering. She emphasizes the importance of understanding the connection between STEM subjects and advocates for more diversity in executive leadership positions. Ashley encourages young women to follow their passion and seek supportive environments. Her work in regulatory affairs has significantly impacted drug development, particularly in paediatric oncology and rare diseases.

title: Conference Preview: NACDS Total Store Expo
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The NACDS Total Store Expo, celebrating its 90th year, will be held from August 12-14, 2023, in San Diego, California. The event will feature insightful panel discussions, partner meetings, and sessions on the evolving pharmacy marketplace. On August 12, discussions will focus on closing gaps in women's health and wellness. On August 13, NACDS President Steven C. Anderson and NACDS Chair Michael Wysong, CEO of Care Pharmacies Cooperative, will lead the Business Program with a discussion on domestic and global events, featuring Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Peggy Noonan. Attendees can also join various Insight Sessions on August 14, covering topics like innovative care models and the Drug Supply Chain Security Act. The Drug Topics team will be present, offering interviews and coverage of key sessions.

title: Envisioning an ideal model for retail pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Retail pharmacies are expanding their role in healthcare, offering services like screenings, immunizations, and chronic disease management. This transformation aims to integrate pharmacies more seamlessly into the healthcare system and ensure they are appropriately compensated. Key to this evolution is reforming the payment framework and pharmacy benefit management (PBM) practices. Rick Gates, senior VP and chief pharmacy officer at Walgreens, emphasized that retail pharmacists are well-positioned to take a more active role in patient care due to their expertise. He highlighted the importance of incorporating technological advancements like telepharmacy and mobile scheduling to extend pharmacists' roles beyond medication dispensing, ultimately improving patient outcomes and job satisfaction. Gates also noted that empowering pharmacists to prescribe for minor conditions would enhance healthcare accessibility and reduce costs, aligning with broader healthcare goals.

title: From pharmacy intern to chief pharmacy officer
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Rick Gates began his pharmacy career as a high school student needing money for car insurance, which led him to a job at a local pharmacy. After studying pharmacy at the University of Iowa, he joined Walgreens as an intern in 1995. Over nearly three decades, Gates progressed through various roles, ultimately becoming Walgreens' first Chief Pharmacy Officer. In this role, he focuses on creating an ecosystem that enhances pharmacists' ability to provide patient care by implementing micro-fulfillment centers and centralized service centers to handle tasks like prescription filling and data entry. Gates attributes his long tenure at Walgreens to the supportive community and opportunities for growth within the company. He is also actively involved in mentoring and supporting Latino professionals within Walgreens.

title: West Virginia-based pharmacy says it’s losing money due to PEIA
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Fruth Pharmacy, a West Virginia-based chain with 27 stores, reports financial losses due to the state's Public Employees Insurance Agency (PEIA). The pharmacy claims state reimbursements for medications are often lower than the costs incurred, while larger national chains receive higher payments for the same drugs. For example, Fruth is reimbursed $307 for a seizure medication compared to $601 for large chains. Similarly, patient co-payments show disparities, with Fruth charging $130 for a cholesterol drug versus $170 at larger chains. Lynne Fruth, President of Fruth Pharmacy, highlights the unfairness to patients, taxpayers, and small businesses, attributing the issue to "Pharmacy Benefit Managers" who favor large chains. Senate Bill 453 aims to address these disparities.

title: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review and The Emerson Group collaborate to celebrate community pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review, and The Emerson Group are collaborating to celebrate the contributions of community pharmacy retailers and the National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) on its 90th anniversary. The event, scheduled for December 13 in New York City, will honor past and present industry leaders who have significantly impacted community healthcare and transformed pharmacies into healthcare destinations. Notable retailers participating include Walmart, Walgreens, CVS, and Amazon. The December issues of both magazines will feature a detailed report on NACDS’s history and achievements. Lynne Fruth, from Fruth Pharmacy, is among the Board of Directors being recognized for their contributions to the industry. The event underscores the importance of relationships between patients, pharmacists, retailers, and suppliers, highlighting the industry's evolution and its growing role in U.S. healthcare.

title: West Virginia Senate Bill to help reign in PEIA drug prices stalls in House
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: A West Virginia Senate Bill aimed at reducing PEIA drug prices is currently stalled in the House Finance Committee. The bill seeks to save the state millions by regulating Pharmacy Benefits Managers (PBMs) who negotiate drug prices. Lynne Fruth, President of Fruth Pharmacies, has been actively protesting and highlighting the disparities in drug payments, where large national chains receive significantly higher payments than smaller pharmacies for the same prescriptions. Fruth argues that these discrepancies cost taxpayers and patients millions, urging the House to pass Senate Bill 453 to address the issue.

title: Albertsons Companies Launches Nutrition Insights to Sincerely Health™ Platform
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Albertsons Companies, Inc. has introduced a new nutrition insights tool to its Sincerely Health™ platform, which evaluates grocery purchases based on USDA’s MyPlate guidelines. This feature helps customers make informed dietary choices by providing real-time nutritional information at both item and basket levels. Omer Gajial, Chief Digital Officer and EVP Health at Albertsons, emphasized the company's commitment to improving lives by making wellness solutions accessible. The tool reviews grocery purchases linked to loyalty accounts, offering personalized food recommendations and recipes. Additionally, the platform rewards healthy eating habits with points redeemable for grocery discounts. This initiative supports the White House Conference on Hunger, Nutrition, and Health, aiming to provide 50 million nutrition recommendations by 2024 and launch health campaigns by 2025. The Sincerely Health platform, available on multiple grocery apps and websites, also integrates various health management features, including activity tracking and telehealth services.

title: Albertsons Partners With FIS and Soda Health; Omer Gajial Comments
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Albertsons Companies has partnered with FIS and Soda Health to offer health benefit cards to its shoppers, aimed at promoting the purchase of nutritious foods and wellness products. These cards, funded by Medicare Advantage plans, employers, healthcare providers, or local governments, can be used for eligible over-the-counter medicine and healthy food items. Omer Gajial, Executive Vice President of Pharmacy and Health at Albertsons, emphasized the importance of these partnerships in providing customers with access to a wide range of nutritious options and supporting their overall well-being. Gajial highlighted Albertsons' commitment to building deeper connections with customers and addressing hunger in vulnerable communities.

title: Albertsons launches app uniting pharmacy, nutrition, telehealth
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Albertsons has launched a new health and wellness platform called Sincerely Health, aiming to guide consumers on their health journeys by integrating pharmacy, nutrition, and telehealth services. The platform, developed with input from providers, payers, tech experts, and feedback from 10,000 customers and employees, allows users to connect wearable data, manage prescriptions, design diets, and schedule telehealth appointments. Omer Gajial, Chief Digital Officer and Executive Vice President for Health at Albertsons, emphasized the platform's goal to improve lives by offering a connected and personalized health view. Users can set health goals and manage their pharmacy needs through Albertsons' partnership with Providence Express Care. The platform ensures user data privacy and aligns with HIPAA rules. The launch coincides with Albertsons' potential merger with Kroger, currently under review by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Rock Hudson: Aids diagnosis saw closeted icon finally accepted
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Rock Hudson, a Hollywood icon, was a symbol of the American Dream, starring in major films with Elizabeth Taylor and Doris Day. Despite his public image, Hudson led a closeted life, hiding his homosexuality due to societal and industry pressures. His career, managed by agent Henry Willson, involved a rigorous transformation from Roy Fitzgerald to the masculine Rock Hudson. The new documentary "Rock Hudson: All That Heaven Allowed," directed by Stephen Kijak, explores his life, career, and the impact of his AIDS diagnosis. Mark Griffin, author of "All That Heaven Allows: A Biography of Rock Hudson," highlights Hudson's journey from a secretive life to being embraced for his true self after his AIDS diagnosis, which challenged stereotypes and changed public perceptions of gay individuals.

title: McKesson kicks off registration for ideaShare
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: McKesson has opened registration for its ideaShare event in Las Vegas from June 22–25, 2023. The event, hosted by McKesson, Health Mart, and Health Mart Atlas, offers expanded clinical and business educational opportunities, including new tracks for pharmacy technicians and a 2% rebate on OneStop Generics purchases. Nimesh Jhaveri, interim president of community pharmacy and health at McKesson, emphasized the importance of equipping pharmacies with resources for optimal healthcare outcomes. The event will feature over 12 CE courses, peer-to-peer learning, interactive sessions, and access to the latest technology and products. Special sessions will address upcoming Medicaid and Medicare changes, and new programs will focus on pharmacy technician education. Attendees can also earn up to 10 CE credit hours. The event will kick off with a keynote by Jason Dorsey and conclude with a party headlined by Boyz II Men.

title: NACDS highlights Kroger's participation in NACDS RxIMPACT
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) highlighted Kroger Health's active participation in NACDS RxIMPACT grassroots programs. Colleen Lindholz, president of Kroger Health, discussed the company's significant involvement, including bringing the most representatives to the NACDS RxIMPACT Day on Capitol Hill in March 2024. This event saw over 300 advocates from 39% of NACDS chain member companies across all 50 states. Lindholz emphasized Kroger Health’s commitment to advocacy through their Project Passion initiative, which supports their pharmacy teams in lobbying for critical issues like PBM reform and pharmacist provider status. The engagement included hosting Congressional pharmacy tours and participating in community events to demonstrate the impact of policies directly to legislators. Lindholz noted the enthusiastic response from Kroger’s pharmacy teams, who were eager to share their experiences and advocate for better healthcare access and reforms.

title: Kroger to sell specialty pharmacy division
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Kroger has agreed to sell its specialty pharmacy division to CarelonRx, a unit of Elevance Health. This sale excludes Kroger's in-store pharmacies and The Little Clinic. Kroger is focusing on its proposed merger with Albertsons, facing opposition from federal regulators. Colleen Lindholz, president of Kroger Health, stated that the decision to sell was part of a regular review of assets, and the specialty pharmacy unit would better realize its potential outside Kroger. She expressed confidence that the transaction would help the business grow and deliver better results for patients. The sale requires regulatory approval and is expected to close in the second half of the year, without affecting Kroger's annual results. Specialty pharmacies cater to patients with chronic conditions requiring complex care. Kroger entered this business in 2012 by merging with Axium Pharmacy.

title: Kroger Health president on the future of pharmacies and their IT infrastructure
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Colleen Lindholz, President of Kroger Health, oversees 22,000 healthcare practitioners serving over 13 million U.S. customers. She played a pivotal role in Kroger's COVID-19 response, facilitating access to vaccines and addressing vaccine hesitancy, leading to the administration of over 4.7 million COVID vaccines. Lindholz advocates for integrating pharmacy-specific tools into EHRs and population health platforms to enhance coordinated care and reduce pharmacist burnout. She emphasizes the evolving role of pharmacists beyond medication dispensing, highlighting their potential in patient consultation, chronic disease management, and community health education. Lindholz also discusses leveraging technology to alleviate burnout and transitioning pharmacies to appointment-based models. She underscores the importance of pharmacists in providing accessible and affordable care, noting Kroger Health's initiatives like "food as medicine" and their recognition by the American Pharmacists Association for high COVID-19 vaccination rates.

title: Elevance PBM CarelonRx to buy Kroger specialty pharmacy business
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Kroger Co. has agreed to sell its specialty pharmacy business to CarelonRx, a subsidiary of Elevance Health. Colleen Lindholz, president of Kroger Health, stated that the decision followed a review of assets, concluding that the specialty pharmacy unit would thrive better outside Kroger. The sale aims to ensure minimal disruption to employees and patients, with expectations for the business to grow and improve patient outcomes. The specialty pharmacy caters to patients with chronic illnesses requiring complex care and offers extensive support, including education, counseling, and financial assistance. The transaction, subject to customary conditions and regulatory approvals, is anticipated to close in the latter half of this year without impacting Kroger's 2024 guidance.

title: Kroger: The jury is still out on weight loss drug impact on food purchases
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Kroger is examining the impact of weight loss drugs like Wegovy and Ozempic on customer food purchases. Colleen Lindholz, President of Kroger Health, predicts that while overall sales may not decrease, the types of foods purchased will shift towards healthier options. Lindholz believes that as people feel better about their health, they will opt for fresher, healthier foods. Walmart has reported a slight reduction in purchases by customers using these drugs, which belong to the GLP-1 class that slows digestion. Analysts suggest these drugs could reduce calorie consumption by 1-3%, potentially affecting sales of snacks, alcohol, and non-alcoholic beverages. Lindholz, having experienced previous GLP-1 drugs, expects them to encourage better eating habits and overall behavior changes, but emphasizes the need to analyze the data for conclusive insights.

title: Kroger to Sell Specialty Pharmacy to Elevance Health's CarelonRx
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Kroger plans to sell its specialty pharmacy business to CarelonRx, a subsidiary of Elevance Health, as announced on March 18, 2024. The sale is expected to close in the second half of the year, pending customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. Colleen Lindholz, president of Kroger Health, stated that the decision was part of a regular review of assets and that the specialty pharmacy unit would achieve its full potential outside of Kroger. The specialty pharmacy, separate from Kroger’s in-store retail pharmacies, serves patients with chronic illnesses and provides comprehensive care, including education, counseling, and financial assistance. Lindholz emphasized the importance of ensuring minimal disruption for associates and patients during the transition and expressed confidence that the transaction would lead to better outcomes for patients. Elevance Health, formerly known as Anthem, rebranded to reflect a broader focus beyond traditional health insurance.

title: Kroger, Advantage Solutions team up for The Kroger Wellness Festival in Cincinnati
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Kroger and Advantage Solutions are collaborating for the Kroger Wellness Festival, the largest free health and wellness festival in the U.S., held in Cincinnati on September 22-23, 2023. The event, expected to attract over 150,000 attendees, will feature health and wellness experiences, food, live music, and appearances by celebrities like Venus Williams and John Cena. Colleen Lindholz, president of Kroger Health, emphasized the festival's alignment with Kroger's mission to promote healthier living through food and nutrition. Advantage Solutions is managing various aspects of the festival, including sponsorships, retail integration, and event production. This year’s event will also include the inaugural Nourishing Change Summit, focusing on food as medicine. The festival aims to provide educational and entertaining programs across six stages, with performances by Barenaked Ladies and Flo Rida.

title: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review and The Emerson Group collaborate to celebrate community pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Drug Store News, Chain Drug Review, and The Emerson Group are collaborating to celebrate the 90th anniversary of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores (NACDS) with an event in New York City on December 13th. This event will honor the contributions of community pharmacy retailers and industry leaders who have transformed pharmacy into a key healthcare destination over the past 90 years. Leading retailers such as Walmart, Walgreens, and CVS will participate. John Kenlon, vice president of DSN, emphasized the industry's evolution and future potential. Chris Stanton, publisher of Chain Drug Review, highlighted NACDS's role in supporting retail pharmacy and fostering retailer-supplier relationships. The event will feature recognition of significant contributions from various industry members, including Bob Narveson of Thrifty White Pharmacy, who served as NACDS Board Chair from 2013-2014. The December issues of both magazines will include detailed reports on NACDS's history and achievements.

title: Speakers at DSN's Industry Issues Summit discuss big trends, such as AI, health equity, the future of pharmacy
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Drug Store News held its 25th annual Industry Issues Summit in New York City on Dec. 13, where industry leaders discussed major trends in technology, health equity, and the future of pharmacy. The summit featured a keynote on the impact of Generative AI in health, wellness, and beauty, led by Sharon Gai of AliHealth. Another panel, moderated by Scott Miller, focused on redefining the modern healthcare experience, with contributions from Dain Rusk, Publix senior vice president, among others. The event also covered topics such as improving collaboration across the supply chain, integrating front-end suppliers with pharmacy healthcare models, and enhancing health outcomes in underserved communities through technology and partnerships.

title: Collaboration Adds Telehealth Center to Retail Pharmacy Location
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: A partnership between Publix Pharmacy and Beaufort Memorial Hospital in South Carolina aims to add a telehealth center to a pharmacy location, featuring telehealth conferencing tools and medical diagnostic equipment. Publix Pharmacy, part of the employee-owned supermarket company Publix, operates 1,324 stores across several states and fills a wide array of prescriptions. This new telehealth center will be the fourth established by Publix Pharmacy, supported by Beaufort Memorial Hospital. Patients will have access to teleconferencing services and diagnostic tools, allowing virtual communication with healthcare providers. Each telehealth visit costs $67, with no appointments necessary. Dain Rusk, Vice President of Publix Pharmacy, emphasized the importance of convenient healthcare services in a press release. The initiative is part of a broader trend of integrating telehealth into care delivery models, driven by the financial and environmental benefits observed during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Register now: DSN Industry Issues Summit 2023 agenda, speaker lineup set
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The DSN Industry Issues Summit 2023 will be held on Dec. 13 at the InterContinental New York Barclay, featuring a lineup of retail pharmacy leaders. Keynote speaker Sharon Gai from AliHealth will discuss the impact of Generative AI on health, wellness, and beauty CPG. The event includes panels on modern healthcare experiences, integrating front-end services into the pharmacy model, and improving health equity and maternal health. Notable speakers include Kevin Host (Walmart), Jeff Key (Pioneer Rx), Julie Lenhard (Wegmans), Valerie Mondelli (RevSpring, Inc.), Craig Norman (H-E-B), Dain Rusk (Publix), and others. Dain Rusk from Publix will contribute to discussions on redefining the modern healthcare experience, focusing on chronic care and early illness detection to reduce costly ER visits. The summit aims to address changes in retail pharmacy, emphasizing its evolving role as a healthcare provider and the impact of technology on service delivery.

title: Over the counter contraceptive now available at Rite Aids nationwide
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The first over-the-counter daily contraceptive for women, Opill, is now available nationwide at Rite Aid. Opill, a progestin-only birth control pill, is sold at a retail price of $19.99 for a one-month supply and $49.99 for a three-month supply. Karen Staniforth, Senior Vice President and Chief Pharmacy Officer at Rite Aid, emphasized that offering an FDA-approved over-the-counter birth control pill is a significant step in enhancing access to reproductive health products and services for women. There are no restrictions for purchasing Opill, which is also available on Rite Aid's website.

title: Rite Aid to hold Family Immunization Day
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Rite Aid is hosting a Family Immunization Day on October 14, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. at select locations, offering walk-in vaccinations for flu, COVID-19, RSV, and other viruses. Karen Staniforth, Rite Aid's chief pharmacy officer, emphasized the importance of convenient access to essential immunizations, especially during busy fall schedules, to help families stay healthy as the holiday season approaches. The event caters to adults and children three years and older, providing vaccines such as shingles, tetanus, pertussis, HPV, and more, based on age and state regulations. Customers can check participating locations and use Rite Aid’s online scheduling tool if unable to attend the event. Additionally, an Immunization Evaluation Questionnaire is available on Rite Aid's website to help customers identify needed vaccinations.

title: Rite Aid Announces Availability of Flu and RSV Vaccine Appointments at All Locations
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Rite Aid announced the availability of flu and RSV vaccine appointments at all store locations, including Bartell Drugs, in recognition of Immunization Awareness Month. Customers can schedule appointments online for the upcoming respiratory virus season. Karen Staniforth, Chief Pharmacy Officer at Rite Aid, emphasized the importance of staying updated on vaccines, especially with back-to-school and flu season approaching. Rite Aid offers various flu vaccines, including Flumist, and provides a $5 coupon for in-store purchases with a flu shot. The CDC recommends RSV vaccines for adults 60 and older, which can be administered alongside other vaccines. Rite Aid also offers COVID-19 and other routine vaccinations. The company provides an Immunization Evaluation Questionnaire on its website to help customers determine their vaccination needs. Rite Aid operates over 2,300 retail pharmacy locations across 17 states and employs more than 6,300 pharmacists.

title: Andre Persaud departs Rite Aid
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Andre Persaud, Rite Aid's chief retail officer, has departed from the company. A Rite Aid spokesperson expressed gratitude for Persaud's service and wished him well in his future endeavors. Following his departure, Bill Miller, the senior vice president of central retail operations, will act as the head of retail operations. Karen Staniforth, the chief pharmacy officer, will now oversee the store pharmacy operations. Persaud had been with Rite Aid since June 2021, managing both retail and pharmacy operations.

title: Rite Aid to Offer After Work Wednesday Walk-In Clinic
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Rite Aid is launching an After Work Wednesday clinic at select stores to provide convenient walk-in immunizations for families. The clinics will be open from 5 to 9 p.m. on Wednesday, Nov. 1, offering vaccines for flu, COVID-19, RSV, and other diseases. Karen Staniforth, Chief Pharmacy Officer at Rite Aid, emphasized the importance of community health and the flexibility of the event to fit busy schedules. Rite Aid pharmacists can immunize adults and children aged three and older. Customers can also schedule appointments online if they cannot attend the event.

title: NutraWomen Wednesday: Lisa Paley, President, North America, Haleon
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: Lisa Paley, President of North America at Haleon, emphasizes gender parity and inclusion to enhance everyday health. Recently elected as CHPA’s Chair of its Board of Directors, Paley has a robust background in consumer healthcare, having worked at Pfizer Consumer Healthcare and Johnson & Johnson. She joined Haleon in 2019 and has been instrumental in driving business opportunities for brands like Centrum and Emergen-C. Paley highlights the shift from traditional healthcare to self-care, noting the increased reliance on technology and personal networks for health information. She advocates for diversity, equity, and inclusion, aiming for gender parity in leadership by 2030. Paley encourages women to boost each other's confidence and pursue opportunities, believing that mutual support can make a significant difference.

title: CHPA appoints Haleon's Lisa Paley as board chair
hco: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF CHAIN DRUG STORES INC
summary: The Consumer Healthcare Products Association (CHPA) has appointed Lisa Paley, president of the North America Region at Haleon, as chair of its board of directors during the annual Self-Care Leadership Summit in Orlando, Fla. Paley, a CHPA board member since 2019, oversees various health and wellness brands like Advil, Centrum, and Sensodyne. She brings extensive experience from previous roles at Pfizer Consumer Healthcare/Warner-Lambert and Johnson & Johnson. Paley is also involved with several industry boards, including the NACDS Retail Advisory Board. She succeeds Michelle Wang Goodridge, who will continue to serve on the board as immediate past chair. Paley expressed her eagerness to advance the consumer health industry and work with CHPA members to promote health inclusivity and sustainability. Scott Melville, CHPA president, highlighted Paley's valuable experience in guiding the association. The CHPA also announced the election of new board members from CrossingWell Consumer Health, Procter & Gamble, Circana, and SBL Consulting.

title: AAFP President Offers Advice for Family Physicians Regarding ADHD Medication Shortages
summary: The ongoing shortage of ADHD stimulant medications like Adderall and Vyvanse, which began in October 2022, has yet to be resolved, causing frustration for patients and physicians. Tochi Iroku-Malize, MD, MPH, MBA, FAAFP, President of the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP), attributes the shortage to increased demand and manufacturing delays, exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Dr. Iroku-Malize emphasizes the importance of patients adhering to their prescribed medication regimens and regularly consulting with their family physicians to manage ADHD effectively. She highlights the potential side effects of ADHD medications and the need for careful monitoring to mitigate these issues. Additionally, Dr. Iroku-Malize discusses non-medication therapies and the risks of medication misuse, advising that family physicians play a crucial role in guiding patients through these challenges and ensuring their overall well-being.

title: To Have a Healthy School Year, Ensure Everyone Has Access to Immunizations
summary: Tochi Iroku-Malize, MD, MPH, MBA, FAAFP, emphasizes the importance of ensuring children have access to immunizations to maintain health during the school year. Despite the decline in vaccination rates and the spread of misinformation, it is crucial for parents, physicians, and policymakers to enhance education efforts and ensure vaccines are accessible, affordable, and widely available. Vaccines are vital for preventing diseases like flu, measles, and polio, which can disrupt children's education and development. Physicians can provide accurate information and help overcome barriers to vaccination, but they need support from policymakers to maintain programs like Medicaid and the Vaccines for Children program. Ensuring that children receive timely vaccinations will safeguard public health and help them thrive academically and socially.

title: 2023 Most Influential in Healthcare R. Shawn Martin
summary: R. Shawn Martin, the Executive Vice President and CEO of the American Academy of Family Physicians (AAFP), has been a significant figure in addressing the primary care shortage in the U.S. since he began leading the organization in 2020. Under his leadership, the AAFP has prioritized expanding residency training programs, resulting in a historic number of 4,530 medical students and graduates matching into family medicine programs this year. Martin has also advocated before Congress to maintain access to primary care in a consolidating market. Additionally, he is a key proponent of the Primary Care for America collaborative, which aims to foster innovation and leadership to drive positive changes and investments in primary care. Before his current role, Martin served as AAFP’s Senior Vice President of Advocacy, Practice Advancement, and Policy.

title: Keeping primary care docs in field isn't impossible, says AAFP CEO
summary: The United States faces a potential shortage of up to 48,000 primary care doctors within the next decade due to the specialty being underpaid. This issue has led many medical residents to abandon their initial plans to become generalists. However, R. Shawn Martin, CEO of the American Academy of Family Physicians, remains optimistic. He notes that concerns about the decline of primary care have been raised multiple times over his 25-year career, but the field has always managed to persist. Martin's experience and perspective suggest that despite current challenges, primary care will continue to endure.

title: No appointments available: America's escalating primary care shortage
summary: America is facing a growing crisis in primary care, with over 100 million citizens lacking access to regular doctors. This shortage is worsened by a significant drop in new primary care physicians, who often opt for higher-paying specialties. R. Shawn Martin, executive vice president and CEO of the American Academy of Family Physicians, highlights the critical role of primary care in community health, disease prevention, and reducing health disparities. The problem is worsened by inadequate training and chronic underfunding, with primary care receiving only 5-7% of healthcare expenditures despite accounting for 35% of visits. Solutions include improving Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, focusing clinician training on community settings, and expanding community health centers.

title: Consolidation and Corporate Ownership in Health Care: Trends and Impacts on Access, Quality, and Costs | The ...
summary: The United States Senate Committee on Finance held a Full Committee Hearing on June 8, 2023, at the Dirksen Senate Office Building to discuss "Consolidation and Corporate Ownership in Health Care: Trends and Impacts on Access, Quality, and Costs." The hearing included statements from committee members Ron Wyden and Mike Crapo. Witnesses included Zack Cooper, Ph.D., Karen Joynt Maddox, MD, MPH, Chris Thomas, FACHE, and Caroline Pearson. R. Shawn Martin, the Executive Vice President and Chief Executive Officer of the American Academy of Family Physicians, also provided testimony. The hearing aimed to explore the implications of health care consolidation on various aspects such as accessibility, quality, and cost of care. Public participation was encouraged through a livestream available on the committee's website. Individuals or organizations wishing to submit statements for the record were instructed on how to do so.

title: Consolidation may help some providers stay afloat, experts say
summary: Experts argue that consolidation is vital for healthcare providers to remain viable. Chris Thomas, CEO of Community Hospital, highlighted the leverage large systems have over smaller entities, which may restrict access to independent hospitals. Zack Cooper from Yale University emphasized the need for better antitrust enforcement to manage consolidation. R. Shawn Martin, CEO of the American Academy of Family Physicians, noted that 73% of family physicians are now employed by larger entities due to factors like inadequate payments and lack of primary care investment. Karen Joynt Maddox from Washington University discussed the significant role of private equity in healthcare mergers. The American Hospital Association defended consolidation as essential for maintaining patient care and hospital survival, particularly in rural areas. Conversely, David Merritt of Blue Cross Blue Shield criticized hospital acquisitions of physician practices for driving up healthcare costs.

title: Ace the Case: A 22-Year-Old Man With Hematuria
summary: The educational activity "Ace the Case: A 22-Year-Old Man With Hematuria" is designed for nephrologists, nurses, and other healthcare professionals. It involves a case study on a young man experiencing painless, gross hematuria, aiming to enhance participants' ability to diagnose and treat immunoglobulin A nephropathy. The activity offers 0.25 CME and CNE credits and is accredited by Vindico Medical Education, which is jointly recognized by ACCME, ACPE, and ANCC. Ronald A. Codario, MD, EMBA, FACP, FNLA, RPVI, CHCP, along with Barbara A. Niedz, PhD, RN, CPHQ, served as planners/reviewers for this educational activity. Participants must complete the posttest and evaluation to earn their credits.

title: Neovascular AMD and DME Management: Continuing Challenges and Dynamic Advancements in Treatment Duration ...
summary: The text discusses a continuing education (CE) activity focused on the management of neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) and diabetic macular edema (DME). It highlights the challenges in achieving real-world outcomes comparable to clinical studies due to high treatment burdens and patient adherence issues. Newer therapies aim to extend dosing intervals and personalize treatment protocols to address these challenges. The CE activity, supported by Genentech, reviews the latest clinical studies on therapies that improve visual and anatomic outcomes. Ronald A. Codario, MD, EMBA, FACP, FNLA, RPVI, CHCP contributed as a reviewer, ensuring the accuracy and integrity of the content. The activity targets ophthalmologists and healthcare professionals, aiming to enhance their understanding of durable vision gains and macular leakage control in nAMD and DME treatment. Participants can earn CME credits by completing the activity requirements, including pretests, content review, posttests, and evaluations.

title: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder: Updates on Diagnosis and Treatment Management
summary: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) is a rare autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, often misdiagnosed as multiple sclerosis. Early and accurate diagnosis relies on clinical characteristics, aquaporin-4 (AQP4) antibody status, and MRI. Recent advancements in diagnostic criteria have improved accuracy. Historically, treatment options were limited, but current therapies are evaluated for their mechanisms, safety, and efficacy. This continuing education activity, supported by Horizon Therapeutics, aims to educate healthcare providers on NMOSD diagnosis and management, featuring expert presentations and panel discussions. Ronald A. Codario, MD, EMBA, FACP, FNLA, RPVI, CHCP, contributed as a planner/reviewer, ensuring the educational content meets high standards. The program targets neurologists, ophthalmologists, pharmacists, nurses, and other healthcare professionals, aiming to enhance their ability to diagnose and manage NMOSD effectively. Participants must complete pretests, view content, and pass posttests to earn continuing education credits.

title: Major Depressive Disorder & Postpartum Depression: Targeting the GABA Deficit
summary: The text discusses a continuing medical education (CME) activity focusing on Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) and Postpartum Depression (PPD), particularly targeting the γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) deficit. Traditional antidepressants often show limited success due to non- or incomplete therapeutic responses and delayed onset of action. A new class of medications targeting GABAergic dysfunction offers a quicker therapeutic onset. The educational program aims to improve understanding of MDD and PPD risk factors, the role of GABAergic dysfunction, and emerging therapeutic strategies. Ronald A. Codario, MD, EMBA, FACP, FNLA, RPVI, CHCP, contributed as a planner/reviewer and disclosed no relevant financial relationships. The activity is supported by Sage Therapeutics, Inc. and Biogen, and it provides 1.25 CME credits. The intended audience includes psychiatrists, obstetricians/gynecologists, and other healthcare professionals managing patients with MDD and PPD. Participants must complete various steps to earn CME credits, and the content adheres to ACCME standards.

title: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder: Updates on Diagnosis and Treatment Management
summary: Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD) is a rare autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, often misdiagnosed as multiple sclerosis. Diagnosis relies on clinical characteristics, aquaporin-4 antibody status, and MRI. Recent advancements in diagnostic criteria aim for earlier and more accurate identification. Historically, NMOSD treatment options were limited, necessitating a thorough examination of current therapies for their mechanisms, safety, and efficacy. A continuing education activity supported by Horizon Therapeutics USA, Inc., focuses on educating healthcare providers about NMOSD. Experts will present didactic information, review case studies, and discuss evidence-based diagnostic criteria and best practices for differential diagnosis. The program aims to enhance therapeutic decision-making and interprofessional management strategies. Jennifer Frederick, PharmD, BCPS, contributed as a planner/reviewer for this activity, ensuring the educational content met high standards.

title: Seattle Magazine's Top Doctors 2016
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Seattle Magazine’s Top Doctors 2016 features 413 of the best physicians in the Puget Sound region, across 66 specialties, as chosen by their peers and compiled by Castle Connolly Medical Ltd. This issue highlights innovative local medical developments, such as egg freezing and less invasive artery-clearing methods. It also addresses challenges related to depression, suicide, and the rise of concierge medical care. The article emphasizes the increasing accessibility of healthcare through walk-in clinics and digital communication. Featured doctors include Fuki Hisama, M.D., Frank Virant, M.D., Sarah Dick, M.D., Marko Yakovlevitch, M.D., John Corman, M.D., and Jane Dimer, M.D. The piece also explores the primary reasons for ER visits in the Puget Sound area and includes detailed Q&As with several top doctors.

title: Report: Allergy season is getting longer around the Seattle area
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A recent report by Climate Central reveals that allergy season is getting longer and more severe in the Seattle area due to a warming climate. The extended growing season allows plants more time to bloom and release pollen, exacerbating symptoms for allergy sufferers. Dr. Jeremy Hess from the University of Washington Medicine confirms that this trend aligns with other findings, indicating a longer spring season. Increased carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere are also contributing to higher pollen production. Dr. Frank Virant, Senior Partner at Northwest Asthma and Allergy Center, noted that allergy season in Seattle now extends into August, compared to July a decade ago. The primary pollen producers causing flare-ups include trees from March to May, grasses from April to August, and weeds from May to August.

title: Is rodeo spurring on your allergies? - Baylor College of Medicine Blog Network
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Dr. Carla Davis, an allergy expert with Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children’s Hospital, highlights the potential for increased allergic reactions during the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo. Individuals with pre-existing seasonal allergies are more susceptible to reactions from animal exposure and outdoor allergens like tree and grass pollen. Dr. Davis explains that even those not typically allergic to petting zoo animals may experience symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, and itchy eyes. Hay and mold spores can also trigger reactions, especially in humid conditions. Preventative measures include taking over-the-counter antihistamines and decongestants before attending the event. For food allergies, she advises checking ingredients with vendors and avoiding uncertain foods. In cases of severe reactions, seeking immediate medical assistance is crucial.

title: As a nurse in rural Tennessee, I know how food deserts harm residents | Opinion
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Carla Davis, a certified advanced practice nurse with over 15 years of experience, highlights the impact of food deserts in rural Tennessee. As a family nurse practitioner, she observes that many residents struggle to access healthy food due to limited options and high inflation. Food deserts, areas lacking supermarkets within a mile in urban settings or ten miles in rural areas, exacerbate food insecurity. Davis emphasizes the importance of guiding patients to make healthier food choices at local discount stores, which often stock processed items high in fat, salt, and sugar. She advises seeking out dairy items, frozen vegetables and fruits, lean proteins, canned fruits and vegetables, and whole grains. Davis also encourages community discussions about healthy eating and the use of SNAP and EBT benefits at convenience stores. She advocates for local solutions to promote healthier diets and combat lifestyle-related diseases in rural communities.

title: FDA Approves Avapritinib in Indolent Systemic Mastocytosis
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The FDA has approved avapritinib (Ayvakit) as the first treatment for adult patients with indolent systemic mastocytosis, supported by data from the phase 2 PIONEER trial. The trial showed significant improvements in total symptom scores at 24 weeks, with avapritinib outperforming placebo. Avapritinib showed a mean change in total symptom scores of –15.6 points compared to –9.2 points with placebo. Investigator Cem Akin, MD, PhD, highlighted the consistent clinical improvements, expressing hope for patients. The trial also reported a higher proportion of patients achieving at least a 50% reduction in serum tryptase, KIT D816V variant allele burden, and bone marrow mast cell aggregates with avapritinib compared to placebo. Adverse effects were generally mild to moderate, with serious adverse events occurring less frequently in the avapritinib group.

title: Ayvakit Approved for Indolent Systemic Mastocytosis - MPR
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The FDA has approved Ayvakit (avapritinib) for treating adults with indolent systemic mastocytosis (ISM), based on data from the phase 2 PIONEER trial. This randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study involved patients with moderate to severe ISM symptoms, despite previous treatments. Participants received either avapritinib or a placebo alongside supportive care. Results showed avapritinib significantly reduced the total symptom score (TSS) by 15.33 points at week 24, compared to a 9.64-point reduction with placebo. Additionally, 25% of avapritinib-treated patients achieved a 50% reduction in TSS, versus 10% with placebo. The trial also met key secondary endpoints, showing significant improvements in measures of mast cell burden. Cem Akin, MD, PhD, highlighted the treatment's significant and consistent clinical improvements, expressing hope for those affected by ISM. Common adverse reactions included eye edema, dizziness, and peripheral edema. Ayvakit is also indicated for advanced systemic mastocytosis and certain gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

title: Mental health of surgeons now getting attention: Rutgers prof
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Anil Nanda, a professor of neurosurgery at Rutgers University, highlighted the increasing attention being given to the mental health of surgeons during the B Ramamurthi Oration, commemorating Dr. B Ramamurthi's birth centenary. Organized by the World Federation of Neurological Societies and Kauvery Hospital, Nanda discussed the various challenges surgeons face, including procedural failures, gun violence, and mental health deterioration. He noted that surgeons record the highest number of suicides among professionals. Nanda emphasized the prevalence of gun violence in the U.S. and its impact on surgeons, citing cases of dissatisfied patients resorting to shooting. He also stressed the importance of continual improvement in medical practice and shared examples where mortality rates have decreased due to advanced medical wisdom.

title: ASCIA 2023 Conference: towards oral immunotherapy's clinical use in Australia for food adverse conditions
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: The ASCIA 2023 Conference, held in Sydney from September 5-8, 2023, focused on advancing oral immunotherapy (OIT) for food allergies in Australia. The Australasian Society of Clinical Immunology and Allergy (ASCIA) hosted the event, which attracted international experts and featured over 60 speakers, including five from abroad. Notably, Prof Anna Nowak-Wegrzyn from the USA was among the prominent speakers. The conference highlighted the urgency of addressing food allergies, with Australia having one of the highest rates globally. Discussions included the Canadian model for OIT, which garnered significant interest. The event also featured numerous Clinical Grand Rounds, posters, and concurrent updates for medical practitioners, nurses, and dietitians. The success of the hybrid conference sets high expectations for ASCIA 2024 in Adelaide, chaired by Jovanka King. The conference emphasized the need for broader NGO involvement and the potential for Australia to lead in OIT implementation under ASCIA guidelines.

title: How to Treat Your Child's Seasonal Allergies, According to Our Pediatric Allergists
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: To manage your child's seasonal allergies, start medications early and use them regularly, as advised by pediatric allergists at the Pediatric Allergy Program, Hassenfeld Children’s Hospital at NYU Langone. Dr. Kanwaljit Brar emphasizes preemptive treatment to calm the immune system. Dr. Anna H. Nowak-Wegrzyn, director of the program, warns against waiting until symptoms worsen, which requires more medication. She recommends over-the-counter antihistamines, nasal sprays, and eye drops for symptom relief. For persistent symptoms, allergy shots or sublingual immunotherapy may be necessary. Lifestyle adjustments, such as monitoring pollen counts and minimizing outdoor exposure, are also suggested. Dr. Nowak-Wegrzyn highlights the importance of accurate allergy testing to tailor treatment effectively.

title: Allergy season arrived early this year. Here's how to keep pollen from ruining your spring
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Allergy season has arrived early in Chicago and other areas, with pollen counts rising sooner than expected. Dr. Rachna Shah, an allergist and director of the Loyola Medicine Allergy Count, noted that tree pollen levels were already moderate by mid-February, much earlier than usual. Experts attribute this to a mild winter and climate change, predicting a longer and more intense allergy season. Dr. Anju Peters, an allergy specialist with Northwestern Medicine, highlighted that nearly 25% of adults and 20% of children suffer from allergies, making it a widespread issue. To mitigate symptoms, Peters suggests keeping windows closed, avoiding high pollen times, changing clothes after being outside, and using pollen trackers. Over-the-counter nasal sprays, antihistamines, and immunotherapies can also help manage symptoms.

title: Fall Allergies: What to Know About Causes, Symptoms and Care
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Fall allergies are becoming more prevalent and severe due to climate change, which lengthens the allergy season and increases pollen production. Ragweed is the primary cause, releasing significant amounts of pollen from August to November. Mold from decaying leaves also contributes to symptoms. Differentiating between allergies, colds, and Covid can be challenging, but allergies typically last longer and do not cause fevers or body aches. Dr. Anju Peters, an allergist at Northwestern Medicine, notes that fall allergy symptoms mirror those of spring allergies, including runny noses, sneezing, and fatigue. Effective management includes keeping windows closed, using HEPA filters, and possibly wearing hats and sunglasses outdoors. Medications such as intranasal steroids and antihistamines can alleviate symptoms, while severe cases may benefit from immunotherapy. Monitoring and treating allergies is crucial, especially as they can trigger asthma, which has serious health implications.

title: A Chillier Spring Isn't Stopping Chicagoans From Having A Tough Allergy Season
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Chicagoans are enduring a tough allergy season despite a chillier and rainier spring, with high pollen levels persisting. Accuweather meteorologist Alan Reppert notes that tree pollen levels are currently high and will decrease as May progresses, but grass and ragweed pollen will rise in the summer and fall. Dr. Anju Peters from Northwestern University highlights that the milder winter has extended the growing season, exacerbating allergies. Peters explains that pollen can cause symptoms like sneezing, itchy eyes, and respiratory issues, particularly affecting asthma sufferers. She advises limiting outdoor activities during high pollen times, using protective gear, and trying over-the-counter treatments. For persistent symptoms, Peters recommends consulting an allergist for tailored treatment.

title: Breathe Easy – Chicago Magazine
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Chicago Magazine's "Breathe Easy" article highlights 80 top doctors in the Chicago area, nominated by their peers for excellence in treating respiratory issues such as asthma, allergies, and lung conditions. The article includes contributions from various specialists across different hospitals and medical centers. Anju Tripathi Peters, recognized for her expertise in asthma, is affiliated with Northwestern Memorial. The list was compiled by Castle Connolly, a reputable healthcare research company with over 30 years of experience. Castle Connolly's rigorous selection process involves evaluating nominees' professional qualifications, education, research leadership, and interpersonal skills. The aim is to connect patients with top-tier healthcare providers, ensuring better health outcomes through informed decision-making.

title: How to Clean Your Water Bottle and Avoid Mold
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Reusable water bottles are eco-friendly and help reduce nanoplastic exposure, but they can become moldy if not cleaned regularly. Dr. Wanda Phipatanakul, an immunologist at Boston Children’s Hospital, explains that mold thrives in moist environments, making water bottles a breeding ground if water sits for days. Common molds like Cladosporium, Penicillium, Aspergillus, and Stachybotrys can colonize bottles, alongside bacteria from your mouth, forming biofilms. While most mold species are harmless, sensitive individuals may experience symptoms like headaches or nasal congestion. To prevent mold buildup, wash bottles daily or weekly, using the hottest dishwasher setting or a bottle brush if hand-washing. A deeper clean can be achieved by soaking in water and white vinegar or using denture tablets. If mold persists after cleaning, it's best to replace the bottle.

title: OTC Budesonide-Formoterol for Asthma Could Save Lives, Money
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A study presented at the AAAAI 2023 Annual Meeting suggests that making budesonide-formoterol available over-the-counter (OTC) for as-needed use in mild asthma could save lives and reduce healthcare costs. Asthma affects 25 million people in the U.S., with many uninsured or underinsured individuals using less effective OTC inhalers like Primatene Mist. Research indicates that as-needed budesonide-formoterol could prevent 12,495 deaths, nearly 14 million severe asthma exacerbations, and save over $68 billion. Dr. Marcus Shaker emphasized the cost-effectiveness and potential health benefits of this approach. Dr. Thanai Pongdee highlighted the associated costs of using less effective treatments and noted insurance coverage challenges for budesonide-formoterol. Pongdee also mentioned alternative strategies to improve asthma management.

title: Spring Allergies Are Back. What Can You Do Now?
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Spring allergies, also known as seasonal allergic rhinitis, affect millions of Americans annually as trees, grasses, and weeds release pollen. Allison Ramsey, MD, an allergist with Rochester Regional Health, offers advice on preparing for and treating these allergies.
