Symptoms include runny or itchy nose, sneezing, itchy eyes, headache, coughing, and post-nasal drip. Dr. Ramsey notes that peak pollen levels typically last 2-4 weeks, ending by late June or early July. To manage allergies, she recommends checking local pollen counts, using dehumidifiers and HEPA filters, keeping windows closed, and purchasing medications early. Over-the-counter antihistamines, intranasal steroids, and immunotherapy are effective treatments. Natural remedies include air filters, washing after outdoor exposure, saline solutions, and maintaining a healthy diet. Dr. Ramsey emphasizes the importance of consulting an allergist if symptoms interfere with daily life.

title: Geisel Professor Named to National Leadership Post
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: Marcus Shaker, MD, MSc, FAAAAI, FACAAI, FAAP, a professor at Dartmouth’s Geisel School of Medicine and an allergy and clinical immunology physician at Dartmouth Health, has been named to the Board of Directors of the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Immunology (AAAAI). The AAAAI, comprising over 7,000 members globally, focuses on advancing knowledge and practice in allergy, asthma, and immunology. Elected for a four-year term, Shaker will focus on education and advocacy. He co-chairs the Joint Task Force on Practice Parameters and is involved in research to optimize value-based care in allergy and clinical immunology. Shaker has published over 150 articles and guidelines and has developed several multidisciplinary clinics at Dartmouth Health Children’s, including the first food oral immunotherapy program in New Hampshire and Vermont.

title: OTC Budesonide-Formoterol for Asthma Could Save Lives, Money
hco: AMERICAN ACADEMY OF ALLERGY ASTHMA & IMMUNOLOGY
summary: A study presented at the AAAAI 2023 Annual Meeting highlighted that over-the-counter (OTC) budesonide-formoterol could significantly save lives and reduce healthcare costs for mild asthma patients. Asthma affects 25 million Americans, with many relying on the only FDA-approved OTC inhaler, Primatene Mist, which has safety concerns. Marcus Shaker, MD, MS, from Dartmouth, emphasized that as-needed budesonide-formoterol is nearly as effective as daily maintenance therapy and aligns with Global Initiative for Asthma guidelines. Shaker's computer modeling study found that OTC budesonide-formoterol could prevent 12,495 deaths, nearly 14 million severe exacerbations, and save over $68 billion. Despite these findings, insurance coverage issues remain a barrier, as current labeling suggests daily use, conflicting with as-needed recommendations. Shaker noted that while OTC budesonide-formoterol wouldn't replace professional medical care, it offers a better alternative to the current situation.

title: Womb for Improvement
summary: The rate of endometrial cancer is rising, posing a significant public health crisis for women. At Johns Hopkins, Amanda Nickles Fader, professor of gynecology and obstetrics, emphasizes the need to raise awareness and develop new tools for early detection and treatment. Fader highlights the alarming increase in uterine cancer cases and deaths, driven by factors like obesity and aggressive tumor types, particularly affecting Black women. She advocates for heightened awareness similar to breast cancer campaigns and stresses the importance of early detection through recognizing abnormal bleeding. Fader's research focuses on fertility-sparing treatments and advanced therapies, including clinical trials for new drugs and immune-targeting therapies. Her efforts, along with those of her colleagues, aim to improve outcomes and offer new hope for patients. Fader also plans to emphasize building relationships with patient advocates and community partners when she becomes president of the Society of Gynecological Oncology in 2025.

title: Drug Shortages Are Affecting Cancer Treatments | Johns Hopkins | Bloomberg School of Public Health
summary: The U.S. is currently experiencing significant shortages of over a dozen cancer drugs, impacting hundreds of thousands of patients. Amanda Nickles Fader, a gynecological oncologist and associate professor at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, has had to adjust cancer treatments due to these shortages. These essential chemotherapy drugs, critical for curative treatments, are in short supply, affecting up to 90% of hospital systems nationwide. Fader discusses how this shortage forces clinicians to alter dosages, intervals, or switch to alternative drugs with potentially higher side effects. The shortage is attributed to manufacturing problems, especially with older generic drugs that lack investment in quality improvements. While the FDA is working to address short-term issues by expediting production and importation, Fader stresses the need for long-term solutions to prevent recurring shortages.

title: Dr Fader on Letrozole With or Without Paclitaxel and Carboplatin in Ovarian Serous Carcinoma
summary: Amanda Nickles Fader, MD, vice chair of Gynecologic Surgical Operations at Johns Hopkins Health System and professor of gynecology and obstetrics at Johns Hopkins Medicine, discussed the phase 3 NRG-GY019 trial. This trial evaluates the efficacy of letrozole with or without paclitaxel and carboplatin in patients with stage II to IV primary low-grade serous carcinoma of the ovary or peritoneum. A prior joint retrospective study by the Cleveland Clinic and Johns Hopkins Medicine indicated that adjuvant hormonal therapy alone, without chemotherapy, showed promising results in advanced low-grade serous ovarian carcinoma. This led to the inception of the NRG-GY019 trial, where patients are randomized to receive either a combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel followed by letrozole or letrozole alone. Fader emphasized that this might be the first advanced-stage ovarian cancer trial to exclude chemotherapy in one treatment arm, potentially highlighting letrozole's standalone efficacy.

title: Cancer drug shortage may force US doctors to ration chemotherapy
summary: A shortage of cancer drugs in the U.S. has led to reduced doses of chemotherapy, putting over 100,000 patients at risk. Elizabeth Arnold, diagnosed with advanced uterine cancer, is receiving fewer doses of carboplatin due to this shortage. Experts, including Dr. Amanda Nickles Fader from Johns Hopkins Hospital and president-elect of the Society of Gynecologic Oncology, emphasize the crisis's severity. Fader's organization surveyed its members and found that facilities in over 40 states are running short of key cancer medications. The shortage is primarily due to supply chain disruptions, with cisplatin and carboplatin being the most affected. The American Society of Clinical Oncology is working to resolve the issue, but the future remains uncertain. Fader's society is also collaborating with insurance companies to relax prior authorization requirements for nonstandard treatments. Structural changes and better supply chain management are needed to prevent future shortages.

title: Gynecologic cancer patients and advocates unite at FWC Forum in San Diego
summary: The Foundation for Women's Cancer (FWC) is organizing a Patient and Advocate Education Forum on March 15, 2024, in San Diego, CA, preceding the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) Annual Meeting. This complimentary event aims to unite gynecologic cancer patients, advocates, family members, and healthcare providers to explore recent developments in cancer treatment, share wellness practices, and engage in group activities. Key contributors include Rachel Miller Garcia, an active patient advocate, and Angeles Alvarez Secord, MD, MHSc, the 2023-2024 President of SGO from Duke University. The forum will feature presentations from renowned experts, including Dr. Ginger J. Gardner from Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, and will cover topics such as precision medicine, clinical trials, and side effect management.

title: Health | Amidst advancements in treating cancer, oncologists face new challenge: drug shortages
summary: Duke Cancer Center celebrated its annual Survivorship Day, highlighting advancements in cancer treatment such as immunotherapy and survivorship services. Despite these advancements, oncologists face a significant challenge: drug shortages. Dr. Angeles Alvarez Secord, a Duke Gynecologic Oncologist and President of the Society of Gynecologist Oncology, emphasized the severity of this issue, calling it a public health crisis. The shortages, affecting drugs like cisplatin and carboplatin, have forced some providers to reduce dosages and extend cycle times. Secord and other doctors have urged federal action to address these shortages, proposing incentives for U.S. manufacturers.

title: Targeting Folate Receptor Alpha Provides Therapeutic Benefits for Platinum-Resistant Ovarian Cancer
summary: Mirvetuximab soravtansine-gynx has shown promise in treating platinum-resistant ovarian cancer by targeting folate receptor alpha (FRα), a protein overexpressed in these tumors. This approach minimizes damage to normal tissues and allows therapeutic agents to be delivered directly into cancer cells. Approved by the FDA in 2022, mirvetuximab soravtansine-gynx has demonstrated significant improvements in progression-free and overall survival. Kathleen N. Moore, MD, emphasizes the importance of testing for FRα status in ovarian cancer patients to optimize treatment. Angeles Alvarez Secord, MD, from Duke, led the PICCOLO trial, which tested mirvetuximab in a platinum-sensitive setting, with results expected to potentially expand its indication. Future studies, like the ongoing GLORIOSA trial, may further advance the use of this therapy.

title: How the Shortage of a $15 Cancer Drug Is Upending Treatment
summary: The shortage of inexpensive chemotherapy drugs, cisplatin and carboplatin, is severely affecting cancer treatment in the U.S., forcing doctors to prioritize patients with the best survival chances. The scarcity has led to delays, altered treatments, and potentially poorer outcomes for many patients, particularly those with ovarian, testicular, breast, lung, and head and neck cancers. The issue stems from the shutdown of a major manufacturing plant, with limited relief from imported drugs. Dr. Angeles Alvarez Secord, president of the Society of Gynecologic Oncology, emphasized the severe impact on patient survival due to the shortage.

title: Salpingectomy for ovarian cancer prevention: Video education for the surgeon
summary: Salpingectomy, the removal of fallopian tubes, is emerging as a preventive measure against ovarian cancer (OC), particularly high-grade serous cancer (HGSC). This approach is gaining traction due to the fallopian tube being identified as the origin of HGSC. To promote the standardization and broader implementation of opportunistic salpingectomy (OS), a peer-reviewed surgical instructional video has been developed. This video aims to educate surgeons on safe and effective techniques for performing salpingectomy, highlighting key anatomic landmarks and preoperative counseling. The collaborative effort involved surgeon stakeholders, medical illustrators, instructional designers, and health education specialists. Karen H. Lu contributed to this initiative, which is strictly educational and aims to expand the practice of salpingectomy safely and equitably. The video resource is publicly available to support universal knowledge and access to this preventive strategy.

title: Dr. Karen Lu Joins Moffitt Cancer Center as New Executive Vice Preside | Moffitt
summary: Dr. Karen Lu has joined Moffitt Cancer Center as the new executive vice president and physician in chief. She will oversee the Moffitt Medical Group, Florida’s largest multidisciplinary medical group practice with over 600 faculty members and advanced practice providers. Dr. Lu is a nationally recognized physician-scientist specializing in ovarian and endometrial cancers, and the management of women at genetically high risk for these cancers. She has published seminal articles on hereditary gynecological cancers and has over 15 years of healthcare leadership experience. Prior to Moffitt, she served as the chair of the Department of Gynecologic Oncology and Reproductive Medicine and co-director of the Clinical Cancer Genetics program at MD Anderson Cancer Center. Dr. Lu holds degrees from Harvard University, Yale University School of Medicine, and the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. She is also involved with the American Society of Clinical Oncology and the Society of Gynecologic Oncology.

title: Phase 1b study of intraperitoneal ipilimumab and nivolumab in patients with recurrent gynecologic malignancies with ...
summary: The phase 1b study investigated intraperitoneal (i.p.) administration of nivolumab and ipilimumab in patients with recurrent gynecologic malignancies with peritoneal carcinomatosis. The trial enrolled 23 patients, mostly with ovarian cancer. The primary goal was to determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination therapy. The study found an objective response rate (ORR) of 18.8%, with a median duration of response of 14.8 months. Only 2 patients (8.7%) experienced grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events, indicating that the treatment is safe. Karen H. Lu contributed to the study, which was funded by Bristol Myers Squibb, MD Anderson Cancer Center, the Ovarian Cancer Moon Shots Program, and other grants. The results suggest that i.p. administration of these immune checkpoint inhibitors may produce durable responses in a subset of patients with advanced gynecologic malignancies.

title: Matthew A. Powell, MD, on Endometrial Cancer: Overall Survival Update on Dostarlimab-gxly Plus Chemotherapy
summary: Matthew A. Powell, MD, of the Washington University School of Medicine, presented phase III findings from the RUBY trial at the SGO 2024 Annual Meeting on Women's Cancer. The study demonstrated that dostarlimab-gxly combined with chemotherapy significantly improves overall survival in patients with primary advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer, regardless of mismatch repair status. Dr. Powell highlighted that this regimen could establish a new standard of care for these patients.

title: Next Steps After New Frontline Therapy for dMMR Endometrial Cancer
summary: Matthew A. Powell, MD, professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology and chief of the Division of Gynecologic Oncology at Siteman Cancer Center, Washington University School of Medicine, discusses the next steps and unmet needs following the phase 3 RUBY/ENGOT-EN6 study and the FDA approval of dostarlimab in combination with chemotherapy for treating patients with mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instability-high primary advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. Powell highlights the importance of researching molecular subtypes to determine which patients benefit most from this frontline therapy and investigating second-line therapies, including antibody-drug conjugates. He emphasizes the rising rate of endometrial cancer, partly due to the obesity epidemic, and the need for preventative strategies. Powell also points out the significant survival disparities among Black Americans, who tend to have more aggressive disease, stressing the importance of understanding and addressing these differences.

title: Key Takeaways From the 2023 Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) Annual Meeting
summary: The 2023 Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) Annual Meeting highlighted significant advancements in endometrial cancer treatment. Dr. Floor J. Backes and Dr. Matthew A. Powell from Washington University in St. Louis presented key findings from the SGO, ASCO, and ESMO conferences. Notably, HER2-targeted therapies showed promising response rates, marking a pivotal development in the treatment landscape. Dr. Powell's contributions were instrumental in elucidating these advancements, underscoring the potential of targeted therapies in improving patient outcomes. The discussions also covered recent data on single-agent immunotherapy, combination treatments, and the impact of real-world evidence on managing advanced endometrial cancer.

title: program | Nordic-American Healthcare Conference | Events | Business from A to Z
summary: The Nordic-American Healthcare Conference 2023 is a two-day event focusing on emerging growth and market sessions in the healthcare sector. Day I includes sessions on exploring the US healthcare market, critical issues for Nordic CEOs, and discussions on financing, M&A dynamics, and healthcare delivery in the US. Marcela G. del Carmen, MD, MPH, a Professor at Harvard Medical School and President of the Massachusetts General Physicians Organization, will deliver a keynote address. The day also features company presentations and networking opportunities. Day II continues with company presentations and a panel discussion on global healthcare capital markets. The event aims to provide insights, networking, and investment opportunities in the healthcare industry.

title: Artificial Intelligence Tool Accurately Answers Patients' Common Questions About Gynecologic Cancer
summary: A study presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology’s Annual Meeting on March 17, 2024, demonstrated that an AI tool, specifically ChatGPT, accurately answered 83% of common genetic counseling questions related to gynecologic cancer. The research, conducted by NYU Langone Health and its Perlmutter Cancer Center, involved inputting 40 frequently asked questions into ChatGPT and having gynecologic oncologists evaluate the responses. The AI provided correct and comprehensive answers to 82.5% of the questions. Emeline M. Aviki, MD, MBA, from the Division of Gynecologic Oncology at NYU Grossman Long Island School of Medicine, contributed to the study. The AI tool shows promise in reducing patient anxiety and improving information dissemination, though further data and refinement are needed before clinical deployment.

title: Gynecologic cancer patients and advocates unite at FWC Forum in San Diego
summary: Gynecologic cancer patients and advocates will gather at the Foundation for Women's Cancer (FWC) Patient and Advocate Education Forum on March 15, 2024, in San Diego. The event will precede the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) 2024 Annual Meeting on Women's Cancer. Attendees, including patients, advocates, and healthcare providers, will explore recent advancements in gynecologic cancer, share health and wellness practices, and engage in group activities. Rachel Miller Garcia, a patient advocate and Co-Chair of the Forum Planning Committee, highlights the significance of community and shared learning in the fight against these cancers. Ginger J. Gardner, MD, Chair of the FWC, emphasizes the importance of raising awareness and providing information to address unmet needs and reduce the burden of gynecologic cancers. The Forum will feature presentations, panels, and networking opportunities aimed at fostering connections and enhancing understanding among participants.

title: AACR Special Conferences Gather Investigators Advancing Research on Gynecologic Cancers
summary: The American Association for Cancer Research (AACR) is hosting Special Conferences this fall to advance research on gynecologic cancers, specifically ovarian and endometrial cancers. The conferences will be held in Boston on October 5-7 and November 16-18, respectively. These events aim to facilitate the exchange of the latest research findings and foster collaboration among scientists. Frances R. Balkwill, PhD, and Victoria L. Bae-Jump, MD, PhD, are among the organizing co-chairs. Bae-Jump emphasized the importance of addressing endometrial cancer, which is increasing in both incidence and mortality, and highlighted the need for more inclusive studies to reduce disparities, particularly among Black women. The conferences will cover topics such as prevention, early detection, and new therapeutic approaches, including immunotherapy and targeted therapies.

title: Machine learning unlocks personalized approach to early ovarian cancer detection
summary: Scientists at the Georgia Tech Integrated Cancer Research Center (ICRC) have developed a new early diagnostic test for ovarian cancer using machine learning and blood metabolite data, achieving 93% accuracy. This test surpasses current methods, particularly in detecting early-stage ovarian cancer. The study, led by John McDonald, was published in Gynecologic Oncology. The research team includes notable contributors such as Victoria L. Bae-Jump from the University of North Carolina. The team's approach uses a patient's metabolic profile to provide a more accurate and personalized probability of disease presence, representing a significant advancement in early cancer detection.

title: Unmet Needs in the Management of Patients With Advanced Endometrial Cancer
summary: Floor J. Backes, MD, highlights several unmet needs in the management of advanced endometrial cancer. Key areas of focus include determining the next steps when patients develop resistance to immunotherapy, utilizing targeted radiation for oligometastatic disease, and categorizing patients into subgroups for personalized care. These strategies aim to improve treatment outcomes and address current gaps in managing this complex condition.

title: Recent Advances in Endometrial Cancer
summary: Matthew Powell, MD, and Floor Backes, MD, discuss recent advances in the molecular profiling and staging of endometrial cancer. They highlight the importance of these developments in improving diagnosis and treatment strategies. The discussion includes insights from various episodes covering key takeaways from the 2023 Society of Gynecologic Oncology Annual Meeting, data on single-agent immunotherapy, and the impact of real-world evidence. Specific studies such as the RUBY Trial on dostarlimab plus chemotherapy and the AtTEnd study on atezolizumab plus carboplatin and paclitaxel are also reviewed. Additionally, they address adverse events associated with systemic therapies and unmet needs in managing advanced endometrial cancer.

title: Adverse Events Seen With Systemic Therapies in Patients With Advanced Endometrial Cancer
summary: Drs. Floor J. Backes and Matthew A. Powell discuss the management of adverse events in patients with advanced endometrial cancer treated with systemic therapies. They compare the adverse events associated with upfront immunotherapy versus chemotherapy followed by later immunotherapy. The discussion emphasizes the need for molecular subgroup data from clinical trials such as LEAP-001 to better understand and manage these adverse events.

title: Two Landmark Studies in Endometrial Cancer 'Hit It Out of the Park'
summary: Two landmark clinical trials, NRG-GY018 and RUBY, presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology (SGO) annual meeting, demonstrated that adding immunotherapy to standard chemotherapy significantly prolongs progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. Paul DiSilvestro, MD, director of the Program in Women's Oncology at Women & Infants Hospital of Rhode Island, emphasized the importance of these findings, noting that they address a significant unmet need in the field. DiSilvestro expressed hope for the near-future approval of these treatments, which could soon be integrated into everyday clinical practice.

title: No Survival Benefit With CRT Versus Chemo for Locally Advanced Endometrial Cancer
summary: A long-term clinical trial revealed no overall survival benefit of chemoradiation (CRT) over chemotherapy alone for locally advanced endometrial cancer. After a median follow-up of 112 months, CRT did not significantly improve recurrence-free survival (RFS) and showed a higher incidence of distant recurrences. Daniela Matei, MD, presented these findings at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology meeting. Paul DiSilvestro, MD, humorously questioned if the results would significantly alter current practices, emphasizing the importance of chemotherapy alone based on the definitive study. The trial, spanning nearly two decades, involved 813 patients and concluded that CRT did not offer a survival advantage.

title: Early Data on Neoadjuvant Olaparib in Ovarian Cancer
summary: Early findings from the phase I NOW trial presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology annual meeting suggest that neoadjuvant treatment with olaparib (Lynparza) before surgery and adjuvant chemotherapy is well tolerated and achieves a 100% optimal resection rate in patients with newly diagnosed, BRCA-mutant ovarian, primary peritoneal, or fallopian tube cancer. Paul DiSilvestro, MD, director of the women's oncology program at Women & Infants Hospital of Rhode Island, highlighted the significance of this new approach, noting it shifts away from traditional combination cytotoxic chemotherapy to using a targeted agent alone before surgery. He finds the initial results compelling and looks forward to further studies expanding this strategy to more patients.

title: Dr Richardson on the UPLIFT Trial of Upifitamab Rilsodotin in Ovarian Cancer
summary: Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, discussed the outcomes of the UPLIFT trial evaluating upifitamab rilsodotin (UpRi; XMT-1536) in patients with ovarian cancer. Conducted during the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting, the phase 1/2 trial aimed to demonstrate efficacy in platinum-resistant serous ovarian cancer. The goal was to achieve an objective response rate (ORR) exceeding 12%, comparable to standard chemotherapy. Upifitamab rilsodotin targets NaPi2b, a protein in various tumors, aiming to reduce toxicities common in similar treatments. Despite this, the trial showed an ORR of 15.6% in NaPi2b-positive patients, falling short of the efficacy threshold. The overall ORR was 13.1%. The presence of NaPi2b did not significantly enhance response rates. Consequently, the development of upifitamab rilsodotin was discontinued, highlighting the challenges in translating preclinical data into effective clinical treatments for platinum-resistant ovarian cancer.

title: Dr Richardson on the Efficacy of Selinexor in TP53 Wild-Type Endometrial Cancer
summary: Dr. Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, discussed the efficacy of selinexor in patients with TP53 wild-type advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer. The phase 3 ENGOT-EN5/GOG-3055/SIENDO trial evaluated selinexor as maintenance therapy but did not show improved median progression-free survival (PFS) compared to placebo in the overall population. However, a subgroup analysis revealed a significant PFS benefit in patients with TP53 wild-type endometrial cancer, with selinexor producing a median PFS of 27.4 months versus 5.2 months with placebo. Selinexor, an oral XPO1 inhibitor, blocks the export of tumor suppressor proteins, potentially enhancing p53 functionality. Richardson emphasized the need for validation through randomized trials, with the ongoing phase 3 XPORT-EC-042 trial aiming to confirm these findings.

title: Journey Ends for Upifitamab Rilsodotin in NaPi2b+ Platinum-Resistant Ovarian Cancer
summary: Upifitamab rilsodotin (UpRi; XMT-1536), a NaPi2b-directed antibody-drug conjugate, showed modest activity in NaPi2b-positive patients with platinum-resistant high-grade serous ovarian cancer. The overall response rate (ORR) in the phase 1/2 UPLIFT trial did not meet the prespecified primary endpoint, with an ORR of 15.6% in NaPi2b-positive patients and 10.2% in NaPi2b-low patients. Debra L. Richardson, MD, FACS, FACOG, highlighted that the development of upifitamab rilsodotin was discontinued as it failed to meet its primary objective. The trial results were presented at the 2024 SGO Annual Meeting on Women’s Cancer, indicating that the presence of NaPi2b does not enrich for response. Richardson, an associate professor and chief of the Section of Gynecologic Oncology at the University of Oklahoma, discussed the rationale, efficacy, and safety profile of upifitamab rilsodotin, and noted that the trial's biomarker did not enhance response rates.

title: Dr Soliman on the Use of ctDNA as a Clinical Trial End Point in Endometrial Cancer
summary: Pamela T. Soliman, MD, MPH, from The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, discussed the use of circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) as a clinical trial endpoint in endometrial cancer at the 2023 Society of Gynecological Oncology (SGO) Annual Meeting. Soliman and her team explored ctDNA collected via liquid biopsy in a phase 2 trial evaluating everolimus and letrozole, with or without ribociclib, in patients with advanced or recurrent endometrial carcinoma. The study aimed to assess genetic mutations in pretreatment biopsies and correlate them with pretreatment ctDNA, monitoring changes in mutational allele frequency (MAF) during treatment. Results showed that pretreatment ctDNA correlated with baseline tumor biopsy results, and responders with pretreatment ctDNA mutations showed a decrease in MAF after eight weeks of therapy. Soliman concluded that ctDNA could be a less invasive method for identifying translational biomarkers in clinical trials.

title: THERESA TOLLE NAMED 2023 NCPA WILLARD B. SIMMONS INDEPENDENT PHARMACIST OF THE YEAR
summary: Theresa Tolle, owner of Bay Street Pharmacy in Sebastian, Florida, has been named the 2023 NCPA Willard B. Simmons Independent Pharmacist of the Year. The award, sponsored by Upsher-Smith Laboratories, LLC, recognizes exemplary leadership and commitment to independent pharmacy. Tolle, a second-generation pharmacist, has led her pharmacy since 1999, providing services like immunizations, diabetes education, and medication therapy management. She has held leadership roles in various pharmacy associations, including the Florida Pharmacy Association and the American Pharmacists Association. Tolle also contributes to her community by chairing the Board of Trustees for Sebastian River Medical Center and participating in local organizations.

title: FDA Roundup: March 19, 2024
summary: The FDA provided an update on quality and performance issues with plastic syringes made in China, issuing warning letters to three entities for violations related to unauthorized syringes. The FDA expects these entities to address the violations and will take further steps as needed. Additionally, the FDA released a podcast featuring Dr. Theresa Michele and Dr. Ilisa Bernstein discussing the advisory committee meeting on oral phenylephrine as a nasal decongestant. A new portal was launched for reporting potential drug shortages directly into the CDER's NextGen system. The FDA also approved DuOtic for treating yeast-only otitis externa in dogs.

title: DSN webinar: Panelists weigh in on pharmacists' expanded role as providers
summary: During an OmniSYS-sponsored webinar on August 22, titled "Healthcare Equity and Access Demands Pharmacists as Providers," panelists discussed pharmacists' contributions during the pandemic and the need to expand their role. Ilisa Bernstein, senior vice president at the American Pharmacists Association, highlighted the critical role pharmacists played, especially in underserved areas, due to their immunization training and the federal PREP Act. She emphasized the need to utilize pharmacists' expertise fully, advocating for changes to allow pharmacists to practice at the top of their license. Bernstein also pointed out the importance of addressing reimbursement and regulatory barriers to enable pharmacists to provide more comprehensive care. The discussion underscored the increased accessibility and trust pharmacists have gained, advocating for their expanded role in healthcare post-pandemic.

title: DSCSA is Coming. Are you Ready?
summary: The Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA) will be fully implemented by November 27, 2023, requiring manufacturers, distributors, and pharmacies to track and verify prescription products down to the unit level. This act aims to formalize existing practices in pharmacies and supersede state pedigree requirements. Ilisa Bernstein, PharmD, JD, senior vice president of Pharmacy Practice and Government Affairs at the American Pharmacists Association (APhA), highlighted the DSCSA's origins in combating counterfeit drugs from the 1990s and early 2000s. She noted the failure of voluntary tracking efforts and the subsequent legislative action in 2013. The DSCSA mandates a secure electronic system for exchanging transaction information and statements, involving all parties in the pharmaceutical supply chain. Compliance relies on interdependence among trading partners, with specific procedures for inspecting, quarantining, and reporting suspect products. Enforcement and maintaining records for six years are critical components, with ongoing updates and resources provided by industry groups.

title: Who are the 50 most influential leaders in pharmacy?
summary: The Pharmacy 50 program, initiated by The Pharmacy Podcast Network in 2021, honors individuals who significantly impact the pharmacy sector. Voted by industry peers, the list features diverse professionals, including Nadia Ahmad for her leadership and mental health advocacy. Ilisa Bernstein, recognized for her dynamic and collaborative approach in regulatory challenges, is praised by Michael Hogue of the American Pharmacist Association for her advocacy work. The program, supported by Cardinal Health and the Independent Pharmacy Cooperative, saw a 300% increase in votes and will host an awards ceremony on January 17, 2024, streamed live on social media.

title: Health Watch: FDA updates oral decongestant recommendations - USC News & Events
summary: On September 12, 2023, an FDA advisory panel determined that phenylephrine, a common ingredient in over-the-counter cold medications, is ineffective as an oral decongestant and comparable to a placebo. Patricia H. Fabel, a clinical associate professor of pharmacy and executive director of the Kennedy Pharmacy Innovation Center, elaborated on the implications of this finding. Phenylephrine became prevalent in 2006 after restrictions were placed on pseudoephedrine due to its potential use in methamphetamine production. Fabel emphasized that pseudoephedrine is a more effective decongestant, despite its side effects and abuse potential. She also highlighted the limited efficacy and safety concerns associated with nasal sprays containing phenylephrine. Fabel advised consumers to consult pharmacists for appropriate medication choices and mentioned alternative treatments like saline sprays and nasal corticosteroids. This update is part of USC’s Health Watch series, aiming to inform readers about current health recommendations.

title: Get to know your 2023–2024 APhA–ASP National Executive Committee: Victoria Lyle, national president
summary: Victoria Lyle, the 2023–2024 APhA–ASP National President, is a final-year PharmD candidate at the University at Buffalo School of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences. Born in Buffalo, she initially worked as a radiologic technologist before transitioning to pharmacy. She joined CVS as a pharmacy technician in 2018 while completing prepharmacy courses. Lyle has also worked as a pharmacy intern at Wegmans. Her involvement with APhA–ASP began in October 2020 after attending a Midyear Regional Meeting, which inspired her to run for a regional position. She was elected Region 1 regional member-at-large, promoting patient care projects. As National President, Lyle aims to motivate student pharmacists to embrace their unique qualities and advocate for the profession. She enjoys spending time with family, journaling, and traveling, with a goal to visit all 50 states.

title: 2023 Visiting Professor Equality Diversity and Inclusion Series - Faculty of Health Sciences
summary: Dr. Vibhuti Arya, a Clinical Professor at St. John's University, will lead the 2023 Visiting Professor Equality Diversity and Inclusion Series at Trinity College Dublin from November 6th to 8th. With 15 years of experience bridging healthcare, well-being, and equity, Dr. Arya is an expert in racial dialogue and structural racism. Her work integrates pharmacists into public health initiatives and advises on legislation. She has contributed to public health detailing, policy planning, naloxone access, syndromic surveillance, correctional health services, and emergency preparedness. Dr. Arya also holds leadership roles in professional bodies and non-profits, has received numerous awards, and gave a TEDx talk on structural racism. The series includes sessions on dismantling structural racism, trauma-informed care, and storytelling workshops, aimed at creating safe spaces for students and staff to discuss and address these issues. Registration is required for participation due to limited spots.

title: Drug Legalization, Decriminalization Policy Will Be Introduced to APHA House of Delegates in 2023
summary: In 2023, the American Pharmacists Association (APhA) House of Delegates will introduce a policy on drug legalization and decriminalization. Currently, APhA opposes both. Pharmacy Times interviewed Vibhuti Arya, a professor at St. John's University, and Adrienne Simmons, director at the National Viral Hepatitis Roundtable, about drug decriminalization's impact on public health. Arya emphasized the structural inequities and racism in current drug policies, advocating for a shift from criminal penalties to human-centered care. Decriminalization reduces criminal penalties for drug possession to civil offenses, aiming to treat substance use as a health issue rather than a criminal one. Arya and Simmons highlighted the need for empathetic care and education to destigmatize substance use disorders. Arya's contributions were crucial in advocating for policy changes and educating pharmacy students on harm reduction and compassionate language.

title: URI pharmacy professor plays key role in national association's recommendations to decriminalize personal drug ...
summary: University of Rhode Island Clinical Professor Jeffrey Bratberg significantly contributed to the American Pharmacists Association’s (APhA) new policy statements advocating for the decriminalization of personal drug possession. These changes aim to address the overdose crisis by shifting from punitive measures to health-focused interventions, emphasizing the essential role of pharmacists in harm reduction services. Bratberg’s research demonstrated the effectiveness of pharmacy-based care in maintaining patient treatment for opioid use disorder. Vibhuti Arya, a professor at St. John’s University, also played a pivotal role, advocating for systemic reform towards health equity and anti-racism. Arya, along with Bratberg and Adrienne Simmons, presented educational sessions on decriminalization and harm reduction at the APhA Annual Meeting. This policy aligns APhA with other major health organizations, reinforcing the view that drug use should be treated as a public health issue.

title: Medicaid pharmacy claims system is back online, but problems may linger for providers
summary: Vermont’s Medicaid pharmacy claims system has been restored after a cyberattack on Change Healthcare disrupted services for nearly a month. While the system is back online, issues may persist for non-pharmacy providers. The cyberattack, which affected the largest health care payment system in the U.S., caused significant disruptions. Alex McCracken from the Department of Vermont Health Access announced the system's restoration, but cautioned that complete resolution is still pending. Lauren Bode, executive director of the Vermont Pharmacists Association, highlighted the extensive backlog of claims that pharmacies now face, estimating thousands of prescriptions need re-billing. Despite interim financial support from DVHA, long-term financial impacts on pharmacies remain uncertain. Bode also noted ongoing challenges with Medicare Part B claims and urged patience as the system fully recovers.

title: After winning UMSOP’s inaugural 'pharmapreneur' contest, this founder is tackling research waste
summary: Meya Ngundam, a recent Pharm.D. graduate from the University of Maryland School of Pharmacy (UMSOP), won $100,000 in UMSOP’s inaugural Pharmapreneur’s Market competition for her startup, LabConnection. This initiative addresses the disposal of outdated lab equipment by connecting labs with potential users, including entities in developing nations. The competition was part of the entrepreneurship education priorities established by Magaly Rodriguez de Bittner, UMSOP associate dean and professor of pharmapreneurship. Rodriguez de Bittner, who helped create the competition to support entrepreneurial students, will serve on LabConnection’s board of directors.

title: ADA Liaison Contact | MUSC | Charleston, SC
summary: The Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) provides comprehensive ADA resources and support through its Office of Equity, which includes documentation guidelines, scholarship information, FAQs, and policies related to disabilities. Students seeking accommodations must apply through the department of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion, where the Director of Equity, EEO, and University Accessibility Services collaborates with the college's ADA Liaison to facilitate reasonable accommodations in academic and clinical settings. Dr. Cathy Worrall, a professor at the College of Pharmacy, is one of the ADA Liaisons involved in this process. These liaisons work with faculty and clinical coordinators to ensure that approved accommodations are implemented. Contact information for various ADA Liaisons across different colleges is provided for further assistance.

title: AMA on HHS response to Change Healthcare cyber incident
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) acknowledges the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) for their prompt response to the Change Healthcare cyber incident, which disrupted medical practices and patient care. Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, President of the AMA, praised the newly announced flexibilities but emphasized the financial struggles physicians face, particularly small, rural, and underserved practices. The AMA urges CMS to provide further support, including financial assistance such as advanced payments, to ensure the viability of these medical practices.

title: 'Humbling, Exhausting, Exhilarating': The Life of AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), described his tenure as "humbling, exhausting, and exhilarating." During his term, Ehrenfeld has engaged in significant activities, including delivering a medical humanities lecture in Gainesville, Georgia, and speaking at the Old North State Medical Society in Greensboro, North Carolina, where he discussed health equity. He has been vocal about the challenges in Congress, particularly the dysfunction affecting healthcare legislation, such as reversing Medicare physician fee cuts and addressing workforce shortages. Ehrenfeld emphasizes the need to rethink healthcare delivery using technology and is concerned about the implications of artificial intelligence in medical systems. Balancing his professional responsibilities with family life, Ehrenfeld credits his husband for managing their home life while he fulfills his AMA duties.

title: Broader Digital Health Trends
summary: The text discusses broader digital health trends, emphasizing the critical juncture in the industry and the need for effective tools to support clinicians. Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), highlighted the importance of physician involvement in technology development at the 2023 AIMed Global Summit. Ehrenfeld, a practicing anesthesiologist, noted the necessity for better tools to manage patient data and improve care. He stressed that digital health tools must work effectively, be covered by insurance, have clear accountability, and integrate seamlessly into practice. Ehrenfeld also warned of past technological failures, like EHRs, due to inadequate physician input. He called for maintaining public trust and ensuring that new tools live up to their promises. Ehrenfeld's contributions include advocating for physician involvement in AI development, managing emerging risks, and ensuring ethical standards and equity in digital health tools.

title: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, address at the 2023 Interim Meeting of the HOD
summary: In his address at the 2023 Interim Meeting of the AMA House of Delegates, AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld emphasized the critical need for Medicare payment reform, highlighting the detrimental impact of the current system on both physicians and patients. He shared personal stories illustrating the pressures faced by medical professionals, including the tragic suicides of colleagues and the exodus of physicians due to political and legislative challenges. Ehrenfeld called for unified action to advocate for change, urging attendees to engage with the "Fix Medicare Now" campaign. He underscored the importance of addressing physician burnout, reforming prior authorization processes, and opposing unsafe scope of practice expansions. Ehrenfeld's speech was a rallying cry for physicians to lead the charge in advocating for systemic healthcare reforms.

title: AMA president Ehrenfeld to address looming physician shortage at a National Press Club Newsmaker on Oct. 25
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, the President of the American Medical Association (AMA) since June 2023, will address the critical issue of the looming physician shortage in the United States at a National Press Club Newsmaker event on October 25. With the health care system facing significant challenges due to record-high physician burnout and a projected shortage of up to 124,000 physicians over the next decade, Ehrenfeld will discuss the implications for patients and health care workers. He will outline the key factors driving physicians away from the profession and present a roadmap for addressing this crisis, focusing on the AMA's Recovery Plan for America's Physicians. The event will include a moderated Q&A session and is open to credentialed media and club members, with virtual attendance options available.

title: The physician shortage is here: AMA implores Congress to address 'urgent crisis'
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), addressed Congress to tackle the critical shortage of radiologists and other physicians in the U.S. healthcare system. Speaking at the National Press Club, Ehrenfeld highlighted significant challenges such as administrative burdens, burnout, attacks on science, healthcare consolidation, and a flawed Medicare payment system. He proposed five solutions: meaningful Medicare payment reform, reducing administrative burdens, expanding residency training and student loan support, ending the criminalization of healthcare, and ensuring mental health support for physicians. Ehrenfeld emphasized the urgent need for bipartisan action to strengthen the physician workforce and ensure adequate healthcare for all Americans.

title: AMA Urges Congress to Address Physician Burnout, Shortage
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), highlighted the severe physician burnout and workforce challenges during a press conference. Ehrenfeld emphasized that two-thirds of doctors experienced burnout during the pandemic, the highest level ever recorded by the AMA. He pointed out that many physicians avoid seeking mental health treatment due to fear of professional repercussions. Ehrenfeld addressed the financial strains on doctors, including a 26% drop in Medicare payment rates since 2001 and further cuts anticipated. He warned about the growing physician shortage, particularly affecting lower-income families, and urged legislative action to stabilize the workforce. Ehrenfeld proposed five steps to address these issues, including Medicare payment reform, reducing administrative burdens, facilitating foreign-trained physicians' practice, decriminalizing evidence-based care, and ensuring mental health support for doctors. He called on Congress and the Biden administration to pass multiple pending bills to prevent further attrition in the medical profession.

title: Physicians criticize insurance lobby's 'tone-deaf' response to Change Healthcare cyberattack
summary: Physicians are criticizing the health insurance lobby's inadequate response to the Change Healthcare cyberattack. AHIP, representing health insurers, stated they have taken steps to support providers, but many physicians feel these measures are insufficient. AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, expressed frustration over AHIP’s delayed and inadequate response, highlighting that the cyberattack has exacerbated administrative burdens and care delays. Ehrenfeld criticized AHIP for prioritizing profits over the stability of the healthcare system, contrasting it with the Biden administration’s call for health plans to provide more support. The federal government has initiated an investigation into the cyberattack, and CMS has offered advance Medicare payments to affected providers. The American Hospital Association has also urged Congress to assist impacted providers, noting the severe financial strain caused by the attack.

title: ChatGPT, AI in health care and the future of medicine with AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH
summary: AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, discussed the potential of generative AI like ChatGPT to revolutionize health care by alleviating administrative burdens and enhancing the patient-physician relationship. Despite its promise, AI's diagnostic capabilities remain limited, as current algorithms lack the nuanced judgment of clinicians. Ehrenfeld emphasized using AI as a supportive tool rather than a replacement for clinical decision-making. He highlighted the regulatory and liability challenges, noting that physicians could be unfairly held accountable for AI errors, which could hinder AI adoption. Additionally, public trust and data privacy are critical concerns. Ehrenfeld urged physicians to engage in shaping AI's regulatory landscape to ensure its safe and effective integration into medical practice.

title: AMA: Patients, physicians continue to endure Medicare cuts
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) has expressed disappointment over the continuation of nearly half of the 2024 Medicare physician payment cuts. Despite widespread support, Congress only reversed 1.68% of the 3.37% cuts required by the Medicare Fee Schedule. Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, President of the AMA, highlighted the detrimental impact on seniors' access to high-quality care, especially in rural and underserved areas. He emphasized the urgent need for Congress to stop the cycle of temporary fixes and implement permanent Medicare payment reforms. The AMA is prepared to offer policy proposals to address the issue, stressing that the current path is unsustainable.

title: CMS prior authorization final rule explained with AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH
summary: The AMA Update video discusses the CMS final rule on prior authorization, highlighting its importance for patients and physicians. AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, explains that the new rule, which the AMA advocated for, includes significant reforms such as integrating electronic prior authorization into health records, requiring specific denial reasons, and shortening decision time frames. These changes aim to reduce administrative burdens and delays in care, potentially saving practices $15 billion over the next decade. Ehrenfeld emphasizes the ongoing advocacy efforts at both federal and state levels to further improve prior authorization processes.

title: Bruce A. Scott, MD, wins office of AMA president-elect
summary: Bruce A. Scott, MD, an otolaryngologist from Kentucky, has been elected president-elect of the American Medical Association (AMA) during the 2023 AMA Annual Meeting. Dr. Scott will serve a year-long term as president-elect before becoming AMA president in June 2024. Throughout his career, Dr. Scott has been a prominent leader in medicine, serving in the AMA House of Delegates for over 25 years. He was first elected as the speaker of the House of Delegates in 2019 and joined the AMA Board of Trustees in 2015. Dr. Scott is committed to addressing physician burnout, reducing administrative burdens, and advocating for a sustainable Medicare system.

title: Medicare payment reform: The fight to fix Medicare now with Bruce Scott, MD
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) is prioritizing Medicare payment reform to address the financial strain on physicians caused by stagnant Medicare payments and rising practice costs. Bruce A. Scott, MD, AMA President-elect, highlights that Medicare physician payments have only increased by 9% over 22 years, while practice costs have risen by 47%, leading to a 26% decline in inflation-adjusted payments. Dr. Scott emphasizes the urgency of this issue, noting the introduction of the Strengthening Medicare for Patients and Providers Act (HR 2474), which aims to tie physician payments to inflation. He also discusses the administrative burdens and financial challenges faced by practices, urging collective advocacy efforts to ensure continued access to quality care. Dr. Scott's personal experiences underline the broader impact on the healthcare system, advocating for reforms to stabilize physician practices and improve patient care.

title: Inaction on Medicare payment reform jeopardizes quality care
summary: Inaction on Medicare payment reform threatens the quality of care for millions of patients, as highlighted by Bruce A. Scott, MD. He explains that stagnant Medicare reimbursement rates over the past two decades have financially strained physician practices, including his own in Louisville, Ky. Adjusted for inflation, Medicare physician pay has decreased by 26% from 2001 to 2023, while practice costs have significantly increased. This financial pressure is exacerbated by private insurers tying their rates to Medicare's, leading to unsustainable contracts. Dr. Scott advocates for tying Medicare payments to inflation and supporting the bipartisan Strengthening Medicare for Patients and Providers Act to ensure financial stability and continued access to high-quality care.

title: What doctors wish patients knew about Medicare physician payment
summary: The Medicare physician payment system is under scrutiny due to its failure to keep up with inflation, impacting patients' access to care. Medicare payments are determined annually through a complex formula, but they do not adjust for inflation, leading to financial strain on physicians. Dr. Bruce A. Scott, AMA President-elect, highlights that physician pay constitutes only 15% of total healthcare expenditure, yet it's often seen as the cost factor. Over the past 23 years, Medicare physician pay has effectively been cut by 30% when adjusted for inflation. This situation forces physicians to make difficult decisions, potentially limiting patient access to care. Private practices are particularly struggling, as Medicare rates influence private payer contracts. Dr. Scott urges patients and physicians to advocate for Medicare payment reform through the AMA's Patient Action Network to ensure sustainable healthcare practices and maintain patient access to trusted physicians.

title: The physician role in changing health care: How does the AMA support medical specialty societies?
summary: The AMA supports medical specialty societies by advocating for key healthcare issues at both federal and state levels. The AMA addresses significant challenges such as prior authorization and Medicare payment cuts, which impact patient care and physician practice. Bruce A. Scott, MD, the AMA President-Elect, highlighted the administrative burdens of prior authorization and the financial strain from Medicare payment cuts, emphasizing the AMA's role in mitigating these issues. Dr. Scott also mentioned the AMA's success in influencing policy changes to reduce these burdens. The AMA collaborates with state and specialty societies, providing critical support through grants and shared knowledge to combat scope of practice expansions by non-physicians. Dr. Scott and Dr. Bobby Mukkamala, AMA Board of Trustees Member, stress the importance of organized medicine in ensuring physicians' voices are heard and advocate for greater physician involvement in the AMA to strengthen their collective impact.

title: AI can highlight important data to enhance patient safety
summary: Dr. Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, an anesthesiology professor at the Medical College of Wisconsin and AMA president, highlighted the role of AI in enhancing patient safety by surfacing critical information buried in patient records. Through a personal story, Ehrenfeld demonstrated how AI can improve treatment outcomes by making important data more accessible to healthcare providers.

title: AMA leader: Physicians must be the lodestar for IT innovation
summary: Dr. Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, president of the American Medical Association, emphasizes the critical role of physicians in driving IT innovation in healthcare. He highlights that technology usability issues significantly contribute to clinician burnout. To address this, Ehrenfeld advocates for the active involvement of clinicians in the development and deployment of healthcare tools to ensure they align with real-world workflows and enhance efficiency. This approach aims to reduce burnout and improve the overall effectiveness of healthcare technology.

title: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH: 5-step solution to address physician shortage
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, the AMA President, addressed the physician shortage crisis in the U.S. during a National Press Club speech on Oct. 25, 2023. He highlighted the severe impact on doctors, patients, and the healthcare system, emphasizing that 83 million Americans lack adequate access to primary care. Ehrenfeld proposed a five-step solution: 1) Financial support for doctors via the Strengthening Medicare for Patients and Providers Act, 2) Reducing administrative burdens like prior authorization, 3) Expanding residency training and support for foreign-trained physicians, 4) Preventing the criminalization of evidence-based healthcare, and 5) Supporting physicians' mental health without penalization. These steps aim to retain current physicians and bolster the workforce to address the urgent shortage crisis.

title: 'Humbling, Exhausting, Exhilarating': The Life of AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld
summary: Jesse Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), describes his tenure as "humbling, exhausting, and exhilarating." In his 8 months as president, Ehrenfeld has found meaningful experiences in unexpected places, such as giving a lecture in Gainesville, Georgia, and speaking at a historic medical society in Greensboro, North Carolina. Despite the rewarding moments, Ehrenfeld faces frustrations with congressional inefficiency, particularly regarding healthcare legislation and workforce development. He emphasizes the need for innovative approaches to healthcare delivery and expresses concerns about the potential harm from embedded AI systems in medical devices. Balancing his professional duties with family life, Ehrenfeld credits his husband for managing their home life and stresses the importance of his work for the future healthcare system.

title: AMA on HHS response to Change Healthcare cyber incident
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, President of the American Medical Association (AMA), commended the Department of Health and Human Services and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services for their prompt response to the Change Healthcare cyber security incident, which caused significant disruptions to medical practices and patient care access. Ehrenfeld highlighted the importance of the newly announced flexibilities but emphasized the need for further support, particularly financial assistance such as advanced payments, to help physicians facing financial difficulties. He expressed concern about the impact on small, rural, and underserved practices, urging federal officials to implement additional measures to ensure the viability of these medical practices.

title: AMA president on the future of AI tools in clinical settings
summary: At the 2024 SXSW conference, Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, M.D., president of the American Medical Association, moderated a panel on the future of AI in clinical settings. The panel addressed the challenges and potential of AI tools in healthcare, emphasizing the importance of safety, quality, and patient privacy. Ehrenfeld highlighted misleading claims by some companies about HIPAA compliance and stressed the need for transparency with patients regarding data usage. He also discussed the difficulties in maintaining AI tools over time and the necessity for ongoing monitoring to ensure their efficacy. Ehrenfeld suggested that creating unbiased data repositories could help benchmark AI tools effectively. He acknowledged the excitement around AI among patients and clinicians but cautioned against the risks of unmonitored AI systems. The discussion underscored the need for collaboration, regulatory frameworks, and best practices to integrate AI safely and effectively into healthcare.

title: Harvard Medical School Affiliates Protest American Medical Association President on Match Day | News
summary: Dozens of Longwood affiliates protested American Medical Association President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld’s speech at Harvard Medical School on Match Day. The protest, organized by groups including Boston Healthcare Workers for Palestine, criticized the AMA’s lack of response to the Gaza conflict, despite its usual advocacy for healthcare workers overseas. HMS assistant professor Hibah Osman highlighted the AMA’s silence despite the deaths of many medical professionals in Gaza. Ehrenfeld acknowledged the silent protest during his lecture, which was part of the Class of 1958 Commemorative Lectureship. HMS Dean George Q. Daley had previously issued guidelines for protests, warning of potential disciplinary actions. Osman condemned threats of professional consequences for protesting students. Grant P. Laster emphasized the protest’s significance on Match Day, a pivotal moment for graduating medical students transitioning to their careers.

title: Broader Digital Health Trends
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPh, FAMIA, FASA, FCPP, president of the American Medical Association (AMA), discussed broader digital health trends at the 2023 AIMed Global Summit. He emphasized the importance of physician involvement in technology development to ensure tools meet clinical needs and improve patient care. Ehrenfeld, an anesthesiologist, highlighted the critical need for better tools and data integration in electronic health records (EHRs). He also addressed the potential and risks of AI in healthcare, advocating for standards and ethical principles to manage these technologies. Ehrenfeld's contributions include influencing AI development, ensuring diverse patient data in AI training, and promoting augmented intelligence with humans at the center of patient care. He stressed the need for transparency, regulatory guidance, and trust in digital health tools to enhance health outcomes and address disparities.

title: AMA: Some AI Use in Medicine Should Require Docs' Consent
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) has released principles for the use of artificial intelligence (AI) in medicine, emphasizing the need for physician consent for certain applications. AMA President Jesse M. Ehrenfeld highlighted AI's potential to enhance diagnostics and patient care but stressed the importance of ethical oversight and risk management. The AMA advocates for AI to simplify administrative tasks and reduce paperwork but warns of potential access barriers and increased liability for physicians. Transparency in AI systems used by insurers is crucial, as these can rapidly deny care without human review. The AMA calls for regular audits to prevent increased claim denials and coverage limitations. Data privacy remains a concern, with AI's "black box" nature potentially revealing confidential patient information. The AMA also pointed out the current gaps in US government oversight of AI in medicine and called for the physician community's involvement in policy development to guide AI adoption.

title: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, address at the 2023 Interim Meeting of the HOD
summary: Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, addressed the 2023 Interim Meeting of the AMA House of Delegates, emphasizing the critical state of the healthcare system and the need for Medicare payment reform. He highlighted the detrimental impact of the broken Medicare physician pay system on both physicians and patients, sharing personal stories to illustrate the pressures faced by medical professionals. Ehrenfeld called for unified advocacy efforts to push for legislative changes, particularly to halt planned Medicare cuts and support the Strengthening Medicare for Patients and Providers Act. He also discussed the AMA's broader advocacy work, including combating inappropriate scope of practice expansions and reducing physician burnout through the Joy in Medicine program. Ehrenfeld urged delegates to actively engage in these efforts, stressing that meaningful change must come from within the medical community.

title: The physician shortage is here: AMA implores Congress to address 'urgent crisis'
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) President, Jesse M. Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, has called on Congress to address the critical shortage of radiologists and other physicians affecting the U.S. healthcare system. In his address at the National Press Club, Ehrenfeld highlighted the significant challenges faced by physicians, including administrative burdens, burnout, attacks on science, and a flawed Medicare payment system. Ehrenfeld, who assumed the AMA leadership in June, proposed five solutions: reforming Medicare payments, reducing administrative burdens, expanding residency training, ending the criminalization of healthcare, and protecting physicians' mental health. He emphasized the urgency of these issues, noting bipartisan support for pending bills in Congress. Ehrenfeld stressed the importance of immediate action to ensure a robust physician workforce capable of meeting the nation's healthcare needs.

title: ChatGPT, AI in health care and the future of medicine with AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH
summary: The AMA Update video features AMA President Jesse Ehrenfeld, MD, MPH, discussing the impact of generative AI, like ChatGPT, on health care. Ehrenfeld emphasizes that while AI can assist with administrative tasks and alleviate physician burdens, it is not yet capable of diagnosing or treating diseases independently. He highlights the importance of AI as a supportive tool rather than a replacement for clinical judgment. Regulatory uncertainties and liability concerns are major barriers to AI adoption. Ehrenfeld advocates for AI to be used primarily to reduce administrative burdens and restore the patient-physician relationship. He also stresses the need for physicians to engage in discussions about data accuracy, health equity, privacy, and liability to ensure AI tools are safe and effective.

title: Bruce A. Scott, MD, wins office of AMA president-elect
summary: Bruce A. Scott, MD, an otolaryngologist from Kentucky, was elected president-elect of the American Medical Association (AMA) at the 2023 Annual Meeting. Dr. Scott will assume the role of AMA president in June 2024. He expressed his commitment to advocating for the AMA Recovery Plan for America’s Physicians, addressing physician burnout, prior authorizations, and Medicare system sustainability. Dr. Scott has been a prominent leader in medicine, serving in the AMA House of Delegates for over 25 years, and has held various positions including speaker and vice speaker. He is also involved in Health2047, the AMA’s innovation subsidiary, and has been active in state and county medical associations, focusing on access to care, public health, and reducing administrative burdens.

title: American Medical Association picks Kentucky doctor as its future president
summary: Dr. Bruce A. Scott, an otolaryngologist from Louisville, Kentucky, has been elected as the American Medical Association's (AMA) president-elect. Scott will serve a three-year term, starting as president-elect, then as president in June 2024, and finally as immediate past president. His role includes being a primary spokesperson for the AMA, which represents over 270,000 doctors and medical students. Scott's election is significant for Kentucky, highlighting the state's challenges and his commitment to addressing issues such as physician burnout, Medicare pay, and insurance barriers. He emphasizes the importance of the physician-patient relationship and opposes government interference in medical decisions.

title: Medicare payment reform: The fight to fix Medicare now with Bruce Scott, MD
summary: The American Medical Association (AMA) is prioritizing Medicare payment reform, emphasizing its urgency due to the substantial financial strain on medical practices. Bruce Scott, MD, AMA President-elect, highlights that Medicare physician payments have only increased by 9% over 22 years, while practice costs have surged by 47%. This disparity has led to a 26% decrease in real terms. Scott discusses the introduction of HR 2474, which aims to tie Medicare payments to inflation, and urges physicians and patients to support it via fixmedicarenow.org. He also underscores the administrative burdens physicians face, which consume significant time and resources. Scott's personal experience in a private practice illustrates the broader challenges, including inadequate reimbursements and high operational costs, stressing the need for reform to ensure continued access to quality care.

title: Dr Miriam J. Atkins: Each One of Us Needs Everyone Else
summary: Dr. Miriam J. Atkins, president of the Community Oncology Alliance and practicing partner at AO Multispecialty Clinic, emphasizes the significant challenges in oncology, particularly the shortages of physicians and nurses. She notes that inadequate guidance for healthcare professionals on job offers exacerbates the issue. Additionally, Dr. Atkins highlights the difficulties in improving minority enrollment in clinical trials due to stringent inclusion/exclusion criteria that often exclude real-world patients with multiple health issues. She advocates for maintaining community practices to build trust with patients, especially in rural areas, as a potential solution to these challenges.

title: COA's Dr Miriam Atkins: PBMs, HR 5526, and Marketplace Strategy
summary: Dr. Miriam J. Atkins, president of the Community Oncology Alliance (COA), addresses the challenges posed by pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) on healthcare costs and the impact of CMS decisions on oncologists and their patients. She testified before the Committee on Oversight and Accountability in May 2023, highlighting the daily struggles with insurance companies and PBMs over patient treatment plans, describing it as "PBM Hell." Atkins advocates for lawmakers to listen to physicians regarding patient care and criticizes insurance companies for prioritizing data over patient well-being. She also discusses HR 5526, which aims to overturn CMS's decision preventing doctors from mailing medications directly to patients, emphasizing the importance of mail-order delivery for cancer patients. As COA president, Atkins leverages her role to raise awareness about PBMs' actions and promote patient advocacy.

title: COA's Dr Miriam Atkins: APMs Can't Be One Size Fits All
summary: Dr. Miriam Atkins, president of the Community Oncology Alliance (COA), emphasizes that alternative payment models (APMs) should not adopt a one-size-fits-all approach, as it is often unfair to community oncology practices. She highlights the challenges faced by these practices, such as additional staffing needs and inconsistent reimbursement criteria under models like the Oncology Care Model (OCM) and the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM). Atkins notes that varying state regulations and practice differences necessitate tailored payment models to ensure fair reimbursement and sustainability for community oncology care. Her leadership aims to address these disparities and foster innovation within the sector.

title: How the Change Healthcare cyberattack is straining providers, and what the government can do
summary: The Change Healthcare cyberattack has severely disrupted healthcare delivery, particularly affecting oncology providers and rural areas. Ted Okon, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance, highlighted the financial and operational strain on providers due to delayed claims processing and manual billing. Patients are experiencing treatment delays, especially for expensive oncology drugs requiring prior authorization. Okon emphasized the need for government intervention to expedite payment processes and provide financial relief, likening the crisis to the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic. He criticized United Health's minimal financial assistance and called for more substantial support from CMS. The attack underscores the vulnerability of the healthcare system to cyber threats and the detrimental impact of industry consolidation.

title: Ted Okon: Pressure Is Mounting on PBMs
summary: Ted Okon, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance, highlighted the increasing pressure on pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) due to their practices driving up drug prices. State-level regulations are now influencing federal actions, with bipartisan support in Congress for reform. Okon noted that the Rutledge v PCMA case in 2020 was pivotal in challenging the practice of white bagging, where PBMs mandate patients to receive drugs from their affiliated pharmacies, often delaying care. He emphasized that this year could be crucial for passing legislation to regulate PBMs, with multiple bills currently under consideration in Congress.

title: Facility type linked to 'significant differences' in survival for head/neck cancer
summary: A study published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute found that the type of facility where head and neck cancer patients receive treatment significantly impacts survival outcomes. Specifically, patients treated at community cancer centers, which have seen a 10% increase in patient care from 2010 to 2019, showed poorer survival rates compared to those treated at academic cancer centers. This trend is particularly evident among patients receiving nonsurgical treatments. Ted Okon of the Community Oncology Alliance criticized the study, arguing that it misleadingly compares hospital-based academic and community centers without considering independent, physician-run oncology clinics that provide accessible and affordable care. He contended that the study's flawed reporting could cause unnecessary fear and confusion among patients.

title: Innovating Community Oncology Care Delivery and Payment Reform: Insights From COA's Ted Okon
summary: Ted Okon, MBA, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance (COA), discusses early feedback from the Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM) and ongoing innovations in community oncology practices. Despite some initial disappointments with EOM participation, Okon emphasizes the necessity for practices to innovate in payment reform and care delivery. He highlights that the Oncology Care Model (OCM) has significantly impacted cancer care and payment systems, prompting practices to explore various models like population health and the Oncology Medical Home. Okon believes these innovations not only improve patient outcomes but also reduce hospital and emergency room visits, suggesting that such strategies could be applied to other areas of medicine.

title: The harsh economic reality of cancer drug shortages
summary: Ted Okon highlights the severe cancer drug shortages in the U.S., affecting treatments for various cancers. He attributes these shortages to a broken drug supply market exacerbated by government policies. Okon explains that low-cost generic injectable drugs are heavily regulated and subject to mandatory discounts and rebates, making production unprofitable for manufacturers. This has led to underinvestment in manufacturing facilities and increased reliance on offshore production. Okon has testified to Congress multiple times, emphasizing the need to address the root economic causes of these shortages. He suggests that recent legislative proposals may offer hope for resolving the issue.

title: Cancer drug shortages decried in congressional hearing • Ohio Capital Journal
summary: Experts testified before a U.S. House subcommittee about the acute shortage of injectable cancer drugs, attributing it to financial unviability for manufacturers. The hearing highlighted the need for broader drug supply chain reforms. Political discord within the House GOP Caucus threatens legislative action. Ted Okon, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance, emphasized the severity of the crisis, noting that shortages of essential drugs like carboplatin and cisplatin lead to treatment delays and inferior care, potentially costing lives. Okon criticized current solutions as inadequate, stressing that the root cause is financial and urging Congress to address this and boost domestic manufacturing.

title: What happens when the COVID public health emergency ends
summary: The end of the COVID public health emergency on Thursday will bring significant changes to healthcare access and costs. Free COVID tests and treatments will largely cease, with Medicare beneficiaries losing access to free over-the-counter tests, while Medicaid users retain coverage until September 2024. Telehealth flexibilities will reduce, including the end of using apps like Apple FaceTime for Medicare-covered services and restrictions on prescribing controlled substances via telemedicine. Financial impacts include the loss of a 20% pay bump for inpatient COVID-19 patients and limitations on telehealth usage in hospitals. Ted Okon, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance, highlighted the end of a waiver to the Stark Law, affecting the delivery of specialty cancer drugs, which is crucial for patients in rural or urban areas with transportation challenges. Despite efforts, Okon noted a lack of assurance from CMS on this issue.

title: As Cancer Drug Shortages Increase, Patients' Lives Are at Stake
summary: Cancer drug shortages in the US are causing treatment delays, inferior treatments, and stoppages, endangering patients' lives. Ted Okon, executive director of the Community Oncology Alliance, testified before a House subcommittee, emphasizing the severity of the crisis and the need for long-term solutions. He attributed the shortages to financial challenges faced by generic drug manufacturers, exacerbated by Medicare's Part B drug reimbursement system and other pricing regulations. Okon called for legislative changes to remove price caps, discounts, and rebates to ensure profitability and encourage manufacturing. He warned that without these changes, shortages will worsen, potentially signing a death sentence for some patients.

title: Federal program forces drug companies to fund hospital profits
