It mandates two-sided risk, where participants can earn performance-based payments but also face financial recoupments if savings targets are not met. Barry Russo, CEO of The Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders in Fort Worth, shared insights from his practice's participation in OCM, highlighting the importance of coordination of care and the complexities involved. His practice is analyzing data to determine the feasibility of participating in EOM, emphasizing the need for actuarial support and potential stop-loss insurance to mitigate risks.

title: Even Oncologists Sold on Value-Based Care Hesitate to Embrace the EOM
summary: At the ACCC 2023 Annual Meeting, oncologists discussed the challenges and hesitations surrounding the upcoming Enhancing Oncology Model (EOM), a value-based care initiative. The panel, which included members of the ACCC Alternative Payment Coalition and representatives from the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI), reflected on lessons from the previous Oncology Care Model (OCM). Barry Russo, CEO of The Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, highlighted the differences between OCM and EOM, particularly the reduced Monthly Enhanced Oncology Services (MEOS) payments, which could impact the ability to maintain value-based practices. Russo suggested pooling with other practices as a potential solution to manage risks under the new model. Overall, while the EOM aims to improve patient care and reduce costs, oncologists expressed concerns about its implementation and financial implications.

title: PatientPoint, Community Oncology Leaders Team Up on Next-Gen Engagement Platform to Improve Care Quality ...
summary: PatientPoint has collaborated with over 20 leaders in community oncology to develop a next-generation patient engagement platform aimed at improving care quality, practice efficiencies, and clinical outcomes. The PatientPoint Oncology Advisory Board, consisting of medical oncologists and practice executives, focuses on enhancing the platform's features to address value-based care, changing reimbursement models, and administrative burdens. The board aims to improve health equity, increase screenings, deliver survivorship care plans, and enable advance care planning. Barry Russo, from The Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders in Fort Worth, TX, is among the notable members contributing to this initiative.

title: End of OCM Brings Drop-Off in Value-Based Care Volume, and New Questions
summary: The end of the Oncology Care Model (OCM) has led to a significant drop in value-based care volume, raising questions about equitable care delivery amid changing financial incentives. At the Community Oncology Alliance conference, Stephen "Fred" Divers, MD, led a panel discussing these impacts. Barry Russo, CEO of the Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, estimated a shift from 70% to 30% in practice volume under value-based care since OCM ended. Russo highlighted the growing importance of relationships with primary care providers for continuity of care and cost management. He also noted challenges with timely data exchange and the need for comprehensive, collaborative care networks to support patients effectively. The panel discussed the economic shifts and the necessity of balancing patient care with financial sustainability.

title: Confronting the Dynamics of Medicare Benefits When Those Eligible Are Still Working
summary: At the Community Oncology Alliance Payer Exchange Summit, experts discussed the increasing trend of Medicare-eligible patients who remain employed and covered by commercial insurance, creating new challenges for employers and benefits administrators. Barry Russo, CEO of the Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, highlighted that over a quarter of Medicare beneficiaries have employer-based coverage, with many enrolled in Medicare Advantage (MA) plans. Russo noted that MA plans present challenges but are growing rapidly, accounting for 60% of his practice's volume. He emphasized the need for oncology practices to proactively navigate MA plans and value-based programs to manage costs and care effectively.

title: Oregon Oncology Specialists and House Rx Partner to Speed Access and Delivery of Life-Saving Cancer Medications
summary: Oregon Oncology Specialists and House Rx have partnered to expedite the delivery of cancer medications using House Rx's medically integrated dispensing (MID) model. This partnership aims to reduce delays in treatment, improve medication adherence, and provide financial assistance to patients. The MID model combines services and technology to streamline prescription filling, benefits investigation, prior authorization, and medication counseling. Erin Wylam, CEO of Oregon Oncology Specialists, emphasized that the partnership will enhance patient care by reducing delays, managing medication side effects, and addressing financial concerns. House Rx's network includes over 200 providers across multiple states, focusing on making specialty medications more accessible and affordable.

title: Prevent Blindness President and CEO gives insight into the Gr8 Eye Movement campaign
summary: Jeff Todd, President and CEO of Prevent Blindness, discusses the Gr8 Eye Movement campaign, aimed at raising awareness about retinal diseases. The campaign, in collaboration with Regeneron and actress Debbie Allen, designates the eighth of every month as a reminder for people to prioritize their eye health. Todd emphasizes the importance of educating those at risk, including the elderly, communities of color, and individuals with diabetes. He highlights the lack of knowledge among at-risk adults, with a survey revealing that 95% are unaware of retinal diseases. The campaign seeks to shift consumer awareness and encourage action towards regular eye check-ups. Todd also mentions the role of ophthalmologists in promoting the campaign and directing patients to resources. Success will be measured by increased awareness and consumer engagement.

title: Prevent Blindness President and CEO Jeff Todd to Lead 2024 National Health Council Board of Directors
summary: Jeff Todd, president and CEO of Prevent Blindness, has been appointed as the chair of the National Health Council (NHC) board of directors for 2024. The announcement was made during the NHC's annual membership meeting. Todd's leadership is expected to be instrumental in navigating the complex political, societal, and technological changes affecting patient communities. Randall Rutta, NHC’s CEO, praised Todd’s experience and commitment to advancing equitable access to health care. Other key members of the Executive Committee include Schroeder Stribling, Michael Osso, Sue Peschin, Harold Wimmer, and Kenny Mendez. Additionally, seven new members have joined the 2024 NHC board, including leaders from the American Diabetes Association, Huntington’s Disease Society of America, and Amazon Health Services, among others. These new members will work alongside current board members who have been reelected for new three-year terms.

title: Young people struggle with mental health — is talk enough?
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic led to a 25% increase in anxiety, depression, and suicidal thoughts, particularly among young people and women, according to the World Health Organization. Mental Health America, a nonprofit focused on mental wellness, analyzed data from 6.3 million Americans who took a mental health screening in 2022. Schroeder Stribling, president and CEO of Mental Health America, highlighted that nearly half of the youth who screened for depression reported frequent suicidal thoughts. Despite advancements in mental health awareness, access to resources remains limited due to issues like insurance coverage and crisis intervention difficulties. Stribling emphasized the need for better access to mental health resources to address the ongoing struggles faced by young people.

title: Walgreens expands commitment to improving mental health, well-being
summary: Walgreens is expanding its commitment to mental health and well-being by collaborating with Mental Health America (MHA) to address youth mental health through the Back-to-School campaign. This initiative will provide free screening tools and educational materials to schools nationwide, reaching over 15 million people last year. Schroeder Stribling, President and CEO of MHA, emphasized the importance of supporting youth in crisis and praised Walgreens for its ongoing support. Walgreens is also enhancing its workplace mental health programs, receiving MHA’s Bell Seal for Workplace Mental Health, and expanding its Be Well Connected program for employees and their families. The company is focusing on health equity through a pilot program in underserved communities, where pharmacists support patients with mental health conditions.

title: Walgreens And Mental Health America Partner To Address Mental Health Issues In U.S. Schools
summary: Walgreens and Mental Health America (MHA) have partnered to launch a back-to-school campaign aimed at addressing youth mental health issues. They created a toolkit to help parents, teachers, and students promote healthy practices and navigate social media's impact on mental health. This initiative comes in response to alarming data from the CDC showing high levels of sadness and suicidal thoughts among teens. Holly May of Walgreens emphasized the importance of balancing social media use to uplift students. Schroeder Stribling, President and CEO of MHA, highlighted the toolkit's potential to harness social media benefits while mitigating risks, offering resources for caregivers and educators to support youth mental health. The toolkit has received significant engagement, with over 28,000 views and 10,000 downloads, and provides webinars, screening information, and educational content to help students with mental health issues.

title: Hollywood & Mind Summit Sets Speakers, Including Charlamagne Tha God, Master P
summary: The inaugural Hollywood & Mind Summit, scheduled for May 11, will feature speakers such as Charlamagne Tha God, Christina Wootton, Vicky Cornell, and Percy "Master P" Miller. This event aims to leverage the entertainment industry's influence to elevate mental health awareness, break stigma, and save lives. The summit will include discussions on mental health storytelling, the power of music, and the role of technology and gaming in promoting mental wellness. Key participants also include Dr. Brook Bello, Devi Brown, Dr. Ken Duckworth, Valerie June, Phil Schermer, Schroeder Stribling (President and CEO of Mental Health America), David E. Tolchinsky, Carmela Wallace, and Zak Williams. Schroeder Stribling's contribution as President and CEO of Mental Health America will be crucial in these discussions. The event will culminate with a launch party featuring networking opportunities and a Mindfulness Wall.

title: Opinion: The UnitedHealthcare-Mount Sinai Contract Dispute Must be Resolved
summary: The contract dispute between UnitedHealthcare (UHC) and Mount Sinai Health System threatens the healthcare coverage of 1.3 million New Yorkers. If unresolved by March 1, patients, including those with chronic conditions like Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), could lose access to their in-network healthcare providers at Mount Sinai. Michael Osso, CEO of the Crohn’s & Colitis Foundation, emphasizes the severe impact on patients who rely on specialized care, urging both parties to prioritize patient needs and reach an agreement. Osso highlights that disruptions in care can lead to dangerous health complications and increased stress for patients. He calls for a patient-centered approach to healthcare negotiations to ensure continuity of care and alleviate patient uncertainty.

title: Celltrion partners with the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation to enhance IBD awareness in US
summary: Celltrion has partnered with the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation (CCF) to enhance awareness and improve perceptions of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) in the U.S. The CCF, established in 1967, has been pivotal in supporting IBD patients through clinical trials, educational programs, and advocacy. This collaboration aims to boost Celltrion's influence in the American IBD sector, following the approval of Zymfentra, a subcutaneous form of infliximab, in the U.S. last year. Celltrion has initiated several activities, including training programs for gastroenterology fellows and CCF staff on Zymfentra. Michael Osso, CCF President and CEO, expressed optimism about the partnership, anticipating new treatment options for IBD patients in the U.S. Celltrion's efforts were recognized at the Crohn’s & Colitis Congress, where the company received the Lucky Seven Alliance Award for its contributions to IBD patient health.

title: Prevent Blindness President and CEO Jeff Todd to Lead 2024 National Health Council Board of Directors
summary: Jeff Todd, President and CEO of Prevent Blindness, has been appointed as the chair of the National Health Council (NHC) board of directors for 2024. The election took place during the NHC's annual membership meeting. Other key officers include Schroeder Stribling as chair-elect, Michael Osso as vice chair, Sue Peschin as secretary, Harold Wimmer as treasurer, and Kenny Mendez as immediate past chair. Michael Osso, President and CEO of the Crohn’s & Colitis Foundation, will serve as vice chair. Randall Rutta, NHC’s CEO, praised Todd for his experience and dedication to equitable healthcare access. Seven new members were also added to the board, including leaders from various health organizations. The new members join current board members who were reelected for new terms.

title: FDA Approves Mirikizumab for Ulcerative Colitis
summary: The FDA has approved mirikizumab (Omvoh, Eli Lilly) for the treatment of moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis (UC) in adults. Mirikizumab is the first IL-23 inhibitor approved in the U.S. for UC, targeting the p19 subunit of IL-23, crucial in UC-related inflammation. It is administered intravenously and aims to alleviate symptoms such as stool frequency, rectal bleeding, and bowel urgency. The approval followed successful phase 3 LUCENT-1 and LUCENT-2 trials, which demonstrated sustained clinical remission and improved bowel urgency in patients. Michael Osso, president and CEO of the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, highlighted that mirikizumab offers new hope for those who have not responded to other therapies, addressing disruptive symptoms like bowel urgency. Common adverse reactions include upper respiratory infections, injection site reactions, and headaches. The drug label includes warnings about hypersensitivity, infection risks, tuberculosis, hepatotoxicity, and immunizations.

title: ZYMFENTRA™(infliximab-dyyb), the first and only FDA-approved subcutaneous infliximab, now commercially available ...
summary: ZYMFENTRA™ (infliximab-dyyb) is the first FDA-approved subcutaneous formulation of infliximab for treating moderately to severely active ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, now available in the U.S. It offers a convenient treatment option for maintenance therapy following initial intravenous infliximab treatment. Approved based on phase III studies (LIBERTY-UC and LIBERTY-CD), ZYMFENTRA demonstrated superior clinical remission and endoscopic response compared to placebo. Michael Osso, President and CEO of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation, emphasized the significance of this advancement, highlighting the increased flexibility and choice it provides to patients. The medication will be under patent protection until 2040.

title: Cyltezo®, first and only FDA-approved Interchangeable biosimilar to Humira®, now commercially available in the U.S.
summary: Cyltezo® (adalimumab-adbm), the first and only FDA-approved interchangeable biosimilar to Humira®, is now available in the U.S., expanding treatment options for patients with chronic inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, plaque psoriasis, and Crohn's disease. Initially approved as a biosimilar in 2017, Cyltezo received its interchangeable designation in 2021. The drug is available in prefilled syringes and autoinjectors. Michael Osso, President and CEO of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation, highlighted the potential benefits of adalimumab biosimilars like Cyltezo in improving patient care for inflammatory conditions. Boehringer Ingelheim emphasizes Cyltezo's role in providing more affordable and accessible treatments, supported by Phase III trials demonstrating its safety and efficacy comparable to Humira.

title: Should Federal Funding for Medical Research Be Used to Ration Access to Alzheimer's Drugs?
summary: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) has significantly increased its funding for Alzheimer's research, reaching $3.5 billion in 2023, leading to advancements like the FDA-approved drug lecanemab. However, concerns arise over whether federal funding should be used to ration access to such drugs through Medicare's restrictive "coverage with evidence development" (CED) policy. Sue Peschin, president and CEO of the Alliance for Aging Research, highlights the potential misuse of the National Institute on Aging's (NIA) real-world data (RWD) platform as a tool for rationing patient access. Peschin advocates for separating the NIA's research efforts from CMS's utilization management to ensure broader access to Alzheimer's treatments.

title: CMS must allow nursing homes to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms of Alzheimer's
summary: Sue Peschin, President & CEO of the Alliance for Aging Research, alongside Chad Worz, Executive Director of the American Society of Consultant Pharmacists, advocates for policy changes to allow nursing homes to treat neuropsychiatric symptoms of Alzheimer’s without penalties. They highlight the significant challenges posed by symptoms like agitation, which affect nearly all Alzheimer’s patients, leading to increased institutionalization and caregiving burdens. Despite available FDA-approved treatments, CMS policies penalize nursing homes for their use, resulting in inadequate care. Peschin and Worz urge CMS to update these policies to reflect appropriate medical use, ensuring patients and providers can access necessary treatments without stigma or barriers. They also call for additional resources for long-term care facilities to better support the growing aging population.

title: Experts, Lawmakers Explore Downside of Drug-Price Negotiation
summary: A panel discussion hosted by The Hill and sponsored by the Alliance for Aging Research examined the potential downsides of Medicare's drug-price negotiation program under the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). Concerns were raised about the program's impact on access to medications for vulnerable patients and the potential stifling of pharmaceutical innovation. Sue Peschin, president & CEO of the Alliance for Aging Research, highlighted that the IRA's restructuring of Medicare Part D could lead insurers to employ utilization management techniques, such as prior authorization, which might restrict access to essential drugs, particularly affecting minority patients. The program, which includes capping insulin costs and negotiating prices for costly medications, could inadvertently harm patients if access is significantly restricted. Critics also questioned the fairness of the negotiation process and its implications for future drug development.

title: American Lung Association Celebrates 120 Years of Impact: A Legacy of Advancing Lung Health and Saving Lives
summary: The American Lung Association, founded in 1904 by Dr. Edward Livingston Trudeau, has been advancing lung health and saving lives for 120 years. Initially established to combat tuberculosis, the organization now focuses on defeating lung cancer, creating a tobacco-free future, championing clean air, and improving the quality of life for those with lung disease. Significant achievements include reducing the U.S. smoking rate, making domestic flights smoke-free, and funding life-saving research. Harold Wimmer, the current President and CEO, highlights the Association's ongoing efforts to address current and future lung health threats such as wildfires, climate change, vaping, and COVID-19.

title: Six Former U.S. Surgeons General Unite To Call For Healthier Buildings
summary: Six former U.S. surgeons general have urged policymakers to prioritize healthier buildings, emphasizing the overlooked impact of the built environment on health and wellbeing. Organized by the International WELL Building Institute, their open letter highlights the benefits of improving indoor air quality and ventilation, which could yield significant economic and cognitive benefits. Dr. Richard Carmona, the 17th surgeon general, stressed the importance of educating the public and policymakers about the need for health-driven building policies. Harold Wimmer, president and CEO of the American Lung Association, highlighted the risks of poor indoor air quality, particularly for vulnerable groups like children and older adults, and expressed eagerness to collaborate with policymakers to enhance public health.

title: FDA delays menthol ban following lobbying war
summary: The FDA has delayed rules banning menthol cigarettes and flavored cigars, shifting the implementation date from August to March 2024. This delay follows intense lobbying and is seen as a strategic move amid the political climate leading up to the 2024 presidential election. The decision is a significant win for the tobacco industry, which is transitioning to vaping products as traditional cigarette use declines. Public health advocates, including Harold Wimmer, President and CEO of the American Lung Association, criticized the delay, accusing the administration of yielding to tobacco industry pressure. Wimmer emphasized that delaying these rules would lead to more deaths and diseases from tobacco use. The menthol ban is particularly contentious due to its popularity among Black and underage smokers. The FDA initially proposed the ban in April 2022, and the issue has divided Congress and sparked legal battles, notably involving R.J. Reynolds in California.

title: American Lung Association Blasts Biden for Inaction on Menthol Cigarette Ban
summary: The American Lung Association criticizes President Joe Biden for delaying the ban on menthol cigarettes and flavored cigars until March. The ALA’s report highlights the importance of finalizing these rules to save lives. Harold Wimmer, president of the ALA, said menthol cigarettes make it easier to start smoking and harder to quit, and their ban would reduce smoking rates and save lives. The proposed ban, announced in April 2022, faced opposition from some civil rights leaders. However, the FDA clarified that enforcement would focus on manufacturers and sellers, not individual consumers. The NAACP and the Congressional Black Caucus support the ban, citing its potential to save Black lives. The ALA urges Biden to finalize the ban and take more actions to combat tobacco use.

title: New American Lung Association Research Institute to Accelerate High Impact, Lifesaving Lung Health Science
summary: The American Lung Association has launched the American Lung Association Research Institute to tackle critical lung health challenges. With over 34 million Americans affected by lung disease, including lung cancer and respiratory illnesses like COVID-19, the institute aims to accelerate lifesaving research. Harold Wimmer, President and CEO of the American Lung Association, emphasized the urgency of addressing lung disease and the institute's commitment to research, collaboration, and innovation. The institute plans to increase research investment to $25 million annually by 2030, expand clinical research in asthma and COPD, convene scientists for collaborative efforts, and partner with government, non-profits, and private industry to accelerate discoveries. The initiative is overseen by a Scientific Advisory Committee comprising top experts in lung health.

title: Almost one-third of Americans live with unhealthy air
summary: Nearly one-third of Americans, or 120 million people, live in areas with unhealthy air quality, according to the American Lung Association's "State of the Air" report. Despite overall improvements in air quality, significant disparities exist between Eastern and Western states and among different racial groups. Harold Wimmer, the national president and CEO of the association, highlighted the progress due to the Clean Air Act but emphasized the ongoing challenges, noting that 120 million people still live in areas with unhealthy pollution levels. The report, covering 2019 to 2021, revealed that people of color are disproportionately affected, with Black Americans and other minorities more likely to live in highly polluted areas. The worst conditions are found in Western states, with significant health risks linked to fine particulate matter from sources like wildfires and coal-fired power plants. The association urges continued efforts to ensure clean air for all.

title: How to prepare for spring allergy season | All Of It
summary: New Yorkers experienced record-breaking temperatures, signaling the start of spring and the accompanying allergy season. Experts Kenneth Mendez, CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, and allergist Dr. Neeta Ogden shared insights on preparing for allergies. Kenneth Mendez highlighted the impact of climate change in extending the allergy season and offered practical tips such as using air filters, keeping windows closed, and washing sheets regularly to reduce pollen exposure. He also emphasized the importance of understanding asthma triggers and seeking specialist advice. Dr. Ogden explained the immune response to pollen and recommended early preparation, including tracking pollen counts and starting medications before symptoms appear.

title: Interview: Dr. Purvi Parikh and Kenneth Mendez talk about asthma
summary: Dr. Purvi Parikh and Kenneth Mendez were interviewed about asthma. Kenneth Mendez, as the CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, highlighted the importance of awareness and education in managing asthma. He emphasized the need for better resources and support for asthma patients, advocating for policies that improve air quality and access to healthcare. Mendez's contribution is crucial in driving initiatives that aim to reduce the burden of asthma on individuals and communities. Dr. Purvi Parikh, an allergist and immunologist, discussed the medical aspects of asthma, including triggers and treatment options. The interview underscored the collaborative efforts needed between medical professionals and advocacy groups to enhance the quality of life for those affected by asthma.

title: Allergy season kicks into high gear across South due to February pollen | Latest Weather Clips
summary: Allergy season has intensified across the southern U.S. due to February pollen. Kenneth Mendez, President and CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, discussed the peak pollen season with FOX Weather.

title: These Are the Top 10 Worst Places in the U.S. for People With Allergies
summary: The Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America (AAFA) has released a report identifying the 10 worst U.S. cities for allergies, noting that the 2024 allergy season is starting earlier and may be more intense. Kenneth Mendez, president and CEO of AAFA, emphasizes the importance of preparing for allergy season in advance by starting treatments early. He suggests that lifestyle modifications and over-the-counter medications can help manage symptoms, particularly in high-pollen areas. Mendez also highlights that longer pollen seasons can exacerbate conditions like allergic asthma and oral allergy syndrome. He advises consulting with healthcare providers for personalized treatment plans, which may include immunotherapy. The report underscores the growing challenge of allergies in the U.S., affecting over 100 million Americans.

title: Price Caps on Asthma Inhalers a Big Win, But Barriers Remain
summary: Major pharmaceutical companies AstraZeneca, Boehringer Ingelheim, and GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) have announced price caps on asthma inhalers, limiting out-of-pocket costs to $35 per month for U.S. patients. This decision, praised by asthma advocacy groups, aims to alleviate the financial burden on patients who often ration or discontinue medication due to high costs. Kenneth Mendez, president and CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America (AAFA), highlighted that the high cost of inhalers is a primary barrier to treatment. The U.S. Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions (HELP) investigation, supported by AAFA, played a crucial role in prompting this action. Despite this progress, issues of availability and affordability of certain asthma medications persist.

title: Fall Allergies: What to Know About Causes, Symptoms and Care
summary: Fall allergies, caused by ragweed pollen and mold from decaying leaves, are worsening due to climate change. Kenneth Mendez, CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, notes higher carbon dioxide emissions increase pollen, worsening symptoms. Warmer temperatures extend the growing season for allergenic plants like ragweed, especially in urban areas. Allergies typically last longer and cause itchiness without fever, unlike colds and Covid. Managing allergies involves minimizing pollen exposure, using HEPA filters, and considering medications or immunotherapy. Mendez stresses the seriousness of allergies, noting their potential to trigger asthma, disproportionately affecting Black Americans.

title: Backward drug industry incentives are hurting asthma patients
summary: Kenneth Mendez highlights how the drug industry’s incentives are adversely impacting asthma patients. The shift from the branded inhaler Flovent to a cheaper generic by GlaxoSmithKline, aimed at avoiding Medicaid penalties, has ironically led to reduced insurance coverage for the generic, forcing patients to pay out-of-pocket. This situation underscores the complexity and dysfunction of the U.S. drug pricing system, where pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) and insurers prefer costlier drugs to maximize rebates, thus making essential medications less accessible. Mendez, as president and CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, calls for systemic reform to prioritize patient needs and ensure affordable access to life-saving medications.

title: Backward industry incentives are hurting asthma patients
summary: Kenneth Mendez, president and CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, highlights the adverse effects of backward industry incentives on asthma patients. A major drug manufacturer replaced its branded inhaler, Flovent, with a cheaper generic version. However, insurers have refused to cover the generic, forcing patients to pay out-of-pocket. This issue stems from the convoluted drug marketplace where pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) and insurers prioritize higher-priced medications to maximize rebates and discounts, neglecting patient affordability. This system disproportionately affects asthma patients, particularly children, leading to increased missed school and workdays. Legislative efforts are underway to address these perverse incentives, but comprehensive reform is needed to ensure patients receive essential medications.

title: What causes fall allergies? Here's how to alleviate symptoms
summary: Fall allergies, primarily caused by ragweed, affect about 1 in 4 adults over 18, according to the CDC. Kenneth Mendez, president and CEO of the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, explains that pollen triggers immune responses leading to allergies. The type of allergies can vary by region, with more moisture-prone areas experiencing higher mold allergies. Medical costs due to pollen allergies exceed $3 billion annually. To alleviate symptoms like itchy eyes and a runny nose, Dr. Mark Montano advises using nasal steroids and avoiding outdoor activities early in the morning when pollen counts are high. Mendez also recommends monitoring weather reports for air quality and pollen counts. Managing indoor air quality and staying updated on vaccinations for other illnesses with similar symptoms, such as the common cold, RSV, and the flu, is also suggested.

title: Millions of Texans have rare diseases. Advocates are pushing for legislation to help them.
summary: Millions of Texans suffer from rare diseases, prompting advocates to push for supportive legislation. The National Organization for Rare Diseases estimates that 10% of Americans have a rare condition. Jorey Berry, President and CEO of the Immune Deficiency Foundation, highlights the cumulative impact of these diseases and emphasizes the need for legislative support. Berry, along with Carol Ann Demaret, mother of David Vetter who had Severe Combined Immune Deficiency (SCID), met with Texas lawmakers to advocate for changes, including copay accumulator policies and the establishment of Rare Disease Advisory Councils. These measures aim to alleviate financial burdens and ensure better healthcare access for those with rare conditions. Berry underscores the importance of education and empathy, especially post-COVID, to garner support for these initiatives.

title: FDA approves Hyqvia for children with primary immunodeficiency
summary: The FDA has approved Hyqvia for children aged 2 to 16 with primary immunodeficiency. This subcutaneous immune globulin infusion can be administered every 3 to 4 weeks. Initially approved for adults in 2014, Hyqvia is unique in its less frequent dosing schedule. The approval is based on a phase 3 clinical trial involving 44 children, which showed no significant differences in IgG levels across age groups and a low rate of serious bacterial infections. Jorey Berry, president and CEO of the Immune Deficiency Foundation, highlighted the importance of having treatment options for families managing primary immunodeficiency.

title: Rare Disease Day: Reasons for Action
summary: Rare Disease Day aims to raise awareness and advocate for the needs of those affected by rare conditions. Leaders from various patient advocacy groups and CSL staff highlight the importance of recognizing and addressing rare diseases. Scott Santarella emphasizes the passion and dedication within the rare disease community. Jorey Berry, CEO of the Immune Deficiency Foundation, notes that rare diseases are more common than perceived, affecting one in ten people globally. Berry also points out that treatments for common conditions often originate from rare disease research. The collective message stresses the need for increased research funding, better patient support, and equitable access to treatment.

title: A Year of Progress for Patients
summary: In 2023, CSL highlighted significant advancements in patient advocacy and support for those with rare and serious diseases. Key initiatives included the LEAP program by Anthony Castaldo's HAE organizations, which trained young advocacy leaders, and Karen Pinachyan's advisory board for hemophilia patients. Jorey Berry, CEO of the Immune Deficiency Foundation, contributed notably by advocating for a new Texas law improving treatment access. Johan Prévot of IPOPI made strides in global primary immunodeficiency care, while Arran Strong promoted positivity through his travels and podcast. Additionally, Lisa Butler and Alain Baumann strengthened international collaborations for hemophilia and respiratory diseases.

title: Nancy Brown recognized as one of Modern Healthcare's 'Top Women Leaders'
summary: Nancy Brown, CEO of the American Heart Association (AHA), has been honored by Modern Healthcare as one of the Top Women Leaders for 2024. Brown's leadership has significantly advanced health, equity, and hope. Since becoming AHA's CEO in 2008, she has championed initiatives like "Go Red for Women®" and "Research Goes Red®," promoting women's health and leadership. Under her guidance, the AHA launched the "Nation of Lifesavers" CPR education movement and the "Health Care by Food" initiative, addressing nutrition's role in well-being. Brown's efforts have also focused on health equity, rural health, and food insecurity, contributing to the AHA's financial success, with revenue exceeding $1.2 billion in fiscal year 2022-23. Her visionary leadership has reinforced the AHA's position as a global health authority.

title: 2024 Women Leaders Nancy Brown
summary: Nancy Brown, CEO of the American Heart Association (AHA) since 2008, has significantly contributed to healthcare leadership. Following the cardiac arrest incident of football player Damar Hamlin in 2023, Brown spearheaded the “Nation of Lifesavers” initiative, promoting public education in CPR and automated external defibrillator use. Under her leadership, the AHA has also focused on elevating the presence of women scientists, achieving nearly 50% female representation among speakers and moderators at AHA conferences. Brown has been pivotal in developing programs aimed at enhancing gender representation in research and clinical trials.

title: Video | Nancy Brown on AHA's 100 years and beyond
summary: Nancy Brown, CEO of the American Heart Association (AHA), discusses the organization's Centennial Celebration in 2024 and its vision for the future. Under her leadership, the AHA continues to advance its mission of combating heart disease and stroke through innovative research, education, and community programs. Brown highlights the significance of the AHA's 100-year history in saving lives and improving cardiovascular health. She emphasizes the organization's commitment to building on its legacy and striving for greater impact in its second century. The video and additional resources are available for those interested in learning more about the AHA's achievements and future goals.

title: AHA CEO named one of Modern Healthcare's 2024 Top Women Leaders
summary: Nancy Brown, the CEO of the American Heart Association (AHA), has been recognized by Modern Healthcare as one of the 2024 Top Women Leaders in Healthcare. She is the first and only female CEO in AHA's 100-year history. The award honors women executives for their contributions to improving care delivery, health equity, and gender equity in healthcare leadership. Brown's leadership has led to significant achievements, including the launch of the Nation of Lifesavers CPR campaign and the Health Care by Food initiative. Under her guidance, the AHA surpassed $1.2 billion in revenue and heightened its focus on health equity and social determinants of health.

title: At the Heart of It with Nancy Brown
summary: "At the Heart of It with Nancy Brown," hosted by American Heart Association CEO Nancy Brown, delves into the personal journeys of notable individuals who have faced significant challenges and emerged stronger. Season 4 features intimate conversations with guests like Jennie Garth, Bob Harper, Laura Bell Bundy, Oscar Munoz, Dr. Mike, Michelle Miller, Micah Johnson, Murphy Jensen, and Damar Hamlin. Each episode explores their stories of resilience, health struggles, and advocacy, offering fresh perspectives on well-being and health. Nancy Brown's contribution lies in her ability to draw out these powerful narratives, helping listeners understand the intersection of personal experiences with broader health and humanity themes.

title: Rare Disease Day: Reasons for Action
summary: Rare Disease Day aims to unite patients with rare conditions and raise global awareness. Leaders from various advocacy groups, including Scott Santarella, Jorey Berry, Karen Pinachyan, Arran Strong, Shane Fitch, Alain Baumann, Lisa Butler, and Paula Manchester, emphasize the importance of recognizing and addressing rare diseases. Lisa Butler, Executive Director of the GBS/CIDP Foundation International, highlights the isolation and fear experienced by those with rare diseases and advocates for better awareness, support, and treatments. The collective message stresses the need for empathy, equitable access to care, and the broader impact of rare disease research on public health.

title: Julie Louise Gerberding, MD, MPH
summary: Dr. Julie Louise Gerberding, MD, MPH, joined the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health (FNIH) as CEO on May 16, 2022. Prior to this, she held significant roles at Merck & Co., Inc., including Chief Patient Officer and Executive Vice President for Population Health & Sustainability, where she managed patient engagement and corporate social responsibility. She initially joined Merck as President of Merck Vaccines, significantly enhancing global vaccine access. Dr. Gerberding also served as Director of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), leading the agency through 40 public health emergencies, including the SARS-CoV-1 outbreak. She currently holds various board positions and co-chairs the Center for Strategic and International Studies Commission on Strengthening America’s Health Security. Dr. Gerberding earned her M.D. from Case Western Reserve University and a Master of Public Health from the University of California, Berkeley. She is an Adjunct Associate Professor of Medicine at UCSF.

title: NIAMS Coalition 2023 Outreach & Education Meeting: Creating Connections for Science | NIAMS
summary: The NIAMS Coalition held its ninth Outreach and Education Meeting on September 19, 2023, at the NIH campus, with over 80 attendees from various organizations. The meeting featured discussions on the NIH budget, partnerships, and research advancements. Dr. Lindsey A. Criswell highlighted the AMP programs and the new NIH Office of Autoimmune Disease Research. Julie Louise Gerberding, MD, MPH, CEO of the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health (FNIH), introduced FNIH's role in bridging public and private sectors to enhance NIH research. She emphasized FNIH’s support for nearly 25,000 scientists and the AMP program, including the AMP BGTC aimed at gene therapy product manufacturing. Dr. Gerberding also discussed FNIH's patient-centric initiatives and the Coalition for Trust in Health & Science. The meeting included breakout sessions on various diseases, the role of patient voices, and the use of AI in advancing organizational missions. The event concluded with a call for continued engagement and leadership within the Coalition.

title: NAMI NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison, Jr. invites you to NAMICon 2024!
summary: NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison, Jr. invites you to NAMICon 2024, an event focused on mental health awareness, education, and advocacy. The convention will take place from June 4–6 in Denver, Colorado, offering attendees the opportunity to build lasting connections and experience inspiring moments. For more information, visit convention.nami.org. Daniel Gillison's leadership in promoting NAMICon 2024 highlights his commitment to advancing mental health initiatives and fostering a supportive community.

title: Act on the facts about mental health and gun violence
summary: The article by Kris Brown and Daniel H. Gillison, Jr. discusses the misconceptions linking mental health issues to gun violence in the U.S. It highlights that while mental illness is often blamed for mass shootings, data shows that people with mental illness are more likely to be victims rather than perpetrators of violence. Only 3-5% of violent acts are attributed to severe mental illness. The U.S. experiences gun violence at a rate 25 times higher than other high-income countries, not due to a higher prevalence of mental illness, but because of other factors. The article stresses the importance of using research and data to address gun violence and emphasizes responsible gun ownership, such as safe storage practices, to prevent suicides, which constitute over half of gun deaths. Daniel H. Gillison, Jr., as CEO of the National Alliance on Mental Illness, contributes to advocating for a fact-based approach to disentangle mental health issues from the gun violence debate.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Help During the Holidays - NAMI HelpLine 101
summary: During the holiday season, NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. discusses with NAMI’s National Director of HelpLine Services, Dawn Brown, how individuals can find help. Daniel Gillison's contributions are significant as he leads NAMI in providing inclusive and culturally competent mental health resources. He emphasizes the importance of support during emotionally challenging times. Dawn Brown, inspired by her son’s schizophrenia diagnosis, leads the NAMI HelpLine team, offering information, resources, and peer support to over 250,000 help seekers annually. The podcast "Hope Starts With Us" aims to inspire and support listeners, reinforcing that they are not alone. Episodes are available bi-weekly on major directories and apps.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Pressure, Professional Football and Pivoting
summary: NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. hosts the "Hope Starts With Us" podcast, featuring conversations with former NFL players Rob Robertson and Devin Funchess about their mental health journeys, the pressures of professional football, and transitioning to life after sports. Gillison, who has a background in leadership roles at the American Psychiatric Association Foundation and major corporations like Xerox, Nextel, and Sprint, is dedicated to making inclusive mental health resources accessible to all. The podcast aims to inspire and support listeners, reinforcing the message that they are not alone in their struggles. Episodes are available bi-weekly on major platforms.

title: Indo-Asian News Service-LG SUPPORTS NCAA MENTAL HEALTH INITIATIVES THROUGH NAMI DONATION ...
summary: LG Electronics USA announced a $100,000 donation to the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) during the NCAA Men’s Final Four at State Farm Stadium. This initiative supports mental health programs for young adults, particularly college athletes. Daniel Gillison, CEO of NAMI, emphasized the importance of this collaboration in raising mental health awareness and reducing stigma. LG also introduced the "Life’s Good Coaches Award" to honor NCAA coaches who promote mental well-being among their players. Additionally, LG launched the third season of its "Transparent Conversations" podcast series, hosted by Taylor Rooks, focusing on student-athlete mental health.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Manifesting Healing in 2024
summary: In the first episode of the year, NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. speaks with international motivational speaker, certified life coach, and bestselling author Steven Anthony King about using purpose, positivity, and perseverance to manifest healing in 2024. Daniel Gillison's contribution is significant as he leads the discussion, emphasizing the importance of mental health and healing. The podcast aims to inspire and support listeners, reminding them they are not alone. Episodes will be available bi-weekly on major directories and apps. Steven Anthony King shares his personal journey of overcoming addiction, imprisonment, and severe eye challenges, highlighting his commitment to helping others through motivational speaking and coaching.

title: Hope Starts With Us: MENtal Health and Music
summary: During "Movember" (Men’s Health Awareness Month), NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. engages in a podcast discussion with Drew Lachey (98 Degrees) and Chris Bullard (CEO of Sound Mind Live) about men’s mental health and the positive impact of music on well-being. Daniel Gillison's contributions include leading the conversation and highlighting the importance of inclusive, culturally competent mental health resources. The podcast aims to inspire and support listeners, emphasizing that they are not alone. Episodes are released bi-weekly and available on major directories and apps.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Setting 2023 Intentions
summary: For NAMI’s first podcast episode of 2023, NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. speaks with motivational speaker and former Ohio State Representative Les Brown about setting mental health intentions for the new year through healthy relationships, positive affirmations, and wellness tools. The podcast encourages and supports listeners, emphasizing they are not alone. Episodes air every other Wednesday on most major directories and apps. Daniel H. Gillison, Jr., as NAMI's CEO, brings experience from the American Psychiatric Association Foundation and companies like Xerox, Nextel, and Sprint to provide inclusive mental health resources.

title: Hope Starts With Us: International Women’s Day: Gender & Mental Health
summary: In the episode of NAMI’s podcast titled "Hope Starts With Us: International Women’s Day: Gender & Mental Health," NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. discusses gender and mental health with actor and advocate Jamie Gray Hyder and NAMI ambassador Elise Banks. The conversation highlights the unique challenges women face and ways to support teenage girls. Daniel H. Gillison Jr., who has a background in leadership roles at the American Psychiatric Association Foundation and various corporations like Xerox, Nextel, and Sprint, emphasizes making inclusive, culturally competent mental health resources accessible to all. The podcast aims to inspire, encourage, and assure listeners that they are not alone. Episodes are released bi-weekly and available on major directories and apps.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Workplace Mental Health
summary: In the "Hope Starts With Us: Workplace Mental Health" episode of NAMI's podcast, CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. discusses the importance of mental health in the workplace with Chief Innovation Officer Darcy Gruttadaro, J.D. They address issues like presenteeism and psychological safety, highlighting the benefits of prioritizing mental health for both employees and employers. The podcast aims to inspire and support listeners, emphasizing that they are not alone. Episodes are released bi-weekly and available on major directories and apps. Daniel H. Gillison Jr. has a background in leadership roles at the American Psychiatric Association Foundation and large corporations like Xerox, Nextel, and Sprint. He is committed to making inclusive mental health resources accessible to all and promotes culturally competent mental health support through NAMI.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Schizophrenia and Coping with Comedy
summary: In the episode "Hope Starts With Us: Schizophrenia and Coping with Comedy" of NAMI’s podcast, NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. interviews social media influencer and mental health advocate Kody Green. Green, who has schizophrenia, shares his journey through drug addiction, incarceration, and serious mental health challenges. He discusses how comedy can aid in spreading awareness and coping with mental health issues. Daniel Gillison's contribution as the host is significant, as he facilitates the conversation, bringing attention to mental health issues and promoting inclusive, culturally competent mental health resources. The podcast aims to inspire and support listeners, emphasizing that they are not alone in their struggles. Episodes are available every other Wednesday on major directories and apps.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Living with Bipolar Disorder
summary: Hope Starts With Us: Living with Bipolar Disorder features a conversation between NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison, Jr. and Gabe Howard, a speaker and podcast host who shares his experiences living with bipolar disorder. The discussion aims to reduce mental health stigma, support those living with bipolar disorder, and emphasize hope. Daniel Gillison's contribution includes facilitating this important dialogue and promoting mental health awareness through NAMI's platforms. The podcast episodes are available bi-weekly on various directories and apps, offering insights from experts and personal stories to inspire and support listeners.

title: Hope Starts With Us: Racism as an Adverse Childhood Experience
summary: Daniel H. Gillison Jr., CEO of NAMI, hosts the first episode of Black History Month, discussing racism as an adverse childhood experience with Dr. Mikah Owen and Dr. Roy Wade Jr. They explore the long-term mental and physical health effects of racism and adverse childhood experiences, providing real-life examples, research insights, and actionable steps to address these issues. Gillison's leadership and dedication to mental health awareness are evident as he facilitates conversations aimed at understanding and mitigating the impacts of toxic stressors on individuals and society.

title: NAMI and AFSP Celebrate Launch of Bipartisan Senate Mental Health Caucus
summary: The National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) and the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention (AFSP) celebrate the launch of the bipartisan Senate Mental Health Caucus, founded by Senators Alex Padilla, Thom Tillis, Joni Ernst, and Tina Smith. This caucus aims to address the mental health crisis through bipartisan solutions. NAMI CEO Daniel H. Gillison Jr. emphasized the importance of mental health as a bipartisan issue and expressed gratitude to the Senators for their leadership. Gillison highlighted NAMI's commitment to collaborating with the caucus to improve lives affected by mental health conditions. The caucus will focus on prevention, early intervention, workforce expansion, crisis response, and access to evidence-based treatments. Both NAMI and AFSP look forward to working with the caucus to reduce stigma and promote mental health awareness.

title: Leah Howard, JD: Advocacy in Chronic Skin Conditions
summary: Leah Howard, JD, President and CEO of the National Psoriasis Foundation (NPF), emphasized the importance of advocacy and mental health in chronic skin conditions during a media roundtable hosted by AbbVie. The event, "Science of Skin: The Psychosocial Impact of Chronic Skin Disease," featured insights from various experts, including Howard. She discussed the relationship between chronic skin conditions and mental health, stressing the need for self-advocacy and organizational support. Howard highlighted NPF's educational programs, patient navigation services, and research funding, specifically for mental health. She encouraged patients to share their journeys, seek supportive healthcare providers, and be honest about their challenges to develop effective treatment plans. Howard's contributions underscore the significance of comprehensive care and patient-provider partnerships in managing chronic skin conditions.

title: Q&A: National Psoriasis Foundation CEO on the science of chronic skin disease
summary: Leah Howard, JD, CEO of the National Psoriasis Foundation, highlighted the importance of vocal patient advocates in challenging the stigmas associated with psoriasis. During a panel discussion hosted by interior designer Nate Berkus, who has psoriasis, Howard emphasized the need for patients and healthcare professionals (HCPs) to engage in open, equal-level conversations. She noted that while clinicians understand the science, patients are experts in their own experiences. Howard discussed advancements in care, communication tools for patients, and the significance of inclusive descriptions and images for accurate diagnoses. She also addressed the challenges of marketing psoriasis treatments, stressing the importance of realistic portrayals. Looking ahead, Howard mentioned the Foundation's commitment to supporting the holistic health of psoriasis patients as they develop their next strategic plan.

title: Newest Psoriasis Treatment is Now Available
summary: UCB has launched Bimzelx (bimekizumab-bkzx), the first dual IL-17 A/F inhibitor, to treat moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis. Priced at $7,200 per syringe, it is available as an autoinjector and pre-filled syringe. The recommended dosage is 320 mg at specified intervals. UCB offers financial assistance to commercially insured patients and those facing insurance delays. Bimzelx is accessible through over 20 specialty pharmacies. Psoriasis affects over 7.5 million adults in the U.S., causing plaques due to overactive immune cells. Bimzelx targets cytokines IL-17A and IL-17F to reduce inflammation. Approved by the FDA on October 17, 2023, based on three phase 3 trials, it showed significant efficacy in achieving clear skin. Common side effects include infections and headaches. Leah McCormick Howard, JD, president and CEO of the National Psoriasis Foundation, emphasized the importance of Bimzelx in providing new treatment options and improving patient outcomes.

title: FDA Grants Approval of Roflumilast Cream 0.3% for Psoriasis Patients Aged 6 to 11
summary: The FDA has approved Arcutis Biotherapeutics' supplemental new drug application for roflumilast cream (ZORYVE) 0.3% to treat plaque psoriasis in children aged 6 to 11. This expands the drug's use to younger patients, offering a steroid-free, once-daily treatment option. Clinical studies showed that ZORYVE is effective and well-tolerated in children, aligning with adult Phase 3 trial results. Leah M. Howard, JD, President and CEO of the National Psoriasis Foundation, highlighted the challenges in treating pediatric psoriasis and expressed optimism about this advancement alleviating the disease burden for young patients. The FDA will review additional data from ongoing studies on roflumilast cream's long-term safety and its use in even younger children.

title: Evan Rieder, MD: Equipping Patients With Tools for Skin Acceptance
summary: Evan Rieder, MD, a dual-board certified dermatologist and psychiatrist, participated in AbbVie's Science of Skin media roundtable discussing the psychosocial impact of chronic skin diseases. The event, moderated by Nate Berkus, featured insights from various experts, including Leah Howard, JD, a psoriasis patient and president & CEO of the National Psoriasis Foundation. Rieder emphasized the link between chronic skin conditions and mental health, advocating for equipping patients with tools for skin acceptance. He highlighted the importance of accurate diagnosis, building rapport, and understanding the psychological comorbidities associated with chronic skin diseases. Leah Howard, JD's role as a panelist and advocate underscores her leadership in addressing psoriasis-related issues.

title: Securing the future: APIC promotes diverse career paths for infection preventionists
summary: The Association for Professionals in Infection Control and Epidemiology (APIC) is working to create diverse career pathways for infection preventionists (IPs) to address a potential shortage as 40% of current IPs near retirement. Devin Jopp, EdD, MS, APIC CEO, emphasized the need for dedicated career pathways and collaboration with universities and the Department of Labor to establish academic and apprenticeship programs. Jopp highlighted the importance of strategic partnerships, such as with Medline, to tackle infection prevention challenges and improve healthcare-associated infection rates. He also stressed the significance of dedicated roles and adequate resources for IPs, especially in long-term care facilities, to prevent burnout and ensure effective infection control.

title: Chief Medical Officer of Amazon Health Services Joins Board of Directors for URAC, the Nation's Leading Health Care ...
summary: Sunita Mishra, MD, MBA, Chief Medical Officer of Amazon Health Services, has been appointed to the board of directors for URAC, the leading health care accreditation organization in the U.S. Dr. Mishra has extensive experience as an internist and primary care physician, practicing for over 20 years in the U.S. and Singapore. At Amazon Health Services, she focuses on creating sustainable clinician experiences and enhancing patient care through services like Amazon Clinic, Amazon Pharmacy, and One Medical. Dr. Mishra expressed excitement about joining URAC's board to further their mission of advancing health care quality through accreditation and certification. Shawn Griffin, MD, URAC's President and CEO, highlighted that Dr. Mishra's experience will help elevate URAC's programs. Dr. Mishra began her tenure in 2023 and will serve a three-year term. URAC, founded in 1990, is renowned for promoting health care quality and patient safety through its accreditation programs.

title: America faces a shortage of primary care doctors–and they're drowning in work. Here's how AI can solve the physician ...
summary: The United States faces a significant shortage of primary care doctors, leading to physician burnout and impacting patient care. Sunita Mishra, MD, MBA, highlights that AI can alleviate this crisis by reducing administrative burdens on doctors. AI technologies can automate tasks such as documentation, allowing physicians to spend more time with patients, thus improving care quality and strengthening doctor-patient relationships. Mishra emphasizes that AI can process and synthesize patient data efficiently, aiding in personalized treatment plans. This approach could make primary care a more sustainable profession and potentially increase U.S. life expectancy.

title: Thought Leaders Converge at National Health Council Leadership Conference to Advance Care for Patients
summary: The National Health Council (NHC) 2024 Health Leadership Conference in Scottsdale, AZ, gathered senior leaders from top patient organizations to discuss emerging health care issues and policies. The conference, themed "The Urgency of Now: Think Patient," aimed to foster collaboration for patient-centered health policy. Jeff Todd, President and CEO of Prevent Blindness, emphasized the importance of diverse organizations working together. Randall L. Rutta, CEO of the NHC, highlighted the conference as a platform for innovation in health care. Sunita Mishra, MD, MBA, Chief Medical Officer of Amazon Health Services, contributed by discussing Amazon's patient-focused approach in the health care market. Other notable sessions included insights on artificial intelligence in health care and advances in medical technology. The event aimed to ensure accessible, affordable, and equitable health care, with a focus on incorporating patient perspectives in decision-making.

title: How Can Cancer Risk Be Cut in Communities Exposed to Toxins?
summary: The Fifth Ward in Houston, Texas, has alarmingly high cancer rates, attributed to historical creosote contamination. This primarily Black and Hispanic community faces significant health challenges, including high incidences of lung, colorectal, multiple myeloma, and Hodgkin's lymphoma. The National Minority Quality Forum (NMQF), led by President Gary A. Puckrein, PhD, is addressing these issues by advocating for better cancer screening and treatment in underserved areas. Puckrein highlighted the disproportionate impact of toxic waste sites on minority communities and the lack of access to modern cancer care. NMQF's Cancer Stage Shifting Initiative aims to document underserved cancer care communities, develop scalable cancer care protocols, and create financial models to support these efforts. This initiative seeks to integrate new diagnostic and treatment technologies into high-risk communities to improve survival rates and healthcare access.

title: Michael Ybarra - IPWatchdog.com | Patents & Intellectual Property Law
summary: Michael Ybarra, MD, FACEP, FAPCR, is the Vice President and Chief Medical Officer at the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America (PhRMA). He oversees teams focused on coalition building, stakeholder engagement, and strategic partnerships to support PhRMA’s public policy priorities, including pandemic preparedness, COVID-19 response, and antimicrobial resistance. His advocacy efforts extend to the implementation of the Inflation Reduction Act, Medicare Parts B and D, the 340B drug discount program, and FDA-related issues. Dr. Ybarra also engages with various healthcare organizations and serves as an Assistant Professor of Emergency Medicine at Georgetown University School of Medicine. He has held leadership roles in the American Academy of Emergency Medicine (AAEM) and currently sits on the boards of the Society for Women’s Health Research (SWHR) and the Academy of Physicians in Clinical Research (APCR). He is also a published author of peer-reviewed articles and book chapters.

title: World Vaccine Congress: Building on vaccine success
summary: The World Vaccine Congress highlights the critical role of vaccines in protecting public health and fostering collaborative progress in vaccine development. Michael Ybarra, MD, underscores the importance of U.S. leadership in developing vaccines that mitigate diseases such as flu, RSV, COVID-19, and potentially HIV and Alzheimer's. Vaccines have eliminated diseases like smallpox and polio, prevented over 1 million early deaths since 1994, and can prevent over 90% of cancers caused by HPV. They support healthy aging, reduce healthcare costs, and prepare for future pandemics and antimicrobial-resistant pathogens. Rigorous clinical trials and continuous monitoring by the FDA and CDC ensure vaccine safety and efficacy.

title: ICYMI: 3 takeaways on the IRA's unintended consequences from America's Physician Groups' 2023 annual fall ...
summary: Michael Ybarra, MD, spoke at America’s Physician Groups’ 2023 annual fall conference to discuss the unintended consequences of the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). He highlighted three main issues: First, government price-setting threatens research and development (R&D), potentially limiting patients' treatment options. Second, the IRA fails to address abusive practices by Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs) and insurers, which drive up costs for patients. Third, government price-setting undermines the Medicare Part D program, possibly reducing access to lifesaving treatments. Despite some positive changes, such as a cap on seniors' out-of-pocket costs, the IRA does not prevent insurers from using aggressive tactics that increase costs. Ybarra emphasized the need for policies that reduce healthcare costs, protect medicine accessibility, and promote drug development.

title: Don't close the door on rare disease research
summary: There is a significant need for continued incentives in rare disease drug development, as it takes nearly four years longer than for non-rare diseases. Michael Ybarra, MD, emphasizes the importance of the Orphan Drug Act (ODA), which provides crucial incentives for companies to invest in rare disease research. Since the ODA's enactment, the FDA has approved nearly 1,200 orphan drugs, contrasting with fewer than 10 in the preceding decade. However, the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) threatens this progress by discouraging additional orphan designations and undermining ODA incentives. To ensure ongoing rare disease R&D, policymakers should amend the IRA to better preserve these incentives, allowing biopharmaceutical companies to continue their high-risk research and development efforts.

title: A conversation with Sepsis Alliance President and CEO Thomas Heymann as World AMR Awareness Week kicks off
summary: World AMR Awareness Week, held from November 18-23, aims to raise awareness about antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and explore solutions to combat drug-resistant infections. The World Health Organization identifies AMR as a major global health threat, potentially causing 10 million deaths annually by 2050. Sepsis, a severe complication of AMR, affects 1.7 million people in the U.S. annually, with 350,000 fatalities. Michael Ybarra, MD, highlights the link between AMR and sepsis, emphasizing the urgent need for new antimicrobials. Sepsis Alliance President Thomas Heymann discusses the critical state of AMR and the necessity of legislative actions like the PASTEUR Act to address the crisis.

title: Celebrating Hispanic Heritage Month at PhRMA
summary: National Hispanic Heritage Month (September 15 – October 15) celebrates the history, culture, and contributions of Hispanic Americans. Michael Ybarra, MD, highlighted the significance of this month at PhRMA, emphasizing the importance of honoring Hispanic health care professionals and addressing health disparities affecting Latino populations. Ybarra, from a Mexican American family, shared stories about his grandparents' health challenges at MANA’s Las Primeras Awards event, where he received the 2023 HerMANO Award. He noted that Hispanic Americans face higher risks for diseases like Alzheimer’s, chronic liver disease, COVID-19, diabetes, high blood pressure, HIV, and tuberculosis. PhRMA is committed to advancing affordable and equitable health care through partnerships, improving vaccine education, enhancing clinical trial diversity, and developing new treatments. Ybarra expressed pride in contributing to an industry focused on improving health outcomes for all Americans, including Hispanic communities.

title: Highlights from ASCO 2023
summary: Michael Ybarra, MD, highlighted significant advancements in cancer research from the 2023 ASCO meeting. Key findings included a breast cancer pill combined with endocrine therapy that reduced recurrence risk by 25%, an antibody-drug conjugate that extended survival in advanced ovarian cancer by 33%, and a pill for non-small cell lung cancer that decreased the risk of death by 51%. These discoveries represent a fraction of ongoing efforts, with over 1,300 cancer medicines and vaccines in development. However, Ybarra expressed concern over the Inflation Reduction Act's price setting provisions, which could hinder future cancer research and innovation, urging Congress to amend these policies to preserve progress in cancer treatment.

title: Watch: New video series spotlights advances in biopharmaceutical science
summary: A new video series highlights the advances in biopharmaceutical science, showcasing the work of researchers dedicated to fighting and curing diseases. Michael Ybarra, MD, emphasizes the importance of these researchers in developing innovative medicines. The series features Pfizer's efforts in combating sickle cell disease, with Dr. Seng Cheng discussing their progress. Amgen's laboratory, led by Dr. Brian Lanman, has made significant strides in treating non-small cell lung cancer. UCB’s Dr. Onur Kas and Dr. Wang Yuan are pioneering gene therapy treatments for muscular and neurodegenerative diseases. These stories illustrate the dedication and intelligence of biopharmaceutical professionals working to alleviate patient suffering and create a healthier future.

title: Cartesian Therapeutics expands clinical advisory board with five internationally recognized experts in autoimmunity
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA HEARTLAND CHAPTER INC
summary: Cartesian Therapeutics, a biopharmaceutical company pioneering RNA cell therapy for autoimmune diseases and cancer, has expanded its clinical advisory board with five internationally recognized experts. Among these experts is Susan M. Manzi, MD, MPH, who is a Professor of Medicine and Chair of the Medicine Institute at Allegheny Health Network. Dr. Manzi is renowned for her pioneering research into premature cardiovascular disease in systemic lupus erythematosus and for discovering biomarkers for lupus diagnosis, monitoring, and stratification. This expansion aims to enhance Cartesian’s clinical pipeline with multidisciplinary perspectives.

title: Lupus Advocates from Across the Country Return to Capitol Hill, Urge Congress to Support Policies that Improve ...
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA HEARTLAND CHAPTER INC
summary: Lupus advocates from across the U.S. gathered in Washington, D.C., for the National Lupus Advocacy Summit from April 23-25. Organized by the Lupus Foundation of America (LFA), the summit aimed to educate attendees on lupus research, advocacy, and care, and to urge Congress to support policies enhancing access to lupus care. Key legislative focuses included the Safe Step Act, HELP Copays Act, and BENEFIT Act, all aimed at improving access to medications and incorporating patient experience in drug development. Mary T. Crimmings, Interim CEO of LFA, highlighted the summit's importance in empowering advocates and stressing the need for congressional support to improve lupus care and research.

title: 2023 Southeast Region's 5th Annual Lupus Empowerment Conference | Southeast
hco: LUPUS FOUNDATION OF AMERICA HEARTLAND CHAPTER INC
summary: The Southeast Region's 5th Annual Lupus Empowerment Conference will be held virtually on August 5, from 10:30 am-2:30 pm EST. The event aims to empower lupus warriors, care partners, family, and friends through expert-led sessions on lupus research, coping strategies, communication with healthcare teams, and patient roles in research. Dr. Karen H. Costenbader, MD, MPH, Chair of the Medical-Scientific Advisory Council, will highlight the Lupus Foundation of America's commitment to addressing health disparities, particularly in marginalized communities. Dr. Costenbader leads efforts to expand strategic partnerships and increase the Foundation’s impact on lupus research and professional development. The conference will also feature a panel of lupus warriors sharing their experiences and strategies for managing the disease. Participants can engage in live Q&A sessions and breakout discussions tailored for lupus patients and their caregivers.

title: Better cancer education could lead to more early detection
summary: April is Cancer Awareness Month, and Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, emphasizes the importance of early detection and routine cancer screenings. Despite common misconceptions, most cancer diagnoses occur in individuals without a family history of the disease. Hoyos highlights that a significant barrier to screening is a lack of education, with many unaware of the necessity for regular check-ups. She advises everyone to contact their primary care providers to schedule screenings, which can help detect cancer at an early stage. The Prevent Cancer Foundation offers various resources, including online screening quizzes and directories for low- and no-cost testing for uninsured or underinsured individuals. Hoyos's contributions focus on raising awareness and providing accessible information to encourage proactive health measures.

title: Survey finds 7 in 10 adults skip cancer screenings
summary: A survey by the Prevent Cancer Foundation reveals that nearly 69% of U.S. adults are behind on at least one routine cancer screening. Jody Hoyos, the CEO of the foundation, emphasized the importance of early detection and noted that many people are unaware they need screenings. President Biden has declared April 2024 as Cancer Prevention and Early Detection Month to raise awareness. The foundation's survey highlighted barriers such as affordability for Hispanic adults and skepticism in the healthcare system for Black adults. The foundation aims to reduce cancer deaths by 40% by 2035 through significant investments in innovative technologies, expanding screenings to underserved communities, and enhancing screening education. Hoyos clarified that most cancers are not hereditary and stressed that everyone should be screened, regardless of family history.

title: Many people are behind on cancer screenings, study shows
summary: A recent study by the Prevent Cancer Foundation reveals that nearly 69% of American adults are behind on routine cancer screenings. The primary reason cited is a lack of awareness about necessary screenings. Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, emphasized that many people are unaware of the screenings they need. Additionally, misconceptions such as the absence of family history of cancer contribute to the delay, despite most cancer diagnoses occurring in individuals without such history. Other reasons vary by race, including skepticism of the healthcare system among Black and African Americans, nervousness about examinations among Asians, cost concerns among Hispanics, and lack of symptoms among whites. Hoyos encourages individuals to discuss screening requirements with healthcare providers and highlights the importance of education and awareness. The Prevent Cancer Foundation offers a free interactive quiz to help people determine recommended screenings.

title: Survey warns against delaying cancer screenings
summary: A survey by the Prevent Cancer Foundation reveals that 69% of U.S. adults are behind on at least one routine cancer screening. The primary reason cited is a lack of awareness about the need for these screenings. This issue spans across all demographics, highlighting a significant need for better education and awareness regarding routine cancer screenings. A common misconception is that a lack of family history negates the necessity for screening, despite the fact that most cancer diagnoses occur in individuals without a family history. Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, emphasized that only about five to ten percent of cancers are hereditary, underscoring the importance of routine screenings for everyone. Understanding and discussing family history with healthcare providers remains crucial, but it should not replace regular screenings.

title: More than half of American adults are behind on at least 1 cancer screening
summary: More than half of American adults are behind on at least one cancer screening, with 69% not up-to-date on routine checks, according to the Prevent Cancer Foundation. Jody Hoyos, the CEO of the foundation, highlights a common misconception that only those with a family history of cancer need screenings. She emphasizes the need for increased awareness and access to cancer screenings for everyone, regardless of age, sex, or ethnicity. Hoyos points out that many people are unaware they need to be screened. The foundation's survey found that Hispanic adults often cite cost as a barrier, while black adults express skepticism towards the healthcare system. Hoyos advises that cervical cancer screenings should start at age 21 and mammograms at age 40 for those at average risk. For more information on recommended screenings, visit preventcancer.org.

title: Illumina: How Organizations Are Closing the Cancer Care Gap
summary: On World Cancer Day, Illumina highlights the efforts of nonprofits and institutions worldwide to improve cancer care access. The 2023 campaign theme, “Close the care gap,” emphasizes equity and accessibility in cancer treatment. Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, contributes significantly by advocating for access to multi-cancer early detection (MCED) screening tests in the US. Hoyos emphasizes the importance of early detection, noting that most cancers lack routine screening tests. The Prevent Cancer Foundation leads over 400 organizations in pushing for Medicare coverage for MCED tests once FDA-approved. This effort aims to ensure seniors, who are at higher cancer risk, have timely access to these innovative screenings.

title: 65% of Americans 21 years of age and older report not being up to date on at least one routine cancer screening
summary: The Prevent Cancer Foundation's first annual Early Detection Survey reveals that 65% of Americans aged 21 and older are not up to date on at least one routine cancer screening. The survey, conducted during National Cancer Prevention Month, highlights the need for increased awareness and access to screenings. Participants cited lack of knowledge, absence of symptoms, and cost as primary reasons for not getting screened. Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, emphasized the importance of routine screenings as part of wellness routines. The Foundation's new campaign, "Early Detection = Better Outcomes," aims to educate the public and provide resources for free or low-cost screenings.
