The survey also found disparities in screening rates among Hispanic and Black communities and noted a rise in health vigilance post-pandemic. The Foundation is committed to investing in early detection technologies and expanding access to screenings and vaccinations.

title: Insight: Survey finds 7 in 10 adults skip cancer screenings
summary: Nearly 69% of U.S. adults are behind on at least one routine cancer screening, as reported by the Prevent Cancer Foundation. This statistic highlights a significant gap in preventive healthcare, with seven out of every ten adults missing the opportunity to prevent cancer or detect it early. Jody Hoyos, the CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, emphasized the critical nature of this issue, pointing out the missed benefits of early detection and prevention.

title: Games Done Quick raises $2.6 million for the Prevent Cancer Foundation at annual gaming marathon
summary: Games Done Quick (GDQ) raised $2.6 million for the Prevent Cancer Foundation during its annual gaming marathon, Awesome Games Done Quick 2023. The event, held virtually from January 8 to January 15, featured gamers from around the world speedrunning their favorite games. Nearly 40,000 donations were made by over 21,000 individuals. The marathon also celebrated GDQ founder Mike Uyama's achievements, who started the organization in 2010 and has since raised over $41 million for various charities. Jody Hoyos, CEO of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, praised Uyama's commitment and vision, highlighting GDQ's significant impact on cancer prevention and early detection efforts.

title: Detection of Early Emphysema During Lung Cancer Screening: Opportunities to Optimize Health
summary: James L. Mulshine, MD, from Rush University, and colleagues highlighted in an article in the Annals of the American Thoracic Society that the frequent detection of emphysema during low-dose CT lung cancer screenings offers significant opportunities to enhance overall health.

title: Core Crisis Challenges and Facing the Unknown
summary: The article "Core Crisis Challenges and Facing the Unknown" discusses how businesses and individuals are adapting to the disruptions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. It emphasizes the importance of business continuity plans and organizational resilience. Drawing parallels to the 2008 financial crisis, the authors suggest that lessons from past crises can guide current decision-making. Key challenges identified include navigating uncertainty, establishing governance and compliance for new operations, and staying agile amidst rapid changes. Paul Phaneuf, one of the contributing authors, is highlighted as a Partner and Digital Services Lead, contributing his expertise to the discussion. The paper underscores the need for proactive thinking in addressing issues like lending, credit exposure, liquidity, and securitizations. By leveraging historical insights, organizations can prioritize impactful changes to navigate the pandemic effectively.

title: Let's Celebrate Your VTE Sheroes! - Blood Clots
summary: May is Women’s Health Month, and the National Blood Clot Alliance (NBCA) celebrates women who have made significant contributions to the blood clot community. These "VTE Sheroes" include healthcare providers, caregivers, blood clot patients, and advocates. The page features numerous stories of women who have shown extraordinary courage and dedication in various capacities related to blood clot awareness and treatment. Heide Bajnrauh, a blood clot survivor and senior policy advisor, has played a pivotal role in NBCA's federal advocacy efforts. She has guided the organization through the federal appropriations process, arranged meetings with congressional offices, and volunteered her time to educate blood clot survivors on advocacy. Her contributions have significantly advanced blood clot awareness and education.

title: Blood Clot Awareness Month Just Got Bigger and Brighter!
summary: The National Blood Clot Alliance has launched a public service announcement on the Nasdaq digital billboard in Times Square, featuring Paralympian Tatyana McFadden, Olympic swimmer Katie Hoff, and health policy adviser Heide Bajnrauh, all blood clot survivors. This announcement, which runs four times per hour until April 15, aims to raise awareness among the 330,000 daily visitors to Times Square. Heide Bajnrauh's contribution as a featured survivor and health policy adviser highlights her role in promoting blood clot awareness. This initiative is made possible by a generous donation from a passionate blood clot survivor, emphasizing the importance of public education on blood clots. Visitors are encouraged to capture and share photos or videos of the billboard to further spread the message.

title: Taking a Breath: A Stop the Clot Podcast
summary: Taking a Breath: A Stop the Clot Podcast highlights real-life experiences of blood clot survivors and shares information on prevention and symptom awareness. Each episode features personal stories and insights from medical professionals. Notably, Episode 6 features Heide Bajnrauh, a health policy strategist, who recounts waking up in the hospital at 19, learning she nearly didn't survive the night. This experience, along with subsequent blood clot diagnoses, led her to become a blood clot awareness advocate. Heide's advocacy is significant as she appears on a Times Square billboard through March, promoting awareness.

title: New appointment at children's charity - TFN
summary: Aberlour Children’s Charity has appointed Lynne O’Brien as its new chief officer of children and families, starting in October. Lynne brings extensive experience in the social care sector and is expected to significantly contribute to the charity's mission of supporting disadvantaged children, young people, and families across Scotland. Lynne expressed her excitement about joining Aberlour and her commitment to ensuring all children have equal opportunities. SallyAnn Kelly OBE, chief executive of Aberlour, also expressed her enthusiasm for Lynne’s appointment, highlighting her valuable expertise and the positive impact she will have on the organization’s efforts.

title: Annual Leukemia Ball raising money to cure blood cancer
summary: The annual Leukemia Ball, held on Saturday, May 13th, aims to raise funds to cure blood cancer. During the event, Andy Eichberg, managing director at Stream Realty, will present the Eichberg award to Lynne O'Brien, the founder and CEO of Line in the Sand. This award recognizes O'Brien's significant contributions and efforts in the fight against leukemia. Eileen interviewed both Eichberg and O'Brien to discuss their inspiring stories and the importance of the event.

title: Creative Landscape Depot raises $15,000 for Sunrise
summary: Creative Landscape Depot organized a charity golf tournament, raising $15,000 for the Sunrise Therapeutic Riding and Learning Centre in Puslinch, a Canadian charity supporting children and adults with special needs for 40 years. The funds will support programs where participants gain life skills and empowerment through interactions with therapy horses. Lynne O'Brien, the executive director, along with Sunrise riders Nicholaus C and Jack I, accepted the donation from tournament organizer Blake Sicard. The inclusive programs include a summer day camp for children of all abilities. Sunrise officials expressed gratitude for the community's support in making these programs successful.

title: Jonathon Nevett and Karen Thiel join Prevent Cancer Foundation board of directors
summary: The Prevent Cancer Foundation has elected Jonathon Nevett and Karen Thiel to its board of directors, effective January 1, 2024. Jonathon Nevett, president and CEO of Public Interest Registry, brings extensive experience from the domain name industry and has actively participated in various leadership roles, including contributions to online safety. Karen Thiel, a former senior counsel at the Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, has provided significant legal advice and pro bono work, notably securing funding for the National Institutes of Health and supporting ethical research practices. Thiel's notable contributions include securing funding for cancer research in California and co-authoring a published article on biospecimen-related research. Both are cancer survivors, bringing personal insights to the Foundation's mission of cancer prevention and early detection.

title: Dr. Huerta sobre el cáncer de Catherine: "En este momento, es imposible decir en qué órgano apareció" | Video
summary: Dr. Elmer Huerta, an oncologist and CNN contributor, discusses the current knowledge about Catherine, Princess of Wales's cancer diagnosis. He emphasizes that at this moment, it is impossible to determine which organ the cancer initially affected. Dr. Huerta's insights provide clarity on the limitations of current information regarding her condition.

title: El doctor Elmer Huerta no es cardiólogo ni fue golpeado en ese programa de televisión
summary: Dr. Elmer Huerta, a Peruvian oncologist and professor at George Washington University, was falsely linked to a video showing a beating in a TV studio. Contrary to claims, Huerta is not a cardiologist and was not involved in the incident. The video, shared on Facebook, falsely depicted Huerta with a black eye and claimed he was attacked for making a sensational statement about hypertension. Huerta confirmed to elDetector that he has never had a black eye and has been misattributed various specialties in the past. The actual video involved a political altercation in Ukraine in February 2022.

title: Video falsificó la imagen de Elmer Huerta para promover supuesto fármaco "contra la hipertensión"
summary: A viral video falsely used the image and voice of Dr. Elmer Huerta and journalist Mávila Huertas to promote a supposed hypertension medication. The 42-second clip, shared on Facebook, mimicked their voices to advertise a product claiming to eliminate hypertension and prevent strokes and heart attacks. Both Huerta and Mávila Huertas have denied making such statements. Dr. Elmer Huerta, a public health and medical oncology specialist, clarified that he has never sold products in his 30 years of medical service and warned against such fraudulent uses of his image. The video, created using AI technology, is confirmed to be fake by La República's Verificador unit. This incident highlights the increasing use of AI-generated deepfakes in spreading misinformation.

title: ¿Debe considerarse a la menopausia como una enfermedad? El Dr. Elmer Huerta responde
summary: Dr. Elmer Huerta, a public health expert and medical consultant for RPP, emphasizes that menopause should not be perceived or treated as a disease. Instead, it should be recognized as a natural physiological process in a woman's life, similar to menarche. Huerta criticizes the historical medicalization of menopause, particularly the indiscriminate use of hormone treatments to counteract associated symptoms. Recent studies have shown that prolonged hormone use can increase the risks of breast cancer, strokes, and heart attacks. Huerta advocates for educating women about menopause as a normal life transition and encourages exploring non-pharmacological therapies like meditation and dance for symptom relief. His perspective aims to shift the view of menopause from a disease to a celebrated life stage.

title: Elmer Huerta sobre uso de vacunas vencidas: "FDA dio hasta 18 meses"
summary: Elmer Huerta, a public health specialist and professor of medicine at George Washington University, spoke about the use of expired Covid-19 vaccines on the program 'Ocurre Ahora'. Huerta explained that the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) allows the use of expired doses for up to 18 months, providing some reassurance regarding the situation. His intervention was crucial in clarifying and providing additional details about the safety and effectiveness of these vaccines, which has been a major concern among public health and epidemiology authorities and specialists.

title: Ensayo clínico demuestra que un medicamento de pérdida de peso puede reducir el riesgo de infartos
summary: A clinical trial has shown that the weight loss drug Wegovy can also reduce the risk of heart attacks. Dr. Elmer Huerta, an expert in oncology and public health, elaborates on the current knowledge regarding these medications, their benefits, and their risks.

title: Detector de Mentiras: Mávila Huertas y Elmer Huerta son víctimas de noticias falsas creadas con Inteligencia Artificial
summary: Mávila Huertas and Dr. Elmer Huerta, both prominent figures at RPP Noticias, have become victims of false news created using Artificial Intelligence. These AI-generated videos and audios falsely depict Mávila promoting dubious medicinal products and Elmer involved in alleged altercations. Dr. Elmer Huerta, a medical consultant at RPP, has publicly refuted these claims in his segment "Espacio Vital," emphasizing that he does not endorse any products nor has he participated in any fights. Legal experts consulted by RPP indicate that while Peru's regulations on AI use are still developing, existing laws can penalize individuals who publish fraudulent content.

title: No, el doctor Elmer Huerta no ofrece un medicamento para "normalizar la presión arterial"
summary: A viral Facebook video falsely attributes a promotion of a blood pressure medication to Dr. Elmer Huerta, a renowned public health specialist. The video, which has over 1,500 reactions and has been shared more than 350 times, uses artificial intelligence to mimic Huerta's image and voice, making it appear as though he endorses a product to "normalize blood pressure" by dissolving blood clots. The video directs viewers to a suspicious link, but Huerta has clarified that he does not sell any products. He stated in his program 'Espacio Vital' that any such use of his image is false. This incident is a 'deepfake,' where AI replicates a person's likeness for misleading purposes. Huerta has consistently refuted claims of product endorsements, emphasizing his non-involvement in commercial activities.

title: JN.1, la nueva subvariante de covid-19, ¿representa un riesgo para la población?
summary: A new subvariant of COVID-19, called JN.1, is rapidly spreading in the United States, accounting for approximately 20% of new infections. The first case of this strain has also been reported in Mexico. Dr. Elmer Huerta, an oncologist and CNN contributor, evaluates whether this subvariant poses a significant risk to the population and assesses the effectiveness of the currently developed vaccines against this strain.

title: Video viral usa imagen falsa del doctor Elmer Huerta para promocionar una web sospechosa
summary: A viral Facebook post falsely claimed that public health specialist Elmer Huerta was "attacked in a TV studio." The post included a video of a fight, featuring a CNN en Español logo and a photoshopped image of Huerta with a black eye, alongside a link to a suspicious "tea sale" website. Dr. Huerta debunked the claim, stating he never had a black eye and that the image was manipulated. The video actually depicted a brawl from a Ukrainian debate program, not a Peruvian TV show. The post also falsely identified a "Sauro Luigi" as a representative of a Peruvian pharmaceutical company, which is incorrect. Dr. Huerta emphasized that such false information is often used by unscrupulous merchants. The video and associated claims are entirely fabricated.

title: ¿Existe una vacuna contra el dengue?
summary: Dr. Elmer E. Huerta, a medical consultant for RPP, discussed the current state of dengue vaccines amidst rising cases worldwide. He highlighted three main vaccines: the French Sanofi vaccine, which is impractical due to its requirement of three doses and a prior blood test; the Japanese Takeda vaccine, which needs two doses and is still under evaluation; and the Brazilian Butantan Institute vaccine, which is in phase 3 trials and shows promising results with a single dose and nearly 80% effectiveness. Dr. Huerta emphasized that while these vaccines are in development, none are yet "super effective."

title: Gran expectativa por medicamento contra el Alzheimer
summary: The FDA is set to approve a groundbreaking medication that slows the progression of Alzheimer's disease. Dr. Elmer E. Huerta, a public health expert, elaborates on the FDA's approval mechanism for this drug, which is the only one proven in trials to delay Alzheimer's progression.

title: ¿Está EE.UU. ante un repunte de contagios de covid-19? El Dr. Elmer Huerta lo analiza
summary: Dr. Elmer Huerta, a professor at George Washington University and a CNN contributor, analyzed the recent increase in new covid-19 cases and hospitalizations in the United States on the program Directo USA. He provided insights and recommendations on the situation in a video segment.

title: Early Cancer Screening Saves Lives. Congress Needs to Act.
summary: Susanna Quinn, a cancer survivor, shares her experience with stage 4 ovarian cancer, stressing the importance of early detection. Diagnosed at 50, her cancer was initially inoperable, but thanks to a skilled surgeon and support from loved ones, she is now cancer-free. Quinn highlights that most cancers are detected too late, leading to high mortality rates. She advocates for Congress to pass the Medicare Multi-Cancer Early Detection Screening Coverage Act, making advanced blood-based screenings more accessible. These screenings can detect multiple cancers early, potentially saving lives and reducing healthcare costs. Quinn underscores the urgency of congressional action to prevent unnecessary deaths and improve early detection. She serves on the board of the Prevent Cancer Foundation, using her platform to push for change.

title: David Charles, MD: How Alternative Funding Programs Negatively Impact Patients with Chronic Illness
summary: David Charles, MD, chief medical officer of the Alliance for Patient Access, discusses the negative impact of alternative funding programs on patients with chronic illnesses. These programs, intended to reduce financial risks for patients needing expensive medical services, often result in negative consequences. Charles highlights that these programs can lead to delays in care, increased anxiety, and higher out-of-pocket costs for patients, particularly those with chronic conditions and lower socioeconomic status. He explains that insurers may exclude certain medications from coverage, forcing patients to rely on alternative funding, which can be distressing and financially burdensome. Additionally, these programs strain charitable resources meant for the underinsured or uninsured, further complicating access to necessary treatments.

title: VIDEO: A conversation on equity in hypertension care
summary: In a Healio video exclusive, Yvonne Commodore-Mensah and Keith C. Ferdinand discuss uncontrolled hypertension in the U.S. and the importance of health equity in its treatment. Keith C. Ferdinand, who holds the Gerald S. Berenson Endowed Chair in Preventive Cardiology at Tulane University, emphasizes that social determinants of health drive disparities in hypertension prevalence and treatment. He argues that while new drugs and devices are beneficial, they must be applied equally to address these disparities. Both experts participated in a session at the American Heart Association Scientific Sessions focused on achieving equity in cardiovascular disease prevention.

title: Starting Combination Therapy Early
summary: The text discusses the importance of starting combination therapy early for patients with hyperlipidemia. Insights from a panel of medical experts, including Dr. Keith C. Ferdinand, highlight the necessity of combination therapy in middle-aged and older patients, especially those at higher risk. The benefits include better LDL lowering results and event reduction, improved patient adherence, and reaching LDL thresholds quickly. The panel also emphasizes educating patients about the need for multiple agents to avoid feelings of failure when single agents are insufficient. Dr. Ferdinand advocates for early and intensive treatment strategies to manage hyperlipidemia effectively.

title: Ferdinand: New agents, devices 'not enough' to address hypertension care disparities
summary: Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, emphasized that while new antihypertensive agents and devices show promise in controlling difficult-to-treat hypertension, they are insufficient to address care disparities. Ferdinand, a professor at Tulane University, highlighted the persistent white/Black mortality gap driven by cardiovascular disease (CVD) and hypertension. He stated that despite the availability of multiple antihypertensive agents and new renal denervation devices, blood pressure (BP) control remains poor, particularly in underrepresented groups. Ferdinand stressed the need to address structural barriers to care and improve the implementation of evidence-based treatments and lifestyle modifications. He also pointed out that accurate BP measurements, team-based care, and standardized medication protocols are crucial for better hypertension management.

title: LDL Cholesterol as a Performance Measure
summary: The cardiology panelists discuss the importance of screening for hyperlipidemia and familial hypercholesterolemia, emphasizing the role of LDL cholesterol as a critical performance measure. Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, highlights the necessity of continually measuring LDL levels to manage patient treatment effectively. He stresses that despite guidelines, LDL measurement remains crucial and should guide management decisions. Ferdinand points out the lack of a performance measure for LDL, arguing that without proper data, healthcare systems cannot improve lipid management. He also emphasizes the importance of early screening, particularly in children, to identify familial hypercholesterolemia and prevent early cardiovascular events. The discussion underscores the need for accurate data and adherence to treatment protocols to enhance patient outcomes in managing lipid levels.

title: Numbers to know for a healthy heart
summary: Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of death globally. Nicole Redmond emphasizes the importance of monitoring blood pressure, body weight, cholesterol, and blood sugar to prevent heart issues. The NHLBI promotes heart-health literacy and the adoption of "Life's Essential 8," a roadmap for maintaining heart health through diet, exercise, and lifestyle changes. Natalie A. Bello supports patients by reviewing these guidelines and offering practical advice. In Louisiana, the CHERISH study, co-investigated by Keith C. Ferdinand, focuses on community-based interventions to manage heart disease risk factors. Ferdinand advocates for partnerships between physicians and community health workers to address heart health proactively. His work highlights the effectiveness of community initiatives, like the Los Angeles Barbershop Blood Pressure Study, in reducing cardiovascular risks and disparities. NHLBI provides resources to promote heart-healthy living and celebrates American Heart Month to raise awareness.

title: Weight-dependent and weight-independent effects of dulaglutide on blood pressure in patients with type 2 diabetes ...
summary: The study investigates the weight-dependent and weight-independent effects of dulaglutide on blood pressure in patients with type 2 diabetes (T2D). Over approximately six months, dulaglutide 1.5 mg significantly reduced systolic blood pressure (SBP) and pulse pressure, with 36% of the SBP reduction and 14% of the pulse pressure reduction attributed to weight loss. Higher doses of dulaglutide (4.5 mg) showed greater reductions, primarily weight-mediated. Keith C. Ferdinand contributed significantly to the conception, design, analysis, and interpretation of the data, as well as drafting and critically revising the manuscript. The research highlights the importance of understanding the mechanisms behind dulaglutide's effects on blood pressure, which could inform future hypertension treatments.

title: New Guidance in Lowering LDL-C
summary: A panel of cardiologists, including Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, discussed updates from the 2022 ACC Expert Consensus Decision Pathway on nonstatin therapies for LDL-C lowering in managing atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk. The pathway updates data and targets, aligning closer to European guidelines, and emphasizes reducing LDL by 50% or more in high-risk patients using maximally tolerated statins and nonstatin therapies if necessary. Keith C. Ferdinand highlighted the importance of early and aggressive treatment in primary prevention, especially using tools like coronary calcium scores to detect disease early. The discussion also stressed personalized risk assessment and proactive management to prevent fatal events, moving beyond the traditional reactive approach.

title: Tulane medical students and mentor investigate racial health disparities
summary: Tulane medical students and their mentor, Dr. Keith C. Ferdinand, have been investigating racial health disparities, particularly in heart disease and hypertension among Black Americans. Dr. Ferdinand, the Gerald S. Berenson chair of preventative cardiology at Tulane University School of Medicine, has guided students in various research projects, including a study that used text alerts to remind Black adults to take blood pressure medications, which significantly improved adherence and lowered blood pressure. Their research was published in the Cardiac Disparities Special Edition of the American Heart Journal Open. Dr. Ferdinand emphasizes the need for a team-based approach involving not just physicians but also nurses, public health officials, and community members to address these disparities. The students' work, ranging from legislative reviews on sugary drinks to neighborhood surveys, aims to understand and mitigate the social factors affecting health outcomes in minority populations.

title: The Role of Lipoprotein A in Lipid Lowering
summary: In the discussion on "The Role of Lipoprotein A in Lipid Lowering," Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, emphasizes the importance of Lp(a) as a causal agent for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. He highlights the need for increased attention and measurement of Lp(a), noting its high prevalence and significant risk factors. Dr. Ferdinand engages with other experts, including Mary McGowan, Erin D. Michos, and Payal Kohli, to explore the implications of elevated Lp(a) levels and the current lack of widespread testing in the U.S. He underscores the actionable steps that can be taken now, such as using statins and PCSK9 inhibitors, and advocates for routine Lp(a) measurement to better manage cardiovascular risk.

title: Clinical Pearls on Lipid Management
summary: A panel of expert cardiologists, including Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, discussed clinical pearls for managing hyperlipidemia. Ferdinand emphasized the importance of recognizing high-risk patients early and using high-intensity statins. He also highlighted the need for culturally and literacy-appropriate education. The discussion covered combining lipid-lowering agents to avoid toxicity, the significance of measuring lipoprotein(a) levels, and practical steps to reduce frustrations in using nonstatin therapies. Ferdinand thanked Dr. McGowan for her work with the Family Heart Foundation and stressed the importance of screening and educating patients about familial hypercholesterolemia. The session concluded with a call to focus on prevention and personalized care to improve patient outcomes.

title: Statin Intolerance
summary: In a discussion on managing statin intolerance, prominent cardiologists, including Keith C. Ferdinand, emphasized the importance of individualized treatment plans and the use of nonstatin therapies when necessary. Keith C. Ferdinand highlighted the complexity of defining and identifying statin intolerance and the significant role of the nocebo effect, where patients' perceptions of harm from statins can influence their symptoms. He stressed the need to screen for secondary causes of intolerance, such as hypothyroidism, and to consider alternative dosing strategies. Ferdinand advocated for a patient-centered approach, acknowledging the real experiences of patients and ensuring that treatment plans are flexible and comprehensive, incorporating lifestyle optimization and nonstatin options as needed.

title: Disparities in Managing Patients
summary: Expert cardiologists, including Keith C. Ferdinand, discussed disparities in managing hyperlipidemia, focusing on gender, racial, and ethnic inequities. Keith C. Ferdinand emphasized the unequal utilization of LDL cholesterol measurement tools and medications across different demographics. He highlighted the need for equitable treatment regardless of race, ethnicity, sex, gender, geography, and socioeconomic status. The discussion included insights on the underuse of statins in women and minority groups, with women less likely to be initiated on high-intensity statins and more likely to discontinue them. Ferdinand also mentioned efforts to address these disparities through community-based initiatives, such as using nurse practitioners and community health workers to control risk factors in high-risk populations.

title: Long-term efficacy and safety of PCSK9 inhibitors
summary: The long-term efficacy and safety of PCSK9 inhibitors were evaluated in a discussion led by Dr. Keith C. Ferdinand. The FOURIER trial, involving over 27,000 patients with stable atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), demonstrated significant LDL-C reduction with evolocumab over a median follow-up of 5 years. The subsequent FOURIER-OLE study followed approximately 6,600 patients for up to 8.4 years, confirming sustained efficacy and safety. Notably, patients who started on evolocumab early exhibited better outcomes, including a reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) and cardiovascular deaths, emphasizing the importance of early initiation. Dr. Ferdinand highlighted the relevance of these findings, reinforcing the long-term benefits and safety of PCSK9 inhibitors in lipid management.

title: Real-World Data on Achieving LDL Thresholds
summary: Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, highlighted the importance of real-world data in assessing the achievement of LDL-C thresholds in patients at elevated cardiovascular risk. He introduced Mary McGowan, MD, FNLA, who presented data from the Family Heart Database, which includes diagnostic, procedural, prescription, and laboratory data on over 324 million individuals in the US from 2012 to 2021. The analysis revealed that 72% of high-risk patients never achieved their LDL-C targets, and those who did only maintained these levels for a short duration. The data also indicated that 80% of healthcare providers did not prescribe combination lipid-lowering therapies, despite guidelines recommending such approaches. This underscores the need for better adherence to guidelines and patient education on the importance of lipid-lowering therapies.

title: Novel Targets for Lipid Level Lowering and Implementation of Lipid Therapy
summary: Medical experts discuss novel targets for lowering lipid levels and the implementation of lipid therapy, emphasizing the importance of screening for lipoprotein(a) [Lp(a)] and reviewing ongoing trials. Keith C. Ferdinand, MD, FACC, FAHA, FNLA, highlights the importance of Lp(a) screening, especially in Black individuals who have the highest levels of Lp(a) and are at greater risk. He discusses advancements in targeted therapies, including antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) and small interfering RNAs (siRNAs), which show promising results in reducing Lp(a) levels. Ferdinand also references the GOULD registry, tracking the effectiveness of lipid-lowering therapies in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) and underscores the need for better implementation of guidelines to improve lipid level management.

title: Eight Emory School of Nursing faculty, alumni named American Academy of Nursing Fellows
summary: Eight faculty and alumni from Emory University's Nell Hodgson Woodruff School of Nursing have been named Fellows of the American Academy of Nursing (AAN) 2023 Class. This prestigious recognition honors their significant contributions to nursing. Calli Cook, DNP, APRN, FNP-C, FAANP, is highlighted for her work in neurology, specifically improving care quality for patients with migraines and other headache disorders. She has reduced unnecessary neuroimaging and served on national quality measures task forces and committees within the American Academy of Neurology. Cook's efforts have enhanced headache care practices and patient experiences.

title: Wesley Mizutani, MD: SB 496 Expands Insurance Coverage for Biomarkers
summary: In October 2023, California Governor Gavin Newsom signed SB 496 into law, mandating insurance coverage for medically necessary biomarker testing by Medi-Cal and private insurers. This legislation aims to improve patient access to individualized treatments by covering current and future biomarkers across various medical specialties. Wesley Mizutani, MD, a rheumatologist at Optum and member of the Alliance for Patient Access, highlighted the importance of this law. He explained that biomarkers are critical for selecting the most effective drugs for patients, particularly in rheumatology. Without insurance coverage, the cost of biomarker testing could prevent patients from receiving optimal treatments, potentially worsening their conditions. Mizutani emphasized that the implementation and oversight of the legislation are crucial to ensure its effectiveness in improving healthcare outcomes. He has no relevant disclosures to report.

title: CareerPhysician Welcomes Dr. Bruce Rubin to the Child Health Advisory Council
summary: CareerPhysician, LLC announced the addition of Dr. Bruce Rubin to the Child Health Advisory Council (CHAC). Dr. Rubin, a distinguished pediatric pulmonologist and professor, brings extensive experience from his roles at Virginia Commonwealth University and Wake Forest School of Medicine. At CHAC, he will leverage his expertise to mentor emerging child health leaders, enhance medical education, and improve pediatric healthcare delivery. Dr. Rubin's significant contributions include over 300 research publications, nine patents, and numerous awards. His appointment aligns with CareerPhysician's mission to support the development of pediatric leadership and improve child health outcomes.

title: Southlake's CareerPhysician Names New Member of Child Health Advisory Council
summary: Southlake-based CareerPhysician LLC has appointed Dr. Bruce Rubin to its Child Health Advisory Council (CHAC), an advisory group of senior child health leaders. Rubin is a renowned expert in pediatric medicine and a board-certified pediatric pulmonologist. He previously served as professor and chair emeritus of pediatrics at Virginia Commonwealth University and held significant roles at Wake Forest School of Medicine. Rubin's extensive experience in pediatric healthcare and academic leadership will be instrumental in guiding CHAC's initiatives, which aim to promote leadership best practices, enhance medical education, and improve healthcare delivery for pediatric patients. Rubin expressed his enthusiasm for joining the council, emphasizing the importance of mentorship and support for current and future child health leaders.

title: 'Grandad started to forget things' - Josie Cooper on her Alzheimer's fundraising walk
summary: Josie Cooper, 50, is participating in a sponsored walk to raise funds for the Alzheimer’s Society in memory of her Grandad Joseph Draper, who passed away from Alzheimer's 15 years ago. The Memory Walk will take place in Windsor on September 10th. Josephine, a Romany Gypsy from Chelmsford, aims to support those affected by this debilitating illness. She recalls her Grandad's gradual decline, from an active horse breeder to someone who couldn’t recognize his family or care for himself. Josephine’s family, particularly her Granny, refused to place him in a home, opting instead for round-the-clock care. Josephine has already raised over £1,000, primarily from the Gypsy and Traveller community, and plans to continue supporting families dealing with Alzheimer’s.

title: Eliminating Anticompetitive PBM Practices Are Free Market Reforms
hco: PACIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY
summary: Wayne Winegarden highlights the malfunctioning of the current drug pricing market due to government-driven, third-party payer systems, which misalign the interests of patients and pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs). These misalignments inflate patients' out-of-pocket costs and encourage the use of expensive drugs over affordable alternatives. Winegarden supports Congressional proposals like the Delinking Revenue from Unfair Gouging Act and the Modernizing and Ensuring PBM Accountability Act, which aim to address these issues by ensuring full disclosure of drug costs, prices, and discounts, and breaking the link between PBM compensation and list prices. These reforms target anticompetitive practices such as "spread pricing" and aim to improve market efficiency, drug affordability, and overall healthcare costs.

title: Reforming PBM Practices Would Improve The Pharmacy Market
hco: PACIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY
summary: Wayne Winegarden discusses the adverse effects of Pharmacy Benefit Manager (PBM) practices on the pharmacy market and patients. He highlights that PBMs create perverse incentives leading to high out-of-pocket costs and restricted access to prescriptions. Winegarden notes that current Congressional proposals, such as the Delinking Revenue from Unfair Gouging Act and the Modernizing and Ensuring PBM Accountability Act, aim to mitigate these issues. These reforms would prohibit PBMs from steering patients to their own pharmacies and eliminate detrimental pricing practices. Despite these efforts, the dynamic nature of the market means that continuous adjustments are necessary. Winegarden emphasizes that these pro-market reforms are crucial for reducing patient costs, supporting small pharmacies, and fostering a more patient-centered healthcare system.

title: Greater Immigration Can Alleviate Troubling Skilled Nurse Shortage
hco: PACIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY
summary: Wayne Winegarden highlights the severe shortage of skilled nurses in the U.S., exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with many nurses leaving due to stress and burnout. Despite the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projecting 203,200 annual openings for registered nurses over the next decade, the shortage is expected to worsen, with a projected gap of 200,000 to 450,000 nurses by 2025. Winegarden argues that increasing immigration of foreign-educated nurses could address this shortage. However, current U.S. visa policies and processing delays hinder this solution. He urges Congress to increase the number of employment-based green cards and streamline processing to prevent a healthcare crisis.

title: The Inflation Reduction Act Was Only The Beginning
hco: PACIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY
summary: The Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) has sparked significant concerns about its potential to lead to a fully socialized healthcare system. Wayne Winegarden highlights that less than a year after the IRA's enactment, Senators Amy Klobuchar, Peter Welch, and 23 Democratic colleagues proposed the SMART Prices Act, which aims to expand Medicare's ability to negotiate drug prices. This move is seen as a step towards comprehensive price controls on innovative medicines, which could hinder pharmaceutical companies' ability to recoup their investment costs, thereby stifling innovation. Winegarden argues that the IRA and subsequent proposals exacerbate existing issues in the healthcare system, such as rising costs and declining quality, by introducing more bureaucratic control and reducing patient access to new treatments. He emphasizes the need to reverse the trend towards socialized medicine to ensure continued drug innovation and patient access to life-saving treatments.

title: OBE for Leeds pioneer in palliative care
hco: PACIFIC RESEARCH INSTITUTE FOR PUBLIC POLICY
summary: Kerry Jackson, the Chief Executive of St Gemma’s Hospice in Leeds, has been awarded an OBE for her exceptional contributions to palliative care. Under her leadership, St Gemma’s Hospice received an Outstanding rating from the Care Quality Commission and became the world's first University Teaching Hospice. Kerry, who joined the hospice in 2010, has a diverse background in healthcare roles, including positions at the Department of Health, Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, and Nova Healthcare. She holds a BA in Economics and English, a PG Diploma in Project Leadership, and is a Chartered Accountant. Kerry credits the pioneering vision of the Sisters of Cross and Passion, who founded the hospice in 1978, and acknowledges the support of the Leeds community in her acceptance of the OBE.

title: Local medical officials say COVID-19 cases are on the rise again
summary: Local medical officials in Johnson City, Tennessee, report a significant rise in COVID-19 cases. Jamie Swift, Chief Infection Prevention Officer for Ballad Health, highlighted the increase in hospital admissions, rising from 10-12 cases to 120-150 daily, and from six to seven hospitalizations to 47. Despite this rise, current numbers are still lower than during the pandemic's peak. Swift emphasized the importance of community awareness and safe practices but noted no immediate return to mask mandates. Sullivan County Regional Health Department Medical Director Dr. Steven May also reported increased cases but less severity compared to 2020. A third booster shot is expected to be available soon.

title: Vanderbilt University honors emeritus and emerita faculty, deans
summary: Vanderbilt University honored 33 retiring faculty members and four outgoing deans during the Commencement ceremony on May 12 at Bridgestone Arena. These individuals were awarded the title of emerita or emeritus faculty for their years of service. The honorees include figures like David Blackbourn, Peter T. Cummings, and Kathryn M. Edwards, who was recognized as Professor Emerita of Pediatrics. The recognition process involves recommendations from the dean and the chancellor, followed by approval from the Board of Trust. This annual event celebrates the dedication and achievements of the university’s esteemed faculty and deans.

title: No Elevated Risk for Stroke Seen After COVID-19 Bivalent Vaccine Receipt
summary: A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found no elevated stroke risk for Medicare beneficiaries aged 65 and older following COVID-19 bivalent vaccine receipt. Researchers, including Yun Lu, Ph.D., from the FDA, analyzed stroke risk after administration of either brand of the COVID-19 bivalent vaccine and concomitant administration with a high-dose or adjuvanted influenza vaccine. No significant associations were observed between the vaccines and stroke outcomes within specific risk windows. However, there were some associations noted for nonhemorrhagic stroke and transient ischemic attack in certain cases. Kathryn M. Edwards, M.D., along with Marie R. Griffin, M.D., M.P.H., highlighted the study's value in providing reassurance about COVID-19 boosters in an accompanying editorial.

title: 180 Life Sciences Corp board member Sir Marc Feldmann resigns
summary: Sir Marc Feldmann, Ph.D., a board member of 180 Life Sciences Corp, has resigned from his position effective immediately. 180 Life Sciences Corp is a biotechnology company focused on developing therapies for inflammatory diseases, fibrosis, and pain. Feldmann, a distinguished immunologist and academic, submitted his resignation without any disagreements with the company's operations, policies, or practices. The announcement was made through a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), which did not provide reasons for his resignation or mention any plans for a replacement. Sir Marc Feldmann's contributions to the company were significant, given his expertise and renown in the field of immunology.

title: Novel phenolate salts of bioactive agents: Cannabidiol phenolate salts
summary: This study explores the creation and evaluation of novel cannabidiol (CBD) phenolate salts to improve CBD's water solubility and bioavailability. CBD, used for treating anxiety, insomnia, chronic pain, and inflammation, suffers from poor water solubility, limiting its effectiveness. The research synthesizes CBD salts with metal and ammonium counterions, achieving high yields through a straightforward dehydration reaction. The salts, characterized using FT-IR, NMR spectroscopy, and CHN analysis, show significantly enhanced water solubility (110 to 1606 times greater than pure CBD). Pharmacokinetic studies in rats indicate improved properties compared to pure CBD. Sir Marc Feldmann contributed to this pioneering work by co-authoring the study, which marks the first report on bioactive phenolate salts of CBD, addressing its solubility issues and paving the way for broader applications in pharmaceuticals.

title: Lupus Research Alliance Unites the U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA) & Lupus Community to Launch Novel ...
summary: The Lupus Research Alliance (LRA) has launched the Lupus Accelerating Breakthroughs Consortium (Lupus ABC) in collaboration with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and other stakeholders. This public-private partnership aims to address scientific challenges in lupus drug development and accelerate the creation of personalized treatments. Lupus, a complex autoimmune disorder, disproportionately affects women and communities of color. The partnership will focus on refining measurement tools and incorporating patient perspectives into the drug development process. Veronica Vargas Lupo, co-lead of the Consortium's Lupus Voices Council, emphasized the importance of patient involvement in designing clinical trials and measuring outcomes to develop tailored therapies.

title: Free International Myeloma Foundation forum is back in March |...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) will resume its in-person Patient and Family Seminar in March 2023 after a three-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Scheduled for March 17-18 in Boca Raton, Florida, the event will also be available virtually. It aims to provide myeloma patients and their families with the latest information on treatments and clinical trials from leading experts. The seminar will feature speakers such as Yelak Biru, Brian G. M. Durie, Beth Faiman, and Sigurður Kristinsson. Susie Durie, IMF's founder and director of global patient initiatives, initiated the first seminar in 1993 to bridge the gap between patients and myeloma experts, enhancing patient education and outcomes. The IMF has since conducted over 250 seminars worldwide, fostering a supportive community for myeloma patients. Safety measures, including masking, social distancing, and vaccination records, will be enforced at the event.

title: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) Honors 2023 Research Achievement Awardees, Dr. Maria-Victoria ...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) announced the recipients of the 2023 Robert A. Kyle Achievement Award and Brian G.M. Durie Outstanding Achievement Award. The awards ceremony will take place on June 8 at the 14th Annual International Myeloma Working Group (IMWG) Summit in Frankfurt, Germany. Dr. Maria-Victoria Mateos received the Robert A. Kyle Lifetime Achievement Award for her significant contributions to myeloma research and clinical trials. Dr. Thomas G. Martin, III was honored with the Brian G.M. Durie Outstanding Achievement Award for his pioneering work in multiple myeloma research, including novel treatments and immunotherapies. Dr. Brian G.M. Durie, Chairman of the Board and Chief Scientific Officer of the IMF, highlighted the importance of these awards and praised the recipients for their exceptional contributions to the field. Dr. Durie also chairs the IMWG Summit and leads the IMF’s Black Swan Research Initiative®.

title: International Myeloma Foundation Celebrates ODAC Meeting Outcome on Minimal Residual Disease (MRD) Testing ...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) celebrated a milestone as the Oncologic Drug Advisory Committee (ODAC) approved the use of minimal residual disease (MRD) testing for accelerated approval of multiple myeloma drugs. This decision, led by IMF’s Chief Scientific Officer Dr. Brian G.M. Durie, is the result of nearly a decade of research by the IMF and i2TEAMM. Dr. Durie’s leadership and presentation at the ODAC meeting were crucial in this achievement, which aims to expedite the approval process for new myeloma treatments, potentially reducing the current 9-12 year timeline.

title: World-Renowned Scientist, S. Vincent Rajkumar, MD, Appointed as Chairman-Elect of the Board of Directors of the ...
summary: S. Vincent Rajkumar, MD, a renowned myeloma clinician and researcher, has been appointed Chairman-Elect of the Board of Directors of the International Myeloma Foundation (IMF). He will assume full responsibilities in Spring 2024, succeeding Brian G.M. Durie, MD, who will become Chairman Emeritus. Dr. Rajkumar, a Professor of Medicine at the Mayo Clinic, has significantly contributed to myeloma research and clinical advancements, transforming it into a manageable condition for many patients. His leadership is expected to drive the IMF's mission forward, focusing on innovative treatments and improved patient outcomes. Dr. Rajkumar has published over 480 peer-reviewed papers and led pivotal clinical trials, earning several prestigious awards for his work. The IMF Board unanimously supports his appointment, anticipating that his expertise will further their efforts in research, education, support, and advocacy for myeloma patients worldwide.

title: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) Welcomes Dr. S. Vincent Rajkumar as Chairperson of the Board
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) has appointed Dr. S. Vincent Rajkumar as the new Chairperson of the Board. Dr. Rajkumar is a distinguished myeloma clinician and researcher, currently serving as a Professor of Medicine at the Mayo Clinic and holding various editorial and committee roles in prestigious medical journals and organizations. He has made significant contributions to myeloma research, notably leading clinical trials that resulted in the approval of thalidomide for myeloma treatment in the U.S. With over 480 peer-reviewed publications, Dr. Rajkumar is highly respected in his field. His accolades include the Jan Waldenstrom Lifetime Achievement Award and the Mayo Clinic Distinguished Investigator Award. As Chairperson, Dr. Rajkumar aims to enhance IMF’s global impact on research, advocacy, patient support, and physician education, striving towards a cure for myeloma.

title: Indian-origin doctor is new chairman of International Myeloma Foundation
summary: Dr. S. Vincent Rajkumar, an esteemed professor of medicine at Mayo Clinic, has been appointed as the chairman-elect of the Board of Directors of the International Myeloma Foundation (IMF). He succeeds Brian G.M. Durie, the co-founder and chairman for 33 years, who will not seek re-election but will remain on the Board as Chairman Emeritus. Dr. Rajkumar, a leading voice in the myeloma community, aims to continue and build upon Dr. Durie's legacy. He is deeply involved in the myeloma field, serving on various committees and as an editor for notable medical journals. His research contributions include pivotal clinical trials that led to the approval of thalidomide for myeloma treatment in the U.S. Dr. Rajkumar has published over 480 peer-reviewed papers and has received multiple prestigious awards, such as the Jan Waldenstrom Lifetime Achievement Award. The IMF, founded in 1999, is the largest global foundation focusing specifically on multiple myeloma.

title: Sustained MRD Negativity Achieved With Isa-KRd in Newly Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
summary: The GMMG-CONCEPT trial investigated a quadruplet regimen (Isa-KRd) for treating newly diagnosed high-risk multiple myeloma. The regimen combined isatuximab, carfilzomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone. The study showed high rates of measurable residual disease (MRD) negativity, with 62.6% of transplant-eligible and 46.2% of transplant-ineligible patients maintaining MRD negativity for at least one year. Median progression-free survival was not reached after more than three years. Dr. Lisa B. Leypoldt presented these findings at the 2023 International Myeloma Society Annual Meeting. S. Vincent Rajkumar, MD, Professor of Medicine at Mayo Clinic, moderated the session and provided expert commentary on the trial and related studies.

title: Mode of progression in smoldering multiple myeloma: a study of 406 patients | Blood Cancer Journal
summary: This study investigates the progression of smoldering multiple myeloma (SMM) to multiple myeloma (MM) in 406 patients. The research, conducted at Mayo Clinic, used the 2018 Mayo 20/2/20 criteria for risk stratification. Key findings include that 45% of high-risk SMM patients on active surveillance developed end-organ damage at progression, with bone lesions and anemia being the most common myeloma-defining events (MDEs). S. Vincent Rajkumar, MD, contributed to the study design, data collection, and manuscript preparation. The study highlights the variability in clinical management and the potential benefits of early intervention in high-risk SMM patients to prevent significant end-organ damage.

title: The fight over what's real (and what's not) on dissociative identity disorder TikTok
summary: The article discusses the controversy surrounding Dissociative Identity Disorder (DID) on TikTok, where users share their experiences, leading to a rise in self-diagnosis among young audiences. Dr. Matthew A. Robinson from McLean Hospital highlighted the issue in a lecture, expressing concern that social media may be contributing to an increase in potentially inaccurate DID claims. He used TikTok examples to illustrate his point, suggesting that some representations of DID on the platform might be sensationalized or even fake. This stance led to backlash from the DID community on TikTok, who felt discredited and stigmatized. The article also explores the broader implications of social media on mental health self-diagnosis and the evolving presentation of DID online. Despite the controversy, Robinson and his peers emphasize the need for accurate diagnosis and treatment, while acknowledging the potential harm caused by misrepresentations on social media.

title: March's Myeloma Action Month leans into bringing hope through action
summary: Myeloma Action Month (MAM), observed each March, focuses on raising awareness about multiple myeloma and supporting those affected. This year's theme is "bringing hope through action," aiming to educate policymakers, researchers, health professionals, and the public about the disease, which accounts for 10% of all blood cancers. The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF), supported by the Global Myeloma Action Network (GMAN), coordinates the event. Yelak Biru, IMF president and CEO, emphasized the importance of collective action to empower patients, accelerate research, and raise awareness. Biru, a 28-year myeloma survivor, highlighted the need for community engagement and shared stories to inspire resilience and hope. Various events, including workshops, fundraisers, and social media campaigns, will be held throughout March to support this cause.

title: International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) Launches #MyelomaActionMonth for 2024 March Myeloma Action Month
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) has launched the #MyelomaActionMonth campaign for March 2024, aimed at raising global awareness and encouraging action for multiple myeloma. Partnering with the Global Myeloma Action Network (GMAN), the campaign invites individuals to share their stories of resilience and hope, highlighting the question, “What Does Myeloma Mean to Me?” Yelak Biru, IMF President & CEO and a 28-year myeloma survivor, emphasized the campaign's goal of empowering patients, accelerating research, and breaking the silence around myeloma. Through various events, including Facebook Live sessions and a 5K run, the IMF aims to unite the global community in support of myeloma patients and research.

title: Free International Myeloma Foundation forum is back in March |...
summary: The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) will resume its in-person Patient and Family Seminar in March 2023 after a three-year hiatus due to COVID-19. Scheduled for March 17-18 in Boca Raton, Florida, the event aims to provide myeloma patients and their families with the latest information on treatments and clinical trials, as well as opportunities to connect with others. Yelak Biru, IMF’s president and CEO, emphasized the seminars' educational and inspirational value, highlighting their role in fostering community and providing a platform for difficult questions. Biru, who is also a myeloma patient, finds the seminars invigorating and educational. The IMF has organized over 250 educational seminars globally since its founding in 1990.

title: World-Renowned Scientist, S. Vincent Rajkumar, MD, Appointed as Chairman-Elect of the Board of Directors of the ...
summary: Dr. S. Vincent Rajkumar, a renowned myeloma clinician and researcher, has been appointed Chairman-Elect of the Board of the International Myeloma Foundation (IMF). He will assume the full role in Spring 2024, succeeding Dr. Brian G.M. Durie, who will become Chairman Emeritus while continuing his other roles. Dr. Rajkumar's appointment was unanimously supported by the Board, including IMF President and CEO, Yelak Biru. Mr. Biru expressed excitement about the new strategic direction under Dr. Rajkumar's leadership, emphasizing targeted innovation and improved patient outcomes. Dr. Rajkumar, a Professor at the Mayo Clinic, has made significant contributions to myeloma research, including pivotal clinical trials and numerous publications. His leadership aims to build on Dr. Durie's legacy and enhance treatment accessibility and innovation for myeloma patients.

title: Goal of Myeloma Action Month? Telling the community's stories. –...
summary: The goal of Myeloma Action Month (MAM), observed every March, is to raise awareness of multiple myeloma by sharing the community’s stories. The International Myeloma Foundation (IMF) is spearheading this initiative with the #MYelomaSTORY campaign, encouraging patients and caregivers to share their experiences. Yelak Biru, IMF’s president and CEO, and a 27-year myeloma survivor, emphasizes the importance of living well with myeloma and urges the community to share their stories. The campaign includes social media activities, infographics, video mashups, and virtual support groups to spread awareness. The IMF also offers in-person events and educational resources to further support the cause.

title: Newmarket families keep up fight, march against blood cancer
summary: Music teacher Jocelyn Kervin, diagnosed with multiple myeloma in 2019, has been actively participating in the Newmarket Myeloma March to raise awareness and funds for research. Despite undergoing multiple treatments, including chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant, Kervin remains committed to the cause. The fifth annual Newmarket Myeloma March, part of a series of events by Myeloma Canada, aims to bring attention to the disease and improve early diagnosis and treatment. Martine Elias, executive director of Myeloma Canada, emphasized the importance of such events in raising awareness and funds to enhance the lives of those affected by myeloma and move closer to a cure. The Newmarket event on September 24 hopes to raise $50,000, with Kervin's team, Jocelyn’s Joggers, aiming for $5,000.

title: Health Canada Authorizes TECVAYLI™ (teclistamab injection), a First-in-Class Bispecific Antibody for the Treatment of ...
summary: Health Canada has authorized TECVAYLI™ (teclistamab injection) for treating adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received at least three prior lines of therapy. This approval is based on the Phase 1/2 MajesTEC-1 study, which showed significant and durable responses in patients. Martine Elias, Executive Director of Myeloma Canada, highlighted the importance of this approval, stating that it offers new hope for patients running out of treatment options. TECVAYLI™ targets CD3 on T-cells and BCMA on myeloma cells, promoting T-cell activation and subsequent lysis of malignant cells.

title: Bike to Beat Myeloma to be held in Red Deer County
summary: The 2nd annual Red Deer County Myeloma Canada Ride: Bike to Beat Myeloma will take place on May 13 at Spruce View Hall, aiming to raise $300,000 nationally. The event is part of a broader effort across seven Canadian municipalities to support myeloma research and awareness. Martine Elias, executive director of Myeloma Canada, emphasized the importance of such events in raising awareness and critical funds for life-saving research to find a cure for myeloma, a common form of blood cancer. Bev Dunn, a myeloma survivor, and Mayor Ken Johnston will participate in the event. The ride offers different routes for cyclists of varying skill levels and includes a virtual option.

title: Cancer treatment process needs update
summary: There is a revolution in cancer treatment shifting from traditional methods to precision medicine, which targets tumors more effectively and reduces side effects. However, complex regulatory processes and fragmented healthcare systems in Canada hinder access to these innovative therapies. The report "Getting Better, Faster: The Case for Optimizing Access to Precision Medicines in the Wake of the Revolution in Cancer Care" highlights the need for reforms in drug approval, pricing, and data collection to improve access. Martine Elias, the executive director of Myeloma Canada, co-authored the report, emphasizing the urgency for government action to ensure timely access to life-saving treatments.

title: Residents march for Multiple Myeloma
summary: Dozens of residents gathered at Tai Chi Park in Marina Park for the 7th annual Thunder Bay Multiple Myeloma March, part of Myeloma Canada’s 15th annual nationwide event. The march aims to raise awareness and funds for multiple myeloma, an incurable blood cancer diagnosed in 11 Canadians daily. Michelle Oana, Director of Development and Community Relations, highlighted the importance of recognizing symptoms like bone pain and anemia for early diagnosis. Martine Elias, Executive Director of Myeloma Canada, emphasized the critical need for awareness and funding to ensure quicker diagnoses and better outcomes for patients. The event in Thunder Bay set a financial goal of $5,000, contributing to Myeloma Canada’s national objective of raising $750,000. Elias stressed that events like these are essential for advancing research and improving the lives of those affected by myeloma.

title: 'Myeloma doesn't discriminate': Penticton woman honouring late husband by raising awareness about rare disease ...
summary: Kristin Weberg, a Penticton woman, is raising awareness about multiple myeloma, a rare and incurable blood cancer, in memory of her late husband, Jamie. Jamie, a pastor and chaplain, passed away in 2015 at the age of 36 after an 18-month battle with the disease. Kristin and her children are participating in the Multiple Myeloma March in Kelowna to raise funds and awareness. The march supports Canadian research, equitable healthcare access, and improved lives for those affected by myeloma. Martine Elias, executive director of Myeloma Canada, emphasized the importance of the march in raising awareness and funds to improve patient outcomes and move closer to a cure.

title: Dr Mikhael on Unmet Needs to Be Addressed in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, professor at the Translational Genomics Research Institute and chief medical officer of the International Myeloma Foundation, addresses significant unmet needs in multiple myeloma treatment. He emphasizes the urgency for developing effective treatments until a cure is found, particularly for high-risk populations like African Americans. Mikhael discusses the importance of redefining diagnostic criteria and optimizing treatment strategies for smoldering multiple myeloma. He also highlights the challenges in determining the optimal duration of induction therapy, the role of transplant in the era of quadruplet regimens, and the integration of CAR T-cell therapy. In heavily relapsed settings, optimizing therapy sequencing to maximize patient quality and quantity of life remains a challenge. Mikhael stresses the importance of health equity and patient-centric care. Despite these challenges, he is optimistic about recent research advancements and hopeful for continued improvements in patient care and outcomes in multiple myeloma.

title: Quadruplet Therapy for Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, MEd, FRCPC, FACP, from the Translational Genomics Research Institute, presented at the 2024 Great Debates & Updates in Hematologic Malignancies meeting in New York. He discussed the potential of quadruplet therapy as the new standard-of-care for multiple myeloma (MM) patients, both transplant-eligible and ineligible. Dr. Mikhael highlighted results from the phase 3 PERSEUS, IsKia, and MAIA trials, showing improved outcomes with quadruplet therapy over triplet therapy. Specifically, the PERSEUS trial demonstrated better 4-year progression-free survival with D-VRd (daratumumab, bortezomib, lenalidomide, dexamethasone) compared to VRd. The IsKia trial showed MRD negativity benefits with isatuximab, carfilzomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (KRD) versus KRD alone. Dr. Mikhael emphasized optimizing drug use, particularly advocating for reduced dexamethasone dosages to minimize side effects. His contributions underscore the evolving treatment landscape for MM.

title: Dr Joseph Mikhael: Researchers, Organizations Must Collaborate to Address Disparities in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, MEd, FRCPC, FACP, emphasizes the critical need for collaboration among researchers and organizations to address disparities in access to multiple myeloma (MM) treatments. As the chief medical officer of the International Myeloma Foundation, Dr. Mikhael highlights the socioeconomic barriers that prevent equitable access to advanced therapies like CAR T-cell therapy, noting that less than 5% of recipients have a household income below $50,000. He underscores the importance of a comprehensive approach that involves regulatory, industry, healthcare provider, and social efforts to ensure these therapies are accessible to all eligible patients. Dr. Mikhael advocates for increased collaboration to enhance recruitment and participation of underrepresented populations in MM clinical trials, emphasizing the need for sustainable, long-term solutions and more diverse geographical trial sites.

title: Dr Mikhael on Research Developments in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, a professor at the Translational Genomics Research Institute and chief medical officer of the International Myeloma Foundation, discussed significant advancements and ongoing research in multiple myeloma at the 2023 ASH Annual Meeting. He emphasized the growing importance of multiple myeloma research, covering topics such as smoldering myeloma, frontline therapy, and strategies for early and late relapsed disease. Mikhael highlighted the superiority of quadruplet regimens over triplet regimens in frontline settings, particularly for transplant-eligible patients, showcasing combinations like daratumumab plus KRd and isatuximab-irfc plus KRd. He also noted ongoing research in transplant-ineligible populations, such as the phase 3 IMROZ trial. Additionally, Mikhael discussed efforts to improve CAR T-cell therapy and bispecific antibodies, aiming for more tolerable and accessible treatments. Overall, Mikhael concluded that impactful research is being conducted in both frontline and relapsed settings in multiple myeloma.

title: CAR-T or Bispecific Antibodies for MM
summary: At the 2024 Great Debates and Updates in Hematological Malignancies in New York, Dr. Joseph Mikhael from the Translational Genomics Research Institute in Phoenix, Arizona, provided expert insights on choosing between CAR-T cell therapy and bispecific antibodies for treating multiple myeloma (MM). He emphasized the importance of disease control when considering CAR-T therapy, suggesting bispecific antibodies for patients with uncontrolled disease due to their quicker implementation. Dr. Mikhael recommended prioritizing CAR-T therapy first for eligible patients to allow a treatment-free interval before considering bispecific antibodies at relapse. This strategy ensures effective use of T-cells and optimizes patient outcomes.

title: Dr Mikhael on the Utility of Isa-KRd in Newly Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, discusses the utility of the quadruplet regimen of isatuximab, carfilzomib, lenalidomide, and dexamethasone (Isa-KRd) for newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients, as observed in the phase 3 IsKia trial. The trial, presented at the 2023 ASH Annual Meeting, showed higher minimal residual disease (MRD) negativity rates post-consolidation with Isa-KRd compared to KRd alone. Mikhael highlights the trial's significance in reinforcing the superiority of four-drug regimens over three, both for patients undergoing autologous stem cell transplant (ASCT) and those who are not. The study's focus on MRD status as a primary endpoint instead of progression-free survival (PFS) is notable, as MRD negativity is a surrogate marker for future PFS and overall survival. Mikhael emphasizes the need for further research to optimize the administration of these drugs and tailor treatments based on patient risk profiles, aiming to balance treatment efficacy and quality of life.

title: Dr Joseph Mikhael on Strategies to Increase Diversity in Multiple Myeloma Trials
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, MEd, FRCPC, FACP, chief medical officer of the International Myeloma Foundation, emphasizes the need for increased diversity in multiple myeloma (MM) clinical trials. He highlights the significant underrepresentation of African Americans in these trials, despite them constituting approximately 20% of MM patients in the U.S., with participation rates historically between 5% to 8%. Mikhael suggests several strategies to address this issue, including addressing systemic racism, improving access to healthcare, building trust within the system, and ensuring clinical trials have diversity officers. Additionally, he advocates for culturally sensitive care training for healthcare providers and greater community engagement to build trust and confidence in clinical trials.

title: Treating Patients With Multiply Relapsed Myeloma
summary: At the 2023 Lymphoma, Leukemia & Myeloma Congress in New York, Joseph Mikhael, MD, from the Translational Genomics Research Institute, City of Hope Cancer Center, shared insights on treating multiply relapsed myeloma. He emphasized the use of XP01 inhibitors, particularly selinexor, which has become more manageable with weekly dosing and anti-emetics. Dr. Mikhael also highlighted the potential of CELMoDs (cereblon E3 ligase modulators), like iberdomide and mezigdomide, as future treatments, especially for older or less fit patients. He stressed the importance of avoiding alkylators before T-cell therapies and adhering to principles such as repeating prior therapies and monitoring discordant disease. Dr. Mikhael's contributions focus on practical approaches and the evolving landscape of myeloma treatment.

title: Dr Joseph Mikhael on Strategies to Increase CAR T-Cell Therapy Access
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, MEd, FRCPC, FACP, chief medical officer of the International Myeloma Foundation, discussed the challenges in manufacturing chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapies and strategies to improve access for underserved patients with multiple myeloma (MM). Mikhael highlighted the multifaceted access issues, including manufacturing, geography, race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status. He emphasized the need for strategic approaches to overcome these disparities, such as increasing manufacturing capacity, expanding treatment sites, and ensuring these sites are accessible to rural and underserved areas. Mikhael also discussed the importance of matching the right treatment to the right patient, considering the unique needs and eligibility of individuals for CAR T-cell therapy versus bispecifics. He stressed that while improving access is complex, ongoing efforts from manufacturers, academic centers, communities, and regulatory agencies are crucial to ensure wider availability and optimize treatment efficacy.

title: Dr Mikhael on Unmet Needs in Cancer Care for Patients With Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, emphasizes the critical need to address disparities in cancer care for multiple myeloma patients, particularly those from underserved populations. He highlights significant racial and ethnic disparities, noting that African American patients have double the mortality rate compared to White patients. Mikhael, who is African American, stresses the importance of understanding and addressing systemic racism and social determinants of health that contribute to these disparities. He advocates for increased access to key treatments such as triplet regimens, transplants, clinical trials, and CAR T-cell therapy, which are often less accessible to minority groups. Mikhael calls for a dedicated effort from healthcare providers, regulatory bodies, and the broader community to ensure culturally sensitive care and equitable access to treatments. He underscores the need for oncologists to move beyond verbal commitments to daily actions that promote health equity and bridge these gaps.

title: Dr Mikhael on the Importance of Disparities Research in Multiple Myeloma
summary: Joseph Mikhael, MD, emphasizes the critical importance of researching disparities in treatment outcomes for multiple myeloma, particularly focusing on African American communities where incidence and mortality rates are higher. Over the past two decades, Mikhael has been a key figure in advocating for health equity and patient-centric studies in multiple myeloma. He highlights significant research presented at the 2023 ASH Annual Meeting, which examined social determinants of health, racial and ethnic variations in treatment outcomes, and patient experiences with therapies such as CAR T-cell therapy. Notably, studies have explored the Black perspective on clinical trial participation and the impact of dexamethasone dosing strategies on patient outcomes. Mikhael concludes that the increasing body of research on health equity and patient experiences is rewarding and essential for advancing treatment in multiple myeloma.

title: Final Thoughts on Case Study and Treating Multiple Myeloma
summary: Dr. Joseph Mikhael and a panel of experts discussed the evolving treatment landscape of multiple myeloma, focusing on clinical trial updates and their implications. Dr. Mikhael emphasized the importance of individualized therapy based on patient-specific factors, including cytogenetics and treatment history. He highlighted the similarities and subtle differences between isatuximab and daratumumab when combined with carfilzomib and dexamethasone, advising against sequencing these drugs one after the other due to resistance issues. The discussion also touched on the potential of newer immunotherapies, such as bispecific antibodies and CAR T-cell therapies, to be used earlier in the treatment course. Dr. Mikhael concluded by noting the significant advancements in myeloma treatment, which have led to improved progression-free survival rates and brought the field closer to potentially curing the disease.

title: Impact of Clinical Trials on the Management of Multiple Myeloma
summary: The text discusses the significant impact of clinical trials on the management of multiple myeloma, emphasizing the importance of data from these trials in shaping real-world treatment practices. Joseph Mikhael, MD, highlights the evolution of myeloma treatment over the past 25 years, noting the cautious application of promising trial results to everyday practice. He underscores the importance of observing trends in clinical trial designs, such as the reduced use of dexamethasone in frontline therapies for older patients. Mikhael also points out the increasing incorporation of real-world evidence in clinical decision-making, which helps apply trial data to patients who might not fit the typical trial profile. This integration of trial data with real-world evidence is crucial for enhancing treatment efficacy and reducing toxicity.

title: Case Study: Myeloma at Early Relapse
summary: Dr. Joseph Mikhael and experts reviewed a case of early relapse multiple myeloma, focusing on cytogenetics in risk assessment. They discussed a 63-year-old female with stage 2 multiple myeloma, noting chromosome 1 abnormalities like 1q gains and amplifications in about 40% of myeloma patients. Dr. Mikhael stressed early, aggressive intervention in relapsed cases, advocating for advanced therapies like CAR T-cell and bispecific therapies. They also discussed lenalidomide maintenance management and risks of long-term use, including secondary malignancies. Dr. Mikhael suggested reducing or stopping dexamethasone after initial treatment. The panel preferred daratumumab plus carfilzomib and dexamethasone for early relapse.

title: Crystal S. Denlinger, MD, FACP, Named New Chief Executive Officer of NCCN
summary: Crystal S. Denlinger, MD, FACP, has been named the new Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), succeeding Robert W. Carlson, MD. Dr. Denlinger, currently NCCN’s Senior Vice President and Chief Scientific Officer, will assume her new role on October 9, 2023. John W. Sweetenham, MD, FRCP, FACP, FASCO, Chair of the NCCN Board of Directors, praised Dr. Denlinger’s dedication and contributions to oncology. Dr. Denlinger has a robust history with NCCN, including roles such as Chief Scientific Officer, Chair of the NCCN Guidelines Panel for Survivorship, and involvement in various committees and panels. She has also led initiatives like the Health Equity Report Card and NCCN Harmonized Guidelines for Sub-Saharan Africa. Dr. Carlson, who announced his retirement in January 2023, significantly expanded NCCN’s guidelines and membership during his tenure. Dr. Sweetenham commended Dr. Carlson for his commitment to excellence and compassion.

title: Cleveland Clinic's Dr. Matt Kalaycio Appointed Chair of Board of Directors for National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Matt Kalaycio of Cleveland Clinic has been appointed as the Chair of the Board of Directors for the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), succeeding his previous role held since 2022. As a leading expert in hematology and medical oncology, Dr. Kalaycio specializes in leukemia, hematopoietic cell transplantation, and CAR T-Cell therapy.
