He is also the Vice-Chair of the Cleveland Clinic Cancer Institute and a professor at Cleveland Clinic Lerner College of Medicine. Dr. Kalaycio expressed his commitment to advancing NCCN's mission to ensure all cancer patients receive the latest evidence-based treatments.

title: Cleveland Clinic doctor named board chair of National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Matt Kalaycio, a Cleveland Clinic physician, has been appointed as the chair of the board of directors for the National Comprehensive Cancer Network. This leadership position underscores his significant contributions to the field of oncology and his role in guiding national cancer care standards.

title: Julie Bauman, Stephanie Blank to lead NRG Oncology Cancer Prevention & Control Committee
summary: Julie Bauman and Stephanie V. Blank were appointed as chair and vice chair, respectively, of the NRG Oncology Cancer Prevention & Control Committee. This appointment highlights their leadership roles within the organization. Additionally, Matt Kalaycio was named the chair of the board of directors at the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), marking a significant contribution to the field of oncology.

title: SPOTLIGHT: Reimbursement for Supportive Care in Cancer Starts With Adequate Staffing
summary: Comprehensive cancer care delivery is essential for optimal patient outcomes, but adequate staffing and appropriate reimbursement for supportive care services pose significant challenges. Al B. Benson III, MD, FACP, FACCC, FASCO, from Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, highlighted these issues in an interview with Evidence-Based Oncology. Benson discussed findings from a 2019-2020 survey by the Association of Cancer Care Centers (ACCC), which revealed that many cancer centers struggle to offer comprehensive supportive services due to insufficient staffing and funding. He emphasized the importance of understanding the specific needs of patients and ensuring proper reimbursement for services like navigation, pharmacy, and chaplain services. Benson suggested potential solutions, including policy changes, demonstration projects, and the utilization of telemedicine to improve service delivery and staffing efficiency.

title: Sequential Therapy Boosts Survival in Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
summary: A phase II study revealed that sequential therapy with nab-paclitaxel plus gemcitabine followed by mFOLFOX significantly improves overall survival (OS) in patients with metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) compared to standard nab-paclitaxel/gemcitabine treatment. The SEQUENCE trial showed a 12-month OS rate of 55.3% for sequential therapy versus 35.4% for the control group, with median OS of 13.2 months versus 9.7 months, respectively. However, the sequential treatment resulted in higher rates of severe neutropenia and thrombocytopenia. Al B. Benson III, MD, of Northwestern University, highlighted the results as "intriguing" and noted the potential for this regimen to be adapted in clinical practice, pending further validation in a phase III trial.

title: CORRECTION – AVEO Oncology Announces Appointment of Chief Medical Officer and Formation of Scientific Advisory ...
summary: AVEO Oncology announced the appointment of Edgar E. Braendle, MD, PhD, as its new Chief Medical Officer. Dr. Braendle, a seasoned life sciences executive, brings over twenty years of clinical research experience, including roles at Autolus Therapeutics and Sumitomo Dainippon Pharma Oncology. His expertise spans early drug discovery to the launch of various therapies and medical devices. Additionally, AVEO, an LG Chem company, formed a Scientific Advisory Committee comprising leading oncology experts to guide its clinical strategy and business development. Notably, Al B. Benson III, MD, FACP, FACCC, FASCO, a Professor of Medicine and Associate Director from the Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center of Northwestern University, is a member of this committee, contributing his extensive knowledge in oncology research.

title: PRIME® Online Activity - Integrating the Latest Evidence to Personalize Care for Patients With Colorectal Cancer
summary: The PRIME® online activity "Integrating the Latest Evidence to Personalize Care for Patients With Colorectal Cancer" focuses on the latest clinical evidence in colorectal cancer care, targeting oncology professionals. The activity, which expired on February 23, 2024, provided 1.0 continuing education credits for various healthcare providers. Key topics included the current treatment landscape, new safety and efficacy data for targeted therapies, and the integration of biomarkers to individualize treatment. Al B. Benson III, MD, FACP, contributed as a speaker, bringing his expertise as a Professor of Medicine and Associate Director for Clinical Investigations at the Robert H. Lurie Comprehensive Cancer Center at Northwestern University. His involvement underscores the activity's emphasis on leveraging expert insights to enhance personalized treatment strategies for colorectal cancer.

title: Longitudinal study of 2 patients with cyclic thrombocytopenia, STAT3 and MPL mutations
summary: The study investigated two patients with cyclic thrombocytopenia (CTP), revealing periodic platelet count oscillations and associated genetic mutations. Both patients exhibited exaggerated TPO and platelet gene cycling, with trilineage gene fluctuations. They had somatic gain-of-function (GOF) STAT3 mutations and clonal T cells; one patient had a novel germline loss-of-function (LOF) MPL mutation. Blood transcriptome analysis indicated cyclical platelet production as the cause of platelet count oscillations, with neutrophil and erythrocyte-specific gene fluctuations linked to TPO effects. Rondeep S. Brar contributed to the experimental work. This research offers new insights into CTP pathophysiology and potential therapeutic approaches.

title: With cancer on the rise, more beds are needed
summary: With cancer rates expected to rise by nearly 50% from 2015 to 2025, there is an urgent need for more inpatient beds dedicated to cancer care. Massachusetts is planning a new free-standing adult inpatient cancer hospital through a collaboration between Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, and Harvard Medical Faculty Physicians. This facility will provide specialized care, improve patient outcomes, and alleviate overcrowded emergency departments. Dr. Craig A. Bunnell, Chief Medical Officer of Dana-Farber, emphasizes the proven value and necessity of a dedicated cancer hospital to meet the unique needs of cancer patients.

title: Removing Race-Corrected Pulmonary Function Tests May Alter Lung Cancer Care
summary: The removal of race-corrected pulmonary function tests (PFTs) may significantly impact lung cancer treatment for African-American patients, according to a study by Sidra N. Bonner and colleagues. The study found that surgeons using race-neutral PFTs were less likely to recommend aggressive treatments like lobectomy. David T. Cooke, MD, along with Araiye Medlock, BA, emphasized in a commentary that race correction in PFTs is rooted in historical racism and perpetuates structural racism in healthcare. They advocate for using multiple race-neutral assessments to ensure accurate treatment. Cooke and Medlock argue that eliminating race-corrected PFTs is essential but challenging, as it may lead to perceptions of worse lung function in African-American patients. The study analyzed data from 515 African-American lung cancer patients and highlighted the need for holistic patient evaluations to improve care.

title: Love Your Lungs event to pre-screen people who may be at risk of lung cancer
summary: UC Davis Comprehensive Cancer Center is organizing a "Love Your Lungs" event on November 6, 2023, at City Church of Sacramento to pre-screen individuals at risk of lung cancer. The event aims to educate the community about lung cancer prevention and detection, offering free low-dose CT scans to catch lung cancer early. David T. Cooke, chief of the Division of General Thoracic Surgery, highlighted the importance of these scans, noting their efficiency and potential to detect treatable lung cancer. Cooke will be present to guide the pre-screening process. The event will also provide resources on tobacco cessation, health insurance, and more, with the goal of reaching diverse and marginalized communities.

title: Thoracic Surgeons on the Lung Cancer Team with David Tom Cooke, MD
summary: Thoracic surgeons play a crucial role in lung cancer detection and management, contributing significantly throughout the disease continuum. David Tom Cooke, MD, Founding Chief of the Division of General Thoracic Surgery at UC Davis, highlights advancements in lung cancer screening and intervention, particularly in minimally invasive, robotic, and bronchoscopic techniques. In the first Lungcast episode of 2023, Cooke discusses the evolving strategies in individualized patient care, emphasizing the importance of shared decision-making and patient involvement in defining invasive and follow-up care strategies. He also elaborates on the role of thoracic surgeons in improving lung cancer screening rates, the use of PET/CT scans in staging, and approaches to stage IV lung cancer. Cooke underscores the significance of thoracic surgeons in palliative care and the promising future of robotic surgery in the field. Lungcast, a monthly respiratory health podcast series from the American Lung Association, is produced by HCPLive.

title: 81yo pilot-doctor David Cooke still flies to treat patients and leads weekly aerial display
summary: 81-year-old David T. Cooke is an accomplished pilot and doctor who continues to fly his vintage aircraft to treat patients in regional areas. Despite his age, Cooke remains active, leading a weekly aerial formation display with a group known as the Bobcats over Port Macquarie. He has served in the Royal Flying Doctor Service and has been a GP in various locations, including Gunnedah and Port Macquarie. Cooke also flies twice weekly to South West Rocks to address the rural GP shortage. He received an Order of Australia Medal in 2020 for his contributions to aviation and medicine.

title: Research into targeted treatments, better prediction models in breast cancer funded
summary: Five researchers from the Fred Hutchinson/University of Washington/Seattle Children’s Cancer Consortium have received additional funding from the Breast Cancer Research Foundation (BCRF) to continue their studies on breast cancer. Nancy E. Davidson, MD, Executive Vice President for Clinical Affairs at Fred Hutch, received funding to research the expanded use of PARP inhibitors, aiming to predict treatment responses using a novel molecular imaging radiotracer. This funding will support a clinical trial starting in early 2024. Other researchers funded include Drs. Chris Li, Anne McTiernan, Nora Disis, and Mary-Claire King, focusing on recurrence prediction models, exercise effects on outcomes, obesity-related inflammation, and undiscovered genetic mutations in breast cancer, respectively.

title: Lumpectomy without radiation for ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast: 20-year results from the ECOG-ACRIN E5194 ...
summary: The ECOG-ACRIN E5194 study evaluated lumpectomy without radiation for ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast over 20 years. Two cohorts were analyzed: low/intermediate-grade DCIS (≤2.5 cm, 561 patients) and high-grade DCIS (≤1 cm, 104 patients). The study found that ipsilateral breast event (IBE) rates increased up to 15 years and then plateaued. The 20-year IBE rates were 17.8% for low/intermediate-grade and 28.7% for high-grade. Invasive IBE rates were 9.8% and 15.1%, respectively. Key predictors of IBE included DCIS size and cohort, but not grade or margin width. Nancy E. Davidson contributed to the study's conceptualization, design, and interpretation of results.

title: Timothy J. Eberlein, MD, FACS | ACS
summary: Timothy J. Eberlein, MD, FACS, is a distinguished figure in surgical oncology. He is the Director of the Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center and serves as the Olin Distinguished Professor and Senior Associate Dean for Cancer Programs at Barnes-Jewish Hospital and Washington University Medical Center. Eberlein is the founding Director of the Siteman Cancer Center, the only cancer center in Missouri with a Comprehensive Cancer Center designation and “Exceptional” rating from the National Cancer Institute. He has held numerous prestigious positions, including Chair of the Board of Regents of the American College of Surgeons and past President of the Society of Surgical Oncology. Eberlein has received multiple awards, including the John Wayne Clinical Research Award and the Distinguished Faculty Award from Washington University. He is also an Honorary Fellow of several international surgical societies. His contributions significantly impact surgical education and cancer research.

title: Meet with Dr. Timothy Eberlein in Fireside Chat this Thursday
summary: The ACS Academy of Master Surgeon Educators Fireside Chat Series offers a unique opportunity this Thursday, June 22, at 7:00 pm CT, to engage with Dr. Timothy J. Eberlein, MD, FACS, Chair of the ACS Board of Regents. Dr. Eberlein will discuss his career, lessons learned, and his roles, including his experience as Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of the American College of Surgeons and his tenure as Board Chair. The session will be driven by audience questions, providing an intimate dialogue with this esteemed professional. Registration is required to attend.

title: Eberlein elected chair of American College of Surgeons board - The Source
summary: Timothy J. Eberlein, MD, the Spencer T. and Ann W. Olin Distinguished Professor and director of Siteman Cancer Center at Barnes-Jewish Hospital and Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, has been elected chair of the American College of Surgeons (ACS) Board of Regents. In his new role, Eberlein will chair the regents’ finance and executive committees and collaborate closely with the ACS executive director and CEO, Patricia L. Turner, MD. Since joining the Board of Regents in 2015, Eberlein has contributed to policy formation and oversight of ACS affairs.

title: Dr. Timothy Eberlein Is Elected Chair of ACS Board of Regents | ACS
summary: Dr. Timothy J. Eberlein, MD, FACS, a surgical oncologist from St. Louis, MO, has been elected Chair of the ACS Board of Regents following the ACS Clinical Congress 2022. Dr. Eberlein is the Spencer T. and Ann W. Olin Distinguished Professor, director of the Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center, and senior associate dean for cancer programs at Washington University School of Medicine and Barnes-Jewish Hospital. In his 1-year term, he will collaborate with ACS Executive Director and CEO Patricia L. Turner, MD, MBA, FACS, and chair the Regents’ Finance and Executive Committees. Dr. Eberlein has been an ACS Fellow since 1988 and a BoR member since 2015. He has served as Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of the American College of Surgeons since 2004, significantly increasing its impact factor. His extensive service includes roles in various ACS committees and contributions to surgical oncology research and education.

title: Clinical Pathways in Practice at Roswell Park Cancer Center
summary: Stephen B. Edge, MD, vice president for system quality and outcomes at Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center, discussed the implementation of clinical pathways for oncology care. About six years ago, Roswell Park decided to adopt clinical pathways to document quality both at the main campus and its community network. They chose to use the Elsevier ClinicalPath system for medical oncology decisions, which helps in making treatment recommendations based on patient data. Edge highlighted the benefits of clinical pathways, including decision support for oncologists, quality monitoring, and identifying patients for advanced therapies. He also mentioned the challenges of implementation, such as the additional work required from providers. Edge emphasized the importance of these pathways in ensuring patients receive appropriate treatments and in supporting clinical trial participation.

title: Hydrogel Spacer Reduces Rectal Dose during Proton Therapy for Prostate Cancer: A Dosimetric Analysis
summary: The study investigated the impact of a biodegradable hydrogel spacer on rectal dose reduction during proton therapy for prostate cancer. Utilizing intensity-modulated proton therapy (IMPT) and passive scattering proton therapy (PSPT) plans for nine patients, the research demonstrated significant reductions in rectal dose parameters with the spacer, particularly in V70, which was 81.1% lower for PSPT with the spacer compared to IMPT without the spacer. The spacer increased the displacement between the prostate and rectum, resulting in decreased rectal doses. Steven J. Frank contributed as an author and reported conflicts of interest, including associations with Varian, C4 Imaging, Eli Lilly, Elekta, and Hitachi. The study concluded that hydrogel spacers significantly reduce rectal radiation doses in proton therapy, with ongoing prospective studies to assess clinical impacts.

title: Dr Goff on Key Takeaways from the SWOG 1815 Trial in Biliary Tract Cancers
summary: Laura W. Goff, MD, discussed the key takeaways from the phase 3 SWOG 1815 trial in newly diagnosed patients with advanced biliary tract cancers. The trial evaluated the addition of nab-paclitaxel to gemcitabine and cisplatin to determine the efficacy and safety of the triplet vs doublet chemotherapy. Despite rapid patient enrollment and high hopes, the triplet therapy did not show a statistically significant improvement in overall survival compared to doublet therapy, missing the trial’s primary endpoint. The median overall survival was 14.0 months for the triplet regimen versus 12.7 months for the doublet. Goff emphasized that although the results were disappointing, the doublet therapy remains a better-tolerated and effective standard of care. She also noted that the doublet regimen could serve as a backbone for future novel therapeutics and that certain patient subgroups might still benefit from the triplet therapy.

title: The Evolving Treatment Landscape of Biliary Tract Cancers
summary: The evolving treatment landscape for biliary tract cancers is discussed by Milind Javle, MD, and Laura W. Goff, MD. They emphasize the importance of current treatment guidelines and address unmet needs in this field. Laura W. Goff highlights the significance of evaluating patient tumors for specific alterations, such as FGFR fusions and IDH1 mutations, and the use of targeted therapies like pemigatinib and futibatinib. She also underscores the benefits of chemotherapy, particularly the combination of 5-FU and liposomal irinotecan. Goff stresses the necessity of multidisciplinary approaches and the importance of considering treatment options to avoid a nihilistic view. The conversation also touches on emerging therapies, the integration of various treatments, and the importance of identifying patients who will benefit most from these therapies. The discussion indicates a promising future with more treatment options and advancements in the next few years.

title: Overview of Biliary Tract Cancers and Diagnosis
summary: Expert oncologists Milind Javle, MD, and Laura W. Goff, MD, discuss the various subsets of biliary tract cancers and the best practices for accurate diagnosis. They highlight that biliary tract cancer encompasses three types: intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, perihilar cholangiocarcinoma (also known as Klatskin tumor), and extrahepatic distal cholangiocarcinoma, along with gallbladder cancer. These cancers differ in epidemiology, clinical presentation, and treatment. Laura W. Goff emphasizes the importance of obtaining tissue for diagnosis and suggests using experienced endoscopists and specialized techniques like SpyGlass for better diagnostic accuracy. She also mentions the use of circulating tumor DNA and CA 19-9 testing to aid in diagnosis. Goff stresses the need for a multidisciplinary approach in early diagnosis stages to improve patient outcomes.

title: Other Clinical Trials With Chemoimmunotherapy in Biliary Tract Cancers
summary: Expert perspectives on the KEYNOTE-966 and IMbrave151 clinical trials and novel chemoimmunotherapy combination strategies in biliary tract cancers were discussed by Milind Javle, MD, and Laura W. Goff, MD. The KEYNOTE-966 trial, involving gemcitabine-cisplatin with pembrolizumab, showed a statistically significant benefit in overall survival but not in progression-free survival. Laura W. Goff highlighted the importance of chemoimmunotherapy in biliary tract cancers and discussed the potential differences between pembrolizumab and durvalumab, as well as the continuation of chemotherapy. She noted that the monthly dosing of durvalumab in the TOPAZ-1 trial is beneficial for patients. The IMbrave151 trial, which combined atezolizumab with or without bevacizumab along with gemcitabine-cisplatin, did not show a significant difference in progression-free survival between the arms. Laura W. Goff emphasized the need for further research to determine the best treatment strategies.

title: Biliary Tract Cancers: Standard of Care Treatment Strategies
summary: Drs. Milind Javle and Laura W. Goff discuss the standard of care treatment strategies for biliary tract cancers, particularly highlighting the significant advancements in the field over the past decade. They focus on the recent updates to the NCCN guidelines, which now recommend the combination of durvalumab with cisplatin and gemcitabine as a first-line treatment, reflecting a shift from the previously standard gemcitabine-cisplatin regimen. Laura W. Goff emphasizes the adoption of this chemoimmunotherapy approach in her practice, noting its tolerability and the delayed yet significant benefits of immunotherapy. The TOPAZ-1 trial's data, showing improved median overall survival and a favorable adverse effect profile, further supports this regimen. Goff's contribution underscores the clinical adoption and validation of this new standard, reinforcing the regimen's efficacy and patient tolerance.

title: CD8+ T cell metabolic flexibility elicited by CD28-ARS2 axis-driven alternative splicing of PKM supports antitumor ...
summary: Metabolic flexibility in CD8+ T cells, crucial for antitumor activity, is influenced by the CD28-ARS2 axis. This study reveals that ARS2, upregulated by CD28 signaling, recruits splicing factors to pre-mRNAs, affecting a third of T-cell activation-induced alternative splicing events. Specifically, the CD28-ARS2 axis suppresses the M1 isoform of pyruvate kinase, favoring PKM2, which is essential for glucose metabolism, interferon gamma production, and antitumor function. PKM2 alternative splicing occurs independently of the CD28-driven PI3K pathway, introducing a novel mechanism of glucose metabolism reprogramming in CD8+ T cells. Kelvin P. Lee contributed significantly to this research, being involved in conceptualization, resource provision, and funding acquisition.

title: Cleveland Clinic's Dr. Matt Kalaycio Appointed Chair of Board of Directors for National Comprehensive Cancer Network
summary: Dr. Matt Kalaycio of Cleveland Clinic has been appointed Chair of the Board of Directors for the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN), a nonprofit focused on patient care, research, and education. Dr. Christopher H. Lieu, from the University of Colorado, has been elected as Vice-Chair, succeeding Dr. Kalaycio. Dr. Lieu, an Associate Director for Clinical Research and Co-Director of Gastrointestinal Medical Oncology, is noted for his work on gastrointestinal cancers and drug development. His contributions include serving on the NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines Panel for Neuroendocrine Tumors and the FDA Oncologic Drugs Advisory Committee. The leadership changes aim to advance high-quality, patient-centered cancer care globally.

title: Population-level comparisons of gene regulatory networks modeled on high-throughput single-cell transcriptomics data
summary: The study presents SCORPION, a tool designed to reconstruct gene regulatory networks from single-cell/nuclei RNA-sequencing data for population-level comparisons. SCORPION uses a message-passing algorithm to integrate multiple data sources, outperforming 12 existing techniques in accuracy and scalability. It effectively identifies regulatory differences, such as those between wild-type and transcription factor-perturbed cells, and demonstrates its utility in analyzing a single-cell RNA-sequencing atlas of colorectal cancer. The tool revealed consistent regulatory patterns across tumor regions and provided insights into phenotypic regulators impacting patient survival. Christopher H. Lieu contributed to this research as part of the team from the University of Colorado Cancer Center.

title: Early vs conventional onset pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma: analysis of surgical and oncologic outcomes in patients ...
summary: The study analyzes surgical and oncologic outcomes in patients with early-onset pancreatic cancer (EOPC) compared to conventional-onset pancreatic cancer (COPC). Conducted at the Mayo Clinic from 2011 to 2021, it involved 1,133 patients, with 65 (5.7%) having EOPC. The study found that EOPC patients had similar preoperative characteristics to COPC patients but were more likely to be non-white and have larger tumors. However, both groups showed similar pathological stages, R0 resection rates, and postoperative outcomes. Importantly, there was no significant difference in overall or recurrence-free survival between the two groups after adjusting for significant factors. Robert R. McWilliams contributed as one of the authors, helping to analyze and interpret the oncologic outcomes of EOPC versus COPC. The study concludes that younger patients undergoing curative resection for pancreatic cancer have comparable survival rates to older patients.

title: Neoadjuvant cobimetinib and atezolizumab with or without vemurafenib for high-risk operable Stage III melanoma: the ...
summary: The Phase II NeoACTIVATE trial explored the efficacy and tolerability of neoadjuvant cobimetinib and atezolizumab, with or without vemurafenib, for high-risk operable Stage III melanoma. Patients received either a combination of vemurafenib, cobimetinib, and atezolizumab (BRAF-mutated) or cobimetinib and atezolizumab (BRAF-wild-type) followed by therapeutic lymph node dissection (TLND) and adjuvant atezolizumab. The study observed significant pathologic responses, with higher rates in BRAF-mutated patients. Adverse events were noted, predominantly dermatologic, but did not delay surgeries. Robert R. McWilliams contributed to the study, specifically in the Department of Oncology at Mayo Clinic, providing critical insights and support for the trial.

title: Genomics increase accuracy in pediatric melanoma diagnosis
summary: Integrating genomic testing with clinical and pathology data significantly improves the accuracy of pediatric melanoma diagnosis, which accounts for less than 1% of all melanomas. Alberto S. Pappo, MD, from St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, emphasized that this approach helps distinguish between different lesion types more accurately, aiding in earlier diagnosis and better treatment guidance. Pappo presented data showing that the accuracy of identifying Spitz vs. non-Spitz lesions increased from 0.267 to 0.835 with genomics, and for conventional vs. unconventional melanoma, it rose from 0.323 to 0.689. This integration also reduces unnecessary procedures in children. Pappo strongly advocates for the use of genomic tests in tumors to improve patient care.

title: and MediSys Health Network Announce New Collaboration to Enhance Cancer Care in Queens | Memorial Sloan ...
summary: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSK) and MediSys Health Network have announced a collaboration to enhance cancer care in Queens and eastern Brooklyn. This partnership aims to integrate MSK's specialized cancer expertise with MediSys's community-focused acute care. The collaboration will address healthcare barriers in Queens, a diverse area with significant socio-economic and language disparities. During the first phase in 2023, MSK and MediSys will develop an oncology program at Jamaica Hospital and streamline patient transfers to MSK for specialized care and clinical trials. David G. Pfister, MD, Chief of Head and Neck Oncology Service and Associate Deputy Physician-in-Chief for Strategic Partnerships at MSK, emphasized the collaboration's goal to bring top-tier cancer care to the community, leveraging MediSys's deep community ties and commitment to patient care.

title: Key Takeaways on Updates in Bladder Cancer
summary: Elizabeth R. Plimack, MD, MS, FASCO, played a significant role in summarizing key updates in bladder cancer as discussed in the recent ASCO GU 2024 conference. The updates cover various aspects of bladder cancer treatment, including neoadjuvant and adjuvant therapies for muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC), emerging data on metastatic urothelial carcinoma, and new approaches in treatment sequencing and maintenance therapy. Plimack, along with other experts, provided insights into the latest research findings and clinical data, emphasizing the importance of these developments for improving patient outcomes. Her contributions were crucial in recapping the discussion and highlighting the advancements in the field.

title: ESMO 2023: The Role of Systemic Therapy in Bladder Preservation for Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer
summary: At the 2023 European Society of Medical Oncology (ESMO) Annual Congress, Dr. Elizabeth Plimack presented on the role of systemic therapy in bladder preservation for muscle-invasive bladder cancer (MIBC). The primary aim is to cure while minimizing quality of life detriments. Dr. Plimack discussed recent trials like RETAIN and HCRN GU 16-257, which explored risk-adapted treatments based on clinical responses and mutational statuses. These trials indicated that a subset of patients could avoid cystectomy and maintain metastasis-free survival with systemic therapy alone. Dr. Plimack emphasized the importance of balancing quality of life with treatment efficacy and highlighted ongoing trials aiming to refine patient selection and treatment approaches. She concluded that systemic therapies, imaging, and biomarkers are crucial in optimizing treatment and avoiding over- or under-treatment.

title: Exciting New Approaches in Metastatic Urothelial Carcinoma
summary: Experts in bladder cancer, including Elizabeth R. Plimack, MD, MS, FASCO, discuss innovative agents and treatment strategies for metastatic urothelial carcinoma. The discussion covers the integration of these new approaches into existing treatment paradigms. Elizabeth R. Plimack's contributions are significant as she co-authors the analysis, providing expert insights into the evolving landscape of bladder cancer treatments.

title: Advanced Clear Cell RCC: Impact of the CLEAR Trial on Real-World Practice
summary: The CLEAR trial, evaluating lenvatinib plus pembrolizumab in advanced clear cell RCC, has significantly influenced real-world clinical practice. Key findings include a high response rate of over 70% and a median progression-free survival of nearly 24 months. Elizabeth R. Plimack highlighted the trial's compelling results, particularly the low rate of disease progression and the importance of achieving stable disease. She emphasized the regimen's durability and efficacy, advocating for its use in achieving long-term disease control. This trial reassures the sustained benefits of IO TKI regimens, influencing treatment approaches and patient counseling.

title: Expert Insights on Updates in Adjuvant Therapy for Muscle-Invasive Bladder Cancer
summary: Experts in muscle-invasive bladder cancer discussed the latest data on adjuvant therapy presented at ASCO GU 2024. Dr. Elizabeth R. Plimack, along with other notable oncologists, contributed significantly to these insights. They reviewed recent advancements and ongoing research in adjuvant therapies, emphasizing their clinical implications. Dr. Plimack, a key author, played a crucial role in analyzing and interpreting the new findings, providing expert commentary on how these updates could influence treatment practices for muscle-invasive bladder cancer. The discussion also covered the impact of these therapies on patient outcomes and future research directions.

title: Updates from ASCO 2023: KEYNOTE-B61 Study in Non-Clear Cell Renal Cell Carcinoma
summary: The ASCO 2023 conference presented significant updates on the KEYNOTE-B61 study focusing on non-clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The study, led by Joe Lee, MD, evaluated the efficacy of combining lenvatinib and pembrolizumab in treating metastatic non-clear cell RCC, which includes various histologies like papillary and unclassified types. This single-arm trial showed promising results, with a progression-free survival (PFS) of nearly 18 months and high response rates across different histologies. Elizabeth R. Plimack, MD, MS, highlighted the compelling nature of these data, emphasizing that pembrolizumab with lenvatinib is now her preferred first-line treatment for papillary RCC. She also discussed treatment strategies for chromophobe RCC, noting the variability in tumor responsiveness and the importance of personalized treatment approaches. The study's results suggest lenvatinib and pembrolizumab as a potent combination for non-clear cell RCC, potentially shifting treatment paradigms.

title: A phase 1 study of nivolumab in combination with interferon-gamma for patients with advanced solid tumors
summary: This phase I study evaluates the safety of combining interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) with nivolumab in patients with metastatic solid tumors. Twenty-six patients were treated in four cohorts to determine the recommended phase two dose (RP2D). The study found that the combination was generally well-tolerated, with common adverse events being low-grade and associated with IFN-γ. The RP2D was established at 50 mcg/m2. Exploratory analyses showed one complete response and five cases of stable disease. Elizabeth R. Plimack contributed significantly by providing oversight for trial design and conduct, participating in data analysis, and offering editorial support. Further study is warranted to evaluate the role of IFN-γ in preventing immune-related adverse events.

title: Clinical Insights on Recent Data in Metastatic Urothelial Carcinoma
summary: GU medical oncologists, including Elizabeth R. Plimack, MD, MS, FASCO, provide their perspectives on recent advancements in metastatic urothelial carcinoma, particularly focusing on the CheckMate 901 and EV-302 trials. These insights are part of a series of episodes exploring various aspects of bladder cancer treatment, from neoadjuvant therapies to emerging data and treatment sequencing practices. Elizabeth R. Plimack's contribution is significant in offering expert analysis and interpretation of the latest clinical data, helping to shape the understanding and future direction of metastatic urothelial carcinoma treatment.

title: Rationale Behind Discontinuing IO Therapy in Clear Cell RCC
summary: The discussion focuses on the rationale behind discontinuing immunotherapy (IO) for patients with advanced clear cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Key points include varying opinions on whether to stop IO at the 2-year mark, as some trials have done, or to continue treatment due to concerns about disease progression. Brian I. Rini, MD, and Eric A. Jonasch, MD, share their perspectives, with Rini highlighting the practice of stopping IO in line with trial protocols, while Jonasch argues for continuation due to the lack of mechanistic rationale for discontinuation. Elizabeth R. Plimack, MD, MS, from Fox Chase Cancer Center, contributes to the discussion by providing insights into the treatment strategies and considerations for advanced RCC. The debate underscores the uncertainty and need for further research to determine optimal treatment durations.

title: University of Chicago Medicine cancer center to commence construction in fall 2023
summary: The University of Chicago Medicine will start building a new cancer center in fall 2023, expected to finish by 2027. The $633 million, 500,000-square-foot facility will be on UCM’s Hyde Park campus with 100 examination rooms and 128 hospital beds. Dr. Mitchell C. Posner, Physician-in-Chief of UCM's Comprehensive Cancer Center, stressed the urgent need for this facility, noting South Side Chicago residents are twice as likely to die from cancer compared to other Americans. Posner emphasized the center's role in expanding access to clinical trials and state-of-the-art care, especially for underrepresented groups. The center aims to handle 200,000 outpatient visits and 5,000 inpatient admissions annually, offering services like imaging, diagnostics, clinical trials, stem-cell treatment, and urgent care. The project needs approval from the Illinois Health Facilities and Services Review Board and is expected to create over 500 construction jobs.

title: Dr Salgia on Clinical Gaps in the Development of Novel Targets in Lung Cancer
summary: Dr. Ravi Salgia, MD, PhD, a medical oncologist and the Arthur & Rosalie Kaplan Chair in Medical Oncology at City of Hope, highlighted the clinical gaps in developing novel targets for lung cancer at the 2023 Bridging the Gaps in Lung Cancer meeting. Salgia emphasized the importance of identifying gaps related to the development and utilization of targeted therapeutics. He discussed the need for better navigation of treatment options, identification of suitable patients, and understanding associated toxicities. Salgia also stressed the significance of combining targeted therapies with other modalities like chemotherapy, exploring their effectiveness in early-stage disease, and ensuring treatments are well-tolerated. He addressed the economic burden on patients and advocated for collaborative efforts to reduce costs, thereby minimizing financial toxicities. Salgia concluded that personalized drug selection, less toxic treatments, and cost-effective strategies are crucial for improving patient outcomes and advancing lung cancer treatment.

title: Lung Cancer Resistance Mechanism Identified for Common Therapy
summary: In a recent study led by Dr. Ravi Salgia, researchers identified nongenetic mechanisms contributing to resistance in lung cancer patients treated with sotorasib, a KRAS G12C inhibitor. Published in Science Advances, the study revealed that while most tumor cells initially respond to sotorasib, some develop resistance through nongenetic means by altering the KRAS-sotorasib interaction network. This resistance can be reversible if treatment is paused but may become permanent with prolonged therapy due to genetic mutations. Additionally, combining sotorasib with carfilzomib, an FDA-approved anti-cancer therapy, showed promise in overcoming resistance. Salgia's work underscores the importance of both genetic and nongenetic factors in therapeutic resistance, offering new strategies for treating resistant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).

title: Dr Salgia on Unmet Needs Associated With Treatment-Related Toxicity in Lung Cancer
summary: Ravi Salgia, MD, PhD, discusses the 2023 Bridging the Gaps in Lung Cancer meeting, emphasizing the unmet needs regarding treatment-related toxicities from commonly used agents in lung cancer patients. He highlights that the assumption of the safety of all TKIs is incorrect, citing adverse effects (AEs) such as rash, diarrhea, and cardiac changes from EGFR-directed TKIs like osimertinib. Salgia stresses the importance of vigilant monitoring of the heart, liver, and kidneys due to these AEs. He also points out that MET inhibitors and KRAS inhibitors can cause significant AEs like edema, liver dysfunction, nausea, and vomiting. Additionally, the combination of KRAS inhibitors with immunotherapy increases toxicity risks. Salgia underscores the unpredictability of specific AEs in patients and the formidable toxicities associated with immunotherapy agents, such as hypophysitis and pneumonitis. He concludes by emphasizing the need for healthcare practitioners to remain aware of these potential complications to manage them effectively.

title: A Gift to Make Patients With Cancer Whole Again
summary: Diane Miller, a stage 4 lung cancer patient, found hope at City of Hope under the care of Ravi Salgia, M.D., Ph.D., a lung cancer expert. Dr. Salgia's reassurance and treatment transformed Miller's outlook, helping her manage the disease. Despite ongoing anxiety and insomnia, Miller's introduction to integrative oncology by Richard T. Lee, M.D., and mind-body specialist Frank Munoz, Ph.D., significantly improved her quality of life. Integrative oncology, combining Eastern and Western medicine, helped Miller achieve better health and reduced anxiety. A $100 million gift from Andrew and Dr. Peggy Cherng will support City of Hope in creating a national integrative oncology program, expanding access to these therapies. Miller, now an advocate, credits City of Hope for saving her life and enhancing it.

title: Leaders of Influence: 2023 L.A.’s Top Doctors – Ravi Salgia
summary: Dr. Ravi Salgia, a distinguished physician-scientist, is recognized for his significant contributions to lung cancer research. As the Arthur & Rosalie Kaplan Chair in Medical Oncology and Chairman of the Department of Medical Oncology at City of Hope, Dr. Salgia has pioneered advancements in therapeutics targeting receptor tyrosine kinases, crucial in lung cancer pathology. His discovery of the MET exon 14 deletion in non-small cell lung cancer led to the development and approval of tepotinib for patient treatment. Additionally, Dr. Salgia has explored nongenetic mechanisms of drug resistance in lung cancer and was the first to clone the cDNA encoding human paxillin, demonstrating its role in metastasis and chemotherapy resistance.

title: Educated Patient® Lung Cancer Summit Advancements in SCLC Presentation: April 29, 2023
summary: Dr. Ravi Salgia, professor and chair in the Department of Medical Oncology at City of Hope, discussed advancements in small cell lung cancer (SCLC) at the CURE® Educated Patient® Lung Cancer Summit on April 29, 2023. He emphasized that early diagnosis of SCLC can lead to potential cures, but extensive disease remains challenging to treat. Salgia highlighted the approval of immunotherapy and advancements in second-line therapy, stressing the need for rapid testing of novel treatments. He expressed excitement about the combination of Tecentriq (atezolizumab) and Imfinzi (durvalumab) with chemotherapy, which has improved survival rates. Salgia also discussed the efficacy of chemotherapy and the importance of clinical trials for patients with relapsed or refractory SCLC. He encouraged participation in ongoing trials exploring immunotherapy, targeted therapies, and chemotherapy combinations, noting the constantly evolving treatment landscape.

title: Analyzing the Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Initial Oncologic Presentation and Treatment of Non-Small Cell ...
summary: The study, "Analyzing the impact of the Coronavirus disease 2019 pandemic on initial oncologic presentation and treatment of non–small cell lung cancer in the United States," examines how the COVID-19 pandemic affected the diagnosis and treatment of non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Conducted by Adam R. Dyas, Michael R. Bronsert, Christina M. Stuart, Madeline B. Thomas, Richard D. Schulick, and others, the retrospective cohort study used data from the National Cancer Database (2019-2020). Findings show a 15% reduction in NSCLC diagnoses during the pandemic, with patients presenting more advanced stages and receiving less treatment compared to the prepandemic period. Richard D. Schulick contributed as one of the key authors, helping to analyze the pandemic's impact on treatment strategies and outcomes for NSCLC patients. The study underscores the significant shifts in oncologic care due to the pandemic, with implications for future patient management and survival outcomes.

title: Regional One oncology department inpatient unit celebrates one year anniversary
summary: Regional One Health's oncology department celebrated the one-year anniversary of its inpatient unit, which opened to provide comprehensive cancer care. Dr. David Shibata, the Executive Director of Regional One’s cancer program, has been instrumental in transforming the hospital's focus from primarily trauma care to include cutting-edge cancer treatment. Dr. Shibata, a cancer surgeon with a passion for treating patients in regions with poor cancer outcomes, initiated the cancer program two years ago through a partnership with the University of Tennessee and Regional One Health. His efforts have led to the establishment of a state-of-the-art operating room with robotic technology and a fully renovated outpatient clinic. These advancements have significantly impacted cancer care in the region, addressing the high cancer mortality rates in Tennessee, Arkansas, and Mississippi.

title: Regional One Health making strides in cancer treatment
summary: Regional One Health (ROH) in Memphis has significantly advanced its cancer treatment capabilities following a $28 million investment in 2021. This investment has benefited over 40,000 patients, including Robert Mayweather, who was diagnosed with advanced stage IV colon cancer. Dr. David Shibata, the executive director of ROH's cancer program, played a crucial role in this progress. He successfully performed a complex nine-hour surgery on Mayweather, improving his quality of life. Dr. Shibata highlighted the growth in ROH's cancer care, including new operating rooms, dedicated oncology inpatient units, and a renovated outpatient cancer unit. ROH's affiliation with the University of Tennessee Health Science Center further supports cancer research and clinical trials.

title: Winners of 2023 President’s Awards Announced
summary: The University of Tennessee System President Randy Boyd announced the recipients of the 2023 President’s Awards during the annual UT Board of Trustees meeting in Memphis. Fourteen faculty and staff members from across the UT System were recognized for their accomplishments and dedication to the Be One UT values, which aim to shape culture, build purpose, improve team cohesion, and create a shared sense of commitment. The awards, established in 2016, are the highest honor a UT employee can receive and include a commemorative plaque and a $3,000 monetary award. Among the nominees, David Shibata, a Professor and Harwell Wilson Alumni Endowed Chair in Surgery at the College of Medicine, UT Health Science Center, was acknowledged for his contributions. Recipients will be honored at a special luncheon on August 3 in Nashville.

title: World-Renowned Surgeon Named New Director of Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health
summary: Diane M. Simeone, MD, has been appointed as the new director of Moores Cancer Center at UC San Diego Health, starting April 1, 2024. Simeone is an internationally recognized expert in pancreatic neoplasms and brings extensive leadership experience from her roles at New York University Langone Health, where she served as the Laura and Isaac Perlmutter Professor of Surgery and director of the Pancreatic Cancer Center. She has led significant initiatives, including the Pancreatic Cancer Early Detection Consortium and the Precision Promise clinical trials consortium. Simeone's appointment follows a national search and she succeeds Joseph A. Califano III, MD. In her new role, she will oversee the center’s research programs, clinical services, and strategic direction, aiming to enhance clinical and scientific innovation and expand access to early therapeutics through clinical trials. Her leadership is expected to further elevate Moores Cancer Center as an international leader in cancer care, research, and education.

title: New Findings in JNCCN Illustrate Pathway for Screening High-Risk Individuals for Pancreatic Cancer in PRECEDE Study
summary: New research in the April 2024 issue of JNCCN highlights the feasibility of early detection and prevention for pancreatic cancer through the Pancreatic Cancer Early Detection (PRECEDE) Consortium. The study reported a high rate of baseline imaging completion among high-risk individuals, showing potential for improved outcomes in a disease with a historically low survival rate due to late-stage diagnosis. Diane M. Simeone, MD, from UC San Diego Moores Cancer Center, emphasized the importance of identifying pancreatic cysts in high-risk individuals, which may signal an increased risk of developing pancreatic cancer. This research underscores the need for further studies to enhance screening programs and tailor surveillance for distinct high-risk subgroups, ultimately aiming to improve early detection and clinical outcomes for pancreatic cancer.

title: Dr Simeone on the EVEREST-1 Trial Evaluating A2B530 in Solid Tumors
summary: Dr. Diane M. Simeone is leading the phase 1/2 EVEREST-1 trial, which is evaluating the autologous CAR T-cell therapy A2B530 in patients with solid tumors. This trial targets patients whose tumors express carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and have lost HLA-A*02 expression. Eligibility requires prior participation in the BASECAMP-1 trial, where patients undergo apheresis to store T cells for potential future intervention. BASECAMP-1 uses next-generation sequencing to identify candidates for EVEREST-1. Although initially limited to HLA-A*02 loss, the trial plans to include more HLA subtypes, broadening patient eligibility. Simeone emphasizes the importance of managing off-target effects while delivering high payloads of A2B530.

title: Single-cell RNA sequencing reveals the effects of chemotherapy on human pancreatic adenocarcinoma and its tumor ...
summary: This study uses single-cell RNA sequencing to explore the effects of chemotherapy on pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and its tumor microenvironment (TME). Researchers analyzed freshly collected human PDAC samples before and after chemotherapy, revealing a heterogeneous mixture of basal and classical cancer cell subtypes, as well as distinct subpopulations of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) and macrophages. The study found that chemotherapy significantly alters the TME, affecting ligand-receptor interactions, particularly between CD8+ T cells and cancer cells, and potentially promoting resistance to immunotherapy. Diane M. Simeone significantly contributed to the study's design, data analysis, and manuscript preparation.

title: Montreal study finds increased screening, early detection grows pancreatic cancer survival odds
summary: A study by the Pancreatic Cancer Early Detection Consortium (PRECEDE) suggests early detection can significantly improve survival rates for pancreatic cancer patients. The research, co-led by Dr. George Zogopoulos from McGill University and Dr. Diane M. Simeone from UC San Diego Moores Cancer Center, highlights that early detection can increase survival rates from 12% to over 80%. The study focuses on individuals at high risk due to family history or genetic mutations, noting that pancreatic cysts may indicate a higher risk of cancer. Dr. Simeone emphasized the importance of longer follow-up to determine if familial pancreatic cancer poses a greater risk than genetic factors alone. The study enrolled over 3,000 participants and underscores the potential of an integrated clinical and research program to improve outcomes in pancreatic cancer. High-risk individuals are advised to adhere to stringent screening protocols.

title: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy found safe, efficacious in penile cancer
summary: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy has been found safe and effective for treating locally advanced penile squamous cell carcinoma (PSCC). Patients who responded to the treatment had a median overall survival of 73 months compared to 17 months for non-responders. The study, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, showed a 57.2% objective response rate, with 43.2% achieving partial response and 13.9% complete response. Philippe E. Spiess, MD, FACS, FRCS, assistant chief of surgical services and senior member of the genitourinary oncology department at Moffitt Cancer Center, emphasized the importance of a multimodal approach for better patient outcomes. The study included 209 patients, and 97% completed planned lymphadenectomy. The primary and secondary endpoints were overall survival and progression-free survival. The research represents the largest retrospective cohort analysis in PSCC to date.

title: New research in finds telemedicine consistently outperforms in-person visits for cancer care when both are available
summary: New research published in the Journal of the National Comprehensive Cancer Network by Moffitt Cancer Center shows that telemedicine consistently outperforms in-person visits for cancer care in terms of access to care and provider response. The study analyzed survey responses from 39,268 patients over more than 50,000 visits, comparing telemedicine and in-person experiences from April 2020 to June 2021. Telemedicine received higher satisfaction ratings for access to care (75.8%) and provider response (90.7%) compared to in-person visits. Senior researcher Philippe E. Spiess, MD, MS, emphasized the benefits of telemedicine, such as increased flexibility and access, and advocated for cross-state licensing and continued reimbursements for telemedicine visits.

title: Moffitt Study Finds Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy Significantly Improves Ou | Moffitt
summary: A study by Moffitt Cancer Center, published in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, reveals that neoadjuvant chemotherapy significantly improves outcomes for patients with locally advanced penile squamous cell carcinoma. This rare cancer has limited treatment options and a poor prognosis in advanced stages. The study involved 209 patients who received neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by consolidative lymphadenectomy. Results showed that over half of the patients responded positively, with responders experiencing a median overall survival of 73 months compared to 17 months for nonresponders. The study also highlighted a median progression-free survival of 26 months and demonstrated that the chemotherapy was well tolerated. Philippe E. Spiess, M.D., assistant chief of Surgical Services and senior member of the Genitourinary Oncology Department at Moffitt, emphasized the importance of a multimodal approach in improving patient outcomes for this challenging disease.

title: New Research in JNCCN Finds Telemedicine Consistently Outperforms In-Person Visits for Cancer Care When Both ...
summary: New research from Moffitt Cancer Center published in JNCCN shows telemedicine consistently outperforms in-person visits for cancer care in terms of access and provider engagement. The study, spanning from April 2020 to June 2021, analyzed 39,268 patient surveys, revealing higher satisfaction rates for telemedicine. Specifically, 75.8% of telemedicine visits were rated highly satisfying for access to care compared to 62.5% for in-person visits. Philippe E. Spiess, MD, MS, a senior researcher and member of the NCCN Board of Directors, emphasized the need for cross-state licensing and continued reimbursements for telemedicine, advocating for its inclusion in routine oncology care.

title: A new study published in NEJM Evidence with University Hospitals Seidman Cancer Center researchers and ArteraAI ...
summary: A new study published in NEJM Evidence, involving University Hospitals Seidman Cancer Center researchers and ArteraAI, validates the first-ever predictive AI biomarker for androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) benefit in prostate cancer. This milestone allows for a personalized approach to treatment, potentially enabling many intermediate-risk patients to avoid the side effects and costs associated with ADT. The study used deep learning and histopathology image data from over 5,000 patients across five Phase 3 trials. Theodoros Teknos, MD, President and Scientific Director of UH Seidman Cancer Center, emphasized the significance of this AI-enabled discovery, highlighting UH-Seidman Cancer Center's leadership in scientific excellence and innovation. This research could change clinical practices and improve outcomes, especially for African American patients, who are disproportionately affected by prostate cancer.

title: Five Star Sensation, foodie fundraiser for UH Seidman Cancer Center, is Aug. 26
summary: Five Star Sensation, a prominent foodie fundraiser for University Hospitals Seidman Cancer Center, will return on August 26 after a hiatus since 2019 due to the pandemic. The event will feature over 30 chefs from across the country and aims to raise $1.5 million to support cancer care innovations. Dr. Theodoros Teknos, president and scientific director of UH Seidman Cancer Center, emphasized the event's importance in raising critical funds for patient care and innovation in cellular therapies. The fundraiser has historically generated over $22 million since its inception in 1987. This year’s honorary chairs include Jane and Lee Seidman and Dr. Teknos, who highlighted the event's goal to support Phase 1 clinical trials and community education to address cancer health disparities. Tickets are available until August 18, with prices ranging from $350 to $75,000.

title: Leadership 100 Concludes 33rd Annual Conference in Naples, Florida - GreekReporter.com
summary: The 33rd Annual Leadership 100 Conference concluded in Naples, Florida, with record attendance and significant events, including the Hierarchical Divine Liturgy officiated by Archbishop Elpidophoros of America. The conference celebrated the 40th Anniversary of the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Fund. Dr. Theodoros Teknos, President and Scientific Director at the UH Seidman Cancer Center, was one of the honorees, receiving the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Award for Excellence. His contributions, along with those of other awardees, were highlighted at the Grand Banquet. The conference featured various speakers and emphasized the importance of youth participation in advancing Orthodoxy and Hellenism.

title: L-100 Conference to Convene in Naples, FL
summary: The 33rd Annual Leadership 100 Conference will be held from February 29 to March 3, 2024, at The Ritz-Carlton in Naples, Florida, celebrating the 40th Anniversary of the Archbishop Iakovos Leadership 100 Fund. The event features an exhibit titled “Leadership 100, 1984 to 2024, 40 Years of Philanthropic Service” at the National Hellenic Museum in Chicago, a commemorative video, and a 40th Anniversary book. Key speakers include General Andrew Poppas, Matina Kolokotronis, Colonel Matthew Bogdanos, Dr. Theodoros Teknos, and Dr. Leonidas Platanias. Dr. Theodoros Teknos, President and Scientific Director at the UH Seidman Cancer Center and Professor at Case Western Reserve University, will contribute his expertise to the conference. The event will also feature various activities such as a Welcome Reception, Young Professionals’ Dialogue, sports tournaments, and a Grand Banquet. Leadership 100 supports the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America and has distributed $75 million in grants since its inception.

title: Five Star Sensation Returns With Cordelia Chef Vinnie Cimino as Host
summary: The Five Star Sensation gala returns to Cuyahoga Community College on August 26, 2023, after its last event in 2019. This benefit event, which began in 1987 with chef Wolfgang Puck, has raised over $22 million for the UH Seidman Cancer Center. Chef Vinnie Cimino from Cordelia restaurant will host this year's event, joined by more than 50 chefs and vintners worldwide. Theodoros Teknos, MD, President, and Scientific Director of UH Seidman Cancer Center, highlighted the event's significance, noting its critical role in raising funds for patient care and innovation in cellular therapies. Under the leadership of co-chairs Ida Haber, Lisa and Kevin Chernikoff, and Margaret Singerman, the goal is to raise $1.5 million to support the Wesley Center for Immunotherapy, Phase 1 clinical trials, and community access to cancer education and resources.

title: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society Welcomes Five Members to Board of Directors
summary: The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) has welcomed five new members to its board of directors as of July 1, 2023, including Leroy M. Ball, Mark J. Barrenechea, Helen E. Heslop, M.D., DSc (Hon), Ari Melnick, M.D., and Yvette Tremonti. This announcement follows the recent appointment of E. Anders Kolb, M.D., as the new president and CEO. The new board members bring unique expertise to help advance LLS's mission to cure blood cancers and improve patient quality of life. Yvette Tremonti, the chief financial and administrative officer of Moffitt Cancer Center, has been recognized for her innovative contributions in human resources and financial operations, significantly enhancing the center's performance and reputation.

title: This small cancer trial led to remission in every single person: 'There were a lot of happy tears'
summary: A small cancer trial at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City led to complete remission in 18 rectal cancer patients using the drug dostarlimab. Dr. Luis A. Diaz Jr., the lead author, noted this as the first instance in cancer history where every patient experienced total remission. Dr. Alan P. Venook, a colorectal cancer specialist at the University of California, San Francisco, highlighted the unprecedented nature of these results, emphasizing that such complete remission in every patient is "unheard of." The trial, sponsored by GlaxoSmithKline, showed no clinically significant complications among participants, suggesting a promising future for this treatment approach.

title: Dr Robert Vonderheide Presents for NCI Division
summary: Dr. Robert Vonderheide, Director of the Abramson Cancer Center, is a leading figure in cancer research, particularly in cancer interception. This approach aims to identify and block cancer at its earliest stages using advancements in genetic and molecular diagnostics, precision medicine, and immuno-oncology. Dr. Vonderheide has extensively studied the mechanisms of malignancy and immunity and has developed novel immunotherapies, such as CD40 agonists, with a focus on pancreatic cancer. He will present on cancer interception for the National Cancer Institute on September 13th, 2023. His work highlights the potential to intervene in cancer progression before it metastasizes, offering a new frontier in cancer treatment. Dr. Vonderheide is also recognized for his contributions to cancer immune surveillance, genetic mouse models, and clinical trials, and serves on multiple prestigious boards, including the NCI Board of Scientific Advisers and the American Association of Cancer Research.

title: National Academy of Medicine elects five new members from Penn | Penn Today
summary: Five experts from the University of Pennsylvania, including Robert H. Vonderheide, have been elected to the National Academy of Medicine (NAM), one of the highest honors in health and medicine. The newly elected members are recognized for their significant contributions to medical sciences, healthcare, and public health. Robert H. Vonderheide, a distinguished scientist and clinician, has made notable advancements in cancer immunotherapy. As the director of the Abramson Cancer Center, he has been instrumental in developing novel cancer treatments, particularly for pancreatic and breast cancer. Vonderheide's work includes the development of agonist CD40 antibodies and the discovery of telomerase as a universal tumor antigen. He is also leading efforts to develop telomerase vaccination for cancer therapy and prevention, and to improve access to clinical trials.

title: A breast cancer vaccine and other UPenn cancer innovations to watch
summary: A cancer vaccine, glowing tumors, and lightning-speed radiation are three significant cancer innovations emerging from UPenn. Robert H. Vonderheide, the director of Penn's Abramson Cancer Center, believes these advancements could be transformative for cancer patients. Vonderheide, an oncologist with a research focus on pancreatic cancer, emphasizes the potential impact of these technologies in improving patient outcomes.

title: AACR Annual Meeting 2023 Overview: Advancing the Frontiers of Cancer Science and Medicine
summary: The AACR Annual Meeting 2023, held from April 14-19, is a pivotal event bringing together thousands of cancer researchers, physician-scientists, policymakers, and advocates to advance cancer research. Robert H. Vonderheide, MD, DPhil, the director of the Penn Medicine Abramson Cancer Center and Program Committee Chair, emphasized the comprehensive nature of the meeting, covering cutting-edge basic, translational, and population science. Vonderheide highlighted significant topics such as KRAS-targeted therapies, early cancer interception, and new anticancer drug developments. He stressed the importance of the AACR's role in uniting the global cancer research community to improve patient outcomes and prevent cancer. The meeting's theme, "Advancing the Frontiers of Cancer Science and Medicine," underscores the ongoing innovation and future-focused approach in cancer research.

title: National Academy of Medicine picks 6 from Penn, CHOP, Jefferson
summary: Five faculty members from the University of Pennsylvania were elected to the National Academy of Medicine, including Kurt T. Barnhart, Christopher B. Forrest, Susan L. Furth, Robert H. Vonderheide, and Desmond Upton Patton. Forrest and Furth are also affiliated with the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). Additionally, the incoming medical school dean at Jefferson was elected. Robert H. Vonderheide's contribution is highlighted by his election to this prestigious body, recognizing his significant impact and achievements in the medical field.

title: Penn Medicine Neurosurgeon Recognized by White House
summary: Nduka M. Amankulor, MD, director of the Penn Brain Tumor Center, has been named a Cancer Moonshot Scholar by the Biden Cancer Moonshot initiative, receiving part of a $5.4 million grant to support his research on novel immune biomarkers for brain tumors. His work focuses on understanding how brain cancers manipulate the immune system and developing ways to make cancer cells detectable by the immune system. Since 2012, Amankulor has been investigating the genetic and immune interactions in brain cancer, particularly targeting epigenetic immune suppression. Robert H. Vonderheide, MD, DPhil, director of the Abramson Cancer Center at Penn Medicine, highlighted the significance of Amankulor’s research, stating it will drive innovations in cancer treatment and improve patient outcomes. Amankulor's recognition and funding underscore the importance of diversity in cancer research and the potential for significant advancements in the field.

title: Eric P. Winer, MD, FASCO
summary: Dr. Eric P. Winer, MD, FASCO, is a prominent figure in oncology, serving as the ASCO President for 2022-2023. He is the Director of Yale Cancer Center and President and Physician-in-Chief of Smilow Cancer Hospital at Yale New Haven. Previously, he spent over two decades at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, where he directed the Breast Oncology Program and held the Thompson Chair in Breast Cancer Research. He also served as Senior Vice President for Medical Affairs at Dana-Farber and was a Professor of Medicine at Harvard Medical School. Dr. Winer has been an active ASCO member, serving on the Board of Directors and chairing several committees. He has received numerous accolades, including the William Silen Lifetime Achievement in Mentoring Award from Harvard Medical School and ASCO’s Gianni Bonadonna Breast Cancer Award.

title: Eric Winer: A Cancer Doctor's Journey | Yale Insights
summary: Dr. Eric Winer, director of the Yale Cancer Center and president of Yale's Smilow Cancer Hospital, shares his journey from studying Russian literature to becoming a leading oncologist. He discusses his personal experiences with hemophilia and HIV, highlighting how these challenges shaped his career and approach to patient care. Winer emphasizes the importance of vulnerability and empathy in medical practice. His contributions include over 350 publications on breast cancer treatment and leadership roles at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute and the American Society of Clinical Oncology. He also addresses current issues in cancer care, such as drug shortages and the need for equitable treatment access.

title: Metastatic Breast Cancer Treatment: What the Future Holds
summary: Eric P. Winer, MD, director of Yale Cancer Center and chair of the Board of the American Society of Clinical Oncology, provided insights into the future of metastatic breast cancer treatment. He highlighted advancements in antibody drug conjugates and targeted therapies, particularly those focusing on the PI3 kinase pathway. Winer emphasized the potential of new CDK inhibitors and the importance of developing therapies that are both effective and better tolerated by patients. He also mentioned the promise of immunotherapy, especially for triple-negative breast cancer, and the possibility of curative treatments for certain patients. Despite progress, Winer acknowledged the ongoing challenges, noting that over 40,000 women still die from breast cancer annually, and stressed the need for continued efforts to improve outcomes.

title: Opinion: Cancer patients should never be put in this situation
summary: Eric P. Winer, Director of the Yale Cancer Center and Physician-in-Chief of Smilow Cancer Hospital, highlights the severe impact of drug shortages on cancer treatment in the US. He emphasizes that these shortages force physicians to make difficult decisions about patient care, which can compromise treatment outcomes. Winer, who has extensive experience in oncology, particularly breast cancer, stresses the need for clinicians and policymakers to collaborate to address and reverse these shortages. He points out that the shortages are particularly detrimental to children with cancer and calls for urgent regulatory and legislative action to ensure a stable drug supply.

title: ASCO 2023: Opening Session
summary: The opening session of ASCO 2023 featured addresses by ASCO President Eric P. Winer, MD, and National Cancer Institute Director Monica M. Bertagnolli, MD. Eric P. Winer emphasized the importance of patient-clinician partnerships in cancer care, drawing from his extensive career and personal experience as a patient with chronic conditions. Winer’s professional journey includes roles at Yale School of Medicine, Duke University, Harvard Medical School, and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. He highlighted the significance of empathy, research, and eliminating stigmatization in oncology. Winer's presidential theme, "Partnering with Patients: the Cornerstone of Clinical Care and Research," underscores the necessity of a collaborative approach to provide optimal cancer care and encourage participation in clinical trials. Winer also praised the resilience of ASCO during the pandemic, noting the high attendance and record-breaking abstract submissions at the meeting.

title: Joint ASCO Sessions With AACR and ESMO to Focus on Cancer Cell Cycle and Cancer and Screening
summary: The 2023 ASCO Annual Meeting will feature joint sessions with AACR and ESMO focusing on cancer cell cycle and screening. The ASCO/AACR session will delve into the cell cycle in cancer, exploring basic biology, clinical science, and CDK inhibitors. The ASCO/ESMO session will address lung and colorectal cancer screening, highlighting disparities and new technologies for precision prevention. Eric P. Winer, MD, FASCO, President of ASCO, emphasized the theme "Partnering With Patients: The Cornerstone of Cancer Care and Research," aiming to enhance patient-clinician experiences. Dr. Winer's efforts include promoting patient engagement in research and clinical care, and he highlighted the increase in submitted abstracts, underscoring the meeting's comprehensive educational agenda.

title: Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion Efforts Start at the Top
summary: Efforts to expand diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) at Yale Cancer Center and Smilow Cancer Hospital focus on diversifying staff, faculty, trainees, and students while addressing healthcare disparities. Eric P. Winer, MD, Director of Yale Cancer Center and Physician-in-Chief of the Smilow Cancer Network, emphasizes the need to combat disparities influenced by sociodemographic factors and unequal access to care. Winer highlights the higher breast cancer mortality rate among Black women in Washington, DC, compared to white women, despite lower incidence rates in Black women. He stresses the importance of addressing these disparities to ensure equitable healthcare outcomes. Other leaders like Faye Rogers, PhD, Paris Butler, MD, MPH, and Alfred Lee, MD, PhD, contribute to DEI efforts by promoting diversity in faculty, staff, and trainees, and creating inclusive environments. These initiatives aim to foster a diverse workforce and ensure that medical advancements benefit all individuals, regardless of their background.

title: Sudip Parikh calls for scientists to build bridges with the public and policymakers
summary: Sudip Parikh, CEO of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), emphasized the importance of scientists building bridges with the public and policymakers during the ninth installment of Johns Hopkins University's Health Policy Forum series. Parikh highlighted the current era as a "Golden Era of Science" and stressed the need for better science communication to dismantle distrust among legislators and the general public. He discussed the polarization around science and the necessity for scientists to engage with community leaders, journalists, and policymakers to restore trust. Parikh also pointed out the challenges faced by graduate students in feeling a sense of belonging in academia and called for inclusive efforts to welcome diverse talents into the scientific community. His conversation with Theodore DeWeese, interim dean of Johns Hopkins Medicine, underscored the critical role of science communication in bridging gaps and addressing contemporary issues in science and research.
